AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SYNOPSIS<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) is developing a new iron ore mine identified as the Tonkolili Iron Ore<br /><br />
mine in Sierra Leone on the west coast of Africa. The Project has three phases of production as<br /><br />
summarised below.<br /><br />
Phase 1 involves mining, beneficiation and export of a surface hematite deposit at a maximum rate of<br /><br />
8 Mtpa. Transport and export of the ore will use a combination of road, rail, stockpiling at the<br /><br />
refurbished port facility at Pepel and transshipment to cargo vessels moored off-shore. Phase 1 is<br /><br />
due to start production in early 2011 and early enabling works are either already underway or close to<br /><br />
starting. The focus of this Environmental, Social and Health Impact Assessment (Stage 1 ESHIA) is<br /><br />
the Phase 1 project.<br /><br />
Phase 2 involves the mining and processing of additional transition material at a rate of approximately<br /><br />
17Mtpa as well as continuation of the phase 1 mining to give a combined production rate of 25Mtpa.<br /><br />
Phase 3 comprises mining a deeper, hard-rock magnetite deposit, processing the magnetite to a<br /><br />
concentrate and export at a design rate of 45Mtpa. This will potentially rise to higher rates of<br /><br />
production depending on the confirmation of subsequent geological resource models. Phase 2 and 3<br /><br />
infrastructure is configured substantially differently from Phase 1 and will transition from light-rail or<br /><br />
road trucking progressively towards dedicated heavy-haul rail transport from the mine to a new deep<br /><br />
water port facility to be located at Tagrin. Phase 2 and 3 are due to commence circa 2014 and are<br /><br />
the subject of a forthcoming ‘Stage 2 ESHIA’ that will follow this document. The Stage 2 ESHIA<br /><br />
therefore primarily evaluates the environmental and social issues that could potentially manifest<br /><br />
during mining phases 2 and 3. The Stage 2 ESHIA will also provide an opportunity to update the<br /><br />
impact assessment with additional findings from an ongoing programme of studies and monitoring.<br /><br />
This ESHIA has been prepared for submission for approval on the understanding that elements of the<br /><br />
infrastructure design and ESHIA study are not yet fully developed. In recognition of this, the<br /><br />
proponent (AML) has committed to undertake completion of the various ESHIA studies, which are<br /><br />
either ongoing or soon to be undertaken and will be reported on in updates to the Environmental<br /><br />
Management Plan (EMP) and as part of the Stage 2 ESHIA. Comprehensive environmental and<br /><br />
social (E&S) management will continue, with the studies inputting to project design, construction and<br /><br />
development. It is recommended that rigorous risk review is applied in the interim ahead of ESHIA<br /><br />
Stage 2 submission in order to identify appropriate Environmental and Social (E&S) management<br /><br />
measures, which will be delivered through the ongoing EMP that will extend into the operational<br /><br />
phase.<br /><br />
This ESHIA includes a review of the legislation framework associated with environmental, social and<br /><br />
health management and assessment. The ESHIA considers the Phase 1 project, the existing physical<br /><br />
conditions i.e. the environmental and human baseline and the likely impacts that may arise, both<br /><br />
positive and negative. Where there are impacts identified that could cause adverse effects, the<br /><br />
ESHIA considers alternatives, mitigating measures and what the likely remaining or residual impact<br /><br />
will be after such intervention. Finally, the ESHIA sets out requirements for ongoing management,<br /><br />
assessment, monitoring and institutional relations.<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A significant volume of physical and social data collection as well as assessment work has been<br /><br />
compiled into this impact assessment to comply with regulatory requirements ensure an adequate<br /><br />
understanding of the project is available for decision making. In some areas, it is recognised that<br /><br />
further work is required, including further project definition in order to be able to define more specific<br /><br />
impacts and mitigation measures and develop effective management strategies. However, the<br /><br />
ESHIA is thought to be sufficiently complete for it to meet its intended decision-making purpose.<br /><br />
Furthermore, an Environmental Management Plan (EMP) has been prepared which provides a<br /><br />
framework for managing the delivery of mitigation measures, further monitoring and continual<br /><br />
improvement in the project’s environmental and social performance. The EMP is a live document that<br /><br />
is part of a management system reporting on updated information as it becomes available, and<br /><br />
allowing feed into ongoing design work.<br /><br />
Where construction management plans can be prepared based on the currently available information,<br /><br />
these have been provided. In other instances, the management plans will need to be formulated<br /><br />
pending further work. All that can be presented at this time is a thematic management plan that<br /><br />
outlines the scope of the management intervention that will likely be necessary.<br /><br />
The EMP in this Stage 1 ESHIA includes a number of thematic plans, describing how mitigation will<br /><br />
be delivered where required and these will be updated with new survey data as it becomes available<br /><br />
and as infrastructure designs progress, enabling decision making to ensure minimisation of potential<br /><br />
adverse effects.<br /><br />
This is particularly important for the terrestrial and marine eco-systems that could be affected by the<br /><br />
project. To date it has been recognised that areas under the direct footprint of the project contain<br /><br />
either recognised high conservation value species or habitat that is of major significance. An<br /><br />
integrated approach involving additional assessment, avoidance wherever possible of critical areas,<br /><br />
mitigation, development of compensatory programmes and community development programmes is<br /><br />
required. Further study work is required and will be included in a Stage 2 ESHIA later in 2010 that<br /><br />
will provide more specific design and definition to these programmes.<br /><br />
It is also important that management plans take into account consequential impacts that will arise,<br /><br />
many of which will be unintended and difficult to control. This includes impacts associated with<br /><br />
speculative influx of migrant workers and accelerated degradation of habitat in areas that was hitherto<br /><br />
relatively inaccessible and sparsely populated. Management plans need to describe a clearer<br /><br />
understanding of how compensation, alternative livelihood schemes, regulation and sustainable<br /><br />
community development can be effectively implemented in order to reduce secondary impacts.<br /><br />
Recommendations are given for ongoing monitoring, auditing and performance evaluation of the<br /><br />
environmental and social elements of the project so that continued improvement, adherence to<br /><br />
agreed standards and effective liaison with SLEPA is maintained.<br /><br />
Monitoring will involve internal and external inspections as well as auditing of performance and<br /><br />
compliance with contract documents. Where a degree of capacity building is required to ensure that<br /><br />
inspection visits and audits by the competent authority (SLEPA) can be achieved then it is understood<br /><br />
and has been recorded (Appendix 1) that AML will make provision for this. In addition, inspection<br /><br />
visits and audits by independent consultants, appointed by AML, will produce monitoring reports that<br /><br />
SLEPA can access and comment on. Currently this has been done by the ESHIA consultants in<br /><br />

<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY<br /><br />
The project has been evaluated using a rigorous impact assessment methodology comprising the<br /><br />
following:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A review of compliance with the Sierra Leone legislation framework;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A description of the project and review of alternatives;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Determination of the project physical and social baseline conditions at a regional and sitespecific level;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Derivation of a standardised methodology based on evaluating valued receptors and impact<br /><br />
index derived from assessing extent, duration and magnitude;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assessment of the likely impacts that may arise, both positive and negative. Where impacts<br /><br />
are identified that could cause adverse effects, the ESHIA considers alternatives, mitigating<br /><br />
measures and what the likely remaining or residual impact will be after such intervention;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The environment and social impact assessment has been applied systematically to four areas<br /><br />
of the project: the mine, the transport corridor, the port and the off-shore and coastal zone.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The following principal issues have been determined:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Air & Noise<br /><br />
Air quality impacts comprising both dust and exhaust emissions arising from land clearance, mining,<br /><br />
stock-piles, vehicles and machinery have been identified as primary emission sources. The<br /><br />
implementation of standard mitigation measures involving adequate containment of loads during<br /><br />
haulage, dust suppression by water spraying, extractive covers at key point sources and machinery<br /><br />
selection should result in no major impacts.<br /><br />
The proximity of the proposed transport route in relation to villages and residential areas remains a<br /><br />
key issue. Whilst a principle of avoidance of resettlement wherever possible has been upheld, the<br /><br />
combination of public safety and dust and noise nuisance issues means that in some instances, even<br /><br />
though mitigation measures may be partially effective, it has been considered more appropriate and<br /><br />
responsible to pursue a resettlement solution. The maintenance of a buffer zone should be sufficient<br /><br />
for most residential areas, but in exceptional cases where a suitable buffer cannot be maintained and<br /><br />
resettlement is not feasible, additional mitigation measures (e.g. noise barriers or noise isolation) at<br /><br />
sensitive receptors will minimize the impacts. A buffer zone of 500m has generally been accepted for<br /><br />
the project, if communities lie within this zone then a review of either resettlement or mitigation is<br /><br />
required.<br /><br />
Noise sources vary, but blasting, crushing and transport noise, including aircraft, are considered to be<br /><br />
potentially the most significant. Assuming that occupational noise limits are maintained within<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-6-10\tonkolili<br /><br />
phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
Page 1<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
facilities then it is predicted that appropriate environmental noise standards will be met at a distance<br /><br />
of 500m from the facilities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ecology & Biodiversity<br /><br />
Ecological impacts across the project have been evaluated and found to be significant primarily due to<br /><br />
the high level of biodiversity and conservation value of certain plant species. This is the case at a<br /><br />
variety of discreet habitat settings including forest and grass-lands located at the mine-site, along<br /><br />
riverine forests, inland valley swamp locations and in mangrove forest in the coastal areas.<br /><br />
Principal direct impacts will arise from the clearance of land within the footprint of the project and its<br /><br />
associated infrastructure. Vegetation that is not cleared or buried may be indirectly impacted by<br /><br />
alteration, spread of invasive species and pressure from the influx of people that will increase the<br /><br />
pressure on resources.<br /><br />
At Pepel Port, the potential release of acidity and metals from disturbed acid sulphate soils (if present)<br /><br />
could cause localised impacts to vegetation.<br /><br />
At the mine and along the transport corridor, disturbance of fauna, particularly large mammals such<br /><br />
as chimpanzees may further reduce natural colonisation by indigenous plant species where fauna<br /><br />
play a role in seed dispersal.<br /><br />
The impacts of habitat loss and fragmentation will affect terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems.<br /><br />
Avoidance of areas of ecological value is the primary tool that is applied to minimise impacts.<br /><br />
However, the impact of land clearance and burial in the primary mining and rock dump areas can<br /><br />
neither be avoided, nor mitigated because of the immovable location of the ore bodies and<br /><br />
practicalities governing design of the mine and waste rock areas. The project proponent (AML)<br /><br />
should therefore undertake a commitment to seed collection, replanting, habitat renewal and<br /><br />
protection at alternative selected conservation site(s). This offset or equivalence approach will not<br /><br />
alter the primary ecological loss and cannot realistically overcome the direct impact resulting from<br /><br />
clearance of forest and vegetation. However, in combination with avoidance of sensitive areas<br /><br />
outside of the mine footprint wherever possible, an off-set conservation programme can contribute to<br /><br />
lowering the overall residual impact to a moderate level.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hydrology and Hydrogeology<br /><br />
The project will result in an increase in suspended sediments in rivers, alteration of river channels and<br /><br />
changes in catchment behaviour. Without mitigation this could lead to flooding as well as a variety of<br /><br />
water quality impacts. Changes of chemistry could occur with the water considered to have low<br /><br />
chemical buffering capacity. At the mine and transport corridor the potable and construction water<br /><br />
demand may lead to over-abstraction of local surface and groundwater sources leading to impacts on<br /><br />
downstream flows affecting both communities and dependent eco-systems.<br /><br />
At Pepel Port, groundwater is considered both a sensitive and vulnerable resource. Construction and<br /><br />
operational groundwater abstraction could lead to lowering of water levels in local wells and saline<br /><br />
<br /><br />

intrusion, while brownfield regeneration and the industrial port operations could lead to contamination<br /><br />
of a system that is important for sustaining potable water supplies as well as providing baseflow<br /><br />
discharging into the inter-tidal zone.<br /><br />
Residual, post mitigation impacts from the project will include some permanent loss of flow from<br /><br />
springs and streams as well as alteration of stream and river channels and local water levels.<br /><br />
However, more significant changes in local hydrology and hydrogeology are expected in Phase 3<br /><br />
which will require a significantly higher water demand.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Soils & Land Use<br /><br />
Soil impacts will arise during construction and operational phases as a consequence of land<br /><br />
clearance or sterilisation / burial, increased erosion or inundation due to the modification of drainage<br /><br />
patterns, compaction from vibration and loading under temporary stockpiles/structures. Chemical<br /><br />
contamination could occur from release of hydrocarbons and other chemicals including diesel and<br /><br />
lubricant oils and explosives residues. Some soil resource can be rehabilitated if progressive<br /><br />
reclamation techniques are applied. These impacts may constrain or modify existing land-uses in the<br /><br />
mine area. The residual (post-mitigation) impacts of land clearance and sterilisation / burial on soil<br /><br />
resources and land-use are likely to remain significant and extremely long-term or permanent in the<br /><br />
mine area. Other residual impacts should be minor if appropriate preventative and mitigation<br /><br />
measures are put in place.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Socio-Economic<br /><br />
Socio-economic effects are strongly dependent on project phase. During construction some villages<br /><br />
may require resettlement. Villages on the periphery of the project area will suffer loss of land resulting<br /><br />
in potential temporary disruption of land used for shelter, access to agriculture and natural resources.<br /><br />
However a compensation principle is being applied throughout the project to ensure affected people<br /><br />
are not disadvantaged or made worse off by the project. Some employment opportunities will be<br /><br />
created with associated economic benefits to the wider community.<br /><br />
During operations, however, there is again a mix of both economic benefit and social disturbance.<br /><br />
Benefits (lasting about 8 years) will mainly be in the form of wages, disbursement for the procurement<br /><br />
of supplies, social investments and payment of revenue to the government. Potential negative<br /><br />
impacts will mainly be due to disturbance to land owners and influx of workers and job seekers<br /><br />
bringing pressure on social infrastructure and natural resources and possible increases in social ills.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures are dependent on establishing transparent and effective social management<br /><br />
processes including harm minimisation, compensation and long-term community development<br /><br />
mechanisms. The following mitigation measures are expected to reduce the intensity of the residual<br /><br />
impacts from major to moderate/minor.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a Resettlement Action Plan (RAP).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a livelihood restoration plan.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Human Health<br /><br />
The major impacts identified in the preliminary health impact assessment were primarily associated<br /><br />
with community resettlement; impacts associated with worker in-migration (disease, food security,<br /><br />
substance abuse, home violence); increased burden of disease such as cholera and malaria due to<br /><br />
project activities and water storage facilities (drinking water tanks, waste and raw water storage<br /><br />
ponds); and degradation of surface and groundwater (sedimentation/erosion, contamination, changes<br /><br />
in drainage patterns). Moderate impacts were associated with increased road traffic, project noise and<br /><br />
reduction of locally produced food.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures have been proposed for those impacts with major or moderate significance<br /><br />
which, if implemented, are predicated to result in moderate, minor, or insignificant residual impacts.<br /><br />
Since human health is dependant on many factors such as good air, soil, water and food quality, and<br /><br />
stable socio-economic status, the assessment of potential impact on human health associated with<br /><br />
the Phase 1 project has been integrated with results of many of the other ESHIA disciplines (e.g., air,<br /><br />
noise, hydrology, hydrogeology, flora, fauna, soil, water quality, and social-economic assessment).<br /><br />
Implementation of mitigation measures recommended by these disciplines would therefore reduce the<br /><br />
potential for adverse human health impacts (HIA) and will be considered in the final HIA.<br /><br />
Positive impacts identified include access to improved healthcare facilities (for general public), health<br /><br />
benefits through local employment, improved access to the region and positive aspects of<br /><br />
resettlement.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Offshore & Coastal Impact Assessment<br /><br />
The baseline preliminary survey indicates that the coastal and marine habitat around Pepel Port is<br /><br />
healthy and contains a high level of biodiversity. There are a number of potential impacts that could<br /><br />
arise from reduction and clearance of habitat areas. However, the majority of the port infrastructure is<br /><br />
already in place, and most of what is required will be refurbished rather than constructed from new.<br /><br />
As a result there should be no significant increase in the existing port footprint, and therefore no<br /><br />
significant area of coastal habitat cleared. The currently proposed development footprint for Pepel<br /><br />
Port will result in reasonably minor losses of mangroves.<br /><br />
There is currently no evidence of any existing impact on the surrounding mangroves due to the<br /><br />
presence of residual hematite ore from the previous operations at Pepel, although there are elevated<br /><br />
levels of heavy metals in the near-shore soil samples.<br /><br />
The construction will increase ambient noise and light levels, and potentially result in disturbance of<br /><br />
sensitive coastal fauna such as birds. Due to the high density of wetland birds present in the project<br /><br />

Therefore a number of mitigation measures are proposed to minimise impact or better still avoid<br /><br />

The construction and refurbishment of marine structures could result in elevated turbidity within the<br /><br />
immediate vicinity of the port. However, given the natural conditions of the estuary particularly during<br /><br />
wet season conditions it is considered that the habitat is likely to be resilient to increased turbidity<br /><br />
levels over the relatively short duration of the construction programme at Pepel Port.<br /><br />
Construction/refurbishment activity also has the potential to disturb marine sediment. Further<br /><br />
characterisation of nearshore and intertidal marine sediments is recommended prior to construction.<br /><br />
Underwater construction activities, in particular pile driving, can generate high levels of underwater<br /><br />
noise. Marine mammal and the impact of underwater noise and ship collisions remain as a moderate<br /><br />
impact due to lack of information at this stage but surveys are underway.<br /><br />
The majority of marine traffic in the estuary is focussed around Freetown. Trans-shipment operations<br /><br />
are currently expected to involve Handymax trans-shipment vessels, which will transfer ore to a<br /><br />
loading on anchorage point outside the mouth of the estuary. The impact of the trans-shipment<br /><br />
operations on shipping in the estuary is not expected to be significant.<br /><br />

Loading of the transshipment vessels at Pepel and offloading at the anchorage during transshipment<br /><br />
will lead to some inevitable overboard spillage of iron ore. Although it is assumed that the system will<br /><br />
be designed to be highly efficient, even minor spillage will create a cumulative impact over the life of<br /><br />
the project. The potential behaviour of the iron ore in the water should be evaluated by a laboratory<br /><br />
assessment of the proposed iron ore product and its constituents.<br /><br />
Capital dredging will be required to open the navigation channel to access Pepel port with subsequent<br /><br />
ongoing maintenance dredging required to keep the channel open. Dredging is designated as a<br /><br />
moderate impact in this report on the basis of what is currently known about dredge location and<br /><br />
ecology of the spoil disposal locations. More detailed assessment will be undertaken when details of<br /><br />
a work programme and contractor have been clarified. A dredging plan is included in the EMP and<br /><br />
will be modified on the basis of the outcome of a more detailed dredging impact assessment once the<br /><br />
requisite data is available.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Distributed Impacts<br /><br />
Provision of bulk materials such as earth and fill for ground conditioning will be controlled through<br /><br />
activity-specific management plans and protocols and contractors will be accountable for adherence<br /><br />
to the plans and protocols.<br /><br />
The project’s dependency on existing infrastructure will be limited. There will be initial reliance on<br /><br />
imported goods and contractor services for food, accommodation and camps with opportunities for<br /><br />
goods and services to create livelihood benefits for project communities. Adherence to prior and clear<br /><br />
project announcements is expected.<br /><br />
An impact is likely to arise from interim storage of wastes in particular pest, odour and litter control.<br /><br />
The AML will need ensure that its contractor’s implement a hierarchy of waste elimination at source,<br /><br />
recycling, reuse, recovery, and as a last resort – disposal. In addition provision for destroying or<br /><br />
treating hazardous waste is required to render it non-hazardous if possible, with provision for safe<br /><br />
storage where-ever and for as long as treatment/destruction is not an option..<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Commitments, Management and Performance<br /><br />
This ESHIA has been prepared for submission for approval on the understanding that elements of the<br /><br />
infrastructure design and ESHIA study are not yet fully developed. In recognition of this, AML has<br /><br />
committed to undertake completion of the various ESHIA studies, which are either ongoing or soon to<br /><br />
be undertaken and will be reported on in updates to the Environmental Management Plan (EMP) and<br /><br />
as part of the Stage 2 ESHIA. Comprehensive environmental and social (E&S) management will<br /><br />
continue, with the studies inputting to project design, construction and development. It is<br /><br />
recommended that rigorous risk review is applied in the interim ahead of final ESHIA Stage 2<br /><br />
submission in order to identify appropriate Environmental and Social (E&S) management measures,<br /><br />
which will be delivered through the ongoing EMP that will extend into the operational phase.<br /><br />
A significant volume of assessment work has been achieved and the impact assessment has been<br /><br />
completed to a sufficient level for regulatory decision making. It is recognised that further work is<br /><br />
required, including further project definition in order to be able to identify more specific impacts and<br /><br />
mitigation measures and develop effective management strategies.<br /><br />
Where generic construction management plans could be generated based on the currently available<br /><br />
information then these are have been provided. In other instances, the management plans will need<br /><br />
to be formulated pending further project description and or study work and all that is presented now is<br /><br />
an outline of the management plan purpose.<br /><br />
This is particularly important for the terrestrial and marine eco-systems that could be affected by the<br /><br />
project. To date it has been recognised that areas under the direct footprint of the project contain<br /><br />
either recognised high conservation value species or habitat that is of major significance. An<br /><br />
integrated approach involving additional assessment, avoidance wherever possible of critical areas,<br /><br />
mitigation, development of compensatory programmes and community development programmes is<br /><br />
required. Further study work is required and will be included in a Stage 2 ESHIA later in 2010 that<br /><br />
will provide more specific design and definition to these programmes.<br /><br />
It is also important that management plans take into account consequential impacts that will be<br /><br />
created many of which will be unintended and difficult to control. This includes the impact associated<br /><br />
with speculative influx of migrant workers and accelerated degradation of habitat in areas that was<br /><br />
hitherto relatively inaccessible and sparsely populated. Management plans need to develop a clearer<br /><br />
understanding of how compensation, alternative livelihood schemes, regulation and sustainable<br /><br />
community development can be effectively implemented to reduce secondary impacts.<br /><br />
Recommendations are given for ongoing monitoring, auditing and performance evaluation of the<br /><br />
environmental and social elements of the project so that continued improvement, adherence to<br /><br />
agreed standards and effective liaison with SLEPA is maintained.<br /><br />
Monitoring will involve both internal and external inspections and auditing of performance and<br /><br />
compliance to contract documents. Where a degree of capacity building is required to ensure that<br /><br />
inspection visits and audits by the competent authority (SLEPA) can be achieved then it is understood<br /><br />
and has been recorded (Appendix 1) that AML will provide provision for this. In addition inspection<br /><br />
visits and audits by independent consultants, appointed by AML, will produce monitoring reports that<br /><br />
SLEPA can access and comment on. Currently this has been done by the ESHIA consultants and<br /><br />
<br /><br />

1<br /><br />
1.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
INTRODUCTION<br /><br />
Background<br /><br />
<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) has identified an extensive magnetic anomaly in the Sula Mountain<br /><br />
range in Sierra Leone and has confirmed the presence of a world-class iron ore deposit. The Tonkolili<br /><br />
Project comprises the construction of a mine, ore processing and pit-to-port infrastructure to transport<br /><br />
materials and product in the form of iron-ore concentrate.<br /><br />
The Project has three phases of production. Phase 1 involves mining, beneficiation and export of a<br /><br />
surface hematite deposit at a maximum rate of 8 Mtpa. Transport and export will occur using a<br /><br />
combination of road, rail and stockpiling at the refurbished port facility at Pepel and transshipment to<br /><br />
waiting off-shore cargo ships. Phase 1 is due to start production in early 2011 and early enabling<br /><br />
works are either already underway or close to starting. This Environmental, Social and Health Impact<br /><br />
Assessment (ESHIA) focuses on the Phase 1 project.<br /><br />
Phase 2 involves the mining and processing of transition material at a rate of approximately 17 –<br /><br />
25Mtpa. Phase 3 comprises mining a deeper, hard-rock magnetite deposit, processing the magnetite<br /><br />
to a concentrate and export at a design rate of 45Mtpa. This will potentially rise to higher rates of<br /><br />
production depending on the confirmation of subsequent geological resource models. Phase 2 and 3<br /><br />
infrastructure is configured substantially differently from Phase 1 and will transition from light-rail or<br /><br />
road trucking progressively towards dedicated heavy-haul rail transport from the mine to a new deep<br /><br />
water port facility to be located at Tagrin. Phase 2 and 3 are due to commence 2014 and will be the<br /><br />
subject of a ‘Stage 2 ESHIA’ in 2010 that will evaluate the Phase 2 and 3 specific impacts and also<br /><br />
report on additional study work for the Stage 1 ESHIA project that has been developed during the<br /><br />
intervening period.<br /><br />
This ESHIA includes a review of the legislation framework associated with environmental, social and<br /><br />
health management and assessment. The ESHIA considers the Phase 1 project, the existing physical<br /><br />
conditions; that is, the environmental and human baseline and the likely impacts that may arise, both<br /><br />
positive and negative. Where there are impacts identified that could cause adverse effects, the ESHIA<br /><br />
considers alternatives, mitigating measures and what the likely remaining or residual impact will be<br /><br />
after such intervention. Finally, the ESHIA sets out requirements for ongoing management,<br /><br />
assessment, monitoring and institutional relations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Purpose<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The ESHIA report for Phase 1 of the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project has been prepared on behalf of AML to<br /><br />
present to the Sierra Leone Environment Protection Agency (SLEPA) for the following purpose:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
To provide an understanding of the potential environmental, social and health impacts<br /><br />
associated with the Phase 1 project activities;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
To outline the environmental, social and health commitments required for the project and the<br /><br />
associated management and mitigation plans identified to address these issues;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
To provide a data baseline for comparison of change.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The report provides an assessment that starts with identification of relevant legislation and<br /><br />
institutional bodies and a summary of the project including the primary project components as well as<br /><br />
the supporting infrastructure and widely distributed effects that could reasonably be assumed to<br /><br />
occur.<br /><br />

TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Much of the report is concerned with obtaining a representative characterisation of the existing<br /><br />
baseline conditions at the project area. This section has been reported as a high level summary and<br /><br />
makes reference to a number of supporting studies that have been completed and included as<br /><br />
Appendices. Following the baseline description the ESHIA presents an overview of the potential<br /><br />
impacts and associated mitigation measures. The impact assessment has used a standardised, semiquantitative methodology based on identifying and ranking valued receptors. The basis for this<br /><br />
methodology is explained.<br /><br />
Within the impact assessment section, there is also analysis of what is the remaining level of impact<br /><br />
after mitigation measures have been implemented. The ESHIA then discusses the need for ongoing<br /><br />
further study programmes where clearly needed as well as future management practices that AML will<br /><br />
have to undertake following the completion of the assessment process.<br /><br />
Some of these management practices are strategic in the sense that they are either not entirely<br /><br />
understood at the moment or may be conditional upon factors that are outside of the control of AML.<br /><br />
So that there is an appropriate level of accountability over future performance and commitments, the<br /><br />
ESHIA describes requirements for future performance monitoring and auditing as part of the<br /><br />
proponent’s Environmental & Social Management System.<br /><br />
The report builds on a series of deliverables that have already been prepared as part of an official<br /><br />
regulatory process in liaison with SLEPA shown in Table 1-1 below. Copies of the transcripts for these<br /><br />
official documents are provided in Appendix 1:<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Glossary<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Definitions<br /><br />
Phase 1 of the Project – is Phase 1 of the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project and represents the mining of<br /><br />
hematite ore found as a shallow capping deposit overlying the main Tonkolili deposits. This is planned<br /><br />
for the initial stages of the project and entails exporting the product via Pepel Port.<br /><br />
Phase 2 of the Project – is Phase 2 of the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project and consist of mining and<br /><br />
processing of transitional material.<br /><br />
Phase 3 of the Project – is Phase 3 of the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project and consist of the open pit mining<br /><br />
operation and transportation of concentrate by rail to a newly developed port at Tagrin Point from<br /><br />
which it is exported to global markets.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
2<br /><br />
2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
ESHIA PROCESS<br /><br />
Relationship between Phase 1, Phase 2 and Phase 3 of the<br /><br />
Tonkolili Iron Ore Project<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Although many aspects of Phase 1, Phase 2 and Phase 3 of the Tonkolili project are separate, the<br /><br />
relationship between these phases is on the whole transitional and may involve at different times<br /><br />
some or all of phases running concurrently.<br /><br />
Phase 1 mining operations will result in a product comprising Direct Shipped Ore (DSO) lump and<br /><br />
fines which will be mined from a surface (duri-crust) deposit. This phase represents an early, smallerscale operation that is reliant on a combination of brownfield refurbishment and mining of the<br /><br />
relatively easily accessible surface hematite deposits at Tonkolili. Because of these factors, the<br /><br />
construction stage of Phase 1 is expected to commence in 2010 and be completed within<br /><br />
approximately 6 months enabling a relatively rapid commencement of mining and export.<br /><br />
Phase 2 mining operations will be a combination of continuing the hematite duri-crust mining plus<br /><br />
extraction of hematite from a deeper saprolite layer. This will require some grinding and separation<br /><br />
probably creating a tailings waste stream. The development scenario is based on providing mine and<br /><br />
process plant facilities supported by a narrow gauge rail network to transfer the product to out-loading<br /><br />
facilities at Pepel and Tagrin Point. It is expected that Phase 2 will deliver 17 Mpta over and above<br /><br />
the 8 Mtpa expected from Phase 1.<br /><br />
Phase 3 represents a significantly larger project reliant on mining a deeper magnetite deposit and<br /><br />
more mineral processing, haulage and out-loading infrastructure development. Export of magnetite<br /><br />
concentrate is planned to commence after 2014. Phase 3 necessitates a longer construction time<br /><br />
than for Phase 1 and 2 and consequently there are elements of the early ‘enabling’ works of Phase 3<br /><br />
that are planned to commence at an earlier date. Therefore Phase 3 construction could occur whilst<br /><br />
the earlier phase are in construction and operation.<br /><br />
The Phase 1 project may create significant positive legacy factors in the form of the refurbished<br /><br />
former ‘Delco’ rail line and Pepel Port area when Phase 1 transitions into Phase 2. It is understood<br /><br />
that this has been considered in the projects lease arrangements with Government of Sierra Leone<br /><br />
(GoSL) and that the legacy potential for these assets may enable other mining operations to develop<br /><br />
in Sierra Leone. AML has also agreed to manage the port and railway, making those facilities<br /><br />
available to other users, including other mining companies and general freight and passenger<br /><br />
transport companies, at commercial rates.<br /><br />
It is intended that this infrastructure will in due course provide a facility servicing the West African subregion, enabling both Sierra Leone and neighbouring countries to export their goods to international<br /><br />
markets. The rail and port infrastructure will provide access for people in the region to a reliable and<br /><br />
efficient mode of transport; it will encourage the development of other businesses in the area whilst<br /><br />
promoting decentralisation from a densely populated Freetown. AML therefore anticipates that the<br /><br />
project will bring positive benefits to the local and national economies as well as improving the<br /><br />
standard of living for the people of Sierra Leone.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
2.2<br /><br />
2.2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
ESHIA Steps<br /><br />
Screening<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The purpose of screening is to determine whether an EIA (or ESHIA) study is required. Therefore the<br /><br />
screening process involves a preliminary determination of the expected impact of a project on the<br /><br />
environment and of its relative significance.<br /><br />
Screening processes for the Tonkolili project have included development of an Environmental<br /><br />
Aspects Register and submission of a Screening Form with outline project information to SLEPA.<br /><br />
Environmental Aspects Register<br /><br />
As part of the screening process an Environmental Aspects Register was developed to gain a<br /><br />
preliminary understanding of the project activities and possible consequences in relation to<br /><br />
environmental and social aspects. The risk pathways were analysed to identify potential biophysical,<br /><br />
social and health impacts. This preliminary screening of environmental and social risks provided a<br /><br />
basis for further investigation ensuring that all the major risk pathways had been considered (See<br /><br />
Appendix 2 for the Environmental Aspects Register.)<br /><br />
Submission of Screening Form<br /><br />
The Screening Form for the project was submitted to the EPA in March 2010. The Screening Form<br /><br />
submission triggered screening of the project by SLEPA, albeit it had already been recognised at the<br /><br />
pre-Screening stage in November 2009 that the project was Category A. Screening also triggered the<br /><br />
Scoping process to obtain agreement on the terms of reference for the ESHIA study.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.2.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Scoping<br /><br />
<br /><br />
On the basis that the project constitutes a Category A project, the next step in the ESHIA process was<br /><br />
agreement on the project approach, appropriate project boundary limits; the information necessary for<br /><br />
decision-making; and the significant effects and factors to be studied in detail. The scoping stage<br /><br />
clarifies the requirements of GoSL through agreed Terms of Reference for the preparation of an<br /><br />
ESHIA.<br /><br />
Accordingly a Scoping Procedure document was submitted to SLEPA in March 2010 that contained<br /><br />
information on the approach to the ESHIA, including scopes of work for the various specialist studies,<br /><br />
examples of rapid assessment surveys and information on the location and preliminary design of key<br /><br />
project facilities.<br /><br />
A Regulatory ‘Road Map’ was also produced to establish a programme of ESHIA deliverables in line<br /><br />
with implementation of the early components of the project.<br /><br />
See Appendix 1 for the Regulatory Road Map and Scoping Documents for the Tonkolili project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Further Scoping was completed in May 2010 when there was formal presentation with stakeholders to<br /><br />

included comments and feedback from interested stakeholders. A transcript of the presentation and<br /><br />
issues raised is included in Appendix 1.<br /><br />
A separate Scoping report was produced in April 2010 for the haul road component of the Phase 1<br /><br />
project as requested by the SLEPA. This report outlined specific environmental and social issues<br /><br />
related to the haul road and was produced at an early stage to reflect the early construction timeline<br /><br />
for this component of the project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.2.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Impact Assessment<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The following components have been included in this impact assessment.<br /><br />
Project Description & Baseline<br /><br />
A full project description is required to gain an understanding of the project elements and activities.<br /><br />
The project description presented in this ESHIA is complete to the best of our ability with the known<br /><br />
information about the project.<br /><br />
The baseline description provides an assessment of the existing environment including social, health<br /><br />
as well as physical aspects within the project area and in the surrounding region.<br /><br />
Impact Assessment<br /><br />
This assessment includes the projects likely effects on the existing environment including social,<br /><br />
health as well as physical aspects. Specific review have been completed to assess potential impacts<br /><br />
to air quality, noise, ecology and biodiversity, hydrology and hydrogeology, soils and land use,<br /><br />
geology and geomorphology, socio-economic effects, cultural heritage and human health. Impacts are<br /><br />
assessed by magnitude, extent and duration and their relationship to sensitive or ‘valued receptors’.<br /><br />
Review of Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
Mitigation measures aim to prevent adverse impacts from happening and to control the impacts that<br /><br />
do occur within an acceptable level. Opportunities for impact mitigation will occur throughout the<br /><br />
project cycle. The objectives of mitigation are to enhance the environmental and social benefits of the<br /><br />
project; avoid, minimise or remedy adverse impacts; and ensure that any residual adverse impacts<br /><br />
are kept within acceptable levels. The mitigation measures are discussed in the impacts section so<br /><br />
that the clearest analysis of what are considered to be remaining or residual impacts can be obtained.<br /><br />
Management Strategies<br /><br />
Management plans and strategies will translate recommended mitigation and monitoring measures<br /><br />
into specific actions that will be carried out by AML. Management plans will then form the basis for<br /><br />
impact management during project construction and operation.<br /><br />
Commitments Register<br /><br />
The Commitments Register presents the issues that require further management after completion of<br /><br />
the assessment. These issues may be residual impacts identified in the ESHIA impact assessment<br /><br />

<br /><br />

STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
process. The register includes a description of the issue, action required to address the issue, person<br /><br />
responsible and date that action is required by.<br /><br />
Auditing, Monitoring & Continual Performance Improvement<br /><br />
The auditing and monitoring step provides information that will assist in impact management and to<br /><br />
improve understanding of cause-effect relationships and mitigation methods. Auditing is necessary to<br /><br />
certify that practice is in accordance with established procedures and to identify how processes or<br /><br />
systems can be improved. Continual improvement is central to auditing, monitoring and performance<br /><br />
assessment.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Terms of Reference for ESHIA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.3<br /><br />
2.3.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Terms of Reference<br /><br />
<br /><br />
One of the principle functions of the scoping stage is to guide the development of appropriate terms of<br /><br />
reference for the ESHIA. This has been developed using a combination of consultation and<br /><br />
procedural techniques.<br /><br />
The stakeholder engagement process is broadly outlined in Section 2.4 below. Consultation<br /><br />
undertaken during project Scoping has enabled the development of ESHIA Terms of Reference by<br /><br />
engagement with stakeholders and determination of their different interests. This has taken place at<br /><br />
many different levels in the project as follows:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
‘Phase 2b‘ survey work has involved community consultation to help define and target<br /><br />
specialist scientific survey work (for example botanical studies near the mine site). Local<br /><br />
names, use of natural resources, distribution and trends in abundance or decline have been<br /><br />
developed from this level of focus-group consultation;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Discussions at a community level through the Early Works Consultation Committee (EWCC)<br /><br />
forum about community level concerns and expectations. This has been recorded and used<br /><br />
to define specific issues such as proximity of project facilities. District level consultation with<br /><br />
affected communities near the mine site has been taking place since September 2009, with<br /><br />
monthly EWCC forums running from February 2010 across the entire project area;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Consultation with high level stakeholders (Ministers and GoSL Department Heads) through<br /><br />
2009 and into 2010 has helped align the study work according to local legislation and cultural<br /><br />
norms. This level of consultation has also helped clarify the expectations associated with the<br /><br />
level and protocol for community consultations. Ministerial consultations have helped focus<br /><br />
studies towards areas of concern, for example ministerial consultations have indicated<br /><br />
specific conservation requirements, data gaps and areas of legislation reform<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SLEPA procedural guidelines associated with conducting an ESHIA for mining and on-site mineral<br /><br />
processing have also been used in preparing the ESHIA Terms of Reference. The following sections<br /><br />
have been developed (procedural guidelines are presented in Appendix 1):<br /><br />

This ESHIA has been prepared for submission for approval on the understanding that elements of the<br /><br />
infrastructure design and ESHIA study are not yet fully developed. In recognition of this, the<br /><br />
proponent (AML) has committed to undertake completion of the various ESHIA studies, which are<br /><br />
either ongoing or soon to be undertaken and will be reported on in updates to the Environmental<br /><br />
Management Plan (EMP) and as part of the Stage 2 ESHIA. Comprehensive environmental and<br /><br />
social (E&S) management will continue, with the studies inputting to project design, construction and<br /><br />
development. It is recommended that rigorous risk review is applied in the interim ahead of final<br /><br />
ESHIA Stage 2 submission in order to identify appropriate Environmental and Social (E&S)<br /><br />
management measures, which will be delivered through the ongoing EMP that will extend into the<br /><br />
operational phase.<br /><br />

4. The scope of the survey work undertaken comprises terrestrial ecology (fauna, flora, avifauna and aquatic); marine ecology and sampling of water and sediment, air and noise<br /><br />
studies, surface and groundwater sampling, weather measurements, flow measurements and<br /><br />
well inventories, soil logging and physicochemical sampling, socio-economic baseline studies<br /><br />
incorporating specialist focus group including women’s groups and youth organizations and<br /><br />
an initial health appraisal across a small randomized population sample along with a district<br /><br />
level health review;<br /><br />
5. Repeat study work in order to evaluate seasonality;<br /><br />
6. The scope of the assessment work undertaken comprises biological species sample<br /><br />
collection and categorization, water, soil, sediment and tissue laboratory assessment and<br /><br />
evaluation against guideline values, numerical modelling and screening to determine air<br /><br />
quality, climate, marine and groundwater behaviour, processing of socio-economic<br /><br />
questionnaires and review of pollution sources and control measures and waste management<br /><br />
capacity;<br /><br />
7. The impact assessment has used standardized impact magnitude and valued receptors<br /><br />
techniques. Extent, duration and likelihood values have been standardized against<br /><br />
WorleyParsons risk management terms;<br /><br />
8. Identification of further work programs have been evaluated, critiqued and scoped based on<br /><br />
gap analysis by relevant specialists in the respective fields;<br /><br />
9. Identification of mitigation techniques, future management practices and ongoing monitoring<br /><br />
and performance auditing has been developed in conjunction with AML’s environmental<br /><br />
management office and represents a commitment from the proponent linked as a<br /><br />
conditionality to the ESHIA licensing process.<br /><br />

2.3.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Exclusions<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Stage 1 ESHIA work has utilised over 12 months worth of survey and study work as described in<br /><br />
the scope above. Notwithstanding the large body of work already collected there are recognized to be<br /><br />
a limited number of areas that are still not well understood. Coverage of these areas in the ESHIA has<br /><br />
been achieved by taking a strategic view on likely impact and behaviour extrapolated from what is<br /><br />
currently known. The following exclusions apply to this work:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SLEPA has not provided direct comment with respect to the Terms of Reference or scope of<br /><br />
this Phase 1 study. Guidance on the coverage and content of this report has been taken from<br /><br />
comments returned by SLEPA relating to the ESHIA interim reports prepared for the Haul<br /><br />
Road;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
There is no single feasibility study report that covers the entire Phase 1 project. Details on<br /><br />
project description, layout and alternatives has been derived from information obtained either<br /><br />
directly from AML or their nominated contractors;<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
The Stakeholder Engagement Process<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Consultation and disclosure about this project to the public, affected people and a wide range of other<br /><br />
stakeholders has been achieved through a stakeholder engagement process. This is still underway<br /><br />
and it can be said there will be maintenance of a forum through community committees and official<br /><br />
liaison throughout the life of project. Implementation of the stakeholder engagement process based<br /><br />
on detailed analysis and a structured approach to public consultation and disclosure in all project<br /><br />
phases is provided in more detail in Chapter 10.<br /><br />
In summary, this process is structured as follows:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Stakeholder analysis will be presented, outlining the different stakeholders involved in the<br /><br />
Project and their potential to influence project outcomes;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
National norms followed in Sierra Leone and international requirements including the Equator<br /><br />
Principles (EP) and the Voluntary Principles on Security and Human Rights (VPSHR) for<br /><br />
stakeholder engagement;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Different types of stakeholder engagement activities will be explained and the activities<br /><br />
undertaken to date will be listed and reported on;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Analysis of comments from stakeholders will be presented at the outset and then updated at<br /><br />
various defined stages throughout the Project lifecycle;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A plan for stakeholder engagement in subsequent phases of the Project is proposed including<br /><br />
the human, logistical and financial resources required for the plan.<br /><br />

3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
PROJECT DESCRIPTION<br /><br />
Project Overview<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
‘Base-case’ engineering options for the project have been used in this report. However, it is also<br /><br />
recognised that further alternatives and options are being considered leading to optimisation during<br /><br />
successive stages of the project. More detail on engineering design and material quantities is given in<br /><br />
the referenced reports. The description below represents the know project description as of May 2010<br /><br />
and has been selected on the basis of relevance to the determination of likely environmental and<br /><br />
social footprint of the project that were identified during the development of the Environmental<br /><br />
Aspects Register (See Appendix 2).<br /><br />
The review of engineering, baseline conditions and preliminary impacts has been structured into four<br /><br />
elements comprising the Mining Area, Transport Corridor, Port Facilities and Offshore.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Proposed Development<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The locations of the principal elements of Phase 1 of the Tonkolili project are described below and in<br /><br />
Table 3-1:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mining Area - hematite deposits from Phase 1 are located along the crown of the Simbili<br /><br />
formation. Supporting mine infrastructure, accommodation facilities and mining plant will be<br /><br />
located in the Mawuru and Tonkolili valleys southwest of Simbili. See Figure 3-3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Transport Corridor – a haul road is under construction from the mine site to a rail interchange<br /><br />
at Lunsar (approximately 120 km). Ore is then transported by narrow-gauge rail to Pepel<br /><br />
along the original Delco rail line which is to be refurbished;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Port Facilities – ore will be exported from Pepel port using a combination of new and<br /><br />
refurbished facilities for rail dumper, ore handling and stockpiling and the existing wharf<br /><br />
interface including refurbishment of the existing jetties;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Offshore – the base-case option assumes off shore anchorage loading of ocean going bulk<br /><br />
carriers (Panamax or Cape size) from transshipment vessels loaded at the primary Pepel<br /><br />
jetty.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Table 3-1 Summary of the different locations of Phase 1<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Element 1 - Mining Area<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The magnetite and hematite deposits that forms the basis for the full-development Tonkolili project<br /><br />
occurs in a north-east to south-west trending hilly outcrop. Drilling work has confirmed the magnetite<br /><br />
ore body reaches commercial grades of iron enrichment beneath three hills named Simbili, Marampon<br /><br />
and Numbara illustrated in Figure 3-2 below. Hematite occurs as a duri-crust deposit on these<br /><br />
deposits extending to approximately 50m depth with a further 50m depth of transitional zone. Phase 2<br /><br />
mining will target this transitional material. Magnetite is encountered at approximately 100m depth<br /><br />
below surface. Phase 3 mining will target magnetite beneath Simbili, Marampon and Numbara and<br /><br />
the expected pit depths extend to approximately 700m depth (SRK, May 2010).<br /><br />
Figure 3-2 Tonkolili Mineral Deposits<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Phase 1 of the Tonkolili project targets the overlying hematite/goethite deposit in the Simbili region,<br /><br />
and is intended to produce 8,000,000 tonnes (8Mtpa) of saleable product per year. Exploration has<br /><br />
indicated an ore reserve in the order of 800 Mt. The iron content of the hematite/goethite ore can be<br /><br />
increased to exportable grades through beneficiation. This requires relatively lower levels of<br /><br />
processing and investment in order to commercialise this phase of the project than needed for Phase<br /><br />
2 and 3. Crushing and sorting techniques will be required during Phase 1 near the point of extraction<br /><br />
with limited to no chemical or processing involved. The hematite deposit extends to approximately<br /><br />
50m depth in some areas, although it is characterised as having a highly variable distribution and<br /><br />
concentration across the deposits. Between the base of the hematite deposit (-50m) and the top of<br /><br />
the underlying Tonkolili deposit (-100m) there is a ‘transition zone’ of heterogeneous mineral<br /><br />
composition. This transition zone will be mined as part of the Phase 2 works.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-6-10\tonkolili<br /><br />
phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
Page 28<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 3-3 Phase 1 Mine Location<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Shipping of the hematite product is planned to commence in January 2011. In order to produce the<br /><br />
required 8 Mtpa, some 10.4 million tonnes of run-of-mine will have to be beneficiated, and a total of<br /><br />
34 million tonnes of material (ore and waste) will need to be mined. The strip ratio is expected to vary<br /><br />
between 0.5 to 1.5 during Phase 1 mining.<br /><br />
Mining will be undertaken with a conventional truck and shovel operation. Ore will be hauled to a<br /><br />
crushing and screening plant, to be located southwest of Simbili. Waste will be initially used for<br /><br />
construction of access and haul roads, and for various other infrastructure projects in preparation for<br /><br />
the commencement of Phase 3 construction. Excess waste will be dumped in areas to the west and<br /><br />
northwest of Simbili, outside the final magnetite pit limits so as to avoid rehandling.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 3-4 Phase 1 Mine Detail<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Phase 1 mining equipment will consist of 3 hydraulic shovels (operating weight 380t each) and 21<br /><br />
haul trucks (payload capacity 130-140t each). Ancillary equipment will include 2 water carts (130t<br /><br />
capacity), three tracked dozers (Caterpillar D10 or equivalent), and 2 graders (Caterpillar 16M or<br /><br />
equivalent).<br /><br />
Mining will be conducted on a 24 hour basis, with three crews working two 12 hour shifts.<br /><br />
The designed pits are 50m deep and 1.3 km2. The approximate location of the mining areas on<br /><br />
Simbili is shown in Figure 3-4 and it is likely that the northern zone will be mined first.<br /><br />
Mine Layout<br /><br />
The proposed Pit with the Stockpiling and Park-up area is located approximately 2.5 km eastsoutheast from the main village of the area, Farangbaia, and 3.3 and 3.7 km east-southeast from the<br /><br />

AML bottom and top camps, respectively. The stockpiling and parking area is approximately 3 km<br /><br />
southwest of Kemadugu, 2.7 km southeast of Kegbema, 2.5 km northeast of Wandugu, 5 km<br /><br />
northeast of Furia, and 5.3 km from other small villages in the greater area.<br /><br />
An airstrip will be oriented approximately north-south in the Tonkolili River valley west of the<br /><br />
Farangbaia forest reserve.<br /><br />
The main access road extends south from the contractor's workshop area to the mine haul road and<br /><br />
is located approximately 800 m east of the centre of the main village, Farangbaia, 850 m east of the<br /><br />
bottom camp and 1.3 km from the top camp.<br /><br />
The mine haul road is approximately 400 m east of the centre of Wandugu and Furia.<br /><br />
The Contractors Workshop is approximately 600 m northeast of the centre of Farangbaia, and<br /><br />
approximately 1.2 km northeast from the centre of the bottom camp to the centre of the top camp.<br /><br />
The Crushing and Loading Facility is approximately 600 m northeast from the centre of Furia and<br /><br />
approximately 2 km south from the centre of Wandugu.<br /><br />
Material from Phase 1 will be hauled down a series of ramps to the north and through a cutting on the<br /><br />
western side of the ridge. Ore will continue to be transported down to the crushing pad, located to the<br /><br />
south of the Tonkolili River, near the village of Wandugu. Waste from this phase will be taken to a<br /><br />
waste dump located to the northwest of the cutting (Figure 3-4) although some of the more competent<br /><br />
waste will be used for additional road and pad construction, in preparation for the commencement of<br /><br />
the second phase and the subsequent magnetite operation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dewatering<br /><br />
Major dewatering should not be required, given the elevation and drainage of the Phase 1 pits,<br /><br />
however, localised dewatering may be necessary from time to time. It should be noted that the<br /><br />
deposit lies in a tropical region, which is subject to a large amount of rainfall during the months of May<br /><br />
to October. The mean annual rainfall for the region is 2,542mm.<br /><br />
Accommodation<br /><br />
Camp facilities will be constructed for the development. Capacity of camps is estimated to be 600.<br /><br />
Blasting<br /><br />
Blasting activities will begin within 3-4 weeks of the project start up and will be conducted for most of<br /><br />
the life of the project as the excavation first progresses along the ridge to the northwest in Phase 1,<br /><br />
then advances to the south in Phase 3. Blasting will occur 2 times each week during the day only, and<br /><br />
will generally be confined to within the top 20 meters of excavation. Each blast will affect an area of<br /><br />
4,000 m2. Given the nature of the rock, powder factors are likely to be low; therefore vibration from<br /><br />
blasting activities should also be low. Some oversize blasting may be required in lower levels of the<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
excavation. Blasting is likely to utilize Ammonium nitrate-fuel oil (ANFO) as a bulk explosive and nonelectric (nonel) surface and down-hole delays. Each hole will be stemmed prior to blasting.<br /><br />
Site Restoration<br /><br />
The entire Simbili hematite mining operation is contained within the larger magnetite pit shell and<br /><br />
therefore, rehabilitation of the pit is not deemed necessary on the assumption that Phase 3 will<br /><br />
continue on from Phase 1 and 2. The haul road to the ore pad will be utilised during Phase 3 as an<br /><br />
access road. The waste dump for Phase 1 will be enlarged as part of the Phase 3 magnetite waste<br /><br />
disposal facility.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Element 2 -Transport Corridor<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Beneficiated hematite ore will be transported using a combination of road-trains on along a specially<br /><br />
constructed haul road followed by haulage using a light-gauge rail track. The 122 km long haul road<br /><br />
built from the mine site to a railhead about 8 km North-West of Lunsar where it ties in with the existing<br /><br />
railway which is to be refurbished.<br /><br />
More detailed description of the haul road design, cross-sections, waypoints, river crossings, villages,<br /><br />
forests and other areas of environmental and social concern have been provided in a stand-alone<br /><br />
Haul Road Scoping report submitted to SLEPA in April 2010 (WorleyParsons Report ref. EN-REP0014). Relevant excerpts are provided in Appendix 1. Only a brief summary is included below.<br /><br />
Figure 3-5: Map 1 of Haul Road Alignment<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Between Lunsar to the Rokel River crossing the topography is slightly sloping, gently undulating and<br /><br />
varying in elevation between about 100 and 110 masl. Here the haul road will be situated generally on<br /><br />
low embankments or shallow cuts. From the Rokel River to the mine site (chainage Km 110 to Km<br /><br />
122), the topography becomes much steeper and there are steep valley slopes and rivers and the<br /><br />
underlying material is hard rock. Here, significant cut and fill volumes should be expected with most of<br /><br />
the cut in hard rock, probably requiring the use of explosives (subject to approvals granted from the<br /><br />
Government of Sierra Leone).<br /><br />
The first part of the schedule of works for the haul road has been initiated comprising initial<br /><br />
reconnaissance survey and in some areas development of a scout road. The development of further<br /><br />
work associated with clearance, road widening, profiling and sealing (drainage etc) are subject to<br /><br />
confirmation from SLEPA in response to prior submissions (Haul Road Scoping, EMP and other<br /><br />
reports that have been generated in April 2010).<br /><br />
During the initial site clearance and creation of the scout road, vegetation has been cleared using<br /><br />
bulldozers. Further clearance will be required for the entire length and width of the route using a<br /><br />
heavy flail attachment on 360 excavators or similar approved fittings for a tractor. Local labour will use<br /><br />
machete / sickle to cut back.<br /><br />
The following environmental management measures are being undertaken. All decomposable<br /><br />
vegetation waste will be re-introduced into neighbouring vegetated areas. Trees will be logged in a<br /><br />
controlled manner and under direct supervision of trained competent personnel. Logging gangs will be<br /><br />
<br /><br />

operating well ahead of road construction activities. Suitable timber will be sent to saw mill for<br /><br />

When completed the road will comprise a compacted but unsealed surface edged with 1m high earth<br /><br />
berms. The road will have two lanes, with a nominal width of 12.5 m (16.5 m with berms). Drainage<br /><br />
from the road will be controlled by a cross-sectional road profile that drains to the edges with gaps in<br /><br />
the berm edging at intervals to release flows.<br /><br />

five motorised trailers with a gross payload of 400 tonnes.<br /><br />

Route Selection<br /><br />
The following design principles have been utilized for the haul road:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
All villages to be provided a clearance of at least 500m where practicable;<br /><br />
Severed access tracks between villages to be maintained with 2.4m diameter corrugated<br /><br />
steel pipe culverts to act as an underpass beneath the haul road. Actual requirements and<br /><br />
locations to be site determined;<br /><br />
A clearance of at least 500m is to be provided to areas of sacred bush where practicable.<br /><br />
Site-specific requirements and locations are subject to local variability;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
100m minimum clearance from any overhead power lines will be observed. All temporary<br /><br />
access beneath lines to be fitted with ticker tape marker poles as notification measure.<br /><br />
Clearance levels to be sited and clearly marked on both sides;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
500m minimum clearance to any Telecom communication towers. All temporary access<br /><br />
beneath lines to be fitted with ticker tape marker poles as notification measure. Clearance<br /><br />
levels to be sited and clearly marked on both sides;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
At road intersections a modular steel bridge to carry the existing road over the haul road will<br /><br />
be installed. Where the existing roads are minor, a manual form of traffic control will be<br /><br />
required (manned boom).<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />

Borrow pits for nodular ferricrete gravel were recorded at various locations adjacent to the existing<br /><br />

material has high nodular gravel content and should have a CBR (California Bearing Ration) well in<br /><br />

ferricrete. It is expected that up to 40 percent of the material excavated from cuttings of more than 3m<br /><br />
depth may be suitable for sub-base and wearing course construction. The haul road is to be<br /><br />
constructed with four layers comprising Sub Grade, Sub Base a Base layer and the Surface.<br /><br />

Construction of the camps is required as an early Phase 1 activity and the project programme<br /><br />

management and power demand will be controlled through specific environmental management<br /><br />

It is assumed that water requirements will be one bore hole per camp. Water treatment plants will be<br /><br />
constructed at each camp. 30,000 L a day of water will be treated, while 50,000 L will be stored at<br /><br />
each camp. At the moment it is assumed that black water treatment plants will be placed at each<br /><br />
camp. Solids will be removed periodically by honey sucker.<br /><br />

The road-trains will offload hematite ore at Lunsar Yard. The loading yard at Lunsar will consist of 3<br /><br />

Rail transport from Lunsar will be along a narrow-gauge railway line which had previously been<br /><br />
between Marampa and Pepel for iron ore transport operations (Delco 1933 to 1975). The ‘Delco’ line<br /><br />
is to undergo refurbishment along with the port and wharfing facilities at the terminus on Pepel Island,<br /><br />
which AML are operating under a 99 year lease agreement with the Government of Sierra Leone<br /><br />

Phase 1 Rail Refurbishment<br /><br />
Construction activities will require a number of works to be undertaken along the existing narrow<br /><br />
gauge (1065mm) single track rail line alignment.<br /><br />
The scope of work includes the repair and construction of approximately a 72km main line, two 1km<br /><br />
loops and a new rail loading yard at Lunsar as well as remedial work on the existing rail infrastructure<br /><br />
at Pepel yard.<br /><br />
Figure 3-10 Rail Map<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Line clearance works will be performed by local workers using hand held machetes The track will be<br /><br />
constructed by initially lifting the existing rails and sleepers wherever they remain in position then<br /><br />
relaying 40kg/m rails comprising reconditioned and new sections to be laid on reconditioned steel<br /><br />
sleepers spaced at 650mm centers laid on 1200m³ ballast profile. One loop lines will be constructed<br /><br />
at approximately 20km and a former loop at 42km reinstated and a new loading yard constructed at<br /><br />
Lunsar.<br /><br />
Construction methodology:<br /><br />
1.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Site Preparation<br /><br />
<br /><br />

3.2.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Element 3 - Port Facilities<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hematite ore will be taken to Pepel Port where the material handling system will be capable of either<br /><br />
directly loading ore from the train or stockpiling and then reclaiming depending on the timing of ship<br /><br />
movements. Ore will be exported via transshipment vessels (TV) to an offshore anchorage. The iron<br /><br />
ore will be transferred to ocean going bulk carriers (OGV) for export.<br /><br />
Ultimately, the total iron ore exported will be 8 million tonnes per annum (8 Mtpa). During the first year<br /><br />
of operation the amount of iron ore exported will ramp up as follows.<br /><br />

Pepel Port is located in the Sierra Leone Estuary about 20km from the sea and 12km upriver from<br /><br />
Freetown. It has not operated since 1985 but infrastructure is still present in the area including housing<br /><br />
and office facilities, a power plant, fuel tanks, conveyer belts and a jetty / ship loader. The area of the<br /><br />
Pepel Port is approximately 1725 ha.<br /><br />
To enable operations, the Port will need to be renovated. The objective of the Pepel Port project is to<br /><br />
refurbish and upgrade the existing facilities to enable a maximum loading capacity of 4000 tonnes per<br /><br />
hour (tph). A schematic of the existing facilities is provided in Figure 3-11. The operations will be similar<br /><br />
to those of the existing port and therefore there is no need to expand the port footprint and no additional<br /><br />
land clearance is required.<br /><br />
The planned refurbishment and upgrade of Pepel will include the following:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Power Generation System;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dual Train Dumping Station;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Stacker Feed System;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reclaim Feed System;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Shiploader;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Offshore Transshipment Anchorage<br /><br />
<br /><br />
