Figure 3-11 Schematic of Existing Pepel Port Layout<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The iron ore will be transferred by rail to Pepel Port and offloaded at a double dump loadout station.<br /><br />
Total train offloading time at the dump station will be approximately 1.5 hours. The iron ore will be<br /><br />
transported to a double boom stacker by conveyors. The capacity of each onshore conveyor will be<br /><br />
2000 tph. The stacker will form 2 stockpiles with capacity of 200000 tonnes each. Four front end<br /><br />
loaders will excavate the ore from the stockpiles and offload it in collecting hoppers. The ore will then be<br /><br />
transported to the jetty by the transfer conveyor. The capacity of the transfer conveyor will be 4000<br /><br />
tonnes per hour.<br /><br />
A schematic diagram of the process flow is presented below (Figure 3-12)<br /><br />
Power requirements for the port are yet to be determined. At present, it is assumed that a new power<br /><br />
generation facility will be established, which utilises diesel generators. It is assumed that it will be a<br /><br />
package plant with no seawater cooling requirement. Diesel will be transported to Pepel by road and<br /><br />
stored within the existing storage facilities following their renovation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

3.2.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Element 4 – Offshore (Marine engineering)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The existing terminal comprises a 140m long jetty with two quadrant ship loaders with a maximum<br /><br />
outreach of 25.5m. The mooring layout comprises the berthing face of the jetty head and two mooring<br /><br />
dolphins set back from the berthing line.<br /><br />
All marine structures will need to be refurbished, including the shiploader booms, stackers/reclaimers,<br /><br />
stockyard conveyor and berths. The two mooring dolphins are beyond refurbishment and will be<br /><br />
replaced. Two additional dolphins may be required to safely moor the TVs.<br /><br />
The detailed design of the mooring and shiploading facility is yet to be finalised a potential layout is<br /><br />
shown in Figure 3-13.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 3-13 Example Ship-Loader Layouts for Pepel Port<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Transshipment is proposed as Pepel Port is unsuitable for cape-sized vessels due to its location<br /><br />
within the estuary and the depth of the access channel. Transshipment results in a significant<br /><br />
reduction in capital and maintenance dredging requirements.<br /><br />
The OGV will be anchored offshore and the ore will be transported from Pepel to the anchorage by<br /><br />
the TV. Self unloading Handymax vessels with a cargo lift of approximately 30000 tonnes – similar in<br /><br />
size to the vessels previously use by the port – are proposed to be used as TVs. Two TVs will be<br /><br />
required and each will be doing approximately one round trip per day between Pepel and the<br /><br />
transshipment anchorage once the objective export volume of 8 Mtpa is reached. The OGV is<br /><br />

<br /><br />
expected to be a Cape-size vessel with a cargo capacity of approximately 170000 tonnes. Panamax<br /><br />
vessels with a lower capacity may be used.<br /><br />
The transshipment anchorage location has not been finalized and is currently being assessed but it<br /><br />
will be located outside the estuary some distance offshore where there is sufficient water depth for the<br /><br />
OGV.<br /><br />
TVs will transport the iron ore to the anchored OGV. The TV will transfer the ore directly into the OGV,<br /><br />

Dredge Channel<br /><br />
Preliminary design of the berthing/manoeuvring area and navigation channel from Pepel Island to the<br /><br />
mouth of the Bunce River comprises the following key elements:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Turning basin depth: -7.0 m chart datum (CD)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Channel depth: -10.5 m CD<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Channel width (straights): 120 m<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Channel width (bends): 250 m adjacent to Tasso Island; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Channel side slopes: 1V:5H (vertical and horizontal)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The dredging works will reinstate the channel used by Pepel port when it was previously in operation.<br /><br />
The initial water depths for the scope of work are derived from the UK Hydrographic Office Admiralty<br /><br />
charts and are a minimum of -7 m CD in the main navigational channel. The estimated dredging<br /><br />
areas are shown in Figure 3-16. This will be dredging of material that has infilled in the Pepel channel<br /><br />
since Pepel port was last used and maintenance dredging took place.<br /><br />
The estimated volume of dredge material is approximately 1.5 million m3. However, further<br /><br />
bathymetry surveys are underway to confirm the dredging requirements.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />

<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 3-16 Proposed dredging areas - manoeuvring area and Navigation Channel<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Additional maintenance dredging will be required on a yearly basis to maintain the navigation<br /><br />
channel. The frequency and volume of maintenance dredging required is currently being assessed.<br /><br />
However, high deposition is expected in some areas during the rainy season such as in Kakim<br /><br />
channel and historical information suggests that volumes of between 0.5 - 1.0 million m3 may need to<br /><br />
be dredged each year to restore depths.<br /><br />
Dredging Methodology<br /><br />
As infill of a previous channel is being dredged, the material is expected to be relatively soft.<br /><br />
Therefore a Trailing Suction Hopper Dredger (TSHD) will be used for the dredging works.<br /><br />
Suction dredging such as TSHD is commonly used for dredging silty, sandy or gravely soils or soft<br /><br />
clayey soils. Sediment grabs indicate that much of the Pepel channel has medium coarse grain<br /><br />
sediments, probably due to the strong tidal currents along the channel. There are some areas where<br /><br />
finer sediments have been deposited. This is described in more detail in the baseline section 6.5.1.<br /><br />
A hopper will be used to collect the dredged material in its cargo hold to transport to the dredge spoil<br /><br />
disposal site.<br /><br />
The dredging cycle starts with the dredger sailing with an empty hopper to the proposed dredging<br /><br />
area using its highly accurate navigation systems.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 50<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The TSHD shall deepen the channel by removing consecutive layers of the seabed material. In<br /><br />
addition to the given dimensions, an average of 2 m overwidth at each side and an over-depth<br /><br />
between 0 m and 0.5 m is dredged as a result of positioning tolerances.<br /><br />
The characteristics of a typical TSHD are presented in Table 3-5.<br /><br />

TSHD Working Principles<br /><br />
The TSHD it is a sea-going, self-propelled dredging vessel, which includes a hopper to store the<br /><br />
dredge material. It is commonly used.<br /><br />
The dredging systems of a TSHD consist of one or two suction tubes, each driven by a powerful<br /><br />
centrifugal pump, called the sand pump. During the dredging, and in a process, which is quite similar<br /><br />
to the domestic vacuum cleaner, the lower ends of the suction tubes are trailing along on the seabed,<br /><br />
while the sand pumps provide the suction power to lift the materials from the seabed into the hopper.<br /><br />
The suction pipe has a special draghead, which is designed to maximize the dredging efficiency<br /><br />
during the loading phase (Figure 3-17).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 51<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 3-17 Typical draghead (left) and suction pipe (right) from TSHD<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The sediment is loosened and removed from the seabed by a combination of suction provided by the<br /><br />
sand pump, the forward motion of the vessel and the cutting and jetting characteristics of the<br /><br />
draghead. The materials dredged from the seabed, will be pumped into the hopper as a<br /><br />
sediment/water mixture. Care will be taken to minimise the water content in the mixture.<br /><br />
In the hopper the sand material settles due to gravity and the water flows back to the sea through the<br /><br />
overflows situated in the hopper.<br /><br />
Figure 3-18 shows the general layout of TSHD operations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 3-18 General layout of TSHD working at dredging site<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The dredge material is stored in the hopper for transport to the offshore disposal area (Figure 3-19).<br /><br />
Figure 3-19 Hopper wells<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />

Page 53<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In order to increase the volume of dredge material that can be stored and minimise the number of<br /><br />
trips to the disposal site excess water overflows from the hopper. There is a risk of increased turbidity<br /><br />
due to the hoper overflow.<br /><br />
To minimize the potential fine plume, an overflow funnel is constructed inside the hopper. It consists<br /><br />
of a height adjustable funnel mounted on top of a vertical cylinder which ends under the keel of the<br /><br />
dredge. The excess water is discharged under the dredger (see Figure 3-20), at the highest level<br /><br />
possible, thus minimising the concentration of suspended solids in the overflow water.<br /><br />
There is also an anti-turbidity valve or “green valve”, which is a hydraulically controlled valve mounted<br /><br />
inside the overflow funnel(s). This valve drastically reduces the turbidity generated by the overflow<br /><br />
water (or dredge plume) drained through the overflow funnels. It reduces the overflow funnel, which<br /><br />
ensures that the water level inside the overflow funnel will be maintained and the mixture will “fall”<br /><br />
from a lesser height. As a result less air gets mixed into the overflow and the dredge plume will not<br /><br />
have a tendency to rise up, next to or behind the vessel. Without the use of this green valve the finer<br /><br />
particles in the overflow mixture are churned up by the vessel’s propellers and hence create those<br /><br />
infamous turbid clouds behind the trailer dredger.<br /><br />
Figure 3-20 Typical overflow funnel with anti-turbidity valve<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />

TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dredge Disposal<br /><br />
As soon as the hopper is fully loaded, the suction tubes will be hoisted back onboard and the dredger<br /><br />
will head to the dredge disposal site.<br /><br />
Bottom dumping is the fastest way to unload the hopper by discharging the load through the opened<br /><br />
bottom doors of the hopper (Figure 3-21). Water jets inside the hopper will ensure the hopper is<br /><br />
completely empty and free of any dredged soil prior to closing the bottom doors. Due to the draft of<br /><br />
the vessel the material will fall approximately ten metres through the water column to the seabed. As<br /><br />
part of the EMP an assessment is required to ensure that the material remains within the disposal<br /><br />
site.<br /><br />
Figure 3-21 Bottom dumping procedures, at disposal sites<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The TSHD can also discharge at sea via its own suction tube, to discharge it at a greater depth. The<br /><br />
depth is restricted to the length of the suction tube but will be sufficient for the proposed disposal<br /><br />
ground.<br /><br />
All dredged materials will be transported to the agreed dumpsite approximately 5 km north of Cape<br /><br />
Sierra Leone, which is shown in<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Duration<br /><br />
Dredging will take place 24 hours/day for 7 days/ week. Therefore it will take up to 7.5 weeks to<br /><br />
remove the estimated 1.5 M m3 of sediment.<br /><br />
The yearly maintenance dredging will take up to 2.5 weeks, assuming a dredge volume of 500,000 m³<br /><br />
of sediment and a dredging capacity of 200,000 m³/wk.<br /><br />
Timescales for capital dredging will be confirmed once the bathymetry survey is complete and the<br /><br />
final dredge volume is calculated. Maintenance dredging requirements will be dependant on infilling<br /><br />
and estimates will be refined following modelling of sediment transport in the estuary.<br /><br />

Power supply<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Power supply to the mine activities will be provided by diesel powered generators with a localised<br /><br />
distribution system within the mine area.<br /><br />
Power demand will be required for the contractors’ workshop, workers’ camps and crushing and<br /><br />
loading facilities, among others.<br /><br />
Haul Road<br /><br />
Power supply to the haul road will be only needed during the construction phase at 3 construction<br /><br />
camp locations (Rogbere, Makeni and Tonkolili).<br /><br />
Energy sources and power demand are yet to be finalised; however, it is anticipated that the demand<br /><br />

Lunsar Interchange<br /><br />
Power will be required for both, the construction and the operation phases of the Interchange Yard.<br /><br />
During construction, power demand will be satisfied through the use of Diesel Generators that will<br /><br />
supply the construction camp and any other machinery in requirement of power. During the operation<br /><br />
phase, the power demands for the office building will be also provided through the use of a Diesel<br /><br />
Generator.<br /><br />
The power demand is still to be finalised for both construction and operation phases.<br /><br />
Rail Refurbishment<br /><br />
Power will be needed during construction / refurbishment at both the rail camp to be located in Pepel<br /><br />
yard and one mobile on track (on the railway line) camp that will move as the work progresses. At this<br /><br />
stage all sources of energy will be self generating i.e. generators varying in size from 6Kva - 25Kva.<br /><br />
AML has taken responsibility for the free issue of electricity at selected locations along the route.<br /><br />
The Pepel Yard Generators will work on diesel and its estimated fuel demand is 8 L.hr-1, making it a<br /><br />
total of 168 960 L of fuel on the basis of 1 200 days for the construction.<br /><br />
Pepel Port<br /><br />
Power supply to the port area during construction will be provided by packet generation sets with a<br /><br />
localised distribution system within the port area. The initial port power requirements, yet to be<br /><br />
estimated, will be provided by 6.6 kV power generators fed by a diesel fuel source.<br /><br />
Pepel Operational Phase Power Requirements:<br /><br />
The stacker power requirements and the power requirements for the reclaimers, which will operate on<br /><br />
diesel, are being determined and there is a base-case assumption that refurbishment of the existing<br /><br />
power house at Pepel in conjunction with generator sets will be the selected model. Diesel was<br /><br />
previously brought into Pepel Port and stored using a dedicated fuel jetty connected to a 6Ml fuel<br /><br />
farm. Confirmation of renewal of this process is still underway. An alternative is that diesel will be<br /><br />
supplied to Pepel from Tagrin Port when Phase 3 operations commence.<br /><br />

3.3.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Water supply<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potable and construction water supply will be required at numerous locations across the project area.<br /><br />
Although preference has been given to utilise groundwater resources for potable use, it is likely that<br /><br />
due to the accelerated nature of Phase 1 a significant component of potable water will be trucked in<br /><br />
from Freetown, as is the current practice at the mine exploration camp. Construction water will be<br /><br />
sourced from nearby groundwater resources through a drilled groundwater borehole or a network of<br /><br />
several boreholes.<br /><br />
Hematite Mine<br /><br />
It is likely that the Phase 1 mine water will be supplied from existing springs / streams that are<br /><br />
currently in use for exploration activities. Currently, potable water demand is estimated as an average<br /><br />
of 20 L per person per day. Construction water demand is yet to be determined.<br /><br />
Haul Road<br /><br />
Haul road construction camps will require a temporary water supply in form of groundwater wells to<br /><br />
be drilled at each location. The latest assumption is that there will be three camp locations along the<br /><br />
haul road alignment, water demand for each of them is yet to be determined.<br /><br />
It is assumed that water requirements will be one bore hole for camp. Water treatment plants will be<br /><br />
constructed at each camp. 30,000 L/day of water will be treated, while 50,000 L will be stored at each<br /><br />
camp.<br /><br />
Lunsar Interchange<br /><br />
At the interchange there will be an office and 2 portable toilets, the location of which is also unknown.<br /><br />
All these facilities will require water, which is likely to come from groundwater wells drilled in the area.<br /><br />
Water requirement specifications for construction and operation are still pending.<br /><br />
Rail Refurbishment<br /><br />
Water supply during the rail refurbishment will be required, as a minimum, at the rail camp in Pepel<br /><br />
yard, and on the mobile (on the railway line) camp. It is anticipated that each location will have a<br /><br />
different water requirement, largely depending on the number of personnel working at each and on<br /><br />
the construction water requirements, yet to be determined.<br /><br />
It is anticipated that drinking water (bottled) will be supplied by AML from Freetown and that<br /><br />
construction water requirements will be sourced from drilling wells at each of the camps.<br /><br />
Pepel Port<br /><br />
During Phase 1 of work, a water supply will be required at Pepel Island. No significant fresh surface<br /><br />
water bodies exist on or near Pepel Island and groundwater is the primary available resource.<br /><br />
Average water demand for the initial construction and operation of the proposed port and related<br /><br />
facilities has been estimated to be about 250 m3/d (2.9 l/s), but could reach a maximum of 300 m3/d<br /><br />
(3.5 l/s).<br /><br />
It was proposed by Scott Wilson that nine production wells are located east and west of Mayela<br /><br />
village. On the basis of a yield of 0.5 l/s per well, seven wells will be required to meet the demand of<br /><br />

3.3.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Solid Waste Management<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Solid Waste from both operational and construction activities will be dealt with in a structured and<br /><br />
auditable manner from the commencement of the project through design, into construction and on to<br /><br />
operation and monitoring and beyond. Waste minimisation will be emphasised from the outset of the<br /><br />
project, in addition to ensuring that the waste produced is dealt with in accordance with the principles<br /><br />
outlined within a defined Waste Hierarchy (reduction, reuse, recovery and recycling, see<br /><br />
WorleyParsons Report Preliminary Concepts for Solid Waste Appendix 3). All applicable in-country<br /><br />
legislation and best practice will be adhered to. Where disposal or treatment is required, this should<br /><br />
be undertaken in accordance with the treatment recommendations included in the section below.<br /><br />
Hematite Mine<br /><br />
Solid waste will be generated at the worker camps will be dealt in accordance with the waste<br /><br />
hierarchy, with a significant fraction of the waste sent to an incineration unit provided specifically for<br /><br />
both workers and operational municipal waste generated at the mine. Currently sewage and solid<br /><br />
waste including putrescible is being dumped at waste pits without pre-treatment. Pits are being<br /><br />
managed only by intermittent cover using surface soils. Improvement and upgrading of waste<br /><br />
management is a priority item currently being undertaken by AML.<br /><br />
Haul Road<br /><br />
It is anticipated that the haul road will generate negligible operational waste. The primary waste<br /><br />
arising from the construction will be spoil potentially in the region of 800,000m3 based on preliminary<br /><br />
cut and fill calculations. This waste is considered to be inert and does not require an engineered<br /><br />
facility for disposal; however areas should be outlined at outset for stockpiling and bunding. Where<br /><br />
possible the road should be designed to achieve a cut and fill balance. As a minimum, land areas<br /><br />
should be set aside for spoil disposal; there may be an opportunity to re-use spoil in some port<br /><br />
reclamation works.<br /><br />
Rail refurbishment<br /><br />
It is not anticipated that the operation of the rail facility will generate significant waste issues;<br /><br />
however, there is a potential for waste arising from existing material that cannot be reused (especially<br /><br />
scrap metal). At this stage the waste related to the construction will be limited to the following:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Packaging from material – 20 to 50kg size bags and cardboard (total estimated tonnage will<br /><br />
be 5 tonnes over the contract period of 10 months);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Paper and cardboard from locals (total estimated tonnage will be 2 tonnes a month over a<br /><br />
period of 10 months).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
All waste will be stockpiled in a suitable area to be identified by AML, where waste can be treated.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Pepel Port<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
At Pepel port, the project development will comprise a materials handling facility, and relevant<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Project Options & Alternatives<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
ESHIA requires an analysis of alternatives, which should provide a systematic comparison of feasible<br /><br />
alternatives to the proposed project and evaluation of their potential social and environmental<br /><br />
impacts. Alternatives to be considered should include, as appropriate, planning alternatives, site or<br /><br />
route locations, location of facilities, infrastructure alternatives, technology, operations, land use<br /><br />
alternatives, financial alternatives, and the ‘without project’ alternative.<br /><br />
Alternatives design, technology and site selection of the project elements has been considered<br /><br />
already. A significant factor that has been taken into consideration has been the attempt to minimise<br /><br />
adverse or negative social or environmental impacts. The project design presented above (the base<br /><br />
case) mostly represents the best trade-off that can be achieved, with the available information<br /><br />
between minimised impacts and good engineering performance.<br /><br />
Consideration of other alternatives is an inherent component of project design, which is ongoing at<br /><br />
present. Consequently the ESHIA alternatives analysis process informs project design. This ESHIA<br /><br />
summarises all alternatives considered, including the ‘without project’ option.<br /><br />
A summary of some of the high level strategic options and alternatives that have been considered to<br /><br />
date or are under consideration in relation to minimising environmental and social impacts is<br /><br />
presented below. More detailed alternatives analysis is provided for specific project elements and<br /><br />
facilities in the relevant impact and mitigation sections that follow:<br /><br />
Mining<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The location of the ore bodies is fixed and there is limited available option to consider in terms<br /><br />
of alternative location or mining methods or scheduling as the mine plan is based on a single<br /><br />
optimised mining model;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
However, it is important to consider that the Phase 1, 2 and 3 mining projects are interactive<br /><br />
in the sense that Phase 1 mining and the mining of transition material as part of Phase 2 has<br /><br />
a significant effect on lowering the amount of Phase 3 overburden and hence waste rock<br /><br />
generation;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The overall ‘without project’ alternative would involve abandoning the mining project as well<br /><br />
as the infrastructure aspects of the project that are conditional upon the mining operation<br /><br />
proceeding. The project represents a nationally significant development opportunity with<br /><br />
major social, environmental and governance impacts both positive and negative. This ESHIA<br /><br />
presents an unbiased assessment of the project so that the GoSL with respect to its<br /><br />
constitutional responsibilities can make an informed decision in its capacity of considering the<br /><br />
national interests and sustainable development.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Transport Corridor<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The road and rail alignments located within the borders of the 6km wide leased transport<br /><br />
corridor have undergone route selection taking into account environmental and social<br /><br />
constraints. The route selected has avoided protected areas such as Farangbaia Forest<br /><br />
Reserve, riverine forest areas and areas of conservation habitat on the basis of constraints<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />

Port Area<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Pepel Port project has wherever feasible looked at alternatives associated with<br /><br />
brownfield regeneration rather than new build so as to minimise cost, material and resourcing<br /><br />
requirements. This carried significant environmental and social benefit in terms of pragmatic<br /><br />
use of resources and limiting impacts to areas that are already have a degree of conditioning<br /><br />
associated with the previous operations;<br /><br />

•<br /><br />

The project has considered design alternatives that wherever feasible put material handling<br /><br />

Offshore<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The alternative of zero dredging in the Sierra Leone estuary whilst still accommodating capesize vessels has been considered by potentially using a much longer approach trestle<br /><br />
spanning across the estuary. This alternative is still under study;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Other alternatives currently under consideration include potential dredging. The inbound bulk<br /><br />
carriers would enter from sea, transit to Freetown to pick up a pilot. Transit to and from Pepel<br /><br />
would be timed to maximize water depth around high tide. Based on the available data there<br /><br />
are shallow depths at various sections along the route. In addition to the potential dredging of<br /><br />
the turning basin off the berth there will be a need for dredging at Tasso Island channel and<br /><br />
Kakim channel. There may be a need to dredge high spots in the river section; however these<br /><br />
areas may be passable at given heights and times of tide. The assumption is Panamax<br /><br />
vessels (80,000 dwt) will be used and require an estimated 6.3 million m3 of dredge material,<br /><br />
based on initial assessments.<br /><br />

4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
LEGAL, POLICY AND ADMINISTRATIVE FRAMEWORK<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The GoSL’s responsibility and role in protecting the nation’s natural resources and ensuring that<br /><br />
sustainable development (Article 21) is pursued has been enshrined in law under the National<br /><br />
Environmental Policy (1994).<br /><br />
This policy places responsibility on the Government to secure for all Sierra Leoneans a quality of<br /><br />
environment adequate for their health and well being and to conserve and use the environmental and<br /><br />
natural resources for the benefit of present and future generations.<br /><br />
The policy also requires that Government manages development so as to restore, maintain and<br /><br />
enhance the ecosystems and ecological processes essential for the functioning of the biosphere; to<br /><br />
preserve biological diversity and the principle of optimum sustainable yield in the use of living natural<br /><br />
resources and ecosystems.<br /><br />
The policy outlines in general terms how these aims can be implemented using a combination of<br /><br />
raising public awareness, encouraging community participation and strengthening environmental<br /><br />
protection standards, monitoring and data use.<br /><br />
The policy states that ESHIA can only be effective when done prior to proposed activities which may<br /><br />
significantly affect the environment or use of a natural resource and to provide relevant information, in<br /><br />
a timely manner, to persons likely to be significantly affected by a planned activity and to grant them<br /><br />
equal access and due process in administrative and judicial proceedings.<br /><br />
The policy promotes environmental management through the creation of administrative and<br /><br />
infrastructural support with appropriate financial backing.<br /><br />
Finally there is reiteration of the need to develop good international relations by adherence to<br /><br />
international treaties, care with regard to transboundary issues effective prevention or abatement of<br /><br />
transboundary environmental protection.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Institutional Bodies<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
In 2008 the GoSL passed the Environment Protection Agency Act No. 11 of 2008 (EPA 2008) which<br /><br />
established the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as the competent authority for reviewing and<br /><br />
processing ESHIA. The EPA Board of Directors also comprises representatives from the following<br /><br />
Ministries:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />

Ministry of the Environment;<br /><br />

•<br /><br />

•<br /><br />

Ministry of Mineral Resources;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ministry of Marine Resources;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry;<br /><br />
<br /><br />

The EPA has a wide range of environmental management functions including coordination of the<br /><br />

and management. The EPA is also responsible for ESHIA compliance and licensing (see Section<br /><br />

At present the EPA is not fully fledged. Predecessors to the EPA include the Department of<br /><br />
Environment (DOE), within the Ministry of Lands, Country Planning and the Environment (MLCPE),<br /><br />
and the 2005 National Environmental and Forestry Commission (NACEF), which was later referred to<br /><br />
as the Environment Commission (SRK Consulting, 2009).<br /><br />

4.2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Legislation Relevant to Ecological Protection<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Forests<br /><br />
No classified forest may be cut, burned, uprooted, damaged or destroyed, except with a written<br /><br />
permission from the Chief Conservator of the forest (Part VI, Section 21 Subsection 2 Forestry Act,<br /><br />
1988). Failure to observe this is an offence punishable with a fine.<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 68<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Classified forests, which may be either national or community forest have protection or production as<br /><br />
their primary purpose, and are to be managed accordingly. There is a general prohibition against<br /><br />
logging and other activities in classified forests, except by authorized exception from the Chief<br /><br />
Conservator of the forest.<br /><br />
Granting of licences for this is conditional upon fee payments to a reforestation fund and also on<br /><br />
agreement of appropriate provision for replanting and undertaking reforestation/rehabilitation of<br /><br />
disturbed land.<br /><br />
Vegetation Clearance<br /><br />
Vegetation clearance is also controlled under Forestry Regulation, 1989 which states that removal of<br /><br />
vegetation has to be carried out under licence and keep to a specific land area within a stated time.<br /><br />
Riverine/Mangrove Vegetation<br /><br />
No land between the high and low water marks, nor those above the high water mark on both sides of<br /><br />
the bank of any waterway, covering a distance of one hundred feet (approximately 33 m), shall be<br /><br />
cleared of any vegetation except permitted by a clearance licence (Part XI,Section 38).<br /><br />
Sacred Bush<br /><br />
Sacred forests/bushes are common throughout rural Sierra Leone and most villages have one or<br /><br />
several forests within close proximity. The values of these forests to communities are many and<br /><br />
varied, ranging from spiritual significance to meeting places to the practical source of trees and nontimber forest products. Increasingly, within the proposed transport corridor, sacred forests/bushes are<br /><br />
some of the last areas of remaining natural habitat left, prominent within wider landscape of degraded<br /><br />
vegetation and agriculture.<br /><br />
The Forestry Regulations of 1989 states under article XI, paragraph 40:<br /><br />
“No tree or vegetation shall be removed from areas abandoned as sacred bush except under the<br /><br />
authority al a clearance licence issued by the Chief Conservator of Forests.”<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
ESHIA Legislative Requirements<br /><br />
<br /><br />
On the basis of a formal application submitted to the Sierra Leone Environmental Protection Agency,<br /><br />
the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project has been classified under Category A (EPA letter to AML dated<br /><br />
4.12.09). According to the Equator Principles a Category A project requires a full environmental<br /><br />
impact assessment to assess the “potential significant adverse social or environmental impacts that<br /><br />
are diverse, irreversible or unprecedented” (Equator Principles Website, March 2010).<br /><br />
It is understood that the government of Sierra Leone use this categorization system to regulate the<br /><br />
ESHIA process and set the terms for an ESHIA licence. As part of the licensing the project’s ESHIA<br /><br />
needs to follow agreed terms of reference which will be established in conjunction with the EPA.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

The EPA 2008 briefly charts the procedure to obtain an ESHIA licence in Sections 23-29, with<br /><br />
emphasis on the responsibilities of the EPA and the EPA Board, as stated below.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />

<br /><br />

<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
If required, the applicant should then prepare an ESHIA;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
On receipt of the ESHIA, the EPA will circulate it to professional bodies or associations<br /><br />
including Government Ministries and non-governmental organisations (NGOs) for review;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Government Ministries and non-governmental organisations (NGOs) for review;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The EPA will also open the ESHIA for public inspection and comment and will notify the<br /><br />
public of this in two issues of the Gazette (consecutive issues) and two issues of a newspaper<br /><br />
(with an interval of at least seven days between the first and second publications);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The EPA will submit the comments on the ESHIA, together with the ESHIA, to the Board for<br /><br />
consideration;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
If the Board approves the ESHIA, it will instruct the Executive Director of the EPA to issue an<br /><br />
ESHIA licence;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The EPA will issue a licence to undertake the activity/ project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The ESHIA can only be approved by a multi-department Government Board. This Board then advises<br /><br />
the Executive Director of the Environment Protection Agency (EPA) on its decision on whether to<br /><br />
issue the licence or not (see Part IV of the Environment Protection Act, 2008 for further details).<br /><br />
In relation to social requirements, the EPA 2008 alludes to a requirement for social impact<br /><br />
assessment in the Third Schedule of the Act. It states that the ESHIA should include “social,<br /><br />
economic and cultural effect that the project is likely to have on people and society”.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
ESHIA requirements in the Mines and Minerals Act 2009<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Mines and Minerals Act 2009 sets out procedures to obtain mining licences and was approved by<br /><br />
the GoSL Cabinet in November 2009. Under this Act, a mining licence cannot be obtained until the<br /><br />
ESHIA has been prepared, submitted, reviewed and approved first. An ESHIA licence is a form of<br /><br />
permit which contains additional stipulations upon the holder such as abatement or remedial<br /><br />
measures.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Sierra Leone is a signatory to the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI). This initiative<br /><br />
supports improved governance in resource-rich countries through the verification and full publication<br /><br />
of company payments and government revenues from extractive industries including oil, gas and<br /><br />
mining. Countries rich in natural resources have tended to under-perform economically, have a higher<br /><br />
incidence of conflict, and suffer from poor governance. Through the EITI, it is hoped that by<br /><br />
encouraging greater transparency some of these negative impacts can be mitigated. Benefits to<br /><br />
companies centre on mitigating political and reputational risks. Sierra Leone was accepted as an EITI<br /><br />
candidate country on 22 February 2008. Sierra Leone has until 9 March 2010 to undertake validation<br /><br />
however an extension has been requested (EITI website, Sierra Leone website, March 2010). In the<br /><br />
new Minerals and Mines Act a section on reporting, disclosure and dissemination of information<br /><br />
related to revenues and payments made by the mineral right holders and the Government provides<br /><br />
the legal basis to make implementation of the EITI compulsory. It is stated as the obligation of the<br /><br />
license holder and contravening this provision would be considered a prosecutable offence.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />

<br /><br />
5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
REGIONAL BASELINE<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Climate, Air & Hydrology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.1.1 Climate<br /><br />
Sierra Leone has a tropical monsoon climate, modified by local influences such as a decrease in<br /><br />
temperature with altitude and variation in rainfall distribution induced by topography.<br /><br />
Characteristic of ‘monsoon’ climates are a wet season and a dry season each year - driven by the<br /><br />
annual cycle in the latitude at which the sun’s diurnal sky trajectory passes directly overhead. During<br /><br />
the northern hemisphere winter, dry northeasterly winds, originating over the Sahara desert, blow<br /><br />
across Sierra Leone. Conversely, in the northern hemisphere summer moist south-westerly winds<br /><br />
from the Gulf of Guinea are drawn across Sierra Leone. Hurricanes are not known to occur in this<br /><br />
region, any strong winds in the area would be related to squall lines.<br /><br />
Between March and November, a broad, east-west-aligned, rain-prone belt associated with the moist<br /><br />
air from the Gulf of Guinea advances northwards across Sierra Leone and then retreats southwards<br /><br />
again, drawn in the direction of the Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ). However, this simplistic<br /><br />
explanation for Sierra Leone’s wet season fails to explain all of its features. For instance, the axis of<br /><br />
rain-prone belt is not co-incidental with the surface position of the ITCZ, but displaced some 300-400<br /><br />
km to the south. In some years there is a brief lull in the rains in the middle of the wet season while<br /><br />
the entire rain-belt lies to the north, despite there being a plentiful supply of moist Gulf air. The<br /><br />
assumed direct coupling between the ITCZ and the position of main seasonal rain belt has been<br /><br />
questioned, and the factors involved are complex and still not fully understood. To the north of the<br /><br />
main monsoon rain belt is a zone where thunderstorms and line squalls develop, and move from east<br /><br />
to west with the tropospheric winds.<br /><br />
Hayward and Oguntoyinbo (1987) provide an overview of the climatology of the different weather<br /><br />
elements experienced in West Africa which results from the mechanisms discussed above. Sunshine<br /><br />
duration is greatest in the winter period, and much reduced in the rainy season as cloudy days<br /><br />
predominate. There is a slight increase in sunshine from the south to the north in Sierra Leone. There<br /><br />
is little seasonal variation in mean air temperatures, with slightly hotter conditions in April and May.<br /><br />
Altitude influences temperature as well as other weather variables, with temperatures generally<br /><br />
decreasing with altitude. Mean wind speeds are generally low, and high impact gusts are rare. The<br /><br />
greatest wind speeds in the dry season occur when the ‘Harmattan’ wind blows from the east or<br /><br />
north-east, while in the wet season higher wind speeds are associated with storms and squalls. The<br /><br />
prevailing wind direction is from the south-west for most of the year, especially near to the coast and<br /><br />
especially during the monsoon. Annual average rainfall is greatest along the coast, and decreases<br /><br />
with distance inland. The Met Office makes a rough estimate of mean annual potential evaporation of<br /><br />
1000 mm for the Sierra Leone area, with a peak in March. This is likely to be higher for inland areas<br /><br />
than on the coast.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 75<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
For more information on climate and weather in the project area see Literature Review of Available<br /><br />
Information and Data - Stage 1 -Prepared by the Met Office in Appendix 6 and Stage 2 – Climate<br /><br />
Assessment and Data Analysis - Prepared by the Met Office in Appendix 7.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.1.2 Hydrology<br /><br />
Sierra Leone possesses a tropical and humid climate, with clearly defined dry and rainy seasons.<br /><br />
Annual rainfall averages about 2 526 mm.year-1, ranging from 1 900 to more than 4 000 mm.year-1,<br /><br />
depending on proximity to the coast. Most of the rain falls between July and September.<br /><br />
The hydrology of Sierra Leone comprises a fairly dense network of rivers and streams, of which the<br /><br />
larger ones generally flow throughout the year. Groundwater contributes baseflow to larger rivers<br /><br />
during the dry season, while many of the smaller tributaries feeding these larger rivers cease to flow.<br /><br />
About 80 percent of the rural population obtains its water from surface water sources.<br /><br />
The country can be divided into twelve river basins, of which five are shared with Guinea and two with<br /><br />
Liberia. The most important ones, from west to east are: the Kolente (Great Scarcies), Kaba, Rokel<br /><br />
(also known as the Seli), Pampana (Jong), Sewa, Loa, and Mona. The river catchments in Sierra<br /><br />
Leone are relatively small, but because of heavy rainfall, produce large flows.<br /><br />
There are numerous valley swamps located in the headwaters of major rivers and their tributaries.<br /><br />
These flat bottomed valleys are drained by slow flowing streams and are normally swamped for more<br /><br />
than six months of the year. These areas are very important in rice and vegetable production. In<br /><br />
1999, Sierra Leone signed the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands with the only confirmed Ramsar site<br /><br />
being the Sierra Leone Freetown Estuary area.<br /><br />
Sierra Leone has two major dams, both built for hydroelectricity (Guma and Bumbuna). There is<br /><br />
considerable potential for the development of small-scale hydroelectric schemes that could also be<br /><br />
designed to accommodate irrigated agriculture.<br /><br />
The internal renewable surface water resource is estimated at 150 km3.year-1; seasonal variations are<br /><br />
very important, as only 11-17 percent of the annual discharge occurs between December and April<br /><br />
(dry season). Internally produced groundwater is estimated to be 50 km3.year-1 of which 40 km3.year-1<br /><br />
are considered to be overlap between surface water and groundwater.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Geology, Hydrogeology, Soils, Land Use & Ecosystems<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.2.1 Regional Geology<br /><br />
Sierra Leone is predominantly underlain by rocks of Precambrian age (older than 500 million years),<br /><br />
with a younger coastal strip approximately 50 km wide. This strip comprises of marine and estuarine<br /><br />
sediments of Tertiary and Quaternary to Recent age.<br /><br />
The Tertiary deposits are from the Bullom Group and occupy the higher ground, while younger<br /><br />
Quaternary and recent deposits occupy the low lying areas. The Bullom Group comprises interlayered<br /><br />
silts, sands, clays and occasional lignites. Onshore, the thickness of the Bullom Group is variable but<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 76<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
is known to be greater than 60 m, possibly reaching up to 120 m. The younger Quaternary deposits<br /><br />
comprise alluvium deposits (generally highly organic soft sandy clay).<br /><br />
The Precambrian rocks can be divided into two major units, the granite-greenstone complex and the<br /><br />
Kasila Group.<br /><br />
The granite-greenstone complex consists of a series of iron and magnesium rich rocks<br /><br />
metamorphosed to amphibolite facies (the Kambui Group, previously known as the Sula Group)<br /><br />
overlying the granitic basement. The grade of metamorphism in the basement generally increases<br /><br />
towards the Kambui Group boundary giving rise to local occurrences of granulites, known as the<br /><br />
Mano-Moa Formation (Birchall, et al., 1979).<br /><br />
The Kasila Group comprises a series of high grade basic granulites and amphibolites that developed<br /><br />
into a zone of shear deformation to form the southwest margin of the basement complex. During the<br /><br />
development of the Kasila Group, part of it was thrusted eastwards onto the basement complex<br /><br />
during an event known as the Rokelide Orogeny (c. 550Ma), giving rise to low grade schists,<br /><br />
metasediments, banded iron formation (BIF) and lavas of the Marampa Group.<br /><br />
The Rokel River Trough developed very late in the Precambrian and a series of sandy and clayey<br /><br />
sediments (quartzites, sandstones and marls) were deposited within this trough to form the Rokel<br /><br />
River Group. Periodic volcanic activity during this time gave rise to basic and intermediate lavas and<br /><br />
ashes (the Kasewe Hills Formation).<br /><br />
Two periods of igneous activity occurred during the break up of Gondwanaland in the early Mesozoic.<br /><br />
The earliest of these, associated with the initial stages of rifting resulted in the intrusion of the<br /><br />
Freetown Igneous Complex, a layered complex of gabbro, norite, troctolite and anorthosite located at<br /><br />
the peninsular of Freetown. Numerous dolerite sills and mainly east-west trending dykes were also<br /><br />
intruded during this time. The second period of activity was the intrusion of kimberlite dykes and pipes<br /><br />
(c. 90Ma) mainly in the eastern section of the country distant from the project area (Birchall, et al.,<br /><br />
1979).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.2.2 Hydrogeology<br /><br />
Limited investigation work have been undertaken to obtain information on the hydrogeology of Sierra<br /><br />
Leone. With a population largely reliant on surface water, groundwater has overall received less<br /><br />
attention.<br /><br />
According to a report published by the World Bank, the aquifers of the Bullom Series are considered<br /><br />
the most productive aquifers in the country (World Bank/UNDP, 1991). This is supported by the high<br /><br />
density occurrence of hand dug wells located within the elevated terraces of the coastal strip. Pump<br /><br />
tests conducted on the aquifer of the upper Bullom Series (top 40 m) at Pepel Port, found that water<br /><br />
from the aquifer could be pumped at a rate of 5 L.s-1 from a single 150 mm diameter well.<br /><br />
WorleyParsons have requested and are waiting for pump test data from GCS Ltd to assess aquifer<br /><br />
properties.<br /><br />
Sierra Leone is largely underlain by igneous and metamorphic rocks, which typically have very low<br /><br />
primary porosity (the porosity that results from the original formation of the rock). However, their<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
5.2.3 Soils<br /><br />
Sierra Leone has a total land area of approximately 7.2 million hectares, about 5.4 million of which is<br /><br />
cultivable. Of this, about 4.3 million hectares are low fertile arable upland and 1.1 million hectares are<br /><br />
of more fertile arable swamps. With nearly 80 percent of the labor force depending upon this land for<br /><br />
their agricultural subsistence activities (largely slash-and-burn, with rice cultivation making up the bulk<br /><br />
of the subsistence activity), the overall health of these lands will depend upon how well farmers are<br /><br />
able to maintain the soil, water, and living resources (US AID, 20007). The combined effects of poor<br /><br />
farming practices — shifting cultivation, recurrent bushfires and overgrazing, increasing population,<br /><br />
ensuing shortening of fallow periods of land — have all been identified as contributing factors to soil<br /><br />
erosion resulting in land degradation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.2.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Land Use<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Sierra Leone has a total land area of approximately 7.2 million hectares, about 5.4 million of which is<br /><br />
cultivable. Of this, about 4.3 million hectares are low fertile arable upland and 1.1 million hectares are<br /><br />
of more fertile arable swamps. With nearly 80 percent of the labor force depending upon this land for<br /><br />
their agricultural subsistence activities (largely slash-and-burn, with rice cultivation making up the bulk<br /><br />
of the subsistence activity), the overall health of these lands will depend upon how well farmers are<br /><br />
able to maintain the soil, water, and living resources (US AID, 2007). The combined effects of poor<br /><br />
farming practices — shifting cultivation, recurrent bushfires and overgrazing, increasing population,<br /><br />
ensuing shortening of fallow periods of land — have all been identified as contributing factors to soil<br /><br />
erosion resulting in land degradation.<br /><br />
Along the project areas, it is apparent that cultivation of land has been practiced for a number of<br /><br />
generations, due to evidence of extensive land working and land scars (slow recovery of cultivated<br /><br />
land). The local economy of the Districts affected by the project seems to be dominated by agriculture<br /><br />
with a traditional focus on rice.<br /><br />
Agriculture is generally subsistence in nature, and, according to other literature on the project affected<br /><br />
areas, poverty levels among the farmers are high, with 70 percent of the population falling below the<br /><br />
UN defined poverty line (Coastal & Environmental Services, 2009).<br /><br />
A wide range of food crops are grown under the shifting cultivation system; sorghum, millet, maize,<br /><br />
cassava, beniseed, groundnut and beans are the associated crops grown with rice. Farmers have<br /><br />
very rudimentary equipment and practices.<br /><br />
During the dry season farming is restricted to valley flood plains (SRK 2009), while hillslopes are also<br /><br />
used for cultivation in the rainy season. Cassava, plantain, sweet potato, cashew nut, ground nut and<br /><br />
sweet corn are all commonly observed growing across the project area and fruits including pineapple,<br /><br />
orange, papaya, banana and mango are also grown, mainly in the immediate vicinity of villages.<br /><br />
Mango seems to be the most important fruit tree, since trees are found in large numbers around all<br /><br />
<br /><br />

STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
villages along the project area. In the rainy season rice is a staple crop. Palm wine tapping is evident<br /><br />
everywhere and fishing is also common in rivers and streams.<br /><br />
At present, forest resources are subjected to increasing deforestation due to the rapidly growing<br /><br />
population and consequent demand for more agricultural land, urban requirement for timber and<br /><br />
fuelwood, mining for minerals, and recurrent bush fires. With population pressure and<br /><br />
commercialization today, the rate of exploitation has far outstripped the rate of regeneration by natural<br /><br />
means. The result is deforestation and an acute threat to biodiversity, observed everywhere along the<br /><br />
project areas.<br /><br />
According to a study completed in 2004, logging, firewood collection, and mining ranked as the top<br /><br />
three perceptions of the actions most responsible for land degradation (US AID, 2007).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.2.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ecology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Sierra Leone is divided into four major biogeographic regions: the coastal lowlands, the interior plains,<br /><br />
the interior plateau and scattered mountains and hills. The coastal lowlands occupy the south-western<br /><br />
third of the country and do not rise above 75 m above sea level (masl). They are interrupted by<br /><br />
inselbergs and merge into the interior plains, which reach 200 masl in the east and cover 43 percent<br /><br />
of the country’s land surface. The interior plains end in an abrupt escarpment which runs from northwest to south-east and marks the start of the eastern interior plateau (at 300–600 masl), which covers<br /><br />
22 percent of the country. Two massifs top the plateau: the Sankan Biriwa–Tingi Hills (1,709 masl)<br /><br />
and Mount Bintumani (1,945 masl). The latter is the highest peak in West Africa to the west of Mount<br /><br />
Cameroon. Ten major rivers flow roughly parallel in a southwesterly direction across the country to<br /><br />
estuaries and bays on the coast.<br /><br />
Two major biomes characterize the country’s vegetation; the Sudan–Guinea Savanna and the<br /><br />
Guinea–Congo Forests. The Sudan–Guinea Savanna biome occurs in the north and includes<br /><br />
grassland, savanna woodland and Lophira-dominated tree-savanna. A large area of forest-savanna<br /><br />
mosaic stretches over parts of the north and north-east and forms a zone of transition between the<br /><br />
savanna and forest biomes. The Guinea–Congo Forests biome occupies much of the north-east and<br /><br />
south-east. The vegetation typical of this zone is moist evergreen lowland forest with Afromontane<br /><br />
elements at higher altitudes. Local climatic conditions and human activities have, however,<br /><br />
particularly modified the climax forest vegetation in various parts of the country so that large areas are<br /><br />
now covered by secondary regrowth.<br /><br />
Ecoregions<br /><br />
Three ecoregions, as described by the World Wildlife Fund, fall within the project area.<br /><br />
On the coast, where the Pepel Port is to be developed, the Guinean Mangroves, an ecoregion that<br /><br />
stretches from Senegal to Ivory Coast, occur. These mangroves are influenced by a large tidal range<br /><br />
and high inputs of freshwater. The mangroves in this ecoregion contain stands that are more than 25<br /><br />
m in height and extend as far as 160 km inland. As the best developed mangroves in western Africa,<br /><br />
this ecoregion provides important habitat for migratory birds and endangered species such as the<br /><br />
West African manatee and the pygmy hippopotamus. The West African mangroves are relatively<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 79<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
species poor containing five tree species, compared, for example, to the East African mangroves,<br /><br />
which host up to nine mangrove tree species.<br /><br />
The Guinean forest-savanna mosaic extends through the central part of the project area, which<br /><br />
mainly corresponds to the transport corridor to be used for haul road and railway development. This<br /><br />
ecoregion of West Africa consists of a band of interlaced forest, savanna, and grassland running east<br /><br />
to west and dividing the tropical moist forests near the coast from the West Sudanian savanna of the<br /><br />
interior. Constantly occurring fires keep back the growth of trees in open country. A typical species of<br /><br />
this ecoregion, Lophira laceolata, is a tree that is more resistant to fire. This species is widely<br /><br />
distributed along the project area. The interlacing forest, savanna and grassland habitats are highly<br /><br />
dynamic, and the proportion of forest versus other habitat components has varied greatly over time.<br /><br />
Savannah vegetation covers 35 percent of Sierra Leone and includes forest savannah, mixed tree<br /><br />
savannah and grassland savannah. This ecoregion is known to support large mammals such as<br /><br />
elephant, leopards, hyenas, chimpanzees, baboons and monkeys, although their densities along the<br /><br />
project area are likely to be very low to non-existent.<br /><br />
On the eastern part of the project, on the Sula Mountains, the Guinean Montane Forest ecoregion is<br /><br />
present. This ecoregion consists of high altitude peaks and plateaus that spread across four countries<br /><br />
in the Upper Guinean region of West Africa. The broad range of elevation, coupled with the<br /><br />
underlying geology and anthropogenic activities, have given rise to different plant associations on<br /><br />
several of the mountains. Although details of the number of endemic plants are not fully compiled, 35<br /><br />
plant species are known to be strictly endemic, with several mountains containing their own unique<br /><br />
plant species. Floristic diversity results from a combination of geographic isolation, varied topography<br /><br />
and soils, migration, speciation, climatic factors and anthropogenic activities. Studies of the Loma<br /><br />
Mountains have produced considerable information about the flora, with records for 1,576 species<br /><br />
distributed in 757 genera and 135 families. The fauna is also diverse with close to 15 strictly endemic<br /><br />
vertebrate species, including species found on single mountains. A number of other rare forest<br /><br />
mammals may also occur marginally in the mountains of this ecoregion, including Johnson’s genet<br /><br />
(Genetta johnstoni, DD) and a murid rat (Praomys rostratus). The western chimpanzee (Pan<br /><br />
troglodytes verus, EN) also occurs in this ecoregion, with high densities reported from Mt Loma. The<br /><br />
largest predator in the ecoregion is the leopard (Panthera pardus, EN). Avifaunal diversity is also<br /><br />
high, and a number of rare species occur (Collar and Stuart 1988), including two near-endemic<br /><br />
species, the Sierra Leone prinia (Prinia leontica, VU) and the iris glossy-starling (Coccycolius iris).<br /><br />
The ecoregion is also of importance for endemic amphibians. More than 10 species are believed to<br /><br />
be strictly endemic (WWF database), including Nimbaphrynoides occidentalis, an endemic toad<br /><br />
occurring in savannas on Mount Nimba (Curry-Lindahl 1966 in WWF). In terms of reptiles, the area is<br /><br />
of lower importance, with less than five species of near-endemic reptile being recorded. Several new<br /><br />
species of insects in the family Coleoptera have been reported for both the Loma and the Nimba<br /><br />
Mountains (Villiers 1965 in WWF). It is very likely that all the mountains of this ecoregion contain<br /><br />
single-site endemic invertebrates, although the data are not compiled to prove this.Mining, slash-andburn farming, and man-made fires are the major threats of this ecoregion. Grassland wildfires are<br /><br />
largely human caused, but natural fires due to lightning strikes also occur (Morton 1986 in WWF).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
