<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Current status<br /><br />
Although once a predominant ecosystem in Sierra Leone, the forest now covers only 5 percent of the<br /><br />
land area and consists of evergreen and semi deciduous vegetation. Sierra Leone is one of the most<br /><br />
heavily deforested countries in the region (Barrie, 2002 in Walston, Hayes and Wolstencroft, 2010). A<br /><br />
study of vegetation-cover showed about 5 percent of the country (c. 350,000 ha) to be covered by<br /><br />
closed canopy evergreen forest, occurring mostly in the south-east, 3.6 percent (c. 250,000 ha) by<br /><br />
secondary forest and about 52 percent (c. 3,700,000 ha) by forest regrowth and bush fallow.<br /><br />
Distinctive fringing vegetation and gallery forests occur along the main riverbanks, while coastal<br /><br />
mangroves cover some 286,600 ha (Davies and Palmer, 1989 in Walston, Hayes and Wolstencroft,<br /><br />
2010). It is worth noting that the whole of Sierra Leone below about 09o15’ North was covered with<br /><br />
largely closed canopy forest 20-40m tall with lianas and epiphytes, but little ground cover or grass<br /><br />
(Grubb et al., 1998 in Walston, Hayes and Wolstencroft, 2010).<br /><br />
Moist closed evergreen lowland forests once covered the inland plains of Sierra Leone and across the<br /><br />
mine site though it would have included areas of moist semi-deciduous forest as well, especially in<br /><br />
the medium-altitude areas such as the Tama-Tonkolili Forest Reserve (Grubb et al., 1998 in Walston,<br /><br />
Hayes and Wolstencroft, 2010). However, farmbush, grasslands and scrub now predominate in the<br /><br />
region.<br /><br />
Lowland and submontane forest throughout West Africa has been impacted by development,<br /><br />
resulting in large and potentially threatening declines in the range of many species unique to this<br /><br />
region. The Tonkolili region is no exception, where forest, the natural climax vegetation of most of the<br /><br />
region, is now largely restricted to narrow strips along river valleys and on the steepest slopes, and<br /><br />
sacred groves and community forests (Darbyshire and van der Burgt, 2009).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Marine<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.3.1 Physical Environment<br /><br />
The Sierra Leone coastline is over 500 km long and includes a number of estuaries and islands<br /><br />
including Banana, Turtle and Sherbro islands. Generally the nearshore profile is relatively steep.<br /><br />
Where the Freetown estuary is located, however it is relatively shallow and rather irregular (Anthonie,<br /><br />
1991).<br /><br />
The Sierra Leone river estuary is a sheltered marine basin receiving waters from several tributaries,<br /><br />
including the Rokel, Seli and Bunce rivers and the Kumrabe Creek (FAO, 1986 and Ramsar, 1999).<br /><br />
The flow of freshwater from these rivers strongly influences the hydrographic conditions of the estuary<br /><br />
as demonstrated by the range of salinity recorded. This reaches a maximum during the wet season<br /><br />
when there is a measurable influence of freshwater extending to the continental shelf (FAO, 1986).<br /><br />
The estuary is bounded to the north and south by a lowland coastal plain, indented by creeks. The<br /><br />
Western Area Peninsular (WAP) (Freetown mountain) rises in the south. At its entrance into the<br /><br />
Atlantic Ocean, the estuary widens to about 11 km and suddenly deepens at its southern shore to<br /><br />
form a natural harbour, the third largest in the world (Ramsar, 1999).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 81<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During the dry season from November to April, currents inside Freetown Estuary are primarily<br /><br />
governed by astronomical tides. Conversely, during the rainy season estuarine circulation is strongly<br /><br />
controlled by the enhanced river run-off currents (Lorax, 2009). The regions tides are semi-diurnal<br /><br />
and tidal range is variable depending on location in the estuary; the maximum tidal range at Freetown<br /><br />
is 2.5m, whilst within the estuary the range is greater at 3 to 4.5m. The highest currents occur in the<br /><br />
entrance to the estuary due to constriction of the flow around the sand banks to the north of the<br /><br />
estuary entrance.<br /><br />
Coastal processes along the Sierra Leone coast are driven by wave energy and tidal currents. The<br /><br />
regional wave climate consists of two long period swells (period = 7 – 16s) and locally generated wind<br /><br />
waves (period < 5s) from the northwest. Wave energy is low to moderate with deep-water heights of<br /><br />
less than 1.2 m occurring for 72 percent of the time. However, between June and October, moderate<br /><br />
to high energy waves (1.5 – 4m) from the south are superimposed on the north-westerly waves<br /><br />
(Anthonie, 1991).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.3.2 Water and Sediment Quality<br /><br />
Other than at Pepel and Freetown, the lack of industry on the shores of the estuary should mean that<br /><br />
the estuarine waters are free of industrial contamination. However, the deficiency of appropriate<br /><br />
sanitary systems in the coastal and river communities may have led to bacterial contamination and<br /><br />
high nutrient concentrations nearshore, although there is no evidence in the water quality data<br /><br />
collected so far. Strong tides and high run-off volumes result in high turbidity levels in the water<br /><br />
column throughout the estuary.<br /><br />
Basic water quality parameters have been measured over a period of approximately two months<br /><br />
throughout the estuary and further offshore, including the Pepel Port site. Preliminary results,<br /><br />
covering 21 sites and 29 profiles taken between 16 February and 12 March 2010, show that the water<br /><br />
column appeared to be well mixed at most sites with little or no variation in temperature, salinity, pH<br /><br />
or DO with depth. Turbidity generally increased with depth.<br /><br />
Similarly, little information is available regarding the estuary’s sediment quality. Estuarine sediment is<br /><br />
a series of sands, clays and gravels with occasional thin beds of argillaceous limestone, calcareous<br /><br />
grit and additional seems of lignite (Tucker, 1973). As for water contamination of sediment is not<br /><br />
expected and has not been indicated by preliminary sample results that have been collected so far<br /><br />
around Tagrin and in the proposed dredge channel. The only exception to this is in the inter-tidal area<br /><br />
at Pepel Port, where there is evidence of iron ore contamination of estuary / seabed sediments due to<br /><br />
previous port operations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.3.3 Coastal and Marine Habitats<br /><br />
Along the northern shelf from Sherbro Island in Sierra Leone to the southern border of Guinea, the<br /><br />
coastline is characterized by extensive mangrove forests, sandy beaches, mudflats and isolated<br /><br />
areas of rocky outcrops (Fisheries and Aquaculture Department, 2010). These habitats serve as<br /><br />
important shelter, feeding and nesting grounds for fish, birds and marine mammals. The northern<br /><br />
stretch of coast, including the Sierra Leone estuary, is influenced by the Canary current, and is the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 82<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
most productive zone, with demersal, pelagic and shellfish resources (Fisheries and Aquaculture<br /><br />
Department, 2010).<br /><br />
In addition to providing a highly valuable habitat for marine and terrestrial fauna, mangrove forest also<br /><br />
plays a crucial role in coastal protection and reducing erosion from run-off and coastal processes.<br /><br />
Locally, the mangroves have an important socio-economic role as a source of wood for<br /><br />
firewood/charcoal and as a medium upon which shellfish anchor which provides an important food<br /><br />
and nutrition source.<br /><br />
The mangroves of Sierra Leone occupy almost half of the country’s coastline and cover a total area of<br /><br />
approximately 100,000 ha (FAO, 2007). Mangrove is concentrated in four major areas, one of which<br /><br />
is the Sierra Leone river estuary. As is the case throughout the world, the mangrove forests in Sierra<br /><br />
Leone have been heavily exploited due to rapid population increase and high levels of poverty. It is<br /><br />
estimated that nearly 40 percent of Sierra Leone’s mangroves were cleared between 1980 and 2000.<br /><br />
The high demand for the land and wood coupled with the lack of community participation in the<br /><br />
management of mangrove resources has created a de facto open-access regime. This has resulted in<br /><br />
mangrove cover that consists mainly of low re-growth with few larger trees, especially in the area<br /><br />
around Freetown.<br /><br />
The Freetown shoreline consists of a rocky foreshore, from the upper inter-tidal zone to deeper<br /><br />
subtidal areas offshore. There is an area of rocky habitat in the deeper waters between offshore<br /><br />
Freetown and offshore Murraytown, close to the main shipping channel. This habitat supports a<br /><br />
diverse community of soft corals, hydrozoans, acsidians and sponges. There are no true coral reefs<br /><br />
along the coast mainly due to the intrusion of the cool waters of the Benguela and Canary currents<br /><br />
and the high turbidity of the estuary waters (Ukwe et al. 2006). There are a number of ship wrecks<br /><br />
along the western coastline of Sierra Leone, which act as artificial reef and provide important habitats<br /><br />
for marine species such as soft corals and sponges. There is also reef habitat in shallow areas of<br /><br />
exposed rock.<br /><br />
Seagrasses are important habitat areas that provide transition ecosytems and can be influential as<br /><br />
marine spawning grounds. However, potential seagrass habitats in the estuary mouth were surveyed<br /><br />
and none was found.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.3.4 Marine fauna<br /><br />
With its high rainfall, Sierra Leone has an extensive system of rivers and swamps. A variety of<br /><br />
mammals, birds and reptiles are found in the water, on rocks and sandy beaches or along the riparian<br /><br />
zone. Rivers that periodically flood and dry have a variety of migratory bird species that nest on the<br /><br />
exposed rocks, sandbanks and mudflats (USAID, 2007).<br /><br />
The Sierra Leone River Estuary is afforded some notoriety for its avifaunal abundance and is<br /><br />
therefore designated as a Ramsar site, under the Convention on Wetlands of International<br /><br />
Importance (the Ramsar convention), to which Sierra Leone is a signatory.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 83<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Turtles are believed to inhabit the coastal waters in and around the estuary mouth1. Five marine turtle<br /><br />
species nest on beaches in Sierra Leone; green turtles, olive ridley, loggerhead, leatherback and<br /><br />
hawksbill. The primary nesting beaches are around the Sherbro and Turtle islands (IUCN, 2010),<br /><br />
which are a significant distance from the project site. Beaches to the north-west of Tagrin point<br /><br />
provide potential turtle nesting sites. However, an initial survey suggests that human presence<br /><br />
already deters the turtles from using these beaches. Therefore, it is believed that the turtles may use<br /><br />
the estuary for foraging and the offshore area as a migration route.<br /><br />
Scientific reports concerning marine mammals’ population dynamics are lacking for Sierra Leone;<br /><br />
however, small cetaceans are sighted frequently in the waters at the mouth of the estuary near<br /><br />
Freetown according to local specialists and observations from marine users2. Marine Mammals<br /><br />
known to inhabit the coastal and estuarine waters of Sierra Leone include cetaceans (for example<br /><br />
Humpback whale, common dolphins and Clymene dolphin) and the sirenean (African manatee). The<br /><br />
threatened humpback dolphin may be present in the mouth of the estuary. However, as it inhabits the<br /><br />
nearshore zone where there is much human activity, it may no longer be present in this area. The<br /><br />
African manatee is believed to inhabit smaller waterways up river, avoiding brackish water and human<br /><br />
presence.<br /><br />
Sierra Leone has abundant fish resources and as a result supports widespread fishing activity<br /><br />
throughout its coastal and inland waters; contributing almost 10 percent of GDP (FAO 2008). This<br /><br />
activity can be broadly classified into three sub-sectors:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Highly mechanized and capitalized industrial fishery,<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Developing aquaculture and inland fisheries; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Low technology but widespread artisanal fishery, which makes up the majority of the fishing in<br /><br />
and around the estuary.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Recent interviews with fishermen in March 2010 operating out of Tagrin confirm that Bonga<br /><br />
(Ethmalosa spp) is the primary fish species for local fishermen within the waters around Tagrin and<br /><br />
Pepel and are available for capture there throughout the year. In addition the ‘Spanish’ (Sphyraena<br /><br />
barracuda) is a prized fish caught offshore in the dry season. The surveys also found that fish known<br /><br />
locally as kutar, snapper, shinenose, bonita fish (March – May), shovelnose, longneck and grab were<br /><br />
landed, with most of these other species taken west of Tagrin Point and outside of the estuary.<br /><br />
Sierra Leone has 23 bird species with global conservation status, including the White-necked<br /><br />
Picathartes, Lesser Flamingo, Damara Tern, Lesser-crested Tern, Avocet, Water Dikkop, Greater<br /><br />
Flamingo, Northern Shoveler Terek Sandpiper, Curvew sandpiper, Great snipe and Rose-ringed<br /><br />
Parakeet. The Sierra Leone river estuary is regarded as one of the four most important sites for<br /><br />
Palaearctic migrants birds in the country as the mud/sand foreshore, intertidal mud and muddy sand<br /><br />
habitats provide the appropriate feeding grounds for most waders and other waterbirds; the estuary is<br /><br />
not only a feeding area but also a roosting area for most waterbirds in the country. A short survey was<br /><br />

<br /><br />
5.3.5 Protected Areas<br /><br />
The Sierra Leone river estuary was designated a Wetland of International Importance under the<br /><br />
Ramsar convention in 1999. To improve the sustainable management of the Ramsar Site (including<br /><br />
the livelihood promotion at the local community level), the Sierra Leone Ramsar Administrative<br /><br />
Authority proposed the establishment of a Marine Protected Areas as a priority for implementation<br /><br />
(Ramsar, 2008).<br /><br />
The link between functional mangrove ecosystems and associated marine/estuarine ecosystem<br /><br />
health and fisheries production was a primary consideration in establishment of the Sierra Leone<br /><br />
River Estuary Ramsar site.<br /><br />
Pepel Island falls within one of the core areas of the Sierra Leone River Estuary Ramsar site (see<br /><br />
Figure 5-1).<br /><br />

5.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Population & Demographics<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Sierra Leone is one of the world’s poorest countries. Decades of economic decline and about ten<br /><br />
years of civil war have had severe consequences on the economy. Poverty is widespread with more<br /><br />
than 70 percent of the population living below the poverty line. The country ranks last in the Human<br /><br />
Development Index. Despite some economic recovery after the end of armed conflict in 2002, the<br /><br />
country is still considered a fragile state as it faces the challenges of poverty, corruption and<br /><br />
economic mismanagement.<br /><br />
The Republic of Sierra Leone is composed of three provinces: the Northern Province, Southern<br /><br />
province and the Eastern province and one other region called the Western Area.<br /><br />
Sierra Leone has a population of about 6 million comprising of over 20 ethnic groups. The Temne in<br /><br />
the north and the Mende in the South are the largest with each group representing around 30 percent<br /><br />
of the total population. Creole, descendants of freed Jamaican slaves who were settled in the<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />

<br /><br />

Liberia’s civil war also reside in the country as well as small numbers of Europeans, Lebanese,<br /><br />
Pakistanis and Indians. Muslim is the dominant religion in Sierra Leone followed by indigenous beliefs<br /><br />
systems and Christianity.<br /><br />
The official language of Sierra Leone is English, however regular use is limited to the literate majority,<br /><br />
and native languages of Mende (principal vernacular in the south) and Temne (principal vernacular in<br /><br />
the north) are widely spoken. The Krio language (English-base Creole) and Bengali are also spoken.<br /><br />
The literacy rate (defined as aged 15 and over who can read and write English, Mende, Temne, or<br /><br />
Arabic) is 31.4 percent.<br /><br />
Annual population growth rate is 2.6 percent. The life expectancy is 37 years. The infant mortality rate<br /><br />
is 170/1000 live births, and the under 5 mortality rate is 286/1000. In 2009 the male to female ratio<br /><br />
was around 0.93. About 70 percent of the population is rural and the annual rate of urbanization is<br /><br />
estimated to be around 2.9 percent between 2005 and 2010.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.4.1 Health Status Summary<br /><br />
A desktop literature review was performed to provide a brief summary of the existing health status in<br /><br />
Sierra Leone, with focus on the Northern Province and project-influenced districts where possible.<br /><br />
The desktop study was carried out in the first quarter of 2010 and involves review of available<br /><br />
literature using internet sources.<br /><br />
In 2007, Sierra Leone ranked as the least developed country in the world (WHO 2009), with an<br /><br />
estimated 53 percent of people living below the international poverty line of US$1.25 per day in 2005<br /><br />
(UNICEF 2008). The country suffered great upheaval during the period of civil war (1991-2002) with<br /><br />
injury, death and displacement amongst the population. There were also consequences for many<br /><br />
areas of Sierra Leonean infrastructure, including the healthcare system. All levels of the system were<br /><br />
affected with displacement of health care professionals and destruction of basic health infrastructure<br /><br />
(WHO 2009).<br /><br />
Health Policy and Initiatives<br /><br />
Various health initiatives, both national, and internationally aided are in progress in Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
Many of these are aimed at tackling the priority health issues. The Sierra Leone National Health<br /><br />
Policy from the Ministry of Health and Sanitation (MoHS) (2002) cites the following as the current<br /><br />
national priority health problems:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Malaria;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Sexually Transmitted Infections (including HIV/AIDS);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Tuberculosis;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Unsatisfactory reproductive health including maternal and neonatal mortality;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Acute respiratory infections;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Childhood immunisable diseases;<br /><br />
<br /><br />

The WHO develops country cooperation strategies for a number of countries as a means of<br /><br />
intensifying its interventions within those countries. The current WHO Country Cooperation Strategy<br /><br />
for Sierra Leone 2008-2012 (WHO 2009) cites four strategic priorities:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reduction of the burden of communicable and non-communicable disease with particular focus<br /><br />
on the prevention and control of malaria, reducing HIV/AIDS and tuberculosis and enhancing the<br /><br />
national vaccination programmes to prevent and control vaccine-preventable diseases;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />

Lowering rates of infant, child and maternal mortality and morbidity along with encouragement of<br /><br />

<br /><br />

Improving access to and quality of health services; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
National health development through cooperation and partnerships.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Life Expectancy<br /><br />
As a nation, the Sierra Leonean life expectancy at birth is currently estimated by WHO at 49.4 years<br /><br />
(WHO 2009); however, in the past decade estimates have been as low as 37 years (WHO 2006). In<br /><br />
2004, the life expectancy in the Tonkolili district was estimated at 47.9 (47.3 for males and 48.6 for<br /><br />
females), slightly below the national estimate and below the average for the Northern Province as a<br /><br />
whole (49.8) (SSL 2004). Life expectancies in Port Loko and Bombali districts were slightly higher<br /><br />
than Tonkolili at 49.0 (males 48.1; females 50.0) and 52.5 (males 51.6; females 53.5) respectively<br /><br />
(SSL 2004). WHO report that the low Sierra Leonean life expectancies are due to the levels of<br /><br />
communicable and non-communicable disease as well as child and maternal mortality rates (WHO<br /><br />
2009). They cite the underlying causes as widespread poverty, limited access to safe drinking water,<br /><br />
poor sanitation, high levels of illiteracy (particularly amongst females), overcrowded living conditions,<br /><br />
poor feeding and hygiene practices and inadequate access to good quality healthcare services (WHO<br /><br />
2009).<br /><br />
Women, Children and Childbirth<br /><br />
At 6.3 per woman, Sierra Leone has one of the highest fertility rates in the world (WHO 2009).<br /><br />
However, maternal mortality rates also rank amongst the highest, with an estimated 2,100 maternal<br /><br />
deaths per 100,000 live births (UNICEF 2008). Contraceptive prevalence is low (5 percent) and<br /><br />
access to good quality care during and after childbirth is lacking, with only 43 percent of births<br /><br />
attended by a skilled professional (UNICEF 2008). In surveys of attitudes toward domestic violence, it<br /><br />
was reported that 85 percent of the population believe a husband to be justified in hitting his wife for<br /><br />
reasons such as burning food, arguing back, or going out without telling him (UNICEF 2008). Female<br /><br />
genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C), a practice carried out for social reasons which affects the health<br /><br />
and well-being of both women and their babies, is extremely common in Sierra Leone. An estimated<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
94 percent of women overall are affected, although rates in rural communities reach 97 percent<br /><br />
(UNICEF 2008).<br /><br />
In general, child health in Sierra Leone is poor. At close to 30 percent, the under-five child mortality<br /><br />
rate is the highest in the world with neonatal deaths representing 20 percent of the total under-five<br /><br />
mortality (WHO 2009). In the Northern Province of Sierra Leone, in which the project is to take place,<br /><br />
infant, child and under-five mortality rates are slightly below the national average (SSL 2004). Malaria,<br /><br />
diarrhoea and pneumonia are the three principal causes of child death, with malnutrition as a<br /><br />
common contributory factor. In 2007 it was estimated that 4,000 children (0-14 years) were living with<br /><br />
HIV in Sierra Leone (UNICEF). Child labour is prevalent; data gathered between 1999 and 2007<br /><br />
estimates that it affects 48 percent of children aged 5 to 14 years (UNICEF 2008). The target for<br /><br />
immunizations in Sierra Leone is 90 percent and some headway has been made in curbing diseases<br /><br />
such as measles (WHO 2009).<br /><br />
Malaria<br /><br />
Malaria is widespread and transmitted year-round in Sierra Leone (WHO 2004). During the past<br /><br />
decade, prevalence of malaria in the general population has at times been greater than 50 percent<br /><br />
(WHO 2009). It is the number one cause of infant mortality and accounts for a large proportion of<br /><br />
outpatient consultations (35 percent) (WHO 2004). In children under five years, malaria was<br /><br />
responsible for between 50-60 percent of all admissions (WHO 2009). Malaria also accounts for 70<br /><br />
percent of the anaemia reported in pregnant women (WHO 2009). Governmental malaria control<br /><br />
programmes and funding are in place, and a joint MoHS/WHO program for the control of malaria was<br /><br />
initiated in 2004. The malaria programs aim to achieve better case management, vector control,<br /><br />
prevention of malaria-in-pregnancy and health promotion but face challenges including changes in<br /><br />
environmental conditions and sales of counterfeit malarial drugs (WHO 2009).<br /><br />
HIV / AIDS<br /><br />
HIV / AIDS is increasing in Sierra Leone, with higher rates in urban areas (2.1 percent) than rural<br /><br />
areas (1.3 percent) (WHO 2009). HIV and AIDS impacts not only those infected, but can also have<br /><br />
knock-on effects in a society. For example, in 2007, an estimated 16,000 children (0-17) had been<br /><br />
orphaned as a result of AIDS, and school attendance amongst that group was almost 20 percent<br /><br />
lower than the general population (UNICEF 2008). Data gathered between 2000 and 2007 suggests<br /><br />
that the level of public understanding about the cause and prevention of AIDS is low; for example only<br /><br />
17 percent of young women (15-24 years old) had comprehensive knowledge of HIV (UNICEF 2008).<br /><br />
Of note is the fact that the prevalence of HIV and AIDS amongst those with tertiary education is three<br /><br />
times greater than those with no education (WHO 2009). In 2007, the Sierra Leone government<br /><br />
introduced the Prevention and Control of HIV and AIDS Act, 2007 covering areas including education<br /><br />
and information, safe practices, testing and access to healthcare, transmission, monitoring and<br /><br />
discrimination.<br /><br />
Other Communicable Disease<br /><br />
Other communicable disease of note in Sierra Leone currently include tuberculosis, leprosy,<br /><br />
neglected tropical diseases (soil transmitted helminthes, onchocerciasis [river blindness] and<br /><br />
lymphatic filariasis, dracunculiasis [guinea worm disease], yaws and schistosomiasis), lassa fever,<br /><br />

<br /><br />
yellow fever and diarrhoeal diseases (WHO 2009). Population movement counts amongst the risk<br /><br />
factors for increased transmission for a good number of these diseases (WHO 2004).<br /><br />
The burden of tuberculosis in Sierra Leone is increasing. Between 2004 and 2007, the number of<br /><br />
registered cases almost doubled, despite a poor case-detection rate of 50 percent (WHO 2009). Also<br /><br />
of concern is the rise in multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) and prevalence of TB/HIV coinfection. A tuberculosis control program is in place in Sierra Leone; however it faces challenges<br /><br />
related to high default rates, low case-detection rates and the high percentage of patients without<br /><br />
sputum results (WHO 2009).<br /><br />
Onchocerciasis or ‘river blindness’ is a vector-borne disease which has a high infection intensity and<br /><br />
high resultant blindness rate in some parts of northern Sierra Leone. Risk factors for increased risk of<br /><br />
exposure to the infectious agent (Onchocerca volvulus, a filarial worm) include subsistence farming<br /><br />
fishing, bathing and mining (some areas) (WHO 2004).<br /><br />
Yaws disease was effectively eradicated prior to the war, but a recent re-emergence has created the<br /><br />
need for public health intervention (WHO 2009). In the past, this disease has been a problem in<br /><br />
remote communities of Bombali and Port Loko (WHO 2004), and there are currently plans for a yaws<br /><br />
survey in the endemic Bombali region. The survey will be a joint initiative between the Sierra Leone<br /><br />
Ministry of Health and Sanitation (MoHS) and WHO (WHO 2009). Portions of the proposed Phase 1<br /><br />
project are expected to operate in both the Bombali and Port Loko districts.<br /><br />
WHO rate the scale of infection with intestinal helminthiasis in Sierra Leone as ‘enormous’. These<br /><br />
worms cause reduction in vigour, illness, impaired intellectual development and reduced quality of life.<br /><br />
Programs are underway in Sierra Leone to map and better understand the types of soil transmitted<br /><br />
helminthes in the districts (WHO 2009).<br /><br />
Yellow fever has a WHO alert threshold of one case. In 2003 there were 4 confirmed cases in<br /><br />
Tonkolili (WHO 2004).<br /><br />
Schistosomiasis is a public health concern and emerging disease in six districts within Sierra Leone,<br /><br />
one of which is Tonkolili (WHO 2009).<br /><br />
Non-Communicable Diseases<br /><br />
There is a heavy burden of non-communicable disease including malnutrition, mental health issues<br /><br />
and substance abuse, disability and injury in Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
Malnutrition is common, especially amongst women and children. It has many direct health effects<br /><br />
and can also act as a contributory factor, increasing the severity of other diseases. In pregnant<br /><br />
women, maternal malnutrition leads to low birth weight, a causative factor in neonatal death (UNICEF<br /><br />
2008). In Sierra Leone, approximately 25 percent of children are born with a low birth weight, and up<br /><br />
to 30 percent of under fives suffer from moderate to severe underweight (UNICEF 2008).<br /><br />
Substance abuse is a significant problem in Sierra Leone, and the facilities to deal with mental health<br /><br />
issues are lacking (WHO 2009). Surveys suggest that a large proportion of the population use<br /><br />
alcohol, tobacco and drugs (e.g. cannabis, cocaine and heroine) (WHO 2009). A draft mental health<br /><br />
policy has been drawn up; however, the availability of resources to implement it remains a challenge.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

The major causes of disability in Sierra Leone are illness, congenital abnormalities, aging, accidents<br /><br />
(including traffic), and war (SSL 2004). Following the civil war, a sizable number of people live with<br /><br />
amputations (WHO 2009). In 2004, 2.2 percent of people in the Northern Province were classified as<br /><br />
disabled and 6 percent of these had war-related disabilities (SSL 2004). The prevalence of warrelated disability is lowest in the Northern Province of Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
Environmental Health<br /><br />
Environmental health and the provision of safe drinking water are important issues in Sierra Leone. At<br /><br />
present, overall, approximately 46 percent of households drink water from unimproved sources, a<br /><br />
number which rises to 68 percent in rural communities (UNICEF 2008, WHO 2009). Only 30.5 percent<br /><br />
of households dispose of excreta by sanitary means and wastewater is rarely treated before release<br /><br />
(WHO 2009). All of these factors increase the burden of water-borne and diarrheal disease and<br /><br />
impact general health.<br /><br />

6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
PROJECT AREA BASELINE<br /><br />
Baseline Study Techniques<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Conducting baseline studies is an iterative process that builds on data already collected and leads to<br /><br />
more targeted and specific information. The aim is to gain an understanding of the existing conditions<br /><br />
in the project area to enables a good understanding of the sensitivity and function of the environment<br /><br />
prior to the project commencing. For consistency across this project we have standardised the<br /><br />
terminology for the baseline study phases as follows:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Phase 1a: Desktop review and planning for the studies to collate relevant information, review<br /><br />
legislation, identify specialists and prepare a base map for further work;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Phase 1b: Undertake reconnaissance-level field studies to ground-truth the base map<br /><br />
produced, identify habitats of potential conservation importance and to record significant<br /><br />
ecological features in the study area. This phase is termed the Rapid Assessment<br /><br />
Programme (RAP);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Phase 2a: Scoping consultations with key stakeholders and the general public to understand<br /><br />
key biodiversity issues related to local livelihoods and cultural significance;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Phase 2b: Specialist investigations to collect detailed baseline data on species and habitats<br /><br />
within the project area for all relevant seasons;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Phase 3a: detailed targeted study (content driven), and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Phase 3b: detailed in-fill study (coverage driven).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This terminology has been used in each of the following thematic disciplines: air and noise, hydrology,<br /><br />
soil and landscape, ecology, social and community and marine for all the relevant project areas.<br /><br />
All the thematic disciplines, to varying levels of detail depending on sensitivity have been applied to<br /><br />
produce a baseline for each of the project elements i.e. the mine area, the transport corridor, the port<br /><br />
area and the marine and coastal zone.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mining Area<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.2.1 Air Quality<br /><br />
A desktop study was conducted that included a review of the available information for the study area<br /><br />
(Phase 1a) and a monitoring campaign was designed (Phase 1b) to assess the background air quality<br /><br />
levels in the study area. The campaign was carried out in February 2010.<br /><br />
Ambient air measurements were conducted with passive sampling monitoring devices (diffusion tubes<br /><br />
installed in the field for a period of 15 days), after which the devices were collected and sent to the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 92<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
laboratory for analysis. Diffusion tubes were obtained from Scientifics Laboratory in the UK. The<br /><br />
contaminants monitored were nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and sulphur dioxide (SO2).<br /><br />
The sampling scenario covered 13 positions for the air quality measurements divided between the<br /><br />
mine site, the port site and the transport corridor. The distribution of the sampling locations is shown<br /><br />
in Figure 6-1.<br /><br />
Figure 6-1 Air Quality Monitoring Campaign Measurement Locations<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Results obtained from the monitoring campaign were analyzed and compared with relevant<br /><br />
guidelines.<br /><br />
Relevant international standards for environmental air quality include those published by the World<br /><br />
Bank Group (WBG) in the WBG Environmental, Health, and Safety Guidelines (known as the “EHS<br /><br />
Guidelines”), which are used by the WBG and the International Finance Corporation (IFC), as<br /><br />
described in the Pollution Prevention and Abatement Handbook (PPAH) (World Bank Group, IFC,<br /><br />
2007). Ambient air measurements were conducted during a period of 15 days; therefore, results are<br /><br />
not directly comparable with the periods given by legislation. When possible, the larger period (1 year)<br /><br />
with a more restrictive limit has been considered.<br /><br />
Existing air quality at the proposed mining area is expected to be very good, because the area is a<br /><br />
Greenfield site without existing industrial development or crowded populations. Dust is considered to<br /><br />
be the primary air pollutant, generated from vehicle movements on unpaved roads and off-road.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

6.2.2 Noise<br /><br />
A desktop study was conducted that included a review of the available information for the study area<br /><br />
(Phase 1a) and a monitoring campaign was designed (Phase 1b) to assess the background noise<br /><br />
levels in the study area. The campaign was carried out in February 2010.<br /><br />
The IFC – WBC (International Finance Corporation – World Bank Group) reference levels for ambient<br /><br />
noise expressed in LAeq for residential, institutional and educational receptors is 55 dB(A) during the<br /><br />
daytime (7:00 to 22:00) and 45 dB(A) during the night-time. For industrial areas, the reference level is<br /><br />
70 dB(A) any time of the day or night.<br /><br />
A noise survey was conducted with a Class I hand-held sound level meter and an ISO Tech sound<br /><br />
level calibrator. The sound level meter measured the parameter LAeq, defined as the constant sound<br /><br />
level that, in a given time period, would convey the same sound energy as the actual time-varying Aweighted sound level. Noise measurements were conducted during daytime hours.<br /><br />
The sampling scenario covered 20 locations for noise survey divided between the mine site, the port<br /><br />
site and the transport corridor. The distribution of the sampling locations is shown in Figure 6-2.<br /><br />
Figure 6-2 Noise Monitoring Campaign Measurement Locations<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The ambient noise at the mine site might be generated by several naturally occurring sources and<br /><br />
rural human sources: wind through the vegetation, animal and cattle noises, traffic in rural and<br /><br />
populated areas, etc. The measurement locations at the Phase 1 mine site were selected based on<br /><br />
the following criteria: in the project area outside the populated areas; and where measurements could<br /><br />
be taken without interference from traffic or industrial noise.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
6.2.3 Archeology & Cultural Heritage<br /><br />
The significance of sites of archaeological value (in-situ) and cultural heritage factors has been<br /><br />
initially screened by discussion with in-country ESHIA practitioners. The preliminary advice indicated<br /><br />
that it was likely there would be limited and in some areas negligible sensitivity. Development of an<br /><br />
understanding of the importance of marine and terrestrial archaeology, burial sites, Society Bush<br /><br />
areas and other important heritage factors has already been included in a number of baseline studies.<br /><br />
Integration of this information with a specialist assessment into a review of possible project impacts is<br /><br />
still underway.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.2.4 Ecology & Biodiversity<br /><br />
Vegetation<br /><br />
The area encompassing the Simbili deposit has been surveyed using Phase 1a, 1b and 2b study<br /><br />
techniques during the wet and dry seasons in September and November 2009 and in February /<br /><br />
March 2010. The area is situated in a tropical moist broadleaf forest zone, but is also close to a<br /><br />
tropical grassland savannah zone and therefore displays some characteristics of each. The summit of<br /><br />
Simbili is host to degraded forest, but the sub-ridge to the north of the summit is largely covered by<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 96<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
grass with scattered tree species typical of the natural wooded grassland habitat. All the grasslands<br /><br />
on Simbili are much disturbed with secondary grassland species dominant and with evidence of<br /><br />
recent farming. Heavily degraded forest patches are present on the western slope of Simbili, although<br /><br />
generally the species found there were characteristic of secondary forest. Only one species of<br /><br />
concern was identified among these patches, the tree species Cryptosepalum tetraphyllum (IUCN:<br /><br />
Vulnerable, VU). (See Appendix 8 for Preliminary Report on Phase 3 Vegetation Fieldwork - Prepared<br /><br />
by SRK, Appendix 9 for Tonkolili Vegetation Survey and Inventory Report - Final - Prepared by<br /><br />
Herbarium, Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew and Appendix 10 for Report on the Vegetation Map of the<br /><br />
Tonkolili Project Area).<br /><br />
Terrestrial Fauna<br /><br />
A Phase 1b rapid assessment of eight sites within the mining area was conducted in March 2010<br /><br />
during the dry season. The natural forest cover of the mining area is heavily fragmented and does not<br /><br />
appear to support viable populations of large mammals, with the exception of Western Chimpanzees<br /><br />
that may be present in the forest patches to the south of the Farangbaia Forest Reserve. The existing<br /><br />
habitats within the mining area support a range of bird species, including forest and non-forest<br /><br />
species of conservation concern. (see Appendix 11 for Summary of Report, Phase 1 Study of<br /><br />
Terrestrial Fauna at Tonkolili Mine Site, Sierra Leone prepared by the Wildlife Conservation Society)<br /><br />
Aquatic Ecosystems<br /><br />
A Phase 1b rapid assessment of two sites located in the vicinity of the southern boundary of the<br /><br />
exploration licence area (the Tonkolili and Matoine Rivers) was undertaken in March 2010 during the<br /><br />
dry season. Both sites have good in-stream habitat, however substantial clearing of riparian<br /><br />
vegetation had occurred along the right-hand bank at the Matoine River site and there was evidence<br /><br />
of in-stream artisanal gold mining. The waters at the sites surveyed generally had low conductivity<br /><br />
and were slightly acidic, which means the waters have little or no buffering capacity against changes<br /><br />
to pH from any acid inputs (For further information see Appendix 12 for Rapid Assessment of Aquatic<br /><br />
Environments for the Tonkolili Project prepared by SRK).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.2.5 Hydrology and Hydrogeology<br /><br />
Phase 1 mining activities will focus on the hematite cap of the Simbili deposit which straddles the two<br /><br />
surface water catchments of the Tonkolili and Mawuru Rivers.<br /><br />
The Tonkolili catchment drains an area of approximately 165 km2 and flows for approximately 48 km<br /><br />
before it joins the larger Rokel River. The Tonkolili River flows throughout the year; minimum and<br /><br />
maximum flow rates measured at 5 gauging stations in the vicinity of the mine and eastern transport<br /><br />
corridor areas and corresponding to the dry and wet season of 2009 are given in Table 6-4 below. A<br /><br />
figure of the gauging stations is given in Appendix 13.<br /><br />
During the dry season, river flow rates represent the base flow component contributed by<br /><br />
groundwater.<br /><br />

Field measured water quality parameters indicate relatively stable chemical conditions with little<br /><br />
variation between the two catchments, and also between the wet and dry season. Electrical<br /><br />
conductivity (EC) of Tonkolili River and Mawuru River water was generally below 20 µS.cm-1 in both<br /><br />
the wet and dry season. pH was found to remain neutral, ranging from 6.2 to 7.1 pH units with slightly<br /><br />
lower pH values generally observed during the dry season.<br /><br />
Water quality samples were collected for laboratory analysis in the UK during the dry season, March<br /><br />
2010. In both rivers, the concentrations of iron ranged from 0.49 mg.L-1 to 1.02 mg.L-1 exceeding the<br /><br />
UK drinking water guideline value of 0.2 mg.L-1. Elevated concentrations of iron are suspected to be<br /><br />
associated with the banded iron formation (BIF) deposits and iron rich soils.<br /><br />
A TPH (C24-C40) concentration of 0.012 mg.L-1 was reported for a sample collected from the Mawuru<br /><br />
River. The presence of a heavy TPH fraction suggests a degree of anthropogenic contamination<br /><br />
most likely from a diesel, oil or grease source. However, the results from single sampling event<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Page 98<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
carried out to date are not sufficient basis upon which to draw any conclusions at this time. Further<br /><br />
sampling has taken place and a regular monitoring programme is being implemented. Results of the<br /><br />
most recent sampling are awaited.<br /><br />
Numerous springs flowing from the upper slopes of the mountains flanking the Tonkolili and Mawuru<br /><br />
Rivers contribute base flow throughout the year. The flow rate of five of these spring fed streams which<br /><br />
discharge into the Tonkolili River have been monitored by SRK and AML using V-notch weirs for a period<br /><br />
of 12 months commencing in April 2009. Flow rates vary between locations and are likely to be heavily<br /><br />
controlled by the local geology and aquifer characteristics. A distinct pattern of peak and low flow periods<br /><br />
are observed in the spring hydrographs and generally mimic the rainfall records with stable, low flow<br /><br />
conditions existing between February and June/July at which time flows are between 0.1 and 4 L.s-1. Flow<br /><br />
rates increase in response to rainfall recharge during August and September to maximums of 8 to 24 L.s-1,<br /><br />
after which time, rates steadily decline.<br /><br />
Several spring-fed streams flow from the eastern flanks of Simbili discharging to the Mawuru River. Spring<br /><br />
flow and water quality has been measured at one location, since April 2009. The spring flow during the wet<br /><br />
season exceeded the capacity of the V-notch and readings could not be taken throughout August and<br /><br />
September. Measure flow rates ranged from 0.5 L.s-1 during the dry season to 7.7 L.s-1 during the wet<br /><br />
<br /><br />
season; however maximum flow rates during August and September are likely to be much higher.<br /><br />
The EC value of spring water at both catchments ranged from <10 µS.cm-1 to1210 µS.cm-1. pH values<br /><br />
were between 6.0 and 7.42 while redox potential indicated consistently oxidizing conditions. The<br /><br />
chemical composition of water discharging from springs was found to contain slightly higher<br /><br />
concentrations of certain dissolved metals. Arsenic (0.057 mg.L-1) and selenium (0.236 mg.L-1) were<br /><br />
above their relevant UK drinking water guideline values while cadmium (0.0017 mg.L-1) and lead<br /><br />
(0.021 mg.L-1) existed at higher concentrations than reported for the Tonkolili River. It is likely that the<br /><br />
hematite cap overlying the BIF provides a source of various metal species which are leached by<br /><br />
groundwater and discharged through these springs, before being diluted in the main river systems.<br /><br />
The maintenance of surface water flows year round is important to both local inhabitants and the<br /><br />
natural environment (groundwater abstraction becomes more difficult during the dry season when<br /><br />
groundwater levels gradually decline). East and south east of Simbili within the Mawuru catchment,<br /><br />
no exploitation of groundwater has been observed and there is apparent total reliance on surface<br /><br />
water from Mawuru tributary streams/ springs or the Mawuru itself in some cases (at the peak of the<br /><br />
dry season) to meet village water demands.<br /><br />
Within the mine area the upper surface of the bedrock (Tonkolili Group) is thought to have weathered<br /><br />
to a depth of between 40 m and 60 m. The uppermost 10-20 m is completely weathered to a laterite<br /><br />
with rock becoming progressively fresher with depth. The weathered zone is thickest on the ridge<br /><br />
tops and thins towards the valley bottoms. The ridge tops are sometimes characterised by hardpan<br /><br />
(duricrust). The flanks of the hills are characterised by weathered material as well as transported<br /><br />
boulders and soils (colluvium). Alluvial deposits of sands, silts, clays and conglomerate have been<br /><br />
deposited in the Tonkolili and Mawuru valley bottoms, but it is not yet known how thick these deposits<br /><br />
are.<br /><br />
SRK (2010) proposed the following conceptual model for groundwater flow in the mine area:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 99<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Recharge percolates through the laterite or duricrust into the weathered cap from<br /><br />
where the majority of the groundwater flows laterally, at the contact with fresh<br /><br />
rock, towards the ridge flanks and discharges through springs to the surface<br /><br />
water network. The component of groundwater flow from the weathered cap to<br /><br />
the colluvium is unknown but is considered low given the generally low<br /><br />
permeability of the colluvium, Similarly, it is thought that groundwater flow from<br /><br />
the weathered cap to the underlying BIF and amphibolite, which appears to be<br /><br />
generally competent, is also low.<br /><br />
The laterite / duricrust may act like a sponge, storing recharge and releasing it more slowly to the<br /><br />
underlying aquifer as well as buffering through-flow to springs. This is an important process for<br /><br />
groundwater-surface water interactions and would be seen on the Tonkolili and Mawuru river flow<br /><br />
hydrographs as a tailing effect.<br /><br />
Water levels in the deposit area monitoring wells are generally within the weathered cap. Monitoring<br /><br />
borehole GWM11 on the neighbouring Marampon deposit is artesian (flowing at 0.2-0.3 L.s-1),<br /><br />
possibly due to intersection of deeper fracture flow, which suggest local flow systems and high aquifer<br /><br />
heterogeneity that may also exist within the Simbili deposit.<br /><br />
In the lower valleys and in the wider study area it is likely that colluvial and alluvial sediments act as<br /><br />
aquifers of unproven thickness which discharge to the Tonkolili or Mawuru Rivers throughout the year.<br /><br />
A deeper, fractured basement aquifer may be present throughout the study area, and if present would<br /><br />
correspond with highly fractured, regional features (lineaments) mapped within the Precambrian<br /><br />
basement rock (Akiwumi, 1988). The existence of these lineaments and the nature of groundwater<br /><br />
flow in the basement rock are poorly understood. Fracturing in the upper strata was noted to reduce<br /><br />
to zero within 30-40 m of the surface in the valley that now contains the Bumbuna Hydroelectric Dam.<br /><br />
Water levels have been monitored at weekly intervals since May 2009 at eight community<br /><br />
groundwater wells which exploit the alluvial and colluvial aquifer. Depth to water ranges from 3.0 to<br /><br />
9.5 m below ground level (m bGL) during the dry season, rising to 1.0 to 6.5 m bGL during the wet<br /><br />
season. The highest wet season water levels and the lowest dry season water levels were both<br /><br />
measured in the lower Tonkolili catchment. The hydrograph response suggests that rainfall recharge<br /><br />
infiltrates quickly to the aquifer with very little delay between the onset of the wet season and the<br /><br />
initial rise in the water table.<br /><br />
Groundwater chemistry is expected to be fairly consistent across the study area, with the exception of<br /><br />
groundwater within the weathered cap overlying the BIF. In general very little water-rock interaction is<br /><br />
anticipated given the dominance of largely non-reactive basement rocks such as granites, schists,<br /><br />
and greenstones.<br /><br />
The conceptual understanding of groundwater occurrence and flow in the lower valleys and in the<br /><br />
wider study area is limited.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.2.6 Soils & Land-use<br /><br />
Soils data have been derived from drilling and interpretation of superficial material. At most drill sites<br /><br />
the top 2 m of material was cleared during preparation of the drill pad and therefore the baseline soil<br /><br />
dataset is incomplete. The uppermost surficial material is dependent on the underlying geology. For<br /><br />
the iron-ore protolith (quartz and silicate itabirites) a ferruginous hardcap or canga profile has<br /><br />
developed, consisting of predominantly angular to subrounded fragments of hematite and pisoliths<br /><br />
partially replaced by goethite and cemented by clays, reprecipitated silica and iron oxide. A simple<br /><br />
laterite profile has developed over footwall or hangingwall acid to intermediate rocks, typically red in<br /><br />
colour, comprising massive and colloform goethite-hematite, with common iron-oxide fragments<br /><br />
cemented by clays, reprecipitated silica and iron oxides. (See Appendix 14 Tonkolili Soils and Laterite<br /><br />
Profile - Prepared by SRK)<br /><br />
Preliminary qualitative information on land-use has been acquired during Phase 1b and Phase 2b<br /><br />
biodiversity studies (flora, fauna and freshwater) in the mining area. While some remaining forest<br /><br />
patches including Society Bush still exist in a mosaic land-use, in general human presence, slash and<br /><br />
burn farming techniques, road and communal ground clearance (including clearance by AML) has<br /><br />
driven a change in the area from forest and patches of grassland on the summits to primarily a<br /><br />
mixture of agriculture and fallow land.<br /><br />
Agriculture comprises a wide range of crops on hill slopes and monocultures of rice or peanuts on<br /><br />
periodically inundated land in the valley bottoms. Non-location specific bushmeat hunting grounds<br /><br />
also occur.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.2.7 Geology & Geomorphology<br /><br />
The Tonkolili ore body is situated in the greenstone belts of the Sula Mountains. The license area is<br /><br />
dominated by rock units of the Sula Group, a greenstone belt that forms part of the Kambui Super<br /><br />
Group. The Sula Group is comprised of two primary formations, the Sonfon and Tonkolili formations.<br /><br />
The upper sequence of the Tonkolili Formation hosts the primary magnetite resource; however Phase<br /><br />
1 of the project is focused on the overlying hematite / goethite deposits. The iron content of the<br /><br />
hematite / goethite ore can be increased to exportable grades through beneficiation. The<br /><br />
geomorphology of the license area is characterised by smooth hill tops (that rise from 200 to 800 m in<br /><br />
elevation) and plateaus that trend in a north-easterly direction and are deeply incised by the Tonkolili<br /><br />
River drainage system which flows to the south east. (For further details see Appendix 15 for<br /><br />
Geological and Geomorphologic Baseline Study - Prepared by SRK)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.2.8 Socio-Economic & Human Health<br /><br />
The socio-economic and human health baseline of these areas has been characterised using a range<br /><br />
of survey techniques at a coarse level and the results have been aggregated and described in a<br /><br />
generalised manner in the regional overview. Although further baseline description is underway, it is<br /><br />
assumed for the time being that the generalized description is an adequate characterization of the<br /><br />
<br /><br />

The baseline data collected from the field studies conducted in March 2010 for other relevant<br /><br />
disciplines will also be considered for the health impact assessment. Water sampling program<br /><br />
conducted in February identified elevated heavy metals concentrations (greater than WHO<br /><br />
guidelines) for arsenic, barium, lead and selenium in samples from some wells in the mine area<br /><br />
(Section 6.2.5). The results for increased concentrations of arsenic, barium, lead and selenium<br /><br />
occurred in two samples (a groundwater well, and an artesian spring). The third groundwater sample<br /><br />
was identified to well contain barium, lead, and selenium exceedances. These results may be an<br /><br />
indication of elevated, naturally occurring metals in the area’s geology which may pose a human<br /><br />
health impact. Further assessment of the water chemistry in the mine pits and catchment areas is<br /><br />
required before the potential health impact can be defined. The chemical results of soil, vegetation,<br /><br />
fish tissue, and surface and groundwater samples collected during additional site visits will be studied<br /><br />
and potential concerns highlighted in the next phase of works (see Section 8).<br /><br />

6.3.3 Archeology & Cultural Heritage<br /><br />
The significance of sites of archaeological value (in-situ) and cultural heritage factors has been<br /><br />
initially screened by discussion with in-country ESHIA practitioners. The preliminary advice indicated<br /><br />
that it was likely there would be limited and in some areas negligible sensitivity. Development of an<br /><br />
understanding of the importance of marine and terrestrial archaeology, burial sites, Society Bush<br /><br />
areas and other important heritage factors has already been included in a number of baseline studies.<br /><br />
Integration of this information with a specialist assessment into a review of possible project impacts is<br /><br />
still underway.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
6.3.4 Ecology & Biodiversity<br /><br />
Vegetation<br /><br />
A Phase 2b assessment was undertaken on the first 20 km of the haul road route, from the mine site<br /><br />
to Rokel River at the end of the wet season in November 2009 and complemented by a new survey in<br /><br />
March 2010, during the dry season. The transport corridor further west (proposed haul road route and<br /><br />
existing rail line up to the Pepel Port facility) was surveyed using Phase 1b techniques in March 2010<br /><br />
(dry season). In the vicinity of the mine site, remnants of original forest vegetation, riverine forest,<br /><br />
secondary forest, river channel communities and various secondary habitats are found. West of Rokel<br /><br />
River, vegetation is largely characterized by a patchwork of inland valley swamps, secondary forest,<br /><br />
farmbush, plantations, agricultural land, wild oil palm, grassland vegetation and inselbergs.<br /><br />
Mangroves, freshwater ecosystems and agroforestry plantations are found in the Port Loko area.<br /><br />
Four habitats of conservation concern are present in the transport corridor. Riverine forest and river<br /><br />
channel communities that have not been already highly disturbed are classified as of high<br /><br />
conservation concern. Inland valley swamps and mangroves that have not been highly disturbed are<br /><br />
classified as being of medium conservation concern. Species of conservation concern have been<br /><br />
found in all these habitats of conservation concern, with the exception of mangroves. The presence of<br /><br />
these conservation species indicates that the vegetation in these habitats is also likely to be relatively<br /><br />
undisturbed and these habitats may also represent the last remaining examples of the natural climax<br /><br />
vegetation in the study area. Although mangroves usually do not contain species of conservation<br /><br />
concern and do not have high plant species richness, they are of considerable ecological value in<br /><br />
terms of their structure and function, and are likely to harbour a wide variety of avifaunal and other<br /><br />
animal assemblages.<br /><br />
Terrestrial Fauna<br /><br />
A Phase 1b assessment of 16 sites along the transport corridor was conducted during the dry season.<br /><br />
As with the mining area, the natural forest cover is heavily fragmented, however, the continuous<br /><br />
riparian forests do provide an important habitat for species that require more extensive habitat areas<br /><br />
(such as large mammals). A diverse range of bird species exist within the remaining forest fragments,<br /><br />
including species of conservation concern. The Port Loko Strict Nature Reserve, located to the north<br /><br />
of the transport corridor does support small populations of two globally threatened mammals (the<br /><br />
Western Chimpanzee and Western Pied Colobus). Western Chimpanzee Populations are also found<br /><br />
in a forested area near the Lunsar Interchange.<br /><br />
Aquatic Ecosystems<br /><br />
The lowland areas are characterised by springs and small streams, which, based on Phase 1b<br /><br />
surveys (March 2010) at two freshwater swamp areas around Pepel, are low to mid quality aquatic<br /><br />
habitats, due to highly disturbed riparian vegetation and limited in-stream habitat types. In contrast,<br /><br />
the aquatic habitats of the rivers surveyed are generally in good condition, with low turbidity, intact<br /><br />
riparian vegetation and a range of in-stream habitat types. In particular, high quality aquatic habitats<br /><br />
were identified along the Port Loko and Rokel Rivers.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 105<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Whilst no physical sampling was conducted, the Phase 1b literature review identified four freshwater<br /><br />
fish species of conservation interest (one critically endangered species (Pristis microdon) and three<br /><br />
endemic species (Leptocypris taiaensis, Marcusenius meronai, and Prolabeo batesi) that may be<br /><br />
present in the aquatic environments along the transport corridor.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.3.5 Hydrology & Hydrogeology<br /><br />
The transport corridor covers an approximate 200km linear section cross-cutting the country in a roughly<br /><br />
east-west direction. The corridor crosses approximately 14 tributary catchments of the Pampana (also<br /><br />
known as the Jong) and Rokel (also known as the Seli) river basins. The more significant tributaries in the<br /><br />
project area include the Little Scaries, Bankasoka, Mabole, Pampana and Tonkolili Rivers. The upper<br /><br />
courses of those rivers commencing in the Sula Mountains, and the interior plateaux region generally, are<br /><br />
shallow during the long dry season, while the lower courses remain fuller and deeper presumably due to<br /><br />
progressive influx of baseflow. The interior planes are subject to flooding during the wet season due to the<br /><br />
relatively subdued relief of these areas. In the costal swamp area, rivers are affected by a tidal range of 2<br /><br />
to 3.5 m and experience severe flooding during the wet season.<br /><br />
The transport corridor commences at the mine-site in the Sula Mountains and loosely follows the Tonkolili<br /><br />
River to its confluence with the Rokel, River. Flow in the Rokel River is controlled by the release of water<br /><br />
from the Bumbuna hydroelectric dam, located approximately 11 km upstream from the confluence with the<br /><br />
Tonkolili River. After crossing north over the Rokel River, the corridor loosely follows the drainage divide<br /><br />
between the Rokel River to the south and the Mabole River to the north. Between the Rokel River crossing<br /><br />
and Makeni, the corridor runs for approximately 30 km through an undulating topography of the interior<br /><br />
plains. Water quality of the Tonkolili and Rokel Rivers in this region are typically fresh with neutral to<br /><br />
slightly acidic pH. The Mabole River flows north east away from the transport corridor where it discharges<br /><br />
to the Little Scarcies River.<br /><br />
From Makeni to Lunsar the corridor runs for 55 km through flatter topography where the major rivers,<br /><br />
Mabole to the north and Rokel to the south meander through areas of low-lying swamp land. Many of the<br /><br />
minor rivers crossing the corridor run northwards towards either the Mabole River or the Bankasoka River.<br /><br />
During the dry season, most of the minor tributaries to the Mabole, Bankasoka and Rokel Rivers are dry<br /><br />
with some of the larger tributaries containing either stagnant pools of water or very low flow. The Tabai and<br /><br />
Bankasoka rivers (where crossed by the existing road) contained stagnant pools of water during February<br /><br />
-1<br /><br />
2010 characterized by low EC (19 to 22 µS.cm ) and slightly acidic pH (5.76 to 6.09 pH units).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
From Lunsar to Port Loko the landscape is characterised by low topographic relief and wetland areas.<br /><br />
The corridor runs along the catchment boundary between the Bankasoka and Rokel Rivers. A higher<br /><br />
occurrence of small ephemeral streams is noted in this area. On reaching Port Loko, the route crosses<br /><br />
north over the Bankasoka River (Port Loko Creek) which is noted to have a high flow all year round. Water<br /><br />
-1<br /><br />
quality measurements taken at this location indicated the water to be fresh with an EC value of 22 µS.cm ,<br /><br />
pH of 6.64.<br /><br />
From Port Loko to Pepel Island, the topographic relief is minimal and streams are inter-spaced with<br /><br />
marshes and wetlands. This subtle change in topography and vegetation cover marks the progression into<br /><br />
the coastal swamp and estuarine area with islands and sand bars. The corridor continues to follow the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />

Page 106<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
north-south catchment divide between the Little Scarcies River to the north, which becomes large as it<br /><br />
enters tidally controlled water, and Bankasoka River (Port Loko Creek) to the south. Very few flowing rivers<br /><br />
were observed in close proximity to the corridor during the dry season (February 2010).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The hydrogeological conditions along the transport corridor vary as the corridor crosses several of the<br /><br />
major geological units present in Sierra Leone. However, the hydrogeology can be divided broadly<br /><br />
into two main zones:<br /><br />
1. Basement outcrop - a weathered profile of thin Tertiary and/or Quaternary alluvial sediments<br /><br />
are likely to form an upper, unconfined aquifer unit. Records indicate that the basement rock<br /><br />
is, on average, 20 m bGL with the depth to water recorded at around 10 m bGL. The extent of<br /><br />
weathering and the depth to basement will be variable across the corridor area and will be<br /><br />
largely controlled by topography and basement geology. The majority of the transport corridor<br /><br />
between the mine site and Port Loko is expected to encounter this conceptual hydrogeological<br /><br />
setting;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2. Coastal sediments - The coastal sediments of the Bullom Group forms a belt along the entire<br /><br />
length of Sierra Leone shown to reach at least 60 m thick, generally comprising layers of<br /><br />
clays and sands. The sand layers represent either unconfined or confined freshwater<br /><br />
aquifers. Groundwater flow is controlled by surface topography. Groundwater discharges<br /><br />
either to swamp areas, freshwater streams or directly to the sea.<br /><br />
Within the basement outcrop zone, water levels are likely to fluctuate significantly between wet and dry<br /><br />
season as rainfall infiltration provides annual recharge. Groundwater flow is expected to be controlled by a<br /><br />
combination of surface topography and basement elevation, but will predominantly flow towards the major<br /><br />
rivers draining the catchments.<br /><br />
Aquifer parameters are largely unknown for this region. Water quality is generally fresh with EC ranging<br /><br />
from 100 to 200 µS.cm-1 and pH from 5.9 to 6.8 pH units. This aquifer has been observed to be widely<br /><br />
exploited by local communities who use hand dug wells to access a potable groundwater supply.<br /><br />
Within the coastal sediments zone which occupies the remaining western section of the corridor from<br /><br />
Port Loko to Pepel., the sediments of the Bullom Group comprises gravels, grits, sands and clays of<br /><br />
lacustrine, estuarine, deltaic and marine origin. This unit forms a coastal belt along the entire length of<br /><br />
Sierra Leone and is likely to be encountered along the corridor at some point west of Port Loko.<br /><br />
The Bullom Group overlies the basement rocks of the Kasila Series and has been shown to be at least<br /><br />
60 m thick. The basement rocks outcrop in a few places in the estuaries of the Little Scarcies and Great<br /><br />
Scarcies rivers and it is probable that the sediments are comparatively shallow throughout the greater part<br /><br />
of this area. The sediments in the northern section of the belt consist of horizontally layered, cemented grits<br /><br />
and sands, and recent river sands and silts. In this section of the belt, light to dark bluish-grey clays are<br /><br />
overlain by brown, red or magenta, angular and poorly graded sands. The sandy layers of the Bullom<br /><br />
Group represent either unconfined or confined freshwater aquifers. Rainfall recharge to the unconfined<br /><br />
water table results in large annual fluctuations in the water levels which closely follow topography.<br /><br />
Groundwater flow is controlled by topography with groundwater flow from higher to lower ground where<br /><br />
groundwater discharges either to swamp areas, freshwater streams or directly to the sea. Aquifer<br /><br />
properties are not well understood, however tests conducted in the Bullom Group suggest a hydraulic<br /><br />
<br /><br />

conductivity value of 5 x 10-4 m.s for the sand units. Groundwater is extremely fresh (< 100 µS.cm-1) even<br /><br />
in close proximity to the coast line and is generally slightly acidic with an average pH of 5.1. Groundwater<br /><br />
of the Bullom Group is extensively used as a potable supply to local communities and is also exploited by<br /><br />
the national water supply company SALWACO on the Tagrin peninsula.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.3.6 Soils & Land-use<br /><br />
To date, no baseline studies to characterise the physio-chemical properties of soils have been<br /><br />
undertaken in the transport corridor. Limited geotechnical investigation works including auguring and<br /><br />
trial pitting are currently being carried out along the transport corridor and some drilling is proposed at<br /><br />
potential river crossings. This work will allow development of soils descriptions and the Sierra Leone<br /><br />
Agricultural department have been approached with regard to providing input based on their past and<br /><br />
ongoing work as well as potential photo-interpretation of recent project imagery.<br /><br />
Preliminary qualitative information on land-use has been acquired during Phase 1b biodiversity<br /><br />
studies (flora, fauna and freshwater) in the transport corridor. While some undisturbed habitats remain<br /><br />
(e.g. remnant riverine primary forest), a significant proportion of land in the transport corridor is now<br /><br />
used for subsistence agriculture, charcoal production and settlements. Non-location specific<br /><br />
harvesting of medicinal plants and bushmeat hunting also occurs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.3.7 Geology & Geomorphology<br /><br />
Limited project-specific geotechnical drilling is currently being undertaken along the rail alignment<br /><br />
within the transport corridor and reports will be available after presentation of this ESHIA document.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.3.8 Socio-Economic & Human Health<br /><br />
The socio-economic and human health baseline of these areas have been characterised using a<br /><br />
range of survey techniques at a coarse level and the results have been aggregated and described in<br /><br />
a generalised manner in the Regional Setting chapter, Section 5.4. Although further baseline<br /><br />
description is underway, it is assumed for the time being that the generalised description is an<br /><br />
adequate characterization of the communities along the transport corridor and the baseline is not<br /><br />
expected to be significantly different from the regional overview. The chemical results of soil,<br /><br />
vegetation, fish tissue, surface water and groundwater samples collected during site visits will be<br /><br />
studied and potential concerns highlighted in the next phase of works (see Section 8 for more<br /><br />
information on the next stage of work).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Port Facilities<br /><br />
<br /><br />

The significance of sites of archaeological value (in-situ) and cultural heritage factors has been<br /><br />
