<br /><br />
6.4.4 Ecology & Biodiversity<br /><br />
Vegetation<br /><br />
The Pepel Port area is comprised of farmbush, plantations, settlements, vegetable gardens and wild<br /><br />
oil palm. The wider Pepel Port land lease area and the rest of Pepel Island also hosts mangroves,<br /><br />
mangrove / freshwater ecotone, oil palm and Acacia mangium plantations and grassland vegetation.<br /><br />
The conservation significance of the mangroves is medium, while all other habitats are classified as<br /><br />
low significance.<br /><br />
Terrestrial Fauna<br /><br />
A Phase 1b rapid assessment of six sites around the Sierra Leone River Estuary was conducted<br /><br />
during the dry season. The area does not appear to have significant habitat value for terrestrial large<br /><br />
mammals, reptiles or amphibians, however it does represent a very important (significant) wintering<br /><br />
area for bird species. The significance of the area for bird species is reflected in the estuaries<br /><br />
designation as a wetland of international importance under the Ramsar Convention (1971) and an<br /><br />
Important Bird Area by BirdLife International.<br /><br />
Aquatic Ecosystems<br /><br />
During the Phase 1b rapid assessment, no freshwater aquatic environments were identified on Pepel<br /><br />
Island.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.4.5 Hydrology & Hydrogeology<br /><br />
Groundwater is the principle source of potable water supply to the inhabitant of Pepel Island. This is<br /><br />
in part due to the lack of a dependable fresh surface water resource, and because Pepel Island is<br /><br />
underlain by one of the most productive aquifers in Sierra Leone, the coastal deposits of the Tertiary<br /><br />
Bullom Group. The group outcrops over the high ground in the form of elevated terraces and extends<br /><br />
to depths of at least 60 m (SRK geotechnical investigation, 2009), possibly up to 120 m thick<br /><br />
(Strasser-King, 1979). The groundwater beneath Pepel Island is expected to comprise a relatively thin<br /><br />
lens of fresh water and become saline with depth; a common feature associated with coastal aquifers.<br /><br />
It is interpreted that the lens is thickest under the elevated terraces, becoming thinner towards the<br /><br />
coast as groundwater elevations approach mean sea level.<br /><br />
Groundwater samples were collected from wells on Pepel in and near the port area during a recent<br /><br />
site visit (March/April 2010) to assess whether historical activities at the port may have had a<br /><br />
detrimental effect on groundwater quality in the area. Background samples were collected from<br /><br />
comparison from wells further north on the island where industrial activities are very unlikely to have<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 111<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
impacted on groundwater quality. Water sampling locations are shown on the map of Pepel Island in<br /><br />
Appendix 16.<br /><br />
The tests showed that at one location only (PPGW001) sulphate was elevated relative to the UK<br /><br />
drinking water guideline value (250 mg.L-1) south of the old stockpile area. Although arsenic<br /><br />
concentrations in all soil sampling locations bar one, were above the detection limit arsenic in waters<br /><br />
was below the guideline concentrations of 0.01 mg.L-1 at all locations. No other potential<br /><br />
contaminants of concern tested above concern levels.<br /><br />
During recent monitoring works, field parameters (electrical conductivity, pH, redox and temperature)<br /><br />
were recorded at sampling locations. Electrical conductivity values ranged between 70 μS.cm-1 and<br /><br />
200 μS.cm-1 (an outlier of 500 μS.cm-1 was measured in May 2010 at PPGW008 a recently drilled<br /><br />
relatively deep water well,) representative of fresh water. A significant exception was the waters<br /><br />
sampled from location PPGW001, located at the edge of the swamp area. The EC value for this water<br /><br />
sample was above the maximum detection limit of the instrument (3900 μS.cm-1), which is indicative<br /><br />
of saline water. The location of this well suggests that it will be impacted by influx of saline water at<br /><br />
high tides. The pH of the groundwater is acidic, ranging between 4.5 and 6.57 pH units.<br /><br />
There are no significant freshwater rivers present on Pepel Island; however, numerous ephemeral<br /><br />
streams are present during the rainy seasons. Runoff from the high ground during the wet drains into<br /><br />
the mangrove swamps. In the swamps themselves, there are a number of creeks discharging into the<br /><br />
sea. Estuarine swamps lie at an elevation of less than 1 m above mean sea level (m amsl) and are<br /><br />
subject to tidal flooding. The island is separated from the mainland by a channel, at least 100 m in<br /><br />
width. One surface water sample was collected from a creek adjacent to Pepel Bridge. An electrical<br /><br />
conductivity reading above the maximum detection limit (3900 μS.cm-1) was recorded for this sample<br /><br />
which is indicative of saline water.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.4.6 Soils & Land-use<br /><br />
A baseline study to characterise the chemical properties of soils within the former Pepel Port facility<br /><br />
was recently undertaken (March-April 2010). The study included the analyses of several surface soil<br /><br />
samples collected from areas within the former port facility to characterise ground conditions<br /><br />
associated with the site’s former use as an industrial facility and hence provide the baseline reflecting<br /><br />
the Brownfield character of this site. The sampling and analysis were designed to test for potential<br /><br />
impact of historical contaminative activities associated with operation of the port (i.e. refuelling, fuel<br /><br />
storage, power generation). Soil samples were also collected from outside former work areas to<br /><br />
obtain information on the background soil characteristic of the area. Sampling locations are shown on<br /><br />
the map of Pepel Island in Appendix 16.<br /><br />
As part of an initial screening exercise, soil concentrations were compared with suitable<br /><br />
WorleyParsons (UK) derived generic criteria in order to identify contaminants of potential concern to<br /><br />
human health. As part of the screening process, each contaminant is compared to three guideline<br /><br />
values which were derived considering three different land use scenarios (i.e. residential land use<br /><br />
with vegetable uptake and without vegetable uptake and commercial land use with hard cover).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 112<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The assessment found that none of the contaminant soil concentrations exceeded commercial land<br /><br />
use guideline values. However, arsenic, benzo(a)pyrene and aliphatic compounds (C16-C35)<br /><br />
concentrations exceeded the derived guideline values for residential land use with or without<br /><br />
vegetable uptake at some locations which are discussed in more detail below.<br /><br />
Arsenic concentrations were above the detection limit of 0.6 mg.kg-1 at all locations with exception of<br /><br />
sampling location PPSS004 within the port area near the rail line but remote from any area of<br /><br />
significant industrial activity. The highest concentration (197 mg.kg-1) was measured at location<br /><br />
PPSS006, which sampled soils in an historically coal tar lined gulley adjacent to the former<br /><br />
powerhouse. This concentration is six times greater than the residential guideline value of 35mg.kg-1<br /><br />
for areas with no vegetable uptake. It is possible that arsenic occurs naturally in local soils (the result<br /><br />
of weathering of arsenic-rich bedrock, i.e. metamorphics). However, the occurrence of significantly<br /><br />
higher concentrations within former port work areas indicates that these activities have contributed to<br /><br />
arsenic levels in soils.<br /><br />
Aliphatic compounds (C16-C35) exceeded the residential guideline value (9.1 mg.kg-1) at several<br /><br />
locations within the former working areas. The highest concentration (1830 mg.kg-1) was measured in<br /><br />
the soils collected from location PPSS006 which is described above.<br /><br />
Benzo(a)pyrene concentration exceeded the residential guideline value at two locations (PPSS001<br /><br />
near the refurbished AML training room and PPSS013 adjacent to rail tracks by the former fuel<br /><br />
storage tanks area). Benzo(a)pyrene is a contaminant often associated with coal tar. Heavily<br /><br />
weathered tarry material is present at Pepel Port at a number of locations where a worker confirmed<br /><br />
that coal tar was used to provide a seal to protect ground from being contaminated by spills of fuels in<br /><br />
the vicinity of the former fuel depot.<br /><br />
Iron concentrations ranged between 9750 mg.kg-1 (PPSS017) and 178000 mg.kg-1 (PPSS013).<br /><br />
These high concentrations are not considered to pose a risk to human health, as iron is not toxic to<br /><br />
human health. However, elevated dissolved iron in surface waters with a low pH, can impact on<br /><br />
aquatic life, especially in circumstance where acidic waters mix with more alkaline waters. Under<br /><br />
these conditions, dissolved iron would start to precipitate out of solution to form an iron oxide orange<br /><br />
stained sludge which will coat the river/stream bed. This coating will kill bottom dwellers, which in turn<br /><br />
will have a knock on effect (e.g. reduced food source) on the larger aquatic environment.<br /><br />
Preliminary qualitative information on land-use has been acquired during Phase 1b biodiversity<br /><br />
studies (flora, fauna and freshwater) in the Pepel Port facility area. In addition to remaining<br /><br />
mangroves, land in the Pepel Port area is used for subsistence and commercial agriculture (oil palm<br /><br />
and Acacia plantations), charcoal production and settlements.<br /><br />
Potential sources of contamination associated with the historical operation of the port remain and<br /><br />
include stockpiled and dispersed hematite product from the former operations, hydrocarbons and<br /><br />
solvents associated with fuel farms, workshops, loco sheds and the power house and transformer<br /><br />
stations. Asbestos containing materials were also identified and tested and demonstrated to contain<br /><br />
chrysotile asbestos.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

6.4.7 Geology & Geomorphology<br /><br />
It is understood that limited project-specific geotechnical test pitting and auguring has been<br /><br />
undertaken to date at the proposed port site and interpretation and reporting will be available after<br /><br />
issue of this ESHIA report. Published data and recent drilling for water well installations confirm the<br /><br />
presence of at least approximately 40m of sedimentary sequence of clay, silt and sand and consistent<br /><br />
with the Bullom Group which outcrops along the entire length of the Sierra Leone coastline.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.4.8 Socio-Economic & Human Health<br /><br />
The socio-economic and human health baseline of these areas have been characterised using a<br /><br />
range of survey techniques at a coarse level and the results have been aggregated and described in<br /><br />
a generalised manner in the Regional Setting chapter, Section 5.4. Although further baseline<br /><br />
description is underway, it is assumed for the time being that the generalised description is an<br /><br />
adequate characterization of the communities along the port area and the baseline is not expected to<br /><br />
be significantly different from the regional overview.<br /><br />
Data collected from the field studies conducted in March 2010 for other relevant disciplines will also<br /><br />
be considered for the health impact assessment. In the Pepel Port area, the pH levels measured at a<br /><br />
number of wells and surface water sampling locations in the project area were outside of the<br /><br />
generally accepted drinking water range of 6.5-8.5 (WHO 2007). WHO have not established a<br /><br />
drinking water guideline for pH, stating that ‘values in drinking-water are well below those at which<br /><br />
toxic effects may occur’; they do, however, remark that pH is an important operational water quality<br /><br />
parameter (WHO 2008). pH can have indirect effects on water quality and health. It is known that<br /><br />
heavy metals and base cations can be mobilized by increasing acidity in groundwater and soil.<br /><br />
The number of samples collected for the baseline study was low. Better definition of the water<br /><br />
chemistry, is required before potential health impacts can be fully defined. Additional testing be<br /><br />
carried out in the next phase of works (Section 8) will more accurately define the surface and<br /><br />
groundwater quality in the Pepel Port catchment area to ensure that appropriate health based<br /><br />
guidelines are met. Testing should include metals, routine potability and microbial parameters.<br /><br />
The baseline soil and marine sediment programs identified elevated heavy metal concentrations<br /><br />
below commercial international standards (CCME) in the Pepel Port area (Sections 6.4.6 and 6.5).<br /><br />
Soil samples collected from the Port area contained concentrations of arsenic, benzo[a]pyrene, and<br /><br />
hydrocarbons C16-C35 in concentrations greater than residential guidelines with or without vegetation<br /><br />
uptake. Sediment samples and intertidal sediment samples were identified to contain arsenic,<br /><br />
chromium and lead concentrations greater than international standards.<br /><br />
In addition, baseline surveys and in-country visits identified materials such as asbestos sheeting,<br /><br />
presumably scavenged from Pepel Port and used in local communities as building materials.<br /><br />
The chemical results of soil, vegetation, fish tissue, surface water and groundwater samples collected<br /><br />
during site visits will be studied and potential concerns highlighted in the next phase of works (see<br /><br />
Section 8 for more information on the next stage of work).<br /><br />

Offshore & Coastal<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.5.1 Marine Physical Environment<br /><br />
Ocean Climate<br /><br />
Accurate bathymetry data for Pepel is not yet available. Although UK admiralty charts do exist, there<br /><br />
are discrepancies between these charts and field observations. In particular, depths around the old<br /><br />
navigation channel have reduced following the port’s closure and discontinued maintenance dredging<br /><br />
(Scott Wilson, 2009).<br /><br />
Located further inside the estuary, tidal variations at Pepel Island are less than in Freetown. Data<br /><br />
from the UKHO (Admiralty Chart no. 625) shows a mean water variation of approximately 2.9m at<br /><br />
spring tides and 2.2m at neap tides.<br /><br />
A 2D hydrodynamic model (DHI MIKE) developed for this project estimated the maximum current<br /><br />
speeds (tides only) in the main channel at Pepel to be 0.82 m/s (WorleyParsons, 2010a). The model<br /><br />
utilised charted bathymetry and predicted water levels and these values are treated with caution. The<br /><br />
model will be improved and a more detailed analysis will be provided in the final ESHIA report based<br /><br />
on calibration against observed data.<br /><br />
The influence of waves in the Pepel part of the estuary is expected to be very low as there is<br /><br />
protection from the open waters of the Atlantic by Tagrin Point and sand banks and bars in the<br /><br />
estuary mouth.<br /><br />
Water and Sediment Quality<br /><br />
Basic water quality parameters have been measured nearshore Pepel (site P1). Figure 6-3 shows the<br /><br />
preliminary results from February 2010. Further data will be available for the Stage 2 ESHIA. The<br /><br />
results show the variability in turbidity with the tidal cycle. The waters are highly turbid during mid-ebb<br /><br />
flow, as expected.<br /><br />

None of the water samples taken during the March 2010 environmental survey reveal concentrations<br /><br />
which are above international water quality guidelines for the protection of aquatic life. The baseline<br /><br />
conditions of estuarine water quality at Pepel are therefore good.<br /><br />
Results for total suspended solids (TSS) describe conditions during the ebbing tide as more turbid<br /><br />
than that of the flood. This is typical of surface run off carrying particulate matter into the estuary from<br /><br />
river channels on the ebbing tide. In contrast, less turbid marine waters enter the estuary on the flood.<br /><br />
Near Pepel measured TSS concentrations were < 5 mg/l around high water and approximately 40<br /><br />
mg/l at low water.<br /><br />
Sediment is well sorted in fast flowing sections of the estuary, ranging from good to moderate coarse<br /><br />
sand. Reduced current speeds behind Mayaba Island at sample location F result in finer particles<br /><br />
settling out of suspension resulting in a silt sediment.<br /><br />
Hydrocarbon analysis of sediments sampled close to Pepel display an increase in total hydrocarbon<br /><br />
concentration at location D. Location D is situated at the end of a trestle, which is part of the existing<br /><br />
port structure. A possible explanation for increased hydrocarbon concentrations at this location is that<br /><br />
vessels would have spent relatively long periods of time at the trestle whilst loading ore and fuel and<br /><br />
or oil could have been spilt at this time. The trestle is also an area of shelter for fish and artisanal<br /><br />
fishermen were observed fishing there during the survey. F fuel may have been accidentally spilt by<br /><br />
these fishermen. A further potential source of hydrocarbon contamination at location D is transport<br /><br />
from other locations, carried in the water column and deposited as the current slows at and around<br /><br />
<br /><br />

6.5.2 Coastal and Marine Habitats<br /><br />
Pepel Port lies in an area of high ecological value associated with extensive mangrove forests within<br /><br />
one of the core areas of the Sierra Leone Ramsar site.<br /><br />
The coastal habitat of Pepel Islands consists of mangroves, mudfalts and sandflats and a small sandy<br /><br />
beach near the community settlement. The habitats have been mapped based on high resolution<br /><br />
aerial and satellite imagery. The results were ground-truthed during the marine environmental site<br /><br />
survey.<br /><br />

coastal fisheries for prawns and fish, as a source of wood products, as nutrient sinks, and for<br /><br />
shoreline protection (Rönnbäck, 1999). The mangrove communities observed near Pepel Island were<br /><br />

6.5.3 Marine and avifauna<br /><br />
The shallow waters of the mud flats in the mangroves are nursery grounds for shrimp species<br /><br />
(Portconsult, 1996). Molluscs are found in the estuarine and mangrove creeks and include the<br /><br />
mangrove oyster (Crassostrea tulipa), the brackish and estuarine intertidal cockle (Senilia senilis),<br /><br />
and the sub-littoral rock oyster (Crassostrea denticulate) (Chaytor & Aleem 1976). The bivalves<br /><br />
include Iphigenia laevigatum, Tagelus angulatus and Tellina nymphalis, and the gastropods include<br /><br />
Cymbrium spp., Tympanotonus fuscatus and Semifusus morio (Lorax, 2009). No specific information<br /><br />
is available regarding fish or shelfish species in the surroundings of Pepel Island. However, artisanal<br /><br />
fishery, including shelfish collection activity, appears to play an important role in the local communities<br /><br />
as observed during the field survey. Further survey and consultation will be included in the Stage 2<br /><br />
ESHIA.<br /><br />
A survey below the Pepel trestle during the marine environmental baseline survey found the sub-sea<br /><br />
structures were covered with oysters (Crassostrea spp) and fish species Silver Dollar (Metynnis spp)<br /><br />
was also observed.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
POTENTIAL IMPACTS & MITIGATION<br /><br />
Impact Identification & Evaluation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.1<br /><br />
7.1.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Techniques for Impact Identification & Evaluation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Methodology<br /><br />
Baseline knowledge identifies the environmental and social parameters that may be affected by the<br /><br />
proposed project. The potential positive and negative changes resulting from the project are predicted<br /><br />
for the study area over the life of the project. These predicted changes (impacts) are then evaluated<br /><br />
using a significance ranking process. An outline of the impact assessment procedure is as follows:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identification of the valued receptors;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identification of the key project activities;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Impact evaluation; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Significance ranking.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The impact evaluation step included identification of potential activity-receptor interactions prior to the<br /><br />
evaluation of impact significance (Aspects Identification).<br /><br />
Valued Receptors<br /><br />
A valued receptor (VR) is any element of the environment that is considered to be important or<br /><br />
valuable and merits detailed consideration in the ESHIA process. In this context the broadest<br /><br />
definition of ‘the environment’ is applied, such that VRs may be selected according to economic,<br /><br />
social, aesthetic or ethical criteria, as well as by consideration of physical, ecological and biological<br /><br />
characteristics. The process of selecting VRs may consider legal status, scientific or cultural value,<br /><br />
and public perception; and may account for the views of national or local government, international,<br /><br />
national or local non-governmental organisations, or the general public.<br /><br />
The selection of VRs is dependent on the nature of the proposed project; only those environmental<br /><br />
components that have the potential to be affected (positively or negatively) by the project are<br /><br />
selected. This depends on the types of interaction with the environment that the proposed project is<br /><br />
expected to have, given its component activities and area of influence. VRs may include components<br /><br />
affected by routine project activities as well as non-routine events.<br /><br />
In order to aid the impact significance rating process, each VR has been categorised as being of<br /><br />
either low, medium or high environmental value. This is based on various factors, including the<br /><br />
resilience of the receptor, its vulnerability to disturbance, its current status within the region of<br /><br />
influence, and its value as a resource. The categorisation may also take into consideration local,<br /><br />
national or international designations and legal protection status, if appropriate. The categorisation is<br /><br />
designed to provide a broad ranking of the VRs, as follows:<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Project Environmental Aspects<br /><br />
The Project description provided in Chapter 3 of this document has been summarised into key<br /><br />
environmental aspects that will occur throughout the life of the project. An environmental aspect is an<br /><br />
element of the project's activities that can interact with the environment. The key environmental<br /><br />
aspects associated with the Project activities are presented in Appendix 2 Environmental Aspect<br /><br />
Register.<br /><br />
Impact Evaluation<br /><br />
An environmental impact can be considered as a change to the environment due to project activity.<br /><br />
Such change can be positive or negative. Environmental impacts may occur where an environmental<br /><br />
aspect (project activity) is denoted, and may be direct or indirect. The evaluation has been conducted<br /><br />
using the following basic criteria for defining an impact:<br /><br />
<br /><br />

•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Magnitude: this is an indication of the proportion of the VR that will experience the impact in<br /><br />
relation to the total resource within the project area. Impacts associated with project changes<br /><br />
that are widely distributed by nature are considered separately;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Spatial extent: the geographical area over which the impact is experienced (for some VRs this<br /><br />
can be equivalent to magnitude of impact); and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Duration: the length of time over which the impact will be experienced. An impact may be<br /><br />
present only while a project activity is active, or it could persist long after the project activity has<br /><br />
ceased, in which case the duration may be regarded as the time the VR needs to recover from<br /><br />
the effect.<br /><br />

<br /><br />

<br /><br />

Where there is any uncertainty, a higher figure is assigned to an impact criterion, so as to reduce the<br /><br />
chance of underestimating an impact (i.e., the precautionary principle is applied), thereby minimising<br /><br />
risk (Crowfoot et al. 1990).<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Mining Area<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.2<br /><br />
7.2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Air Quality<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
The most significant impacts on air quality may arise from dust emission generated during vegetation<br /><br />
clearance and earth movements (e.g., creation of new access routes, extraction of borrow material at<br /><br />
the mine, and surface grading and leveling for buildings and facilities construction). Pollutants emitted<br /><br />
by these activities are mainly coarse particles that do not result in human health effects.<br /><br />
Nevertheless, vegetation may be affected by particle deposition on leaves. Additionally, elevated<br /><br />
sedimentation in streams could occur with ensuing effects on aquatic organisms. This impact can be<br /><br />
mitigated by spraying the affected land surfaces with water under dry conditions.<br /><br />
Additionally, diesel generators used for power supply, vehicles and machinery exhaust gases will<br /><br />
contain several air pollutants (SO2, CO, NO2 and fine particles: PM10 and PM2.5). The use of efficient<br /><br />
machinery (vehicles, motors and pumps) and the use of a good practices policy will avoid<br /><br />
unnecessary fuel consumption (e.g., limit journeys, switch-off machinery when not in use, and reduce<br /><br />
diesel generators use to a minimum); and therefore, will minimise the potential impacts on air quality.<br /><br />
Other potential sources of air pollutants are uncontrolled fires used for cooking or heating and the<br /><br />
associated risk of the fire propagating. This impact could be controlled by instructing and supervising<br /><br />
construction contractors.<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
Activities undertaken in the mining area that may impact air quality are as follows:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Excavation works: Operations that involve blasting, drilling, movement of soil or exposure of<br /><br />
erodible surfaces will generate some volumes of fugitive dust. The majority of the particles<br /><br />
generated during these activities will exceed 10µm in size and will not be easily respired;<br /><br />
therefore, the emitted particles are not expected to generate impacts on human health. These<br /><br />
activities may impact air quality at the project boundaries, disturbing the nearest populations<br /><br />
and potentially reducing the photosynthesis capacity of vegetation by deposition on leaves.<br /><br />
The application of the proposed mitigation measures (see below) will reduce the negative<br /><br />
effects on air quality;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Material processing: The Crushing and Loading facility will be located southwest of Simbili.<br /><br />
The material processing emissions will be dependant on the mitigation measures to be<br /><br />
applied; properties of the material being disturbed (e.g. particles size or moisture content);<br /><br />
and meteorological conditions (wind speed and direction). Efficient mitigation measures at the<br /><br />
point sources (filters) and at the storage areas (water, chemical foam, partial enclosure for<br /><br />
screen or crushers and full enclosure) may reduce the potential effects;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Power supply generation: Generators and engines will produce exhaust emissions, the<br /><br />
amount of which will depend on the volume of fuel consumed and its sulphur content. The<br /><br />
expected pollutants are SO2, NOx, CO and PM10. Since the power requirements are not<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
excessive and the project might use power from external suppliers, the impact's extension<br /><br />
and magnitude are not expected to be high. Diesel generators should be designed to comply<br /><br />
with the air quality standards for compliance with occupational health conditions and<br /><br />
boundary sampling locations;<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Stockpiles: Total dust emissions from stockpiles result from various activities within the<br /><br />
storage cycle: loading of aggregate onto the storage pile, wind erosion of the pile and loading<br /><br />
of aggregate for continuing the process stream. Fines are easily released to the atmosphere<br /><br />
upon exposure to air currents; however, moisture can aggregate and bond fines to the<br /><br />
surfaces of larger particles and greatly reduce the potential of dust emission. Total particulate<br /><br />
emissions can be reduced from aggregate storage operations up to 90 percent (USEPA,<br /><br />
AP42 methodology, ref 13.2.4-1).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
Generic recommendations for reducing impacts from construction and operational phase activities are<br /><br />
listed below:<br /><br />
Reduction of air quality impacts from dust emissions:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Suppress dust during dry periods by spraying water onto potential sources for airborne<br /><br />
particles (e.g., unpaved roads, stockpiles, earth being moved);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Cover truck loads to avoid dust emissions during transportation;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Keep vehicle movements to a minimum and use paved areas, where possible;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Minimise discharge heights from trucks (not to exceed 1 m) for fine particles and consider the<br /><br />
use of dust suppression spray systems;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Design stockpiles based on the wind pattern and consider installing windscreens;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Considering the installation of filters in the design of the Crushing and Loading Facility.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reduction of air quality impacts from engine emissions:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Review machinery permits and ensure appropriate maintenance;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Limit unnecessary journeys and adopt a policy of switching off machinery and equipment<br /><br />
when not in use;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Consider a choice of machinery, equipment, vehicles and materials that are fuel-efficient as<br /><br />
part of the purchasing procedure.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reduction of impacts from controlled and uncontrolled fires (airborne emissions):<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Avoid uncontrolled fires;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Open fires will be prohibited. To limit air emissions, avoid accidents and reduce fire risk<br /><br />
during the construction phase;<br /><br />

TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.2.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Noise<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
Sources of noise emissions associated with the construction phase may include noise from<br /><br />
machinery engines, vehicles used for transport, loading and unloading of rock and materials, chutes<br /><br />
and power generation. Potential impacts are not limited to the project boundaries and will propagate<br /><br />
beyond. Mitigation measures described in this section should be applied near the populated areas<br /><br />
located close to the potential noise sources. Of special interest are villages close to the roads where<br /><br />
traffic will be high (Farangbaia, Wandugu and Furia).<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
The Phase 1 Mining Area spans the crest of Simbili and includes an area that extends 4 km southeast<br /><br />
to southwest, as shown in the project description from which the following information can be drawn:<br /><br />
Potential impacts on the bottom and top camps were analysed in the same manner as for villages on<br /><br />
the basis that residential use is projected for both camps. It is noted that the bottom camp will also be<br /><br />
used for laundry, kitchen, offices and vehicle parking.<br /><br />
For the purposes of this ESHIA, the following qualitative analysis describes the likely impacts:<br /><br />
Mining Activities<br /><br />
Mining activities will result in an increase in sound levels due to the operation of machinery.<br /><br />
The equipment to be used will consist of 3 hydraulic shovels (operating weight 380 t) and 21 haul<br /><br />
trucks (payload capacity 130-140 t). Blasting will occur twice per week and will generally be confined<br /><br />
to within the top 20 m of the excavation.<br /><br />
Ancillary equipment will include 2 water carts (130 t capacity), three track dozers (Caterpillar D10 or<br /><br />
equivalent), and 2 graders (Caterpillar 16 M or equivalent).<br /><br />
Machinery movements and motors will generate noise, but the potential impacts on ambient noise will<br /><br />
be limited to within 500 m of the sources. Assuming that occupational health limits are maintained for<br /><br />
noise power limits at the facility boundaries (85 dB(A)) then it is predicted that appropriate<br /><br />
environmental noise standards will be met at a distance of 500m from the facilities.<br /><br />
The noise from a blasting explosion in a canyon between mountains can be propagated over large<br /><br />
distances from the source, but as the blasting noise frequencies are low (2 to 25 Hz) the equivalent<br /><br />
dB(A) will be much lower than the ambient noise values. Audible frequencies are above 20 Hz. If AML<br /><br />
maintain blasting operation standards then the noise power and sound pressure at receptors should<br /><br />
be limited to within acceptable environmental noise standards within a distance of 500m from the<br /><br />
facilities.<br /><br />
If the expected safety measures are in place, the generated sound pressure levels dB(A) should not<br /><br />
generate impacts at the nearest receptors located several kilometres from the site.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Noise impacts generated from blasting will be dependent on the following:<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Blasting conditions (e.g., amount of explosive, hole size and depth and rock type);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Noise propagation conditions defined by the terrain.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Contractors Workshop<br /><br />
No specific information was available regarding the equipment that will be used in the workshop;<br /><br />
however, the close proximity of this facility to the camps and to Farangbaia village will necessitate<br /><br />
further layout planning to avoid noise impacts. Depending on the outcome of the lay-out planning<br /><br />
further mitigation measures such as attenuation screens may be required.<br /><br />
The nearest residential areas are located approximately 600 m from the facility, so it is not expected<br /><br />
that the populations will be significantly affected. Assuming that occupational health limits are<br /><br />
maintained for noise power limits at the facility boundaries (85 dB(A)) then it is predicted that<br /><br />
appropriate environmental noise standards will be met at a distance of 500m from the facilities.<br /><br />
Crushing and Loading Facility<br /><br />
No specific information was available regarding the acoustical emission of the equipment that will<br /><br />
produce noise in the facility; however, the proximity to Furia and the cumulative effect expected from<br /><br />
truck traffic indicate that mitigation measures should be applied or the village should be resettled.<br /><br />
The Aircraft Stand<br /><br />
Due to the proximity of the Aircraft Stand to villages and the camps, possible noise impacts, though<br /><br />
limited, must be studied. The air strip is only expected to be used for transporting mine workers and<br /><br />
hence aircraft movements will be scheduled according to staff mobilisation, as opposed to freight<br /><br />
movement.<br /><br />
The Aircraft Stand will likely be used for urgent shipments and light-aircraft, and a noise buffer around<br /><br />
the Stand and into the Farangbaia village should be considered. Aircraft noise is expected to be<br /><br />
directed primarily in concert with the take-off direction, and to a lesser extent in the landing direction.<br /><br />
Aircraft take-off routes should avoid populated or sensitive areas within 2 to 6 km, depending on the<br /><br />
aircraft to be used and the take-off routes. A more detailed assessment should be conducted before<br /><br />
the airstrip operations begin when the types and schedule of aircraft are known.<br /><br />
Roads<br /><br />
Both of the camps and the villages, Farangbaia, Wandugu and Furia, are located near unpaved roads<br /><br />
on which the volume of vehicle and truck traffic will be high. Due to the high noise levels expected<br /><br />
from these roads, noise at the camp accommodation buildings might exceed the Environmental,<br /><br />
Health, and Safety (EHS) IFC Guidelines for residential areas (45 dB(A) at night and 55 dB(A) during<br /><br />
the day). The camp design shall avoid locating the accommodation buildings and medical centres<br /><br />
near the road.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
Noise emissions may occur during each stage of the mine cycle, in particular during construction and<br /><br />
operational activities.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Generic recommendations for reducing impacts from activities to be conducted during the<br /><br />
construction phase of the project are listed below:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Use machinery and generators with ‘quiet’, ‘muffled’ or ‘silenced’ settings, when available;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Consider choices of machinery and equipment that guarantee low noise emissions;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
As long as hoppers and dumper boxes are more than 500m from residential areas there is no<br /><br />
need for any special mitigation measure. If this machinery is within 500m then it is<br /><br />
recommended that elastic coatings are used;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Limit unnecessary journeys and adopt a policy of switching off machinery and equipment<br /><br />
when not in use;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Optimise internal-traffic routing to reduce the need to reverse vehicles (avoiding noise from<br /><br />
the reversing alarm) and to allow the maximum distances possible between traffic and the<br /><br />
nearest sensitive receptors;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Conduct regular inspections and maintenance of construction vehicles and equipment to<br /><br />
maintain smooth operation; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Limit vehicle speeds in the vicinity of populated areas.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The preventive and corrective measures to reduce the impact on noise pressure during the<br /><br />
operational activities are defined below:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Correct blast design and charging is essential and should include a survey of the face profile<br /><br />
prior to design and continuous review of charge requirements.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The setting-out and drilling of blasts should be as accurate as possible, the drilled holes<br /><br />
should be surveyed for deviation along their lengths, and the blast design should be adjusted,<br /><br />
if necessary.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Particular care is necessary with a first blast. It may otherwise give rise to abnormally high<br /><br />
overpressure and vibration because there is no free face to give relief to the forces produced.<br /><br />
Blast noise is usually controlled by limiting the amount of explosive and employing staggered<br /><br />
detonation. Problems may occur if there are faults in the strata and other forms of<br /><br />
heterogeneity; blasting in tight corners; blasting near made ground; excessive charge and<br /><br />
non-compliance with manufacturers' tolerances/errors in explosives or detonators.<br /><br />
It is<br /><br />
assumed that expert computerised firing sequence control would remove most risk<br /><br />
associated with operator's error resulting in simultaneous detonation of more than one<br /><br />
charge/hole/deck.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Noise levels will need to be monitored under normal and blasting conditions considering the<br /><br />
day and night noise limits. If cumulative noise levels are exceeding criteria for sensitive<br /><br />
receptors, additional mitigation measures should be defined, such as sound barriers. If the<br /><br />
source of noise will not bee effectively mitigated by these barriers (e.g. due to aircraft noise),<br /><br />
then additional measures should be considered, such as noise isolation at the sensitive<br /><br />
receptors.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.2.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ecology & Biodiversity<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
It is noted that impacts associated with Phase 1 mining activities overlap with likely impacts from the<br /><br />
other phases and may become more significant as the scale of the mining operations increases in the<br /><br />
course of the next project phases.<br /><br />
Vegetation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Conservation importance<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The principal direct impacts will arise from the clearance of land within the footprint of the open pit<br /><br />
and associated infrastructure and the burial of vegetation in waste dump areas which will have a longterm to permanent impact on the current vegetation coverage. Vegetation that is not cleared or buried<br /><br />
may be indirectly impacted by alteration of drainage patterns and exposure to contaminated surface<br /><br />
runoff (contaminants may include petroleum products from operations and also mobilised trace<br /><br />
metals present in the hematite ore deposit). Further impacts may arise through the spread of invasive<br /><br />
species. These may also spread to undisturbed land following natural colonisation or deliberate<br /><br />
introduction in disturbed areas (where such species tend to thrive). An influx of people to the area will<br /><br />
increase the pressure on resources (e.g. clearance of land for agricultural use, subsistence and<br /><br />
commercial logging of timber). Impacts on fauna may further reduce natural colonisation by<br /><br />
indigenous plant species where fauna play a role in seed dispersal. The impact classification of these<br /><br />
impacts is influenced by the nature of the vegetation present in the area being impacted (defined as<br /><br />
high and low conservation importance for semi-natural or degraded vegetation respectively):<br /><br />
<br /><br />
High<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Low<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Major<br /><br />
Land clearance;<br /><br />
burial; drainage<br /><br />
alteration;<br /><br />
exposure to<br /><br />
contaminated runoff; spread of alien<br /><br />
invasive species<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Impact classification<br /><br />
Moderate<br /><br />
Minor<br /><br />
Increased local<br /><br />
human population;<br /><br />
reduced<br /><br />
dispersion of<br /><br />
seeds by fauna<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Land clearance;<br /><br />
burial; drainage<br /><br />
alteration; spread<br /><br />
of alien invasive<br /><br />
species<br /><br />
<br /><br />

contaminated runoff<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Increased local<br /><br />
human population;<br /><br />
reduced<br /><br />
dispersion of<br /><br />
seeds by fauna<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Terrestrial Fauna<br /><br />
The most significant potential impact is a change in species diversity and abundance (and potentially<br /><br />
a loss of species of conservation concern) through habitat loss and fragmentation directly associated<br /><br />
with the mining activities (such as vegetation removal) and indirectly through increased pressure due<br /><br />
to population influx on the resources in the area (such as increased vegetation removal for timber<br /><br />
supply and use as agricultural land). Displacement of terrestrial fauna may also occur through<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 137<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
increased sensory disturbance as a result of the mining activities. Increases in local human<br /><br />
populations may increase hunting and bushmeat consumption. Bushmeat is an important source of<br /><br />
protein for local villages around the mining area. Food shortage has been identified in the social<br /><br />
surveys as an issue facing many villages, and therefore any significant ecological impacts (such as<br /><br />
ongoing displacement of fauna) as a result of the project-related activities may have indirect social<br /><br />
impacts. The impact classification of these impacts is as follows:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Major: habitat loss, habitat fragmentation, habitat disturbance and increase in hunting.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Moderate: displacement of fauna.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Aquatic Ecosystems<br /><br />
The most significant potential impact is a decrease in species richness and abundance through<br /><br />
deterioration of water quality in the area. Deterioration of water quality may occur through increased<br /><br />
sedimentation in aquatic environments as a result of sediment mobilisation during construction and<br /><br />
operation and / or changes in water chemistry that may arise from sediment runoff or acid rock<br /><br />
drainage from the mining activities (depending on the geochemical characteristics of the overburden /<br /><br />
ore). Direct modification of the aquatic environments within the vicinity of the Simbili deposit may also<br /><br />
occur during Phase 1 (for example diversion or obstruction of surface waters), which may cause the<br /><br />
loss of locally endemic species and concomitant impacts on subsistence fishing and food availability<br /><br />
for local populations. All of these impacts are classified as major.<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
The primary impact during the operations phase will be caused by the increase in population. This will<br /><br />
have regional significance for biodiversity and ecology receptors. This could create unintended<br /><br />
consequential impacts associated with increase in access and demand for natural resources.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures have been identified for significant ecology and biodiversity issues:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Forest on hillslopes and Riverine forest are the most important habitats of conservation<br /><br />
concern in the wider Simbili pit area. Mining infrastructure should be planned outside the<br /><br />
forest patches and if this is not possible, a botanist should survey the affected forest well in<br /><br />
advance of the construction work to allow possible adjustments to be made.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Roads should be kept to the minimum width possible, commensurate with relevant design<br /><br />
and safety standards.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Minor in-stream infrastructure can constitute barriers to fish migration. Where possible, these<br /><br />
should be designed to be compatible with the passage of migratory stream organisms, and<br /><br />
crossings of any drainage lines or water bodies should have appropriate culverts built to<br /><br />
international environmental standards.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Plants belonging to species with conservation status Endangered (EN) or of Conservation<br /><br />
Importance (CR) should at all times be left undisturbed. Plants belonging to species with<br /><br />
conservation status Vulnerable (VU) should be left undisturbed as much as possible.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 138<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Species of conservation concern which were found on the deposits or near proposed<br /><br />
infrastructure should be relocated to suitable localities outside the project area, by way of<br /><br />
seed collection and / or translocation of specimens.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Replanting of vegetation should use indigenous species and should be based on silvicultural<br /><br />
systems that promote natural ecosystem functions and that increase the probability that<br /><br />
native species and ecological processes will be maintained. Planting of exotic species in<br /><br />
natural forest areas should not be permitted.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Establish and enforce a total ban on the hunting and capture of wildlife by company<br /><br />
employees and contractors.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Recognizing the importance of wildlife as a protein source to indigenous peoples, government<br /><br />
and the company should cooperate with local communities in the development of sustainable,<br /><br />
community-based wildlife management programs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project affected communities should be supported in the development of improved animal<br /><br />
husbandry techniques and provided with starter stocks. This would be a positive contribution<br /><br />
to the livelihoods of people and also reduce demand for bushmeat and limit the impact of<br /><br />
hunting restrictions on local communities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The project should investigate the potential for supporting local plantations, which would be<br /><br />
beneficial to the project, local livelihoods and the remaining natural forests (and therefore,<br /><br />
also for fauna).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Work with government to explore opportunities to control and minimise the uncontrolled inmigration of people into areas newly opened-up by road construction, especially along the<br /><br />
roads themselves. Uncontrolled in-migration will lead to further forest and wildlife losses and<br /><br />
compound pressures on existing human communities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Consider biodiversity offsets to compensate for the unavoidable habitat loss (including<br /><br />
vegetation and fauna).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increased sedimentation in the aquatic environments due to mobilization of sediments may<br /><br />
subsequently result in a change in fish distribution, with more turbid-tolerant species<br /><br />
becoming prevalent. Best practice erosion and sediment control measures should be<br /><br />
implemented during construction to minimise the significance of this impact.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.2.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hydrology & Hydrogeology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
Assessment of potential impacts on the hydrological and hydrogeological setting have been<br /><br />
conducted based on a Phase 2B – Reconnaissance Level baseline assessment carried out during<br /><br />
February March and April 2010. The following potential impacts have been identified during the<br /><br />
construction phase:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Erosion of exposed surfaces and loose material by wind, water and construction activities<br /><br />
generating higher sediment loads in surface runoff entering the Tonkolili and Mawuru Rivers<br /><br />
and their tributaries.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increased potable and construction water demand may lead to over-abstraction of surface<br /><br />
water from nearby rivers leading to impacts on environmental flows and/or downstream users.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Uncontrolled discharge of sewage and other waste water to groundwater or directly to surface<br /><br />
water contaminating freshwater aquifers, waterways and impacting on human health and/or<br /><br />
aquatic ecosystems.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Uncontrolled release of drilling fluids associated with ongoing exploration, geotechnical or<br /><br />
hydrogeological drilling works. Potential impacts on aquatic ecosystems and downstream<br /><br />
potable water supply.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Modification and interruption of the existing hydrological regime of the Tonkolili and Mawuru<br /><br />
catchments. Excavation of the weathered cap of Simbili will interrupt the flow of several<br /><br />
springs discharging from the flanks of the deposit providing base flow to both rivers.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Alteration to the natural hydrologic regime of both catchments as excess water produced<br /><br />
during dewatering of the weathered cap is discharged.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increased flood risk and/or increased flow rates in rivers following storm events due to the<br /><br />
loss of the buffering capacity of the Simbili weathered cap aquifer.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increased water demand on site may lead to over abstraction from surface water bodies<br /><br />
leading to reduced environmental flows and impacts on downstream users.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Generation of contaminated runoff where rainfall infiltration comes in contact with stockpiled<br /><br />
waste rock. Rainfall infiltrating through the Phase 1 waste rock dump may become acidic<br /><br />
and/or leach metals from the waste rock before entering groundwater and surface water. Low<br /><br />
natural chemical buffering potential of groundwater and surface water exacerbates this risk.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The use of specific units of waste rock that may potentially be acid generating for construction<br /><br />
purposes could lead to surface and groundwater contamination.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />

Page 143<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increased recharge of rainfall to groundwater beneath waste rock dumps. The porous waste<br /><br />
rock dump may promote greater rainfall recharge and create a localised groundwater mound<br /><br />
beneath the dump potentially water-logging surrounding soils.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Uncontrolled release of toxic chemicals to the environment. A range of chemicals will be<br /><br />
stored and used during construction and mining activities. The most common chemicals<br /><br />
likely to be used are hydrocarbons (diesel fuel, oil and grease) and solvents. Where toxic<br /><br />
chemicals are present, the potential for spillages will exist.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures have been identified for hydrology and hydrogeology issues that<br /><br />
are considered to have a significant impact:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Robust surface and groundwater monitoring programmes in order to establish comprehensive<br /><br />
baseline and identify any impacts to flows, turbidity and chemistry.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Treatment of all potentially contaminated wastewater sources prior to discharge to ground or<br /><br />
surface.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Acid Mine Drainage (AMD) study to assess likelihood of formation of acid waters from waste<br /><br />
rock dumps or areas where waste rock may be used as a fill or construction material.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Acid-base accounting of waste rock material to be applied in assessment of optimal dump<br /><br />
locations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Appropriate engineering design measures to contain and capture potentially contaminated<br /><br />
water escaping rock dumps.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Detailed hydrological study to determine minimum required environmental flows in rivers<br /><br />
which may be affected by construction and mining operations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hydrochemical environmental study to determine potential sensitivity of local receptors to<br /><br />
changes in surface water and groundwater chemistry.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.2.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Soils & Land Use<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
The principal direct impact will arise from land clearance or sterilisation / burial, leading to long-term<br /><br />
or permanent loss of soil resources and existing land-use capabilities at Simbili. Additional impacts<br /><br />
on soils that are not cleared or sterilised include contamination by windblown dusts (from bare<br /><br />
ground, blasting activities and plant movements), increased erosion or inundation due to the<br /><br />
modification of drainage patterns, compaction from vibration and loading under temporary<br /><br />
stockpiles/structures, contamination with hydrocarbons and other chemicals including diesel and<br /><br />
lubricant oils and explosives residues. Invasive species may also spread to undisturbed land following<br /><br />
natural colonisation or deliberate introduction in disturbed areas (where such species tend to thrive).<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
Operational stage works in the mine area will primarily result in ongoing impacts for soil and land use<br /><br />
as defined for the construction stage. Land clearance or sterilisation will increase with development<br /><br />
of the resource strip and associated infrastructure and expansion of waste dumps and access routes.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures have been identified for soils and land use issues that are<br /><br />
considered to have a significant impact:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Minimise land / soil to be cleared or buried and concentrate such activities in areas with<br /><br />
limited soil quality and land-use capability.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Consider biodiversity offsets for unavoidable long-term and permanent soil / land clearance<br /><br />
and soil / land burial. Integrate livelihoods components as necessary with offsets to replace<br /><br />
lost land-use capability.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Prior to commencement of mining, prepare a waste rock management plan and rehabilitation<br /><br />
programme to include designs for progressive rehabilitation/re-vegetation of suitable areas<br /><br />
throughout the mining lifecycle in order to minimise cleared / buried areas. Inspect and<br /><br />
monitor rehabilitated surfaces to establish success of revegetation and soils recovery.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implement appropriate conservation and preservation of stripped top-soils and sub-soils from<br /><br />
all areas to retain physical and chemical characteristics and seed-bank for subsequent use<br /><br />
for rehabilitation activities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implement required storm water drainage and control prior to prevent erosion of exposed<br /><br />
areas and inundation of down-slope areas.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Minimise access by vehicles to essential areas to reduce compaction of soils.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Isolate and manage potential soil contaminants (including wind blown dusts and water-borne<br /><br />
contaminants).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Avoid disturbance / exposure of acid sulphate soils if present.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Avoid deliberate introduction of alien invasive species during rehabilitation activities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Manage pathways by which alien invasive species can enter a disturbed area (including<br /><br />
avoidance of non-indigenous plant species in rehabilitation activities).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Undertake studies to determine appropriate recolonisation programme for impacted areas.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Table 7-7 Mining Area - Soils and Land Use<br /><br />
Aspect<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.2.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Geology & Geomorphology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
The impacts associated with major mine construction such as stripping of surface vegetation, soils,<br /><br />
and deposits include changes in slope stability and topography and local drainage and spring flow.<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
Impact of the mining inevitably includes loss of the non renewable resource itself. Mining in general<br /><br />
can commonly sterilise associated deposits of lower value or undiscovered resources making them<br /><br />
effectively inaccessible beneath waste rock and tailings. Some of the low value ‘sterilised’ deposits<br /><br />
may become economically viable in the future with increase in market value of the commodity.<br /><br />
There will be major changes to the landscape with the top of Simbili hill being effectively removed<br /><br />
while substantial overburden and rock waste dumps will be formed nearby.<br /><br />
Stripping of overburden will be followed by mining of the hematite which will lead to further impacts on<br /><br />
topography and drainage as it forms the upper Simbili hill outcrop. However the hematite also<br /><br />
overlies BIF deposits that are to be mined under Phase 3 and ultimately the entire hill will be mined<br /><br />
out and an opencast pit extend beneath ground level. Phase 3 and associated cumulative impacts<br /><br />
will be addressed in a Stage 2 ESHIA report.<br /><br />
Mining of the upper hematite deposit will initiate changes in runoff patterns and erosion and<br /><br />
sedimentation rates potentially impacting permanently on local geomorphology. Construction of mine<br /><br />
infrastructure may have similar but lower level impacts.<br /><br />
Blasting of hard rock layers throughout the mining may destabilize soils and trigger landslides with<br /><br />
very localized impacts on geomorphology.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures have been identified for geology and geomorphology issues that<br /><br />
are considered to have a significant impact:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Although a major impact, the loss of the exploitable ore body is the purpose of the mining<br /><br />
activity. The impact can be outweighed by the opportunity presented by exploitation of the<br /><br />
resource though adherence to a resource management and mine plan which maximises the<br /><br />
efficiency of resource extraction and ensures that stakeholders derive the maximum potential<br /><br />
benefit. Without appropriate considered management through processes such as ESHIA and<br /><br />
good governance, potential long term detrimental impacts on the local and national economy<br /><br />
and community can outweigh the short term gains.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Risk of sterilising future resources can be mitigated in part by ensuring adequate exploration<br /><br />
has been completed both for definition of the ore body to be exploited and areas that will be<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
covered by waste rock, tailings and other major structures such as the raw water supply dam<br /><br />
and associated inundation zone. However there is a limit to mitigation that can be applied to<br /><br />
prevent sterilisation of low grade deposits that may become economically viable in the future.<br /><br />
Such deposits may inevitably be lost as potential future resources due to burial beneath<br /><br />
waste materials or further to flooding of mined out pits.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Geomorphological mitigation measures include the preservation of watercourses (where<br /><br />
possible) and diversion of watercourses around infrastructure to maintain downstream<br /><br />
drainage patterns, rehabilitation and revegetation of disturbed areas, and re-contouring<br /><br />
disturbed areas to original topography (to the extent possible).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Appropriate management measures need to be addressed (see Commitments Register ,<br /><br />
section 12) to avoid instabilities include appropriate mine design (so that slopes do not fail),<br /><br />
adopting the correct slope angle, benching of slopes, including appropriate drainage around<br /><br />
the slopes (and the toe and crest of the slopes) and incorporating stand offs at the base of the<br /><br />
slopes to prevent impacts on people if instabilities do occur.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reclaim and rehabilitate land disturbed during construction and operation by re-grading, recontouring and replacing topsoil following closure and decommissioning.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reuse excavated material, where possible, for further construction and earth works, in order<br /><br />
to minimise the necessity for construction-associated quarrying in the area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reduce harmful effects on the shape of the landscape (scars) through minimising the<br /><br />
development of potential geotechnical failure surfaces. Well-designed blasting programmes<br /><br />
and mining techniques should be followed to minimise the creation of these geotechnical<br /><br />
issues.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.2.7<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Socio-Economic<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
Land acquisition<br /><br />
Depending on the final footprint area for hematite mining, some villages may require resettlement.<br /><br />
Villages on the periphery of mining area will suffer loss of land resulting in loss of shelter, loss of<br /><br />
access to agricultural land, artisanal mining sites and natural resources leading to decrease in<br /><br />
economic stability. There are also likely to be graves and sacred sites within the footprint area that will<br /><br />
require relocation.<br /><br />
Land acquisition related impacts can result in long-term and severe impacts on social and economic<br /><br />
well being of affected populations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
The socio-economic benefits of hematite mining (lasting about 8 years) will mainly be in the form of<br /><br />
wages, disbursement for the procurement of supplies, social investments and payment of revenue to<br /><br />
the government. The negative impacts will mainly be due to disturbance to land owners and influx of<br /><br />
workers and job seekers.<br /><br />
Economic aspects<br /><br />
The economic impacts are mainly beneficial in nature:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mining will generate employment during both construction and operation phases. It will<br /><br />
mainly benefit Kalansogia and neighbouring chiefdoms, although skilled manpower will<br /><br />
also be sourced from other districts.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Business opportunities for suppliers and contractors at the district and national levels.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Payment to Government of Sierra Leone in the form of taxes, royalties and duties.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project induced influx of workers and job seekers<br /><br />
The economic opportunities created by the Project are expected to lead to an influx of workers and<br /><br />
job seekers (as has already happened in Farangbaia Village). This can result in the following<br /><br />
negative impacts:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Pressure on social infrastructure and natural resources.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increases in social ills such as crime, alcoholism, drug abuse and prostitution.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increases in communicable diseases due to intermingling of the local population with<br /><br />
outsiders.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increases in the cost of living and potential for conflict with migrants.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />

<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Community investment<br /><br />
The social investment programme of AML developed in consultation with local stakeholders is<br /><br />
expected to result in the following benefits to the community:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increases in education and skills levels.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Improvement in social infrastructure such as water supply, schools and health centres.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Development of livelihood opportunities, independent of the mine.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Other initiatives to address community needs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mine closure<br /><br />
Closure impacts have not been assessed for the Phase 1 project as completion of hematite mining<br /><br />
will lead into the larger magnetite mining project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures are expected to reduce the intensity of the residual impacts from<br /><br />
major to moderate/minor.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a Resettlement Action Plan (RAP).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a livelihood restoration plan.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implementation of a grievance mechanism.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation and implementation of a Community Development Plan.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
Project induced influx of workers and job seekers<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures are expected to minimise the impacts from major to<br /><br />
moderate/minor:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Planning with relevant stakeholders to minimise speculative migration.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Providing assistance to local government to increase (and improve) infrastructure<br /><br />
services.<br /><br />

7.2.8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Human Health<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction & Operations<br /><br />
Based on the current available project and existing health information, preliminary impacts at Phase 1<br /><br />
have been identified for the mine area. It is important to note, that the Project description has not<br /><br />
been finalized, nor has all the baseline data been analysed, therefore, the qualitative impact<br /><br />
designations and significance may change as the Phase 1 details are finalized.<br /><br />
The preliminary health impacts associated with Phase 1 mine area are described below. Impacts<br /><br />
relate to both phases of the project (construction and operation) unless otherwise stated.<br /><br />
Potential negative impacts of major significance:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Community resettlement;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In-migration related impacts (disease, food security, substance abuse, home violence);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increased burden of disease due project activities and water storage facilities (drinking water<br /><br />
tanks, waste and raw water storage ponds);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Degradation and/or reduction of surface water (sedimentation/erosion, contamination, changes in<br /><br />
drainage patterns); and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Degradation of groundwater quality.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential negative impacts of moderate significance:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increased road traffic accident rate (during operation phase);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Impacts of noise on health and well-being (blasting and heavy vehicle activity); and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reduction in quality or quantity of locally produced foods.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential negative impacts of minor or insignificant significance:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increased road traffic accident rate (during construction phase);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Exposure to increased levels of particulate matter (PM) (diesel power generators, crushers,<br /><br />
blasting, vehicles, road dust; assuming no thermal power generation requirements); and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Acute exposure to elevated SO2 and NO2 in air (diesel power generators, heavy vehicle<br /><br />
emissions) (assuming no thermal power generation requirements).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential positive impacts:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Access to improved healthcare facilities (for general public);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Health benefits to AML employees and through local employment;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AML financed community development initiatives;<br /><br />
<br /><br />

: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
