AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Improved access to the region; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Positive aspects of resettlement.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A number of assumptions were made for the preliminary impact assessment specific to the Phase 1<br /><br />
mine area. It was assumed that all communities on or within 500 m of the Project area were resettled<br /><br />
to a distance greater than 500 m before construction associated with each pit area is begun. Thus,<br /><br />
the Health VR used in the preliminary impact assessment for exposure to particulate matter (PM),<br /><br />
SO2, and NO2 was categorized as Medium (an AML employee, or HR2 see Table 7-1).<br /><br />
Also, with respect to PM, SO2, and NO2 emissions, it was assumed that a thermal power generating<br /><br />
facility (a potentially significant generator of these types of emissions) will not be built at the mine site.<br /><br />
If power generation arrangements are altered significantly from those described in Section 3, this<br /><br />
preliminary impact will require re-assessment. Should a thermal power generator be implemented, the<br /><br />
significance of the impact and the sensitivity of the VR would be expected to increase.<br /><br />
The positive class impacts associated with access to healthcare facilities only apply if AML undertake<br /><br />
to provide these facilities.<br /><br />
Where there was uncertainty in significance designation, the more conservative assumption was<br /><br />
selected so as to ensure that the preliminary potential impact of the Project was not underestimated.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
Potential mitigation measures have been identified in association with each headline health impact as<br /><br />
listed below. The headline impacts were identified with the assumption that no mitigating measures<br /><br />
were applied. Thus, implementation of the recommended mitigating measures is expected to reduce<br /><br />
the significance of the headline health issues and thus avoid potentially major health issues for<br /><br />
persons living in the vicinity of the Phase 1 mine area.<br /><br />
Health related mitigation measures are listed below, however, it is important to note that mitigation<br /><br />
recommended by the other disciplines, particularly socio-economic as well as other environmental<br /><br />
assessments (e.g., air, surface and groundwater, flora and fauna) can also affect human health.<br /><br />
Alteration of the current project description and further monitoring results may result in the<br /><br />
recommendation of additional mitigation measures, or modification of those currently recommended.<br /><br />
Community resettlement<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Social mitigation measures regarding loss of land and re-settlement (see social assessment<br /><br />
results and mitigation measures).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In-migration related impacts (disease, food security, substance abuse, home violence)<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Adherence to the requirements of the Prevention and Control of HIV and AIDS Act.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Appropriate education of workforce regarding transmittable diseases.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Employing local labour where appropriate.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

tanks, waste and raw water ponds).<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Transport Corridor<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.3<br /><br />
7.3.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Air Quality<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
The air quality impacts produced during the haul road construction and rail refurbishment are<br /><br />
common to the other project construction activities:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dust emissions during vegetation clearance along the haul road route and temporal access<br /><br />
routes for the construction phase.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Particles emissions caused by earth movements: creation of temporary access routes and<br /><br />
grading and levelling of the haul road route.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Material and waste management: dust emissions during loading and unloading activities and<br /><br />
wind erosion of the stockpiles.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Vehicles transport and operation of heavy equipment will generate exhaust emissions and<br /><br />
increase dust due to movements over unpaved roads.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It should be noted that some sections of the transport corridor are close to populated areas. At these<br /><br />
locations, mitigation measures described below should be implemented.<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
Air emissions will depend on the frequency and the fuel consumption of vehicles that travel the haul<br /><br />
road (approximately 120 km long) and the train emissions between Marampa and Pepel. The<br /><br />
contaminants of potential concern are listed below:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Exhaust emissions from the vehicles and the train (NOx, SO2, PM10 and CO)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dust from the material transport and the haul road traffic. These emissions will be mainly<br /><br />
coarse particulate matter larger than 10 µm with little effect on human health, but with<br /><br />
potential effects on vegetation and on near residents due to disturbance.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Exhaust gas emissions can be controlled by minimising fuel consumption and maintaining train and<br /><br />
truck motors. Dust emissions can be controlled by covering wagons and trucks to avoid airborne<br /><br />
particulate matter.<br /><br />
The potential impact on air quality will be restricted to a buffer zone along the haul road and the<br /><br />
railway. As detailed in the project description, all villages were provided with a clearance of at least<br /><br />
500 m during the route selection assessment. Topographical constraints do not allow for avoiding all<br /><br />
of the residential areas along the haul road and the train corridor. For those populated areas located<br /><br />
close to the transport corridor, additional mitigation measures should be implemented<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Additionally, a stockpile with an approximate capacity of 4 million tonnes will be located at Lunsar<br /><br />
Interchange. Storage piles may be sources of dust emissions during loading and unloading activities<br /><br />
and due to wind erosion of the pile.<br /><br />
The potential for particles emissions will depend on the stored material size, the total stockpile<br /><br />
surface and the wind speeds. Emissions can be reduced by up to 90 percent with appropriate<br /><br />
mitigation measures (USEPA, AP42, ref 13.2.4-1).<br /><br />
Loading mining product onto the train wagons should be conducted using a Car Dumper Dust<br /><br />
Collector to minimise dust emissions. The Car Dumper Dust Collector will filter dust emissions with an<br /><br />
efficiency of 99%.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
The following recommendations for reducing impacts on air quality from activities associated with<br /><br />
transport corridor construction are generic mitigation measures that should be applied during the<br /><br />
entire construction phase.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dust suppression measures should be applied, such as spraying water during dry seasons on<br /><br />
unpaved roads and stockpiles. Vehicle movements should be minimised, truck loads should<br /><br />
be covered with mesh to avoid dust emissions, and discharge heights from trucks should not<br /><br />
typically exceed 1 m.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Exhaust emissions should be minimised through the use of fuel efficient machinery and<br /><br />
appropriate machinery maintenance. Unnecessary journeys should be avoided, and a policy<br /><br />
of switching off machinery when not in use should be implemented. Uncontrolled fires will be<br /><br />
prohibited.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The negative impacts on air quality during the operation of the transport corridor can be minimised<br /><br />
through the following measures:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Avoid unnecessary journeys and optimise transport traffic<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Regular maintenance of vehicles and machinery<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Avoid airborne dust during transport by covering the truck and train loads, and/or select<br /><br />
closed wagons for transport by train<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Minimise discharge heights (not to exceed 1 m) for fine particles and consider the use of dust<br /><br />
suppression spray systems<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Spray trailer boxes, wheels and undersides with water before leaving the mine site<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Suppress dust emissions from the stockpiles during dry periods by spraying the surface with<br /><br />
water.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

7.3.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Noise<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
The following noise emission sources during the transport corridor construction are common to almost<br /><br />
all construction activities:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Machinery engines used during construction activities, e.g., clearance, road widening,<br /><br />
profiling and sealing<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Vehicles used for transport<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Loading and unloading rock, construction materials and waste<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Motors and other construction equipment (compressors, dozers, etc.)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Diesel engines used for energy supply<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It should be noted that some sections of the transport corridor are close to populated areas. At these<br /><br />
locations, mitigation measures described below should be implemented.<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
Noise sources along the transport corridor will arise from road trains and railway stock that will use<br /><br />
the existing railway line between Lunsar (Marampa) and Pepel.<br /><br />
The potential impact will be restricted to a buffer zone along the haul road and the railway. During the<br /><br />
route selection assessment, all villages were provided a clearance of at least 500 m. Topographical<br /><br />
constraints do not allow for avoiding all of the residential areas along the haul road and the train<br /><br />
corridor. For those populated areas located close to the transport corridor, additional mitigation<br /><br />
measures should be implemented where the sound levels might exceed the Environmental, Health,<br /><br />
and Safety (EHS) IFC Guidelines for residential areas (45 dB(A) at night and 55 dB(A) during the<br /><br />
day).<br /><br />
The design of the mitigation measures will require study before the beginning of the haul road and<br /><br />
train operations considering the distance of the nearest buildings within the villages to the transport<br /><br />
corridor.<br /><br />
Additionally, the loading and offloading of ore in the Lunsar Interchange area will constitute an<br /><br />
important noise source, and mitigation measures should be applied.<br /><br />
Community safety regarding noise emissions as one of the environmental aspects will be addressed<br /><br />
through a Community Safety Plan to be developed by AML and rolled out in conjunction with the<br /><br />
EWCC.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
Noise prevention measures for the construction phase include the use of machinery and equipment<br /><br />
that guarantee low noise emissions and the regular inspections and maintenance of construction<br /><br />

<br /><br />
vehicles and equipment. Journeys will be limited to only those necessary and a policy of switching off<br /><br />
machinery and equipment when not in use will be implemented. Vehicle speeds will be limited in the<br /><br />
vicinity of populated areas.<br /><br />
Recommendations for reducing impacts on noise levels from the transport activities are listed below:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Select vehicles and equipment that guarantee low noise emissions<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Avoid unnecessary journeys and optimise transport traffic<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Conduct regular inspections and maintenance of vehicles and equipment to maintain smooth<br /><br />
operation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Limit vehicle speeds in the vicinity of populated areas<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mitigations measures, such as sound barriers, should be installed where ambient noise levels<br /><br />
may be exceeded. When these barriers are not effective, additional measures should be<br /><br />
considered, such as noise isolation at sensitive receptors.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

7.3.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ecology & Biodiversity<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction and Operations<br /><br />
Vegetation<br /><br />
The principal impact will arise from the land clearance required for road construction, leading to the<br /><br />
removal of vegetation. Fragmentation of habitats may also occur. Outside the direct footprint of the<br /><br />
road, localised clearance of vegetation may occur in borrow areas (potential sources for bridge<br /><br />
construction materials). Invasive species may also spread to undisturbed land following natural<br /><br />
colonisation or deliberate introduction in disturbed areas (where such species tend to thrive).<br /><br />
Localised erosion or inundation of vegetated areas due to the modification of drainage patterns may<br /><br />
occur. Impacts on vegetation may occur due to disturbance during the refurbishment of the Delco rail<br /><br />
line. Impacts on rheophytes (aquatic plants) may occur at and downstream of river crossings as a<br /><br />
result of changes in fluvial geomorphology. Impacts on fauna may further reduce natural colonisation<br /><br />
by indigenous plant species where fauna play a role in seed dispersal. The classification of these<br /><br />
impacts is influenced by the nature of the vegetation present in the area being impacted (defined as<br /><br />
high, medium and low conservation importance):<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Conservation importance<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />

crossings<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Terrestrial Fauna<br /><br />
The most significant potential impact is a change in species diversity and abundance (and potentially<br /><br />
a loss of species of conservation concern) through habitat loss and fragmentation directly associated<br /><br />
with the construction of the transport corridor. Habitat alteration may occur through vegetation<br /><br />
removal and the construction of physical barriers within the habitat range of species (for example the<br /><br />
frequent train / vehicle movements may prevent migration across the transport corridor).<br /><br />
Displacement of terrestrial fauna may also occur through increased sensory disturbance as a result of<br /><br />
haul road traffic. The impact classification of these impacts is as follows:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />

<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Major: habitat loss, habitat fragmentation, habitat disturbance and increase in hunting.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Moderate: displacement of fauna.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Aquatic Ecosystems<br /><br />
The aquatic environments along the transport corridor could potentially be impacted by the<br /><br />
construction of new road crossings and the re-development of existing rail crossings. The most<br /><br />
significant impacts associated with the construction and redevelopment of crossings is uncontrolled<br /><br />
sedimentation (and increased turbidity) in aquatic environments from in-stream (such as piling) and<br /><br />
land disturbance activities (such as removal of riparian vegetation, construction of bridge foundations,<br /><br />
sourcing borrow material), changes to fluvial geomorphology and the introduction of physical barriers<br /><br />
to fish migration. Riparian vegetation can reduce runoff and trap potential water contaminants prior to<br /><br />
entering the watercourse. The direct removal of riparian vegetation for the construction of the<br /><br />
transport corridor may increase diffuse pollutant transport from the adjoining areas. The impact<br /><br />
classification of these impacts is as follows:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Major: changes to fluvial geomorphology, physical barriers.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Moderate: sedimentation / increased turbidity, entry of diffuse pollutants.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The aquatic environments along the transport corridor are relied upon by local villagers for<br /><br />
subsistence fishing. Food shortage has been identified in the social surveys as an issue facing many<br /><br />
villages, and therefore fishing is undertaken to supplement diets. As such, any significant ecological<br /><br />
impacts as a result of the project-related activities may have indirect social impacts.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures have been identified for ecology and biodiversity issues that are<br /><br />
considered to have a significant impact:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mining infrastructure should be planned outside the forest patches and if this is not possible,<br /><br />
a botanist should survey the affected forest well in advance of the construction work to allow<br /><br />
all possible adjustments to be made.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Minimise tree felling at river crossings. The project should source all timber from certified<br /><br />
plantations (i.e. not local sources of timber, which come only from the last remaining natural<br /><br />
forests, which now require the highest level of protection).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
All roads should avoid sacred forests / bushes by at least 200 m.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Roads should be kept to the minimum width possible, commensurate with relevant design<br /><br />
and safety standards.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implement best practice sediment control measures during construction of river crossings.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Where bridges are built, ensure they are designed in a manner that does not confine the river;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Minor in-stream infrastructure can constitute barriers to fish migration. Where possible, these<br /><br />
should be designed to be compatible with the passage of migratory stream organisms, and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />

Page 176<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
crossings of any drainage lines or water bodies should have appropriate culverts built to<br /><br />
appropriate environmental standards.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Plants belonging to species with conservation status Endangered (EN) or Critically<br /><br />
Endangered (CR) should at all times be left undisturbed. Plants belonging to species with<br /><br />
conservation status Vulnerable (VU) should be left undisturbed as much as possible.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Species of conservation concern which were found on the deposits or near proposed<br /><br />
infrastructure should be relocated to suitable localities outside the project area, by way of<br /><br />
seed collection and / or translocation of specimens.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Replanting of vegetation for any purpose should use indigenous species and should be based<br /><br />
on silvicultural systems that promote natural ecosystem functions and that increase the<br /><br />
probability that native species and ecological processes will be maintained. Planting of exotic<br /><br />
species in natural forest areas should not be permitted, with the possible exception of erosion<br /><br />
control activities utilising species that are proven to be short-lived and non-invasive.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Establish and enforce a total ban on the hunting and capture of wildlife by company<br /><br />
employees and contractors.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Recognizing the importance of wildlife as a protein source to indigenous peoples, government<br /><br />
and the company should cooperate with local communities in the development of sustainable,<br /><br />
community-based wildlife management programs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project affected communities should be supported in the development of improved animal<br /><br />
husbandry techniques and provided with starter stocks. This would be a positive contribution<br /><br />
to the livelihoods of people and also reduce demand for bushmeat and limit the impact of<br /><br />
hunting restrictions on local communities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The project should investigate the potential for supporting local plantations, which would be<br /><br />
beneficial to the project, local livelihoods and the remaining natural forests (and therefore,<br /><br />
also for fauna).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Work with government to explore opportunities to control and minimise the uncontrolled inmigration of people into areas newly opened-up by road construction, especially along the<br /><br />
roads themselves. Uncontrolled in-migration will lead to further forest and wildlife losses and<br /><br />
compound pressures on existing human communities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Consider biodiversity offsets to compensate for the unavoidable habitat loss (including<br /><br />
vegetation and fauna).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The risk of injury to endangered species and other fauna from vehicle movements will be<br /><br />
minimised by adopting safe speed limits, reducing night driving to the minimum possible, and<br /><br />
restricting driving to marked access routes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The project should consider establishing a relationship with the Tacugama Chimpanzee<br /><br />
Sanctuary and to work through it to enhance conservation of chimpanzees in the project area<br /><br />
and more widely in Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.3.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hydrology & Hydrogeology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential impacts pertaining to local surface and groundwater have been determined based on the<br /><br />
partial project descriptions available and field observation of early haul road construction and rail<br /><br />
refurbishment activities.<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction works at or near watercourses may lead to increased runoff and erosion with<br /><br />
increase in turbidity and reduction in water quality impacting aquatic environment and<br /><br />
downstream users.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction of temporary stream and river crossings includes creation of river bed crossings<br /><br />
and infill with rock, soil and organic debris arising from the route clearance and stripping<br /><br />
works. Construction process of these crossings and vehicles passing through river bed<br /><br />
crossings disturb river bank and river bed sediments raising downstream turbidity, impacting<br /><br />
on water quality and potentially increasing long term erosion in the vicinity of the crossing.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Infill crossings lead to increased downstream turbidity impacting on water quality as fines are<br /><br />
washed downstream by increasing flows with onset of the wet season.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
High rainfall events will carry larger infill material and similar materials deposited in general on<br /><br />
road alignment adjacent to river banks and flood areas downstream - including rocks and<br /><br />
trees which can destroy community foot crossing. High organic content in water courses may<br /><br />
impact on water quality.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dewatering of aquifers leading to impacts on surface water hydrology and local communities.<br /><br />
Groundwater will be abstracted to supply potable and construction water at various locations<br /><br />
along the haul road and existing rail alignment. Surface water may also be abstracted for<br /><br />
construction use. Over-exploitation of aquifers could locally reduce the water table and<br /><br />
potentially dry nearby community wells, surface water streams and/or wetland habitats.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Modification and interruption to the existing hydrological regime of the bounding catchments<br /><br />
may occur. The raised haul road and diversion of storm water runoff may alter the natural<br /><br />
drainage patterns of the various catchments.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Erosion of exposed surfaces by wind, water and construction activities generating higher<br /><br />
sediment loads in surface runoff entering the surrounding river catchments. This will be of<br /><br />
particular concern in the vicinity of river crossing and wetlands.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Alterations to the natural course of rivers may be required where major river crossing are<br /><br />
planned. Deepening of river channels and alterations to the surrounding topography could<br /><br />
alter the natural course or flow rates of rivers as well as the flood plain dynamics during the<br /><br />
wet season.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />

<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potentially contaminated soil waste may be generated during the re-development of the<br /><br />
existing rail alignment. Contaminants could be mobilised from excavated soils and migrate to<br /><br />
surface or groundwater.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
Assessment of potential impacts on the hydrological and hydrogeological setting have been<br /><br />
conducted based primarily on a Phase 1B – Walkover baseline assessment supplemented with<br /><br />
limited reconnaissance level assessment conducted during February 2010. Potential impacts<br /><br />
associated with the project will be accurately quantified during the impact assessment but may<br /><br />
include the following:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Uncontrolled release of toxic chemicals to the environment. Diesel fuel, oil, grease and<br /><br />
solvents will all be used during the operation and maintenance of vehicles using the haul road<br /><br />
and rail. Accidental spillage and contact with rainfall runoff may lead to the pollution of<br /><br />
groundwater and/or surface water bodies.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Lack of hard surfacing of the haul road may lead to dusting and erosion and runoff carrying<br /><br />
material into water courses where the road is nearby or at crossings. This may impact on<br /><br />
turbidity and other water quality parameters. Groundwater and or surface water abstraction at<br /><br />
permanent camps/facilities along the transport corridor may locally reduce the water table and<br /><br />
potentially dry nearby community wells, surface water streams and/or wetland habitats.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dust and spillage of ore from haul road and rail wagons may enter water courses or leach into<br /><br />
groundwater impacting water quality<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures have been identified for hydrology and hydrogeology issues that<br /><br />
are considered to have a significant impact:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Robust surface and groundwater monitoring programmes to establish baseline and ensure<br /><br />
early identification of impacts.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Treatment of all potentially contaminated wastewater sources prior to discharge to ground or<br /><br />
surface.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rapid replacement of riverbed crossings and infill crossings with appropriately designed<br /><br />
culverted/bridged crossings. Prohibit construction of similar crossings and ensure culvert and<br /><br />
bridge crossings commence only when suitable plant and materials available on site.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Strict adherence to Environmental Management Plans prepared in line with industry and<br /><br />
international best practice.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Appropriate hydrogeological/hydrological assessment of water resources and careful design<br /><br />
of water abstraction points so as to minimise impacts on other users.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Strict load level and moisture control of materials to be transported in open rail/road wagons<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Design to ensure potentially contaminating materials are not stored in proximity to surface<br /><br />
water courses and adequate bunding for spill control. Prepare spill response plans and<br /><br />
materials handling management plans. Avoid storage over potentially sensitive/important<br /><br />
shallow aquifers and prepare engineered low permeability surfaces with drainage/runoff<br /><br />
controls for storage and handling areas.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.3.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Soils & Land Use<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
While there are no baseline soil data currently available for the transport corridor, the preliminary<br /><br />
identification and evaluation of impacts is possible based on field observations of baseline conditions<br /><br />
as well as current haul road construction activities, qualitative land-use information and an<br /><br />
understanding of Phase 1-related activities in this area.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Land clearance including slash and burn of vegetation and surface soils strip being carried<br /><br />
out for scout road construction and subsequent widening may lead to significant erosion.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Temporary stream and river crossings include river bed crossings or ‘infill’ crossings where<br /><br />
earth/rocks and vegetation have been pushed into the watercourse restricting the natural flow<br /><br />
of water. Onset of the wet season will lead to severe erosion of river bank soils in the vicinity<br /><br />
of these crossings and flooding associated with infill type crossings may lead to deposition of<br /><br />
sediment on surrounding areas impacting on soils and land use.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The construction of the road may constrain certain land-uses and / or access to land and<br /><br />
leads to permanent loss of some land to former land use..<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Localised impacts may occur associated with borrow pit areas and quarries (potential sources<br /><br />
for road and bridge construction materials).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Invasive species may also spread to undisturbed land following natural colonisation or<br /><br />
deliberate introduction in disturbed areas (where such species tend to thrive).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Localised erosion or inundation may occur due to the modification of drainage patterns.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Stripping of soils and shallow deposits has been carried out over much of the haul road scout<br /><br />
route and to date the stripped material has been pushed to the sides of the road to form<br /><br />
bunds mixed with cleared vegetation and subsoil and non-organic sediments. Unmanaged<br /><br />
storage of soils can lead to a loss of the soils structure as well as wash out and erosion<br /><br />
during high rainfall events leading to permanent loss of the soil.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• Temporary and minor impacts on soil resources and land-use during the refurbishment of the<br /><br />
Delco rail line may also occur. Historical soil quality impacts are highly likely to have occurred<br /><br />
during operation of the rail line and there are visible deposits of ore spillage in many areas<br /><br />
along and immediately adjacent to the line. Renovation/construction works could lead to the<br /><br />
spread or redistribution of this material.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Soil resources and land-use in areas adjacent to the road may experience localised dustrelated impacts from truck movements and earth moving activities during road construction.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Compaction and permanent loss of soil structure may occur in the vicinity of the road<br /><br />
construction due to the movement of plant and vehicles beyond the necessary work areas.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 188<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
Road haulage and renewed operation of the rail line is likely to result in spillage of some ore product<br /><br />
for which detailed chemistry is not yet known. However the very narrow, linear form of the transport<br /><br />
lines means that any impacts on soils are likely to be localised and limited.<br /><br />
Although the product grain sizes are not anticipated to lead to dusting in their own right, the heavily<br /><br />
weathered nature of some of the material means that some abrasion and dust formation may occur.<br /><br />
Dust may be blown from road and rail wagons and accumulate on local soils. Again, potential<br /><br />
chemistry of any dust is not yet known. For now, limited impacts are assumed.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures have been identified for soils and land use issues that are<br /><br />
considered to have a significant impact:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Minimise land / soil to be cleared or buried and concentrate such activities in areas with<br /><br />
limited soil quality and land-use capability. Given the advanced stage of design and<br /><br />
construction the opportunity to apply this mitigation may not apply.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Consider biodiversity offsets for unavoidable long-term and permanent soil / land clearance<br /><br />
and soil / land burial. Integrate livelihoods components as necessary with offsets to replace<br /><br />
lost land-use capability.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identify suitable storage locations and implement appropriate conservation and preservation<br /><br />
of stripped top-soils and sub-soils from all areas to retain physical and chemical<br /><br />
characteristics and seed-bank for subsequent use for rehabilitation activities. Where<br /><br />
practical, soils can be formed as roadside bunds or caps to roadside bunds and be planted in<br /><br />
order to maintain soil structure and quality. This mitigation can be retrospectively applied for<br /><br />
road sections that have already been partially cleared where extensive mixing with unsuitable<br /><br />
materials has not occurred.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implement required storm water drainage, culvert and bridge construction and flow control<br /><br />
prior to construction and during the dry season to prevent erosion of exposed areas and<br /><br />
inundation of low lying and down-stream areas. For crossings which have already been<br /><br />
breached and either have river bed crossings or temporary infill crossings, install engineered<br /><br />
crossings as soon as possible ahead of increasing rainfall and runoff.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Restrict access by vehicles to essential areas only, in order to reduce compaction of soils.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Isolate and manage potential soil contaminants (including wind blown dusts and water-borne<br /><br />
contaminants) through careful selection of storage sites and moisture control prior to transport<br /><br />
and during storage.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Avoid deliberate introduction of alien invasive species during rehabilitation activities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Manage pathways by which alien invasive species can enter a disturbed area (including<br /><br />
avoidance of non-indigenous plant species in rehabilitation activities).<br /><br />
<br /><br />

TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.3.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Geology & Geomorphology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
No project-specific baseline geological or geotechnical drilling or mapping has been undertaken to<br /><br />
date along the rail route or haul road however limited information is available in published regional<br /><br />
geological descriptions and from observations during field visits. Since the rail line is already<br /><br />
established and was operated for many years, no further significant impacts on geology or<br /><br />
geomorphology are anticipated. Construction of the haul road and re-instatement of the rail line will<br /><br />
require quarrying of some construction materials for ballast, bridges and road base. Potential<br /><br />
changes to watercourses and runoff and erosion patterns crossed by the road alignment may impact<br /><br />
on local geomorphology. The eastern 20km stretch of road passes through the very hilly Sula range<br /><br />
which are locally deeply incised by streams and rivers. Cut and fill requirements in this region will be<br /><br />
much more significant than for the western road sections and will result in localised significant<br /><br />
changes in geomorphology. However, overall, at this stage and based on limited design data<br /><br />
reviewed to date, no major impacts to geology and geomorphology along the transport corridor are<br /><br />
anticipated.<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
Operation of the transport corridor is not anticipated to have any significant impact on geology or<br /><br />
geomorphology.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures have been identified for geology and geomorphology issues that<br /><br />
are considered to have a significant impact:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Geomorphological mitigation measures include the preservation of watercourses (where<br /><br />
possible) and diversion of watercourses around infrastructure to maintain downstream<br /><br />
drainage patterns, rehabilitation and revegetation of disturbed areas, and re-contouring<br /><br />
disturbed areas to original topography (to the extent possible).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Design of the road should be optimised so as to minimise unnecessary cut and fill. It is<br /><br />
understood that this is anyway consistent with one of the primary design aims for the road.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
7.3.7<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Socio-Economic<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
Land acquisition<br /><br />
The impacts due to land acquisition for construction of the haul road (rail refurbishment will take place<br /><br />
on the existing rail embankment) will range from loss of access to land-based resources to loss of<br /><br />
shelter, all of which may potentially lead to a decrease in economic stability. These can include (but<br /><br />
may not be limited to):<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Loss of income.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Impact on dwelling units.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Impact on community structures.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increases in physical and mental stress.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The haul road may pass through the sugar plantations to be developed as part of the Addax Biofuel<br /><br />
Project. The compensation for potential impacts on the sugarcane plantations may require separate<br /><br />
negotiations with relevant stakeholders. The mitigation measures given below are expected to reduce<br /><br />
the impacts from major to moderate/minor.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a Resettlement Action Plan (RAP).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a livelihood restoration plan.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implementation of a grievance mechanism.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation and implementation of the CDAP.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project induced influx of workers and job seekers<br /><br />
An influx of population will result from the arrival of workers and job seekers to the construction sites<br /><br />
along the transport corridor. This influx is likely to lead to the following impacts:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Pressure on social infrastructure, natural resources.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increases in social ills such as crime, alcoholism, drug abuse and prostitution.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increases in communicable diseases.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential for conflict between the local community and outsiders.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Given the high level of unemployment in Sierra Leone, it will be difficult to control the influx of job<br /><br />
seekers to villages and towns along the transport corridor. The following measures can reduce<br /><br />
impacts from moderate to minor.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Planning for self sufficient and closed workers camps to minimise intermingling of<br /><br />
workers with local population.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 194<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Providing assistance for the control of communicable diseases and for educational<br /><br />
campaigns for prevention of social ills.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Planning jointly with local Paramount Chief and other stakeholders to minimise<br /><br />
speculative migration.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In the long term, the improved transport infrastructure may also lead to growth of industry and other<br /><br />
economic activities along the corridor (more likely along the haul road), which may contribute to<br /><br />
general economic development. The above benefit will be independent of the project and hence has<br /><br />
not been evaluated.<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
The social impacts of the transport corridor are likely to occur mainly during the construction phase<br /><br />
due to disturbance to the existing land users. The impacts on land are expected to occur during<br /><br />
construction of a new 120 km haul road between Farangbaia and Lunsar and refurbishment of the<br /><br />
existing rail line between Lunsar and Pepel Port.<br /><br />
Economic aspects<br /><br />
The economic impacts are expected to be mainly beneficial in nature as described below:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Employment of workers for the construction and operation phases (with additional<br /><br />
indirect and induced jobs with contractors and suppliers).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Initial investment and sustaining capital for maintenance and operation of the railway<br /><br />
line translated into business opportunities for contractors.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Government income in the form of excise duties on imports (mainly during construction)<br /><br />
and taxes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Community investment<br /><br />
As part of its social investment programme, AML is expected to contribute towards development of<br /><br />
social infrastructure in communities along the transport corridor. These could include safe drinking<br /><br />
water, support to schools, construction of roads and other social infrastructure within the settlements<br /><br />
along the rail line. No mitigation measures are suggested for these positive impacts.<br /><br />
Closure of transport operations<br /><br />
The use of the haul road and a refurbished rail line from Lunsar to Pepel Port is planned to be used<br /><br />
for an initial period (at most 8 years). After this the transport activities will take place through a new<br /><br />
rail corridor from the mine site to Tagrin Port as part of Phase 2 and 3. However it is not expected that<br /><br />
there will be large scale retrenchment and consequent impacts as much of the workforce can be<br /><br />
deployed at the new transport corridor or other project operations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />

<br /><br />
7.3.8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Human Health<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction & Operations<br /><br />
Based on the current available project and existing health information, preliminary impacts for Phase<br /><br />
1 of the Tonkolili project have been identified for the transport corridor. It is important to note that the<br /><br />
Project has not been finalized, nor has all the baseline data been analysed, therefore, the qualitative<br /><br />
impact designations and significance may change as the Phase 1 details are finalized.<br /><br />
The preliminary health impacts associated with the Phase 1 transport corridor are described below.<br /><br />
Impacts relate to both construction and operation of the transport corridor unless otherwise stated.<br /><br />
Potential negative impacts of major significance:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Community resettlement (during construction);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In-migration related impacts (disease, food security, substance abuse, home violence) (during<br /><br />
construction); and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Degradation and/or reduction of surface water (sedimentation/erosion, contamination, changes in<br /><br />
drainage patterns).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential negative impacts of moderate significance:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increased road traffic accident rate; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reduction in quality or quantity of locally produced foods.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential negative impacts of minor or insignificant significance:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Impacts of noise on health and well-being (heavy vehicle activity);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Exposure to increased levels of particulate matter (PM) (diesel power generators vehicle<br /><br />
emissions, and road dust); and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Acute exposure to elevated SO2 and NO2 in air (diesel power generators, heavy vehicle<br /><br />
emissions).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential positive impacts:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Access to improved healthcare facilities (for general public);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Health benefits to AML employees and through local employment;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AML financed community development initiatives;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Improved access to the region; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Positive aspects of resettlement.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />

<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A number of assumptions were made for the preliminary impact assessment specific to the Phase1<br /><br />
transport corridor. It was assumed that all communities on or within 500 m were to be resettled to a<br /><br />
distance greater than 500 m. Thus, the Health VR used in the preliminary impact assessment for<br /><br />
impacts associated with PM, SO2, and NO2 was categorized as Medium (an AML employee or HR2<br /><br />
see Table 7-1).<br /><br />
Also, with respect to PM, SO2, and NO2 emissions, it was assumed that a thermal power generating<br /><br />
facility (a potentially significant generator of these types of emissions) will not be built in this area.<br /><br />
Should the arrangements for power supply be altered from those described in Section 3, this<br /><br />
preliminary impact will require re-assessment. Should a thermal power generator be implemented, the<br /><br />
significance of the impact and the sensitivity of the VR would be expected to increase.<br /><br />
It was assumed that activities associated with the haul road construction and railway up-grade would<br /><br />
be superficial and not impact groundwater along the transport corridor. Thus, an impact to<br /><br />
groundwater was not included in preliminary impact assessment of the Phase 1 transport corridor.<br /><br />
The positive class impacts associated with access to medical facilities only apply if AML undertake to<br /><br />
provide these facilities.<br /><br />
Where there was uncertainty in significance designation, the more conservative assumption was<br /><br />
selected so as to ensure that the preliminary potential impact of the Project was not underestimated.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
Potential mitigation measures have been identified in association with each headline health impact as<br /><br />
listed below. The headline impacts were identified with the assumption that no mitigation measures<br /><br />
were applied. Thus, implementation of the recommended mitigation measures is expected to reduce<br /><br />
the significance of the headline health issues and thus avoid potentially major health issues for<br /><br />
persons living in the vicinity of the Projects.<br /><br />
Health related mitigation measures are listed below, however, it is important to note that mitigation<br /><br />
recommended by the other disciplines, particularly socio-economic as well as other environmental<br /><br />
assessments (e.g., air, surface and groundwater, flora and fauna) can also affect human health.<br /><br />
Alteration of project descriptions and monitoring results may result in the recommendation of<br /><br />
additional mitigation measures, or modification of those currently recommended.<br /><br />
Increased road traffic accident rate<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implementation of sound health and safety measures during the construction phase, including<br /><br />
safe driving practices.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Road Health and Safety and awareness training for all employees.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assigned crossing areas for pedestrians.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Lighting along dangerous sections of the road and busy intersections.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Building good quality roads with adequate signage.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Keeping Project-related night time traffic to a minimum.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Port Facilities<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.4<br /><br />
7.4.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Air Quality<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
Construction activities at Pepel Port will comprise a combination of existing asset refurbishment and<br /><br />
new development.<br /><br />
Contaminants of potential concern are dust emissions and exhaust gases that will contain several<br /><br />
pollutants (SO2, CO, NO2, PM10 and PM2.5).<br /><br />
Dust will be generated during vegetation clearance and earth movements (creation of new access<br /><br />
routes, and surface grading and levelling for buildings and facilities construction). Pollutants emitted<br /><br />
by these activities are mainly coarse particles (above 10 µm) without health effects. Nevertheless,<br /><br />
vegetation in this area (mangrove ecosystems) may be affected by the deposition of particles on the<br /><br />
leaves.<br /><br />
Dust (coarse particles) dispersion might travel up to 1 km depending on the wind characteristics,<br /><br />
believed to be prevailing westerly.<br /><br />
Additionally, diesel generators used for power supply, vehicles and machinery will generate exhaust<br /><br />
emissions. The use of efficient machinery (vehicles, motors and pumps) and a good practices policy<br /><br />
(e.g., minimise journeys, switch-off machinery when not in use, and reduce diesel generators use to a<br /><br />
minimum) will avoid unnecessary fuel consumption, minimising the potential impacts on air quality.<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
The most significant potential impacts may arise from two stockpiles located in the Port Facilities<br /><br />
area, with a capacity of 200,000 tonnes each, and the diesel generators used for the power supply.<br /><br />
Total dust emissions from aggregate storage piles will result from the following distinct source<br /><br />
activities during the storage cycle:<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Loading of aggregate onto storage piles (batch or continuous drop operations).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Equipment traffic in the storage area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Wind erosion of the fines within the pile and ground surfaces around the piles.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Loadout of aggregate for shipment or for return to the process stream (batch or continuous<br /><br />
drop operations).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The quantity of dust emissions from aggregate storage operations will vary with the volume of<br /><br />
aggregate passing through the storage cycle, the size of the particles, the surface of the stockpiles,<br /><br />
the moisture content (moisture aggregates and bonds fines to the surfaces of larger particles) and the<br /><br />
wind conditions.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 206<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Suspended particle emissions could be controlled with great efficiency if measures are applied (e.g.,<br /><br />
humidification or protection from wind). When the appropriate measures are not taken, negative<br /><br />
effects will likely increase considerably.<br /><br />
Other potential sources of pollutant emissions (NOx, SO2 and PM) are the transport ships, periodically<br /><br />
present close to the port.<br /><br />
The project power requirements at the port will be supplied by small diesel generators. The installed<br /><br />
power (currently undefined) and the fuel characteristics will define the pollutant emissions. The power<br /><br />
generators should be specified to comply with the International Finance Corporation / World Bank<br /><br />
Group HSE Ambient Air Quality guidelines.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
Generic recommendations for reducing impacts from activities to be conducted during the<br /><br />
construction phase of the project are listed below:<br /><br />
Decrease air quality impacts due to dust emissions:<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Suppress dust during dry periods by spraying with water the potential sources that could<br /><br />
release airborne particles (unpaved roads, earth being moved)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Cover truck loads to avoid dust emissions during the transport of excavated earth<br /><br />
<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Keep vehicle movements to a minimum and use paved areas, where possible<br /><br />
<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Minimise discharge heights from trucks (not to exceed 1 m) for fine particles and consider the<br /><br />
use of dust suppression spray systems<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Decrease air quality impacts due to combustion emissions:<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Review machinery permits and ensure appropriate maintenance<br /><br />
<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Limit unnecessary journeys and adopt a policy of switching off machinery and equipment<br /><br />
when not in use<br /><br />
<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Consider a choice of machinery, equipment, vehicles and materials that are fuel-efficient as<br /><br />
part of the purchasing procedure<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Controlled and uncontrolled fires (airborne emissions):<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Open fires will be prohibited. To limit air emissions, avoid accidents and reduce fire risk<br /><br />
during the construction phase.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The negative impacts on air quality during the operation of the Pepel Port facilities can be minimised<br /><br />
through the following measures:<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Design stockpiles based on wind patterns and consider the installation of windscreen if dust<br /><br />
emissions are observed.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
♦<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Suppress dust emissions from the stockpiles during dry periods by spraying the surface with<br /><br />
water.<br /><br />

TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.4.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Noise<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
An increase in noise levels may be generated by machinery, engines, vehicles used for transport,<br /><br />
loading and unloading of rock, materials and waste and power generation. Preventive and corrective<br /><br />
measures for construction phase are described below.<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
Identified noise sources are ship traffic (motors, sirens, etc.), machinery movement, conveyors,<br /><br />
loading and unloading activities at Dual Train Dumping Station, the Stacker Feed System, the<br /><br />
Reclaim Feed System and the Shiploader Feed System.<br /><br />
Noise can affect receptors far from the sources, depending on the noise power and frequency.<br /><br />
Industrial noise is typically reduced at 500 m to 1 km from the source as a consequence of the noise<br /><br />
power attenuation, soil absorption and the elements affecting the noise propagation. Noise generated<br /><br />
by offshore vessels might reach greater distances before being attenuated due to the low noise<br /><br />
absorption capacity of the sea and the absence of barriers to the noise propagation.<br /><br />
The potentially sensitive areas near the port are the nearest villages, Kalangba and Mapota, and the<br /><br />
Sierra Leone estuary fauna.<br /><br />
No specific information was available regarding the acoustical emission (noise power) of the<br /><br />
equipment that will produce noise in the port facilities. The proximity to Kalangba, located adjacent to<br /><br />
the facilities boundary, and the cumulative effect expected from truck traffic and railway corridor,<br /><br />
suggests that noise emissions will require mitigation measures.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
Generic recommendations for the construction phase include the use of machinery and equipment<br /><br />
that guarantee low noise emissions and the regular inspections and maintenance of construction<br /><br />
vehicles and equipment. Journeys will be limited to only those necessary and a policy of switching off<br /><br />
machinery and equipment when not in use will be implemented. Vehicle speeds will be limited in the<br /><br />
vicinity of populated areas.<br /><br />
The preventive and corrective measures to reduce the impact on noise pressure during the<br /><br />
operational activities are defined below:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Select vehicles and equipment that guarantee low noise emissions<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Conduct regular inspections and maintenance of vehicles and equipment<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mitigations measures, such as sound barriers, should be installed where ambient noise levels<br /><br />
may be exceeded. When these barriers are not effective, additional measures should be<br /><br />
considered, such as noise isolation at the sensitive receptors.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Noise impacts at nearest receptors (Kalangba) should be minimised through an appropriate<br /><br />
layout plan. Community safety regarding noise as one of the environmental aspects will be<br /><br />
addressed through a Community Safety Plan to be developed by AML and rolled out in<br /><br />
conjunction with the EWCC.<br /><br />

7.4.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ecology & Biodiversity<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction & Operations<br /><br />
Vegetation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Conservation importance<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The principal impacts will arise from the potential clearance of mangrove during installation or<br /><br />
refurbishment of infrastructure. Invasive species may also spread to undisturbed land following<br /><br />
natural colonisation or deliberate introduction in disturbed areas (where such species tend to thrive).<br /><br />
The release of acidity and metals from disturbed acid sulphate soils (if present) can cause the die<br /><br />
back of vegetation in the localised area and hydraulically connected areas. Impacts on fauna may<br /><br />
further reduce natural colonisation by indigenous plant species where fauna play a role in seed<br /><br />
dispersal. The impact classification of these impacts is influenced by the nature of the vegetation<br /><br />
present in the area being impacted (defined as high and low conservation importance).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
High<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Low<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Major<br /><br />
Land clearance;<br /><br />
contamination;<br /><br />
spread of alien<br /><br />
invasive species;<br /><br />
contamination;<br /><br />
exposure to<br /><br />
acidity / heavy<br /><br />
metals<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Impact classification<br /><br />
Moderate<br /><br />
Minor<br /><br />
Reduced<br /><br />
dispersion of<br /><br />
seeds by fauna<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Land clearance;<br /><br />
spread of alien<br /><br />
invasive species<br /><br />
<br /><br />

exposure to<br /><br />
acidity / heavy<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Reduced<br /><br />
dispersion of<br /><br />
seeds by fauna<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Terrestrial Fauna<br /><br />
The most significant potential impact is a change in species diversity and abundance (and potentially<br /><br />
a loss of species of conservation concern) through habitat loss and fragmentation directly associated<br /><br />
with land clearance and the refurbishment / construction of the port infrastructure. Although the area<br /><br />
may not be significant for terrestrial mammals, reptiles and amphibians, the area is an important<br /><br />
wintering spot for migratory bird species and therefore unnecessary habitat alteration should be<br /><br />
avoided. Displacement of terrestrial fauna may also occur through increased sensory disturbance as<br /><br />
a result of the mining activities. The impact classifications for these impacts are:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Major: habitat fragmentation and habitat disturbance.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Moderate: displacement of fauna.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Aquatic Ecosystems<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />

<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During the Phase 1b rapid assessment, no freshwater aquatic environments were identified on Pepel<br /><br />
Island (the location of the port infrastructure for Phase 1); therefore no impacts have been identified.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures have been identified for ecology and biodiversity issues that are<br /><br />
considered to have a significant impact:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mining infrastructure should be planned outside the forest patches and if this is not possible,<br /><br />
a botanist should survey the affected forest well in advance of the construction work to allow<br /><br />
all possible adjustments to be made.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Roads should be kept to the minimum width possible, commensurate with relevant design<br /><br />
and safety standards.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Plants belonging to species with conservation status Endangered (EN) or Critically<br /><br />
Endangered (CR) should at all times be left undisturbed. Plants belonging to species with<br /><br />
conservation status Vulnerable (VU) should be left undisturbed as much as possible.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Species of conservation concern which were found on the deposits or near proposed<br /><br />
infrastructure should be relocated to suitable localities outside the project area, by way of<br /><br />
seed collection and / or translocation of specimens.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Replanting of vegetation for any purpose should use indigenous species and should be based<br /><br />
on silvicultural systems that promote natural ecosystem functions and that increase the<br /><br />
probability that native species and ecological processes will be maintained. Planting of exotic<br /><br />
species in natural forest areas should not be permitted, with the possible exception of erosion<br /><br />
control activities utilising species that are proven to be short-lived and non-invasive.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In the localities with extensive areas of mangrove, such as at the Pepel Port lease areas,<br /><br />
construction activities should be planned outside the mangroves as much as possible, and<br /><br />
mangrove disturbance kept to a minimum where construction is unavoidable.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Establish and enforce a total ban on the hunting and capture of wildlife by company<br /><br />
employees and contractors.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Recognizing the importance of wildlife as a protein source to indigenous peoples, government<br /><br />
and the company should cooperate with local communities in the development of sustainable,<br /><br />
community-based wildlife management programs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project affected communities should be supported in the development of improved animal<br /><br />
husbandry techniques and provided with starter stocks. This would be a positive contribution<br /><br />
to the livelihoods of people and also reduce demand for bushmeat and limit the impact of<br /><br />
hunting restrictions on local communities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The project should investigate the potential for supporting local plantations, which would be<br /><br />
beneficial to the project, local livelihoods and the remaining natural forests (and therefore,<br /><br />
also for fauna).<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Work with government to explore opportunities to control and minimise the uncontrolled inmigration of people into areas newly opened-up by road construction, especially along the<br /><br />
roads themselves. Uncontrolled in-migration will lead to further forest and wildlife losses and<br /><br />
compound pressures on existing human communities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Consider biodiversity offsets to compensate for the unavoidable habitat loss (including<br /><br />
vegetation and fauna).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
