AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.4.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hydrology & Hydrogeology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assessment of potential impacts on the hydrological and hydrogeological setting at Pepel Island has<br /><br />
been conducted based on a Phase 2B – Reconnaissance Level baseline assessment conducted<br /><br />
during February, March and April 2010 as well as observations on early works construction activities.<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction and pumping of new water wells may lead to salt water intrusion and permanent<br /><br />
loss of water quality impacting other site and community wells if locations, depths or pumping<br /><br />
rates are not appropriate to the local aquifer morphology. Scott Wilson (March 2010) have<br /><br />
carried out a detailed non intrusive site study at Pepel that recommended installation of water<br /><br />
wells only in the northern part of the Island where current groundwater utilisation is negligible.<br /><br />
They also recommend a maximum installation depth of 25m and a pumping rate of 0.5 l/s in<br /><br />
order to minimise saline intrusion. Two well have recently (April 2010) been installed in the<br /><br />
Port Area to meet current construction and potable water demand. The wells extend to 32<br /><br />
and 42 mbgl and will be pumping approximately 2 l/s per well. Recently recorded electrical<br /><br />
conductivity values which are higher than in any other groundwater wells.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Modification and interruption to the existing hydrological regime may occur, particularly where<br /><br />
new raised roads or railway alter the path of the natural surface water drainage network.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Contamination of surface and / or groundwater due to loss of containment of fuels and other<br /><br />
chemicals associated with mobile and static plant and vehicle maintenance.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mobilisation/solution of historical contaminants in soils including arsenic, oils and tars further<br /><br />
to disturbance of soils and structures and ground cover on site may impact on groundwater<br /><br />
and surface water runoff quality.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Demolition/renovation of historical plant and structures may lead to loss of containment of<br /><br />
historically present sources which include significant volumes of liquid hydrocarbons<br /><br />
(fuels/insulating oils/lubricants) in storage tanks, transformers and sumps may impact on<br /><br />
groundwater and surface water quality.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Groundwater abstraction leading to reduced community access to potable water supplies.<br /><br />
Groundwater will be abstracted at a rate of between 2.9 and 3.5 L.sec-1 across a proposed<br /><br />
network of nine groundwater bores. Over exploitation of the aquifer could locally reduce the<br /><br />
water table and potentially dry nearby community wells.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Induced salt water intrusion into freshwater aquifer through unsustainable groundwater<br /><br />
pumping. Saline water may be drawn into the aquifer either horizontally from the coast or<br /><br />
vertically from depth (if present) causing degradation of the freshwater resource.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 219<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Contaminated runoff from stockpiled ore may cause sedimentation or heavy metal pollution to<br /><br />
local groundwater and surface water resources.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Loss of containment of fuel, solvents, lubricants and chemicals during transport or storage<br /><br />
could lead to contamination of surface water and groundwater.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures have been identified for hydrology and hydrogeology issues that<br /><br />
are considered to have a significant impact:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Robust surface and groundwater monitoring programmes to establish baseline and ensure<br /><br />
early identification of impacts. Groundwater at Pepel Island is considered to be a highly<br /><br />
sensitive receptor both to contamination through construction and operational activities and<br /><br />
over exploitation. Failure to rigorously implement appropriate resource and environmental<br /><br />
management and protective measures could readily lead to very long term damage to the<br /><br />
aquifer beneath Pepel Port. The monitoring will allow mitigation measures to be refined and<br /><br />
ensure they are appropriate and effective.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Waste water treatment and testing to confirm compliance with relevant discharge standards.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Strict adherence to Environmental Management Plans prepared in line with industry and<br /><br />
international best practice.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Appropriate hydrogeological/hydrological assessment and field testing of water resources and<br /><br />
careful design of water abstraction points so as to minimise impacts on other users. This<br /><br />
process has been initiated by Scott Wilson (March 2010)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Detailed study and testing to determine whether recently drilled construction phase water<br /><br />
supply wells pose a risk of saline intrusion and long term or permanent damage to the aquifer.<br /><br />
In the event that a risk is established, carry out repair works to seal the base of the well/s with<br /><br />
cement/bentonite or abandon the risk wells and redrill in line with recommendations of the<br /><br />
Scott Wilson report or any subsequent study as per bullet point above.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Design to ensure potentially contaminating materials are not stored in proximity to surface<br /><br />
water courses and adequate bunding for spill control. Prepare spill response plans and<br /><br />
materials handling management plans. Avoid storage of materials at locations overlying<br /><br />
potentially sensitive/important shallow aquifers and prepare engineered low permeability<br /><br />
surfaces with drainage/runoff controls for storage and handling areas.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Perform leachate tests on ore to be stockpiled at the port to determine risks to groundwater<br /><br />
from stockpiles and allow for design of suitable storage area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
As part of routine baseline ESHIA studies, testing of surface soil scrapes, groundwater from<br /><br />
available water supply wells and inspection of readily accessible historical plant and<br /><br />
structures was carried out. Determination of mitigation measures to prevent potential impact<br /><br />
on groundwater due to disturbance of and leaching from potential existing historically<br /><br />
contaminated soils requires completion of more detailed understanding through site<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
investigation including intrusive investigation techniques to assess subsurface soils in any<br /><br />
areas to be cleared or excavated as part of the proposed port development works.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A detailed audit of potential point sources of contamination should be carried out by a suitable<br /><br />
contractor and a site register prepared recording details of all risk areas such as location and<br /><br />
condition of structures and plant containing oils and tars for example. All transformer oils<br /><br />
should be tested for PCB’s. All existing leaks of oils and tars or other potential contaminants<br /><br />
to be repaired. All potential contaminating liquids currently within plant/structures with no<br /><br />
secondary containment to be drained of and disposed of in a safe manner or provided with<br /><br />
secondary containment or alternative storage facilities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
All current and future development works should be permitted only after reference to the<br /><br />
contamination register so that works can either avoid contaminated areas or go ahead after<br /><br />
appropriate remedial measures have been implemented.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dependent on results of further sampling and testing, if appropriate, ensure that scraped<br /><br />
surface soils and excavation arisings are disposed of in a safe, suitable manner or stockpiled<br /><br />
in a suitable secure engineered location within the site boundary.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ensure stockpiles of any potentially contaminative materials including ore stockpiles are<br /><br />
located in engineered low permeability bunded areas with surface drainage guided to catch<br /><br />
pits and settling areas to prevent runoff of rainwaters and leachate from dispersing dissolved<br /><br />
contaminants.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Minimise land / soil to be cleared or excavated and concentrate such activities in areas of low<br /><br />
soil quality and land-use potential.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implement required storm water drainage and controls prior to earthworks and construction<br /><br />
activities to prevent release of potentially contaminated waters.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.4.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Soils & Land Use<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
Baseline soil data for the historical industrial Pepel Port area has been collected for a few indicative<br /><br />
surface samples only and indicates a probably relatively low level historical impact on quality,<br /><br />
principally with some elevated levels of arsenic and some localised leakage or spillage of fuels and<br /><br />
oils as well as coal tar related contamination. On the whole, the reinstatement of the Port is not<br /><br />
considered likely to have a significant impact on the soils at or outside the port if works are designed<br /><br />
and managed with due consideration given to current conditions.<br /><br />
Stripping of surface soils and other earthworks associated with preparation of new stockpile areas<br /><br />
and foundations for new port infrastructure could potentially mobilise or expose historically present<br /><br />
contaminants such as arsenic, asbestos and coal tar constituents. Full details of the proposed layout<br /><br />
of the port are not yet available but there will be a requirement for some foundation construction<br /><br />
activities. Working and disposal of excavated soils could potentially spread contamination to<br /><br />
uncontaminated soils including areas of the port and surrounds where farming and grazing is still<br /><br />
carried out.<br /><br />
Several sources of potential contamination remain on site since it was last operated as a port. These<br /><br />
sources include significant volumes of liquid hydrocarbons (fuels/insulating oils/lubricants) in storage<br /><br />
tanks, transformers and sumps. Coal tars are also present where they were used as sealants to<br /><br />
reduce infiltration of spillage/leakage of fuels along pipe runs and around the fuel farm tanks area.<br /><br />
Demolition and salvage and recycling works associated with development could lead to spillage and<br /><br />
spread of contaminants which could significantly reduce soil quality in the vicinity.<br /><br />
Asbestos containing materials (ACM) have been identified on the site. Construction board and<br /><br />
cement bound asbestos board and cement bound asbestos piping were used in buildings and<br /><br />
underground infrastructure (wastewater piping). Some of the piping has also been used as bollards –<br /><br />
placed in the ground as posts and filled with cement as observed on the boat jetty. Demolition and<br /><br />
salvage and recycling works associated with development could lead to disturbance / break up of<br /><br />
ACM and spread of asbestos fibres which could significantly reduce soil quality in the vicinity.<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
Operation of Pepel Port will include a number of activities with potential to impact on soils and land<br /><br />
use at and near the Port. Transport, storage and handling of fuel, solvents, lubricants and chemicals<br /><br />
as well as the ore itself could all impact on local soil quality including at residential areas adjacent to<br /><br />
the port and cultivation and mangrove areas at and near the port.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures have been identified for soils and land use issues that are<br /><br />
considered to have a significant impact:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />

<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Only sampling of surface soils, groundwater in available water supply wells and inspection of<br /><br />
readily accessible historical plant and structures was carried out during ESHIA field studies.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures to prevent potential impact on soils due to disturbance of potential<br /><br />
existing historically contaminated soils requires completion of more detailed understanding<br /><br />
through site investigation including intrusive investigation techniques to assess subsurface<br /><br />
soils in areas to be cleared or excavated as part of the proposed port development works.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A detailed audit of potential point sources of contamination should be carried out by a suitable<br /><br />
contractor and a site register prepared recording details of all risk areas such as location and<br /><br />
condition of structures and plant containing oils and tars for example. All transformer oils<br /><br />
should be tested for PCB’s.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
An asbestos survey should be carried out by a qualified contractor and professional guidance<br /><br />
followed with regard to removal and safe disposal to ensure no spread of fibres. Asbestos<br /><br />
survey should screen for free fibres in and near all areas where ACM has already been<br /><br />
removed or is known or likely to have been located.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identify areas of ACM disposal from recent development/renovation works on site on the<br /><br />
contamination register. Include these areas in the asbestos survey and seek surveyor<br /><br />
recommendations for future management of disposed materials.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Materials that pose a risk to soils and land use in their current condition (oil and tar leaks<br /><br />
known to be present) should be removed and disposed of in a safe manner or secured and<br /><br />
isolated.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
All current and future development works should be permitted only after reference to the<br /><br />
contamination register so that works can either avoid contaminated areas or go ahead after<br /><br />
appropriate remedial measures have been implemented.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dependent on results of further sampling and testing, if appropriate, ensure that scraped<br /><br />
surface soils and excavation arisings are disposed of in a safe, suitable manner or stockpiled<br /><br />
in a suitable secure engineered location within the site boundary.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ensure stockpiles of any potentially contaminative materials including ore stockpiles are<br /><br />
located in engineered bunded areas with surface drainage guided to catch pits and settling<br /><br />
areas to prevent runoff of rainwaters from dispersing soils/sediment loading.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Minimise land / soil to be cleared or excavated and concentrate such activities in areas of low<br /><br />
soil quality and land-use potential.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Consider biodiversity offsets for unavoidable long-term and permanent soil / land clearance<br /><br />
and soil / land burial. Integrate livelihoods components as necessary with offsets to replace<br /><br />
lost land-use capability.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implement appropriate conservation and preservation of any good quality stripped top-soils<br /><br />
and sub-soils from all areas to retain physical and chemical characteristics and seed-bank for<br /><br />
subsequent use for rehabilitation activities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implement required storm water drainage and controls prior to earthworks and construction<br /><br />

<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Restrict access by vehicles and construction plant to essential areas to minimise erosion and<br /><br />
compaction of soils.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Isolate and manage potential soil contaminants (including wind blown dusts and water-borne<br /><br />

<br /><br />

<br /><br />

<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />

avoidance of non-indigenous plant species in rehabilitation activities).<br /><br />

<br /><br />
7.4.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Geology & Geomorphology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
The impact on geology and geomorphology within the Pepel Port area is expected to be minor as the<br /><br />
site has operated as a dedicated port facility servicing to a mine site in the past. Impacts on the<br /><br />
geology and geomorphology would already have occurred. All details of the Port design are not yet<br /><br />
known and there is potential for construction of new port facilities to impact on coastal geomorphology<br /><br />
but given the significant historical development and operation of the port, additional facilities are not<br /><br />
considered likely to greatly increase these impacts.<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
As with the construction phase, no operational activities are anticipated to impact significantly on<br /><br />
geology or geomorphology.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
No significant impacts are considered likely based on current information with regard to<br /><br />
construction and operation of Pepel Port and therefore no mitigation measures are proposed<br /><br />
at this stage.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.4.7<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Socio-Economic<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
Land acquisition<br /><br />
The refurbishment of the Pepel Port may require additional land in its vicinity for construction and<br /><br />
operational activities and facilities. The land near the port is currently used for dwellings, trading,<br /><br />
agriculture and grazing. Potential impacts include impacts on the land base as well as sea based<br /><br />
activities such as fishing.<br /><br />
The following mitigation measures are expected to reduce the intensity of the residual impacts from<br /><br />
major to moderate/minor.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a Resettlement Action Plan (RAP).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a livelihood restoration plan.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implementation of a grievance mechanism.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation and implementation of the CDAP.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project induced influx of workers and job seekers<br /><br />
The economic opportunities created at the Pepel Port are expected to lead to an influx of workers and<br /><br />
job seekers mainly during the construction phase. This is likely to lead to:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Pressure on social infrastructure and natural resources.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increases in social ills such as crime, alcoholism, drug abuse and prostitution.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increases in communicable diseases.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increases in the cost of living.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The following measures are expected to reduce the impacts from major to moderate/minor.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Planning jointly with local government, Paramount Chief and other stakeholders to<br /><br />
minimise speculative migration.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Providing assistance to local government to increase (and improve) infrastructure<br /><br />
services.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Support for strengthening of programmes for control of communicable diseases and<br /><br />
educational campaigns for prevention of social ills.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Operations<br /><br />
The refurbishment of the Pepel Port is expected to have predominantly beneficial socio-economic<br /><br />
impacts during its construction and operation phase (up to 8 years).<br /><br />
<br /><br />

TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Economic aspects<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The employment generation within Port Loko District and at national level.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The investment for refurbishment of the port.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Skill building of people employed at the port.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Revenue earnings for the government.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
No mitigation measures are required for these positive impacts.<br /><br />
Community investment<br /><br />
In line with its corporate policy, AML is expected to initiate a social investment programme in the<br /><br />
Pepel Port area with the start of construction work. This is expected to mitigate to some extent the<br /><br />
negative impacts on the affected communities. Potential benefits to the community are expected to<br /><br />
include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increases in education and skills levels.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Improvement in social infrastructure such as water supply, schools and health centres.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Development of livelihood opportunities, independent of the port.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Other initiatives to address community needs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Closure of the port activities<br /><br />
Once the Tagrin Port is constructed, operations at Pepel Port will be transferred to the new port. It is<br /><br />
expected that the workers and contractors at Pepel Port may either be transferred and engaged at<br /><br />
Tagrin Port or continue working at Pepel if it continues to operate as a facility under lease to another<br /><br />
operator and therefore the negative socio-economic impacts associated with closure are expected to<br /><br />
be avoidable.<br /><br />

7.4.8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Human Health<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction & Operations<br /><br />
Based on the current available project and existing health information, preliminary impacts for the<br /><br />
construction and operation of Phase 1 have been identified for the Pepel Port facilities. It is important<br /><br />
to note, that the Project description has not been finalized, nor has all the baseline data been<br /><br />
analysed, therefore, the qualitative impact designations and significance may change as the Phase 1<br /><br />
details are finalised. In addition, the implications of incineration of waste at the Pepel Port site have<br /><br />
not been assessed at this point in time. Assessment of this issue will be undertaken for the Stage 2<br /><br />
ESHIA.<br /><br />
The preliminary health impacts associated with the Pepel port facilities are described below. Impacts<br /><br />
relate to both the construction and operation of the port unless otherwise stated.<br /><br />
Potential impacts of major significance:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Community resettlement (during construction);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In-migration related impacts (disease, food security, substance abuse, home violence) (during<br /><br />
operation phase);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increased burden of disease due project activities and water storage facilities (drinking water<br /><br />
tanks, waste and raw water storage ponds);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Degradation and/or reduction of surface water (sedimentation/erosion, contamination, changes in<br /><br />
drainage patterns); and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Degradation of groundwater quality.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential impacts of moderate significance:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In-migration related impacts (disease, food security, substance abuse, home violence) (during<br /><br />
construction phase);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increased burden of disease due project activities and water storage facilities (drinking water<br /><br />
tanks, waste and raw water storage ponds)(for construction phase);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Impacts of noise on health and well-being (port and heavy vehicle activity); and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reduction in quality or quantity of locally produced foods.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential impacts of minor or insignificant significance:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increased road traffic accident rate;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Exposure to increased levels of road dust and particulate matter (PM) (diesel power generators,<br /><br />
crushers, blasting, vehicles, road dust)(assuming no thermal power generation requirements);<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Acute exposure to elevated SO2 and NO2 in air (diesel power generators, heavy vehicle<br /><br />
emissions)(assuming no thermal power generation station); and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Exposure to hazardous materials removed from the exiting port facilities to the local villages (e.g.,<br /><br />
materials containing asbestos).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential positive impacts:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Access to improved healthcare facilities (for general public); and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Health benefits through local employment.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A number of assumptions were made for the preliminary impact assessment specific to the Phase 1<br /><br />
port area. It was assumed that all communities on or within 500 m of the Project area were to be<br /><br />
resettled to a distance greater than 500 m before the construction phase begins. Thus, the Health VR<br /><br />
used in the preliminary impact assessment for exposure to PM, SO2, and NO2 was categorized as<br /><br />
Medium (Human HR2 see Table 7-1 in Section 7).<br /><br />
With respect to PM, SO2, and NO2 emissions, it was assumed that a thermal power generating facility<br /><br />
(a potentially significant generator of these types of emissions) will not be built at the Pepel port. As<br /><br />
the precise method of power generation has not yet been determined, this preliminary impact will<br /><br />
require re-assessment once the Phase 1 project details have been finalized. Should a thermal power<br /><br />
generator be implemented, the significance of the impact and the sensitivity of the VR would be<br /><br />
expected to increase.<br /><br />
The positive class impacts associated with access to medical facilities only apply if AML undertake to<br /><br />
provide these facilities.<br /><br />
Where there was uncertainty in significance designation, the more conservative assumption was<br /><br />
selected so as to ensure that the preliminary potential impact of the Project was not underestimated.<br /><br />
Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
Potential mitigation measures have been identified in association with each headline health impact as<br /><br />
listed below. The headline impacts were identified with the assumption that no mitigation measures<br /><br />
were applied. Thus, implementation of the recommended mitigation measures is expected to reduce<br /><br />
the significance of the headline health issues and thus avoid potentially major health issues for<br /><br />
persons living in the vicinity of the Projects.<br /><br />
Health related mitigation measures are listed below, however, it is important to note that mitigation<br /><br />
recommended by the other disciplines, particularly socio-economic as well as other environmental<br /><br />
assessments (e.g., air, surface and groundwater, flora and fauna) can also affect human health.<br /><br />
Alteration of project descriptions and monitoring results may result in the recommendation of<br /><br />
additional mitigation measures, or modification of those currently recommended.<br /><br />
Community resettlement<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Social mitigation measures regarding loss of land and re-settlement (see social assessment<br /><br />
results and mitigation measures).<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
7.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Offshore & Coastal<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.5.1 Port Layout<br /><br />
Land Clearance and Earthworks<br /><br />
The port will sit within the existing footprint and no land clearance is planned.<br /><br />
The proposed port infrastructure is located on a wetland within the Sierra Leone Estuary Ramsar site.<br /><br />
The Ramsar site covers the majority of the estuary, and Pepel sits within one of the core areas.<br /><br />
Coastal habitat includes mangrove and mudflats which provide important nesting and feeding<br /><br />
grounds for marine fauna and avifauna, and serve as a nursery for marine fish and shellfish.<br /><br />
Mangroves stabilise soils and marine sediment, and clearance can lead to increases in erosion and<br /><br />
run-off. Any disturbance to these habitats may therefore have significant consequences on marine<br /><br />
and coastal fauna and flora, as well as on the local communities that depend on them for food and<br /><br />
resources. Figure 7-1 is a habitat map of the Pepel Island area; the proposed port layout is overlaid to<br /><br />
give an initial indication of the potential impacts of any clearance of habitat.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 7-1 Pepel habitat map overlaid with the early port layout<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 245<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The baseline preliminary survey indicates that the coastal and marine habitat around Pepel is healthy<br /><br />
and contains a high level of biodiversity. Land clearance and significant earthworks are not required<br /><br />
but there are a number of potential impacts to the coastal habitat and mangrove in particular including<br /><br />
altered hydrology and spill over of development effects to surrounding habitat.<br /><br />
The majority of the port infrastructure is already in place, and most of what is required is expected to<br /><br />
be refurbished rather than constructed. As a result there should be no significant increase in the<br /><br />
existing port footprint and no area of coastal habitat will have to be cleared. However, changes to<br /><br />
hydrology and its affect on coastal habitat requires further investigation and the layout of the port<br /><br />
must be finalised before the impact rating can be reduced to the minor that is expected..<br /><br />
The potential impact on the VR coastal habitat of clearance of the port footprint could be major if the<br /><br />
existing port footprint is not maintained.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures:<br /><br />
• Ensure that the port remains within the existing footprint to avoid mangrove clearance and<br /><br />
disruption; and<br /><br />
• Mangrove protection and management should be considered as compensatory measures<br /><br />
within the next phase of the Tonkolili project.<br /><br />
Pressure on the Use of Resources due to Population Increase<br /><br />
The construction camp could increase pressure on local resources if all workers are not fully catered<br /><br />
for, potentially affecting marine coastal habitat and fauna, including mangroves (used as a primary<br /><br />
source for fuel) and fisheries. Currently the mangroves located in and around the island are in a<br /><br />
healthy and diverse state, therefore the potential impact on mangroves is considered to be significant.<br /><br />
The local fish populations are already subject to a high degree of exploitation from the local villages,<br /><br />
so any increase in fishing activity is also viewed as significant.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the potential impact on VR coastal habitat is considered to be of major significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the potential impact on VR human development potential i.e. fisheries is considered<br /><br />
to be of moderate significance.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures:<br /><br />
• Construction Management Plans must ensure that construction workers have access to<br /><br />
appropriate facilities to avoid the need to use local resources, in particular relating to<br /><br />
mangrove.<br /><br />
Clearance of Existing Port including Stockpiles<br /><br />
The current Port development plans do not require removal of old stockpiles that remain on site.<br /><br />
Given that the two stockpiles located at the south west area of the former facility have been in place<br /><br />
for a matter of decades, it is assumed that any significant dusting, washout of fines and leaching has<br /><br />
already occurred and they do not pose a significant risk while they remain undisturbed. In the event<br /><br />
that at some future point the existing ore stockpiles are to be removed this operation has the potential<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 246<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
to lose material through dust dispersion and rainwater run-off, leading to direct impacts in estuarine<br /><br />
water quality, and secondary impacts to coastal and subtidal habitats and fauna. Considering the<br /><br />
large volume of old ore currently present at Pepel, these could potentially be significant, depending on<br /><br />
the clearance and transport procedures put in place.<br /><br />
Whilst it has been shown that slight positive impacts associated with increased rates of growth<br /><br />
(particularly in younger mangrove plants) have been associated with iron contamination, toxicity limits<br /><br />
are not known and the potential for synergistic negative responses remain.<br /><br />
Alongi (2010) found that growth of five mangrove species from seedling to sapling stage were<br /><br />
enhanced by increasing iron supply, although some species showed iron toxicity at higher supply<br /><br />
rates. Paling et al., (2001) note that iron ore dust does not enter or damage the stomatal cells in<br /><br />
leaves of the white mangrove (Avicennia marina). The authors concluded that if iron ore dust affects<br /><br />
mangroves, “it must do so by some other mechanism, such as either increased temperature, shading<br /><br />
or a restriction of transportation by the thickness of the dust on the abaxial surface”.<br /><br />
Over the past 24 years rain and wind activity has subjected the old stockpiles to leaching, and there is<br /><br />
a chance that the percentage of leachable material remaining is now very low. Results of leachate<br /><br />
tests on a single sample comprising principally ore filings from the stockpile support this assumption.<br /><br />
This would substantially diminish the potential impact, and further assessment on the nature of the<br /><br />
residual material is required before a full conclusion can be made. There is currently no evidence of<br /><br />
any existing impact on the surrounding mangroves due to the presence of the residual hematite ore,<br /><br />
although there are elevated levels of heavy metals in the nearshore soil samples (Hydrological<br /><br />
baseline survey, April 2010).<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR marine fauna is considered to be of moderate significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR coastal habitat is considered to be of moderate significance.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures:<br /><br />
• Undertake physical and chemical analysis of the residual iron ore prior to removal;<br /><br />
• Ensure appropriate collection and treatment of run-off during construction; and<br /><br />
• Implement an appropriate Waste Management Plan to guarantee minimal loss of material to<br /><br />
the coastal and marine environment during removal.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.5.2 Port Facilities<br /><br />
In general, port construction or refurbishment activities tend to disturb coastal and marine flora and<br /><br />
fauna due to the generation of noise and dust, the continuous use of electric lighting, and changes in<br /><br />
water quality from runoff and discharges of contaminants.<br /><br />
Increased Noise<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 247<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The use of heavy machinery during construction tends to temporarily increase ambient noise levels,<br /><br />
which can potentially result in disturbance of sensitive coastal fauna such as birds. The Ramsar site<br /><br />
covers the majority of the estuary, and Pepel sits within one of the core areas. The current level of<br /><br />
noise in Pepel is relatively low, due to the low human population and lack of any significant port<br /><br />
activity. As a result, higher noise levels may result in significant impacts on birds. Further information<br /><br />
is provided on the impacts to avifauna and terrestrial fauna in the terrestrial noise assessment.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the potential impact on VR avifauna is considered to be major<br /><br />
Mitigation measures:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Adapt construction activities to avoid areas of high avifauna population, important nesting and<br /><br />
feeding sites, and migratory and nesting seasons; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Avoid the most sensitive times of the day e.g. extended night operations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Increased Light Levels<br /><br />
Persistent man-made light can be a major issue for a range of marine fauna, with birds in particular<br /><br />
sensitive to increased and extended levels. Non-natural light can deter them from feeding, breeding<br /><br />
and nesting, and can generally confuse their natural behaviour (Longcore and Rich, 2004, Lorne &<br /><br />
Salmon, 2007, Witherington, 1992).<br /><br />
Due to the high density of wetland birds present in the project location, and its position inside a<br /><br />
designated Ramsar site, increased light is a potentially significant impact, especially if construction<br /><br />
work would take place during bird migratory or breeding seasons. The low levels of current manmade light at Pepel also contribute to this impact.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the potential impact on VR avifauna is considered to be major<br /><br />
Mitigation measures:<br /><br />
• Avoid strong lighting on any sensitive habitat areas, use shading methods wherever possible;<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
• Evaluate the use of low-pressure sodium vapour lamps, as this wavelength does not disorient<br /><br />
fauna as much as regular full spectrum lighting.<br /><br />
Wastewater Discharge<br /><br />
If appropriate collection and treatment systems are not in place, the presence of construction camps<br /><br />
pose a threat to estuarine water quality due to wastewater discharge. Discharge of untreated<br /><br />
wastewater into the estuary has the potential to affect water pH, colour, temperature, smell, dissolved<br /><br />
oxygen, nutrient levels and bacterial contamination. This can create indirect impacts on the estuary<br /><br />
ecosystem, as well as posing a health risk to local communities; especially if the discharge point is<br /><br />
located near to beaches used by locals for fishing or bathing.<br /><br />
The significance of the impact of waste water discharge is highly dependant on the treatment system<br /><br />
implemented in the project design, and the location of the discharge point in the estuary.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR marine fauna is considered to be of moderate significance.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR coastal habitat and VR subtidal habitat is considered to be of<br /><br />
moderate significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR human development potential (i.e. fisheries) is considered to be of<br /><br />
moderate significance.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Design an appropriate wastewater collection and treatment system utilising the best available<br /><br />
techniques;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Install a temporary treatment plant to treat construction camp discharges;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The treated water discharge point should be located away from sensitive locations such as<br /><br />
mudflats, mangroves and areas of community use; in an area with strong tidal currents to<br /><br />
increase dilution and removal; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In the absence of national legislation, the treatment system should meet World Bank<br /><br />
discharge limits, to ensure the receiving water quality is within appropriate international<br /><br />
standards.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A more detailed assessment of wastewater discharges is required to develop the mitigation methods<br /><br />
further.<br /><br />
Spills and Run-off of Oil and Chemical contaminants<br /><br />
During construction and refurbishment there is a risk of increased run-off due to earthworks, and the<br /><br />
use of heavy machinery, including the disturbance of contamination from the previous port operations.<br /><br />
There is also a risk of oil and chemical contamination from fuel, lubricants and coatings used in<br /><br />
construction machinery, and from potential oil spills.<br /><br />
The significance of this impact will depend upon the level of increased run off and/or spills, and their<br /><br />
location and proximity to coastal habitat such as mangroves or mudflats; mangroves are particularly<br /><br />
sensitive to oil spills.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR marine fauna is considered to be of moderate significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR coastal habitat and VR subtidal habitat is considered to be of<br /><br />
moderate significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR human development potential (i.e. fisheries) is considered to be of<br /><br />
moderate significance.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Design an appropriate run-off collection and treatment system using the best available<br /><br />
techniques prior to discharge. Coatings (e.g. anti-fouling) should be selected to minimize<br /><br />
contamination risk;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Develop and implement an appropriate Waste Management Plan that would define the best<br /><br />
ways of dealing with waste oils, following the industry best practices;<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />

<br /><br />

<br /><br />
The ESHIA process to date has already been influential in modifying the Pepel Port design so that<br /><br />
earthworks at Pepel are designed to slope away from water and include a settling sump to collect<br /><br />
sediment in run-off. This is subject to ongoing assessment and drainage design to manage run-off<br /><br />
during construction stage. As such further modifications and improvement will be controlled through<br /><br />
a management process in order to implement mitigation methods.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.5.3 Marine Structures<br /><br />
In addition to the terrestrial port infrastructure, the refurbishment of marine structures has the potential<br /><br />
to cause a range of additional effects on the marine environment. These include disturbance of<br /><br />
coastal and subtidal habitat, changes in water quality and associated underwater noise.<br /><br />
Refurbishment of Mooring Dolphins<br /><br />
The refurbishment and potential construction of mooring dolphins, to enable the mooring of<br /><br />
transshipment vessels will primarily impact on the sub-tidal habitat. The sub-tidal habitat directly<br /><br />
beneath could be impacted through smothering, pile driving, and placement of rock material. At the<br /><br />
time of writing, detailed information on the precise nature of sub-tidal habitat at the proposed locations<br /><br />
of the dolphins had not been collected but is believed to be soft sediment, with no sensitive habitat.<br /><br />
As the structures are relatively small, disturbance will be localised and restricted. No other major<br /><br />
structures will be added to the existing loading jetties during port operations.<br /><br />
The impact on VR sub-tidal habitat without mitigation is considered to be minor.<br /><br />
No mitigation measures are required other than further characterisation of the subtidal habitat.<br /><br />
Increased Turbidity<br /><br />
The construction and refurbishment of marine structures could result in elevated turbidity within the<br /><br />
immediate vicinity of the port. Activities such as piling can significantly disturb bottom sediments,<br /><br />
introducing material into the water column. Increased turbidity can result in a number of direct and<br /><br />
indirect impacts on coastal and marine ecosystems; for example, levels of photosynthesis can fall due<br /><br />
to a drop in light penetration down through the water column. This can impact on marine flora, and on<br /><br />
up through the marine fauna food chain, limiting the ability of organisms to grow, reproduce and<br /><br />
survive.<br /><br />
The degree to which turbidity and smothering affects benthic species is dependent on pre-existing<br /><br />
ambient water quality conditions and the tolerances of local species (ABP Research, 1999; Ellison,<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 250<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1999). Coastal habitats such as mangroves can also be affected by high levels of turbidity, but<br /><br />
specific tolerances vary with species (Ellison, 1999).<br /><br />
During the wet season, the Sierra Leone River Estuary is characterized by high rainfall, and<br /><br />
associated run-off and riverine input. The estuarine water flowing through the project area<br /><br />
experiences high levels of turbidity all year round and particularly during the wet season and on the<br /><br />
ebb tide. This has been confirmed by a specific monitoring campaign. Therefore marine fauna and<br /><br />
habitats in the Pepel area are likely to be resilient to increased turbidity, particularly over short<br /><br />
durations such as that required for construction.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR marine fauna is considered to be of minor significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR coastal habitat and VR subtidal habitat is considered to be of<br /><br />
minor significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR human development potential (i.e. fisheries) is considered to be of<br /><br />
minor significance.<br /><br />
Although the impact is expected to be minor the following mitigation measures should be considered:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Use of floating turbidity barriers and/or silt curtains to contain turbidity plumes during marine<br /><br />
construction activities; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Design construction activity to occur in periods of high dispersion (e.g. ebb tide).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Disturbance of Contaminated Sediments<br /><br />
Construction/refurbishment activity has the potential to disturb marine sediment. If the sediment<br /><br />
retains any pre-existing contamination (e.g. hydrocarbons or metals) water quality may be impacted<br /><br />
through the re-introduction of these contaminants into the water column. If these released<br /><br />
contaminants are assimilated by marine flora or fauna (e.g. mangroves, fish and shellfish) they can<br /><br />
accumulate in the food chain, impacting on many areas of the marine ecosystem and the local human<br /><br />
population dependant on these resources.<br /><br />
Whilst showing elevated levels of hydrocarbons directly opposite the main loading jetty the sediment<br /><br />
analysis from the preliminary marine baseline survey (March 2010) showed little signs of major<br /><br />
contamination. However, the hydrological baseline survey (April 2010) sampled several onshore<br /><br />
areas close to the high water mark, and showed high levels of arsenic, chromium, copper, lead and<br /><br />
zinc7; potentially a result of the leached materials from the pre-existing port infrastructure. The area<br /><br />
where the mooring dolphins are to be constructed lies between these two areas. At the time of writing,<br /><br />
no detailed study has been completed on intertidal sediment quality and around the proposed dolphin<br /><br />
locations but a survey covering this area is underway and will be reported in the Stage 2 report.<br /><br />
Undertake a detailed characterization of nearshore and intertidal marine sediments (Physical,<br /><br />
Chemical and Biological) to assess the risk of contamination prior to construction; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Increased Underwater Noise<br /><br />
Underwater construction activities, in particular pile driving, can generate high levels of underwater<br /><br />
noise with the frequency, intensity and persistence of underwater noise dictating its potential effects<br /><br />
on different marine species. Whilst temporary, these levels of noise can disturb sensitive marine<br /><br />
fauna.<br /><br />
Many marine organisms such as marine mammals, fish, and even some invertebrates use sound for<br /><br />
a variety of purposes; for example in communication, to locate mates, to search for prey, to avoid<br /><br />
predators and hazards, and for short- and long-range navigation (OSPAR, 2009). All these species<br /><br />
and others such as turtles may alter their behaviour if subject to high noise levels. It is generally<br /><br />
accepted that exposure to anthropogenic sound can induce a range of adverse effects on marine life,<br /><br />
from insignificant impacts to significant behavioural changes, to in some cases stranding and death<br /><br />
(OSPAR, 2009; Southall et al. 2007).<br /><br />
No evidence exists showing that cetaceans are present in the immediate project area, although heavy<br /><br />
piling can affect whales and dolphins many kilometres away from the source. Manatees generally<br /><br />
remain higher up the estuary, and do not venture as far down as Pepel, and no significant turtle<br /><br />
presence is expected at Pepel. All these statements are subject to review following dedicated marine<br /><br />
mammal and turtle surveys.<br /><br />
Heavy underwater noise could be expected to impact on small pelagic fish, particularly during<br /><br />
spawning season, leading to indirect effects in fisheries. However, considering that the impact would<br /><br />
be localized and temporary, impacts are not considered to be significant.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR marine fauna is considered to be of moderate significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR human development potential (i.e. fisheries) is considered to be of<br /><br />
moderate significance.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Design the construction activities to avoid critical spawning and breeding seasons; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />

7.6.1 Presence of Marine Structures<br /><br />
The coast is a dynamic environment and is subject to constant change; with natural processes such<br /><br />
as tidal currents and wave action leading to coastal erosion, accretion and reshaping. Any changes to<br /><br />
or construction of marine structures has the potential to alter these established physical processes.<br /><br />
Over time changes in the sediment transport regime may result, leading to alterations in general<br /><br />
coastal morphology. These changes may have secondary impacts on marine ecology and human<br /><br />
users of the sea e.g. fisheries nursery grounds.<br /><br />
However, this project is primarily a refurbishment of existing marine structures at Pepel. The marine<br /><br />
structures have been in place for decades. The current coastal morphology has therefore developed<br /><br />
to account for their presence. In addition, the two extra, if required, mooring dolphins are relatively<br /><br />
small, and the degree of any disturbance to physical transport processes will be localised and<br /><br />
restricted. No other major marine structures will be added to the existing loading jetties.<br /><br />
Before mitigation, the impact on VR coastal morphology is considered to be insignificant.<br /><br />
No mitigation measures are required<br /><br />
<br /><br />

The impact of the wastewater discharge is highly dependent on the treatment system implemented in<br /><br />

required.<br /><br />

Handling of Iron Ore<br /><br />
During bulk handling operations such as stockpiling, processing and transport, the potential exists for<br /><br />
iron ore dust to enter the coastal and marine environment through wind and/or surface run-off. Iron is<br /><br />
an essential trace element required by most organisms, but it can be toxic at extreme concentrations.<br /><br />
There is little information currently available on toxicity for marine species, but iron forms colloidal<br /><br />
suspensions of ferric hydroxide in the presence of oxygen, which can remain suspended in water or<br /><br />
settle into sediment, causing problems with turbidity, light penetration and smothering of benthic<br /><br />
organisms.<br /><br />
If not treated correctly, large volumes of dust and/or run-off have the potential to directly affect<br /><br />
mangroves, by reducing photosynthesis and chemical impacting their root structures. Most mangrove<br /><br />
species breathe via their surface roots, and wind and surface water-borne pollutants can easily affect<br /><br />
this process. Additionally, iron supply often limits production in marine environments and can exert<br /><br />
controls on the dynamics of plankton blooms (Boyd et al., (2007); a secondary impact on fish might<br /><br />
be the occasional local increase in food availability for Bonga (Ethmalosa fimbriata) which feed on<br /><br />
plankton. Inputs of iron to the marine environment can also create a visual impact, as the presence of<br /><br />
high concentrations8 can turn the water an ochre (red) colour.<br /><br />
Pepel Island is located in a core area of the Sierra Leone Estuary Ramsar site, and is considered an<br /><br />
area of high ecological value. The potential impact of metal contamination on coastal and subtidal<br /><br />
habitats, marine fauna and human users of the estuary i.e. fisheries is considered to be highly<br /><br />
significant. Iron ore can possibly render fish to a higher risk of toxic effects from potentially harmful<br /><br />
algal exudates. Bury and Grosell (2003) note that whilst iron is a vital micronutrient for teleost fish, in<br /><br />
excess it can be toxic. Fish in SLRE may be exposed to increased iron levels in both dissolved and<br /><br />
dietary phases (Bu-Olayan and Thomas, 2008). Mudskippers are prey for many predators and hence<br /><br />
a path for bioaccumulation.<br /><br />
Bury et al., (2003) note that iron is an essential nutrient to almost all organisms. One of irons key<br /><br />
cellular functions is to confer redox activity to the cytochromes involved in respiration, due to its ability<br /><br />
<br /><br />
8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Maximum concentrations for iron in marine waters in the US are 0.3 mg/l and in the UK 0.1 mg/l. These are believed to be<br /><br />
primarily for aesthetic reasons.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
to exchange electrons in aerobic conditions. A negative consequence of irons redox flexibility is that<br /><br />
it produces oxygen free radicals that are toxic to the cell. Consequently, in excess, iron can be<br /><br />
detrimental to health. In addition, excess waterborne iron may be toxic to fish, due to the formation of<br /><br />
iron flocs on the gills, resulting in gill clogging and respiratory perturbations.<br /><br />
The current existence of a diverse and healthy mangrove environment at Pepel demonstrates that the<br /><br />
coastal habitat can adapt in the long term to a certain level of metal contamination. Fish and shellfish<br /><br />
sampling is ongoing and will yield information on iron contamination in fish.<br /><br />

of material to the coastal and marine environment.<br /><br />

Fuel Handling Operations<br /><br />
Fuel for power generation will be transported by road and vessels will not refuel at Pepel, therefore no<br /><br />
fuel handling operations are planned within the marine area of the port.<br /><br />
The movement and use of fuel oils for power generation is a potentially significant source of<br /><br />
hydrocarbon contamination to local coastal and subtidal habitats. Mangroves are particularly<br /><br />
susceptible to hydrocarbon pollution, which manifests itself in the intertidal and particularly affects the<br /><br />
ability of pneumatophores (in particular) and prop roots to regulate salt content and for the mangrove<br /><br />
to breathe. Therefore, if there are any fuel handling operations a detailed environmental management<br /><br />
and contingency plans must be in place.<br /><br />
Any spills within the port facility have the potential to contaminate the coastal habitats via run-off or<br /><br />
groundwater.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR marine fauna is considered to be minor.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR coastal habitat is considered to be moderate.<br /><br />

7.6.3 Associated Shipping Activities<br /><br />
As Pepel Port has been out of use for several years, its regeneration will increase marine traffic<br /><br />
between Pepel Port and Freetown, creating disturbance to other marine users such as fishing boats.<br /><br />
Ports may have a role in terms of appropriate reception facilities, guidance to port users and<br /><br />
inspection of documentation.<br /><br />
Navigation and Fishing<br /><br />
The majority of marine traffic in the estuary is focussed around Freetown. Numbers from 2008<br /><br />
indicate that 368 vessels used the main commercial port, 352 of which were cargo ships, whilst the<br /><br />
rest were industrial fishing, military and research vessels. In the wider estuary shipping is believed to<br /><br />
be limited to small artisanal fishing boats and passenger vessels, and the Freetown to Tagrin ferry.<br /><br />
Transshipment operations are currently expected to involve Handymax transshipment vessels, which<br /><br />
will transfer ore to a loading on anchorage point outside the mouth of the estuary. These vessels will<br /><br />
be of a similar size to those previously using Pepel port. As the port has been inactive for some time,<br /><br />
vessels of this size have not been used as far up the estuary as Pepel for a number of years.<br /><br />
However, only two transshipment vessels will be in operation and each will make one round trip per<br /><br />
day. Although relatively large, the volume of movement of these vessels up and down the estuary will<br /><br />
be low. Considering the amount of other commercial traffic and large cargo vessels using Freetown<br /><br />
port, the impact of the transshipment operations on shipping in the estuary is not expected to be<br /><br />
significant.<br /><br />
Consultation with the fishing community is ongoing and further assessment will be undertaken. The<br /><br />
transshipment anchorage location is also yet to be finalised. Therefore it is considered to be a<br /><br />
moderate impact within this assessment.<br /><br />
The impact on VR Infrastructure Changes – shipping is considered to be of minor significance.<br /><br />
The impact on VR Infrastructure Changes – shipping is considered to be of minor significance.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Further consultation with the fishing community (already underway).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Navigation Guidance must be provided to vessels using the port and other shipping and<br /><br />
fishing vessels in the area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Risk to Marine Fauna – Underwater Noise and Collisions<br /><br />
As discussed in Section 7.5.2, underwater noise can impact on marine mammals, sea turtles and fish.<br /><br />
Marine vessels, in particularly large bulk carriers are relatively loud sources of underwater noise.<br /><br />
Their continued presence in the estuary, and the offshore area outside of the mouth, has the potential<br /><br />
to affect the behavioural ecology of local marine fauna. In addition, many species of whales and<br /><br />

Increased Light Levels<br /><br />
Persistent man-made light from vessels, an operational port, and navigation aids throughout the<br /><br />
channel could impact significantly on marine fauna; with birds in particular sensitive to increased and<br /><br />
extended levels. Non-natural light can deter them from feeding, breeding and nesting, and can<br /><br />
generally confuse their natural behaviour (Longcore and Rich, 2004, Lorne & Salmon, 2007,<br /><br />
Witherington, 1992).<br /><br />
Due to the high density of wetland birds present in the project location, and its position inside a<br /><br />
designated RAMSAR site, increased light is a potentially significant impact, especially as year round<br /><br />
operations will continue during bird migratory and breeding seasons. The current low levels of manmade light at Pepel exacerbate this potential impact, particularly if bright navigation aids are to be<br /><br />
placed in the approach channel to the port.<br /><br />
With respect to vessels moving up and down the estuary, there is already a large degree of light<br /><br />
pollution at Tagrin and Freetown, and transshipment vessels are not expected to significantly<br /><br />
increase the level of light at the mouth of the estuary. Closer to the port however, this impact may<br /><br />
become significant.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the potential impact on VR avifauna is considered to be moderate<br /><br />
Before mitigation the potential impact on VR marine fauna is considered to be moderate.<br /><br />

Ballast Water and Marine Pests<br /><br />
The introduction of invasive species is of concern during the operational phase with the increase in<br /><br />
shipping activities. Before a voyage when they are not laden with cargo, ships take in a certain<br /><br />
amount of water for stability. Once the ship arrives at its destination it may release the ballast water<br /><br />
at the destination location. Ballast water can contain large amounts of sediment and microscopic<br /><br />
organisms, eggs and larvae. International shipping is responsible for the majority of these alien<br /><br />
species invading foreign waters. The effects of introducing new animals and plants can be almost<br /><br />
undetectable, or conversely they can completely displace native communities.<br /><br />
The 2004 International Convention for the Control and Management of Ships' Ballast Water and<br /><br />
Sediments (from which Sierra Leone is signatory) establishes that all ships using ballast water<br /><br />
exchange should whenever possible, conduct ballast water exchange at least 200 nautical miles from<br /><br />
the nearest land and in water at least 200 metres in depth. The transshipment vessels to be used in<br /><br />
the estuary will only have to release foreign ballast water once on arrival, and as all bulk carriers<br /><br />
arriving for ore loading will not be entering the estuary, this impact is considered to be minor as long<br /><br />
as correct exchange procedures are followed.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR marine fauna is considered to be of moderate significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR coastal habitat is considered to be of minor significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR subtidal habitat is considered to be of moderate significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR human development potential – fisheries is considered to be of<br /><br />
minor significance.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ensure the 2004 International Convention for the Control and Management of Ships' Ballast<br /><br />
Water and Sediments is strictly followed by all ships approaching the anchorage loading<br /><br />
point; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A monitoring program to check for the presence of invasive species, and to undertake regular<br /><br />
assessment of sensitive habitat areas.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Vessel Waste Management and Discharges<br /><br />
Routine discharges from vessels include uncontaminated deck drainage, potentially contaminated<br /><br />
drainage from machinery spaces, engine cooling water and treated sewage / grey water. The<br /><br />
potential effects on water quality are similar to the effects created by discharges from the port, such<br /><br />
as changes in water pH, colour, temperature, smell, dissolved oxygen, nutrient levels and bacterial<br /><br />
contamination.<br /><br />
The source of pollution in the case of barges/tugs is a moving source, with a potentially larger area of<br /><br />
impact but a higher dilution rate, and therefore the impact is not considered to be significant.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR marine fauna is considered to be of moderate significance.<br /><br />

Transshipment Anchorage<br /><br />
Loading on anchorage impacts during transshipment are generally associated with material spillages<br /><br />
and dust dispersion, leading to impacts on water quality, coastal and subtidal habitats and marine<br /><br />
fauna. Although the system is designed to be highly efficient, the cumulative impact over the life of the<br /><br />
project could be significant.<br /><br />
The potential behaviour of the iron ore in the water will depend on the spillage particle size and its<br /><br />
chemical composition. Generally, iron often forms colloidal suspensions of ferric hydroxide in the<br /><br />
presence of oxygen, which can remain suspended in water or settle into the sediment. Potential<br /><br />
impacts include increased turbidity, reduced light penetration, smothering of benthic organisms and<br /><br />
aesthetic impacts (water discolouration). Iron is not generally toxic to marine fauna. A full chemical<br /><br />
assay is required to understand if there are any other contaminants of concern within the hematite,<br /><br />
although this is considered unlikely. Modelling can be used to assess concentrations within the water<br /><br />
column for comparison to toxicity thresholds.<br /><br />
There is also a risk non-routine events such as a vessel collision leading to much larger spills into the<br /><br />
estuary. It is considered pertinent to conduct a QRA to ascertain the level of risk associated with<br /><br />
accidental spills at sea or within the Pepel Port area once details concerning shipping are confirmed.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR marine fauna is considered to be of moderate significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR coastal habitat and VR subtidal habitat is considered to be of<br /><br />
moderate significance.<br /><br />

moderate significance.<br /><br />

•<br /><br />
<br /><br />

and<br /><br />

Design and implement an appropriate Transport Management Plan to guarantee minimal loss<br /><br />
of material to the coastal and marine environment.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Undertake a QRA of port and shipping activities.<br /><br />
