AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.6.4 Associated Dredging Activities<br /><br />
Capital dredging will be required to open the navigation channel to access Pepel port. The capital<br /><br />
dredging is expected to only remove infill that has occurred since the closure of Pepel Port to<br /><br />
reinstate the previous channel. Ongoing maintenance dredging will then be required to keep the<br /><br />
channel open but the volume required will be smaller. The total predicted dredging volume is<br /><br />
approximately 1.5 million m3 based on UKHO admiralty charts. As explained in the Project Description<br /><br />
the dredging volume will be finalised following bathymetric and geotechnical surveys.<br /><br />
Key potential impacts from dredging activities include changes in water quality due to increased<br /><br />
turbidity and disturbance of potentially contaminated sediments; removal and smothering of the<br /><br />
benthos. There are also potential impacts from light and noise, particularly as 24 hour operations will<br /><br />
take place. Secondary impacts can include changes in waves and currents due to changes in<br /><br />
bathymetry. There is also a potential impact on fishing.<br /><br />
Sediment grabs from the dredge channel indicate that most of the channel is medium to coarse sand,<br /><br />
which is expected given the strong tidal currents through the channel. Coarse silt was found at one<br /><br />
location to the north-west of Tasso Island, this may be due to the slowing of the tidal currents around<br /><br />
the bend in the channel. There is no evidence of any areas of reef in and around the channel and as<br /><br />
the channel is being reinstated these sand and silt sediments are expected to exist throughout.<br /><br />
Macrofaunal communities are typical of such sediments in an estuarine environment and are not of<br /><br />
high biodiversity value.<br /><br />
The estuary is turbid in the area around the dredge channel due to the high sediment load from the<br /><br />
tributaries and wetlands inputting to the estuary and the strong tidal currents. Suspended solids<br /><br />
concentrations of up to 40 mg/l were measured in the lower part of the water column in the dredge<br /><br />
channel. Turbidity of up to 350 NTU was measured in the channel close to Pepel, for comparison 25<br /><br />
NTU is considered murky. Although the dredging methodology has not been finalised there are<br /><br />
mitigation measures inherent in the design to reduce the concentration and extent of any dredge<br /><br />
plumes, in particular from the hopper overflow though the use of the adjustable overflow funnel and<br /><br />
green valve described in the Project Description. Therefore the impact is expected to be minor.<br /><br />
However, within the EMP any dredge plumes will be modelled and compared to background turbidity<br /><br />
and suspended solids data.<br /><br />
The dredging will take place over a relatively short period and due to the type of dredger proposed<br /><br />
underwater noise levels are expected to be comparable with those created by shipping.<br /><br />
As the dredging will involve only the reinstatement of the previous channel no significant changes in<br /><br />
currents, sediment transport or morphology are expected. As the dredge channel is within the estuary<br /><br />
waves are not an issue.<br /><br />
Consultation with local fishing communities is underway. There is some fishing activity in the vicinity<br /><br />
of the channel and potential setting of nets. Further information is being collected through the<br /><br />
consultation process. The period of dredging is relatively short but it will still be necessary to ensure<br /><br />
that the fisherman and communities close to the dredge channel are informed of activities and<br /><br />
procedures. This will be facilitated through the consultation process, which will be within the EMP.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 260<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The effects of dredged spoil disposal will be site specific and dependent on the characteristics of the<br /><br />
dredged material and the hydrodynamic conditions in the area. The primary issues are the smothering<br /><br />
and changing of the benthos and the risk of contamination of the disposal site. In addition, there is a<br /><br />
risk of increased suspended sediment and turbidity. The finer the material and the greater the energy<br /><br />
at the disposal site, the greater the possibility of increased suspended sediments and turbidity.<br /><br />
A video survey of spoil ground was undertaken during the marine environmental baseline survey. This<br /><br />
found that the area was dominated by soft bottom sediments with no areas of reef. There are reef<br /><br />
areas, such as Carpenter’s rocks, to the south of the dredge spoil disposal ground but these are<br /><br />
some distance away. Therefore an initial assessment indicates that the impact will be minor. Once the<br /><br />
dredging methodology is finalised an assessment of the deposition of the dredge material will be<br /><br />
undertaken including modelling of the dredge material to ensure that it is deposited within the spoil<br /><br />
ground and any dredge plume does not impact the reef habitats that have been identified within the<br /><br />
vicinity of the dredge spoil disposal ground.<br /><br />
There is evidence of sediment contamination around the existing Pepel port above sediment quality<br /><br />
guidelines9. However, initial samples within the dredge channel indicate that the area of<br /><br />
contamination does not extend that far from the port land-side. As part of the EMP cores will be taken<br /><br />
and sub-sampled for environmental analysis to confirm whether there are any seabed sediment<br /><br />
contamination issues and, if found appropriate action will be taken.<br /><br />
There is also a risk of dredging impacting on shipwrecks which may have Cultural Heritage. A review<br /><br />
of the UK Hydrographic Office wrecks database does not indicate that there are any wrecks in the<br /><br />
dredge channel or at the disposal site. The geophysical survey of the channel will confirm this.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR marine fauna is considered to be of moderate significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR coastal habitat and VR subtidal habitat is considered to be of<br /><br />
moderate significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR human development potential i.e. fisheries is considered to be of<br /><br />
moderate significance.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR cultural heritage (marine archaeology) is considered to be<br /><br />
insignificant.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The primary mitigation measure is to follow the London Convention of 1972 and subsequent<br /><br />
protocol of 1976, to which Sierra Leone is a signatory (see Legislation and Guidance section).<br /><br />
This includes guidance on the sampling of sediments for contamination and the selection of a<br /><br />
dredged disposal site.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mitigation measures will be included within the dredging equipment and methods to minimise<br /><br />
the extent of any dredge plumes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In the absence of national or international standards the Canadian Sediment Quality Guidelines for the Protection<br /><br />
of Aquatic Life (Update 2002) are used, which are based upon recognised toxicological methods.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.7<br /><br />
7.7.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Distributed Impacts from Project<br /><br />
Bulk material management<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Material required for ground improvement across the project will need to be sourced locally from<br /><br />
multiple quarry sites and borrow pit. This has the potential for significantly broadening the impacts<br /><br />
from the project. Consequently all bulk material activities will need to be managed through specific<br /><br />
environmental management and be accountable through contract terms to a single, best-practice<br /><br />
source of guidelines.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.7.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Demand on existing infrastructure & resources<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The provision of goods and services to maintain the project, co-use of infrastructure such as roads,<br /><br />
power and telecoms networks and the effect of a large logistics operation and mobilization throughout<br /><br />
the project footprint has the potential to create significant impact and over-demand on the existing,<br /><br />
fragile and undeveloped infrastructure and resources.<br /><br />
Logistics, programming, procurement and the provision and expectations for good and services are<br /><br />
dealt with under a project’s feasibility study and execution plan which is outside of the scope of this<br /><br />
study.<br /><br />
Due to the broad scope of these activities it is not considered meaningful to suggest a single source<br /><br />
of management to regulate this. Instead the project consultation and disclosure system coupled with<br /><br />
a grievance system, established by the proponent will be utilized to ensure that project activities are<br /><br />
announced publicly and that a response system is in place should problems arise. This has been<br /><br />
described under the social management section.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.7.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Solid waste management<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It is anticipated that sound waste management practice will have limited impact on the existing<br /><br />
infrastructure within the region. Waste management proposals have been determined based on the<br /><br />
proximity principle, locating facilities as close as possible to major waste generation sources.<br /><br />
Delivery of the proposed incineration units should consider the existing road infrastructure.<br /><br />
The greatest impact is likely to arise from interim storage of wastes in particular pest, odour and litter<br /><br />
control. During storage organic waste will decay and generate small volumes of methane gas which<br /><br />
should be allowed to vent to the atmosphere.<br /><br />
Consideration should be made in waste storage areas for adequate drainage, particular during the<br /><br />
rainy season. Run off from waste storage should be minimised and treated as leachate rather than<br /><br />
being discharged into the conventional drainage system. Provision should be made for storage and<br /><br />
evaporation ponds where existing infrastructure is inadequate.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Potential Mitigation Measures<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implement a hierarchy of waste elimination at source, recycling, reuse, recovery, and – as a<br /><br />
last resort - disposal;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Destruct or treat hazardous waste to render it non-hazardous if possible;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
If the hazard cannot be eliminated, contain waste in a secure manner and monitor to ensure it<br /><br />
cannot damage the environment;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Segregate and quantify waste for effective management;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Use a system of waste manifests to track generation, transportation, receipt and disposal;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Audit waste transport or disposal companies prior to contracting.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
ONGOING ASSESSMENT WORKS<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Further ESHIA works required for this project (Stage 1) which will be reported in the Stage 2<br /><br />
assessment are set out in the Environmental Management Plan (EMP) in Appendix 18.<br /><br />
Air & Noise<br /><br />
Spot sampling of air quality parameters and baseline noise have been conducted to date. Detailed<br /><br />
impact assessment requires a more accurate knowledge of the background air quality and a refined<br /><br />
estimate of the project contribution to the existing background levels. For this purpose a second round<br /><br />
of baseline data collection is currently being undertaken at the start of June 2010 and further<br /><br />
seasonal coverage will be required which will involve works that extend into and beyond the Stage 2<br /><br />
ESHIA reporting period. Some targeted baseline data collection, interpretation and assessment can<br /><br />
only be carried out after detailed Phase 1 designs are available including major power source<br /><br />
designs/locations and airfield/aircraft details. Air assessment and design feedback to ensure<br /><br />
compliance with air quality standards will be presented in the Stage 2 report. Based on the currently<br /><br />
advised programme it is also assumed that some Tonkolili Phase 1 construction works will be<br /><br />
underway and therefore monitoring data will be available to support the assessment. An air<br /><br />
dispersion model will be developed in order to predict the expected air quality contributions from the<br /><br />
routine operations of the project with assessment standards based on national and international<br /><br />
guidelines.<br /><br />
Sampling to date has indicated (subject to verification) a predominantly non-industrial baseline for the<br /><br />
project area. It is therefore reasonable to assume that there will not be additional significant air<br /><br />
quality impact sources (i.e. from other industry) that could lead to a cumulative air quality loading in<br /><br />
addition to project contributions. Therefore assuming that mitigation and management applied by<br /><br />
AML is effective in mitigating air and noise sources this should mean that project contributions will not<br /><br />
lead to excessive levels.<br /><br />
The impacts from the proposed development on noise quality will be assessed following a quantitative<br /><br />
approach. Due to the large project area potentially affected by noise emissions, the target zones to<br /><br />
be modelled will be limited to the surroundings with the predicted highest noise emissions: the<br /><br />
perimeter of the mine facilities, the transport corridor (railway and roads) nearby populated areas and<br /><br />
the Phase 1 power plant/plants. Where significant potential noise impacts are identified, specific<br /><br />
mitigation measures will be suggested (e.g. construction of barrier panels) and tested in the noise<br /><br />
model to ensure that the predicted noise impacts will be mitigated.<br /><br />
Noise modelling will be conducted with SoundPLAN, an industry standard noise prediction software<br /><br />
used to calculate sound pressure levels and to generate noise mappings, considering reflections and<br /><br />
diffractions of sound, the geometry of buildings at the site, topography and climatic conditions. The<br /><br />
pressure levels calculated or interpolated for each point within the defined calculation area will be<br /><br />
shown as a grid of sound pressure values, from which a contour map will be generated showing<br /><br />
isophones (lines of equal sound pressure). The noise maps will show only the project contributions<br /><br />
and the cumulative effects will be assessed adding the existing noise background conditions at<br /><br />
sensitive receptors.<br /><br />

Ecology & Biodiversity<br /><br />
Vegetation<br /><br />
Further work will concentrate on the assessment of species and habitats of conservation concern in<br /><br />
the project area as well as on the study of habitats and localities that are not yet well documented or<br /><br />
understood and that are likely to be impacted by the mining activities. Requisite works include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Detailed aerial image interpretation to determine whether there is additional riverine system of<br /><br />
interest along the transport corridor that has not been previously identified or surveyed and<br /><br />
may deserve consideration.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Inland valley swamps have not yet been studied in detail and further surveys of selected inland<br /><br />
valley swamps are required to assess the presence/absence of species of conservation<br /><br />
concern.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The freshwater river areas and saline / freshwater transition zone of Port Loko Creek will be<br /><br />
surveyed in more detail, especially for rheophytes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Survey of Farangbaia Forest Reserve to determine the presence of species of conservation<br /><br />
concern found on project affected areas and the potential as an offsetting area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Surveys outside the anticipated impacted project footprint aimed at confirming presence of<br /><br />
species already identified as of conservation concern and so far found only on the Simbili<br /><br />
deposit or near proposed infrastructure. This will allow reassessment and potential lowering of<br /><br />
the conservation status of these species. This survey will also identify potential areas to be<br /><br />
protected and used as offsetting zones or relocation zones if required.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Inselbergs will be visited to assess remnant forest patches.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Other localities and habitats of potential conservation concern that have not yet been studied in<br /><br />
detail will be explored further. The most important localities and habitats are some parts of the<br /><br />
Tonkolili River (focusing mainly on the western valley, where some infrastructure related to rail<br /><br />
development may be located), the river channel community of the Tonkolili River near<br /><br />
Farangbaia, Pepel Port land lease, Port Loko freshwater ecosystems, the Toka River, and<br /><br />
some of the inland valley swamps along the rail / road corridor.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Fauna<br /><br />
In order to establish and validate pre-project baseline and trends the following supplementary Phase<br /><br />
2a and Phase 2b baseline studies are required and will be reported in the Tonkolili Stage 2 ESHIA or<br /><br />
follow up study reporting where seasonal constraints entail later works:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assess potential conservation strategies for Western Chimpanzee populations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assess the conservation value of extensive semi-natural seasonal wetlands and scattered<br /><br />
forest patches along the Toka river valley, essentially those between Makeni and Lunsar, and<br /><br />
the gallery evergreen forest along the Rokel upstream from Makeni to its confluence with the<br /><br />
Tonkolili River. These investigations will be most productive if undertaken in May and<br /><br />
November-December.<br /><br />

Freshwater<br /><br />
The Phase 1b aquatic ecosystem studies to date are high-level, rapid assessments that represent a<br /><br />
‘snapshot’ of conditions at the site. Pre-project trends as seasonal variations (such as water levels,<br /><br />
migration and breeding patterns) have not been investigated and defined. To establish pre-project<br /><br />

Wet and dry season aquatic surveys to describe the aquatic biota in the mining lease area and<br /><br />
transport corridor.<br /><br />

•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Aquatic fauna tissue metal survey to assess existing metal concentrations (that are likely to be<br /><br />
influenced by activities of artisanal miners and natural mineralisation in the area).<br /><br />

•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A comprehensive baseline water quality sampling programme will be undertaken in conjunction<br /><br />
with the hydrology and hydrogeology studies and monitoring programme.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Seasonal hydrological flow data collection, particularly for the downstream reaches of the<br /><br />
Mawuru and Tonkolili Rivers (where dams are proposed) is required and will be collected in<br /><br />
conjunction with the hydrology and hydrogeology studies and monitoring programme. Aquatic<br /><br />
surveys have not yet been undertaken in this area which contains many small streams and<br /><br />
brooks that may house endemic species and an aquatic fauna survey will describe establish<br /><br />
baseline conditions. A long term monitoring survey programme will be implemented in order to<br /><br />
assess effectiveness of any mitigation measures and allow remedial action in the event that<br /><br />
negative impacts are detected.<br /><br />

Health impact assessment. The list of health impacts developed during Stage 1 will be reevaluated and refined in light of the most up-to-date project details and the healthrelated inputs received from other assessment disciplines; and<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9<br /><br />
<br /><br />
MANAGEMENT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
An Environmental Management Plan (EMP) has been developed for the project (Appendix 18). The<br /><br />
EMP will interact with the project feasibility study and the ongoing ESHIA. The EMP includes<br /><br />
provisions for the control, mitigation, monitoring, reporting and auditing necessary to prevent or limit<br /><br />
potentially adverse environmental, social and health effects from the construction and operation of the<br /><br />
Project.<br /><br />
The EMP has been developed in parallel to the Stage 1 ESHIA. The intention is that the ongoing<br /><br />
ESHIA process will inform the EMP as requisite monitoring data becomes available. The EMP<br /><br />
provides a combination of environmental management practices as well as guidance on the principles<br /><br />
and elements to be included as the EMP develops over time and becomes more substantive with the<br /><br />
inclusion of further impact assessment information and data.<br /><br />
It is critical that an EMP is developed with the full participation of the owner/operators of the Project in<br /><br />
order that appropriate management and monitoring responsibility is embedded and communicated to<br /><br />
those who will be responsible for implementing these plans. AML have contributed significantly to the<br /><br />
development of this EMP document in terms of fully endorsing the intent of the EMP and its content<br /><br />
and structure. AML will be using the EMP as their environmental management reference for the<br /><br />
project.<br /><br />
The EMP should be treated as a ‘live’ document that requires updating and ongoing development<br /><br />
during all stages of the project. It is envisaged that the EMP would also in part be defined by, and<br /><br />
implemented through, the Environmental Management System (EMS) adopted by AML.<br /><br />
In addition, the EMP at this stage aims to provide a basis for the development of component-specific<br /><br />
(thematic) environmental management plans, which may be developed according to the requirements<br /><br />
of the project schedule giving priority to early works.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction vs. Operational Management Plans<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction management plans have already been developed as part of the current ESHIA works<br /><br />
program. This includes the materials prepared for the haul road which were presented to SLEPA at<br /><br />
an early stage to ensure the fast-tracked elements of the project are managed correctly. A Solid<br /><br />
Wastes Management Practice Guidelines has also been produced for Phase 1 of the Tonkolili project.<br /><br />
Further management plans will be required for the construction, operations and closure of specific<br /><br />
project components and facilities. An over-arching Environmental Management Plan (see Appendix<br /><br />
18) is needed to set out common approaches to standardise the specific plans. As the project<br /><br />
progresses management plans will be developed to address potential issues during the construction,<br /><br />
operations and closure phases and may include some of the following examples:<br /><br />
<br /><br />

will need to be further defined and scoped as part of the Stage 2 ESHIA.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Soil management<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Introduction<br /><br />
Many of the construction activities associated with the Phase 1 project will require some land<br /><br />
clearance however this will depend on features that materialize such as community land use,<br /><br />
environmental or community assets and/or ground conditions.<br /><br />
The haul road construction will involve clearance of a scout track for survey, ca. 6m width, followed by<br /><br />
widening, either symmetrically or asymmetrically depending on environmental and social<br /><br />
considerations. The scout track, but particularly the widening process will involve clearing of scrub<br /><br />
predominantly (as routing through well wooded areas has been minimised wherever possible) and<br /><br />
non-woody vegetation, followed by topsoil stripping. Topsoil is an important environmental and social<br /><br />
resource, as it is key to supporting natural vegetation and farming processes. In addition, where<br /><br />
vegetation is reasonably diverse, it contains the seeds and other propagules that under the right<br /><br />
circumstances can allow recolonisation of the original vegetation assemblage, hence reducing the<br /><br />
adverse effects on ecological resources.<br /><br />
There are other reasons for promoting rapid revegetation of disturbed areas not required for<br /><br />
trafficking, such as reducing erosion and preventing washout and scouring of cuts and embankments,<br /><br />
minimising fugitive dust emissions and contributing to landscape and noise screening.<br /><br />
Procedure<br /><br />
In all areas where depths permit, topsoil will be stripped to a minimum depth of 300mm and stored in<br /><br />
a berm (or two berms) parallel to the alignment, for later use. Topsoil shall not be stored where it<br /><br />
would result in blockage of formalized and agreed accesses or encroach onto farmland or where it<br /><br />
impedes water flow. It will not be stored where it can readily be washed into streams and rivers and<br /><br />
cause pollution.<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 287<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Following finalization of works the intention will be to cover non trafficked surfaces and in particular<br /><br />
cuts and embankments with topsoil to allow natural vegetation colonization.<br /><br />
In the case of the haul road construction, the height of the road train vehicles and the large diameter<br /><br />
of the curved bends, it is unlikely that vegetation will become a safety hazard due to reducing sight<br /><br />
lines. However, vegetation growth will be monitored by AML and the appropriate maintenance will be<br /><br />
introduced.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Borrow Pits<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Borrow pits and quarries to be used for this project will be managed with due consideration to social<br /><br />
and environmental concerns and after appropriate permits, where required, are in place. The<br /><br />
contractor will:<br /><br />
• Obtain AML approval before sourcing material from quarries, not opening borrow pits without<br /><br />
informing AML<br /><br />
• Not open borrow pits within 100m of riverbanks or well forested areas, where a risk to water<br /><br />
quality or forest resources is foreseen<br /><br />
For any new borrow pits, topsoil has to be managed carefully to allow for restoration of some<br /><br />
temporarily affected areas. Where possible topsoil will be stripped off to a typical depth of 300mm and<br /><br />
stored in windrow or berm for later use (e.g. landscaping embankments to reduce erosion during wet<br /><br />
season). Topsoil will not be mixed with low fertility subsoil to facilitate its use for restoration needs.<br /><br />
In the case of the haul road construction, where hills or hummocks along the transport route contain<br /><br />
suitable material, the relevant permissions will be obtained from local authorities, such as the<br /><br />
Paramount Chief, if applicable.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Water management<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Introduction<br /><br />
Water is of considerable importance throughout the project area, from surface water resources used<br /><br />
for irrigation, fishing, washing, bathing and in some cases potable supply. It is therefore necessary to<br /><br />
manage the construction works in such a manner that they forecast potential adverse effects and<br /><br />
either design them out or apply mitigation to minimize negative effects.<br /><br />
• Disturbance to river banks will be minimised by limiting the movement of machinery close to the<br /><br />
river’s edge;<br /><br />
• The areas to be cleared will be clearly defined before the start of works and no works/clearance<br /><br />
will be conducted outside this. If bridges are to be build, only higher trees will be removed,<br /><br />
leaving the low growth vegetation on site to avoid erosion issues and surface run-off.<br /><br />
• Clearing near to water courses will be conducted to minimise any materials or plant entering or<br /><br />
damaging the water course.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• Wherever possible, free-spanning bridge structures will be used with piled / trestle bridges as a<br /><br />
secondary option; solid embankment / causeway structures will not be used;<br /><br />
• Consideration will be given to wet season flow in designing watercourse crossings including<br /><br />
potential for blockage by trees and debris etc<br /><br />
• Flume pipes or pre-fabricated culverts will be used for crossings in areas with lower flow<br /><br />
• Machinery and other construction materials will be stockpiled no less than 50m back from the<br /><br />
river banks or otherwise to prevent pollution;<br /><br />
• A pre-construction photographic record will be recorded to establish a benchmark against<br /><br />
which post construction site rehabilitation can be monitored, where applicable;<br /><br />
• Sampling of water quality upstream, at work locations and downstream; locations and<br /><br />
parameters to be determined at a later date in the design of the haul road and subject to<br /><br />
agreement with environmental regulators as may be appropriate.<br /><br />
• Each river crossing will be surveyed to ascertain whether the river course is used as a transport<br /><br />
route by locals and / or a water source;<br /><br />
• The river bank either side of the crossing will be protected with sand bagging or other means<br /><br />
as may be necessary.<br /><br />
• Drainage control/ runoff protection including settling areas to prevent sudden influx of high<br /><br />
sediment from earthworks, will be implemented.<br /><br />
In view of the impending wet season, early identification of wet areas such as inland valley swamps<br /><br />
will be undertaken and where feasible, consideration will be given to early installation of flume pipes.<br /><br />
This will reduce potential pollution of water courses and damage to agricultural areas, as many of<br /><br />
these low lying areas are farmed by communities with dry season crops prior to the wet season crops.<br /><br />
These measures will also enable contractors to access their portion of the haul road without being<br /><br />
hindered by wet ground conditions following the onset of rains. An example of a flume pipe installed<br /><br />
on a haul road is presented below in Figure 9-1.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

9.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Swamp Areas & Riverine Vegetation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The swamp areas and riverine ecosystems are considered to have a high fragility and often a high<br /><br />
agricultural value and, therefore, impacts will be limited to the maximum extent possible.<br /><br />
Project activities will be limited to the maximum extent possible in close proximity to seasonally<br /><br />
flooded areas (swamps), rivers and associated vegetation; advice will be sought from a local ecologist<br /><br />
where necessary.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures to keep impacts within acceptable limits include the following:<br /><br />
• Keep earth movements to the minimum required near riverine vegetation areas<br /><br />
• Avoid excavating material (borrow pits) or landfills near watercourses or inundated areas, and<br /><br />
especially through riverine forest areas<br /><br />
• Where a river is not to be crossed a minimum of 50 m buffer zone from the riverine area will be<br /><br />
respected (100 m in case of the Rokel River), wherever feasible<br /><br />
• Where disturbance is necessary, clear only the minimum to facilitate safe access and work<br /><br />
• Ensure workforce is aware of environmental and/or community sensitivities<br /><br />
• It is recommended that the haul road is diverted if an area with higher trees density is found.<br /><br />
Rivers and seasonally flooded areas will preferentially be crossed through locations where<br /><br />
vegetation coverage is less dense and/or valuable<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• Clearly define and mark the construction locations before activities begin and avoid<br /><br />
construction outside the defined area<br /><br />
• Control vehicle movements and plan to minimise journeys<br /><br />
• Plan subsequent restoration requirements. Make photographic records of areas to be disturbed<br /><br />
before development, to assist in after-use site restoration, as applicable<br /><br />
• Practice progressive site clean-up through the life of the project<br /><br />
The risk of contamination of permanent and temporary surface water bodies will be minimised by the<br /><br />
adoption of appropriate operating procedures as follows:<br /><br />
• Potentially contaminating liquids, such as fuel, oil and chemicals, will be stored and handled<br /><br />
according to manufacturers’ recommendations/MSDS, good industry practice and HSE plan<br /><br />
stipulations (this also applies to subcontractors delivering supplies)<br /><br />
• Such liquids will be stored away from seasonally flooded areas and rivers<br /><br />
• Spill response equipment and procedures will be in place in all areas where the potential for<br /><br />
spills exists<br /><br />
• Settlement pits excavated for the treatment of liquid waste will not be located near permanent<br /><br />
or temporary surface water bodies and the pits will be appropriately lined; and<br /><br />
• To preserve surface water bodies from accidental spills or leakages, no temporary camps will<br /><br />
be located within a preferential radius of 500m of the nearest river / water body; ground<br /><br />
conditions to determine distance.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Work in Proximity to Communities<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Introduction<br /><br />
The most important mitigation for potential negative impacts to the local community is to ensure that<br /><br />
people are aware of the start of the activities and ensure their protection. This will be achieved in<br /><br />
consultation with local authorities in all affected communities before construction starts.<br /><br />
Appropriate authorities will be consulted with regard to access creation, temporary camp locations,<br /><br />
and advice for dealing with any particular sensitivities including the existing infrastructure (community<br /><br />
water wells, schools and roads), agricultural and grazing areas and society bush.<br /><br />
With the construction of the haul road there will be an increase in vehicle traffic in the area that will<br /><br />
lead to potential increases in vehicle-related incidents or accidents. The health and safety of the local<br /><br />
population is a primary concern throughout the project.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures designed to minimise the risks include the following:<br /><br />
• The adoption of driving regulations to be adhered to by all personnel including subcontractors<br /><br />
• Strict enforcement of speed limits<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 291<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• Careful planning of all journeys, particularly in areas where members of the public may be<br /><br />
encountered<br /><br />
• No night driving except in an emergency or with specific management measures<br /><br />
• Implement a journey management system<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9.6.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Noise emissions<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Impacts on local air quality (noise) resulting from the use of heavy machinery and equipment and<br /><br />
transport activities can be minimised by carefully planning vehicle movement and using machinery<br /><br />
that has been certified and appropriately maintained.<br /><br />
Recommendations for minimising noise include the following:<br /><br />
• Carefully plan mobilisation of personnel and equipment to limit transport to essential travel;<br /><br />
• Noise-efficient vehicles and equipment will be used and serviced regularly (in accordance with<br /><br />
the manufacturers’ recommendations) to ensure efficient operation and minimal emissions;<br /><br />
• Keep operations as distant from populated areas as possible and limit operations during<br /><br />
morning and evening times to avoid causing nuisance. Restrict the number of engines working<br /><br />
at night;<br /><br />
• In general, plan the project so that equipment and vehicle use are minimised (e.g. in terms of<br /><br />
staff movements and the delivery of supplies);<br /><br />
• Switch off generators and engines whenever equipment or vehicles are not in use; and<br /><br />
• Avoid running engines at excessive speed.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9.6.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Air Quality (Air Emissions)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Local reductions in air quality will result from a number of factors, including the use of diesel powered<br /><br />
equipment, dust generation during civil works and potential vapour emissions during fuel transfer or<br /><br />
maintenance activities or from hazardous material handling and storage.<br /><br />
Air quality may be reduced by waste incineration. In order to minimise the impact on air quality from<br /><br />
waste incineration, these activity will be reduced when conditions are such that impacts could be<br /><br />
exacerbated (e.g., during calm and high pressures situations that might help accumulate air pollutants<br /><br />
at one area). In addition, the general aim will be to minimise the quantity of waste to be incinerated.<br /><br />
General procedures for minimising impact to air quality from vehicle emissions will be in place for the<br /><br />
duration of the programme, including the following:<br /><br />
• Consider fuel efficiency when selecting equipment and vehicles;<br /><br />
• Many of the items listed in the noise section above.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

9.6.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dust & Particles Generation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dust generation (from heavy vehicle use, line clearance, earth movement, etc), may also contribute to<br /><br />
a degradation of local air quality. Dust and particulate emissions will be mitigated by observing the<br /><br />
following dust suppression measures, as appropriate:<br /><br />
• Use of water trucks for regular watering of unsealed roads<br /><br />
• Operator awareness training on the causes of dust and how it can be minimised (in particular to<br /><br />
unpaved surfaces and stockpiles)<br /><br />
• Use of surface binding/sealing agents on high-traffic surfaces<br /><br />
• Minimise traffic on unsealed roads<br /><br />
• Strictly enforce speed limits when driving on unpaved roads<br /><br />
• Limit civil works involving earth movements during periods of high winds<br /><br />
• Cover truck loads of earth or excavated materials<br /><br />
• Minimise dust generating activities when conditions could exacerbate the impacts (e.g., during<br /><br />
high winds)<br /><br />
• Avoid off-track driving<br /><br />
• Minimise vehicle use<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9.7<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Work near Society Bush, Thick Forests & Protected Areas<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Society bush areas are important both for local communities, due to the use of these areas, and for<br /><br />
conservation purposes, since these areas host important flora and fauna.<br /><br />
The importance of vegetation in the area will be clearly communicated to all project personnel. Other<br /><br />
remaining thick forest areas are also important in terms of conservational values since they represent<br /><br />
the last remnants of what used to be the main habitat in the project areas. Protected areas,<br /><br />
independent of their state of conservation, are safeguarded by Sierra Leone laws and works will not<br /><br />
be undertaken in these areas unless appropriate permits issued by the Ministry of Lands, Country<br /><br />
Planning and the Environment are in place, as applicable. The general rule is that no Society Bushes<br /><br />
(or large trees in any areas) are to be disturbed except in exceptional circumstances.<br /><br />
A local ecologist and a local community representative will view the proposed haul road locations<br /><br />
where a Society Bush / thick forest is located or flora of particular interest has been observed.<br /><br />
General recommendations for vegetation clearance include:<br /><br />
• Avoid clearance through thick forests<br /><br />
• If clearance is required, consult with AML to ensure appropriate permits have been obtained in<br /><br />
advance<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
• Consult with communities and AML community liaison to identify “no-go” areas (e.g. Society<br /><br />
Bush)<br /><br />
• Do not cut trees for firewood<br /><br />
• Cut large trees with chainsaw rather than bulldozing, to avoid unnecessary soil disturbance<br /><br />
Fires will be strictly prohibited outside temporary camp sites, and fires within the camps will be<br /><br />
appropriately controlled. Local wood will not preferentially be used as fuel for temporary camp<br /><br />
activities.<br /><br />
Recommendations to prevent deterioration of habitats may be provided by a local ecologist / zoologist<br /><br />
(or an ecology survey team) and will be followed.<br /><br />
Furthermore, the following measures will be considered:<br /><br />
• Inform personnel that hunting during their time in the area will be prohibited.<br /><br />
• Raise and maintain personnel awareness of the importance of not damaging plants and<br /><br />
animals. For example, most of the monkeys that could be encountered are likely to face<br /><br />
conservation threats.<br /><br />
• Control personnel movements. Restrict personnel from the most sensitive areas.<br /><br />
• Create and implement a site restoration plan to mitigate impacts on Society Bushes or any<br /><br />
other forest areas with significant tree growth to the greatest extent possible.<br /><br />
• Access roads locations will be selected in a way that minimises effects on sensitive fauna.<br /><br />
Block access routes that could lead poachers to areas where endangered species might roam.<br /><br />
The risk of injury to fauna from vehicle movements will be minimised by the adoption of safe speed<br /><br />
limits and a ban on night driving, except in emergency situations.<br /><br />
Neither temporary camps nor waste disposal areas will be established near society bush / thick<br /><br />
forests / protected areas (100 metres buffer zone). Mature trees stands will be avoided as far as<br /><br />
possible, except if the main trees in the stands are palm trees.<br /><br />
Noise, air pollutant emissions and dust generation may also impact forested areas.<br /><br />
Impacts on local fauna likely to inhabit Society Bush areas and other forested strips resulting from<br /><br />
noise generation produced through the use of heavy machinery and equipment and transport<br /><br />
activities can be minimised by carefully planning vehicle movement and using machinery that has<br /><br />
been certified by international standards and appropriately maintained.<br /><br />
Dust generation (from heavy vehicle use, line clearance, earth movement, etc), may also contribute to<br /><br />
a degradation of the floral community. To avoid impact on flora from dust and particulate emissions<br /><br />
the dust suppression measures previously presented will be applied.<br /><br />

9.8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Waste management<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The development of construction and mine workers camps will generate significant quantities of<br /><br />
typical household solid waste, at varying times throughout the project. It is recommended that an<br /><br />
approach to dealing with waste is developed prior to the construction of the camps and that the<br /><br />
following high level principles are adopted:<br /><br />
• Where possible waste will be managed in accordance with the waste hierarchy;<br /><br />
• Potential disposal sites will be identified at the outset and an assessment made of the most<br /><br />
appropriate treatment / disposal method, based on the availability and of fit for purpose<br /><br />
disposal sites;<br /><br />
• Waste will be separated at source, the extent of which to be determined by the availability of<br /><br />
local recycling markets and final disposal options;<br /><br />
• Local community will be engaged to develop a mechanism for recycling materials back into the<br /><br />
local area;<br /><br />
• Liaise with AML CLO to identify suitable locations for temporary waste facilities and identify<br /><br />
existing waste facilities in project areas that can be used for waste disposal<br /><br />
• Waste storage and collection provision will make consideration for local climate, and in<br /><br />
particular for pest and odour control;<br /><br />
• Locate waste collection areas at least 1km from populated areas and 500m from agricultural<br /><br />
areas<br /><br />
• Do not discharge any waste into rivers; grey and black waters to be disposed in lined pits sited<br /><br />
close to workers’ camp(s) or otherwise as appropriate so as to avoid contamination<br /><br />
• Do not leave any waste on site: workers must carry bags to collect all wastes for return to camp<br /><br />
waste storage facility<br /><br />
• Consideration will be made for composting of organic fractions;<br /><br />
• It is understood that burning of waste is widespread practice through the region, this will not be<br /><br />
undertaken without due consideration for the appropriate air quality standards;<br /><br />
• The local waste regulatory body will be engaged at the earliest opportunity with respect to any<br /><br />
waste management proposals;<br /><br />
• Ultimately an integrated approach will be adopted with respect to all worker camps waste<br /><br />
management.<br /><br />
• Litter and waste collection systems are to be implemented and litter bins covered at all sites.<br /><br />
Hard waste at site has to be removed to the central camp for sorting and burying/ burning/ reuse as appropriate.<br /><br />
Vegetation clearance will generate almost exclusively organic wastes that will be suitable for self<br /><br />
biodegradation in the surrounding forest.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
• Set down areas for any useful timber will be identified at the outset, including engagement with<br /><br />
the local community as to suitability of location;<br /><br />
• The vegetation may contain elements of valuable hardwood, where possible this will be<br /><br />
separated at source by machine and procedures set in place in order that the local community<br /><br />
can safely recover elements of hardwood;<br /><br />
• Small fractions of vegetation may become contaminated with diesels, hydraulic oils etc. these<br /><br />
will be stockpiled separately and disposed to an appropriately facility to be determined in liaison<br /><br />
with AML;<br /><br />
• Given the volume of organic waste likely to be generated the potential for composting will be<br /><br />
considered and additional proposals may be developed accordingly.<br /><br />

Fuel & Spillages<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9.9<br /><br />
9.9.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Refueling & Maintenance Procedures<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Oil and fuel storage and refuelling activities will be guided by the following principles:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Store all fuels and oils within secondary containment (double skinned tanks, impermeable<br /><br />
bunds, drip trays or plastic sheeting on sand bags)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Provide a sealed surface refuelling (or spill prevention) and machinery maintenance area at<br /><br />
the workers’ camp(s)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Do not carry out refuelling or maintenance works outside designated area<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Carry spill response and clean-up materials to deal with any accidental spills of fuels and<br /><br />
lubricants<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Train designated workers in fuels storage and handling and spill clean up<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Do not store quantities of fuels and oils within 100m of water courses, swamps or drainage<br /><br />
ditches<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It is envisaged that some refuelling and maintenance requirements will generate hazardous wastes<br /><br />
such as hydraulic oils, heavy metals, lubricants etc. These will be identified, removed and kept<br /><br />
separate from other waste materials to avoid further contamination and be disposed of in accordance<br /><br />
with all relevant legislation and best practice guidelines at point of origin or at an alternative suitable<br /><br />
site.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9.9.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Spill response<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Accidental events have the potential to cause major impacts. Mitigation will include the following<br /><br />
guiding principles and are discussed further below:<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
• Prevention: Following standard protocols and procedures adhering to best practice will help<br /><br />
avoid accidental event occurrence. Best practice includes personnel training and setting<br /><br />
adequate health, safety and security measures.<br /><br />
• Quick response: Preparing an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) for implementing<br /><br />
countermeasures against non-routine events.<br /><br />
Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure<br /><br />
Vehicles and equipment shall be serviced regularly in a manner which minimises spills and leaks.<br /><br />
Service areas will be designated and shall be used for vehicle maintenance. Heavy equipment (e.g.,<br /><br />
large trucks) will produce large quantities of waste oils and lubricants that need to be stored in<br /><br />
labelled containers and removed from the site. Use drip pans, or trays, for protection from leaks<br /><br />
during vehicle maintenance. Machinery maintenance and refuelling will only take place at<br /><br />
designated, preferably lined areas; the construction of dykes and berms may be appropriate at the<br /><br />
site in a manner that will contain any fluid spills that might occur during camp operations.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A written procedure for inspecting and testing pollution prevention equipment and systems<br /><br />
will be prepared and maintained at the worker’s camp. The procedures will form part of the<br /><br />
overall spill prevention control and countermeasure plans.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
All tanks to be subject to periodic integrity testing (visual inspection), taking into account tank<br /><br />
design and use.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Spill cleanup and emergency response equipment to be centrally located and staff trained in<br /><br />
its proper use.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Personal protection equipment to be located at all fluid handling points, i.e. in vehicle yard,<br /><br />
generators and workshops<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Relevant emergency response equipment to be located at working points, equipment to<br /><br />
include as a minimum: First aid - including eyewash; Fire extinguishers; Sorbents; and<br /><br />
Personal protection equipment (hardhats, visors, gloves, aprons, face mask)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Contingency and Emergency Response Plan<br /><br />
Contractors shall develop an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) to deal with incidents that occur<br /><br />
during the construction programme.<br /><br />
Facilities and procedures to prevent spills shall be in place during operations, including:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Provide safe oil and chemical packaging and storage;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Provide containment around oil-containing areas and equipment;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Use efficient oil/water separators where necessary; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Operate safe fuel transfer procedures.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Emergency response plans that address spill incidents shall be prepared during the planning phase<br /><br />
for specific locations. Plans shall include the following:<br /><br />
<br /><br />

9.10<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Agricultural areas<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• The details of the haul road construction activities will be discussed with local authorities prior<br /><br />
to construction start and this process in currently ongoing concomitant with the design. The<br /><br />
discussions will include concerns regarding disturbance to agricultural and grazing areas and<br /><br />
activities planned near human settlements.<br /><br />

an area<br /><br />
• Agricultural land is to be avoided to the maximum extent possible; and contractors/AML are<br /><br />
and will continue to document and photographically recorded agricultural activity prior to<br /><br />
commencing work in or near agricultural land<br /><br />
• Agricultural and grazing areas will be avoided unless adequate compensation or alternative<br /><br />
land schemes are agreed; this is an ongoing initiative with the EWCC mechanism.<br /><br />
• Residents will be allowed to recover material and private property prior to commencing works, if<br /><br />
applicable<br /><br />
• Land inventories will be developed and agreed with local authorities. These will include records<br /><br />
of location, land area, crops grown and allocated owner. Photographic records will be<br /><br />
employed.<br /><br />

9.11<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Site Selection for Camps<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Introduction<br /><br />
This section is included here to address the issues associated with establishment of any temporary<br /><br />
camps and facilities required during construction. Currently contractors are accommodated in existing<br /><br />
hotels, such as in Makeni or AML guest houses or at the mine camp, however as staff numbers ramp<br /><br />
up there will be a need to establish camps along the route local to the work site.<br /><br />
Procedure<br /><br />
Site selection for temporary workers’ camps will be guided by the following principles:<br /><br />
• Camps must, as far as possible be located on previously cleared or sparsely vegetated, flat<br /><br />
areas along road alignment<br /><br />
• Agree location of workers’ camps with local chiefs; liaise with AML Community Liaison<br /><br />
Officer(s) (CLO) designated to the area<br /><br />
• Camps must be located at least 500m from villages and well outside active agriculture areas<br /><br />
where feasible<br /><br />
• Camps must be located at least 100m from densely forested areas and 100m from rivers /<br /><br />
swamps<br /><br />
• Personnel movement outside camps will be restricted<br /><br />
• Hunting will be prohibited<br /><br />
• A photographic record of camp(s) area(s) will be made prior to site clearance<br /><br />
Access roads to be opened for accessing temporary working facilities and infrastructure will follow<br /><br />
these principles:<br /><br />
• Use existing roads as access roads wherever possible taking into account health and safety of<br /><br />
other (community) users<br /><br />
• Align new access roads, to the maximum extent possible, along the haul road alignment to<br /><br />
avoid excessive vegetation clearance<br /><br />
• Access roads must avoid forest and riverine vegetation wherever possible<br /><br />
• Minimise width of access roads and give attention to potential wash-out and offsite pollution<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9.11.1 Transport Activities / Equipment Use<br /><br />
Transport activities will be regulated by the following principles:<br /><br />
<br /><br />

• Avoid night time driving wherever possible or implement measures to reduce accidents, such<br /><br />
as flagmen and signage<br /><br />
• Enforce speed limits (30km/h maximum near villages); lower through villages<br /><br />
• Track and road crossings:<br /><br />
- Ensure advance liaison via CLO; activities must not start without prior notification of proposed<br /><br />
works to local communities<br /><br />
- Ensure safety of road users via use of flagmen and signage<br /><br />
Furthermore, to avoid nuisances to local communities and impacts to fauna and flora, the following<br /><br />
will be adhered to:<br /><br />
• Always cover trucks carrying material likely to generate dust or otherwise ensure dust is not an<br /><br />
issue<br /><br />
• Turn engines off when machinery is not in use / stationary<br /><br />
• Limit illumination sources and generator use at night<br /><br />
Carrying out construction operations during the night is potentially dangerous and will only be<br /><br />
undertaken if the contractor considers the activity absolutely necessary due to time constraints (i.e., to<br /><br />
avoid the start of the wet season), and under the following conditions:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Where a prior investigation of the area to be surveyed has been carried out during the<br /><br />
daytime so that tracks and GPS co-ordinates are known to the crew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Where drivers have received night driving training<br /><br />

9.11.2 Camp Site Decommissioning<br /><br />
Once construction is completed, temporary facilities will need to be removed. Site restoration / site<br /><br />
rehabilitation will be undertaken following best-practice and ensuring local authorities are informed of<br /><br />
the process; some facilities may be left for future community use and this will be determined at a later<br /><br />
date.<br /><br />
In order to complete effective restoration measures, the following principles will be followed:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Remove all waste from site and dispose of in an appropriate facility<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Grade all areas to original topography as far as possible<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Infill all borrow pits and landfills with natural material and cover the abandoned site with<br /><br />
topsoil to allow vegetation re-growth<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Compare final state of camp area after decommissioning with pre-clearance photographic<br /><br />
record<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Determine need for further restoration based on “before and after” comparison<br /><br />
<br /><br />

10<br /><br />
STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT PROCESS & RESETTLEMENT<br /><br />
PLANNING<br /><br />
10.1 Stakeholder Engagement<br /><br />
10.1.1 Background<br /><br />
A program of consultation should be established to allow for stakeholder engagement that will inform<br /><br />
regional authorities and local communities in the run-up to implementation and beyond. This process<br /><br />
has already been initiated. This section provides an outline of the activities intended to deliver a<br /><br />
participatory approach to dealing with social aspects of the Phase 1 component of the Tonkolili Iron<br /><br />
Ore Project.<br /><br />
As the Phase 1 Development program is primarily along a linear corridor, this consultation package is<br /><br />
designed primarily to address issues relating to replacement of agricultural land and compensation for<br /><br />
agricultural crops. Impacts on structures and houses have been minimized during the design but<br /><br />
some instances of relocation have been identified.<br /><br />
The modalities of relocating these structures away from the alignment are embedded into the<br /><br />
consultation process as described below.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
10.1.2 Affected Chiefdoms<br /><br />
The following chiefdoms will play host to sections of the Phase 1 program:<br /><br />
1. Tonkolili District<br /><br />
a. Kalansongoia<br /><br />
b. Kafe Simiria<br /><br />
2. Bombali District<br /><br />
a. Safroko Limba<br /><br />
b. Makari Gbanti<br /><br />
3. Port Loko District<br /><br />
a. Buya Romende<br /><br />
b. Maforki<br /><br />
c.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Lokomasama<br /><br />
<br /><br />

10.1.3 Early Works Chiefdom Committee<br /><br />
Preparation meetings were held with the paramount chief of each of the listed chiefdoms. The need<br /><br />
for a chiefdom level committee was discussed with local authorities (district council chairmen) and a<br /><br />
draft of the Early Works Chiefdom Committee (EWCC) terms of reference (see Section 11.3.2 below)<br /><br />
and preliminary participation lists prepared.<br /><br />
EWCC Structure<br /><br />
Membership<br /><br />
The EWCC will be tasked with high level discussions on relocation, identifying alternative agricultural<br /><br />
land and compensation deliverables. In order to achieve this, the committees include the following<br /><br />
key players:<br /><br />
1. Paramount Chief<br /><br />
2. Relevant Section Chiefs<br /><br />
3. District or government heads of department ensuring that all departments responsible for all<br /><br />
valuations are represented.<br /><br />
4. Political leaders (MP’s and Councillors)<br /><br />
5. AML<br /><br />
6. NGO’s, women’s and youth groups<br /><br />
This was subject to deliberations within the introductory EWCC meetings held in March 2010.<br /><br />
Minutes of EWCC meetings held to date are included in Appendix 19.<br /><br />
Scheduling<br /><br />
The EWCC will sit once a month in accordance with the schedule agreed at the EWCC introductory<br /><br />
session. It is envisaged that Community Sensitisation Meetings will be held under the guidance of<br /><br />
each Section Chief in the period between EWCC meetings.<br /><br />
Additional meetings will be held at any level if the need arises.<br /><br />
EWCC Operating Philosophy<br /><br />
The EWCC will achieve progress through the consensus of it’s members.<br /><br />
EWCC Terms of Reference<br /><br />
The EWCC will act as the primary executive body in all matters relating to social issues facing the<br /><br />
early works program. It will be constituted in such a manner as to be regarded as the primary<br /><br />
representative voice of those affected by the early works program and recognised by AML as such.<br /><br />
Under the overall authority of the Paramount Chief, its reporting officer, the EWCC has the following<br /><br />
functions:<br /><br />
<br /><br />

• To act as the primary channel of communication between the various interest<br /><br />

will serve to facilitate communication between AML and the affected population;<br /><br />
• To serve as the court of first appeal to solve any problems that may arise relating to the early<br /><br />

appropriate grievance procedures;<br /><br />

to be the role played by AML. It will:<br /><br />
• Ensure maximum participation of the affected people in the planning of their own relocation<br /><br />
circumstances;<br /><br />
• Accept financial responsibility for payment of compensation and other designated relocation<br /><br />
related costs;<br /><br />
• Pay the affected farmers compensation to the amounts agreed or establish mechanisms that<br /><br />
allow for replacement of assets when it is preferable to do so;<br /><br />
• With the EWCC, ensure monitoring and evaluation of the affected households and the<br /><br />
undertaking of appropriate remedial action to deal with grievances and to ensure that income<br /><br />
restoration is satisfactorily implemented and food security achieved.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
10.1.4 Community Sensitisation Meetings<br /><br />
The purpose of these meetings is to provide closer links to the directly affected communities to<br /><br />
ensure their participation in the decisions that will affect their future. It will also allow for more efficient<br /><br />
planning for surveys and relocation and establish a forum in which compensation for personal and<br /><br />
community assets such as society bush can be discussed.<br /><br />
These meetings will be coordinated through the EWCC and attendance will be limited to selected<br /><br />
GoSL departments, the relevant section chief, AML, NGOs that may operate in the area, the village<br /><br />
chief and open attendance for village residents.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
10.1.5 Grievance Mechanism<br /><br />
A grievance mechanism will be discussed with the EWCC which will define the protocol for receiving<br /><br />
and responding to questions and concerns raised by the villagers.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

10.1.6 Resource Requirements<br /><br />
This section describes the resources that will be provided to undertake stakeholder engagement for<br /><br />
the Phase 1 program.<br /><br />
1. Staff – On top of existing community relations staff at the mine site and Pepel, AML has<br /><br />
employed sixteen community liaison staff (Community Liaison Officers or CLOs). Training of<br /><br />
these CLOs has been undertaken by senior AML staff and WorleyParsons. A Social<br /><br />
Coordinator has been assigned by AML with the task of coordinating consultation over all<br /><br />
areas.<br /><br />
2. Resettlement Specialist – AML have engaged the services of a suitably experienced<br /><br />
resettlement/social specialist to lead the social team through the three phases of the Tonkolili<br /><br />
Project.<br /><br />
3. Field Staff Equipment – Each field team should have a GPS and a camera to record location<br /><br />
and condition of land and structures. It would be advisable for the construction contractors to<br /><br />
be equipped with cameras to record their progress as well.<br /><br />
It is recognized that to achieve efficiencies in mitigating social impacts resulting from the<br /><br />
implementation of the Phase 1 Program, AML will also provide:<br /><br />
• Offices or contact points/persons in all Phase 1 project areas to ease communication. These<br /><br />
should be open to all stakeholders.<br /><br />
• Agricultural extension services – Loss of agricultural land is possibly the most severe impact on<br /><br />
affected persons as their livelihoods revolve around farming. Although alternative land is<br /><br />
defined as a mitigation measure, access may be reduced for them and others in surrounding<br /><br />
communities. Because of this it may become necessary to provide the services of an<br /><br />
agricultural extension worker to train them on improved agricultural techniques designed to<br /><br />
increase yields and ensure food security.<br /><br />
• Community Safety Plan – As community safety has been highlighted as a concern by various<br /><br />
stakeholders a formal Community Safety Plan should be developed.<br /><br />

10.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Resettlement Policy Framework<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Resettlement Policy Framework (RPF) outlined in this report provides guidelines for the<br /><br />
compensation of those who will be affected by physical and/or economic displacement. In line with<br /><br />
IFC Performance Standard 5, it aims to:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Clarify the legal requirements and principles for compensation for loss of property, livelihood<br /><br />
and relocation or resettlement (of directly affected people) in order to ensure that project<br /><br />
affected people (PAP) will not be negatively affected by resettlement or economic<br /><br />
displacement.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Describe the social context in which the resettlement will take place.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identify affected parties.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Define the actions and tasks that need to be undertaken to plan the resettlement programme.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Define the roles and responsibilities necessary to develop a full RAP.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Describe the arrangements for funding resettlement and compensation as well as a timeline<br /><br />
for activities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
These objectives are addressed in the RPF document (Appendix 20). Key action items arising from<br /><br />
this are summarised below.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
10.2.1 Resettlement Planning Actions<br /><br />
This section of the RPF sets out the main tasks and procedures required to develop a RAP for the<br /><br />
Project. It outlines the procedures for identification of affected people, assessment of eligibility for<br /><br />
compensation, identification of host areas for resettlement, procedures for resettling and<br /><br />
compensation, budget categories, procedures for monitoring and evaluating the resettlement process<br /><br />
and the necessary institutional arrangements for execution of the resettlement and compensation<br /><br />
process.<br /><br />
It is important to note that this conceptual document differs from a RAP, which sets out in detail the<br /><br />
strategies for resettling people affected by land acquisition. In order to develop a full scale RAP there<br /><br />
are several additional requirements:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Detailed final information about the mining process and the location of the different project<br /><br />
components.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A detailed social baseline.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The RPF needs to be debated and approved by the various stakeholders.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
10.2.2 Minimising Resettlement<br /><br />
The IFC standards require that resettlement be minimised as far as possible. The primary reason for<br /><br />
resettlement in the mine area is the location of the mineral resource and technologies for its<br /><br />
exploitation, in this case open pit mining. The location of the pits is fixed by the location of the mineral<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 308<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
resource; and will invoke involuntary resettlement. As such, resettlement cannot be minimised in this<br /><br />
area.<br /><br />
More broadly resettlement will be influenced by the development and location of project infrastructure<br /><br />
in the mine area, the transport corridor and at the port facility. Such infrastructure includes rock<br /><br />
dumps, processing plant, tailings storage facility, stockpiles, offices, workshops, stores, power<br /><br />
generation, housing, the railway line and port facilities. Resettlement is also influenced by health and<br /><br />
safety considerations (e.g. human settlements should be an appropriate distance from hazards).<br /><br />
AML’s engineering and environmental and social consultants should be working in tandem to ensure<br /><br />
that infrastructure across the Project area is developed and located in a way that minimises<br /><br />
resettlement.<br /><br />
The following has been done in this respect:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The rail loop, which requires a large area, has been positioned at the mine site where<br /><br />
population density is lower than at Tagrin, the other option;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The rail and haul road alignment has been designed to avoid villages using Quantum<br /><br />
optimisation software;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction and operations camps are planned in areas with low population densities;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Waste rock dumps have been optimised to minimise additional area required beyond the fly<br /><br />
rock zone;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Refurbishment of the Pepel rail and port is to be undertaken on the existing footprint to<br /><br />
minimise the need to acquire more land for project operations;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
At this stage, nonetheless, it is certain that there will be a requirement to relocate villages<br /><br />
either partially or entirely.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
10.2.3 Identifying Eligibility for Compensation<br /><br />
The definition of eligibility requires an assessment of the type and number of people residing or using<br /><br />
the affected area and the types of loss they incur. This is outlined below.<br /><br />
Project Affected People<br /><br />
Project affected people (PAP) can be divided into two categories:<br /><br />
1. Affected household: households10 are affected if one or more of its members suffer loss of<br /><br />
assets, land and property, and/or access to natural and/or economic resources as a result of<br /><br />
the project activities;<br /><br />
2. Host area households: households in any of the host resettlement sites (sites where people<br /><br />
may be resettled), whose infrastructures and/or resources will be impacted.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
10<br /><br />
<br /><br />
For the purposes of this RPF a household consists of people who are economically dependent on<br /><br />
each other and who typically live in the same compound and eat from the same pot.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
