STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Types of Loss<br /><br />
PAP may incur a loss or disruption of access to the following assets and resources:<br /><br />
1. Buildings, homesteads and related structures (such as storage facilities, graves);<br /><br />
2. Land;<br /><br />
3. Permanent or temporary use of agricultural land;<br /><br />
4. Sacred sites;<br /><br />
5. Mining deposits (artisanal mining);<br /><br />
6. Natural plant and animal (including fish) resources;<br /><br />
7. Small enterprises;<br /><br />
8. Communal infrastructure (wells, boreholes, irrigation works, schools, clinics);<br /><br />
9. Access routes (between villages, to towns and other resources i.e. fishing beaches).<br /><br />
A detailed description of the number and type of beneficiaries in terms of the various eligibility criteria<br /><br />
will need to be provided once the exact location of the Project infrastructure is known and a census<br /><br />
has been conducted. At this stage, however, the following information is available:<br /><br />
Homesteads<br /><br />
It is envisaged that 47 villages will have to be partially or entirely resettled. It is estimated that 2,441<br /><br />
houses and related structures will be affected.<br /><br />
Land<br /><br />
It is envisaged that 12 674 ha will be affected by the Project; 11,507 ha at the mine site, 288 ha along<br /><br />
the rail corridor and 880 ha at the Port. These belong to various villages/towns. A land survey will<br /><br />
need to be conducted to assess which land belongs to which villages and to which landowning<br /><br />
families.<br /><br />
Agricultural Crops<br /><br />
Approximately 215.30 ha of currently cultivated land will be affected by the Project; 95 ha at the mine<br /><br />
site, 56 ha along the rail corridor and 64 ha at the Port. A survey will have to be conducted to assess<br /><br />
the number and size of fields of affected households, as well as the crops cultivated.<br /><br />
Tree Plantations<br /><br />
Approximately 21 ha of current plantation will be affected by the Project; 8 ha along the rail corridor<br /><br />
and 12 ha at the Port. A survey will have to be conducted to assess the number and size of<br /><br />
plantations of affected households, as well as the trees/plants cultivated. The main plantations are<br /><br />
palm, mango, banana and pineapple.<br /><br />
Forests<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-610\tonkolili phase 1 eshia report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020 Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
Page 310<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Some forested areas may be affected. These serve several needs. For instance sacred bushes are<br /><br />
an important cultural heritage of the local people in the Project area and significant for their spiritual<br /><br />
well being. It is likely that several sacred bushes will be affected. Sacred bushes will need to be<br /><br />
identified along with other potential uses of the forest.<br /><br />
Sacred Sites<br /><br />
Sacred sites include such sites or places/features that are important for customary practices, tradition<br /><br />
and culture, and thus considered sacred. Sacred sites include tombs, graves and cemeteries and<br /><br />
ritual sites.<br /><br />
In general people bury their deceased in tombs near their homestead. Resettlement of villages may<br /><br />
involve the relocation of graves.<br /><br />
Artisanal Mining<br /><br />
The social description of the affected villages in the mine lease area shows that households maintain<br /><br />
a mixed livelihood consisting of mining as well as farming.<br /><br />
There are a significant number of artisanal miners (exact figures be established during RAP<br /><br />
preparation) working in and around the concession area, including in the areas which will be required<br /><br />
for the mining infrastructure. Consequently these miners may lose their livelihoods.<br /><br />
Natural Plant and Animal Life<br /><br />
Some areas used by local residents for collection of natural resources (fire wood, wild foods, timber,<br /><br />
medicinal plants, game) may be affected by the mining and transport infrastructure. Generally,<br /><br />
however, natural resources used by the local population are plentiful in the larger area and the loss of<br /><br />
the area needed for the project may not require compensation. This will however need to be verified<br /><br />
by the census conducted as part of the RAP.<br /><br />
The port lease area may impact on the access of fishermen to the beach (i.e. homesteads of<br /><br />
fishermen may need to be moved or access to the landing and fishing beach may be constrained or<br /><br />
removed).<br /><br />
Small Enterprises<br /><br />
The villages and towns affected by resettlement are host to several small businesses. These<br /><br />
businesses are generally run from small structures near the homestead or from the homestead itself.<br /><br />
The exact number of small businesses affected will need to be identified.<br /><br />
Social Infrastructure<br /><br />
The villages affected by physical resettlement are host to schools, clinics, community halls, drying<br /><br />
areas and potentially other communal infrastructure. The RAP census will need to identify all<br /><br />
communal infrastructure which may be affected.<br /><br />
Access Routes<br /><br />
The mining and transport infrastructure may have impact on communications between villages and<br /><br />
towns and villages and agricultural fields, cutting some residents off from their resources. Loss of<br /><br />

AUDITING, MONITORING & CONTINUAL PERFORMANCE<br /><br />
IMPROVEMENT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
11.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Introduction<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This section gives details of the monitoring and reporting elements of the environmental and social<br /><br />
management process, which forms part of the overall management system that is under development<br /><br />
by AML, in conjunction with design of the project as a whole.<br /><br />
To date the ESHIA has focussed on providing the ‘assessment’ stage and setting out the scope of<br /><br />
potential impacts with plans or commitments setting out how to manage and mitigate the impacts<br /><br />
associated with the project.<br /><br />
According to best practice principles (Equator Principles and IFC Performance Standards) the<br /><br />
assessment and management plans should be incorporated through a Social and Environmental<br /><br />
Management System (SEMS). Such a system is required to make sure that environmental and<br /><br />
social activities are coordinated, resourced and focused and audited. This has been initiated through<br /><br />
the EMP (section 9), which provides a framework for environmental management and delivery of<br /><br />
mitigation and will be continually developed and expanded as detailed designs and assessments<br /><br />
progress.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
11.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Monitoring<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Monitoring is an essential element in evaluating performance to agreed targets and objectives, as it<br /><br />
provides information on the observed effects (positive and negative), allowing feedback to those<br /><br />
responsible for carrying out the task monitored.<br /><br />
For the Phase 1 project it is envisaged that the monitoring will involve:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ongoing site-based inspections by AML Environment and social staff, who will be auditing<br /><br />
performance and compliance to contract document scopes of work and preparing advice /<br /><br />
instructions to guide the Phase 1 works;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Inspection visits and audits by Environmental regulators such as SLEPA and/or their<br /><br />
nominated monitoring agents (also see Appendix 1, project monitoring and audit<br /><br />
arrangements);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Inspection visits and audits by independent consultants, appointed by AML, who will produce<br /><br />
monitoring reports that SLEPA can access and comment on. Currently this is being managed<br /><br />
under the ESHIA process with in-country consultants (CEMMATS) responsible for developing<br /><br />
the monitoring data.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
An Environmental Information System (EIS) will be established to record the results of monitoring and<br /><br />
evaluation of compliance to EMPs and project standards. This EIS will be managed by AML<br /><br />
Environmental staff, in conjunction with effective liaison with the road contractors, who are also<br /><br />
charged with an element of self-monitoring.<br /><br />

Inspections and surveillance of work activities and sub-contractors will be undertaken on a day-to-day<br /><br />

•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Compliance with contractual requirements<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Effectiveness of environmental protection measures<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Maintenance of environmental protection measures<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The monitoring strategy proposed for the project can be termed "Adaptive Environmental Monitoring".<br /><br />
It is adaptive in the sense that the responsible party must adapt its methods and activities to the<br /><br />

11.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Incident Investigation and Reporting<br /><br />
<br /><br />
All incidents will be documented, investigated and action plans established in order to prevent<br /><br />
reoccurrence if possible. Where lessons are learnt and/or current procedures are identified as being<br /><br />
ineffective, the EMP will be revised accordingly.<br /><br />
An environmental or social investigation includes the following basic elements:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identifying the cause, extent and responsibility of the incident<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identifying and implementing the necessary corrective action<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identifying the personnel responsible for carrying out the corrective action<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implementing or modifying the controls necessary to avoid a repeat occurrence of the incident<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Recording any changes in written procedures required<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Advising the environmental authorities if any substantial pollution has occurred.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
All personnel are required to report all incidents as it is regarded as a valuable method of addressing<br /><br />
shortcomings in procedures, training and equipment, and is an opportunity for improvement.<br /><br />
All Incident Investigation Reports and associated documentation will be distributed to the Environment<br /><br />
Manager, the Construction Manager and Project Manager. All incident reports and documentation will<br /><br />
be stored in the EIS.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
11.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Non-compliance: Corrective and Preventive Actions<br /><br />
<br /><br />
An environmental non-compliance will be detected through processes such as monitoring,<br /><br />
inspections, audits and receipt of complaints. Non-compliance covers incidents which do not conform<br /><br />
to the EMP and procedures as well as incidents which violate statutory obligations.<br /><br />
The process for managing environmental non-compliance will be as follows:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
When an environmental non-compliance is detected the nature of the event will be evaluated<br /><br />
by the environmental staff as specified in the relevant procedure, the effectiveness or need<br /><br />
for new/additional controls will be reviewed and strategies identified to prevent recurrence.<br /><br />
Corrective actions will subsequently be identified and logged. Details of the non-compliance,<br /><br />
the corrective actions proposed and the responsibilities and timing for completion of the<br /><br />
actions will be entered.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Once an action is completed, the form will be updated to close the action including input of<br /><br />
comments and completion date.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Environmental Compliance Tracking and Corrective Action forms will be reviewed weekly<br /><br />
by the appropriate member of the construction/environmental team to ensure actions are<br /><br />
completed in time.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In addition to the above, where an incident is of a more serious nature, has been identified repeatedly<br /><br />
or constitutes a violation of statutory regulations, the following will apply:<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
When required, the work on the identified operation or site will be stopped until remedial<br /><br />
action is taken to eliminate the issue.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
An incident report will be completed and logged in the EIS.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The incident report will be forwarded to the Environment Manager, and if deemed noncompliant with statutory regulations, to the environmental authorities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
11.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AML are building up a functioning environmental and social management capability with sufficient<br /><br />
resources to oversee the project’s construction and operations and ensure that contractor’s<br /><br />
performance is also of a high standard.<br /><br />
At the same time, the monitoring and reporting systems are still under development while AML<br /><br />
continues to recruit staff to cover environmental and social management in the field, incorporate<br /><br />
baseline information from the ESHIA and eventually develop a project information system.<br /><br />
SEMS will provide a structured, effective means to manage environmental, social and economic<br /><br />
commitments throughout the life of the project. The SEMS provides a consistent framework for social<br /><br />
and environmental management through the project life-cycle: construction, operation to<br /><br />
decommissioning. SEMS enables an operator to develop operating standards and continual<br /><br />
improvement targets that help define and maintain performance standards.<br /><br />
The development of a SEMS by AML is a comprehensive undertaking that will take several years to<br /><br />
fully implement. It is recommended that AML aim to attain compliance requirements with a<br /><br />
recognised standard such as ISO 14001 before Phase 3 operations commence so that the<br /><br />
appropriate control and audit systems are in place to regulate environmental issues and maximise<br /><br />
efficiency in energy, water and material management.<br /><br />
SEMS need to function within the standard management system structure so as to integrate<br /><br />
environmental, social and economic considerations into business and project operations. Continual<br /><br />
improvement in overall environmental performance is a fundamental principle in SEMS and is<br /><br />
accordingly defined within respective standards, such as ISO14001. The principle is one that allows<br /><br />
for phased improvement (achievable over a period). It also helps to ‘build in' and sustain achieved<br /><br />
improvements. An effective SEMS will enable organisations to target, achieve and demonstrate<br /><br />
continuous improvement in environmental performance as one integrated management process.<br /><br />
SEMS will require development of policies and goals which are currently missing other than<br /><br />
achievement of compliance and general principles associated with good corporate citizenry. Possible<br /><br />
generic environmental objectives that could be applied are:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Comply with legislation and good international industry practice;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Design, construct and operate the facilities in a manner that protects human health and<br /><br />
minimises impacts on the environment;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Encourage and promote waste minimisation, the sustainable use of natural resources,<br /><br />
recycling, energy efficiency, resource conservation and resource recovery;<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Environmental objectives are the responsibility of all staff;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Monitor and review procedures regularly and strive for ‘beyond compliance’ performance;<br /><br />
<br /><br />

11.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Auditing<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SEMS audits are typically conducted in accordance with ISO 14001 guidance and procedures, and<br /><br />
oriented toward continuous improvement in managing the environmental impacts of an organisation,<br /><br />
site, process, product, supply chain or input-output balances.<br /><br />
The Sierra Leone 2009 Mining Technical Assistance Project (MTAP) report includes a section on<br /><br />
monitoring requirements including the following statement:<br /><br />
“It is expected that monitoring will be conducted during all phases of each project venture –<br /><br />
preconstruction, start-up, operations, closures and post closure. The program is expected to play a<br /><br />
pivotal role in ensuring that the trends for specific parameters are tracked and it will provide<br /><br />
information on compliance with legislative norms, set guidelines or desirable operational limits; and<br /><br />
form the basis for corrective actions and modification of activities if necessary. GOSL will ensure that<br /><br />
part of the cost is borne by the Mining agencies.”<br /><br />
Therefore, in addition to in-house performance audits as required to maintain accreditation for ISO<br /><br />
14001, there is also a requirement for independent, government-led audit that seeking to evaluate<br /><br />
performance, improvement and achievement of commitments.<br /><br />
An SEMS needs to take into account and provide access for 3rd party auditing and evaluation. It is<br /><br />
recommended that Audit takes place depending on project phase to provide an opportunity for<br /><br />
continual improvement using a lessons learnt approach. Therefore it would be reasonable to expect<br /><br />
at least an annual audit during the construction phases of the project, with frequency to be modified<br /><br />
depending on the timing and location of the subsequent development activities and the results<br /><br />
derived from the monitoring data.<br /><br />
In summary therefore, continuous evaluation and auditing (both internal and independent) is requred<br /><br />
in order to ensure continuous improvement in all aspects of the project and minimise environmental<br /><br />
impacts.<br /><br />
Environmental auditing is used to certify whether practice is in accordance with standard procedures<br /><br />
and to determine how processes or systems under review can be improved. The main environmental<br /><br />
auditing techniques are:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
examination of records and documentation relating to impacts, actions taken to manage them<br /><br />
and aspects of performance;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
interviews with management and line staff to corroborate factual information and probe areas<br /><br />
of concern; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
site inspection to check that environmental measures and controls are operating as described<br /><br />
and intended.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
13<br /><br />
<br /><br />
CONCLUSION<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The project has been evaluated using a rigorous impact assessment methodology.<br /><br />
This includes a review of the legislation framework associated with environmental, social and health<br /><br />
management and assessment. The ESHIA considers the Phase 1 project, the existing physical<br /><br />
conditions i.e. the environmental and human baseline and the likely impacts that may arise, both<br /><br />
positive and negative. Where there are impacts identified that could cause adverse effects, the ESHIA<br /><br />
considers alternatives, mitigating measures and what the likely remaining or residual impact will be after<br /><br />
such intervention.<br /><br />
The environment and social impact assessment has been applied systematically to the project affected<br /><br />
areas and the following conclusions have been determined:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
13.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mine Area<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Impact Assessment<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Air & Noise<br /><br />
Air quality impacts comprising both dust and exhaust emissions arising from land clearance, mining,<br /><br />
dusting from stock-piles and machinery have been identified as primary emission sources. The<br /><br />
implementation of standard mitigation measures involving covering of loads during haulage, dust<br /><br />
suppression by water spraying, extractive covers at key point sources and machinery selection should<br /><br />
result in no major impacts.<br /><br />
Noise sources will be variable but blasting, crushing, potential transport noise including aircraft are<br /><br />
considered to be the most important sources of impact. Assuming that occupational noise limits are<br /><br />
maintained within facility boundaries (85 dB(A)) then it is predicted that appropriate environmental noise<br /><br />
standards will be met at a distance of 500m from the facilities.<br /><br />
Appropriate choice of location for key noise-emitting site facilities such as workshops is still required<br /><br />
and should adhere to the minimum noise buffer recommendations included in this report. Further<br /><br />
mitigation and management, where considered necessary is predominantly associated with selecting<br /><br />
machinery with noise limiters maintaining equipment to run quietly and ensuring that blast design is<br /><br />
optimised and doesn’t create excessive noise power. There are no major impacts expected after<br /><br />
mitigation although further study work is required to review the effects of an airstrip, should this option<br /><br />
go ahead.<br /><br />
Ecology & Biodiversity<br /><br />
Ecological impacts at the mine have been evaluated and found to be significant primarily due to the<br /><br />
high level of biodiversity and conservation value of plants at the mine-sites and along the Tonkolili River<br /><br />
valley. The Farangbaia Forest Reserve, which is in close proximity to the project is considered to be<br /><br />
currently only of moderate conservation value. This area by virtue of its protected status and location<br /><br />
may be a suitable site for a replanting, off-set and conservation programme.<br /><br />
Principal direct impacts will arise from the clearance of land within the footprint of the open pit and<br /><br />
associated infrastructure and the burial of vegetation in waste dump areas which will essentially be<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-6-10\tonkolili phase 1 eshia<br /><br />
report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
Page 328 : 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
permanent impacts to the current vegetation coverage with little to no recourse for mitigation.<br /><br />
Vegetation that is not cleared or buried may be indirectly impacted by alteration of drainage patterns<br /><br />
and exposure to contaminated surface runoff (contaminants may include petroleum products from<br /><br />
operations and also mobilised trace metals present in the hematite ore deposit). Further impacts may<br /><br />
arise through the spread of invasive species. These may also spread to undisturbed land following<br /><br />
natural colonisation or deliberate introduction in disturbed areas (where such species tend to thrive). An<br /><br />
influx of people to the area will increase the pressure on resources (e.g. clearance of land for<br /><br />
agricultural use, subsistence and commercial logging of timber).<br /><br />
The residual post-mitigation impacts of habitat loss and fragmentation will remain significant to fauna.<br /><br />
Opening access and influx to the area to the extent envisaged could lead to significant further loss of<br /><br />
fauna through habitat destruction and increased hunting. With the exception of burial (which is an<br /><br />
irreversible impact), residual (post-mitigation) impacts on aquatic ecosystems should be minor if<br /><br />
appropriate international best practice preventative and mitigation measures are put in place.<br /><br />
The most significant potential impact for fauna and the aquatic ecosystem is a change in species<br /><br />
diversity and abundance (and potentially a loss of species of conservation concern) through habitat loss<br /><br />
and fragmentation directly associated with the mining activities. Indirectly this may also occur through<br /><br />
increased pressure due to population influx.<br /><br />
Avoidance of areas of ecological value is the primary tool that is being used to minimise impacts. As<br /><br />
the impact of land clearance and burial in the primary mining and rock dump areas can not be avoided if<br /><br />
the project is to go ahead because of the immovable location of the ore bodies, nor can it be mitigated<br /><br />
against then the only measure remaining is for the project proponent to undertake a commitment to<br /><br />
attempt seed collection, replanting, habitat renewal and protection at alternative selected conservation<br /><br />
site(s). This offset or equivalence approach will not alter the primary ecological loss and cannot<br /><br />
realistically overcome the direct impact resulting from clearance of forest and vegetation. However, in<br /><br />
combination with avoidance wherever possible in the first place then an off-set conservation programme<br /><br />
could help to lower the overall residual impact to a moderate level.<br /><br />
Further evaluation of habitat areas is required and understanding of ecosystem dynamics and<br /><br />
behaviour is required if ecological management initiatives are going to be effective. As this remains<br /><br />
unknown pending further evaluation, the expert view on residual impact magnitude in association with<br /><br />
fragmentation, loss of species richness and abundance from disturbance has been conservatively set<br /><br />
as remaining as an impact of major significance. It is therefore essential for AML and its contractors to<br /><br />
minimise and avoid areas of ecological importance where possible<br /><br />
Assuming avoidance of sensitive areas is rigorously followed by AML, then in conjunction with a<br /><br />
number of conservation off-set measures, the residual (post-avoidance and post-mitigation) impacts on<br /><br />
ecology and biodiversity should be minor. However, this is reliant on AML also immediately adopting a<br /><br />
conspicuous and pro-active policy to restricting any habitat disturbance within their concession area and<br /><br />
developing programmes that support alternative food supply to local people including animal husbandry<br /><br />
and farming to reduce the reliance on hunting and frontier fuel-wood collection.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hydrology and Hydrogeology<br /><br />
Assessment of surface water and groundwater impacts has identified a range of water resources and<br /><br />
water quality issues that may be expected to arise from the project. This includes an increase in<br /><br />
suspended sediments in rivers, alteration of river channels and changes in catchment behaviour leading<br /><br />
to flooding as well as a variety of contamination issues that could arise from the project. These issues<br /><br />
can be mitigated through a comprehensive environmental management plan. The most significant<br /><br />
issue identified is the increased potable and construction water demand that may lead to overabstraction of surface water from nearby rivers leading to impacts on environmental flows and/or<br /><br />
downstream users.<br /><br />
Residual, post mitigation impacts will include some permanent loss of flow from springs and streams on<br /><br />
Simbili feeding the Tonkolili and Mawuru Rivers and loss of the storage effect of the overburden and<br /><br />
weathered cap rocks of the hematite deposit. Waste rock dumps will develop their own surface and<br /><br />
groundwater systems and dependent on location may supplement baseflow to the rivers. Even with<br /><br />
controls, there may be some acid drainage and other factors contributing to changes in groundwater<br /><br />
and surface water chemistry, especially given the low buffering capacity and high sensitivity of the local<br /><br />
waters. More significant changes in local hydrology and hydrogeology are expected in Phase 3 which<br /><br />
will require a significantly higher water demand.<br /><br />
There will be localized residual but reversible impacts on surface and groundwater resources due to<br /><br />
abstraction for construction and operational demands. This is the only residual water impact that has<br /><br />
been assessed as remaining as major. The rationale behind this is that although water treatment and<br /><br />
re-use will return a component of the water to the catchment. There will inevitably be a net reduction as<br /><br />
water is removed from the catchment and conveyed away in either the form of retained water in<br /><br />
product, alteration in drainage patters and losses due to water use from activities like dust spraying.<br /><br />
Soils & Land Use<br /><br />
Soil impacts will arise during construction and operational phases as a consequence of land clearance<br /><br />
or sterilisation / burial, increased erosion or inundation due to the modification of drainage patterns,<br /><br />
compaction from vibration and loading under temporary stockpiles/structures, contamination<br /><br />
hydrocarbons and other chemicals including diesel and lubricant oils and explosives residues. Some<br /><br />
soil resource can be rehabilitated if progressive mine reclamation is applied, although it is also<br /><br />
recognised that irreversible loss of soil can occur in this tropical setting where there is also high<br /><br />
potential for vegetation loss, erosion and run-off. Invasive species colonising disturbed land and also<br /><br />
propagating to undisturbed land is recognised as a major impact. Residual impact may be only<br /><br />
moderate through appropriate implementation of mitigation measures.<br /><br />
These impacts may constrain or modify existing land-uses in the mine area. The residual (postmitigation) impacts of land clearance and sterilisation / burial on soil resources and land-use are likely<br /><br />
to remain significant and extremely long-term or permanent in the mine area. Other residual impacts<br /><br />
should be minor if appropriate international best practice preventative and mitigation measures are put<br /><br />
in place.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mining will inevitably include loss of the non renewable resource of ore itself and deposition of wastes<br /><br />
can sterilise associated deposits of lower value or undiscovered resources making them effectively<br /><br />
inaccessible beneath waste rock and tailings. There will be major changes to the landscape with the<br /><br />
top of Simbili hill being effectively removed while substantial overburden and rock waste dumps will be<br /><br />
formed nearby leading to visual and landscape changes. None of these impacts have been assessed<br /><br />
as major however and mitigation in the form of appropriate mine planning and dump design should<br /><br />
ensure that only moderate to insignificant impacts remain.<br /><br />
Socio-Economic<br /><br />
Socio-economic effects are strongly dependent on project phase. During construction some villages<br /><br />
may require resettlement. Villages on the periphery of mining area will suffer loss of land resulting in<br /><br />
loss of shelter, loss of access to agricultural land, artisanal mining sites and natural resources leading to<br /><br />
a decrease in economic stability. There are also likely to be graves and sacred sites within the footprint<br /><br />
area that will require relocation. During operations however there is a mix of economic benefit and<br /><br />
social disturbance. Benefits (lasting about 8 years) will mainly be in the form of wages, disbursement<br /><br />
for the procurement of supplies, social investments and payment of revenue to the government.<br /><br />
Negative impacts will mainly be due to disturbance to land owners and influx of workers and job<br /><br />
seekers bringing pressure on social infrastructure and natural resources and possible increases in<br /><br />
social ills. Furthermore there is likely to be a localised disruption in the cost of living which could<br /><br />
significantly disadvantage those who are disenfranchised from the project and create potential for<br /><br />
conflict with migrants. Mitigation measures are dependent on establishing transparent and effective<br /><br />
social management processes including harm minimisation, compensation and long-term community<br /><br />
development mechanisms. The following mitigation measures are expected to reduce the intensity of<br /><br />
the residual impacts from major to moderate/minor.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a Resettlement Action Plan (RAP).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a livelihood restoration plan.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implementation of a grievance mechanism.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a Community Development Action Plan.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In some instances these community mitigation measures co-opt support from NGOs .<br /><br />
Human Health<br /><br />
The preliminary health impacts associated with Phase 1 construction and operations of the mine have<br /><br />
been identified as those related to community resettlement, worker in-migration, increased burden of<br /><br />
disease due project activities and water storage facilities, potential changes to surface and<br /><br />
groundwater, vehicle traffic, noise, and changes in locally produced foods. Beneficial impacts such as<br /><br />
access to improved healthcare facilities, health benefits through local employment, increased access to<br /><br />
the region, and community re-settlement have also been identified.<br /><br />
Implementation of the recommended mitigative measures regarding community resettlement and<br /><br />
worker in-migration, malaria control measures, and programs designed to control the spread of<br /><br />
communicable diseases such as HIV/AIDs and cholera is expected to reduce the significance of the<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />

Project.<br /><br />
It is important to note that impacts to health cannot be mitigated in isolation. Therefore the mitigation<br /><br />
measures recommended by other disciplines such as socio –economics, air, surface and groundwater,<br /><br />
flora and fauna.would also help in reducing health impacts.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
13.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Transport Corridor Impact Assessment<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Air & Noise<br /><br />
Principal air and noise issues along the transport corridor are related to earthworks and vehicle<br /><br />
movement during the construction and operational phases respectively. Potential issues may be<br /><br />
associated width dust control and emissions from a power source at the Lunsar interchange. Standard<br /><br />
mitigation measures such as road dampening to reduce dust levels and imposing appropriate buffer<br /><br />
zones will have the effect of reducing impacts to minor or insignificant level.<br /><br />
The proximity of the proposed transport route in relation to villages and residential areas remains a key<br /><br />
issue. Whilst a principle of avoidance of resettlement wherever possible has been upheld, the<br /><br />
combination of public safety and dust and noise nuisance issues means that in some instances, even<br /><br />
though mitigation measures may be partially effective, it has been considered more appropriate and<br /><br />
responsible to pursue a resettlement solution. The maintenance of a buffer zone should be sufficient<br /><br />
for most residential areas, in exceptional cases where resettlement is not feasible, additional mitigation<br /><br />
measures (e.g. noise barriers or noise isolation) at sensitive receptors will minimize the impacts. A<br /><br />
buffer zone of 500m has generally been accepted for the project, if communities lie within this zone then<br /><br />
a review of either resettlement or mitigation is required.<br /><br />
Stockpiles and operations at Lunsar Interchange could create moderate residual impact however<br /><br />
detailed design for the stockpile should alleviate this impact through optimizing the siting and orientation<br /><br />
of the stockpile.<br /><br />
Ecology & Biodiversity<br /><br />
The principal impact on vegetation will arise from the land clearance required for road construction,<br /><br />
leading to the removal of vegetation. Fragmentation of habitats may also occur. Outside the direct<br /><br />
footprint of the road, localised clearance of vegetation may occur in borrow areas (potential sources for<br /><br />
bridge construction materials) and also through consequential influx to areas that have been cleared<br /><br />
and access opened. Invasive species may spread along the area of disturbed land and propagate<br /><br />
beyond into undisturbed land. Impacts on rheophytes (aquatic plants) may occur at bridges and<br /><br />
downstream of river crossings.<br /><br />
Habitat loss and fragmentation directly associated with the construction of the transport corridor as<br /><br />
described above could lead to a reduction in fauna species diversity and abundance (and potentially a<br /><br />
loss of species of conservation concern). Habitat alteration may also occur as a result of disruption of<br /><br />
migration across the transport corridor. The residual (post-mitigation) impacts should be minor if habitat<br /><br />
hot-spot avoidance is used as a first principle and appropriate international best practice preventative<br /><br />
<br /><br />

TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
and mitigation measures are put in place. Particular care and control associated with bridge works is<br /><br />
required, including the use of containing coffer dams to minimise impact (se below).<br /><br />
The most significant impacts to aquatic ecosystems are associated with the construction and<br /><br />
redevelopment of crossings resulting in uncontrolled sedimentation (and increased turbidity from instream (such as piling) and land disturbance activities. This may be compounded by removal of<br /><br />
riparian vegetation which will increase diffuse pollutant transport from the adjoining areas. Residual<br /><br />
(post-mitigation) impacts should be minor if appropriate environmental engineering control and design is<br /><br />
applied.<br /><br />
Any significant ecological impacts as a result of the project-related activities may have indirect social<br /><br />
impacts.<br /><br />
Avoidance of key habitat areas has already been attempted with interaction between the haul road<br /><br />
designers and environmental specialists (see Haul Road EMP, WorleyParsons 2010). In instances<br /><br />
where there is close proximity or unavoidable overlap (for example at River Crossings) between the<br /><br />
transport corridor and sensitive habitat then residual impacts should be minor if appropriate<br /><br />
international best practice preventative and mitigation measures are put in place. Restoration of the<br /><br />
transport corridor is unlikely following completion of Phase1 as the road will be retained as a mine<br /><br />
service road.<br /><br />
Further evaluation of habitat areas, transport design and routing and ecological management is<br /><br />
required. As this remains unknown pending further evaluation, the expert view on residual impact<br /><br />
magnitude in association with fragmentation, loss of species richness and abundance from disturbance<br /><br />
has been conservatively set as remaining as an impact of major significance. It is therefore essential<br /><br />
for AML and its contractors to demonstrate good design in selecting the route and avoiding areas of<br /><br />
ecological importance. It is also essential that further habitat study and review is completed so that<br /><br />
there is better understanding of ecosystem behaviour. This is essential if management approaches are<br /><br />
going to be relied upon.<br /><br />
Assuming avoidance of sensitive areas is rigorously followed by AML, then in conjunction with a<br /><br />
number of conservation off-set measures, the residual (post-avoidance and post-mitigation) impacts on<br /><br />
ecology and biodiversity should be minor. However, this is reliant on AML also immediately adopting a<br /><br />
conspicuous and pro-active policy to restricting any habitat disturbance within their concession area and<br /><br />
developing programmes that support alternative food supply to local people including animal husbandry<br /><br />
and farming to reduce the reliance on hunting and frontier fuel-wood collection.<br /><br />
Hydrology and Hydrogeology<br /><br />
Potential impacts pertaining to local surface and groundwater along the transport corridor are<br /><br />
predominantly associated with increase in turbidity and reduction in water quality during both<br /><br />
construction and operations phases. There is a requirement for risk assessment to evaluate the<br /><br />
likelihood and potential consequences associated with accidental spillage. The transport corridor may<br /><br />
also result in changes to drainage patterns due to diversions and alterations.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures significantly reduce potential impacts on surface water and groundwater.<br /><br />
Residual, post mitigation impacts will include some potentially long term changes to valley swamp<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
drainage systems that are crossed by the road. There will be localized residual but reversible impacts<br /><br />
on surface and groundwater resources due to abstraction for construction and operational demands.<br /><br />
Soils & Land Use<br /><br />
The principal impact will arise from the land clearance including slash and burn of vegetation and<br /><br />
surface soils strip being carried out for road construction. The construction of the road may also<br /><br />
constrain certain land-uses and / or access to land. Temporary and minor impacts on soil resources and<br /><br />
land-use during the refurbishment of the Delco rail line may also occur.<br /><br />
The residual (post-mitigation) impacts of land clearance on soil resources and land-use are unlikely to<br /><br />
be significant if appropriate design and site management is applied. Change in land use leading to loss<br /><br />
of farming land may remain as a moderate residual impact as access restrictions may constrain land<br /><br />
use.<br /><br />
Socio-Economic<br /><br />
The social impacts of the transport corridor are likely to occur mainly during the construction phase due<br /><br />
to disturbance to the existing land users. Rail refurbishment will take place on the existing rail<br /><br />
embankment. Impacts will range from loss of access, land-based resources, and loss of shelter, all of<br /><br />
which may potentially lead to a decrease in economic stability<br /><br />
The haul road may pass through the sugar plantations to be developed as part of the Addax Biofuel<br /><br />
Project. The compensation for potential impacts on the sugarcane plantations may require separate<br /><br />
negotiations with relevant stakeholders.<br /><br />
The mitigation measures given below are expected to reduce the residual impacts from major to<br /><br />
moderate/minor.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a Resettlement Action Plan (RAP).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a livelihood restoration plan.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implementation of a grievance mechanism.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation and implementation of the CDAP<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Given the high level of unemployment in Sierra Leone, it will be difficult to completely control an<br /><br />
anticipated influx of job seekers to villages and towns along the transport corridor. However, the<br /><br />
following measures can reduce impacts from moderate to minor.<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Planning for self sufficient and closed workers camps to minimise intermingling of workers<br /><br />
with local population.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Providing assistance for the control of communicable diseases and for educational<br /><br />
campaigns for prevention of social ills.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Planning jointly with local Paramount Chief and other stakeholders to minimise<br /><br />
speculative migration.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
In the long term, the improved transport infrastructure may also lead to growth of industry and other<br /><br />
economic activities and benefits including employment, investment and revenue along the corridor<br /><br />
(more likely along the haul road), which may contribute to general economic development.<br /><br />
All social impacts can be mitigated against which could result in either the development of beneficial<br /><br />
opportunities or minimisation of residual impact to a minor level. However, it is noted that this strategy<br /><br />
is reliant on rapid implementation of a challenging social management programme which will require<br /><br />
support and collaboration from stakeholders including local government, people’s organisations and<br /><br />
NGOs.<br /><br />
Human Health<br /><br />
The preliminary health impacts associated with the Phase 1 construction and operation of the transport<br /><br />
corridor have been identified as those related to community resettlement, worker in-migration,<br /><br />
increased burden of disease due project activities and water storage facilities, potential changes to<br /><br />
surface water, vehicle traffic, and changes in locally produced foods. Beneficial impacts such as access<br /><br />
to improved healthcare facilities, health benefits through local employment, increased access to the<br /><br />
region, and community re-settlement have been identified.<br /><br />
Implementation of the recommended mitigative measures regarding community resettlement and<br /><br />
worker in-migration, malaria control measures, programs designed to control the spread of<br /><br />
communicable diseases such as HIV/AIDs and cholera, and traffic regulation is expected to reduce the<br /><br />
significance of the major and moderate health impacts and thus avoid potentially major health issues for<br /><br />
persons living in the vicinity of the Project.<br /><br />
It is important to note that impacts to health cannot be mitigated in isolation. Therefore the mitigation<br /><br />
measures recommended by other disciplines such as socio –economics, air, surface and groundwater,<br /><br />
flora and fauna would also help in reducing health impacts.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
13.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Port Impact Assessment<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Air& Noise<br /><br />
Construction activities at Pepel Port will comprise a combination of existing asset refurbishment and<br /><br />
new development.<br /><br />
Air emissions arising from land clearance (dust), power generation and wind dispersal of fines from<br /><br />
stockpiles can be mitigated to moderate /minor residual significance by dust suppression, machinery<br /><br />
emission control and good design and orientation of stockpiles.<br /><br />
An increase in noise levels may be generated by machinery, engines, vehicles used for transport,<br /><br />
loading and unloading of rock, materials and waste and power generation. Further operational phase<br /><br />
identified noise sources are ship traffic (motors, sirens, etc.), machinery movement, conveyors, loading<br /><br />
and unloading activities at the Dual Train Dumping Station, the Stacker Feed System, the Reclaim Feed<br /><br />
System and the Shiploader Feed System<br /><br />
Generic recommendations for the construction phase include the use of machinery and equipment that<br /><br />
guarantee low noise emissions. Noise impacts at nearby community receptors (Kalangba) should be<br /><br />
<br /><br />

minimised through an appropriate layout plan. If further mitigation measures are required then sound<br /><br />
barriers could be installed. The residual impacts on air quality and noise are classified as Minor.<br /><br />
Ecology & Biodiversity<br /><br />
The principal impacts to vegetation will arise from the potential clearance of mangrove during<br /><br />
installation or refurbishment of infrastructure. Invasive species may also spread to undisturbed land<br /><br />
following natural colonisation or deliberate introduction in disturbed areas (where such species tend to<br /><br />
thrive). The release of acidity and metals from disturbed acid sulphate soils (if present) can cause the<br /><br />
die back of vegetation in the localised area and hydraulically connected areas. Impacts on fauna may<br /><br />
further reduce natural colonisation by indigenous plant species where fauna play a role in seed<br /><br />
dispersal.<br /><br />
The residual (post-mitigation and post-closure) impacts on terrestrial fauna should be minor if<br /><br />
appropriate international best practice preventative and mitigation measures are put in place and the<br /><br />
site is rehabilitated on closure of Phase 1 of the Tonkolili project.<br /><br />
There are no major or moderate impacts expected to affect aquatic ecosystems in the Pepel Port area<br /><br />
on the basis that to surface water systems were encountered. However, it is noted that groundwater<br /><br />
and potential freshwater spring discharges in the inter-tidal zone could be significant to the maintenance<br /><br />
of the mangrove ecosystem and will be vulnerable to pollution or contamination at Pepel. Furthermore<br /><br />
groundwater abstraction and the movement of the saline interface could also affect specialised<br /><br />
ecological communities. The adoption of stringent water quality guidelines and further hydrogeological<br /><br />
review is being used to also assess and protect dependent ecosystems.<br /><br />
Further evaluation of habitat areas, port design and construction techniques and ecological<br /><br />
management is required. As this remains unknown pending further evaluation, the expert view on<br /><br />
residual impact magnitude in association with fragmentation, loss of species richness and abundance<br /><br />
from disturbance has been conservatively set as remaining as an impact of major significance. It is<br /><br />
therefore essential for AML and its contractors to avoid areas of ecological importance. It is also<br /><br />
essential that further habitat study and review is completed so that there is better understanding of<br /><br />
ecosystem behaviour. This is essential if management approaches are going to be relied upon.<br /><br />
Assuming avoidance of sensitive areas is rigorously followed by AML, then in conjunction with a<br /><br />
number of conservation off-set measures, the residual (post-avoidance and post-mitigation) impacts on<br /><br />
ecology and biodiversity should be minor. However, this is reliant on AML also immediately adopting a<br /><br />
conspicuous and pro-active policy to restricting any habitat disturbance within their concession area and<br /><br />
developing programmes that support alternative food supply to local people including animal husbandry<br /><br />
and farming to reduce the reliance on hunting and frontier fuel-wood collection.<br /><br />
Hydrology and Hydrogeology<br /><br />
Impacts at Pepel are predominantly associated with groundwater contamination through chemical<br /><br />
spillage and conventional contaminated land pollutant linkages. In addition, the coastal setting and use<br /><br />
of groundwater creates a risk associated with saline intrusion.<br /><br />
Groundwater at Pepel Island is considered to be a highly sensitive receptor and requires a detailed<br /><br />
groundwater management to protect it otherwise the operations could lead to long term damage to the<br /><br />
<br /><br />

aquifer beneath Pepel Port. Monitoring will be critical to ensure that mitigation measures can be refined<br /><br />
and are appropriate and effective. Residual, post mitigation impacts are anticipated to be minimal if<br /><br />
regulated through a well developed management plan - localized residual impacts are expected to be<br /><br />
reversible as surface and groundwater resources should recover through high rates of recharge after<br /><br />
abstraction.<br /><br />
Soils & Land Use<br /><br />
Baseline soil data for the historical industrial Pepel Port area has been collected for a few indicative<br /><br />
surface samples only and indicates a probably relatively low level historical impact on quality, principally<br /><br />
with some elevated levels of arsenic and some localised leakage or spillage of fuels and oils as well as<br /><br />
coal tar related contamination.<br /><br />
Stripping of surface soils and other earthworks associated with preparation of new stockpile areas and<br /><br />
foundations for new port infrastructure could potentially mobilise or expose historically present<br /><br />
contaminants.<br /><br />
On the whole, the reinstatement of the Port is not considered likely to have a significant impact on the<br /><br />
soils at or outside the port if works are designed and managed with due consideration given to current<br /><br />
conditions. Measures are described in the ESHIA that set out a contamination material inventory and<br /><br />
methods for the appropriate handling of soils after reference to a site-specific contamination register.<br /><br />
Further studies to better delineate contamination and appropriate remediation if required is<br /><br />
recommended. Residual (post-mitigation) impacts should be minor if this is implemented.<br /><br />
Socio economic<br /><br />
The refurbishment of Pepel Port may require additional land in its vicinity for construction and<br /><br />
operational activities and facilities. The land near the port is currently used for dwellings, trading,<br /><br />
agriculture and grazing. Potential impacts include resettlement, and reduction in the available<br /><br />
community land base as well as sea based activities such as fishing<br /><br />
The economic opportunities created at the Pepel Port are expected to lead to an influx of workers and<br /><br />
job seekers mainly during the construction phase. The refurbishment of Pepel Port is expected to have<br /><br />
predominantly beneficial socio-economic impacts during its construction and operation phase (up to 8<br /><br />
years).<br /><br />
Mitigation measures are expected to reduce the intensity of the residual impacts from major to<br /><br />
moderate/minor. This includes<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a Resettlement Action Plan (RAP).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preparation of a livelihood restoration plan.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implementation of a grievance mechanism.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Planning and coordination with local government, Paramount Chief and other<br /><br />
stakeholders to minimise speculative migration and maximise opportunity for local<br /><br />
communities through provisioning goods and services, education and skill-building.<br /><br />

In line with its corporate policy, AML is expected to initiate a social investment programme in the Pepel<br /><br />
Port area with the start of construction work. This includes improvement in social infrastructure such as<br /><br />
water supply, schools and health centres and development of livelihood opportunities, independent of<br /><br />
the port.<br /><br />
Human Health<br /><br />
The preliminary health impacts associated with Phase 1 relate to both construction and operation of the<br /><br />
Pepel port have been identified as those related to community resettlement, worker in-migration,<br /><br />
increased burden of disease due project activities and water storage facilities, potential changes to<br /><br />
surface and groundwater, noise, and changes in locally produced foods. Beneficial impacts such as<br /><br />
access to improved healthcare facilities, health benefits through local employment were identified.<br /><br />
Implementation of the recommended mitigative measures regarding community resettlement and<br /><br />
worker in-migration, malaria control measures, and programs designed to control the spread of<br /><br />
communicable diseases such as HIV/AIDs and cholera is expected to reduce the significance of the<br /><br />
major and moderate health impacts and thus avoid potentially major health issues for persons living in<br /><br />
the vicinity of the Project.<br /><br />
It is important to note that impacts to health cannot be mitigated in isolation. Therefore the mitigation<br /><br />
measures recommended by other disciplines such as socio –economics, air, surface and groundwater,<br /><br />
flora and fauna.would also help in reducing health impacts.<br /><br />

13.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Offshore & Coastal Impact Assessment<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mangrove Clearance<br /><br />
The baseline preliminary survey indicates that the coastal and marine habitat around Pepel is healthy<br /><br />
and contains a high level of biodiversity. There are a number of potential impacts including: reduction<br /><br />
and clearance of habitat areas for access and enabling works to support the predominantly brownfield<br /><br />
refurbishment, altered soil elevations, altered hydrology and spill over of development effects to<br /><br />
surrounding areas. Land clearance and significant earthworks are not required. However, alteration of<br /><br />
hydrology requires further investigation.<br /><br />
However, the majority of the port infrastructure is already in place, and most of what is required will be<br /><br />
refurbished rather than constructed from new. As a result there will be no significant increase in the<br /><br />
existing port footprint, and therefore no significant area of coastal habitat will have to be cleared. The<br /><br />
currently proposed development footprint for the Pepel leasehold area will result in reasonably minor<br /><br />
losses of mangroves.<br /><br />
Therefore the residual impact is considered to be of minor significance if the port remains within the<br /><br />
existing footprint and avoids mangrove clearance and disruption; and compensatory measures for<br /><br />
mangrove protection are undertaken through the life of the Tonkolili project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-6-10\tonkolili phase 1 eshia<br /><br />
report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
Page 338 : 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Effects of Iron Ore Release into Estuary<br /><br />
Whilst it has been shown that slight positive impacts associated with increased rates of growth<br /><br />
(particularly in younger mangrove plants) have been associated with iron contamination, toxicity limits<br /><br />
are not known and the potential for synergistic negative responses remain.<br /><br />
Over the past 24 years rain and wind activity has subjected the old stockpiles at Pepel to leaching,<br /><br />
There is currently no evidence of any existing impact on the surrounding mangroves due to the<br /><br />
presence of the residual hematite ore, although there are elevated levels of heavy metals in the near<br /><br />
shore soil samples (Hydrological baseline survey, April 2010).<br /><br />
Increased Noise and Light Levels<br /><br />
The use of heavy machinery during construction will increase ambient noise levels, and potentially<br /><br />
result in disturbance of sensitive coastal fauna such as birds. The current level of noise in Pepel is<br /><br />
relatively low, due to the low human population and lack of any significant port activity. As a result,<br /><br />
higher noise levels may result in significant impacts on birds which are a key aspect of the Ramsar<br /><br />
designation.<br /><br />
Persistent man-made light can be a major issue for a range of marine fauna, with birds in particular<br /><br />
sensitive to increased and extended levels. Non-natural light can deter them from feeding, breeding<br /><br />
and nesting, and can generally confuse their natural behaviour. Due to the high density of wetland<br /><br />
birds present in the project location, and its position inside a designated Ramsar site, increased light is<br /><br />
a potentially significant impact, especially if construction work would take place during bird migratory or<br /><br />
breeding seasons.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures need to consider both of these issues as impacts with potentially major<br /><br />
significance and adapt construction activities to avoid sensitive habitat areas (eg high avifauna<br /><br />
population, important nesting and feeding sites, and migratory and nesting seasons). Adaptations<br /><br />
include use of shading and avoiding of strong lighting use of low-pressure sodium vapour lamps and<br /><br />
limiting activity during sensitive times of the day e.g. extended night operations.<br /><br />
Wastewater Discharges<br /><br />
Discharge of untreated wastewater into the estuary has the potential to affect water pH, colour,<br /><br />
temperature, smell, dissolved oxygen, nutrient levels and bacterial contamination. This can create<br /><br />
indirect impacts on the estuary ecosystem, as well as posing a health risk to local communities;<br /><br />
especially if the discharge point is located near to beaches used by locals for fishing or bathing. The<br /><br />
significance of the impact of waste water discharge is highly dependant on the treatment system<br /><br />
implemented in the project design, and the location of the discharge point in the estuary. A more<br /><br />
detailed assessment of wastewater discharges is required to develop the mitigation methods further.<br /><br />
Mitigation measures to be considered should include installation of temporary treatment plant to treat<br /><br />
construction camp discharges. Ensuring treated water discharge is located away from sensitive<br /><br />
locations and in areas of strong tidal currents to increase dilution and removal; and compliance with<br /><br />
World Bank discharge limits as specified in the Stage 2 Environmental basis of Design document.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Spills and Run-off of Oil and Chemical contaminants<br /><br />
During construction and refurbishment there is a risk of increased run-off due to earthworks, and a risk<br /><br />
of oil and chemical contamination from disturbance of existing contaminated land, and new incidents of<br /><br />
fuel, lubricant and coating spills used in construction machinery, and from potential oil spills.<br /><br />
The significance of this impact will depend upon the level of increased run off and/or spills, and their<br /><br />
location and proximity to coastal habitat such as mangroves or mudflats; mangroves are particularly<br /><br />
sensitive to oil spills.<br /><br />
Before mitigation the impact on VR marine fauna is considered to be of moderate significance.<br /><br />
A more detailed assessment of run-off during construction is required to develop the mitigation methods<br /><br />
further. It should include run-off collection and treatment systems, waste management planning, spill<br /><br />
response plans (contingency planning and emergency response measures should be in place).<br /><br />
Industry best practice regarding refuelling activities, oil handling activities and machinery maintenance;<br /><br />
Refurbishment of Mooring Dolphins<br /><br />
The refurbishment and potential construction of mooring dolphins, to enable the mooring of<br /><br />
transshipment vessels will primarily impact on the sub-tidal habitat. The sub-tidal habitat directly<br /><br />
beneath could be impacted through smothering, pile driving, and placement of rock material. No<br /><br />
mitigation measures are required other than further characterisation of the sub tidal habitat<br /><br />
Increased Turbidity<br /><br />
The construction and refurbishment of marine structures could result in elevated turbidity within the<br /><br />
immediate vicinity of the port. Activities such as piling can significantly disturb bottom sediments,<br /><br />
introducing material into the water column. Increased turbidity can result in a number of direct and<br /><br />
indirect impacts on coastal and marine ecosystems; for example, levels of photosynthesis can fall due<br /><br />
to a drop in light penetration down through the water column<br /><br />
However, given the natural conditions of the estuary particularly during wet season conditions it is<br /><br />
considered that the habitat is likely to be resilient to increased turbidity levels over the short duration of<br /><br />
the construction programme at Pepel.<br /><br />
Although the impact is expected to be minor the following mitigation measures should be considered:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Use of floating turbidity barriers and/or silt curtains to contain turbidity plumes during marine<br /><br />
construction activities; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Design construction activity to occur in periods of high dispersion (e.g. ebb tide).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Disturbance of Contaminated Sediments<br /><br />
Construction/refurbishment activity has the potential to disturb marine sediment. There are some<br /><br />
indications that sediment in the vicinity of Pepel retains pre-existing contamination (e.g. hydrocarbons<br /><br />
or metals). If sediment is disturbed there is a risk the contaminants could be released and assimilated<br /><br />
by marine flora or fauna (e.g. mangroves, fish and shellfish) and there is a risk of bio-accumulation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
q:\mandm select\aml - tonkolili\10.0 engineering\10.13 es - environmental and social\stage 1\phase 1 (ecf)\eshia\7-6-10\tonkolili phase 1 eshia<br /><br />
report pb 7-06-10_updated+appendices.doc<br /><br />
Page 340 : 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0020Rev 0 : 18 Jun 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
STAGE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The potential impact on both marine habit and human receptors is considered to be of moderate<br /><br />
significance and it is recommended that a detailed characterisation of near shore and intertidal marine<br /><br />
sediments is undertaken prior to construction. Thereafter avoid disturbance of contaminated areas.<br /><br />
Increased Underwater Noise<br /><br />
Underwater construction activities, in particular pile driving, can generate high levels of underwater<br /><br />
noise Marine mammal and the impact of underwater noise and ship collisions remains as a moderate<br /><br />
impact due to lack of information at this stage but surveys are underway.<br /><br />
Fuel Handling Operations<br /><br />
Fuel for power generation will be transported by road and vessels will not refuel at Pepel, therefore no<br /><br />
fuel handling operations are planned within the marine area of the port.<br /><br />
Navigation and Fishing<br /><br />
The majority of marine traffic in the estuary is focussed around Freetown. Trans-shipment operations<br /><br />
are currently expected to involve Handymax transshipment vessels, which will transfer ore to a loading<br /><br />
on anchorage point outside the mouth of the estuary. The impact of the transshipment operations on<br /><br />
shipping in the estuary is not expected to be significant.<br /><br />
Ballast Water and Marine Pests<br /><br />
The location of the trans-shipment anchorage is not currently confirmed. Therefore there remains a<br /><br />
possibility that cargo vessels could introduce invasive species during the operational phase by releasing<br /><br />
ballast water at the destination location, particularly important if this occurs within the estuary or near<br /><br />
enclosed waters rather than off-shore. If an anchorage is selected that makes this impact viable then<br /><br />
AML will need to ensure the 2004 International Convention for the Control and Management of Ships'<br /><br />
Ballast Water and Sediments is strictly followed.<br /><br />
Vessel Waste Management and Discharges<br /><br />
Routine discharges from vessels may have effects on water quality similar to the effects created by<br /><br />
discharges from the port, such as changes in water pH, colour, temperature, smell, dissolved oxygen,<br /><br />
nutrient levels and bacterial contamination. Mitigation of these effects will need to be achieved through<br /><br />
ensuring the prevention of pollution from shipping (MARPOL), i.e. diligent regulation of the port authority<br /><br />
/ contractors.<br /><br />
Trans-shipment Anchorage<br /><br />
Loading at the anchorage during transshipment, although designed to be highly efficient will create a<br /><br />
cumulative impact over the life of the project. The potential behaviour of the iron ore in the water will<br /><br />
depend on the spillage particle size and its chemical composition. Generally, iron often forms colloidal<br /><br />
suspensions of ferric hydroxide in the presence of oxygen, although the hematite particle size will<br /><br />
probably preclude wide spread dispersal. It is recommended that a full assessment of the proposed<br /><br />
iron ore product is undertaken to understand its constituents.<br /><br />
Dredging<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Capital dredging will be required to open the navigation channel to access Pepel port. Ongoing<br /><br />
maintenance dredging will be required to keep the channel open.<br /><br />
Dredging remains as a moderate impact awaiting a more detailed dredging impact assessment once<br /><br />
the required data are available.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
13.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Distributed Impact Assessment<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Bulk Materials<br /><br />
Bulk materials such as earth and fill for ground conditioning will be controlled through activity-specific<br /><br />
management plans and protocols and contractors will be accountable for adherence to the plans and<br /><br />
protocols.<br /><br />
Demand on Existing Infrastructure<br /><br />
The project’s dependency on existing infrastructure will be limited. There will be initial reliance on<br /><br />
imported goods and contractor services for food, accommodation and camps with opportunities for<br /><br />
goods and services to create livelihood benefits for project communities. Adherence to prior and clear<br /><br />
project announcements is expected.<br /><br />
Solid and Liquid Waste Management<br /><br />
The greatest impact is likely to arise from interim storage of wastes in particular pest, odour and litter<br /><br />
control. AML will be required to ensure its contractor’s implement a hierarchy of waste elimination at<br /><br />
source, recycling, reuse, recovery, and as a last resort – disposal. In addition provision for destroying or<br /><br />
treating hazardous waste is required to render it non-hazardous if possible.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
13.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Commitments, Management and Performance<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This ESHIA has been prepared for submission for approval on the understanding that elements of the<br /><br />
study are not yet fully developed. In recognition of this, the proponent (AML) has committed to<br /><br />
undertake the completion of the study work in Stage 2 and meanwhile apply comprehensive<br /><br />
environmental and social (E&S) management to project design, construction and development. It is<br /><br />
recommended that rigorous risk review is used from this point, in the interim ahead of final ESHIA<br /><br />
Stage 2 submission so as to identify appropriate E&S management measures.<br /><br />
A significant volume of assessment work has been achieved and the impact assessment has been<br /><br />
completed to a sufficient level for regulatory decision making. It is recognised that further work is<br /><br />
required, including further project definition in order to be able to define more specific impacts and<br /><br />
mitigation measures and develop effective management strategies.<br /><br />
Where generic construction management plans can be implemented from the currently available<br /><br />
information then these have been provided. In other instances, the management plans will need to be<br /><br />
formulated pending further work and all that can be given now is an outline of the management plan<br /><br />
purpose.<br /><br />
This is particularly important for the terrestrial and marine eco-systems that could be affected by the<br /><br />
project. To date it has been recognised that areas under the direct footprint of the project contain either<br /><br />

TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
recognised high conservation value species or habitat that is of major significance. An integrated<br /><br />
approach involving additional assessment, avoidance wherever possible of critical areas, mitigation,<br /><br />
development of compensatory programmes and community development programmes is required.<br /><br />
Further study work is required and will be included in a Stage 2 ESHIA later in 2010 that will provide<br /><br />
more specific design and definition to these programmes.<br /><br />
It is also important that management plans take into account consequential impacts that will be created<br /><br />
many of which will be unintended and difficult to control. This includes the impact associated with<br /><br />
speculative influx of migrant workers and accelerated degradation of habitat in areas that was hitherto<br /><br />
relatively inaccessible and sparsely populated. Management plans need to develop a clearer<br /><br />
understanding of how compensation, alternative livelihood schemes, regulation and sustainable<br /><br />
community development can be effectively implemented to reduce secondary impacts.<br /><br />
Recommendations are given for ongoing monitoring, auditing and performance evaluation of the<br /><br />
environmental and social elements of the project so that continued improvement, adherence to agreed<br /><br />
standards and effective liaison with SLEPA is maintained.<br /><br />
Monitoring will involve both internal and external inspections and auditing of performance and<br /><br />
compliance to contract documents. Where a degree of capacity building is required to ensure that<br /><br />
inspection visits and audits by the competent authority (SLEPA) can be achieved then it is understood<br /><br />
and has been recorded (Appendix 1) that AML will provide provision for this. In addition inspection<br /><br />
visits and audits by independent consultants, appointed by AML, will produce monitoring reports that<br /><br />
SLEPA can access and comment on. Currently this has been done by the ESHIA consultants and their<br /><br />
baseline data collection.<br /><br />
The monitoring strategy proposed for the project can be termed "Adaptive Environmental Monitoring". It<br /><br />
is adaptive in the sense that the responsible party must adapt its methods and activities to the ongoing<br /><br />
design and implementation and prevailing environmental conditions in a continuous process.<br /><br />
