APPENDIX 1<br /><br />
Public Consultation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AML WORKSHOP <br /><br />
Date: 17th May, 2010 <br /><br />
Agencies in attendance:  SEE ATTACHED <br /><br />
Commencement of the meeting <br /><br />
The meeting was declared open by the Corporate Manager of AML, Mr Mustapha J. Kamara as <br /><br />
he introduced a representative of the organization, Think Tank. The representative went on to <br /><br />
attributing  her  visit  to  Sierra  Leone  to  the  level  of  religious  tolerance  expressed  in  the  bi‐<br /><br />
religious prayers said at the beginning of meetings. This was immediately followed by individual <br /><br />
Christian  and  Muslim  prayers  by  two  paramount  chiefs,  including  P.C  Bai  Shebora  of  Kafu <br /><br />
Bullom chiefdom. <br /><br />
The Chairman of the Port Loko District council, Mr Hamid Fofanah introduced the Paramount <br /><br />
Chiefs present; Hon. Bineh Bangura followed suite in introducing the members of Parliament. <br /><br />
The list of all the organizations present at the meeting was read, as were the presenters from <br /><br />
AML. The Acting Director of Mines introduced the ministers. <br /><br />
The Chairman`s Opening Remarks <br /><br />
The  Deputy  Minister  of  Mines  was  introduced  as  Chairman  of  the  meeting,  and  he  gave  his <br /><br />
opening  remarks  recognizing  important  members  of  organizations  such  as  the  4th  estate <br /><br />
present. He started by saying ‘AML has discovered the largest iron ore deposit in the world’ and <br /><br />
that the company called the meeting to officially present their story to important stakeholders, <br /><br />
all of which, according to him, were present. He looked forward to AML discussing the present <br /><br />
state  of  the  mining  project  with  the  community;  discuss  timelines  and  schedules;  and  the <br /><br />
benefit of the mines to Sierra Leoneans and the government.  He assured Sierra Leoneans to be <br /><br />
proud  of  the  amount  of  ore  in  the  deposit  already  found  and  still  being  explored  in  the  Sula <br /><br />
Hills.  He  briefly  elucidated  the  process  from  exploration  to  definite  feasibility  studies,  mining <br /><br />
and shipment abroad, and that AML will be discussing road construction for mining operations, <br /><br />
the benefits in terms of income generation and employment to Sierra Leoneans. And that the <br /><br />
meeting would culminate in an open discussion, question and answer period.    <br /><br />
Presenter ‐ Mining Operations, John Blanning <br /><br />
Following  tea  break,  John  Blanning,  the  Chairman  of  mining  operations  of  AML  led  the <br /><br />
presentation  by  showing  an  impressive  animation  of  the  entire  mining  process  and  shipping <br /><br />
operation. He gave an overview of the area of the 3 sites housing the ore and that, in which the <br /><br />
ore  is  concentrated;  the  road  trains  that  will  be  transporting  the  mine  product  to  Lunsar  for <br /><br />
transfer onto rail trains bound for Pepel, where it will be stacked and transported on conveyor <br /><br />
<br /><br />
belts to the jetty for shipment. He mentioned Sierra Leone’s competitive advantage over other <br /><br />
suppliers like Brazil, by way of shorter distance (half the distance) for the shipment of the ore to <br /><br />
China  and  Europe.  He  further  discussed  the  refurbishment  of  the  defunct  Marampa  mines’ <br /><br />
railways and some of their rail cars. According to him, 2 rails will be involved: a refurbished one <br /><br />
to Pepel and a brand new rail; a new port will also be constructed at Targrin. John B. further <br /><br />
iterated  that  the  exploration  and  drilling  for  the  magnetite  is  completed,  whilst  that  for  the <br /><br />
hematite  is  underway.  He  also  discussed  the  mining,  drilling  and  blasting  process,  the <br /><br />
engineering and design details. He went on the talking about the equipment, locomotives and <br /><br />
rolling stock to be purchased and the cars for the railway that are being constructed in South <br /><br />
Africa. Following Mr Blanning, the Chairman gave a summary of his talk.  <br /><br />
Presenter ‐ Infrastructure (Steve) <br /><br />
Steve the infrastructure manager started his talk by declaring that AML creates value through <br /><br />
exploration and that the company holds an extensive mining portfolio. He gave all the statistics: <br /><br />
ore tonnage, potential number of employees, expenditure ESHIA process and social community, <br /><br />
revenue for government, local and regional development. As for Phase 2, he discussed mining <br /><br />
(blast, mine haul), processing input (power, water), infrastructure (water supply, tailings dam, <br /><br />
accommodation, support services which will be large), heavy haul railway ore hauled down to <br /><br />
targrin port, at targrin, the ore is offloaded from the train, to conveyor belts and channelled to <br /><br />
a stockyard to be loaded on ship; lots of dredging 30 million tons of materials hauled out for <br /><br />
navigation,  <br /><br />
Presenter ‐ ESHIA studies (Andrew Huckbody) <br /><br />
He  stated  that  there  is  an  intensive  study  underway  for  both  phases  of  the  project  in  the <br /><br />
following  areas:  flora,  mine  site,  haul  road,  inland  valley  swamps,  coastal  habitats,  marine <br /><br />
ecology,  birds  with  special  reference  to  the  RAMSAR  site,  inter‐tidal  and  sub‐tidal, <br /><br />
hydrodynamic  model  of  estuarine  processes,  terrestrial  fauna  –  birds,  mammals,  bats; <br /><br />
hydrology, hydrogeology‐ surface and groundwater quantity and quality; Waste management – <br /><br />
poor  facilities,  strategies  required;  air  quality,  noise;  health  impact  assessment;  and  Soils  and <br /><br />
geomorphology. <br /><br />
He  intimated  that  US$  2.5  million  has  been  spent  on  ESHIA  studies  so  far,  and  that  the <br /><br />
conclusion of the studies will have seen some US$ 3 million spent. Organizations participating in <br /><br />
the studies include: WP, SRK, CEMMATS, CSSL, NU, FBC, Kew Gardens, WCS, Hydrobiology, the <br /><br />
Meteorology office etc. <br /><br />
The timeline is as follows: Phase 1 (hematite) studies underway, report to be submitted in June <br /><br />
and Phase 2 to be submitted in September <br /><br />
<br /><br />
Presenter – Employment and Stakeholder Engagement (Colin Forbes): <br /><br />
Sierra  Leone  has  one  of  the  most  stringent  legislations  for  employment  in  the  West  African <br /><br />
region;  The  recruitment  coverage  include,  in  order  of  decreasing  preference,  local,  national <br /><br />
personnel  and  Sierra  Leoneans  in  the  diaspora  and  then  lastly,  international.  However,  local <br /><br />
personnel  with  the  requisite  skills  within  the  country  are  seriously  lacking.  There  are  good <br /><br />
resources in the diaspora, that notwithstanding. The skilled labour required for the construction <br /><br />
stage  will  be  in  excess  of  10,000,  but  most  of  the  jobs  will  likely  end  up  in  the  hands  of <br /><br />
foreigners, since trained people are few and far between. Most contractors also feel obliged to <br /><br />
bring their staff with them. In any case, given the typical 1:10 paradigm in mining communities, <br /><br />
ten (10) other Sierra Leoneans could benefit from ancillary jobs within the community for every <br /><br />
person employed by AML. The company`s primary focus in the operational phase is training of <br /><br />
local  personnel  through  vocational  skills  development,  with  the  objective  of replacing  foreign <br /><br />
staff with Sierra Leoneans.  <br /><br />
Regular  community  meetings  during  exploration  phase  with  stakeholders  within  the <br /><br />
operational areas. Socio‐economic baseline surveys to address community concerns is on going <br /><br />
at  the  moment  and  this  has  resulted  in  the  set  in  up  of  committees.  Early  Works  Chiefdom <br /><br />
Committees  (EWCC)  has  been  formed  to  address  the  immediate  impacts  of  the  Haul  Road <br /><br />
Construction and the railway refurbishment. The committees have got a well defined scope of <br /><br />
work  and  mandate.  EWCC  membership  include  Government  departments,  paramount  and <br /><br />
section chiefs, political leaders (Members of Parliament and district councillors), youth leaders <br /><br />
and NGOs.  District Consultative Forums would also be set up with the same defined scope of <br /><br />
work  and  mandate  as  the  EWCC  but  with  expanded  membership.  Several  sub‐committees <br /><br />
would  be  set  up  to  include  compensation,  community  development,  public  awareness, <br /><br />
monitoring and evaluation, influx management and Host site identification.  <br /><br />
Presenter ‐ Community project (Mr Mustapha Karama) <br /><br />
Mr  Kamara  went  through  a  list  of  community  projects  already  been  being  funded  by  AML: <br /><br />
Infrastructure, roads, bridges, water, health, signs for road safety, assisting with water projects, <br /><br />
initiatives for diseases like malaria, scholarships (800 to Tonkolili this year alone, primary and <br /><br />
secondary), agriculture training projects,  sports, donation to mosques, over 4 billion leones on <br /><br />
community projects in Sierra Leone. <br /><br />
There  are  plans  for  extensive  stakeholder  engagement,  GoSL  district  consultative  forum, <br /><br />
subcommittees to deal with social aspect of the project, (compensation, host site identification, <br /><br />
community development, employment and training and influx management).   <br /><br />
Social and community departments that are overseen by community liaison officers (16 in all) <br /><br />
will play an active role in community development projects.  <br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
QUESTION AND ANSWER SESSION <br /><br />
Qu: How many jobs will be provided by AML? <br /><br />
Ans:  Not  everyone  will  get  a  job  at  AML.  Trained  personnel  are  lacking  in  Sierra  Leone,  but <br /><br />
efforts are being made to bring in Sierra Leoneans working abroad and so far, the venture has <br /><br />
proven successful. In areas where trained Sierra Leoneans are unavailable, AML will temporarily <br /><br />
employ  an  expatriate  until  a  Sierra  Leonean  has  been  sufficiently  trained  to  replace  him. <br /><br />
Training at AML has been and will be an on‐going process, and the employees are encouraged <br /><br />
to be multi‐skilled.   <br /><br />
Qu: How will AML stack up against competitors from other parts of the world such as Brazil and <br /><br />
India? <br /><br />
Ans: To start with, the market for iron and steel will not be saturated in the foreseeable future. <br /><br />
If  for  example,  everyone  in  China  buys  a  dishwasher  and  a  laundry  machine  as  the  Chinese <br /><br />
economy grows to projected levels, no amount of steel in the world will meet such demand. As <br /><br />
for  now  and  in  the  future,  the  demand  for  iron  remains  high,  albeit  it  does  fluctuate.  AML <br /><br />
capitalizes  on  the  fact  that  Sierra  Leone  has  a  world  class  iron  ore  deposit  in  the  form  of <br /><br />
magnetite, as a good enough reason to try and stay ahead of the competition, a concept that <br /><br />
would be relied upon when global demand for iron dips. Much of the benefit would come from <br /><br />
the cost‐effectiveness of mining the ore that is concentrated in a small area, within 28km. At <br /><br />
this point, it is fair to state that at 50‐62% iron, the ore may not be the best in the world, but it <br /><br />
could be the most cost‐effective to mine. <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
Qu: When would the haul road be constructed? <br /><br />
Ans:  Some  major  contractors  are  being  brought  in  right  now  from  South  Africa;  WBHN  will <br /><br />
cover the Tonkolili axis, whilst two others will be in charge of the Port Loko and Bombali area. <br /><br />
There  is  not  enough  equipment  in  the  country  to  undertake  such  a  gargantuan  task.  As  we <br /><br />
speak,  there  are  mitigation  measures  being  put  in  place  to  carry  on  operations  in  the  rainy <br /><br />
season. A bridge designer is currently in the country and we are on track to complete that part <br /><br />
of  the  project  at  the  end  of  December.  The  old  Marampa  rail  tracks  are  undergoing <br /><br />
refurbishment that we expect to complete by the end of the year. Although rail cars are being <br /><br />
constructed in South Africa at the moment, some old cars at Pepel are being refurbished for the <br /><br />
trains. The cars from South Africa are being prepared for shipment to Sierra Leone and will be <br /><br />
here in the next 2‐3 months. <br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
Qu: Where does AML plan to obtain all the energy required for this work? <br /><br />
Ans: That’s the challenge! As for phase 1, no additional power is needed, the 4‐5MW required <br /><br />
for this phase is sufficient. Phase 2 will be the major challenge. We hope to be able to derive <br /><br />
energy from a renewable source, supplemented by fossil fuel, i.e., mixing thermal with hydro <br /><br />
energy. We do need an independent power provider.  <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
Qu: What is your plan for dealing with scrap metals? <br /><br />
Ans: Our mission is to mine iron ore and ship it oversees. We will be having no dealings with <br /><br />
scraps. <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
Qu: In the area of needs assessment for the affected communities, is mapping done to target <br /><br />
actual needs? <br /><br />
Ans: AML is at an exploratory stage, and this implies that needs met are those requested by the <br /><br />
communities.  Nonetheless,  the  company  intends  to  hold  consultative  meetings  with <br /><br />
community representatives, authorities and affected people when the need for mapping arises, <br /><br />
consequent upon AML is moving to the mining phase. <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
Qu: How do you classify the 10.1 billion tons of magnetite, measured or indicated? <br /><br />
Ans: The 10.1 billion tons of iron ore is an indicated and inferred resource. 80 million tons of <br /><br />
indicated  and  inferred  resource  have  been  registered  so  far.  The  classification  of  hematite  is <br /><br />
more complicated at this stage.   <br /><br />
   <br /><br />
Qu: Do you intend to register with indigenous insurance company? <br /><br />
Ans:  AML  plans  to  first seek  local  insurance  companies  and  we  look  forward  to  working  with <br /><br />
them.  <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
Qu:  If  you  accidentally  discover  other  minerals,  such  as  diamonds  or gold,  would you  include <br /><br />
their mining in your operations? <br /><br />
Ans: No diamonds have been found at any of the sites. There are small amounts of bauxite and <br /><br />
nickel, but our focus and operations will be exclusively in the mining and export of iron ore. We <br /><br />
have not found any gold either. <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
Qu: Since you would be trucking huge quantities of loose ore through communities, how would <br /><br />
you ensure that people will not be in danger of being affected by the dust particles in the air? <br /><br />
Ans: Measures will be put in place to minimize dust released into the atmosphere. The ore, for <br /><br />
starters,  will  be  wet,  and  there  will  also  be  wetting  of  roads.  The  road  trains  that  would  be <br /><br />
transporting mined materials from the mine at the Sula Mountains to Lunsar are huge vehicles, <br /><br />
which  makes  stopping  in  an  emergency  situation  very  difficult.  AML  will  sensitise  the <br /><br />
communities  of  the  transportation  process  and  the  dangers  involved.  There  will  be  sufficient <br /><br />
road and warning signs. <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
Qu: How about the environmental disasters that lurk in the dark, land reclamation, release of <br /><br />
toxic materials?  <br /><br />
Ans:  An  ESHIA  study  is  underway,  as  earlier  iterated  by  Mr  Andy  Huckbody.  All  details <br /><br />
pertaining  to  the  environment  will  be  addressed  by  the  reports  that  are  due  in  June  and <br /><br />
September, respectively. But we can safely say that no toxic chemicals will be employed in the <br /><br />
process plants producing magnetite. We anticipate no huge environmental risk resulting from <br /><br />
our  operations  as  health  and  safety  measures  have  been  put  in  place  in  the  conduct  of  our <br /><br />
operations.  <br /><br />
   <br /><br />
Qu: Under what category of license is AML operating? How do we ensure that AML will not be a <br /><br />
repeat of the National Diamond Mining Company?  <br /><br />
Ans:  AML  is  an  exploratory  company  as  at  yet.  There  will  be  no  unrealised  promises,  unlike <br /><br />
NDMC.  We  have  a  world  class  mineral  in  our  hands  and  so  much  to  offer.  We  are  guided  by <br /><br />
statutory rules and regulations by which we will strictly abide. An ESHIA study is going on right <br /><br />
now,  and  the  environmental  impacts  of  our  work  will  be  done  and  publicly  disclosed.  In  that <br /><br />
document, post operation activities such decommissioning and land reclamation plans will be <br /><br />
discussed.  <br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
Qu: How do you plan to raise money for such a massive operation? <br /><br />
Ans: The project has commenced with an early cash flow (ECF) that involves the initial mining of <br /><br />
the  hematite  that  overlies  the  magnetite  deposit  in  Tonkolili.  Following  the  construction  of  a <br /><br />
haul road from the mine site to Lunsar and the rehabilitation of the defunct Marampa‐Pepel rail <br /><br />
track,  the  hematite  will  be  transported  and  shipped  overseas.  Proceeds  from  this  project  will <br /><br />
help build the momentum for the second phase of the project, which is the mining and export <br /><br />
of  magnetite.  The  world  class  nature  of  the  magnetite  deposit  could  provide  a  basis  for <br /><br />
additional funding to be solicited. <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
Qu: Where would you obtain the water needed for your operations? <br /><br />
Ans:  The  water  requirement  for  Phase  1  is  minimal  and  is  adequately  met.  For  Phase  2,  150 <br /><br />
engineers are involved in the feasibility studies to ensure that water is available for the project <br /><br />
without any significant impact on other (downstream or riparian) users or the environment. <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
OTHER COMMENTS EMERGING FROM THE MEETING WORTH MENTIONING <br /><br />

Mr Andrew Keili (CEMMATS Group Ltd) <br /><br />

details  of  the  content  of  the  report  that  would  be  written  at  the  end  of  the  study:  the <br /><br />
Community Development Action plan (CDAP), the public disclosure plan, mine reclamation and <br /><br />

capacity  of  the  Sierra  Leone  Environmental  Protection  Agency  (SLEPA)  and  the  potential  for <br /><br />
AML  to  help  in  capacity  building  for  the  agency.  He  appeased  all  present  that  there  will  be <br /><br />
enough time for comments to be made on the ESHIA report. <br /><br />
Representative of the Civil Society <br /><br />
<br /><br />

 <br /><br />

Vote of Thanks by P.C. Bai Kurr from Masimgbe <br /><br />
He thanked AML for given everyone present an opportunity to hear about the progress made <br /><br />

PC expressed his excitement at the prospect of a world class mineral found in the country and <br /><br />
the implications for national revenue and employment.  <br /><br />

Tonkolili Iron Ore Project<br /><br />
Update and Overview<br /><br />
1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Introduction to AML<br /><br />
• African Minerals aims to create value through<br /><br />
exploration, discovery and development<br /><br />
• The Company holds an extensive portfolio of mineral<br /><br />
rights in Sierra Leone – actively investing since 2003<br /><br />
• Tonkolili iron ore project, 10.5 Bt of magnetite - the<br /><br />
world’s largest reported JORC compliant magnetite<br /><br />
resource<br /><br />
• Additional exploration has confirmed the potential for 500<br /><br />
Million tonnes of hematite mineralisation<br /><br />
• Currently have around 740 employees in Sierra Leone<br /><br />
• Expenditure to date circa $100m US<br /><br />
• International Year of Planet Earth Award December<br /><br />
2009<br /><br />

Phase 1 Process Description<br /><br />
• Mining<br /><br />
– Conventional truck and shovel mining method, drilling and<br /><br />
blasting<br /><br />
– Minimal beneficiation required to produce export grade hematite<br /><br />
– 8mtpa target tonnage<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• Road Transport<br /><br />
– Hauling of ore by road train trucks to Rogbom (near Lunsar)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• Rail Transport<br /><br />
– Transport of ore to Pepel along rail line<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• Shiploading and Export<br /><br />
– Loading of 50,000 DWT transhipment vessels<br /><br />
– Transhipment to 170,000 DWT vessels off shore<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
REPORT TITLE<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SYNOPSIS<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) is developing a new iron ore mine identified as the Tonkolili Iron Ore<br /><br />
mine in Sierra Leone on the west coast of Africa. The Project is planned to produce 45 Mtpa of iron<br /><br />
ore concentrate. WorleyParsons Europe has been engaged as the PMC Contractor to assist AML<br /><br />
with the definition of the project that will include a Definitive Feasibility Study report supported by<br /><br />
capital and operating costs.<br /><br />
This section of the document is to be updated by the originator as the responsible person to provide a<br /><br />
summary as to the key purpose of the report<br /><br />
NOTE: all red italic notes in this document template are for guidance only. Please delete them before<br /><br />
issuing the document.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

This report has been prepared on behalf of and for the exclusive use of African Minerals Limited,<br /><br />
and is subject to and issued in accordance with the agreement between African Minerals Limited<br /><br />
and WorleyParsons Services Pty Ltd. WorleyParsons Services Pty Ltd accepts no liability or<br /><br />
responsibility whatsoever for it in respect of any use of or reliance upon this report by any third<br /><br />
party.<br /><br />
Copying this report without the permission of African Minerals Limited or WorleyParsons Services<br /><br />
Pty Ltd is not permitted.<br /><br />

REPORT TITLE<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
INTRODUCTION<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
General<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This document presents an Environmental Management Plan (EMP) for the haul road element of the<br /><br />
Early Cash Flow Project and has been prepared following a request by the Sierra Leone<br /><br />
Environmental Protection Agency (SLEPA). The term EMP is used here as synonymous with<br /><br />
Environmental & Social Management Plan (ESMP), as the current international approach is to<br /><br />
prepare a management document that addresses both environmental and social issues during<br /><br />
construction and into operation.<br /><br />
This report builds on and extends the ‘Environmental and Social Management principles for haul<br /><br />
Road Development for ECF’, which was originally produced in February 2010 as guidance to AML for<br /><br />
use with haul road planning and implementation and the document was reproduced (as Appendix 13)<br /><br />
in the Haul Road Scoping Document issued 15 April 2010, which was sent to and reviewed by<br /><br />
SLEPA.<br /><br />
The report cited above contains many elements of an Environmental Management Plan and was<br /><br />
produced in advance of completion of the ESHIA for the Early Cash Flow (ECF) project, as an<br /><br />
environmental management response to early works implementation. It was informed by the early<br /><br />
scoping of potential issues associated with haul road design and construction and much of it is still<br /><br />
valid and appropriate at this stage in the development of the haul road. Consequently, much of the<br /><br />
content is common to the EMP presented in this document.<br /><br />
Since the design of the haul road is still ongoing it is not possible at this stage to finalise all the<br /><br />
potential environmental or social effects, therefore the present report is preliminary and will be a<br /><br />
living document, which will be updated periodically in line with the design and potential effects as they<br /><br />
arise.<br /><br />
The need for preparation of specific EMPs for individual project infrastructure components has not yet<br /><br />
been determined and in fact it is envisaged that an ESHIA will be prepared for the ECF project as a<br /><br />
whole and will include an EMP or ESMP, to describe the management of potential impacts and the<br /><br />
delivery of mitigation for environmental and social issues. This particular EMP has been requested to<br /><br />
cover only the haul road and it must be considered as a part of an ongoing ESHIA process for ECF<br /><br />
and Tonkolili and is therefore not ‘stand alone’, but part of a larger project and process. This is<br /><br />
particularly the case for many of the social elements, which are addressed through a range of<br /><br />
initiatives, such as Social Impact Assessment, Resettlement Policy Framework, Resettlement Action<br /><br />
Plan, Stakeholder Engagement Plan (equivalent to a Public Consultation and Disclosure Plan) – all<br /><br />
associated with the main Tonkolili project. In addition, there are some initiatives for the ECF, which<br /><br />
include the Early Works Chiefdom Committees (EWCC); see later in this document.<br /><br />
The social aspects for the haul road alone are being addressed in a separate document, specifically<br /><br />
requested by SLEPA, namely a Community Development Action Plan (CDAP). The CDAP should be<br /><br />
referred to for the latest update on the status of community initiatives, such as ongoing community<br /><br />
consultation and community development actions.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
document3<br /><br />
Page 1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
305000-00006 : Document NumberRev A : 6/1/2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
REPORT TITLE<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Objective of the EMP<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The objective of the EMP is to ensure that any potentially negative environmental and social impacts<br /><br />
during construction are kept at an acceptable level. It sets out to ensure that all aspects of the works<br /><br />
comply with the relevant legislation and good practice, and that measures to mitigate impacts<br /><br />
identified in the scoping documents are implemented. An EMP implements appropriate environmental<br /><br />
controls and monitoring procedures during construction and after the work is completed. An EMP (or<br /><br />
ESMP) is normally produced towards the end of an ESHIA process, when potential impacts and their<br /><br />
mitigation have been determined. In this case it has been prepared in a very short timescale at the<br /><br />
request of SLEPA, specifically for the haul road and has consequently not had the benefit of the rest<br /><br />
of the ESHIA process. It has therefore been informed by the scoping of potential issues that has been<br /><br />
undertaken for the haul road and in-country knowledge and experience of the consultants.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project Description<br /><br />
<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) is developing a new iron ore mine identified as the Tonkolili Iron Ore<br /><br />
mine in Sierra Leone on the west coast of Africa. The Project is planned to produce 45 Mtpa of<br /><br />
magnetite concentrate with a grade containing not less than 69% iron (Fe) and less than 3% silica<br /><br />
(SiO2)with a minimum particle size (P80) of 38 micron, from a resource deposit identified containing<br /><br />
5.1 billion tonnes of recoverable ore.<br /><br />
The mine project area is located approximately 200 km east of Freetown, the capital city of Sierra<br /><br />
Leone.<br /><br />
The project will comprise the mine and process plant facilities supported by a rail network to transfer<br /><br />
the concentrate product to the stockyards and handling facilities at the port area which is located at<br /><br />
Tagrin Point adjacent to Lungi airport to the north of Freetown.<br /><br />
Three ore bodies have been identified for production; Simbili, Marampon and Numbara. It is<br /><br />
envisaged that staged development will be undertaken dependent on the exploration activities which<br /><br />
are currently underway, to maximize the return on the investment. It is likely that additional ore bodies<br /><br />
will subsequently be developed as the understanding of the geological conditions and the mine<br /><br />
reserves mature.<br /><br />
To commercialise the Tonkolili Resource, AML will execute an integrated greenfield development<br /><br />
through the construction of new facilities which include:<br /><br />
 A new mine and ore processing plant at Tonkolili, to produce 45 Mtpa of magnetite<br /><br />
concentrate;<br /><br />
 Approximately 200 km of new standard gauge, heavy haul railway from Tonkolili to Tagrin<br /><br />
Point;<br /><br />
 A new deepwater port and associated infrastructure at Tagrin Point suitable for loading vessels<br /><br />
up to Cape size for the export of 45 Mtpa magnetite concentrate; and,<br /><br />
 All associated support infrastructure to deliver and operate the project safely and successfully.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
document3<br /><br />
Page 2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
305000-00006 : Document NumberRev A : 6/1/2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
REPORT TITLE<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
At the mine, the project development will comprise an open cut mine, ROM pad, the minerals<br /><br />
processing facilities and support infrastructure such as power, water, access roads, air terminal,<br /><br />
accommodation facilities, workshops, warehouses, laboratories and administration buildings and train<br /><br />
loading facility.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Location<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The following figure provides an indication of the mine site location relative to the coast and the<br /><br />
borders with Guinea and Liberia. The mine site at Tonkolili is approximately 200km ENE of the capital<br /><br />
of Freetown and the port location at Tagrin Point.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
INTRODUCTION<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
General<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This document presents a Community Development Action Plan (CDAP) for the haul road element of<br /><br />
the Early Cash Flow Project and has been prepared following a request by the Sierra Leone<br /><br />
Environmental Protection Agency (SLEPA).<br /><br />
This report builds on the ‘Haul Road Scoping Report’ issued 15 April 2010, which was sent to and<br /><br />
reviewed by SLEPA.<br /><br />
The report cited above sets out the consultation mechanism established through discussions with<br /><br />
local authorities (District Councils and Paramount Chiefs) to address social issues related to the Early<br /><br />
Cash Flow (ECF) project as a social management response to early works implementation. .<br /><br />
Since the consultation process for this component of the ECF program is still ongoing it is not<br /><br />
possible at this stage to finalise all the issues that would normally feature conclusively in a document<br /><br />
of this nature. Furthermore, this report is preliminary and will be a living document, which will be<br /><br />
updated periodically in line with ongoing consultation and adoption the outcomes as they arise.<br /><br />
The need for preparation of a specific CDAP for the haul road has been brought by SLEPA. Broader<br /><br />
community development issues will need to be considered at the appropriate time to cover the<br /><br />
Tonkolili phase of the Project so this CDAP is therefore not ‘stand alone’, but part of a larger project<br /><br />
and process. This is particularly the case for many of the social elements, which are addressed<br /><br />
through a range of initiatives, such as Social Impact Assessment, Resettlement Policy Framework,<br /><br />
Resettlement Action Plan, Stakeholder Engagement Plan – all associated with the main Tonkolili<br /><br />
project. In addition, there are some initiatives for the ECF, which include the Early Works Chiefdom<br /><br />
Committees (EWCC); see later in this document.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Scope of the CDAP<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The scope of this CDAP is to identify assistance methodology that the haul road project will provide to<br /><br />
local and affected communities in compliance with local legislation and define how AML will extend<br /><br />
such assistance beyond compliance. In many cases these additional measures are associated with<br /><br />
the need to deal with impacts that the haul road may have from both a social and environmental<br /><br />
perspective.<br /><br />
The CDAP sets out to ensure that programs are established to enhance socio-economic development<br /><br />
and in the process mitigate impacts identified in the scoping documents. It also helps to focus project<br /><br />
resources on stakeholder agreed deliverables which assist the proponents planning and<br /><br />
implementation process. To achieve this level of stakeholder participation a CDAP is normally<br /><br />
produced towards the end of an ESHIA process, when potential impacts and their mitigation have<br /><br />
been determined. In this case it has been prepared in a very short timescale at the request of SLEPA,<br /><br />
specifically for the haul road and has consequently not had the benefit of the rest of the ESHIA<br /><br />
<br /><br />

of Freetown and the port location at Tagrin Point.<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
HAUL ROAD SCOPING REPORT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SYNOPSIS<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) is developing a new iron ore mine identified as the Tonkolili Iron Ore<br /><br />
mine in Sierra Leone on the west coast of Africa. The Project is planned to produce 45 Mtpa of iron<br /><br />
ore concentrate. WorleyParsons Europe has been engaged as the PMC Contractor to assist AML<br /><br />
with the definition of the project that will include a Definitive Feasibility Study report supported by<br /><br />
capital and operating costs. In addition WorleyParsons are responsible for preparing an<br /><br />
Environmental, Social and Health Impact Assessment for the project.<br /><br />
This document represents a scoping report covering one element (the haul road) of the project. The<br /><br />
report is intended to provide sufficient information on this element so that appropriate terms of<br /><br />
reference for the ESHIA study can be defined and the full ESHIA can be successfully implemented.<br /><br />
Disclaimer<br /><br />
This report has been prepared on behalf of and for the exclusive use of African Minerals Limited,<br /><br />
and is subject to and issued in accordance with the agreement between African Minerals Limited<br /><br />
and WorleyParsons Services Pty Ltd. WorleyParsons Services Pty Ltd accepts no liability or<br /><br />
responsibility whatsoever for it in respect of any use of or reliance upon this report by any third<br /><br />
party.<br /><br />
Copying this report without the permission of African Minerals Limited or WorleyParsons Services<br /><br />
Pty Ltd is not permitted.<br /><br />
The following sections of this report have been prepared by our project partners SRK:. Ecology<br /><br />
and biodiversity, Soils and land-use, Geology and geomorphology and Socio-economic<br /><br />
environment. SRK maintain that while the standard of work has been completed with<br /><br />
consideration of in-country requirements and relevant international standards and guidelines. The<br /><br />
scope of the work is limited geographically and / or in terms of level of detail and therefore the<br /><br />
work reported does not meet the criteria for a baseline study. This work is considered to only be<br /><br />
the starting point for baseline characterisation for the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project. SRK and its subconsultants considered that significant supplementary work is required taking cognisance of<br /><br />
seasonal variations (as a minimum 12 months) is required to fulfil international requirements for a<br /><br />
baseline study.<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
HAUL ROAD SCOPING REPORT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY<br /><br />
This document has been prepared at the request of the Sierra Leone Environmental Protection<br /><br />
Agency (EPA) and serves to provide additional information on the potential environmental and social<br /><br />
effects associated with the proposed Haul Road which is part of the Early Cash Flow component of<br /><br />
the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project. This report must be viewed within the context of the overall<br /><br />
Environmental, Social and Health Impact Assessment (ESHIA) process which is underway for the<br /><br />
Tonkolili project as a whole.<br /><br />
To date, the Tonkolili ESHIA process has undergone the following procedural steps:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A screening stage was undertaken in February 2010 during which a project screening form,<br /><br />
compliant to in-country procedures was submitted to the EPA. This provides information on<br /><br />
the project and potential Environment & Social issues.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Following this, agreement was sought with the EPA on the terms of reference for the ESHIA<br /><br />
study. A report submitted to the EPA in March 2010, in the form of a discussion document<br /><br />
which set out a proposed plan describing the area of interest of the project and the<br /><br />
methodology and type of study work that could be undertaken. The discussion document<br /><br />
contained a considerable amount of information on the approach to the ESHIA, including<br /><br />
scopes of work for the various specialist studies, examples of rapid assessment surveys and<br /><br />
information on the location and preliminary design of key project facilities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Further to this discussion document, it was agreed that a specific scoping report should be<br /><br />
produced for the haul road which represents a fast-track project element. The scoping report<br /><br />
(this document) would comprise an element of a larger scoping process that would<br /><br />
encompass the entire Tonkolili project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Section 1 of this report provides an introduction; section 2 gives definitions and abbreviations; section<br /><br />
3 lists referenced documents; section 4 provides a project description; section 5 outlines relevant<br /><br />
legislation; section 6 gives information on baseline conditions, but not full information, as this is only a<br /><br />
scoping document; sections 7 and 8 give information on the potential impacts and preliminary<br /><br />
mitigation that can be identified at this early stage in the assessment process, commensurate with the<br /><br />
early level of design information and route selection available to date.<br /><br />
In recognition of the dynamic phasing of the project, driven by investment processes and other<br /><br />
factors, it is envisaged that the EPA and other authorities can work together with the project as formal<br /><br />
stakeholders, with formal permissions being issued in parallel with the implementation of the enabling<br /><br />
works of the ECF.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
HAUL ROAD SCOPING REPORT<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
INTRODUCTION<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This document has been prepared at the request of the Sierra Leone Environmental Protection<br /><br />
Agency (EPA) and serves to provide additional information on the potential environmental and social<br /><br />
effects associated with the proposed Haul Road which is part of the Early Cash Flow component of<br /><br />
the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project. This report must be viewed within the context of the overall ESHIA<br /><br />
process which is underway for the entire Tonkolili project. Similarly, many of the baseline surveys<br /><br />
and scoping of potential impacts have been focused on either the ECF or the Tonkolili project<br /><br />
as a whole and given the very short notice for preparation of this scoping report it is not<br /><br />
feasible in all cases to dis-aggregate data and present aspects specifically for the haul road<br /><br />
alone.<br /><br />
The document presents a scoping of Environmental, Social and Health issues associated with the<br /><br />
Haul Road, which is one component of the Early Cash Flow (ECF) works, which are considered as<br /><br />
enabling works for the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project.<br /><br />
Conventionally a scoping document is prepared as part of the overall Environmental, Social and<br /><br />
Health Impact Assessment (ESHIA) process for a major project, leading on to agreement of the<br /><br />
issues to be addressed in the ESHIA (terms of reference) and then evaluation of potential impacts<br /><br />
and development of mitigation and reporting and approvals. In this case a scoping document for the<br /><br />
overall Tonkolili project is underway and is due to be presented to AML and then EPA at the end of<br /><br />
April 2010. This follows on from submission of the Screening Form for the project to EPA in February<br /><br />
2010. The Screening Form submission triggers screening by EPA and agreement of the terms of<br /><br />
reference for the ESHIA study.<br /><br />
The Screening Form was followed in March 2010 by submission of a discussion document to the EPA<br /><br />
that contained a considerable amount of information on the approach to the ESHIA, including scopes<br /><br />
of work for the various specialist studies, examples of rapid assessment surveys and information on<br /><br />
the location and preliminary design of key project facilities.<br /><br />
As part of the discussion document it was suggested that an ESHIA report for the ECF component<br /><br />
could be submitted to AML and EPA, with ESHIA studies and reports to follow for Tonkolili later in the<br /><br />
year.<br /><br />
The haul road is to be constructed to link the mine site at Tonkolili with the refurbished railway line<br /><br />
that runs to Pepel Port. The haul road is intended to connect to a railhead that will be located in<br /><br />
Lunsar. In view of the dynamics of the project and in particular the ECF works, the route selection of<br /><br />
the haul road (‘alignment’) is still being designed. An initial alignment has been determined in<br /><br />
principle using a constraints analysis that incorporates topography, maximum road curvature, ground<br /><br />
conditions as well as social and environmental constraints. The procedure being implemented is that<br /><br />
a scout or survey track is being cleared at ca. 6m width, which will allow surveyors good access and<br /><br />
enable ground conditions to be assessed, following which the final alignment and eventual widening<br /><br />
will take place.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
A range of environmental and social (E&S) studies have been undertaken covering the haul road<br /><br />
alignment, some of which are still ongoing. In addition, several baseline studies have either been<br /><br />
completed or are ongoing which cover large parts of the ECF and Tonkolili study areas. These<br /><br />
studies have been carried out together where the transport corridor from the mine site towards Lunsar<br /><br />
area is common to both ECF and Tonkolili and the haul road lies entirely within this wider common<br /><br />
transport corridor.<br /><br />
In recognition of the dynamic phasing of the project, driven by investment processes and other<br /><br />
factors, it is envisaged that the EPA and other authorities can work together with the project as formal<br /><br />
stakeholders, with formal permissions being issued in parallel with the implementation of the enabling<br /><br />
works of the ECF.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Tonkolili Scoping Introduction<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This section provides the context of the haul road in relation to the overall approach of the ESHIA<br /><br />
process, of which the haul road and its scoping is but one component. The full scoping for the overall<br /><br />
Tonkolili project is nearing completion and is due to be submitted to AML and EPA at the end of April<br /><br />
2010.<br /><br />
A project-wide Scoping report in currently in preparation to provide the following:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A description of the scope of works;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The basis for the full terms of reference of the ESHIA;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
An overview of potential environmental impacts and early identification of environmental and<br /><br />
social risks that can be identified at this stage associated with the Tonkolili project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This report also covers the above requirements for the Early Cash Flow (ECF) project. The scoping<br /><br />
report follows on from the Screening Form that was completed and submitted to EPA in February<br /><br />
2010, as per in-country procedures.<br /><br />
The main Tonkolili Iron project will consist of open cast mining, transportation of concentrate by rail to<br /><br />
a port at Tagrin Point, near the mouth of the Sierra Leone River Estuary. The ECF project involves<br /><br />
mining of the hematite cap overlying the magnetite deposit and transporting the product via dedicated<br /><br />
haul road and refurbished railway to Pepel Port. In the report the Tonkolili project is segregated into<br /><br />
four elements: Mining Area, Transport Corridor, Port Facilities and Offshore. The elements that<br /><br />
constitute the ECF project are dealt with separately.<br /><br />
The report identifies relevant legislation and institutional bodies, provides a description of the existing<br /><br />
environment within the project area, an overview of potential impacts, and scope of works and<br /><br />
methodology for the development of the ECF ESIA and the Tonkolili ESHIA. The document outlines<br /><br />
the topics that will be covered and how each topic will be assessed in future works, including the<br /><br />
preparation of an implementation strategy of environmental and social baseline programs and a<br /><br />
regulatory schedule.<br /><br />
This report will feed into and inform the ongoing Project design and will also form a common basis for<br /><br />
consultation on the scope and methodology for the ESHIA process. The report outlines the future<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
DEFINITIONS AND ABBREVIATIONS<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.1.1 General Definitions<br /><br />
The Tonkolili Project – Tonkolili Iron Ore Project is the open pit mining operation and transportation of<br /><br />
concentrate by rail to a newly developed port at Tagrin Point from which it is loaded out to global<br /><br />
markets.<br /><br />
The convention used in this report for describing location along the haul road (the ‘chainage’)<br /><br />
assumes that ‘Km 0’ is at the western end near Lunsar whilst Km 122 terminates at the mine site.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
PROJECT DESCRIPTION<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.1 Project Overview<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) has been exploring an extensive magnetic anomaly in the Sula<br /><br />
Mountain range in Sierra Leone and in 2009 confirmed the presence of a world-class magnetite iron<br /><br />
ore deposit. The mine project area is located approximately 200 km east of Freetown, the capital city<br /><br />
of Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
The Tonkolili Project focuses on the three magnetite banded iron formation (BIF) targets that occur in<br /><br />
the southern portion of the northeast – southwest trending anomaly. These deposits are named<br /><br />
Simbili, Marampon and Numbara and the current combined ore estimate is 5.1 billion tonnes.<br /><br />
Exploration to date also indicates that the Simbili-Marampon-Numbara magnetite anomaly is overlain<br /><br />
with a hematite deposit, estimated to be in the order of 800 million tonnes.<br /><br />
To commercialise the Tonkolili Resource, AML will execute an integrated greenfield development<br /><br />
through the construction of new facilities which include:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A new mine and ore processing plant at Tonkolili, to produce 45 Mtpa of magnetite<br /><br />
concentrate;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Approximately 200km of new standard gauge, heavy haul railway from Tonkolili to Tagrin<br /><br />
Point,<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A new deepwater port and associated infrastructure at Tagrin Point suitable for loading Cape<br /><br />
size vessels for the export of 45 Mtpa of magnetite concentrate; and,<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
All associated support infrastructure to deliver and operate the project safely and<br /><br />
successfully.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In addition to the proposed Tagrin Point port, AML has signed a 99 year lease agreement with the<br /><br />
Government of Sierra Leone (GoSL) to reconstruct, manage and operate Pepel Port and the Pepel –<br /><br />
Marampa Railway. AML is working toward mining hematite ore found in the Tonkolili deposits during<br /><br />
the initial stages of the project and exporting the product via Pepel Port. A dedicated haul road<br /><br />
(approximately 120 km in length) will be built from the mine site to a railhead near Lunsar and the<br /><br />
existing railway line refurbished between Marampa and Pepel while the Tagrin Point export route<br /><br />
infrastructure is under construction. These works form what is referred to as the Early Cash Flow<br /><br />
(ECF) project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.2 Location<br /><br />
The following figure provides an indication of the mine site location relative to the coast and the<br /><br />
borders with Guinea and Liberia. The mine site at Tonkolili is approximately 200km ENE of the capital<br /><br />
of Freetown and the port location at Tagrin Point.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Figure 4-1: Overview Location Map showing the Haul Road Alignment<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.3 Early Cash Flow (ECF) Project<br /><br />
The principal elements of the ECF project are described below:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mining Area - hematite deposits from the ECF project are located along the crown of the<br /><br />
Simbili formation. Supporting mine infrastructure, accommodation facilities and mining plant<br /><br />
will be located in the Mawuru and Tonkolili valleys south of Simbili.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Transport Corridor – a haul road is under construction from the mine site to Lunsar<br /><br />
(approximately 120 km). Ore is then transported by narrow-gauge rail transport to Pepel<br /><br />
along the same rail trace as occupied by the original Delco rail line;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Port Facilities – ore will be exported from Pepel port using a combination of new facilities for a<br /><br />
rail dumper, ore handling and stockpiling and the wharf interface including refurbishment of<br /><br />
the existing ship-loading jetty, fuelling jetty and fuel farm and power house.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Offshore – the base-case option assumes panamax sized shipping will berth and be loaded<br /><br />
from the primary Pepel jetty.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

4 .3 .1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
ECF Pro jec t sta tus<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In view of the seasonal constraints of working on earthworks during the wet season, work has<br /><br />
commenced on the haul road in March 2010. Minor refurbishment works to buildings have<br /><br />
commenced in the Pepel port compound, using locally recruited and specifically trained labour.<br /><br />
In late January development work on the mine haul road (specifically vegetation clearing in some of<br /><br />
the easement / Right of Way (ROW)) commenced in the eastern reaches of the haul road adjacent to<br /><br />
the mine.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.4 Haul Road<br /><br />
The ECF project will transport iron ore using a 122.6 km long haul road built from the mine site to a<br /><br />
railhead near Lunsar. The haul road commences about 8Km North-West of Lunsar (where it ties in<br /><br />
with the existing railway which is to be refurbished) and extends about 122Km to the mine at Tonkolili.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
SYNOPSIS<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) is developing a new iron ore mine identified as the Tonkolili Iron Ore<br /><br />
mine in Sierra Leone on the west coast of Africa. The Project is planned to produce 45 Mtpa of iron<br /><br />
ore concentrate. WorleyParsons Europe has been engaged as the PMC Contractor to assist AML<br /><br />
with the definition of the project that will include a Definitive Feasibility Study report supported by<br /><br />
capital and operating costs.<br /><br />
This ESIA scoping document has been prepared to facilitate discussions of the ESIA deliverables<br /><br />
with EPA.<br /><br />
Disclaimer<br /><br />
This report has been prepared on behalf of and for the exclusive use of African Minerals Limited, and<br /><br />
is subject to and issued in accordance with the agreement between African Minerals Limited and<br /><br />
WorleyParsons Services Pty Ltd. WorleyParsons Services Pty Ltd accepts no liability or<br /><br />
responsibility whatsoever for it in respect of any use of or reliance upon this plan by any third party.<br /><br />
Copying this plan without the permission of African Minerals Limited or WorleyParsons Services Pty<br /><br />
Ltd is not permitted.<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
REPORT NAME<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
INTRODUCTION<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Background<br /><br />
<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) has been exploring an extensive magnetic anomaly in the Sula<br /><br />
Mountain range in Sierra Leone and recently confirmed the presence of a world-class magnetite iron<br /><br />
ore deposit. The Tonkolili Project focuses on the three magnetite banded iron formation (BIF) targets<br /><br />
that occur in the southern portion of the northeast – southwest trending anomaly.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Purpose of this document<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Tonkolili project requires an EIA or ESIA (hereinafter referred to as an Environmental, Social,<br /><br />
Health Impact Assessment, ESHIA), as it constitutes a Category A project, requiring ESHIA. The<br /><br />
Screening Form required by the EPA has been completed and submitted to EPA in February 2010,<br /><br />
as per in-country procedures. The process is that the EPA agrees with the project proponent a terms<br /><br />
of reference for the ESHIA, prior to completing the studies. In the case of Tonkolili, there is a need for<br /><br />
advanced or enabling works which centre on extracting hematite from a deposit overlying the<br /><br />
magnetite deposit. These works are termed the Early Cash Flow (ECF) component. In addition, the<br /><br />
ECF component requires advanced construction of a new haul road prior to start of the wet season.<br /><br />
In recognition of the fast moving nature of the project, it is necessary to establish a programme of<br /><br />
ESHIA deliverables in line with implementation of the early components of the project. This<br /><br />
‘Regulatory Road Map’ is required to be agreed with the Government of Sierra Leone (GoSL) and<br /><br />
specifically with the EPA, as competent authority and lead agency in environmental and social<br /><br />
management planning. This document presents details of the project and its implementation, along<br /><br />
with details of the scopes of work for the various elements of the ESHIA and their status and should<br /><br />
be of use during discussions regarding ESHIA.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project Description<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.3.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The project<br /><br />
<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) has been exploring an extensive magnetic anomaly in the Sula<br /><br />
Mountain range in Sierra Leone and recently confirmed the presence of a world-class magnetite iron<br /><br />
ore deposit. The Tonkolili Project focuses on the three magnetite banded iron formation (BIF) targets<br /><br />
that occur in the southern portion of the northeast – southwest trending anomaly. These deposits are<br /><br />
named Simbili, Marampon and Numbara and are illustrated in Figure 1 below. The current combined<br /><br />
ore estimate is 5.1 billion tonnes. Exploration to date also indicates that the Simbili-MaramponNumbara magnetite anomaly is overlain with a hematite deposit, estimated to be in the order of 800<br /><br />
million tonnes.<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
REPORT NAME<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 1 Project deposits<br /><br />
The Project will consist of mining operations with an ore-production rate of about 167 million tonnes /<br /><br />
year and a total material movement in the order of 270 million tonnes / year. A concentrate will be<br /><br />
produced on site at a rate of about 45 million tonnes / year. The life of the mine is expected to be in<br /><br />
excess of 50 years at these production rates. The feasibility of increased production will be subject to<br /><br />
studies in subsequent phases of project development.<br /><br />
Mining will be open cast method and will produce a concentrate to be transported by rail to a port at<br /><br />
Tagrin Point, near the mouth of the Sierra Leone River Estuary. Rail infrastructure will be required to<br /><br />
link Tonkolili with Tagrin Point (a distance of ca. 200 km). The proposed port facility will be a deep<br /><br />
water port comprising a causeway, trestle and berths located between 700-800 m offshore. The<br /><br />
location of the Tonkolili Project facilities is shown in Figure 2 and preliminary, indicative designs are<br /><br />
presented in Appendix A.<br /><br />
In addition to the proposed Tagrin Point port, AML has signed a 99 year lease agreement with the<br /><br />
Government of Sierra Leone (GoSL) to reconstruct, manage and operate Pepel Port and the Pepel –<br /><br />
Marampa Railway. AML is working toward mining hematite ore found in the Tonkolili deposits during<br /><br />

accommodation facilities, workshops, warehouses, laboratories and administration buildings and train<br /><br />
loading facility.<br /><br />

REPORT NAME<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.3.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Early cash flow<br /><br />
<br /><br />
As described earlier there is a need to undertake advanced works for the overall Tonkolili project,<br /><br />
comprising a haul road, refurbishment of Pepel railway line and refurbishment of Pepel Port. In view<br /><br />
of the seasonal constraints of working on earthworks during the wet season, work has commenced<br /><br />
on the haul road in March 2010. Minor refurbishment works to buildings have commenced in the<br /><br />
Pepel port compound, using locally recruited and specifically trained labour.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
EIA PROCEDURES<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
EIA legislation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
As part of the ongoing studies WorleyParsons has undertaken a review of relevant legislation in the<br /><br />
country and has also undertaken a gap analysis as part of the Environmental Basis of Design Study,<br /><br />
which informs engineering designs for process plants, water treatment and equipment procurement.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project ESHIA deliverables<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The following deliverables are suggested as to the way forward.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Time line<br /><br />
April 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
June 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
September 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
DFS<br /><br />
<br /><br />
ECF ESHIA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Tonkolili ESHIA (preliminary)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Scoping study<br /><br />
The Definitive Feasibility Study for the Tonkolili Project will cover all aspects of the project<br /><br />
(engineering, mine processing, cost etc) and the Environmental and Social Scoping Study will cover<br /><br />
baseline conditions and identification of issues and potential impacts identified from the work to date.<br /><br />
It is suggested that the ESHIA for the ECF component is brought forward to around June, to allow<br /><br />
evaluation and consideration by EPA. There is a final deliverable (under WorleyParsons current<br /><br />
arrangements with AML) of a preliminary ESHIA for Tonkolili Project as a whole, as part of FEED.<br /><br />

ESHIA SCOPE OF WORK<br /><br />

3.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project Schedule<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Please see attached chart in Appendix C<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Descriptions of thematic studies<br /><br />
<br /><br />
As shown on the Gant chart a range of environmental and social investigations are currently<br /><br />
underway, with a view of obtaining baseline conditions, potential impacts associated with the project<br /><br />
and ultimately mitigation where necessary. The studies are outlined below, comprising air and noise,<br /><br />
ecology (marine, flora and fauna), hydrobiology, social, health, water and soils.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Environmental Studies<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.3.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Air and Noise<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AIR<br /><br />
B AS E L I N E M E T H O D S T AT E M E N T<br /><br />
The scope of this initial monitoring campaign is to obtain background data on air quality in the project<br /><br />
area. The sampling will be conducted with passive monitoring devices (diffusion tubes to be installed<br /><br />
in the field for a period of 15 days, collected and sent to the laboratory for analysis) due to their the<br /><br />
lower cost compared with active sampling devices (complex analysers with an active air intake and<br /><br />
internal pollutant monitoring).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SCOPE<br /><br />
Nitrogen Oxides (NOx) and Sulphur Dioxide (SO2) will be monitored during this first air monitoring<br /><br />
campaign. Although it would be convenient to simultaneously monitor Particulate Matter (PM2.5 and<br /><br />
PM10), commercial passive particulate matter monitoring devices are not currently available.<br /><br />
Consequently, the monitoring of particulate matter will be conducted during future monitoring<br /><br />
campaigns using experimental passive devices or commercial active devices.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
METHOD OF ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
Ambient air measurements will be conducted using passive diffusion tubes to measure sulphur<br /><br />
dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2). For passive sampling, the use of diffusion sampling tubes<br /><br />

<br /><br />

REPORT NAME<br /><br />
<br /><br />
is recommended due to their low cost, their ease of use and their utility for baseline and screening<br /><br />
studies. Appropriate diffusion tubes will be obtained from Scientifics laboratory in the UK. Each tube<br /><br />
has a unique identification number to aide in tracking.<br /><br />
If possible, the diffusion tubes will be exposed for the preferable period of two (2) weeks (15 days),<br /><br />
which represents the minimum required period by the European Union for air quality monitoring. In<br /><br />
the case that the 15-day exposure is not possible, a minimum period of one (1) week will be used. All<br /><br />
diffusion tubes will be collected and returned to the laboratory, accompanied by completed and<br /><br />
signed chain-of-custody forms.<br /><br />
For QA/QC purposes, one travel blank will be included in the measurements to assess exposure of<br /><br />
the tubes to contaminants during transport.<br /><br />
Additionally, the following actions shall be undertaken:<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The coordinates of the locations will be noted using GPS hand-held kits.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Photographs of the monitoring locations shall be taken.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Notations shall be made of any activity or contaminant source in the surroundings of the<br /><br />
selected locations during the monitoring campaign.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The date and hour of installation and removal of the tubes will be clearly noted.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Pertinent meteorological and climatological information may be obtained from the local<br /><br />
weather department to support the interpretation of the data from the monitoring campaign<br /><br />
and the assessment of the pollution potential of the area.<br /><br />

For the installation of the passive diffusion tubes, the following recommendations, which are included<br /><br />
in the ASTM Standards relative to Air Sampling, should be considered:<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The individually numbered diffusion-sampling tubes shall be placed at a minimum height of<br /><br />
1.5 m above ground and in sites where land use, topography and meteorology are preferably<br /><br />
common and representative of the regional area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The specific monitoring locations shall be selected so as to avoid undue influence by any<br /><br />
local source that may cause local elevated concentrations that are not representative of the<br /><br />
project area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Particulate Matter samplers (for future monitoring campaigns) shall be sited at locations that<br /><br />
are greater than 200 m from unpaved streets or roads.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Monitoring sites shall be located away from population centres. A recommended distance of<br /><br />
1 km per 1000 persons.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The passive diffusion tubes shall be placed no closer than 100 metres from intensive<br /><br />
agricultural, waste treatment activities, open or surface storage of agricultural or industrial<br /><br />
products, and transportation related sources of emissions. This distance shall be increased in<br /><br />
proportion to increases in traffic volume and diversity.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Prominent discontinuities in terrain, such as large bodies of water, isolated hills or valleys and<br /><br />
cliffs shall be located at least 5 km from the diffusion tubes.<br /><br />

305000-00006 : Rev A : 9-3-2010<br /><br />

AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
REPORT NAME<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 Mine: six positions surrounding the projected mine site.<br /><br />
These locations will coincide with the locations selected for the air quality sampling programme, as<br /><br />
they are considered to be representative and will facilitate the monitoring campaign.<br /><br />
Two measures will be taken at each position to assure that a noise event (e.g., animal sounds or<br /><br />
vehicle movements) do not invalidate the results. The total number of noise measurements will be<br /><br />
forty (40).<br /><br />
The duration of the measurements will be five (5) minutes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
METHOD OF ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
A Class II hand-held sound level meter and ISO Tech sound level calibrator will be used to conduct<br /><br />
the noise survey. The readings acquired from the sound meter will be analysed and compared to<br /><br />
relevant guidelines and set as the baseline for reference during further monitoring activities.<br /><br />
The sound level meter will measure the parameter LAeq, defined as the constant sound level that, in<br /><br />
a given time period, would convey the same sound energy as the actual time-varying A-weighted<br /><br />
sound level.<br /><br />
Some factors need to be taken into account when taking measurements to assure the quality of the<br /><br />
results since sound levels vary as a function of height above ground level and can be perturbed<br /><br />
depending on the distance between the point of measurement and facades or obstacles. These<br /><br />
requirements must be noted and applied by taking measurements:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Away from facades and other obstacles at a minimum distance of 1.5 meters;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Away from noise sources;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Downwind;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Utilising a sound level meter with an anti-wind protection (normally provided by the supplier).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In dry conditions with a wind speed of less than 5 m/s.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 With the microphone 1.2 - 1.5 m above ground level.<br /><br />
Based on the screening results, the following monitoring campaign will be designed.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Measurement procedure used<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Calculations used<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Prevailing conditions<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Atmospheric conditions (wind direction and speed, rain, temperature, atmospheric pressure,<br /><br />
humidity)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Nature/state of ground between source and receiver<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Source variability<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Calibration data<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Measurement date, start and stop time<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Number of measurements made<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 Description of the sound sources under investigation<br /><br />
It is also advisable to include additional information, such as:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The purpose of the measurement<br /><br />

3.3.2<br /><br />

Marine ecosystem<br /><br />

PRECEDING WORKS<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This work builds on a previous study conducted in 2009 (LORAX, 2010) which comprised a rapid<br /><br />
overview of the main physical, chemical and ecological characteristics of the Estuary. This survey<br /><br />
has enabled at least one wet-season monitoring event to be completed before the current phase of<br /><br />
work.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
B AS E L I N E M E T H O D S T AT E M E N T<br /><br />
We are following the overarching methodology of desk based 1a through to data collection 2b. In<br /><br />
addition, to providing a broad understanding of the existing marine environment, the specific aims of<br /><br />
the baseline are:<br /><br />
 Mapping of key marine and coastal habitats<br /><br />
 To identify any existing impacts, for example contamination, and to understand how the<br /><br />
environment has reacted<br /><br />
 Provide a baseline for monitoring through the project life cycle<br /><br />
The marine baseline covers all habitats up to high water plus any species that are marine in origin<br /><br />
e.g. that inhabit the mangroves.<br /><br />

o Physico-chemical<br /><br />
o In-fauna<br /><br />

In addition to the survey methods discussed above a range of methods will be used to assess<br /><br />

3.3.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Flora<br /><br />
<br /><br />
PRECEDING WORKS<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This work builds on previous studies conducted under licence within Sierra Leone comprising a desktop review of the Simbili-Marampon-Numbara habitat areas with rapid reconnaissance of the<br /><br />
surrounding areas (phases 1a and 1b). Phase 2a and 2b studies comprise respectively consultation<br /><br />
with key stakeholders and the general public to understand key biodiversity issues and return visits to<br /><br />
areas of interest.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
B AS E L I N E M E T H O D S T AT E M E N T<br /><br />
Phase 3 of the vegetation studies for the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project (the Project) in Sierra Leone, West<br /><br />
Africa. Phase 3 will consist of detailed vegetation surveys of Simbili and part of the haul road, and a<br /><br />
rapid assessment programme of the preferred tailings area and transport corridor associated with the<br /><br />
Project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SCOPE<br /><br />
The overall objective of Phase 3 is to characterise the baseline in areas likely to be affected by early<br /><br />
construction works prior to disturbance and to understand the biodiversity value of the transport<br /><br />
corridor. Phase 3 will also aim to identify any areas or species of high ecological importance that<br /><br />
require specific consideration or management during the construction activities or subsequent phases<br /><br />
of project design.<br /><br />

Desktop review, in-field observation and limited sample collection (with subsequent sample<br /><br />

<br /><br />
C O V E R AG E<br /><br />
The study area for the Phase 3 rapid assessment will cover the areas affected by the Tonkolili<br /><br />
Project. This includes haematite extraction from Simbili, other proposed extraction sites, preferred<br /><br />
tailings option, new haul road from the mine site to Lunsar and an existing railway line from Lunsar to<br /><br />
Pepel Port. In order to avoid overlap between the terrestrial and marine studies, Mean High Water<br /><br />
Springs has been selected as the cut off point for the terrestrial studies at Pepel Port.<br /><br />
The Phase 3 vegetation survey will be separated into two tasks:<br /><br />
Phase 3a: detailed characterisation of baseline conditions at the mine site and the first 20 km of the<br /><br />
haulage road; and<br /><br />
Phase 3b: rapid assessment field surveys of the preferred tailings option, remainder of the haulage<br /><br />
road to Lunsar, existing rail corridor, and Pepel Port.<br /><br />
The survey will also include rheophytic communities located in the rivers with low water levels.<br /><br />
Two team comprising staff from Kew Gardens, supported by local specialists will undertake the field<br /><br />
work. One team will work from Pepel Port and Tagrin point eastwards towards Rokel River, while the<br /><br />
other will cover the mine site area and work westwards towards Rokel River.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
R E P O R T I N G S T AN D A R D S<br /><br />
The findings of the Phase 3 surveys will provide input to a high level Environmental, Social and<br /><br />
Health Impact Assessment (ESHIA) which is being undertaken for the Tonkolili Project. A report will<br /><br />
be prepared containing an assessment and interpretive discussion on the character, condition and<br /><br />
conservation importance of habitats in the study area including transition areas or ecotones;<br /><br />
identification of sensitive or potentially critical habitats that need immediate consideration by the<br /><br />
project team; lists of the key species present within the various habitat types; and assessment of the<br /><br />
likelihood and actual presence of rare species. A combined report of the faunal, floral and freshwater<br /><br />
studies will also be prepared, using consistent classification and impact assessment schemata, will<br /><br />
be prepared. This will include preliminary identification and definition of impacts and mitigation<br /><br />
measures for Project activities at the construction and operational stages.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
P O T E N T I AL I S S U E S<br /><br />
The detailed surveys are limited to flowering species only due to the difficulty of plant species<br /><br />
identification outside of the flowering period.<br /><br />
