3.3.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Fauna<br /><br />
<br /><br />
B AS E L I N E M E T H O D S T AT E M E N T<br /><br />
Phase 1 of terrestrial fauna studies for the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project (the Project). Phase 1 will consist<br /><br />
of a rapid assessment programme of the potential mine site, tailings location, haul road alignment and<br /><br />
preliminary railway corridor associated with the Project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SCOPE<br /><br />
The Phase 1 rapid assessment for fauna will provide input directly to the ESHIA(s) so that areas of<br /><br />
high ecological value can be defined prior to completion of the engineering design.<br /><br />
The main objectives of Phase 1 rapid assessment are as follows:<br /><br />
Understand the biodiversity value of the study area (as defined below);<br /><br />
Identify areas of high ecological value that require consideration during project design;<br /><br />
Identify any areas of potentially critical habitat;<br /><br />
Identify any red flag issues for the Project in the context of fauna species; and<br /><br />
Provide recommendations for further detailed studies to characterise baseline conditions in the study<br /><br />
area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
M E T H O D O F AS S E S S M E N T<br /><br />
Primarily direct observation, supplemented (where time allows) by camera-traps, sampling and<br /><br />
opportunistic village-based interviews.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
C O V E R AG E<br /><br />
Two teams comprised of staff from WCS and WorleyParsons, with assistance from local specialists<br /><br />
will cover approximately 31 sites from the mine site to Pepel Port and Tagrin Point via the proposed<br /><br />
haul road route and existing railway line. In order to avoid overlap between the terrestrial and marine<br /><br />
studies, Mean High Water Springs has been selected as the cut off point for the terrestrial studies at<br /><br />
Pepel Port. Faunal groups that span this divide will be separated into the terrestrial or marine studies<br /><br />
on a case-by-case basis. A rapid survey of migratory birds will be undertaken at Tagrin Point.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
R E P O R T I N G S T AN D A R D S<br /><br />
A high-level report with a brief assessment and interpretive discussion on ecological value, protection<br /><br />
status and potential impacts will be prepared for fauna. A combined report of the faunal, floral and<br /><br />
freshwater studies, using consistent classification and impact assessment schemata, will be<br /><br />
prepared. This will include a preliminary biodiversity impact assessment associated with Project<br /><br />
activities at the construction and operational stages.<br /><br />

3.4.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Human Health Impact Assessment (HIA)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
B AS E L I N E M E T H O D S T AT E M E N T<br /><br />
Health Impact Assessment is "a combination of procedures, methods and tools by which a policy,<br /><br />
program or project may be judged as to its potential effects on the health of a population, and the<br /><br />
distribution of those effects within the population" (ECHP 1999). Currently, there is no one authority<br /><br />
defining HIA methodology; however, most agencies have adopted similar procedures. For the Early<br /><br />
Cash Flow (ECF) and Tonkolili ESHIAs, the HIA approach applied will be as described by the World<br /><br />
Health Organization (WHO 2005) and the International Finance Corporation (IFC 2009).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SCOPE<br /><br />

End of August 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Health Impact Assessment is an iterative process. Typically, the first steps involve a semi-quantitative<br /><br />
approach or ‘Rapid HIA', which uses all available data so as to quickly identify those impacts which<br /><br />
require more quantitative evaluation and those which are adequately described qualitatively. Based<br /><br />
on the outcome of the Rapid HIA, the methodology may then become progressively more detailed as<br /><br />
the assessment focuses on more accurately defining potential impacts. In this manner, more detailed,<br /><br />
quantitative assessment is applied to a smaller list of potential impacts. There are clear benefits to<br /><br />
applying this kind of phased approach since some projects only require qualitative or semiquantitative appraisal while others require a fully quantitative detailed assessment<br /><br />
<br /><br />
TIMING<br /><br />
Maximum benefit of conducting an HIA occurs when it comes before the final engineering design<br /><br />
specifications and before the construction contract is locked in. Also its important to conduct and HIA<br /><br />
along with an social and environmental impact assessment and not as a standalone assessment.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
C O V E R AG E<br /><br />
Based on the project information available to date, the coverage of the HIA conducted for the ECF<br /><br />
Project will include impacts on persons assumed to be at four locations: the mine site (including<br /><br />
worker camp), the haul road, the existing railroad, and the renovated port facilities. Persons to be<br /><br />

<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
included in the assessment will include those living at camp facilities at the mine, as well as those not<br /><br />
directly involved in the Project operations, but living in the vicinity of each of the four locations.<br /><br />
The coverage of the HIA for the Tonkolili project will be defined at later date once more concrete<br /><br />
project information becomes available.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
R E P O R T I N G S T AN D A R D S<br /><br />
International organizations such as the World Bank, the IFC, and the WHO endorse the completion of<br /><br />
an HIA at the beginning of a project’s lifecycle. Increasingly, HIAs are becoming a requirement for<br /><br />
regulatory and financial approvals of industrial activities such as those proposed for the ECF and<br /><br />
Tonkolili Mining Projects. In 2009, the IFC published "Introduction to Health Impact Assessment"<br /><br />
which provides good practice guidance for conducting HIAs to determine all potential impacts on<br /><br />
community health as a result of a proposed development.<br /><br />
Where possible, the HIAs planned for the ECF and Tonkolili ESHIAs will employ regulatory standards<br /><br />
as described by the Sierra Leone Environmental Protection agency (SL EPA). In addition, other<br /><br />
internationally recognised standards/guidelines will be applied if and when required (e.g. WHO,<br /><br />
Health Canada (HC), US EPA, and RIVM) for the completion of the HIA and used in the HIA with the<br /><br />
approval of SL EPA.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
P O T E N T I AL I S S U E S<br /><br />
Health Impact Assessment (HIA) is a real-world tool which must function within time and budget<br /><br />
constraints. As such, it is to be expected that there will be certain limitations. Some common<br /><br />
examples include a lack of availability of baseline monitoring data for the region of the proposed<br /><br />
development (e.g. air, soil and water), or difficulty in obtaining detailed health information for persons<br /><br />
living in the proposed region before implementation of a new policy or activity.<br /><br />
The limitations and recommendations of the HIAs will be defined at each reporting Phase.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

ECF MANAGEMENT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The ECF phase comprises haul road, rail line and Pepel port refurbishment. To date, the haul road<br /><br />
has started due to wet season constraints and the assessment and management of environmental<br /><br />

<br /><br />
P R AC T I C E G U I D E S<br /><br />
Practice guidelines have been prepared as a way of achieving good practice during haul road<br /><br />
construction, in advance of the more conventional evaluation and management planning approach,<br /><br />
due to the rapid implementation schedule. These have been rolled out to the haul road contractors<br /><br />
prior to work commencement. The guides and a management plan can be made available at a later<br /><br />
date.<br /><br />

A series of Early Works Chiefdom Committees (EWCC) have been established throughout the project<br /><br />
area, with participation from Paramount Chiefs, Section Chief, Councillors, NGO and women’s and a<br /><br />
youth leader. These EWCC are designed to ensure that communities are consulted about the<br /><br />
proposed project works. Further details can be made available if required. The meetings are also to<br /><br />
be attended by district officers from EPA and representatives of the MPs.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
DESCRIPTION OF THE INDUSTRY / FACTORY / COMPANY /<br /><br />
PROJECT AND OR PROPOSED PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Name: Tonkolili Iron Ore Project (Tonkolili Project)<br /><br />
Date Operations started<br /><br />
Exploration commenced in and has been ongoing since 2003. Construction of mining infrastructure is<br /><br />
due to begin in 2010.<br /><br />
Description of the project<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) has been exploring an extensive magnetic anomaly in the Sula<br /><br />
Mountain range in Sierra Leone and recently confirmed the presence of a world-class magnetite iron<br /><br />
ore deposit. The Tonkolili Project focuses on the three magnetite banded iron formation (BIF) targets<br /><br />
that occur in the southern portion of the northeast – southwest trending anomaly. These deposits are<br /><br />
named Simbili, Marampon and Numbara and are illustrated in Figure 1 below. The current combined<br /><br />
ore estimate is 5.1 billion tonnes. Exploration to date also indicates that the Simbili-MaramponNumbara magnetite anomaly is overlain with a hematite deposit, estimated to be in the order of 800<br /><br />
million tonnes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
File Ref: Q:\MandM Select\AML - Tonkolili\10.0 Engineering\10.13 ES - Environmental and Social\reports\GOSL EIA Screening Form<br /><br />
09022010.doc<br /><br />
2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Environmental Impact Assessment Screening Form<br /><br />
WorleyParsons<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 1:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Tonkolili Iron Ore Project<br /><br />
February 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Relative Locations of Resources in the Tonkolili Exploration Licence Area<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Kasafoni deposit, which extends over a length of approximately 20 km north of Numbara has the<br /><br />
potential to double the size of the total ore resource to over 10 billion tonnes. Ongoing exploration<br /><br />
work is focussed on the Kasafoni area, with the objective of identifying additional BIF mineralisation<br /><br />
to realise the resource target of 10 billion tonnes. At this stage however, the Kasafoni resource is not<br /><br />
included in the Tonkolili Project.<br /><br />
The Tonkolili deposit is covered by an exploration licence (Exploration Licence No:EXPL:05/06) in<br /><br />
the name of AML’s wholly owned subsidiary, Tonkolili Iron Ore (SL) Limited. The Licence was<br /><br />
renewed on the 1st of July, 2009 for a period of two years. The bounding coordinates stated on the<br /><br />
licence encompass an area covering approximately 209 km2.<br /><br />
Proposed Operations<br /><br />
The Project will consist of mining operations with an ore-production rate of about 167 million tonnes /<br /><br />
year and a total material movement in the order of 270 million tonnes / year. A concentrate will be<br /><br />
produced on site at a rate of about 45 million tonnes / year. The life of the mine is expected to be in<br /><br />
excess of 50 years at these production rates. The feasibility of increased production will be subject to<br /><br />
studies in subsequent phases of project development.<br /><br />
Mining will be open cast method and will produce a concentrate to be transported by rail to a port at<br /><br />
Tagrin Point, near the mouth of the Sierra Leone River Estuary. Rail infrastructure will be required to<br /><br />
link Tonkolili with Tagrin Point (a distance of ca. 200 km). The proposed port facility will be a deep<br /><br />
water port comprising a causeway, trestle and berths located between 700-800 m offshore. The<br /><br />
location of the Tonkolili Project facilities is shown in Figure 2 and Figure 3.<br /><br />
In addition to the proposed Tagrin Point port, AML has signed a 99 year lease agreement with the<br /><br />
Government of Sierra Leone (GoSL) to reconstruct, manage and operate Pepel Port and the Pepel –<br /><br />
Marampa Railway. AML is working toward mining hematite ore found in the Tonkolili deposits<br /><br />
during the initial stages of the project and exporting the product via Pepel Port. A dedicated haul road<br /><br />
File Ref: Q:\MandM Select\AML - Tonkolili\10.0 Engineering\10.13 ES - Environmental and Social\reports\GOSL EIA Screening Form<br /><br />
09022010.doc<br /><br />
3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Environmental Impact Assessment Screening Form<br /><br />
WorleyParsons<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Tonkolili Iron Ore Project<br /><br />
February 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(approximately 120 km in length) will be built from the mine site to a railhead near Lunsar and the<br /><br />
existing railway line refurbished between Marampa and Pepel while the Tagrin Point export route<br /><br />
infrastructure is under construction.<br /><br />
Mine Design and Associated Infrastructure<br /><br />
AML have commissioned WorleyParsons and SRK to undertake preliminary engineering studies on<br /><br />
the mine pits, mine infrastructure and potential tailings dams for the Tonkolili Project. The pit outline<br /><br />
limits and possible sites for the tailings dams are illustrated in Figure 4.<br /><br />
It is anticipated that about 120 million m3 of tailings will be produced per year for an ore production<br /><br />
rate of 45 million tonnes / annum. The study shows that the tailings dam will be positioned largely<br /><br />
within the existing exploration lease. Alternative tailings dam sites have been considered however a<br /><br />
site has been selected as the preferred options based primarily on engineering and geotechnical<br /><br />
considerations.<br /><br />
The acceptability of the preferred tailings facility site will be confirmed once existing environmental<br /><br />
and social baseline conditions with the area are more fully and thoroughly understood.<br /><br />

February 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Current Land Use<br /><br />
Mine Site<br /><br />
Much of the land around the mine site has been subject to slash-and-burn agricultural practices. There<br /><br />
are tracts of forest land comprising a mixture of secondary and mature forest notably along the northwestern margin of Simbili, south of the village of Kegbema and in the Tonkolili River valley east of<br /><br />
Farangbaya village. During the dry season farming is restricted to valley flood plains which retain<br /><br />
high soil moisture content and permit at least two cropping seasons. During field investigations<br /><br />
undertaken for the Tonkolili Project environmental and social work programme, cassava, plantain,<br /><br />
sweet potato, ground nut and sweet corn were all observed growing across the concession and fruits<br /><br />
including pineapple, banana, orange, and mango were also observed. In the rainy season rice is a<br /><br />
staple crop. Palm wine tapping is evident and fishing is also common in rivers and streams. Artisanal<br /><br />
gold mining activity was observed in the Tonkolili River and is carried out by area residents and<br /><br />
transient labourers.<br /><br />
Railway Route<br /><br />
Most of the rail route and the port site are on the coastal plain. Land use and primarily agriculture, has<br /><br />
altered the natural vegetation and most of the route is now typified by wooded grassland, secondary<br /><br />
palm tree forests and swamp areas where different crops are grown. Part of the rail route is along a<br /><br />
previously existing railway line, the Marampa-Pepel line, originally developed by the Sierra Leone<br /><br />
Development Corporation (DELCO) in the 1930s as a mineral railway to transport ore from the<br /><br />
Marampa Iron Ore Mine<br /><br />
The railway has not operated since 1985, when the last iron ore shipment was made. Since that time,<br /><br />
the GoSL has assumed ownership and management of the disused rail line. The remaining<br /><br />
infrastructure is the subject of the AML / GoSL 99-year lease agreement referred to above.<br /><br />
Port<br /><br />
A car and passenger ferry service is in operation between Tagrin Point Ferry Terminal across the<br /><br />
estuary to the Kissy Ferry Terminal located 4 km to the east of central Freetown. This service<br /><br />
provides a link between Freetown and the Lungi Airport located 16 km from the Tagrin Point Ferry<br /><br />
Terminal. Passenger-only ferry services also run on a daily basis from Port Loko to Tagrin and Kissy<br /><br />
using large pirogue vessels.<br /><br />
The area is estimated by local authorities to have a population of upto 9,000 as of November 2009. It<br /><br />
is anticipated that commercial activity near the ferry terminal supports further livelihoods in the wider<br /><br />
region. Approximately 35 fishing boats operate from a fish landing facility adjacent to the ferry<br /><br />
terminal. Fishing is an important socio-economic activity in the area.<br /><br />
Describe any possible alternative site(s)<br /><br />
The location of the ore at Tonkolili is fixed and the preferred locations of the logistics infrastructure,<br /><br />
transportation routes and ancillary features such as tailings facilities have been selected based<br /><br />
predominantly on engineering factors and will be evaluated for their environmental and social effects,<br /><br />
along with any feasible alternatives, in accordance with Best Practice. These will be the subject of<br /><br />
more detailed studies prior to selecting the final sites and routes. In terms of the project’s linear<br /><br />
features, adherence as far as possible to existing / pre-existing rail and road routes will be a priority<br /><br />
where feasible to minimise environmental and social impacts.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Although Pepel Port is under consideration as a short term solution for export of the hematite product,<br /><br />
it is not considered a viable long-term option to the proposed Tagrin Point Port development due to the<br /><br />
port being unsuitable for cape-sized vessels (i.e. approximately 19 m draft) and dredging that may be<br /><br />
required to maintain deep water access through the channel.<br /><br />
As with the Marampa-Pepel railway, Pepel Port has not been operated since 1985 but infrastructure is<br /><br />
still present in the area including housing and office facilities, a power plant, fuel tanks, conveyer belts<br /><br />
and a jetty / ship loader. The current and predominant land use around the existing railway and port<br /><br />
facilities is agriculture. Fishing activities and passenger ferries operate in Pepel Town and nearby<br /><br />
Tasso Island, while Bunce Island, located 1.8 km off Pepel Port, has some tourist potential.<br /><br />
Describe other types of industries or facilities (including health centres and schools), which are<br /><br />
located within 100 metres of the site, or are proposed to be located near the facility. Indicate the<br /><br />
proximity of the industrial, factory or project site and or proposed site to residential areas, national<br /><br />
parks or areas of ecological, historical or cultural importance.<br /><br />
Proximity to residential areas<br /><br />
The Tonkolili Project ore bodies lie largely within the Kalansogia Chiefdom. Potentially affected<br /><br />
villages include Kalansogia, Kafe-Simiria and Sambia-Bendugu Chiefdoms (Figure 5). The nearest<br /><br />
villages to the ore bodies are Farangbaya, Kegbema, Keimadugu 1, Keimadugu 2 and Gbonbomba.<br /><br />
These villages are most likely to fall within the project’s direct footprint and hence may have to be<br /><br />
relocated prior to commencement of mine development. Several other villages in the lease area may<br /><br />
lie within the project affected area depending on the final design and location of mine infrastructure.<br /><br />
The railway corridor extends across several chiefdoms (Figure 6). There are several settlements along<br /><br />
the railway corridor and there are households situated next to the existing railway Right of Way<br /><br />
(ROW).<br /><br />
There are numerous villages and settlements at and in the vicinity of Tagrin Point, most of which are<br /><br />
located along the road from Lungi to the ferry terminal at Tagrin Point itself. Many of these<br /><br />
settlements will fall in the project affected area and as such, may also require relocation.<br /><br />
The project will consider community investment options in the vicinity of project developments<br /><br />
including programmes that would enhance the reliability of supply and quality of drinking water,<br /><br />
medical facilities, employment, schooling and livelihood schemes in project affected areas.<br /><br />

Proximity to Ecological Areas<br /><br />
There are two designated forest reserves within the vicinity of the project; the Farangbaya Forest<br /><br />
Reserve (12.6 ha), which has a rainforest ecosystem and is located approximately 10 km south-east of<br /><br />
the town of Bumbuna and the Malal Hills (3.39 ha), located 10 km south of the alignment east of the<br /><br />
town of Marampa (Figure 4). The Port Loko Strict Nature Reserve (2.16 ha) is located approximately<br /><br />
4.5 km north of the proposed ore transport corridor nearby to Port Loko town.<br /><br />
Within the mine concession, there are mainly two habitats of conservation interest both of which have<br /><br />
limited distribution within the existing exploration lease area:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Forest patches on slopes in limited locations, notably Simbili and Kegbema, some of which are<br /><br />
associated with Society Bush areas access which is restricted to local communities; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Riverine forest strips along river valleys, notably well preserved east of Farangbaya village.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The proposed port location at Tagrin Point is situated within the Sierra Leone River Estuary which is<br /><br />
characterised by substantial areas of mudflats and mangrove forests. It is the receiving environment<br /><br />
for the Rokel / Seli Rivers. The larger estuarine environment is a designated Ramsar (wetlands<br /><br />
conservation) site acknowledging its international importance for palae-arctic migrant wader birds that<br /><br />
are present in large numbers on the rich feeding ground mudflats during northern hemisphere winter<br /><br />
periods. The estuary is known to support at least 36 over-wintering wader species, the most common<br /><br />
being the Curlew Sandpiper, Red Shank and Ringed Plover as reported by Birdlife International.<br /><br />
Rail lines at Port Loko that are proposed for upgrading, traverse an area of high ecological value<br /><br />
associated with extensive mangrove forests along Port Loko Creek and at Pepel Island, both of which<br /><br />
are within the Sierra Leone River Estuary designated Ramsar site. Birdlife International reports that a<br /><br />
total of 36 wader species have been recorded in the estuary and numbers are known to exceed 20,000<br /><br />
regularly during the migration season. The IUCN also reports, among other species of conservation<br /><br />
value, populations of West African Manatee (Trichechus senegalensis) in the estuary.<br /><br />
Proximity to Areas of Historical and /or Cultural Importance<br /><br />
Refurbishment of the Pepel Port facility and export of iron ore product will lead to the rejuvenation of<br /><br />
marine traffic between Taso Island and Pepel Island. The port itself is approximately 1.8 km from<br /><br />
Bunce Island, which was declared a national monument in 1948 for its historical links to the Atlantic<br /><br />
slave trade and is a focus of international interest.<br /><br />
Indicate whether adequate infrastructure exists at the location and / or proposed location and<br /><br />
whether old or new buildings, roads, electricity and water lines or drainage systems exist at the<br /><br />
location and / or proposed site.<br /><br />
Current infrastructure at the mine site is limited to unpaved roads and community infrastructure such<br /><br />
as water wells, social halls and market buildings within a few villages. Although the Bumbuna<br /><br />
Hydroelectric facility is nearby, it provides no electricity distribution in the immediate project area.<br /><br />
Sealed roads are situated along a portion of the proposed rail ROW adjacent to the main MakeniFreetown highway and the Lungi-Tagrin Ferry road. Water and electricity supplies are not available<br /><br />
in these areas.<br /><br />
Infrastructure development is required across all project areas and is the subject of current design<br /><br />
studies. The new infrastructure required includes:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Power generation / distribution infrastructure;<br /><br />

SECTION 3: EMPLOYEES AND LABOURERS<br /><br />
Number of people employed<br /><br />
The Tonkolili Iron Ore Project, currently in the exploration phase, already employs approximately 700<br /><br />
people making it a significant employer in Sierra Leone. When the Project advances to the<br /><br />
construction phase a substantial increase in workforce numbers is envisaged. Current estimates<br /><br />
indicate total construction phase employment (comprising international and national project personnel)<br /><br />
will be around 5,000. This work-force will be spread across all project locations (i.e. mine site,<br /><br />
processing plant, transport routes and port facilities) according to the construction schedule. It is<br /><br />
therefore important to note that certain areas may be more active at an earlier stage than others during<br /><br />
the infrastructure development phase of the project. Construction is expected to take approximately<br /><br />
36 months to complete.<br /><br />
While some production will be generated during the project construction phase, when construction<br /><br />
reaches completion, the Project will enter the fully operational phase during which employment will<br /><br />
stabilise at a lower level than during the construction phase. Although fewer in number, jobs available<br /><br />
during the operational phase will represent long-term opportunities with the potential to support<br /><br />
families and communities over the lifetime of the mining operations<br /><br />
Indicate whether you have or plan to construct housing / sanitation facilities for temporary or<br /><br />
permanent workers.<br /><br />
It is envisaged that temporary construction camps will be built to house the project construction<br /><br />
workforce during the construction phase. The housing needs for the construction workforce will be<br /><br />
evaluated in consultation with local community leaders and stakeholders. Facilities associated with<br /><br />
these construction camps (such as on-site sewerage treatment plants and waste management facilities)<br /><br />
will be required and are being designed by current studies.<br /><br />
During operations, accommodation for international and TCN employees will be provided possibly in<br /><br />
the scaled down construction camps. All infrastructure requirements such as access roads, power<br /><br />

SECTION 4:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
DESCRIPTION OF INDUSTRIAL PROCESS<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Briefly describe the type and nature of industrial processes at the installation and / or proposed<br /><br />
installation.<br /><br />
The mining process will follow industry standards for open cast mining and will include drilling,<br /><br />
blasting, loading, hauling and primary crushing.<br /><br />
Following excavation, ore will be loaded onto large haul trucks for transfer to the primary crushers. It<br /><br />
is envisaged that at least six primary crushers will be utilized before product is conveyed to a Run of<br /><br />
Mine (ROM) stockpile.<br /><br />
Hematite ore will undergo beneficiation consisting of segregation and sorting with limited enrichment<br /><br />
or processing. Magnetite ore will undergo additional milling to achieve a finer size fraction. This will<br /><br />
be followed by further processing including magnetic separation and flotation to produce a<br /><br />
concentrate.<br /><br />
Finally, the concentrate or beneficiated ore stockpiled at the mine location will be transported by rail<br /><br />
to the port facility for export.<br /><br />
Tailings will be pumped to the tailings facility from the ore process plant.<br /><br />
State the type and quantity of energy used (including the origin of the energy i.e. public utility, on<br /><br />
site generator, wood, solar, wind etc.)<br /><br />
At this stage, AML are assessing a number of different options for energy supply, including hydroelectric power from existing sources available in-country and a new power supply (fuel choice as yet<br /><br />
undefined). It is likely that the power supply for the Tonkolili Project will come from a combination<br /><br />
of sources. The project power requirements currently under assessment but will be a minimum of<br /><br />
450 MW.<br /><br />
Estimate the quantity of water used<br /><br />
Water supply for the Tonkolili Project will be derived from a combination of surface and groundwater<br /><br />
sources. At the mine, water will be supplied from a purpose built reservoir (Mawura) which will have<br /><br />
a sufficiently large water storage capacity (currently assumed to be 20Gl) for the project to have<br /><br />
security of supply through dry season conditions. Outflow from the tailings facility may have a net<br /><br />
positive benefit to downstream users by regulating flow during the dry season. It is assumed that<br /><br />
make-up water will be needed during the initial 18 months of production before the reservoir achieves<br /><br />
design storage capacity. Water losses from evaporation, seepage and retention of moisture in the<br /><br />
tailings and concentrate will be met by drawing down impounded, excess wet season flow. A project<br /><br />
water balance is currently being confirmed. Groundwater abstraction is the preferred water supply<br /><br />
option for other infrastructure elements of the project.<br /><br />
List the type and quantity of raw material (s) used per year in the production process (including soil,<br /><br />
sand, cement, aggregates, wood, animals etc). Identify the source (s) of raw material (s).<br /><br />
Significant quantities of raw materials including water, cement, sand, aggregate, steel and timber will<br /><br />
be required for the construction and operation of the Tonkolili Project. At the time of writing, details<br /><br />
regarding the quantities and sources of raw materials are still being assessed.<br /><br />

List all of the chemical (s) used in the production process or expected to be used for any aspect of<br /><br />
the production process.<br /><br />
Chemicals used in iron ore production and processing include explosives, binders and flotation<br /><br />
chemicals, although a variety of other products will also be required including fuels, lubricants, dust<br /><br />
control agents and water treatment chemicals. At the time of writing, a full inventory of chemicals<br /><br />
and the quantities required is being prepared as part of design works.<br /><br />

SECTION 6:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
OUTPUT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
BY PRODUCTS, WASTE MANAGEMENT AND DISPOSAL<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Specify the nature of each waste or by-product and the quantity generated or to be generated.<br /><br />
Waste from mining operations is primarily waste rock excavated to expose the ore bearing material<br /><br />
and tailings comprised of water and unwanted (unrecoverable and uneconomic) minerals. Current<br /><br />
estimates suggest that approximately 120 million tonnes / annum of tailings will be produced . Waste<br /><br />
volumes are dependent on density and bulk water content and final project waste volumes will be<br /><br />
determined as part of the current project design works.<br /><br />
Other hazardous and non-hazardous waste streams include vegetation wastes (i.e. wood waste and<br /><br />
green wastes from vegetation clearance), hydrocarbon wastes, domestic wastes (both biodegradable<br /><br />
and non-biodegradable), medical waste and chemical wastes. Wastes inventories (i.e. types and<br /><br />
volumes) have not yet been determined but will be calculated during later stages of the project design<br /><br />
process.<br /><br />
Liquid waste will be present in the form of wastewater from the mine site facilities and camp<br /><br />
including sewage and grey water, mine wastewater derived from dewatering activities in the mine pits<br /><br />
and supernatant from the tailings facility. Treated wastewater will be used as process make-up water<br /><br />
as far as practicable.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

09022010.doc<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Environmental Impact Assessment Screening Form<br /><br />
WorleyParsons<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Tonkolili Iron Ore Project<br /><br />
February 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
No major gaseous emissions are expected from the project however diesel powered machinery and<br /><br />
processors will produce exhaust gases emissions including carbon dioxide (CO2), NOX, and SOX and<br /><br />
PM10 (particulates). Fugitive dust control will be implemented especially during the dry season.<br /><br />
Details on the quantity of project-related liquid wastes and gaseous emissions are the subject of<br /><br />
ongoing studies and appropriate waste management plans focusing on minimisation, re-use, recycling<br /><br />
in preference to straight disposal, will be developed for each waste stream.<br /><br />
State the method of disposal or management (e.g. dump site, burning, bury etc).<br /><br />
Details of waste management strategies have not yet been finalised. All hazardous and non-hazardous<br /><br />
wastes will however, be collected, transported, processed, recycled or disposed of in a manner that<br /><br />
meets the requirements of the GoSL and Good International Industry Practice as defined in IFC's<br /><br />
Performance Standard 3 on Pollution Prevention and Abatement.<br /><br />
Waste rock will be placed in engineered waste rock dumps within the mining lease<br /><br />
Tailings will be discharged to a tailings facility. Tailings dams will be engineered for the storage of<br /><br />
these wastes and to maximise the volume of water available for reclamation for re-use as process<br /><br />
make-up water.<br /><br />

Noise pollution sources will vary between the different project phases (i.e. construction, operation and<br /><br />

blasting noise and vibration and will be both sporadic and continuous as detailed below.<br /><br />

ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Please indicate environmental impact (s) that may occur as a result of the factory / industrial<br /><br />
process and or the process of proposed project.<br /><br />
Potential environmental and social impacts associated with the Tonkolili Project have been identified<br /><br />
at a preliminary level and are presented in the following table. Impacts have been identified via an<br /><br />
initial screening process based on the present understanding of project design and its environmental<br /><br />
and social setting. Knowledge gained from previous experience with similar projects has also been<br /><br />
used.<br /><br />

sulphur oxides (SOX), nitrous oxides (NOX), carbon<br /><br />
monoxide (CO) and carbon dioxide (CO2).<br /><br />

infrastructure including mine pits, tailings facility,<br /><br />
buildings, roads and railways.<br /><br />
Alteration of surface drainage flows due to the<br /><br />
impoundment of water for use in ore processing and<br /><br />
other mine related activities (e.g. wetting down during<br /><br />
dry seasons).<br /><br />

SECTION 8:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
PROPOSED MITIGATION MEASURES<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Indicate the measures (s) employed to mitigate against damage likely to be caused by the factory /<br /><br />
industrial process and / or proposed project to humans and /or the environment.<br /><br />
At this stage of the project, only a preliminary screening and scoping of potential environmental and<br /><br />
social impacts has been possible. As baseline studies and impact assessments have not been<br /><br />
completed, potential risks / impacts cannot be fully quantified. Mitigation measures are therefore, still<br /><br />
to be fully defined but will be guided by the principles outlined in the table below.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

MITIGATION MEASURES<br /><br />

vehicles.<br /><br />
Avoidance of incineration as a waste disposal method.<br /><br />
Implement dust control measures during dry season.<br /><br />
Prepare and implement an Emissions Management Plan.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Drainage<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Prepare and implement a Water Management Plan.<br /><br />

3<br /><br />

<br /><br />

prioritise naturally flat areas for the siting of the transport<br /><br />
corridor and the establishment of camps / project<br /><br />
infrastructure.<br /><br />

State any and all experience you have with implementing the above mentioned mitigation measure<br /><br />
(s). If you do not have prior experience, what skill (s) do you possess to implement these mitigation<br /><br />
measures?<br /><br />
WorleyParsons has considerable experience in conducting Environmental and Social Impact<br /><br />
Assessments (ESIA) processes globally across all regions of the world. A list of recent ESIA projects<br /><br />
conducted by WorleyParsons is attached. Projects included the development and implementation of<br /><br />
mitigation and management measures for large industrial (including mining) operations.<br /><br />
What staff training is provided or will be provided to ensure compliance with health and safety<br /><br />
standards?<br /><br />
Health and Safety training will be provided by AML to ensure that all activities associated with the<br /><br />
Tonkolili Project are undertaken in accordance with the requirements of the GoSL and GIIP. Health<br /><br />
and Safety training will be compulsory for all employees, prior to commencing any work.<br /><br />

APPENDIX 1<br /><br />
ESHIA Pre-Screening Announcement & Correspondence<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Date: 13 November 2009<br /><br />
<br /><br />
ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA)<br /><br />
Attn. Mr Jusu<br /><br />
Director of the Environment, EPA<br /><br />
rd<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3 Floor, Youyi Building<br /><br />
Freetown, Sierra Leone<br /><br />
Re: Tonkolili Iron Ore Project<br /><br />
Dear Mr Jusu,<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) is pleased to announce our intention to develop the Tonkolili<br /><br />
iron ore mine in Sierra Leone. We would like to request the EPA formally consider this project<br /><br />
in terms of regulation of environmental and social aspects.<br /><br />
Due to the project’s size and significance AML anticipate that an Environmental Impact<br /><br />
Assessment (EIA) will be required in accordance with the regulations set out in the<br /><br />
Environment Protection Act 2008.<br /><br />
Additionally, AML understands that in order to transition from exploration activities to<br /><br />
operational mining, a lease is required from the Ministry of Mineral Resources. The lease<br /><br />
application needs to be accompanied by an EIA with proposals for mitigation of identified<br /><br />
environmental impacts. We therefore realise the EIA could be a critical aspect of the project<br /><br />
schedule.<br /><br />
It is understood that we may only undertake EIA under licence from the EPA. We are also<br /><br />
aware that the EPA is required to screen the project and advise on statutory procedures. We<br /><br />
wish to launch the environmental and social process as quickly as possible so that EIA work<br /><br />
can interact with the engineering design which is currently being assessed in a Feasibility<br /><br />
Study due to be completed in 2010. To this purpose we are attaching a brief project<br /><br />
description of the planned activities in Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AML are committed to maintaining the highest corporate and ethical standards throughout the<br /><br />
life of this project. It is anticipated that the EIA will address not only environmental but also<br /><br />
social and health aspects, subject to EPA’s determination. We would therefore kindly request<br /><br />
the EPA to consider the project and advise on the appropriate screening and further<br /><br />
procedures to obtain an EIA licence, if required.<br /><br />
We believe this project will be of national significance and convey significant benefits to Sierra<br /><br />
Leone through increasing local employment, infrastructure, government revenue, institutional<br /><br />
capacity building and commitment to high standards of environmental and social practice.<br /><br />
AML has already invested significantly in the exploration activities at Tonkolili and are<br /><br />
confident of developing a world-class iron project. The project is aiming to produce 45 Mtpa<br /><br />
of iron ore from a resource that has currently has been proven to contain more than 5.1 Bt of<br /><br />
recoverable ore making it one of the world’s largest magnetite deposits.<br /><br />
We have nominated the company WorleyParsons as EIA contractor for this project who will<br /><br />
be represented in Sierra Leone by a local agent to facilitate the regulatory approval and<br /><br />
maintain in-country continuity. We request that your response is emailed to the following:<br /><br />
Mr Steve Allard (AML) – steve.allard@african-minerals.com<br /><br />
Mr Philip Burris (WorleyParsons) – philip.burris@worleyparsons.com<br /><br />
We sincerely look forward to working with the EPA on this project and developing good<br /><br />
environmental outcomes by furthering the opportunities for sustainable development in<br /><br />
conjunction with the Government of Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
Yours sincerely,<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Steve Allard<br /><br />
VP Infrastructure - African Minerals Limited<br /><br />
<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT DESCRIPTION<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) is developing a new iron ore mine identified as the Tonkolili<br /><br />
Iron Ore mine in Sierra Leone. The Project is planned to produce 45 Mtpa of iron ore<br /><br />
comprising:<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Predominantly magnetite with a grade containing 68% to 70% Fe with a<br /><br />
minimum particle size of 38 µm from a resource deposit identified containing 5.1<br /><br />
Billion tonnes of recoverable ore.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Some Hematite (lump and fines)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The mine project area is located approximately 200 km east of Freetown, the capital city of<br /><br />
Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
The project will comprise the mine and process plant facilities supported by a rail network to<br /><br />
transfer the concentrate product to the stockyards and handling facilities at the port area<br /><br />
which is to be located in the Tagrin Point area, North of Freetown and South of the Lungi<br /><br />
airport.<br /><br />
Three ore bodies have been identified for production and it is envisaged that staged<br /><br />
development will be undertaken, dependent on the exploration activities which are currently<br /><br />
underway to maximize return on the investment. It is likely that additional ore bodies will<br /><br />
subsequently be developed as the understanding of the geological conditions and the mine<br /><br />
reserves mature.<br /><br />
To commercialise the Tonkolili Resource, AML will execute an integrated greenfield<br /><br />
development through the construction of new facilities which include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A new mine and ore processing plant at Tonkolili, to produce 45 Mtpa of magnetite;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A new deepwater port and associated infrastructure at Tagrin Point suitable for loading<br /><br />
Cape size vessels for the export of 45 Mtpa iron ore;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Approximately 200km of new standard gauge, heavy haul railway from Tonkolili to Tagrin<br /><br />
Point, and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
All associated support infrastructure to deliver and operate the project safely and<br /><br />
successfully.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
At the mine the project development will comprise three open cast mines, ROM pads, the<br /><br />
central minerals processing facilities and support infrastructure such as power, water, access<br /><br />
roads, air terminal, accommodation facilities, workshops, warehouses, laboratories,<br /><br />
administration buildings and train loading facility.<br /><br />
The port will initially be capable of 45MTPA which will be expandable to 90MTPA plus. At the<br /><br />
port a rotary train unloader will convey the concentrate to stockpiles. Reclaimers in the 2<br /><br />
stockyards will collect the product and convey to the open water port which will then be<br /><br />
loaded onto a ship via the ship loader.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mine and Process Plant<br /><br />
The Mine and Process Plant will be sited to enable the extraction and processing of the iron<br /><br />
ore resource body to enable overland transport by rail to the Port for the export of the iron<br /><br />
concentrate. Current mine processing site selection is about to commence and as such<br /><br />
various options are to be investigated. The facilities to be provided for the overall<br /><br />
development include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Development of three open cast pits to access the ore deposits at Simbili, Marampon and<br /><br />
Numbara;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Overburden waste management;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Location of the Run of Mine (ROM) pad;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Primary Crushing facilities<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Secondary Crushing facilities;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Product Screening facilities;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Tertiary Crushing facilities;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Primary and Fine Grinding;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Flotation;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Tailings Storage Facility;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Product Handling;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Train Loading Facility;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reagent Storage Facility;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Laboratory and Sample Stations;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Airport;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Power Plant;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Water Treatment Plant;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Waste Water Treatment Plant; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Administration, Training, Maintenance and Warehousing Facilities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rail<br /><br />
The Tonkolili rail encompasses the construction of approximately 200km of heavy haulage<br /><br />
railway and associated infrastructure from the Tonkolili mine to Tagrin Port. The aim is to<br /><br />
develop the rail infrastructure with a minimum capacity of 45 Mtpa. The design of the railway<br /><br />
and associated facilities needs to be able to be readily expanded to 90 Mtpa while ensuring<br /><br />
sufficient space is available to expand the operation to an ultimate development capacity of<br /><br />
200 Mtpa plus.<br /><br />
The rail alignment will be designed to best suit the project with regards to construction costs<br /><br />
and social impact.<br /><br />
Key areas of the rail are the Port, Mine and marshalling yards.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Access Roads<br /><br />
An access road will run the full length of rail alignment from port to mine. The utilisation of this<br /><br />
road is to be determined whether it will be the main Tonkolili mine access road or be a rail<br /><br />
maintenance road.<br /><br />
Construction of a temporary haul road for hauling product from Tonkolili to the existing railway<br /><br />
at Marampa is envisaged as a separate project to the current Project. Synergies however will<br /><br />
need to be encompassed and it would seem likely that the temporary haul road will follow the<br /><br />
proposed Tonkolili rail alignment and the balance between rail and road will be optimized<br /><br />
once the heavy haul rail system is operational.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Port Facilities<br /><br />
A port facility with a capacity of 45 Mtpa will be developed. The design of the facilities needs<br /><br />
to ensure sufficient capacity for increased expansion in future. This port facility will likely<br /><br />
become the paramount Port facility in the West African region. The overall port layout needs<br /><br />
to provide sufficient space to enable an ultimate development of a total capacity of 200 Mtpa.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The port is separated into In-Loading and Out-Loading circuits separated by the product<br /><br />
stockpiles. There is the ability to through load built into this system, i.e. there is a direct ore<br /><br />
path from the Car Dumpers to the Ship loaders.<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The In-Loading circuit is defined as the area and equipment between the ore wagon<br /><br />
and the stockpiles. There is one In-Loading circuit constructed as part of initial port<br /><br />
with a second In-loading circuit (for the 90 Mtpa) being incorporated in the design of<br /><br />
the facilities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The stockpiles rows will consist of 5 stockpiles each of a nominal 200 kt live capacity.<br /><br />
The length of the live stockyard is nominally 1,100 m. The 45 Mtpa yard will require 2<br /><br />
live stockyard rows which will result in 4 total stockyard rows, the outer two being<br /><br />
dead rows (which can be stacked but not reclaimed). The 90 Mtpa expansion will<br /><br />
add an additional 2 live stockyard rows which will result in 6 stockyard rows, the outer<br /><br />
two will be dead rows (which can be stacked but not reclaimed).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Out-Loading circuit is defined as from the stockpiles to the ship. There is one<br /><br />
Out-Loading circuits constructed as part of 45 Mtpa. The Out-Loading circuit will<br /><br />
have the ability to be able to feed either ship loader from either reclaimer for the 90<br /><br />
Mtpa design.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SYNOPSIS<br /><br />
This document is provided as a preliminary guide to the waste infrastructure proposals, for both<br /><br />
operational and construction phases of the Tonkolili Mine project. This document should be treated as<br /><br />
a guide only in order that adequate provision is made at the earliest stage for waste infrastructure.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Disclaimer<br /><br />
This report has been prepared on behalf of and for the exclusive use of African Minerals Limited,<br /><br />
and is subject to and issued in accordance with the agreement between African Minerals Limited<br /><br />
and WorleyParsons Europe Limited. WorleyParsons Europe Limited accepts no liability or<br /><br />
responsibility whatsoever for it in respect of any use of or reliance upon the whole or any part of<br /><br />
the contents of this report by any third party.<br /><br />
Copying this report without the express written permission of African Minerals Limited or<br /><br />
WorleyParsons Europe Limited is not permitted.<br /><br />

PRELIMINARY CONCEPTS FOR SOLID WASTE<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
ADMINISTRATION AND PLANNING<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Introduction<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This document has been produced for the development of the Tonkolili project on behalf of African<br /><br />
Minerals Limited (AML). To ensure that were possible all waste is managed, stored and disposed of in<br /><br />
an appropriate manner in accordance with all relevant in-country legislation and global best practice.<br /><br />
This is a live document and requires ongoing review and revision. Given the extent and complexity of<br /><br />
the project, the project scope is subject to change and the concepts will require to be updated to<br /><br />
reflect any changes as necessary.<br /><br />
The purpose of this report is to enable the issue of operational and construction waste production to<br /><br />
be dealt within a structured and auditable manner from the commencement of the project during the<br /><br />
design stage, through construction to its operation and monitoring and beyond. This ensures that the<br /><br />
aim of waste minimisation is emphasised from the outset of the project, in addition to ensuring that<br /><br />
the waste produced is dealt with in accordance with the principles outlined within the Waste Hierarchy<br /><br />
(reduction, reuse, recovery and recycling). Given the absence of any existing in-country infrastructure<br /><br />
the report will also look to recommend a waste management infrastructure development base case,<br /><br />
for the project.<br /><br />
Construction waste will arise from either surplus materials imported to site, those generated on site or<br /><br />
day to day operational activities. Imported materials are those which are brought to the project for<br /><br />
inclusion into the permanent works. Generated materials are those which exist on the project such as<br /><br />
topsoil, sub-soil, stabilized fill, trees and materials from demolition works etc. An overview of waste<br /><br />
arising from workers construction and operational camps is also addressed in this report.<br /><br />
Operational wastes will vary per facility, although will predominate around the port and mine facilities<br /><br />
and are described within this report.<br /><br />
This document should be read in conjunction with the “ECF Solid Waste Management Practice<br /><br />
Guidelines” and the “Tonkolili Accommodation Waste Management Strategy”, although it should be<br /><br />
understood that the recommendations of this document superceed the recommendations made in<br /><br />
these documents.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

1.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Site Location<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The following figure provides an indication of the mine site location relative to the coast and the<br /><br />
borders with Guinea and Liberia. The mine site at Tonkolili is approximately 200 km ENE of the<br /><br />
capital of Freetown.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 1-1 Sierra Leone Map<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Proposed Development Description<br /><br />
<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) is developing a new iron ore mine identified as the Tonkolili Iron Ore<br /><br />
mine in Sierra Leone on the west coast of Africa. The Project is planned to produce 45 Mtpa of<br /><br />
magnetite concentrate with a grade containing 68% - 70% Fe with a minimum particle size to be<br /><br />
confirmed from a resource deposit identified containing approximately 5.1 Billion tonnes of<br /><br />
recoverable ore.<br /><br />
The mine project area is located approximately 200 km north east of Freetown, the capital city of<br /><br />
Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
The project will comprise the mine and process plant facilities supported by a rail network to transfer<br /><br />
the concentrate product to the stockyards and handling facilities at the port area which is located at<br /><br />
Tagrin Point adjacent to Lungi airport to the north of Freetown.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 2 305000-00006 : 305000-00006-2440-EN-REP-0001Rev B : 13-Apr-10<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
PRELIMINARY CONCEPTS FOR SOLID WASTE<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Three ore bodies have been identified for production; Simbili, Marampon and Numbara. It is<br /><br />
envisaged that staged development will be undertaken dependent on the exploration activities which<br /><br />
are currently underway, to maximize the return on the investment. It is likely that additional ore bodies<br /><br />
will subsequently be developed as the understanding of the geological conditions and the mine<br /><br />
reserves mature.<br /><br />
To commercialise the Tonkolili Resource, AML will execute an integrated Greenfield development<br /><br />
through the construction of new facilities which include:<br /><br />
 A new mine and ore processing plant at Tonkolili, to produce 45 Mtpa of magnetite<br /><br />
concentrate;<br /><br />
 Approximately 200km of new standard gauge, heavy haul railway from Tonkolili to Tagrin Point;<br /><br />
 A new deepwater port and associated infrastructure at Tagrin Point suitable for loading vessels<br /><br />
up to Cape, sized for the export of 45mtpa of iron ore concentrate; and;<br /><br />
 All associated support infrastructure to deliver and operate the project safely and successfully.<br /><br />
The port will initially be capable of handling 45 Mtpa which will be expandable to 90 Mtpa plus.<br /><br />
The rail component encompasses the construction of approximately 200km of heavy haulage railway<br /><br />
and associated infrastructure from the Tonkolili mine to Tagrin Port.<br /><br />
For the purposes of this report the development elements have been broken down into the following<br /><br />
areas:<br /><br />
 Rail<br /><br />
 Haul Road<br /><br />
 Pepel Port<br /><br />
 Targin Port<br /><br />
 Workers Camps<br /><br />
SRK Consulting have been engaged to undertake the mine pit waste design, as such it is anticipated<br /><br />
that they will develop a separate waste management plan for this element of the works. All process<br /><br />
waste issues will be addressed by Ausenco Ltd and are excluded from this report. Issues associated<br /><br />
with sewage waste are also excluded.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
1.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Local Legislation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Irrespective of the lack of waste management infrastructure in-country, a high level legislative review<br /><br />
has been undertaken. The following in-country legislation is considered applicable to the<br /><br />
development:<br /><br />
- The Environment Protection Agency Act, 2008<br /><br />
With respect to waste management the act sets out very general guidance and policy statements as<br /><br />
listed below, detailing the Agency’s responsibilities with respect to permitting and control of facilities.<br /><br />
“Subject to the Act, the Agency shall perform the following functions:-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Secure, in collaboration with such persons it may determine the control and prevention of<br /><br />
discharge of waste into the environment and the protection and improvement of the quality of<br /><br />
the environment;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Issue environmental permits and pollution abatement notices for controlling volume, types,<br /><br />
constituents and effects of waste discharges, emissions, deposits or other sources of<br /><br />
pollutants and of substance which are hazardous or potentially dangerous to the quality of the<br /><br />
environment or any segment of the environment;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Prescribe standard and guidelines relating to ambient air, water and soil quality, the pollution<br /><br />
of air, waste land and other forms of environmental pollution including discharge of wastes<br /><br />
and the control of toxic substances;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Agency shall take all necessary and appropriate measures to monitor, control and<br /><br />
regulate the manufacture, sale, transportation, handling or disposal of toxic and hazardous<br /><br />
substances including toxic and hazardous wastes;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 4 305000-00006 : 305000-00006-2440-EN-REP-0001Rev B : 13-Apr-10<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
PRELIMINARY CONCEPTS FOR SOLID WASTE<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The introduction or importation of toxic or hazardous wastes into Sierra Leone for storage of<br /><br />
disposal by any means whatsoever if prohibited;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A license if required for the projects whose activities involve or include the following<br /><br />
(g) Waste management and disposal (e.g. sewerage systems and treatment plants, landfills,<br /><br />
treatment plants for house hold and hazardous waste.)<br /><br />
No specific waste management regional strategies or directives were determined; this is not untypical<br /><br />
of developing regions. Although research indicates that there are moves by development agencies<br /><br />
such as the United Nations to further understand the waste management issues in-country, and<br /><br />
ultimately fund improvement schemes. These schemes are in their infancy and there is no visibility of<br /><br />
what assets are likely to be delivered if any.<br /><br />
Irrespective of the legislation it should be recognised that good waste management practice through<br /><br />
both the construction and operation of facilities will provide heath, social and economic benefits to the<br /><br />
project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
WASTE MANAGEMENT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Existing Waste Management Settling<br /><br />
<br /><br />
There is very limited information with respect to the national waste picture. It is understood that there<br /><br />
is currently no or limited waste management throughout Sierra Leone with most waste simply being<br /><br />
discarded in unregulated dumping areas around cities or burnt in make shift pits. WorleyParsons is<br /><br />
unaware of any regulated landfill facilities in-country.<br /><br />
It is envisaged that there will be immature markets for dry recyclates in the local community, focusing<br /><br />
around metals and larger plastic containers. It is unclear if these will be re-use or recycling,<br /><br />
irrespective it should be a priority to maximise recycling/re-use where possible and to benefit the local<br /><br />
community. It is anticipated that there will be no market for other dry recyclates such as paper, card,<br /><br />
plastics and certain types of wood, due to the level of development within Sierra Leone, although this<br /><br />
should remain under constant review.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Waste Generation Forecasting<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In the absence of a definitive description for some elements of works to be undertaken as part of the<br /><br />
project at the time of this report, it is not possible to generate an accurate waste model for the entire<br /><br />
scheme. A waste model has been developed for both construction and operational workers camps<br /><br />
and is included in Appendix 3. For construction waste, tables included in Appendix 1 should be<br /><br />
populated by the contractors who are better placed to advise of waste generation based on<br /><br />
construction materials to be used, construction methods etc. Detailed in the preceding sections is a<br /><br />
generic summary of the types of waste that are likely to be generated by the different elements of the<br /><br />
work.<br /><br />
Whilst not a specific waste issue it is noted that the proposals are likely to generate issues with<br /><br />
respect to dust, further details of dust management should be provided in the Dust Management Plan.<br /><br />
Figure 2-1 Project Location Plan<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Rail<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A 6km wide corridor from the proposed mine to Targin port has been approved by the Sierra Leone<br /><br />
government for the construction of the proposed railway. The rail route is proposed to run from the<br /><br />
Tonkolili mine site, south through the Tonkolili Valley before turning west at the end of the ranges of<br /><br />
Targin Port.<br /><br />
AML wish to undertake early construction of the mine access road to Lunsar for the early shipment of<br /><br />
ore through Pepel Port. This will be achieved by refurbishing elements of the existing railway from<br /><br />
Lunsar to Pepel Port. To minimize costs the haul road is proposed to be constructed along the<br /><br />
proposed rail access road.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Primary waste types arising from the construction of the new railway and refurbishment of the existing<br /><br />
railway line include:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
off cuts from rail;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
broken sleepers;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
contaminated ballast;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
existing rail wagons (some containing full loads of ore)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In addition there are four bridge crossings required in excess of 25m spans and a further seven minor<br /><br />
bridge crossings. The likely primary waste type arising from construction of these crossings is<br /><br />
concrete depending on the construction method adopted.<br /><br />
There is anticipated to be limited wastes arising from operational activities of the railway. These are<br /><br />
likely to be focused around refurbishment of equipment and waste oils; there may also be a small<br /><br />
element of municipal waste arisings from passengers.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.2.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Haul Road<br /><br />
<br /><br />
As detailed in section 2.2.2, the haul road is to be constructed between the Mine and Lunsar to<br /><br />
facilitate early extraction of the ore. Whilst there is no definitive route available and it is understood<br /><br />
that the route of the haul road is under constant refinement, cut and fill calculations have been<br /><br />
undertaken.<br /><br />
Quantum analysis undertaken by WorleyParsons indicates that the proposed haul road development<br /><br />
will generate 1,500,000m3 of cut and 810,000m3 of fill. This is based on a 12.5m wide haul road, with<br /><br />
2m shoulders on fills and 4m shoulders in cuts. Whilst there is still significant uncertainly around these<br /><br />
numbers and the percentage of material that could potentially be re-used is unknown, there will based<br /><br />
on the current proposal be significant spoil arising that will require management and disposal.<br /><br />
The construction detail of the haul road is unknown, but it is considered that there will also be an<br /><br />
element of waste generated from contaminated, unsuitable and surplus materials.<br /><br />
There is anticipated to be no waste waste arisings from the operation of the haul road.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.2.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Pepel Port<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
At the Port, the project development will comprise a materials handling facility, and relevant support<br /><br />
infrastructure such as power, water, access roads, accommodation facilities, workshops, warehouses,<br /><br />
laboratories and administration buildings, train unloading facility, stockyard and wharf. This will<br /><br />
comprise a combination of existing asset refurbishment and new development.<br /><br />
Mayer International Machines South Africa has been commissioned by AML and visited the<br /><br />
inoperative Iron Ore plant at Pepel port producing a study detailing the works required to reinstate the<br /><br />
plant included components that should be refurbished, replaced or where a totally new installation is<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
appropriate. An extract from the study detailing the structures to be refurbished or replaced is shown<br /><br />
in Appendix 2. It is anticipated that the primary component of these wastes will be metals that will<br /><br />
have a residual scrap value either locally or could be readily exported in sufficient quantities. There is<br /><br />
also likely to be significant quantities of hazardous waste in the form of oils and other industrial<br /><br />
wastes which should be disposed of to a suitable facility, this is discussed further in section 2.5.2.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
2.2.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Targin Port<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction<br /><br />
The works to be undertaken in the port marine at Targin Port are extensive including the development<br /><br />
of a new Port facility with consideration for navigation and ship-handling, this will include Port<br /><br />
structures for a ship-loader jetty at the primary port and structures for service berths at the secondary<br /><br />
port, in addition to Navigation aids. Waste generation from these activities are likely to be concrete,<br /><br />
rubble, metals etc, refer to Appendix 1 for full details.<br /><br />
The proposed works at Targin port will generate significant dredged material that will be addressed<br /><br />
through a separate disposal strategy, at the time of this report it is understood that the dreging may<br /><br />
be suitable for offshore disposal. No additional consideration has been made for waste dredging<br /><br />
within this report.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
-<br /><br />

<br /><br />
2.2.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Power<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dependent on the ability to attract external investment, a Power plant may be constructed to meet<br /><br />
some of the projects power requirements; however there is almost no detail available on this aspect<br /><br />
and as such it is excluded from this report. Depending on the type of plant to be adopted this may<br /><br />
present a disposal route for some of the operational wastes, this should remain under constant<br /><br />
review.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Proposals for minimization<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Given the lack of available appropriate in-country disposal routes, a strong focus should be placed on<br /><br />
waste minimization at source. Although waste types will vary significantly between the different<br /><br />
elements of the project. Generally by volume the majority of the waste will arise mainly from<br /><br />
construction through demolition and site clearance, excavation and any unavoidable construction<br /><br />
waste. The proposed scheme will require specific construction materials (such as rail, railway sleeper,<br /><br />
ballast, specialist components etc) to be imported to the site.<br /><br />
Actions to be taken to facilitate resource efficiency throughout the project and therefore minimise the<br /><br />
waste produced are detailed below:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Excavated soils and clay will be carefully stored in segregated piles for subsequent reuse on<br /><br />
the site. The soils and clay will be reused as deposition material for infilling or landscaping.<br /><br />
Any surplus soils and clay will be removed from site for direct beneficial use elsewhere;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Concrete waste will be source segregated, for subsequent separation and re-use were<br /><br />
appropriate e.g. as hardcore;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Wood will be source segregated for subsequent recovery through the local community,<br /><br />
contaminated woods such as shuttering and metal film pallets should be disposed of to an<br /><br />
appropriate facility (see section 2.8);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hazardous wastes including any contaminated soil materials will be identified, removed and<br /><br />
kept separate from other Construction and Demolition (C&D) waste materials in order to avoid<br /><br />
further contamination and will be disposed of to an appropriate licensed facility;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Metals will be collected in receptacles, for subsequent recovery through the local community;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Plastic container (for example anything above 2 litres) will be collected in receptacles, for<br /><br />
subsequent recovery through the local community.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
