<br /><br />
Waste Storage and Collection<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Appropriate consideration should be made for waste storage through the scheme, particularly the<br /><br />
workers camps and it is suggested that should the recommendations of this report be adopted that all<br /><br />
waste infrastructure, consolidation centers, incinerators and recycling areas be co-located. Thought<br /><br />
should be made early in the design for the location of the waste consolidation centers, making<br /><br />
consideration of living quarters, easy access for removal of recyclates and proximity to surrounding<br /><br />
villages. It is likely that recyclates will be removed from camps and work areas on a site by site basis.<br /><br />
All waste storage areas should be adequately sized taking account of the estimated waste generation<br /><br />
presented in this report. Waste storage and collection provision should also take account of local<br /><br />
climate and in particular pest and odour control.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 12 305000-00006 : 305000-00006-2440-EN-REP-0001Rev B : 13-Apr-10<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
PRELIMINARY CONCEPTS FOR SOLID WASTE<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.5.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Waste Segregation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It is essential that the construction and operational activities are carried out closely with the waste<br /><br />
management contractors, in order to determine the best “on the ground” techniques for managing<br /><br />
waste and ensure a high level of recovery of materials for recycling. WorleyParsons is not aware of<br /><br />
any global waste management companies operating in the region as a result due diligence is<br /><br />
recommended on any proposed contractor in order to ensure that wastes are dealt with in a manner<br /><br />
that is compliant with in-country legislation and the best practice outlined in this document.<br /><br />
Alternatively the project may employ operatives directly to collect and transport waste to an<br /><br />
appropriate facility.<br /><br />
On a site by site basis set down areas should be developed and labeled to facilitate the separation of<br /><br />
materials, where possible, for potential recycling, salvage, reuse and return. Recycling and waste bins<br /><br />
are to be kept clean and clearly marked in order to avoid contamination of materials. Skips for<br /><br />
segregation of waste identified currently are:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mixed Inert (e.g. concrete and rubble), for re-use in construction;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hazardous (e.g. asbestos, Poly Chlorinated Bi-phenols), for disposal to an appropriate facility;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mixed non-hazardous (biodegradable waste), for disposal to an appropriate facility;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Metal (e.g. copper and iron), for return to the local community, or re-use;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Wood (e.g. fencing/hoarding), for re-use in construction or return to the local community<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It is recommended that waste is removed regularly, perhaps daily, depending on the phasing of the<br /><br />
project. As such there should be a robust process in place for removing waste from site prior to the<br /><br />
commencement of the project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.5.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hazardous Waste<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It is likely that different elements of the project will generate small quantities of hazardous wastes<br /><br />
such as healthcare, waste oils and some electronic equipment. Solid hazardous waste should be<br /><br />
stored in sealable clip-top drums (25-205 liter capacity) and hazardous liquid wastes stored in<br /><br />
sealable bung-top drums (25-205 liter capacity). Hazardous wastes must remain in their original,<br /><br />
labeled containers. Bulking of hazardous wastes should not occur in storage areas.<br /><br />
The small quantities of Hazardous waste that are generated should be disposed to an incineration<br /><br />
unit were possible (see section 2.8), were this is not the case they may require temporary storage<br /><br />
prior to shipping to an appropriate facility. It is understood that there are small local crushing mills that<br /><br />
can be used for disposal of medical waste, specifically syringes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 13 305000-00006 : 305000-00006-2440-EN-REP-0001Rev B : 13-Apr-10<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
PRELIMINARY CONCEPTS FOR SOLID WASTE<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Re-use of Materials<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Uncontaminated material will be reused where possible within the proposed construction works for<br /><br />
site leveling and fill.<br /><br />
Any contaminated materials, which will not be re-used on-site, will be treated in accordance with all<br /><br />
relevant legislation and best practice guidelines at the point of origin or at an alternative suitable site<br /><br />
prior to disposal.<br /><br />
Surplus inert excavated materials with some engineering strength (e.g. stone, bricks, clay, rubble,<br /><br />
rock) can be suitable for crushing and re-use as hardcore through the project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.7<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Waste Disposal Categorization<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Global best practice, classifies waste streams as Inert, Non-Hazardous, and Hazardous.<br /><br />
Responsibility for the basic classification of waste rests with the producer and waste operator.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Disposal and Treatment Options<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The inherent difficult with dealing with waste within Sierra Leone is the lack of an appropriate disposal<br /><br />
routes, coupled with a lack of recyclate markets, requires a waste infrastructure solution be developed<br /><br />
specifically for this project.<br /><br />
WorleyParsons have developed a base case for the DFS, which should be reviewed and refined as<br /><br />
more information becomes available.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.8.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
From this study it is recognised that there will be significant wastes generated during primarily the<br /><br />
construction of the project but also during operation. In developing the base case it is important to<br /><br />
consider the “Tonkoliil Accommodation Solid Waste Management Strategy”, summary<br /><br />
recommendations of which are shown in Table 2.3, also identified within the table is the anticipated<br /><br />
spare capacity of the recommended infrastructure proposals to address waste arisings from the<br /><br />
accommodation camps, which could be utlised to address some of the waste resulting from<br /><br />
operational and construction activities.<br /><br />

Haul Road<br /><br />
It is anticipated that the haul road will generate negligible operational waste. The primary waste<br /><br />
arising from the construction will be spoil potentially in the region of 800,000m3 based on preliminary<br /><br />
cut and fill calculations. This waste is considered to be inert and does not require an engineered<br /><br />
facility for disposal; however areas should be outline at outset for stockpiling and bunding. Where<br /><br />
possible the road should be designed to achieve a cut and fill balance. As minimum land areas should<br /><br />
be set aside for spoil disposal, there may be an opportunity to re-use spoil in some any port<br /><br />
reclamation works.<br /><br />

4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RECOMMENDATIONS<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Procurement/Development<br /><br />
<br /><br />
On review, the infrastructure recommendations for the construction and operational camps will go<br /><br />
some way to addressing the waste arisings of both the construction and operation of the proposed<br /><br />
facilities.<br /><br />
The volumes of waste generated by the operation and construction of the ports and mine in particular<br /><br />
remain a relative unknown, but will progress with the development of the project. By increasing the<br /><br />
landfill capacity at each of the camps and re-sizing the incineration unit at the Port Operation camp to<br /><br />
a unit capacity of 1-1.25t/hr over a 10-16hr shift, we believe that this we meet the initial waste<br /><br />
management demands of the facilities. It should also be considered that as the construction<br /><br />
population and activities decrease the operational activities will increase presenting fluctuating waste<br /><br />
generation volumes and type, several years into the project .The facilitates that have been<br /><br />
recommended have been developed with this is mind.<br /><br />
In addition given Allterrain Services will be managing the camps, its is recommended that an<br /><br />
integrated approach is adopted to avoid replication of infrastructure and other equipment. A summary<br /><br />
of the procurement / delivery items to support waste management is shown in table 4.1 below:<br /><br />

<br /><br />
4.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Further Work<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It should be noted that in the absence of detailed material take offs, significant assumptions have<br /><br />
been made in the waste infrastructure recommendation in the report. It is recommended that on<br /><br />
completion of Appendix 1, by the contractors that this report and recommendations are reviewed and<br /><br />
the infrastructure recommendations amended accordingly. A comprehensive waste strategy should<br /><br />
also be developed with respect to the operation of the facilities particularly the ports.<br /><br />
Given the uncertainly surrounding the permitting process for any waste infrastructure in-country, all<br /><br />
proposals should be afforded adequate time in the programme and dialogue commenced with the<br /><br />
local regulatory bodies at the earliest opportunity. The delivery process associated with waste<br /><br />
infrastructure, as shown indicative figure 4.2 should not be under estimated.<br /><br />

SOLID WASTES MANAGEMENT PRACTICE GUIDELINES<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
INTRODUCTION<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project Description<br /><br />
<br /><br />
African Minerals Limited (AML) is developing a new iron ore mine identified as the Tonkolili<br /><br />
Iron Ore mine in Sierra Leone on the west coast of Africa. The Project is planned to produce<br /><br />
45 Mtpa of magnetite concentrate with a grade containing 68% - 70% Fe with a minimum<br /><br />
particle size to be confirmed from a resource deposit identified containing approximately<br /><br />
5.1 Billion tonnes of recoverable ore.<br /><br />
The mine project area is located approximately 200 km north east of Freetown, the capital<br /><br />
city of Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
The Early Cash Flow Element (ECF) of the project will comprise the select development of the<br /><br />
mine, approximately 100km of haul road to Lunsar, were ore will be transported by the<br /><br />
Delco rail line which will ultimately be refurbished to Pepel Port were it will be shipped. It is<br /><br />
anticipated that the immediate works will comprise the haul road construction through the<br /><br />
surrounding jungle and the existing processing facilities at Pepel port would be refurbished<br /><br />
to accept the ore.<br /><br />
This report provides high level waste management principles that should be adopted<br /><br />
throughout the project but given the immediately of the construction of the haul road and<br /><br />
refurbishment of infrastructure and processing plant at Pepel Port, is targeted at driving<br /><br />
waste management best practice through these elements of the work. Given the uncertainly<br /><br />
and availability of time for the development of these guidelines they should be treated as a<br /><br />
guide only and are anticipated to be supplemented by more comprehensive guidance in due<br /><br />
course.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

1.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project Location<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The following figure provides an indication of the mine site location relative to the coast and<br /><br />
the borders with Guinea and Liberia. The mine site at Tonkolili is approximately 200 km ENE<br /><br />
of the capital of Freetown.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

SOLID WASTES MANAGEMENT PRACTICE GUIDELINES<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
PRACTICE GUIDELINES<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The objectives of the practice guidelines are to:<br /><br />
1. Reduce waste arisings from all activities associated with the Tonkolili development<br /><br />
resulting in economic and environmental benefit;<br /><br />
2. To provide a framework to ensure development for facilities, that would enable<br /><br />
waste to be managed in accordance with the waste hierarchy;<br /><br />
3. To encourage the sustainable use of waste, in terms of benefit for both the local<br /><br />
community and for the project;<br /><br />
4. To begin the process of developing an integrated mix of techniques with respect to<br /><br />
managing waste in accordance with the proximity principle. Delivering the optimum<br /><br />
balance of environmental and economic costs and benefits, whilst minimising the<br /><br />
risk of immediate and future environmental pollution and harm to human health<br /><br />
(Best Practicable Environmental Option, BPEO);<br /><br />
5. To ensure compliance with local regulatory waste legislation environmental<br /><br />
legislation and international best practice, and<br /><br />
6. To protect the immediate health of the construction workers<br /><br />
In the absence of detailed waste generation rates, the guidelines are intend to provide a<br /><br />
generic high level guide to deal with the types of waste likely to arising from the<br /><br />
construction proposals.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Waste Arisings<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Given the relatively unknown scope of the project waste forecasting is difficult at this stage.<br /><br />
However we would anticipate the following waste types will be generated, with construction<br /><br />
of the Haul Road and refurbishment of Pebel Port:<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Jungle Clearance, considered 100% organic, elements of hardwood may be present<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Spoil arising<br /><br />
<br /><br />
-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction waste<br /><br />
- Packaging (Wood, Plastics, Metals, Cardboard)<br /><br />
- Contaminated stone<br /><br />
- Potential for contaminated land<br /><br />
- Hydraulic Oils<br /><br />
- Fuel<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0019Rev A : 20 September 2009<br /><br />

SOLID WASTES MANAGEMENT PRACTICE GUIDELINES<br /><br />
<br /><br />
- Worker Municipal Solid Waste<br /><br />
- Demolition waste, concrete and steel<br /><br />
- Hazardous Wastes from plant decommission / refurbishment<br /><br />
Given the extent of the project and the potential for wastes arising it is recommended that a<br /><br />
Waste Management Strategy be developed for the entire scheme, part of which a<br /><br />
comprehensive waste modelling exercise will be required, detailing volume and waste types.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
High level Guidelines<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1. Waste management consideration should be made at the earliest opportunity in the<br /><br />
project in order to be effectively implemented on site;<br /><br />
2. Decisions regarding waste management, should in broad terms , be based on that of<br /><br />
the waste hierarchy shown below:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Image Courtesy of: Wasteonline<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The aim of the guidelines is to focus waste management throughout all activities at the<br /><br />
top of the hierarchy;<br /><br />
3. A detailed set of waste Key Performance Indicators (KPI) based on the waste<br /><br />
hierarchy should be adopted.<br /><br />
4. Waste collection will be key to the successful delivery of the project. An integrated<br /><br />
approach should be adopted throughout all waste collection activities eliminating the<br /><br />
in-efficiencies caused by a piecemeal approach;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
: 305000-00006-0000-EN-REP-0019Rev A : 20 September 2009<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINES LIMTED<br /><br />
TONKOLILI EARLY CASH FLOW PROJECT<br /><br />
SOLID WASTES MANAGEMENT PRACTICE GUIDELINES<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5. Early and continued engagement of local regulatory bodies should be adopted<br /><br />
throughout the project;<br /><br />
6. Reduction in waste generation is key to the financial and environmental success of<br /><br />
the project. As part of the overarching strategy education measures should be<br /><br />
implemented in waste minimisation techniques;<br /><br />
7. A reuse strategy should be developed including:<br /><br />
a. Identify opportunities for re-use and repair;<br /><br />
b. Stimulate / create in-country markets for re-use and recycling;<br /><br />
c. Help facilitate reuse partnerships between the construction activates and the<br /><br />
local community;<br /><br />
8. There should be review of existing and consideration for provision of new waste<br /><br />
facilities, targeted at the waste forecast;<br /><br />
9. Separation of wastes should be adopted at source through the project, given the<br /><br />
type of waste and availability of cheap labour in the region this is likely to be<br /><br />
undertaken by hand;<br /><br />
10. Engagement with the local community should be sought at the earliest opportunity<br /><br />
and a partnering approach developed;<br /><br />
11. Incentives should be provided to contractors who meet or exceed waste KPI targets;<br /><br />
12. As part of the ongoing engagement, the client or clients representative will work<br /><br />
proactively with the local regulatory body to reduce the amount of fly tipping<br /><br />
generated by the project;<br /><br />
13. The client will take steps to enure that waste produced by its own organisation on<br /><br />
site is minimised and recycling opportunities are maximised;<br /><br />
14. All intended disposal facilitates should be named at outset and verified as suitable<br /><br />
for use, by a suitably experience practitioner;<br /><br />
15. Responsibilities for all waste management activities should be clearly set out at the<br /><br />
outset of the project;<br /><br />
16. A spoil movement methodology should be developed by earthworks contractors or<br /><br />
as part of the waste management strategy, this will include detailed calculation of<br /><br />
spoil generated, targets and movement patterns;<br /><br />
17. There will be a Waste Management Strategy produced which will form the framework<br /><br />
for the management of all wastes arising from the development of Tonkolilli Mines<br /><br />
and associated infrastructure from construction, through to operation and final<br /><br />
closure. This Strategy should be reviewed and updated at appropriate intervals to be<br /><br />
<br /><br />

determined during the development of the strategy to include changes in waste<br /><br />
management legislation, best practice and reviewing waste generation forecasts.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Specific Recommendations<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.3.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Wast e Minim isat ion<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Waste will arise from the project mainly from demolition and site clearance, excavation and<br /><br />
any unavoidable construction waste. The proposed scheme will require specific construction<br /><br />
materials to be imported to the site. Actions to be taken to facilitate resource efficiency<br /><br />
throughout the project and therefore minimise the waste produced are non-exhaustively<br /><br />
detailed below:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Excavated soils and clay should be carefully stored in segregated piles for<br /><br />
subsequent reuse during construction. The soils and clay will be reused as<br /><br />
deposition material for infilling or landscaping. Any surplus soils and clay will be<br /><br />
removed from site for direct beneficial use elsewhere.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Concrete waste will be source segregated, for subsequent separation and recovery;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Masonry and wood will be source segregated for subsequent separation and<br /><br />
recovery;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Any packaging waste will be source segregated for recycling or returned to<br /><br />
suppliers;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hazardous wastes including any contaminated soil materials will be identified,<br /><br />
removed and kept separate from other Construction and Demolition (C&D) waste<br /><br />
materials in order to avoid further contamination and will be disposed of in<br /><br />
accordance with all relevant legislation and best practice guidelines at point of orgin<br /><br />
or at an alternative suitable site prior to disposal<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Other C&D waste materials will be collected in receptacles with mixed C&D waste<br /><br />
materials, for subsequent separation and disposal;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Given the volume or organic waste likely to be produced, the market for compost<br /><br />
should be investigated and potential for mobile composting units considered.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Resource E fficiency<br /><br />
<br /><br />

be confirmed in the Strategy.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
2.3.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Wast e S egregat ion<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It is essential that the construction and demolition/refurbishment work is carried out closely<br /><br />
with the waste management contractors, in order to determine the best techniques for<br /><br />
managing waste and ensure a high level of recovery of materials for recycling. This is also<br /><br />
true of community engagement as it recognised that there is high level of re-use and<br /><br />
recycling often referred to as scavenging in this region.<br /><br />
Specific areas shall be laid out and labelled to facilitate the separation of materials, where<br /><br />
possible, for potential recycling, salvage, reuse and return. Recycling and waste bins are to<br /><br />
be kept clean and clearly marked in order to avoid contamination of materials. Skips / set<br /><br />
down areas for segregation of waste identified currently are:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mixed Inert (e.g. concrete and rubble)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hazardous (e.g. asbestos, Poly Chlorinated Bi-phenols)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mixed non-hazardous (biodegradable waste)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Metal (e.g. copper and iron)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Wood (e.g. fencing/pallets)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
WEEE (Waste electrical/electronic equipment e.g. cables, very limited volumes<br /><br />
anticipated)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It is recommended that waste is removed regularly, depending on the phasing of the<br /><br />
project. As such the contractor should ensure that they have a robust process in place for<br /><br />
recording any waste that is removed from site.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.3.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Wast e Re-use<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Uncontaminated material will be reused where possible within the proposed works for site<br /><br />
levelling and fill. It is unlikely that there will be a requirement for importation of additional<br /><br />
bulk fill materials for the project although this should be confirmed on receipt of further<br /><br />
design information.<br /><br />
Any contaminated materials, which will not be re-used on-site, will be treated in accordance<br /><br />
with all relevant legislation and best practice guidelines at the point of origin or at an<br /><br />
alternative suitable site prior to disposal.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

3.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
REFERENCE<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Sierra Leone Environmental Protection Agency was created by an act of Parliament in<br /><br />
2008. All waste management practice must comply with local legislative and regulatory<br /><br />
standards and this is reflected in the practice guidelines.<br /><br />
It is currently unclear to what extent they have been able to develop waste management<br /><br />
guidance and regulatory framework. In the absence of local guidance, US EPA guidance<br /><br />
should be referenced including:<br /><br />
US EPA Part 260 - 282 – Hazardous Waste Management System: General<br /><br />
US EPS Part 239 - 258 – Municipal and Industrial Solid Waste Management: General<br /><br />
<br /><br />

© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1. Background<br /><br />
Worley Parsons are undertaking a Definitive Feasibility Study for the Tonkolili Iron Ore<br /><br />
Project on behalf of African Minerals Limited. The proposed mine site is located in the<br /><br />
Sula Mountain range in the Tonkolili District of Sierra Leone. A railway line is planned<br /><br />
between the mine site and Tagrin Point, which includes the refurbishment of an existing<br /><br />
railway from Lunsar. Tagrin Point is the location for a proposed new deep water port<br /><br />
within Freetown Harbour at the estuary of the Sierra Leone River.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In addition, the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
refurbishment of existing port facilities at Pepel and mine works at Marampa are<br /><br />
planned.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A weather and climate study is required as part of the Environmental and Social Impact<br /><br />
Assessment (ESIA). This study needs to cover four geographic areas as follows:<br /><br />
Area 1: The mine and mine-infrastructure area.<br /><br />
Area 2: Tagrin Point and Pepel Port, including the marine conditions at offshore and<br /><br />
estuary locations.<br /><br />
Area 3: The railway alignment zone.<br /><br />
Area 4: The Sierra Leone River catchment area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Information on the spatial and temporal variations in rainfall is particularly important, with<br /><br />
the aim of estimating rainfall quantities for different durations and recurrence intervals.<br /><br />
This is required in order to estimate the supply of water available to the planned water<br /><br />
impoundment for processing at the mine site, and for the design of structures, e.g.<br /><br />
tailings, dams and cross-drainage. Information on mean wind speed and direction and<br /><br />
gust speeds are also required for the design of storage and stockpiling facilities, both at<br /><br />
the mine site and at the port. Also included in the study are averages of air temperature,<br /><br />
wet-bulb and dry-bulb temperature, relative humidity and evaporation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Finally<br /><br />
<br /><br />
information on dust levels during Harmattan Winds is required.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In this first stage of the meteorological study, a literature review has been carried out to<br /><br />
determine what data and information is already available, and its integrity and reliability.<br /><br />
This report will be split into sections covering each of the four areas specified above, and<br /><br />
will provide an overview of the climate of each of these areas as well as details about<br /><br />
the sources of data available.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 1: Map of the area of interest, showing the mine site, Pepel Port and Tagrin Point as red<br /><br />
triangles, joined by the railway alignment. Meteorological stations are marked, with relevant<br /><br />
stations labelled.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2. Climate Overview<br /><br />
This section has been synthesised from standard texts on West African climate, for<br /><br />
example Ojo (1977) and Hayward & Oguntoyinbo (1987), as well as reports and papers<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
specific to Sierra Leone including Mukharjee and Massaquoi (1973), and a 1941 report<br /><br />
from the Sierra Leone Meteorological Service.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Sierra Leone has a tropical monsoon climate, modified by local influences such as<br /><br />
decrease in temperature with altitude and variation in rainfall distribution induced by<br /><br />
topography. Characteristic of ‘monsoon’ climates are a wet season and a dry season<br /><br />
each year - driven by the annual cycle in the latitude at which the sun’s diurnal sky<br /><br />
trajectory passes directly overhead. Latitudinal and smaller-scale spatial differentials in<br /><br />
the sun’s heat energy distribution are the fundamental driving force for all weather and<br /><br />
seasons. In the case of West African countries close to the Gulf of Guinea, the latitude<br /><br />
of overhead sun-path (and hence maximum heating potential) lies out to sea to the south<br /><br />
in the northern hemisphere winter but over the Sahara Desert to the north in the northern<br /><br />
hemisphere summer. Given that air density is inversely proportional to temperature, the<br /><br />
latitude of maximum heating becomes a zone of rising air into which surface winds<br /><br />
converge. This zone is known as the Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ). Hence,<br /><br />
in the northern hemisphere winter, the ITCZ lies out to sea to the south and dry northeasterly winds, originating over the Sahara desert, blow towards it across Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
Conversely, in the northern hemisphere summer, the ITCZ lies to the north and moist<br /><br />
south-westerly winds from the Gulf of Guinea are drawn across Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Between March and November, a broad, east-west-aligned, rain-prone belt associated<br /><br />
with the moist air from the Gulf of Guinea advances northwards across Sierra Leone and<br /><br />
then retreats southwards again, drawn in the direction of the ITCZ.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
However, this<br /><br />
<br /><br />
simplistic explanation for Sierra Leone’s wet season fails to explain all of its features.<br /><br />
For instance, the axis of rain-prone belt is not co-incidental with the surface position of<br /><br />
the ITCZ, but displaced some 300-400 km to the south. In some years there is a brief lull<br /><br />
in the rains in the middle of the wet season while the entire rain-belt lies to the north,<br /><br />
despite there being a plentiful supply of moist Gulf air. The assumed direct coupling<br /><br />
between the ITCZ and the position of main seasonal rain belt has been questioned, and<br /><br />
the factors involved are complex and still not fully understood. To the north of the main<br /><br />
monsoon rain belt is a zone where thunderstorms and line squalls develop, and move<br /><br />
from east to west with the tropospheric winds.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hayward and Oguntoyinbo (1987) provide an overview of the climatology of the different<br /><br />
weather elements experienced in West Africa which results from the mechanisms<br /><br />
discussed above. Sunshine duration is greatest in the winter period, and much reduced<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
in the rainy season as cloudy days predominate. There is a slight increase in sunshine<br /><br />
from the south to the north in Sierra Leone. There is little seasonal variation in mean air<br /><br />
temperatures, with slightly hotter conditions in April and May.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Altitude influences<br /><br />
<br /><br />
temperature as well as other weather variables, with temperatures generally decreasing<br /><br />
with altitude. Mean wind speeds are generally low, and high impact gusts are rare. The<br /><br />
greatest wind speeds in the dry season occur when the ‘Harmattan’ wind blows from the<br /><br />
east or north-east, while in the wet season higher wind speeds are associated with<br /><br />
storms and squalls. The prevailing wind direction is from the south-west for most of the<br /><br />
year, especially near to the coast and especially during the monsoon. Annual average<br /><br />
rainfall is greatest along the coast, and decreases with distance inland. The authors<br /><br />
make a rough estimate of mean annual potential evaporation of 1000 mm for the Sierra<br /><br />
Leone area, with a peak in March. This is likely to be higher for inland areas than on the<br /><br />
coast.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3. Review of Other Relevant Literature<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Kamara and Jackson (1997a) apply a classification of rain days and dry days based on<br /><br />
soil-moisture to 8 stations in Sierra Leone. Days are divided into rain days ( 0.25 mm)<br /><br />
and dry days and sub-divided into “deficit”, “limiting”, “adequate” and “surplus” soil<br /><br />
moisture. In order to classify days based on soil moisture, a simple water balance model<br /><br />
based on rainfall and estimated evapotranspiration was used. The results, based on the<br /><br />
1948 to 1977 period, show that the most frequently occurring days are dry days with<br /><br />
deficit soil moisture and rain days with surplus soil moisture. This indicates a climatic<br /><br />
regime characterised by extreme conditions of dryness and wetness, which has<br /><br />
hydrological implications. The percentage of days in each category for three stations,<br /><br />
representative of the mine area, the railway and the port respectively, are shown in<br /><br />
Table 1. The percentage of dry days ranges from 54 % at Makeni to 62 % at Kabala.<br /><br />
There is also some analysis of seasonality in the different types.<br /><br />

Kabala<br /><br />

<br /><br />
5<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In a companion paper, Kamara and Jackson (1997b) use the classification above<br /><br />
together with maximum spells of these categories to divide Sierra Leone into eight agrohydrologic regions using cluster analysis. The mine site is located near to the boundary<br /><br />
between their Eastern Highlands region and Mid West region. Most of the railway is<br /><br />
covered by the Mid West region, except a small area around Port Loko which is in the<br /><br />
Northwest region. The port area is in their West Coast region.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Le Barbé et al (2002) analyse rainfall variability over West Africa during the 1950 to 1990<br /><br />
period. Although they do not include any data from Sierra Leone in their study, their<br /><br />
results that the 1951 to 1970 period was wet while the 1971 to 1990 period was dry are<br /><br />
likely to apply also to Sierra Leone. They estimate that the rainfall deficit of the latter<br /><br />
period compared to the former is 180 mm per year, which is fairly consistent over the<br /><br />
area. A similar result is obtained by Owusu and Waylen (2009), who find a 200 mm<br /><br />
deficit in the 1981 – 2000 period compared to the 1951 – 1970 period in Ghana.<br /><br />
Nicholson el al (2000) found that West African rainfall from 1968 to 1997 was 10 to 20 %<br /><br />
lower than that for 1931 to 1960.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
However, the greatest decreases have occurred<br /><br />
<br /><br />
further north in the Sahel and sub-humid areas. For the Soudano-Guinean region which<br /><br />
includes Sierra Leone, 29 out of 30 years from 1969 to 1998 had annual rainfall below<br /><br />
the long term mean. Most of the decrease was concentrated in the months of June and<br /><br />
September. Bowden (1980) analysed rainfall data from Sierra Leone for the 1949 to<br /><br />
1976 period, also finding a decreasing trend with a particularly dry period from 1970 to<br /><br />
1975 compared to a wet period from 1949 to 1955. Since 2000, however, the rainfall<br /><br />
has shown signs of increasing again (Owusu and Waylen, 2009).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4. Data Sources<br /><br />
4.1 Land Observations<br /><br />
The National Meteorological Library in Exeter holds a significant amount of<br /><br />
meteorological records from Sierra Leone in its archives. This is mostly in the form of<br /><br />
bound hard copy paper records. The records relate mainly to the period from 1874 to<br /><br />
1968; Sierra Leone was a British Colony until 1961 when it gained its independence.<br /><br />
The records are of observations of a range of weather variables including air<br /><br />
temperature, rainfall, wind speed and direction, humidity, thunderstorms, sunshine and<br /><br />
evaporation. There are records for many stations throughout Sierra Leone, but most of<br /><br />
the records are only at monthly time resolution, and many are only recorded for short<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
periods of time and have periods of missing or unreliable data.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Daily records are<br /><br />
<br /><br />
available for some stations, especially for Freetown and the airport at Lungi. A selection<br /><br />
of the available records has been digitised as part of this project, and full details of these<br /><br />
data can be found in Appendix 1.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The data is of high quality as it has been recorded by professional observers using<br /><br />
standard recording instruments. This is especially true for the main synoptic stations at<br /><br />
Freetown, Lungi, Makeni and Kabala. The digitisation of the paper records has been<br /><br />
carried out using double entry which has enabled careful quality checks to be made.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A weakness of this data is that the most recent records we currently have available to us<br /><br />
are over 50 years old, so that recent trends such as those caused by human-induced<br /><br />
climate change will not be accounted for. In particular, in light of the results of Le Barbe<br /><br />
et al (2002) and Nicholson et al (2000), it seems that the period for which we have most<br /><br />
data was significantly wetter than has been experienced in more recent decades. Some<br /><br />
more recent data has been obtained from contacts in the country however, and this has<br /><br />
enabled the data from Makeni and Lungi to be updated to 2009 (albeit with some<br /><br />
missing data). In addition, the spatial and temporal resolution of the observations is not<br /><br />
generally as high as is required for the applications involved in this project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
There is little data available for direct measurement of evaporation; the only data we<br /><br />
have is for 23 years from Lungi, and 3 years from Kortright. Hayward and Oguntoyinbo<br /><br />
(1987) explain the difficulties with measuring evaporation, with significant differences<br /><br />
depending on the measurement method used (Piché evaporimeters or raised or sunken<br /><br />
tank evaporimeters). Lungi used a Piché evaporimeter, while Kortright has data from all<br /><br />
three methods.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Piché measurements generally underestimate evaporation in high<br /><br />
<br /><br />
humidity conditions.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Three Automatic Weather Stations (AWS) have been set up for this project, two at the<br /><br />
mine site (Farangbaya and Numbara), and one at Pepel Port. They only have very short<br /><br />
data records so are likely to be of limited use, but could be useful for storm analysis if<br /><br />
10-minute rainfall data can be obtained. Griffiths (2010) presents graphically data for<br /><br />
September to November 2009. This report also mentions the intention to monitor dust<br /><br />
levels.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.2 Numerical Model<br /><br />
Another source of data used in this study is numerical model data. The model used is<br /><br />
the Met Office Unified Model® (the MetUM), the forecast model used operationally by<br /><br />
the Met Office to produce numerical weather forecasts both regionally and across the<br /><br />
entire globe. The Global model has a horizontal resolution of approximately 50 km in the<br /><br />
region of interest, and analysis data from this model was extracted for four grid points,<br /><br />
for the port, two locations along the railway and the mine site. The period for which data<br /><br />
is available is 2000 to 2009.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Numerical model data provides a full representation of atmospheric conditions for a<br /><br />
recent time period. It will be particularly useful for variables such as wind, temperature<br /><br />
and humidity. The coarse resolution of the global model means, however, that small<br /><br />
scale features and local orography will not be well represented. It would be possible to<br /><br />
carry out high resolution modelling simulations of the area to generate much more<br /><br />
accurate results, but this would be an extremely computer intensive exercise.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5. Area 1: Mine site<br /><br />
5.1 Climate overview<br /><br />
The mine site is located 165 km inland from the coast at Lungi in an ENE direction, and<br /><br />
is shown on the map (Figure 1) by red triangles marking the SW and NE extents of the<br /><br />
mine site. The Sula mountain range rises up to about 1000 m above sea level from an<br /><br />
extensive, gently undulating plateau of 300 m to the west and 400 m to the east.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The dry season runs from December to March, with very little rain or cloud. Especially<br /><br />
during December and January, the ‘Harmattan’ wind may occur, a dry wind blowing from<br /><br />
the east or north-east which leads to poor visibility due to the dust which it carries, as<br /><br />
well as a reduction in humidity.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rainfall at the mine site is spread much more evenly throughout the wet season than at<br /><br />
the coast. In the early wet season, thunderstorms start to develop in the highlands,<br /><br />
particularly during the afternoons. These thunderstorms are accompanied by strong<br /><br />
easterly squalls which may occasionally reach gale force in gusts. The monsoon rains<br /><br />
are shorter and less intense than further south and towards the coast, but there are still<br /><br />
<br /><br />
8<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
some longer periods of rain during July and August. Thundery activity resumes from<br /><br />
September to November as the wet season recedes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.2 Data Sources<br /><br />
There is very little observed data available for the mine site itself as it is a very remote<br /><br />
and mountainous area. We have short records of monthly data from Sakasakala (1936<br /><br />
to 1937), located at 576 masl (metres above sea level) in the centre of the mine site, and<br /><br />
from Tonkolili Farangbaira (1957 to 1961), also located in the mine area at 852 masl. To<br /><br />
supplement this, we have longer records from sites which are likely to be representative<br /><br />
of the mine area. The longest record comes from Kabala, which is 50 km to the north of<br /><br />
the mine site at an altitude of 444 masl. From this site we have a 50 year record (1913<br /><br />
to 1968) for a range of weather variables including rainfall, temperature, humidity and<br /><br />
wind. We also have 25 years of data from Mabonto, which is just to the south-west of<br /><br />
the mine area at the foot of the mountain range (129 masl).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In addition, we have<br /><br />
<br /><br />
monthly rainfall data from two sites on the plateau to the east, Sumbaria and Kaiyima.<br /><br />
The Sumbaria record has been extended from 20 years to a reconstituted series of 50<br /><br />
years for a study related to the Bumbuna Hydroelectric Project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
There is very limited daily data representative of the mine site, although the initial<br /><br />
hydrological assessment of the Tonkolili iron ore project (Griffiths, 2010) states that daily<br /><br />
rainfall data are available for Bumbuna (1991 – 1992) and Kabala (1951 – 1979). We<br /><br />
have not found any evaporation data representative of the mine area, or any solar<br /><br />
radiation data which would be required for its calculation. There is also no data available<br /><br />
on dust levels.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6. Area 2: Tagrin Point and Pepel Port<br /><br />
6.1 Climate overview<br /><br />
Tagrin Point and Pepel Port, marked by red triangles on the map (Figure 1) are located<br /><br />
on the northern side of the Sierra Leone harbour, opposite the Freetown peninsula. The<br /><br />
Freetown peninsula reaches an altitude of 800 m and provides some shelter to the<br /><br />
harbour. Tagrin Point is at the end of the railway alignment, 165 km WSW from the mine<br /><br />
site.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Sea temperatures off the coast of Freetown are around 27 °C with little seasonal<br /><br />
variation. Air temperatures also have little seasonal variation as the location is only 8.5°<br /><br />
north of the Equator. They remain hot throughout the year with a peak in April and May.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The dry season runs from December to March, and is characterised by fine days, with<br /><br />
perhaps a little cloud drifting in from the sea. The Harmattan wind sometimes reaches<br /><br />
the coast from the east, causing a reduction in visibility. Land breezes (from the northeast) often occur after sunrise, before the flow reverts to the prevailing south-westerly by<br /><br />
noon, reaching its peak speed in the early afternoon.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
April to June is the early wet season or the ‘pre-monsoon’ season. Some convective<br /><br />
thunderstorms start to develop (but less than further inland), carried from the east by the<br /><br />
easterly winds at mid-levels. These storms are often accompanied by strong easterly<br /><br />
winds which can cause choppy seas in the harbour. The rain showers in June and<br /><br />
October can be particularly intense. From July through to September is the monsoon<br /><br />
season, with large amounts of cloud and long periods of rain, at times occurring with<br /><br />
high intensity. The south-west (ocean-facing) side of the Freetown peninsula has an<br /><br />
annual average rainfall of 5000 - 6800 mm, while the north-eastern side of the peninsula<br /><br />
and the area on the opposite side of the harbour receive only an annual average of 3000<br /><br />
– 3500 mm due to the rain shadow effect of the peninsula’s orography.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rainfall<br /><br />
<br /><br />
increases with altitude, especially in the rain shadow, and decreases with distance from<br /><br />
the coast (Hayward and Clarke, 1996; Kamara and Jackson, 1997b).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Humidity is high throughout the year, but is especially high during the monsoon season.<br /><br />
The steady prevailing wind flows from the south-west during this period, especially<br /><br />
during the afternoon and evening. The persistence of SW winds may cause large waves<br /><br />
(swell). During October and November the wet season rapidly subsides, with further<br /><br />
convective showers occurring.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.2 Data Sources<br /><br />
We have data from a weather station which operated at Pepel Port from 1933 to 1967,<br /><br />
recording observations of rainfall, temperature and humidity.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
There is a significant<br /><br />
<br /><br />
amount of missing data within this record however, and a better record comes from the<br /><br />
site at Lungi Airport which is 12 km north of Tagrin Point. We have a 60 year record for<br /><br />
the 1947 to 2007 period, which includes daily and monthly rainfall and wind speed and<br /><br />
direction data, as well as monthly averages of temperature and humidity. Freetown is<br /><br />
<br /><br />
10<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
located just on the opposite side of the harbour entrance from Tagrin Point, and we have<br /><br />
a long record of daily rainfall data from here, running from 1916 to 1948. We also have<br /><br />
a 60 year record of monthly data from Freetown, covering rainfall, temperature, humidity<br /><br />
and wind speed. Other nearby stations for which we have shorter records include Kissy<br /><br />
Dockyard and Cline Town.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The availability and analysis of any relevant marine data will be investigated in the next<br /><br />
stage of the project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7. Area 3: Railway alignment<br /><br />
7.1 Climate overview<br /><br />
The railway alignment will run from the south-west of the mine area WSW for about 170<br /><br />
km to Tagrin Point, at the entrance to the harbour.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It goes from the edge of the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
highlands, at an altitude of about 400 masl, and passes through the interior low plains<br /><br />
which are rolling lowlands of swampy grasslands to the coastal lowland plain. The<br /><br />
proposed railway is marked on the map (Figure 1) as a black crossed line.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The decrease in altitude, the move towards the coast, and the movement to the WSW<br /><br />
with respect to the ITCZ means that there is a gradual change in the climate along the<br /><br />
length of the railway. Annual average rainfall decreases towards the coast, but most of<br /><br />
this decrease occurs during the height of the rainy season in July and August due to a<br /><br />
decreasing influence of the south-west monsoon.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
However, there is an increase in<br /><br />
<br /><br />
rainfall in the centre of the country around Makeni, as the escarpment which forms the<br /><br />
mine area triggers instability in the moist south-westerly winds (Kamara and Jackson,<br /><br />
1997b). There is also a slight increase in average cloudiness and humidity closer to the<br /><br />
coast. During February to April, fog sometimes forms in valleys after a calm night.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.2 Data Sources<br /><br />
There are several meteorological stations for which we have some data records located<br /><br />
near to the railway alignment at fairly regular spatial intervals. Starting from the mine<br /><br />
site and proceeding to the coast, we have a good rainfall record from Mabonto, near to<br /><br />
the mine site. The railway then passes through Makeni, a large city of around 100,000<br /><br />
people from where we have a long record (over 50 years) of rainfall, temperature and<br /><br />
humidity data, as well as a short record of wind speed and direction. Further rainfall<br /><br />
<br /><br />
11<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
data is available from Teko, just to the south of Makeni. The next major stop for the<br /><br />
railway is Marampa, the location of existing mine works. We have a 34 year record of<br /><br />
rainfall, temperature and humidity data from here. The railway next passes Port Loko,<br /><br />
which is situated on Port Loko Creek, which flows into the Sierra Leone River. We have<br /><br />
a good record of rainfall data form here, as well as a shorter record of temperature and<br /><br />
humidity.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
8. Area 4: Sierra Leone River catchment<br /><br />
The Rokel River is the largest river in Sierra Leone, and passes near to the mine area as<br /><br />
it flows in a south-westerly direction down to the Sierra Leone River estuary (Freetown<br /><br />
Harbour). It follows a similar path to the railway but further to the south. A smaller river,<br /><br />
Port Loko Creek, also feeds into the estuary, having crossed the railway at Port Loko.<br /><br />
Consequently the climate overview and data sources from the previous sections,<br /><br />
especially section 7 on the railway alignment, are also applicable to the river catchment.<br /><br />
This section provides a review of hydrological methods relevant to the applications<br /><br />
required and the data available.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
8.1 Hydrological Applications<br /><br />
The hydrometeorological and climate data that has been acquired has potential for a<br /><br />
number of uses to assist the hydrological design and planning of the different facets of<br /><br />
the Tonkolili Mine Project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The extensive historic rainfall record is useful in a number of respects. The availability of<br /><br />
long records of daily rainfall at Freetown and Lungi will provide useful information on<br /><br />
rainfall frequency and the estimation of probabilities (return periods). Aspects such as<br /><br />
persistence of wet and dry periods can be extracted from such data, which will be helpful<br /><br />
in determining the significance of dry season duration for water supply requirements.<br /><br />
However, both sites are close to the coast (Area 2), and may not be directly applicable to<br /><br />
the river catchment.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The extensive array of monthly rainfall should prove useful for the examination of the<br /><br />
range of seasonal conditions which will be important in planning water supply to the<br /><br />
mine camp, and broader aspects of water management, such as effluent disposal and<br /><br />
runoff control. These can be of particular importance to ecological management, where<br /><br />
tailings disposal to rivers is involved. An empirical means of estimating catchment runoff<br /><br />
<br /><br />
12<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
from annual average rainfall and catchment area is available from studies by the former<br /><br />
UK Institute of Hydrology (Meigh et al 1997). The basic equation produces an estimate<br /><br />
of mean annual flood (MAF), which can be adjusted by growth factor to return periods of<br /><br />
5 to 200 years. These will provide good first estimates for design floods at a range of<br /><br />
infrastructure, including cross-drainage along the railway line.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The monthly data provided (see Appendix 1) also include the maximum daily fall in each<br /><br />
month. At least one station within each area of interest has records of 50 years or more.<br /><br />
These record lengths should be capable of producing estimates of rainfall probabilities at<br /><br />
20-year and 50-year with some confidence. These data should also produce reasonable<br /><br />
estimates out to the 100-year probability, which may in turn provide verification and<br /><br />
refinement of estimates from empirical relationships.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The estimation of runoff from small catchments where no flow or rainfall measurements<br /><br />
are available commonly uses the well-established US Soil Conservation Service method<br /><br />
(WMO 2009). Selection of rainfall input in the estimating method allows for the rainfall to<br /><br />
be distributed over time, i.e. a storm profile. The example of data so far provided from<br /><br />
the AWS’s at the mine site present rainfall integrated over 10-minute intervals. Although<br /><br />
there is only a short record, if they contain a selection of discrete storm events these<br /><br />
data should provide some information to assist in identifying a representative storm<br /><br />
profile for local conditions. The data could also confirm or otherwise whether standard<br /><br />
design storm rainfall profiles, e.g. SCS or FSR (NERC 1975), could be applied. There<br /><br />
are also two published papers with storm hyetographs for locations on the Freetown<br /><br />
Peninsula which may be used for comparison (Davies et. al., 1966; Barrie, 2007).<br /><br />
Davies et. al. used sub-daily data from Freetown, while Barrie used annual maximum<br /><br />
daily rainfall amounts from Guma Valley, converted into shorter durations using a<br /><br />
reduction formula.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Some critical infrastructure such as tailings dams, which require a high level of safety in<br /><br />
their design, will require an estimate of extreme rainfall. For large dams, or those where<br /><br />
failure presents a high risk to life, it is common practice to estimate a probable maximum<br /><br />
flood (PMF). This requires the estimation of probable maximum precipitation (PMP), and<br /><br />
a recognised means of providing this is done by the Herschfield method (WMO 2009),<br /><br />
which uses the following equation:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rmax = Rmean + KSd<br /><br />
<br /><br />
13<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
where;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rmax is the PMP for a given duration<br /><br />
Rmean is the mean of the annual maximum rainfall series<br /><br />
K is a factor determined by Rmean and duration<br /><br />
Sd is the standard deviation of the annual maximum rainfall series.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Annual maximum daily rainfall from the longest available records at Freetown, Makeni<br /><br />
and Kabala should prove suitable for this estimation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9. Conclusions<br /><br />
This report reviews the currently available literature on the climate of Sierra Leone, and<br /><br />
describes a range of data sources which have been found to be available. The report<br /><br />
focuses especially on four areas of interest; the mine area, the port area, the railway<br /><br />
alignment linking the mine to the port, and the river catchment.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The data and methods described in this report will be used to provide more detailed<br /><br />
analysis of the climate of the areas of interest. This further analysis will focus on the<br /><br />
requirements of Worley Parsons as stated in the proposal. Although a large amount of<br /><br />
information has been obtained, data on some aspects are not sufficient to meet the<br /><br />
requirements. The types of analysis expected to be included in the next stage of the<br /><br />
project are as follows:<br /><br />
Rainfall: Long-term averages of monthly rainfall representative of each of the areas of<br /><br />
interest. Recent trends will be incorporated using data form Makeni and Lungi. Analysis<br /><br />
of intra-annual variability of rainfall, including return periods of wet and dry years.<br /><br />
Extreme value analysis of daily data, using annual maximum values, and PMP<br /><br />
estimation. Estimation of design storm profiles (return periods for sub-daily durations),<br /><br />
making use of limited daily and sub-daily rainfall data together with estimation methods.<br /><br />
Wind: Frequency analysis of wind speed and direction, which will include seasonal<br /><br />
variations and the likelihood of occurrence of winds speeds exceeding certain<br /><br />
thresholds. Data from Kabala, Makeni, Lungi and Freetown will be used to make<br /><br />
inferences about the areas of interest.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
14<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Temperature and humidity: Long-term averages of daily maximum, minimum and<br /><br />
mean temperature and relative humidity representative of each of the areas of interest,<br /><br />
including seasonal variations. Recent trends will be incorporated using data from<br /><br />
Makeni and Lungi.<br /><br />
Evaporation: Long-term averages of monthly evaporation from Lungi (as measured by<br /><br />
a Piché evaporimeter).<br /><br />
<br /><br />

1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1. Background<br /><br />
Worley Parsons are undertaking a Definitive Feasibility Study for the Tonkolili Iron Ore<br /><br />
Project on behalf of African Minerals Limited. The proposed mine site is located in the<br /><br />
Sula Mountain range in the Tonkolili District of Sierra Leone. A railway line is planned<br /><br />
between the mine site and Tagrin Point, which includes the refurbishment of an existing<br /><br />
railway from Lunsar. Tagrin Point is the location for a proposed new deep water port<br /><br />
within Freetown Harbour at the estuary of the Sierra Leone River.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In addition, the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
refurbishment of existing port facilities at Pepel and mine works at Marampa are<br /><br />
planned.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A weather and climate study is required as part of the Environmental and Social Impact<br /><br />
Assessment (ESIA). This study needs to cover four geographic areas as follows:<br /><br />
Area 1: The mine and mine-infrastructure area.<br /><br />
Area 2: Tagrin Point and Pepel Port<br /><br />
Area 3: The railway alignment zone.<br /><br />
Area 4: The Sierra Leone River catchment area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Information on the spatial and temporal variations in rainfall is particularly important, with<br /><br />
the aim of estimating rainfall quantities for different durations and recurrence intervals.<br /><br />
This is required in order to estimate the supply of water available to the planned water<br /><br />
impoundment for processing at the mine site, and for the design of structures, e.g.<br /><br />
tailings, dams and cross-drainage. Information on mean wind speed and direction and<br /><br />
gust speeds are also required for the design of storage and stockpiling facilities, both at<br /><br />
the mine site and at the port. Also included in the study are averages of air temperature,<br /><br />
relative humidity and evaporation. Also required if available is information on dust levels<br /><br />
during Harmattan Winds, and marine conditions offshore from Tagrin Point.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In the first stage of the meteorological study, a literature review was carried out to<br /><br />
determine what data and information is already available, and its integrity and reliability.<br /><br />
This second stage report will be split into sections covering each of the four areas<br /><br />
specified above, and will provide an overview of the climate of each of these areas,<br /><br />
details about the sources of data available, and a summary of analysed data.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 1: Map of the area of interest, showing the mine site, Pepel Port and Tagrin Point as red<br /><br />
triangles, joined by the railway alignment. Meteorological stations are marked, with relevant<br /><br />
stations labelled.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2. Climate Overview<br /><br />
This section has been synthesised from standard texts on West African climate, for<br /><br />
example Ojo (1977) and Hayward & Oguntoyinbo (1987), as well as reports and papers<br /><br />
specific to Sierra Leone including Mukharjee and Massaquoi (1973), and a 1941 report<br /><br />
from the Sierra Leone Meteorological Service.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Sierra Leone has a tropical monsoon climate, modified by local influences such as<br /><br />
decrease in temperature with altitude and variation in rainfall distribution induced by<br /><br />
topography. Characteristic of ‘monsoon’ climates are a wet season and a dry season<br /><br />
each year - driven by the annual cycle in the latitude at which the sun’s diurnal sky<br /><br />
trajectory passes directly overhead. Latitudinal and smaller-scale spatial differentials in<br /><br />
the sun’s heat energy distribution are the fundamental driving force for all weather and<br /><br />
seasons. In the case of West African countries close to the Gulf of Guinea, the latitude<br /><br />
of overhead sun-path (and hence maximum heating potential) lies out to sea to the south<br /><br />
in the northern hemisphere winter but over the Sahara Desert to the north in the northern<br /><br />
hemisphere summer. Given that air density is inversely proportional to temperature, the<br /><br />
latitude of maximum heating becomes a zone of rising air into which surface winds<br /><br />
converge. This zone is known as the Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ). Hence,<br /><br />
in the northern hemisphere winter, the ITCZ lies out to sea to the south and dry northeasterly winds, originating over the Sahara desert, blow towards it across Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
Conversely, in the northern hemisphere summer, the ITCZ lies to the north and moist<br /><br />
south-westerly winds from the Gulf of Guinea are drawn across Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Between March and November, a broad, east-west-aligned, rain-prone belt associated<br /><br />
with the moist air from the Gulf of Guinea advances northwards across Sierra Leone and<br /><br />
then retreats southwards again, drawn in the direction of the ITCZ.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
However, this<br /><br />
<br /><br />
simplistic explanation for Sierra Leone’s wet season fails to explain all of its features.<br /><br />
For instance, the axis of rain-prone belt is not co-incidental with the surface position of<br /><br />
the ITCZ, but displaced some 300-400 km to the south. In some years there is a brief lull<br /><br />
in the rains in the middle of the wet season while the entire rain-belt lies to the north,<br /><br />
despite there being a plentiful supply of moist Gulf air. The assumed direct coupling<br /><br />
between the ITCZ and the position of main seasonal rain belt has been questioned, and<br /><br />
the factors involved are complex and still not fully understood. To the north of the main<br /><br />
monsoon rain belt is a zone where thunderstorms and line squalls develop, and move<br /><br />
from east to west with the tropospheric winds.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hayward and Oguntoyinbo (1987) provide an overview of the climatology of the different<br /><br />
weather elements experienced in West Africa which results from the mechanisms<br /><br />
discussed above. Sunshine duration is greatest in the winter period, and much reduced<br /><br />
in the rainy season as cloudy days predominate. There is a slight increase in sunshine<br /><br />
from the south to the north in Sierra Leone. There is little seasonal variation in mean air<br /><br />
temperatures, with slightly hotter conditions in April and May.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Altitude influences<br /><br />
<br /><br />
temperature as well as other weather variables, with temperatures generally decreasing<br /><br />
with altitude. Mean wind speeds are generally low, and high impact gusts are rare. The<br /><br />
greatest wind speeds in the dry season occur when the ‘Harmattan’ wind blows from the<br /><br />
east or north-east, while in the wet season higher wind speeds are associated with<br /><br />
storms and squalls. The prevailing wind direction is from the south-west for most of the<br /><br />
year, especially near to the coast and especially during the monsoon. Annual average<br /><br />
rainfall is greatest along the coast, and decreases with distance inland. The authors<br /><br />
make a rough estimate of mean annual potential evaporation of 1000 mm for the Sierra<br /><br />
Leone area, with a peak in March. This is likely to be higher for inland areas than on the<br /><br />
coast.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3. Review of Other Relevant Literature<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Kamara and Jackson (1997a) apply a classification of rain days and dry days based on<br /><br />
soil-moisture to 8 stations in Sierra Leone. Days are divided into rain days ( 0.25 mm)<br /><br />
and dry days and sub-divided into “deficit”, “limiting”, “adequate” and “surplus” soil<br /><br />
moisture. In order to classify days based on soil moisture, a simple water balance model<br /><br />
based on rainfall and estimated evapotranspiration was used. The results, based on the<br /><br />
1948 to 1977 period, show that the most frequently occurring days are dry days with<br /><br />
deficit soil moisture and rain days with surplus soil moisture. This indicates a climatic<br /><br />
regime characterised by extreme conditions of dryness and wetness, which has<br /><br />
hydrological implications. The percentage of days in each category for three stations,<br /><br />
representative of the mine area, the railway and the port respectively, are shown in<br /><br />
Table 1. The percentage of dry days ranges from 54 % at Makeni to 62 % at Kabala.<br /><br />
There is also some analysis of seasonality in the different types.<br /><br />

Kabala<br /><br />
