moisture.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In a companion paper, Kamara and Jackson (1997b) use the classification above<br /><br />
together with maximum spells of these categories to divide Sierra Leone into eight agrohydrologic regions using cluster analysis. The mine site is located near to the boundary<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
between their Eastern Highlands region and Mid West region. Most of the railway is<br /><br />
covered by the Mid West region, except a small area around Port Loko which is in the<br /><br />
Northwest region. The port area is in their West Coast region.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Le Barbé et al (2002) analyse rainfall variability over West Africa during the 1950 to 1990<br /><br />
period. Although they do not include any data from Sierra Leone in their study, their<br /><br />
results that the 1951 to 1970 period was wet while the 1971 to 1990 period was dry are<br /><br />
likely to apply also to Sierra Leone. They estimate that the rainfall deficit of the latter<br /><br />
period compared to the former is 180 mm per year, which is fairly consistent over the<br /><br />
area. A similar result is obtained by Owusu and Waylen (2009), who find a 200 mm<br /><br />
deficit in the 1981 – 2000 period compared to the 1951 – 1970 period in Ghana.<br /><br />
Nicholson el al (2000) found that West African rainfall from 1968 to 1997 was 10 to 20 %<br /><br />
lower than that for 1931 to 1960.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
However, the greatest decreases have occurred<br /><br />
<br /><br />
further north in the Sahel and sub-humid areas. For the Soudano-Guinean region which<br /><br />
includes Sierra Leone, 29 out of 30 years from 1969 to 1998 had annual rainfall below<br /><br />
the long term mean. Most of the decrease was concentrated in the months of June and<br /><br />
September. Bowden (1980) analysed rainfall data from Sierra Leone for the 1949 to<br /><br />
1976 period, also finding a decreasing trend with a particularly dry period from 1970 to<br /><br />
1975 compared to a wet period from 1949 to 1955. Since 2000, however, the rainfall<br /><br />
has shown signs of increasing again (Owusu and Waylen, 2009).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4. Data Sources<br /><br />
4.1 Land Observations<br /><br />
The National Meteorological Library in Exeter holds a significant amount of<br /><br />
meteorological records from Sierra Leone in its archives. This is mostly in the form of<br /><br />
bound hard copy paper records. The records relate mainly to the period from 1874 to<br /><br />
1968; Sierra Leone was a British Colony until 1961 when it gained its independence.<br /><br />
The records are of observations of a range of weather variables including air<br /><br />
temperature, rainfall, wind speed and direction, humidity, thunderstorms, sunshine and<br /><br />
evaporation. There are records for many stations throughout Sierra Leone, but most of<br /><br />
the records are only at monthly time resolution, and many are only recorded for short<br /><br />
periods of time and have periods of missing or unreliable data.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Daily records are<br /><br />
<br /><br />
available for some stations, especially for Freetown and the airport at Lungi. A selection<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
of the available records has been digitised as part of this project, and full details of these<br /><br />
data can be found in Appendix 1.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The data is of high quality as it has been recorded by professional observers using<br /><br />
standard recording instruments. This is especially true for the main synoptic stations at<br /><br />
Freetown, Lungi, Makeni and Kabala. The digitisation of the paper records has been<br /><br />
carried out using double entry which has enabled careful quality checks to be made.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A weakness of this data is that the most recent records we currently have available to us<br /><br />
are over 50 years old, so that recent trends such as those caused by human-induced<br /><br />
climate change will not be accounted for. In particular, in light of the results of Le Barbe<br /><br />
et al (2002) and Nicholson et al (2000), it seems that the period for which we have most<br /><br />
data was significantly wetter than has been experienced in more recent decades. Some<br /><br />
more recent data has been obtained from contacts in the country however, and this has<br /><br />
enabled the data from Makeni and Lungi to be updated to 2009 (albeit with some<br /><br />
missing data). In addition, the spatial and temporal resolution of the observations is not<br /><br />
generally as high as is required for the applications involved in this project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
There is little data available for direct measurement of evaporation; the only data we<br /><br />
have is for 23 years from Lungi, 3 years from Bumbuna and Kortright. Hayward and<br /><br />
Oguntoyinbo (1987) explain the difficulties with measuring evaporation, with significant<br /><br />
differences depending on the measurement method used (Piché evaporimeters or raised<br /><br />
or sunken pan evaporimeters). Lungi used a Piché evaporimeter and Bumbuna used a<br /><br />
‘Class A’ pan, while Kortright has data from all three methods. Piché measurements<br /><br />
generally underestimate evaporation in high humidity conditions.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Three Automatic Weather Stations (AWS) have been set up for this project, two at the<br /><br />
mine site (Farangbaya and Numbara), and one at Pepel Port. Five months of 10-minute<br /><br />
data is available for Farangbaya (400 masl) and Numbara (800 masl). Due to the short<br /><br />
data records currently available these are of limited use, but will provide an indication of<br /><br />
likely conditions and data for storm analysis. Griffiths (2010) presents graphically data<br /><br />
for September to November 2009. This report also mentions the intention to monitor<br /><br />
dust levels, which was not proceeded with.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.2 Numerical Model<br /><br />
Another source of data used in this study is numerical model data. The model used is<br /><br />
the Met Office Unified Model (the MetUM), the forecast model used operationally by the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Met Office to produce numerical weather forecasts both regionally and across the entire<br /><br />
globe. The Global model has a horizontal resolution of approximately 50 km in the<br /><br />
region of interest, and analysis data from this model was extracted for four grid points,<br /><br />
for the port, two locations along the railway and the mine site. The period for which data<br /><br />
is available is 2000 to 2009.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Numerical model data provides a full representation of atmospheric conditions for a<br /><br />
recent time period. It was particularly useful for variables such as wind and humidity.<br /><br />
The coarse resolution of the global model means, however, that small scale features and<br /><br />
local orography will not be well represented. It would be possible to carry out high<br /><br />
resolution modelling simulations of the area to generate much more accurate results, but<br /><br />
this would be an extremely computer intensive exercise.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5. Hydrological Methods<br /><br />
The hydrometeorological and climate data that has been acquired has potential for a<br /><br />
number of uses to assist the hydrological design and planning of the different facets of<br /><br />
the Tonkolili Mine Project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The extensive array of monthly rainfall is useful for the examination of the range of<br /><br />
seasonal conditions which will be important in planning water supply to the mine camp,<br /><br />
and broader aspects of water management, such as effluent disposal and runoff control.<br /><br />
These can be of particular importance to ecological management, where tailings<br /><br />
disposal to rivers is involved. An empirical means of estimating catchment runoff from<br /><br />
annual average rainfall and catchment area is available from studies by the former UK<br /><br />
Institute of Hydrology (Meigh et al 1997). The basic equation produces an estimate of<br /><br />
mean annual flood (MAF), which can be adjusted by growth factor to return periods of 5<br /><br />
to 200 years. These will provide good first estimates for design floods at a range of<br /><br />
infrastructure, including cross-drainage along the railway line.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The monthly data provided (see Appendix 1) also include the maximum daily fall in each<br /><br />
month. At least one station within each area of interest has records of 50 years or more.<br /><br />
These record lengths are capable of producing estimates of rainfall probabilities at 20year and 50-year with some confidence.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
These data can also produce reasonable<br /><br />
<br /><br />
estimates out to the 100-year probability, and the 500-year probability with higher<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
uncertainty. The Generalised Extreme Value (GEV) distribution has also been used to<br /><br />
analyse extremes of annual rainfall totals in order to provide estimates of wet and dry<br /><br />
years for probabilities ranging from 5 years to 500 years.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The estimation of runoff from small catchments where no flow or rainfall measurements<br /><br />
are available commonly uses the well-established US Soil Conservation Service method<br /><br />
(WMO 2009). Selection of rainfall input in the estimating method allows for the rainfall to<br /><br />
be distributed over time, i.e. a storm profile.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The analysis of hourly rainfall data from Freetown (1944-47) and of 10-minute data from<br /><br />
automatic weather stations (AWS) operating at the mine site since September 2009<br /><br />
have given some insight into the intensity-duration characteristics of storm rainfall. The<br /><br />
data from Freetown suggests that there are two main types of rainfall event.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Firstly there are heavy downpours lasting a few hours, where one hour, usually in the<br /><br />
early part of the storm has a significantly high rainfall. The rainfall in a single hour can<br /><br />
amount to 70% of the storm total.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It would appear that this type of storm is most<br /><br />
<br /><br />
prevalent in the early part of the rainy season, late May or early June, and at the end of<br /><br />
the rains, in September and October. These convective rains are associated with the<br /><br />
advancing and retreating ITCZ.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The second type of storm is of longer duration, from 8 to 15hours, where individual peak<br /><br />
hourly intensities are lower than in convective storms, and moderate intensities may<br /><br />
persist for 2 to 3 hours in a longer period of light rainfall. Peak hourly intensities are only<br /><br />
20-30% of the storm total. This type of storm appears typical of the main part of the wet<br /><br />
season, July and August, when the ITCZ is to the north, and the equatorial rain band<br /><br />
predominates, with large depressions being the main rainfall producing mechanism.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The recent data obtained from AWS records provide examples of heavy rainfalls in<br /><br />
September and October. These are characteristically of short duration, matching the<br /><br />
end of season pattern noted at Freetown. However, it cannot be assumed that the midseason pattern will be the same, as orographic and local influences at the mine site may<br /><br />
affect rainfall intensities. Analysis of the data has produced information on durations<br /><br />
from 10 minutes to 3-4 hours. Neither source of data is sufficient to produce probability<br /><br />
estimates at different durations, but maximum or “envelope” values have been obtained.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In the absence of enough recorded data, rainfall intensity-duration data may be obtained<br /><br />
from generalised methods. Two are considered here:<br /><br />
1: From the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO, 1993). This reference provides a<br /><br />

From the characteristics of sub-daily rainfall information available, two storm durations<br /><br />

the annual maximum series of 1-day rainfalls, on the evidence that the 1-day data<br /><br />
almost invariably represents a rainfall event which has duration of less than 24-hours.<br /><br />

short duration with intense peaks, or of longer duration with a more extended period of<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Some critical infrastructure such as tailings dams, which require a high level of safety in<br /><br />
their design, will require an estimate of extreme rainfall. For large dams, or those where<br /><br />
failure presents a high risk to life, it is common practice to estimate a probable maximum<br /><br />
flood (PMF). This requires the estimation of probable maximum precipitation (PMP), and<br /><br />
a recognised means of providing this is done by the Herschfield method (WMO 2009),<br /><br />
which uses the following equation:<br /><br />
Rmax = Rmean + KSd<br /><br />
where Rmax is the PMP for a given duration, Rmean is the mean of the annual<br /><br />
maximum rainfall series, K is a factor determined by Rmean and duration, and Sd is the<br /><br />
standard deviation of the annual maximum rainfall series.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Annual maximum daily rainfall from the longest available records at Freetown, Makeni<br /><br />
and Kabala should prove suitable for this estimation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
12<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6. Area 1: Mine site<br /><br />
6.1 Climate overview<br /><br />
The mine site is located 165 km inland from the coast at Lungi in an ENE direction, and<br /><br />
is shown on the map (Figure 1) by red triangles marking the SW and NE extents of the<br /><br />
mine site. The Sula mountain range rises up to about 1000 m above sea level from an<br /><br />
extensive, gently undulating plateau of 300 m to the west and 400 m to the east.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The dry season runs from December to March, with very little rain or cloud. Especially<br /><br />
during December and January, the ‘Harmattan’ wind may occur, a dry wind blowing from<br /><br />
the east or north-east which leads to poor visibility due to the dust which it carries, as<br /><br />
well as a reduction in humidity.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rainfall at the mine site is spread much more evenly throughout the wet season than at<br /><br />
the coast. In the early wet season, thunderstorms start to develop in the highlands,<br /><br />
particularly during the afternoons. These thunderstorms are accompanied by strong<br /><br />
easterly squalls which may occasionally produce gusts at gale force. The monsoon<br /><br />
rains are shorter and less intense than further south and towards the coast, but there are<br /><br />
still some longer periods of rain during July and August. Thundery activity resumes from<br /><br />
September to November as the wet season recedes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.2 Data Sources<br /><br />
There is very little observed data available for the mine site itself as it is a very remote<br /><br />
and mountainous area. We have short records of monthly data from Sakasakala (1933<br /><br />
to 1937), located at 576 masl (metres above sea level) in the centre of the mine site, and<br /><br />
from Tonkolili Valley / Farangbaya (1957 to 1960), also located in the mine area at 400<br /><br />
masl.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
There is also a short record of monthly rainfall and evaporation data from<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Bumbuna (1972 to 1975). The mining will take place at a higher altitude of about 800<br /><br />
masl, and we have 11 months of data from a site at 850 masl in the mine area, as well<br /><br />
as 5 months of data from the AWS at Numbara.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
To supplement this, we have longer records from sites which may be representative of<br /><br />
the mine area. The longest record comes from Kabala, which is 50 km to the north of<br /><br />
the mine site at an altitude of 444 masl. From this site we have a 50 year record (1913<br /><br />
to 1968) for a range of weather variables including rainfall, temperature, humidity and<br /><br />
wind. We also have 25 years of data from Mabonto, which is just to the south-west of<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
13<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the mine area at the foot of the mountain range (129 masl). In addition, we have rainfall<br /><br />
data from two sites on the plateau to the east, Sumbaria and Kaiyima.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.3 Rainfall<br /><br />
The recent data from the AWS sites at Farangbaya and Numbara provide examples of<br /><br />
heavy rainfall in September and October. These are characteristically of short duration,<br /><br />
but it cannot be assumed that the mid-season pattern will be the same, as orographic<br /><br />
and local influences at the mine site may affect rainfall intensities. Maximum values for<br /><br />
durations from 10 minutes to one hour are shown in Table 8.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Extreme value analysis of annual maximum daily totals has been carried out on historic<br /><br />
data from Sumbaria and Kabala to obtain daily rainfall totals for a range of return periods<br /><br />

to carry out similar analysis. Of the 7 years of annual maxima data available from the<br /><br />
mine area, the average is 141 mm, with a range from 102 mm to 173 mm.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This<br /><br />
<br /><br />
suggests that Sumbaria and Kabala are not representative of the mine area, having<br /><br />
significantly lower rainfall intensities. The daily intensities from Makeni (Table 43) are<br /><br />
most likely to be representative of the mine area, but rainfall intensities at the mining<br /><br />
altitude of around 800 masl may be greater than those recorded at around 400 masl.<br /><br />
The annual maximum series have also been used to estimate a Probable Maximum<br /><br />
Precipitation of 566 mm for Makeni and 459 mm for Kabala.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
6.4 Temperature<br /><br />
As the temperature varies much less from year to year than rainfall, it is possible to<br /><br />
make good estimates of average temperature from only a few years of data. Table 16<br /><br />
and Figure 2 provide averages of daily maximum and minimum temperature for the mine<br /><br />
area and for Kabala, which is 50 km to the north. Temperature is strongly dependant on<br /><br />
altitude, so data from the mine area has been split into records coming from an altitude<br /><br />
of 400 – 500 masl (4 - 5 years of data), and records coming from about 800 masl (1 - 2<br /><br />
years of data). The values compare well with those from Kabala (for the 30 year period<br /><br />
1939 to 1968), with the main differences being that Kabala get a bit hotter in the daytime in February and March, and colder at night in December and January. As the high<br /><br />
altitude record is only 1 – 2 years, it has less confidence, but still gives a good indication<br /><br />
of the effect of altitude in lowering the daily maximum temperatures by approximately 2<br /><br />
°C. Daily minimum temperatures are also lower in t he wet season.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
6.5 Relative Humidity<br /><br />
Table 18 shows monthly averages of morning (usually measured at 09 GMT) and<br /><br />
afternoon (usually measured at 15 GMT) relative humidity (RH). The data from Kabala<br /><br />
is for the period 1955 to 1968, while data from Farangbaya (a site in the mine area at<br /><br />
400 masl) is for 1957 to 1961. AWS data from the mine site for the period October 2009<br /><br />
to January 2010 has been added to this. According to model data for the mine area<br /><br />
(Figure 3), 15 GMT is the time of minimum RH in the diurnal cycle, while 09 GMT is just<br /><br />
after the time of maximum RH, which occurs at around 06 GMT. The maximum daily RH<br /><br />
would be expected to be between 8 – 10 % higher than the 09 GMT values shown. The<br /><br />
annual cycle of RH reaches a peak in August, while the time of lowest RH is in the<br /><br />
afternoons of January to February when dry air is often brought from the north by the<br /><br />
Harmattan wind.<br /><br />

6.6 Evaporation<br /><br />
Monthly averages of evaporation for Bumbuna are given in Table 19. This shows that<br /><br />
evaporation reaches a peak in the monthly cycle in March, and dips to a low in<br /><br />
September. The actual values cannot be relied upon due to the short duration of the<br /><br />
record and uncertainty in differences between the measuring methods.<br /><br />

6.7 Wind<br /><br />
Wind speed and direction data is available from Kabala for the period 1955 to 1968, but<br /><br />

along with those from Kabala. Kabala has its highest mean wind speeds from January<br /><br />

<br /><br />
7. Area 2: Tagrin Point and Pepel Port<br /><br />
7.1 Climate overview<br /><br />
Tagrin Point and Pepel Port, marked by red triangles on the map (Figure 1) are located<br /><br />
on the northern side of the Sierra Leone harbour, opposite the Freetown peninsula. The<br /><br />
Freetown peninsula reaches an altitude of 800 m and provides some shelter to the<br /><br />
harbour. Tagrin Point is at the end of the railway alignment, 165 km WSW from the mine<br /><br />
site.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Sea temperatures off the coast of Freetown are around 27 °C with little seasonal<br /><br />
variation. Air temperatures also have little seasonal variation as the location is only 8.5°<br /><br />
north of the Equator. They remain hot throughout the year with a peak in April and May.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The dry season runs from December to March, and is characterised by fine days, with<br /><br />
perhaps a little cloud drifting in from the sea. The Harmattan wind sometimes reaches<br /><br />
the coast from the east, causing a reduction in visibility. Land breezes (from the northeast) often occur after sunrise, before the flow reverts to the prevailing south-westerly by<br /><br />
noon, reaching its peak speed in the early afternoon.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
25<br /><br />
<br /><br />
April to June is the early wet season or the ‘pre-monsoon’ season. Some convective<br /><br />
thunderstorms start to develop (but less than further inland), carried from the east by the<br /><br />
easterly winds at mid-levels. These storms are often accompanied by strong easterly<br /><br />
winds which can cause choppy seas in the harbour. The rain showers in June and<br /><br />
October can be particularly intense. From July through to September is the monsoon<br /><br />
season, with large amounts of cloud and long periods of rain, at times occurring with<br /><br />
high intensity. The south-west (ocean-facing) side of the Freetown peninsula has an<br /><br />
annual average rainfall of 5000 - 6800 mm, while the north-eastern side of the peninsula<br /><br />
and the area on the opposite side of the harbour receive only an annual average of 3000<br /><br />
– 3500 mm due to the rain shadow effect of the peninsula’s orography.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rainfall<br /><br />
<br /><br />
increases with altitude, especially in the rain shadow, and decreases with distance from<br /><br />
the coast (Hayward and Clarke, 1996; Kamara and Jackson, 1997b).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Humidity is high throughout the year, but is especially high during the monsoon season.<br /><br />
The steady prevailing wind flows from the south-west during this period, especially<br /><br />
during the afternoon and evening. The persistence of SW winds may cause large waves<br /><br />
(swell). During October and November the wet season rapidly subsides, with further<br /><br />
convective showers occurring.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.2 Data Sources<br /><br />
We have a high quality, long period record from Lungi Airport, which can be considered<br /><br />
representative of Tagrin Point, although being 12 km to the north it may be less affected<br /><br />
by the rain shadow of the Freetown Peninsula than Tagrin Point. The data runs from<br /><br />
1947 to 2007, although some variables are only available for part of this time. The<br /><br />
record includes daily and monthly rainfall; wind speed and direction, as well as monthly<br /><br />
averages of temperature, humidity and evaporation. Freetown is located just on the<br /><br />
opposite side of the harbour entrance from Tagrin Point and we have a long record of<br /><br />
daily rainfall data from here, running from 1916 to 1948, as well as 60 years of monthly<br /><br />
data for a range of variables from 1909 to 1968. Other nearby stations for which we<br /><br />
have shorter records include Kissy Dockyard and Cline Town.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
We also have data from a weather station which operated at Pepel Port from 1933 to<br /><br />
1967, recording observations of rainfall, temperature and humidity.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Although this<br /><br />
<br /><br />
stations is possible less reliable, and is a shorter record with some missing data, it will<br /><br />
be useful for assessing the climate of Pepel Port.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
26<br /><br />

Table 30: Monthly statistics of rainfall for Freetown, 1923 to 1968.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Table 31 shows monthly statistics from Lungi for the 1971 to 2005 period. This shows<br /><br />
that there was considerably less rainfall during this period than during the earlier period<br /><br />
of 1923 to 1968. During the May to October period, the rainfall amount was 81 % of the<br /><br />
1923 to 1968 average, while for the November to April period it was just 56 %. The wet<br /><br />
season has become shorter and less intense on average compared to the earlier period.<br /><br />
Figure 4 shows that there has been a clear decreasing trend in rainfall over the whole<br /><br />
period since 1923, and annual rainfall has rarely exceeded 3000 mm in the last 20<br /><br />
years.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
7.5 Relative Humidity<br /><br />
Table 36 shows monthly averages of morning (usually measured at 09 GMT) and<br /><br />
afternoon (usually measured at 15 GMT) relative humidity (RH).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The data from<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Freetown and Pepel is for the 30 year period 1939 to 1968, while data from Lungi is for<br /><br />
1947 to 1968 and 1991 to 2009. There is less data for the afternoon, however, as these<br /><br />
values were not recorded from 1939 to 1942 nor from 1943 to 1946. According to model<br /><br />
data for the port area, 15 GMT is the time of minimum RH in the diurnal cycle, while 09<br /><br />
GMT is just after the time of maximum RH, which occurs at around 06 GMT. The<br /><br />
maximum daily RH would be expected to be between 2 – 3 % higher than the 09 GMT<br /><br />
values shown. The annual cycle of RH reaches a peak in August to September, while<br /><br />
the time of lowest RH is in the afternoons of January to February.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
7.6 Evaporation<br /><br />
Table 37 provides monthly averages of evaporation. Although the data from the Piche<br /><br />
evaporimeters at Lungi and Kortright are expressed in different units, they seem to be<br /><br />
roughly comparable.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
These values give a good indication of the annual cycle of<br /><br />
<br /><br />
evaporation, but are not directly comparable to free water measurements made using a<br /><br />
pan or tank, and should only be considered as an index of evaporation. The annual<br /><br />
cycle of evaporation at Lungi (Table 37) has a maximum in March and a minimum in<br /><br />
August. Free water evaporations measurements such as those from the raised tank are<br /><br />
known to be susceptible to over-reading during heavy rainfall events, and this seems to<br /><br />
have occurred at Kortright giving dubious high values for July to September.<br /><br />

7.7 Wind<br /><br />
Wind speed and direction data recorded at three times during the day is available from<br /><br />
Lungi for the period 1947 to 1968, but the speed is only recorded as a Beaufort Force.<br /><br />
Although this makes precise analysis difficult, the Beaufort Force values have been<br /><br />
converted into knots and monthly mean wind speeds are shown in Table 38. These<br /><br />
values are higher than the monthly mean wind speeds for the 1984 to 2007 period, also<br /><br />
from Lungi. The model data for the port area is more similar to the data from Lungi for<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
36<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the earlier period. Both of these sources show a double peak in the annual cycle, in<br /><br />
March – April and July – August. The lowest mean speeds occur during the November<br /><br />
to January period.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Monthly maximum gust speeds are also recorded at Lungi from 1954 to 1968, and<br /><br />
averages of these are also shown in Table 38. May and June are the months with the<br /><br />
highest gust speeds; these are the months when regular squalls pass through the area.<br /><br />
The highest recorded gust speed was 62 knots in June 1966.<br /><br />

The data from Lungi for 1947 to 1968 has been analysed for the frequency of high wind<br /><br />
speeds (Table 39).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This shows that high wind speeds of over 17 knots are rare<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(occurring less than once a year on average). Most of the occurrences of winds > 22<br /><br />
knots (forces 6+) were in May or June, but most of the force 5 winds (17 – 21 knots)<br /><br />
were in July and August, especially in the afternoon. There were three events with wind<br /><br />
speed of at least 28 knots recorded in the 20 year period.<br /><br />

7.8 Marine<br /><br />
Significant wave heights have been extracted from model data for a grid point just off the<br /><br />
coast from Freetown, and a summary of the analysis of this data is provided in this<br /><br />
section.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
38<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Annually, most waves approach from the southwest or west-southwest, most of these<br /><br />
(87%) 2.0 metres or less. Wave periods range from zero to 11 seconds with most waves<br /><br />
(77%) having periods between 5 and 7 seconds.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Monthly frequencies of wave heights are provided in Table 41. The roughest month is<br /><br />
July, with seas in the rough category: (2.6 metres to no higher than 3.5 metres) making<br /><br />
up 0.6 % of the time. There is more directional spread in July and August with more<br /><br />
waves approaching from the south or south-southwest (23% in July, 29% in August,<br /><br />
reducing to 14% in September).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Even during these months, the majority of waves<br /><br />
<br /><br />
approach from the southwest or west-southwest. The quietest month is December with<br /><br />
69% of waves heights modelled at 1 metre or below, compared to 9% in this category in<br /><br />
July.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
8. Area 3: Railway alignment<br /><br />
8.1 Climate overview<br /><br />
The railway alignment will run from the south-west of the mine area WSW for about 170<br /><br />
km to Tagrin Point, at the entrance to the harbour.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It goes from the edge of the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
highlands, at an altitude of about 400 masl, and passes through the interior low plains<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
39<br /><br />
<br /><br />
which are rolling lowlands of swampy grasslands to the coastal lowland plain. The<br /><br />
proposed railway is marked on the map (Figure 1) as a black crossed line.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The decrease in altitude, the move towards the coast, and the movement to the WSW<br /><br />
with respect to the ITCZ means that there is a gradual change in the climate along the<br /><br />
length of the railway. Annual average rainfall decreases towards the coast, but most of<br /><br />
this decrease occurs during the height of the rainy season in July and August due to a<br /><br />
decreasing influence of the south-west monsoon.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
However, there is an increase in<br /><br />
<br /><br />
rainfall in the centre of the country around Makeni, as the escarpment which forms the<br /><br />
mine area triggers instability in the moist south-westerly winds (Kamara and Jackson,<br /><br />
1997b). There is also a slight increase in average cloudiness and humidity closer to the<br /><br />
coast. During February to April, fog sometimes forms in valleys after a calm night.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
8.2 Data Sources<br /><br />
There are several meteorological stations for which we have some data records located<br /><br />
near to the railway alignment at fairly regular spatial intervals. Starting from the mine<br /><br />
site and proceeding to the coast, we have a good rainfall record from Mabonto, near to<br /><br />
the mine site. The railway then passes through Makeni, a large city of around 100,000<br /><br />
people from where we have a long record (over 50 years) of rainfall, temperature and<br /><br />
humidity data, as well as a short record of wind speed and direction. Further rainfall<br /><br />
data is available from Teko, just to the south of Makeni. The next major stop for the<br /><br />
railway is Marampa, the location of existing mine works. We have a 34 year record of<br /><br />
rainfall, temperature and humidity data from here. The railway next passes Port Loko,<br /><br />
which is situated on Port Loko Creek, which flows into the Sierra Leone River. We have<br /><br />
a good record of rainfall data form here, as well as a shorter record of temperature and<br /><br />
humidity.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
8.3 Rainfall<br /><br />
Extreme value analysis of annual maximum daily totals has been carried out on historic<br /><br />
data from Port Loko, Marampa and Makeni to obtain daily rainfall totals for a range of<br /><br />
return periods, and the results are shown in Tables 42 and 43. The annual maximum<br /><br />
series at Makeni has also been used to estimate a Probable Maximum Precipitation of<br /><br />
566 mm.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Monthly statistics of rainfall for the 1923 to 1968 period are shown in Tables 46, 47 and<br /><br />

area however, and is more evenly spread over the wet season months. The three<br /><br />
locations have similar annual rainfall profiles, although Makeni has more rainfall, and<br /><br />

Table 48: Monthly statistics of rainfall for Makeni, 1923 to 1968.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Table 49 shows monthly statistics from Makeni for the 1971 to 2009 period (note that<br /><br />
this period has some missing data – 19% of months are missing – for example 1999 to<br /><br />
2002). In contrast to Lungi, this shows that there was very little difference in average<br /><br />
annual rainfall compared to the earlier period of 1923 to 1968. However, like Lungi,<br /><br />
there has been a decrease in rainfall during the dry season, with 68 % of the 1923 to<br /><br />
1968 period falling during the November to April period. This was compensated by a<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
43<br /><br />
<br /><br />
small increase in rainfall for the months of July and August in the recent period. Figure 7<br /><br />
shows that there has been no overall significant trend in rainfall over the whole period<br /><br />
since 1923. Note however that the two driest years in the Lungi record (1999 and 2000)<br /><br />
are missing from Makeni. There does seem to have been a greater variability of annual<br /><br />
rainfall in the last 20 years.<br /><br />

8.4 Temperature<br /><br />
Monthly averages of daily maximum and minimum air temperature for the 30 year period<br /><br />
from 1939 to 1968 are shown in Table 53 and Figure 8. Again missing values have<br /><br />
been estimated where possible.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Maximum temperatures are higher and minimum<br /><br />
<br /><br />
temperatures lower compared to the port area, meaning that there is a greater diurnal<br /><br />
range. The highest temperatures occur in March, especially further inland at Makeni.<br /><br />
The lowest minimum (night-time) temperatures occur in January and the highest in May.<br /><br />

8.5 Relative Humidity<br /><br />
Table 55 shows monthly averages of morning (usually measured at 09 GMT) and<br /><br />
afternoon (usually measured at 15 GMT) relative humidity (RH). Values are provided for<br /><br />
Port Loko (1954 to 1968), Marampa (1939 to 1968) and Makeni (1939 to 1968 and 1980<br /><br />
to 2009). There is less data for the afternoon, however, as these values were not<br /><br />
recorded from 1939 to 1942 or from 1943 to 1946. According to model data for the<br /><br />
Makeni area (Figure 10), 15 GMT is the time of minimum RH in the diurnal cycle, while<br /><br />
09 GMT is just after the time of maximum RH, which occurs at around 06 GMT. The<br /><br />
maximum daily RH would be expected to be between 7 – 9 % higher than the 09 GMT<br /><br />
values shown. The annual cycle of RH reaches a peak in August, while the time of<br /><br />
lowest RH occurs in the afternoons from January to March. At this time, the humidity<br /><br />
can vary considerably from year to year depending on the prevalence of the dry<br /><br />
Harmattan wind. In January 1986, for example, the average RH at 15 GMT at Makeni<br /><br />
was only 21 %, and model data shows the RH dropping below 10 % on occasions.<br /><br />

8.6 Evaporation<br /><br />
No evaporation data is available for stations along the railway alignment.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Average<br /><br />
<br /><br />
evaporation is likely to be between that for Lungi (Table 37) and Bumbuna (Table 19).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
8.7 Wind<br /><br />
Monthly wind speed and direction data is available from Makeni for the period 1949 to<br /><br />
1954, but the speed is only recorded in Beaufort Force categories. Also available are<br /><br />
mean wind speeds for 1990 to 2009, but 40% of months are missing in this period.<br /><br />
Model data has been extracted for Port Loko and Makeni areas. The model data is<br /><br />
probably the best source of data for mean wind speeds, but it does not capture extremes<br /><br />
well. The recent recorded data at Makeni gives surprisingly low wind speeds, possibly<br /><br />
due to poor exposure of the anemometer. Table 56 shows that the model data has a<br /><br />
double peak in the annual cycle, in March – April and July – August. The lowest mean<br /><br />
speeds occur in November to December. The model mean wind speed at Makeni is<br /><br />
lower than that at Port Loko, which in turn is lower than the mean wind speed at Lungi.<br /><br />
This suggests that the mean wind speed decreases inland (in an easterly direction), and<br /><br />
that the mean wind speed for Marampa is likely to be between that for Lungi and<br /><br />
Makeni.<br /><br />

52<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9. Area 4: Sierra Leone River catchment<br /><br />
The Rokel River is the largest river in Sierra Leone, and passes near to the mine area as<br /><br />
it flows in a south-westerly direction down to the Sierra Leone River estuary (Freetown<br /><br />
Harbour). It follows a similar path to the railway but further to the south. A smaller river,<br /><br />
Port Loko Creek, also feeds into the estuary, having crossed the railway at Port Loko.<br /><br />
Consequently the climate overview and data sources from the previous sections,<br /><br />
especially section 8 on the railway alignment, are also applicable to the river catchment,<br /><br />
depending on which part of the catchment is of interest.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
10. Conclusions<br /><br />
A large amount of information and data on the weather and climate of Sierra Leone has<br /><br />
been gathered, and much of it digitised. This report presents a summary of the analysis<br /><br />
which has been carried out on this data.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Although a large amount of data has been obtained, there are limitations in the data<br /><br />
which may affect the results. In particular for the mine area, there is a lack of long series<br /><br />
of data in the area, with the closest long period stations being Kabala and Makeni.<br /><br />
Analysis has shown that Makeni is fairly representative of the mine area for rainfall, and<br /><br />
that Kabala is fairly representative for relative humidity and wind. However, the mine<br /><br />
area is mountainous and the climate is likely to change considerably on a small spatial<br /><br />
scale. In particular, the climate at the mining site itself, which is approximately 800 masl,<br /><br />
may be quite different to that at an elevation of 400 masl. The two AWS sites which are<br /><br />
at different elevations in the mine area currently only have five months of data available,<br /><br />
and it would be beneficial to re-visit the analysis once a record of at least one year has<br /><br />
built up.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Available long series of rainfall data has enabled extreme value analysis to be carried<br /><br />
out, both on annual maximum daily rainfall totals and on annual totals. Using the results<br /><br />
from this analysis, rainfall estimates for return periods from 5 years to 500 years have<br /><br />
been made, with increasing uncertainty as the return period increases. Theoretical<br /><br />
storm profiles, corroborated by evidence from the small amount of available sub-daily<br /><br />
data, have been used together with the estimated return levels of daily rainfall, to<br /><br />
<br /><br />
© Crown copyright 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
53<br /><br />
<br /><br />
generate design storm profiles. These have been used to estimate maximum 1 hour<br /><br />
and 5-minute rainfalls for 10 and 50 years return periods.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Monthly averages of mean, daily maximum and minimum air temperature, and relative<br /><br />
humidity have been provided. Wet bulb temperature is not included as it was generally<br /><br />
not recorded separately, but it can be derived from air temperature and relative humidity<br /><br />
if required. Evaporation data is limited, and the measurement methods used have their<br /><br />
weaknesses. Monthly averages have been included for the port and mine areas; these<br /><br />
give a good indication of variations in the annual cycle but their accuracy cannot be<br /><br />
relied upon.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In some cases, data from Met Office numerical models has been used to supplement<br /><br />
available observations, and this has provided useful information on seasonal variations<br /><br />
in mean wind speed and wave height. The available wind data is not suitable for<br /><br />
extreme value analysis due to the short records available of precise, short duration<br /><br />
values. The data has been used to provide guidance on frequencies of wind speed and<br /><br />
direction. No data on dust levels is available, but the wind direction results give an<br /><br />
indication of the frequency of occurrence of the Harmattan wind at different times of<br /><br />
year.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Summary of report, Phase 3 of the vegetation studies <br /><br />
at the Tonkolili mine site, Sierra Leone <br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Xander van der Burgt & Benedict John Pollard<br /><br />
Herbarium, Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Riverine forest and river with rocky areas suitable for rheophytes<br /><br />
<br /><br />
March 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
THIS REPORT IS PRELIMINARY AND CONFIDENTIAL<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Executive Summary  <br /><br />
Four habitats of high conservation value were identified by this study and the two preceding<br /><br />
vegetation studies:<br /><br />
1. The strips of forest along the Tonkolili River and the river bed of this river, from Kegbema<br /><br />
and Farangbaia up to the confluence with the Rokel River, and the strips of forest along the<br /><br />
Rokel River near this confluence.<br /><br />
2. The forest patch to the southwest of the village Kegbema.<br /><br />
3. The summits of the Numbara deposit, due to the presence of a sizeable population of the<br /><br />
conservation priority species Pseudovigna sp. nov.<br /><br />
4. The seasonally wet (seepage) grassland on the southern slopes of Marampon, which is host<br /><br />
to a concentration of high conservation priority species.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The conservation status of the summit of the Numbara deposit may be lowered if further areas<br /><br />
hosting Pseudovigna sp. nov. are identified outside the mining license area. Opportunities<br /><br />
may exist for African Minerals to establish conservation measures for this species, e.g. seed<br /><br />
collection and translocation of specimens from Numbara to a suitable locality outside the<br /><br />
mining license area, which may also lower the conservation status of the species. Similar<br /><br />
approaches may be relevant to the grassland on the southern slopes of Marampon.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Unlike the summits of Numbara, the high conservation status of the forest strips and forest<br /><br />
patch noted above is now fixed and will not change as a result of further field studies.<br /><br />
Translocation of tree species is not feasible; therefore infrastructure should be planned outside<br /><br />
these areas where at all possible. Where work is essential in these areas, river crossings should<br /><br />
be made with the greatest care, especially if there are trees present, or rocks in the river bed.<br /><br />
Planned river crossing sites should be surveyed for plant species of conservation concern by a<br /><br />
botanist and well in advance of construction work to allow the crossing location to be<br /><br />
modified based on survey results (i.e. the proximity of haul road already constructed to the<br /><br />
river should not be such that it constrains adjustments to the crossing point).<br /><br />
Apart from mining infrastructure, the forest patches are also threatened by an increase in<br /><br />
construction wood extraction by local people. The increased demand for houses in the study<br /><br />
area seems to be a cause of increased logging activities. Since the increased pressure on the<br /><br />
last remaining forest patches seems at least partly linked to the activities of African Minerals,<br /><br />
the company may wish to identify options with appropriate partners (e.g. the government of<br /><br />
Sierra Leone) to prevent further damage to these forest patches. As part of this process,<br /><br />
opportunities to compensate villagers for preserving the forest patch could be explored.<br /><br />
In addition, there are also several habitats of medium conservation value identified, including<br /><br />
a forest strip along a small stream in the rail loop area; forests around Nerekoro; the forest<br /><br />
patch on the western slopes of the Simbili deposit; mangroves in the Tagrin and Pepel Port<br /><br />
lease areas and Port Loko; inland valley swamps in the Tagrin port camp and infrastructure<br /><br />
area, railroad marshalling yard, Petifu Junction, Port Loko area and along the haul road route<br /><br />
between Lunsar and the western bank of Rokel River, and forest in the area of the River Toka<br /><br />
rail and road crossing points. The construction of any infrastructure in these habitats must be<br /><br />
carefully planned and managed.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The results and recommendations in this summary are subject to changes based on the<br /><br />
outcome of confirmatory identification of the 461 botanical samples collected. The<br /><br />
conservation status of some habitats may also change as a result of any further detailed field<br /><br />
studies that are undertaken.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1. Introduction <br /><br />
This is a summary of the Phase 3 vegetation studies for Tonkolili mine, Sierra Leone. For<br /><br />
more information the reader is referred to the full fieldwork report (in preparation) and to the<br /><br />
previous two reports on the vegetation studies at Tonkolili by the Royal Botanic Gardens,<br /><br />
Kew (van der Burgt, 2009; Darbyshire & van der Burgt, 2010).<br /><br />
The Phase 3 vegetation survey was divided into two tasks:<br /><br />
• Phase 3a – detailed characterisation of baseline conditions at the mine site and the first 20<br /><br />
km of the haulage road.<br /><br />
• Phase 3b – rapid assessment field surveys of the preferred tailings option, remainder of the<br /><br />
haulage road to Lunsar, existing rail corridor, Pepel port, railroad marshalling yards, Petifu<br /><br />
Junction and Tagrin port.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Collectively the sites surveyed comprised key areas for the Early Cash Flow (ECF) project<br /><br />
and the Tonkolili project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Fieldwork was undertaken between 23 February and 12 March 2010, by Abdulai Feika and<br /><br />
Matthew James from the Njala University Herbarium; Kabbie Kanu and Julius Sesay from the<br /><br />
Fourah Bay College Herbarium; and Xander van der Burgt, Benedict Pollard and Sue Frisby<br /><br />
from the Herbarium of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew.<br /><br />
A total of 461 botanical samples were collected during the present study. Most samples were<br /><br />
preliminarily identified in the field; with confirmatory identification taking place at Kew. This<br /><br />
report is based on the preliminary field identification data. The full report will describe<br /><br />
species based on confirmed identification data.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2. Methods <br /><br />
<br /><br />
The methodology of the present study is similar to that described in the two previous reports<br /><br />
(van der Burgt, 2009; Darbyshire & van der Burgt, 2010). In summary, the Phase 3a<br /><br />
methodology resembles that of Phase 2 and Phase 3b methodology resembles that of Phase 1.<br /><br />
Aerial photography, satellite imagery and drawings were used to pre-identify different<br /><br />
vegetation types. These were visited methodically to characterise each major habitat type<br /><br />
identified from the maps and identify key plant species. Habitat types of potential<br /><br />
conservation concern were then assessed in more detail. Limited botanical specimen sampling<br /><br />
was carried out to enable identification of typical or unusual species, and to record the<br /><br />
presence of species thought to be of conservation concern. The conservation importance of a<br /><br />
habitat (described here as high, medium or low) is preliminarily assessed in this report<br /><br />
according to two factors, as described below.<br /><br />
1) The presence/absence of plant species assessed as being globally threatened, following<br /><br />
the criteria set out in IUCN (2001):<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
HIGH if there are Endangered (EN) plant species present.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Medium if there are Vulnerable (VU) plant species present.<br /><br />
Low if there are no plant species of conservation concern present.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2) The ecological structure and function of a habitat (assessed qualitatively). Three habitat<br /><br />
types that represent original vegetation are considered as being or as likely to be of<br /><br />
medium conservation concern, especially where levels of disturbance are low:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Forest vegetation, which, in the study area and indeed in the whole of Sierra Leone,<br /><br />
has become so rare that any more or less natural forest vegetation must be considered<br /><br />
to be at least of medium conservation importance.<br /><br />
Mangroves are a species-poor habitat type botanically, but are of considerable<br /><br />
ecological value in terms of their structure and function, and are likely to harbour a<br /><br />
wide variety of avifaunal and other animal assemblages.<br /><br />
Inland valley swamps represent an ecologically rich habitat with a valuable<br /><br />
structure and function, containing some rare plant species (notably Aeschynomene<br /><br />
deightonii) and providing habitat for a broad range of plant species and other taxa,<br /><br />
such as invertebrate groups (e.g. Coleoptera, Odonata etc). Further detailed surveys<br /><br />
of selected inland valley swamps are required to better understand the overall plant<br /><br />
species composition and more fully assess the presence/absence of potential species<br /><br />
of conservation concern. Water flow and drainage within these valleys should not be<br /><br />
significantly altered by AML during construction in this habitat type.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Three plant species from the list of conservation species (all VU) were found to be both<br /><br />
common in the study area and to regenerate easily in disturbed habitats. Therefore, the<br /><br />
presence of one or more of these species would not necessarily classify the habitat as being of<br /><br />
medium conservation importance:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• Afzelia africana (IUCN: VU) is a tree that was often found near villages and in farmbush.<br /><br />
• Hallea stipulosa (IUCN: VU) is a tree that colonises inland valley swamps, and is<br /><br />
expected to invade the tailings area and other swampy disturbed areas as once the level of<br /><br />
disturbance declines.<br /><br />
• Terminalia ivorensis (IUCN: VU) is a secondary forest tree that was found to be abundant<br /><br />
in some parts of the secondary vegetation in the study area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3. Limitations and assumptions <br /><br />
• The results and recommendations in this summary are subject to changes based on the<br /><br />
outcome of confirmatory identification of the 461 botanical samples collected.<br /><br />
• For some study areas aerial photography and/or satellite imagery was not available or of<br /><br />
insufficient resolution to enable targeting of sampling locations likely to be of conservation<br /><br />
concern.<br /><br />
• Phase 3b consisted of rapid assessment field surveys only. These rapid assessments should<br /><br />
be followed by a detailed botanical inventory of the areas that were found to be of potential<br /><br />
conservation concern. The conservation status of habitats may change subject to further<br /><br />
detailed field studies.<br /><br />
• The survey was somewhat restrained by ongoing changes in the haul road alignment<br /><br />
during the survey and by logistical constraints (limited time for fieldwork, limited<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
telecommunications facilities and a period of fuel shortages which prevented or delayed<br /><br />
planned travel).<br /><br />
• Further limitations and assumptions are noted in the previous two reports (see van der<br /><br />
Burgt, 2009 and Darbyshire & van der Burgt, 2010).<br /><br />
<br /><br />

overall conservation importance has been assessed in terms of the actual or likely presence of<br /><br />
plant species of conservation concern. Further information for each location is available in<br /><br />
Appendix A.<br /><br />

 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
5. Conclusions <br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Fieldwork has identified four habitats of high conservation value. Two of these habitats<br /><br />
intersect with project activities that are fixed in space (the planned open pits at Numbara and<br /><br />
Marampon) and for which avoidance options do not exist. Consequently, African Minerals<br /><br />
may need to pursue alternative conservation measures for the plant species found in the<br /><br />
affected habitats, such as seed collection and translocation of specimens to suitable localities<br /><br />
outside the mining license area. The other two habitats intersect with project activities that are<br /><br />
not fixed in space (e.g. construction of the haul road and related river crossings) and therefore<br /><br />
avoidance can play a role in minimising impacts. Where work is essential in these habitats,<br /><br />
care should be taken to minimise the felling of trees and to select river crossings with the least<br /><br />
impact.<br /><br />
Fieldwork has also identified a number of habitats of medium conservation value around the<br /><br />
mine area and along the transport corridor to the coast. The construction of any infrastructure<br /><br />
in these habitats must also be carefully planned and managed. Where possible, habitats of<br /><br />
medium conservation value should be avoided.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6. Recommendations <br /><br />
<br /><br />
See Table 1 (above) for location-specific recommendations.<br /><br />

ANNEX A<br /><br />
A.1 Results for Phase 3a <br /><br />
Detailed characterisation of baseline conditions at the mine site and the first 20 km of the<br /><br />
haulage road.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A.1.1. River Rokel crossing points <br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Key habitats: riverine forest, river channel communities, various secondary habitats.<br /><br />
Species of conservation concern: Aphanocalyx pteridophyllus, Copaifera salikounda,<br /><br />
Dialium pobeguinii, Gilbertiodendron sp. nov.?.<br /><br />
Conservation importance: the conservation value of the riverine forest strip is HIGH, not<br /><br />
only because of the presence of conservation species, but also because of its structure and<br /><br />
high species richness. This forest is one of the last remaining examples of the original forest<br /><br />
vegetation in the study area.<br /><br />
Recommendations: river crossings should be made with the greatest care, especially if<br /><br />
uprooting of trees is likely. During construction of bridges, tree felling should be kept to an<br /><br />
absolute minimum. No tree trunks should be used for the construction of the bridge itself, for<br /><br />
scaffolding or for temporary bridges.<br /><br />
Notes on the haul road crossing: The haul road crossing point selected by the South African<br /><br />
contractor Jeffares & Green, 9° 00’ 59.5’’ N; 11° 49’ 53.5’’ W is situated close to the point<br /><br />
selected by WorleyParsons. On the east side there is a large rock slab (visible on Google<br /><br />
Earth) which has prevented the growth of trees. There is enough space here to construct a haul<br /><br />
road bridge without uprooting any trees. However, in the forest strip immediately north and<br /><br />
south of this point conservation species do occur. On the west side there is a narrow strip of<br /><br />
forest with several species of conservation concern. Nevertheless, this locality seems most<br /><br />
appropriate from a botanical point of view.<br /><br />
Notes on the rail crossing: Two possible rail crossing points were selected by the botanical<br /><br />
teams, close to the point selected by WorleyParsons: Locality 1 at 9° 00’ 44.0’’ N; 11° 49’<br /><br />
49.0’’ W and locality 2 at 9° 00’ 29.0’’ N; 11° 49’ 44.5’’ W. At locality 1 there is a narrow<br /><br />
strip of forest on the east side. On the west side there is a palm plantation bordering the river,<br /><br />
but just upstream there is a Dialium pobeguinii tree (a species of conservation concern). At<br /><br />
locality 2 there is a small gap in the forest strip on the east side, and a strip of forest on the<br /><br />
west side. No conservation species were seen. A number of trees will have to be felled here; a<br /><br />
few of these may be of conservation concern although none were seen.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A.1.2. Haul road, Rokel River to Nerekoro; airport, mine village, rail loop <br /><br />
Key habitats: riverine forest, river channel communities, various secondary habitats.<br /><br />
Conservation importance: HIGH (riverine forest), medium (forest strip along small stream<br /><br />
in rail loop area), low (remaining area).<br /><br />
Species of conservation concern: Dialium pobeguinii; Gilbertiodendron sp. nov.?; a number<br /><br />
of other species (which will be listed in the report).<br /><br />
Recommendations: river crossings should be made with the greatest care, especially if there<br /><br />
are trees or rocks in the river bed. Planned river crossings should be surveyed for species of<br /><br />
conservation concern by a botanist. If there are no trees and no large rocks in the river bed, a<br /><br />
river crossing could be made.<br /><br />
Notes: Most of the strip of forest along the Tonkolili River in this area contains conservation<br /><br />
species. Trees of Dialium pobeguinii (possibly EN) were found in most places on muddy soil<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
10<br /><br />
<br /><br />
along the Tonkolili River from the village of Balaya up to the Rokel River, and along the<br /><br />
Rokel River. The airport area was briefly surveyed; the area appears to be of low conservation<br /><br />
concern. The location of the Mine village was not visited; the aerial photographs of the site do<br /><br />
not show any forest and it also appears to be of low conservation concern. The rail loop was<br /><br />
partly surveyed. The forest strip along a small stream in this area should be avoided, because<br /><br />
of the presence of conservation species. This forest strip is classified as medium conservation<br /><br />
concern, but the remaining area around the rail loop is probably of low conservation concern.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A.1.3. Haul road, Nerekoro to Farangbaia <br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Key habitats: riverine forest, river channel communities, various secondary habitats.<br /><br />
Conservation importance: HIGH (riverine forest), medium (forests around Nerekoro), low<br /><br />
(remaining area).<br /><br />
Species of conservation concern: Neolemonniera clitandrifolia, Tessmannia baikiaeoides.<br /><br />
For further species see Darbyshire & van der Burgt, 2010.<br /><br />
Recommendations: river crossings should be made with the greatest care, especially if there<br /><br />
are trees, or rocks in the river bed. Planned river crossings should be surveyed for species of<br /><br />
conservation concern by a botanist.<br /><br />
Notes: During the stay of the botanical team in Farangbaia, Jeffares & Green, a contractor<br /><br />
from Cape Town began the construction of the haul road. They made a new crossing of the<br /><br />
Tonkolili River just south of Farangbaia. The contractor was determined to avoid uprooting<br /><br />
trees, not only because this is time-consuming, but also because they are aware of the<br /><br />
importance of forest in Sierra Leone from a conservation perspective. The contractor was<br /><br />
planning to put the road alignment south of Nerekoro and south of the forest patches around<br /><br />
this village. The road was then planned to turn to the northwest, towards the Rokel River, but<br /><br />
beyond Nerekoro the exact route was not yet determined.<br /><br />
The locality of the second Tonkolili River haul road crossing on the map made by Worley<br /><br />
parsons (issued 22 Feb 2010) is unsuitable from a botanical point of view, due to the presence<br /><br />
of several species of conservation concern, two of which are new to the survey:<br /><br />
Neolemonniera clitandrifolia (IUCN: EN) and Tessmannia baikiaeoides (possible VU or EN).<br /><br />
In general, plant species of conservation concern are common along the Tonkolili River, but<br /><br />
careful searching by a botanist may give a suitable crossing point.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A.1.4. Farangbaia Forest Reserve <br /><br />
Key habitats: forest, farmland and secondary thicket.<br /><br />
Conservation importance: medium.<br /><br />
Species of conservation concern: Cryptosepalum tetraphyllum.<br /><br />
Notes: The Farangbaia Forest Reserve may be a good candidate for a habitat restoration<br /><br />
project, with translocation of forest species from the deposit sites. This could provide a high<br /><br />
profile positive conservation project for AML in collaboration with both national government<br /><br />
and local communities.<br /><br />
Recommendations: Explore the potential use of Farangbaia Forest Reserve as an offset site<br /><br />
in greater detail.<br /><br />
Farangbaia Forest Reserve was surveyed previously, but is summarised here for comparative<br /><br />
purposes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
11<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A.1.5. Kegbema forest patch <br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Key habitats: forest.<br /><br />
Conservation importance: the conservation value of this forest patch is HIGH, not only<br /><br />
because of the presence of conservation species, but also because of its structure and high<br /><br />
species richness. This forest is one of the last remaining examples of the original forest<br /><br />
vegetation in the study area.<br /><br />
Species of conservation concern: see previous report.<br /><br />
Coordinates: 9°00’26’’ N; 11°42’06’’W.<br /><br />
Notes: Plot 12, set up in the Kegbema forest patch southwest of the village of Kegbema, in<br /><br />
December 2009, has been partly destroyed by local people extracting wood for use in<br /><br />
construction. The activity of loggers in the area is increasing, supposedly because of increased<br /><br />
demand for timber for construction of houses and furniture. This increased demand is possible<br /><br />
linked to the inward migration of people to the study area in search of jobs at the Tonkolili<br /><br />
project. The socio-economic team visited the village of Kegbema and may be able to develop<br /><br />
an initial overview of the social context behind the destruction of Plot 12 (note: the socioeconomic team has not reported at the time of preparation of this botanical report).<br /><br />
Recommendations: The Kegbema forest patch is the best preserved example of the original<br /><br />
forest vegetation in the area, and is also inside the Farangbaia Forest Reserve. Since the<br /><br />
increased pressure on the last remaining forest patches seems at least partly linked to the<br /><br />
activities of African Minerals, the company may wish to identify options with appropriate<br /><br />
partners (e.g. the government of Sierra Leone) to prevent further damage to these forest<br /><br />
patches. As part of this process, opportunities to compensate villagers for preserving the forest<br /><br />
patch could be explored.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A.1.6. Numbara deposit <br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Key habitats: natural grassland.<br /><br />
Conservation importance: HIGH.<br /><br />
Species of conservation concern: Pseudovigna sp. nov.<br /><br />
Recommendations: establishment of in-situ and ex-situ conservation measures such as seed<br /><br />
collecting and translocation to sites outside the mining license area. Further information is<br /><br />
available in van der Burgt (2009) and Darbyshire & van der Burgt (2010).<br /><br />
Notes: The natural grassland on the summit area of Numbara was revisited to look for<br /><br />
pyrophytes; plants that grow shortly after fire. Only a few were found. Some of the<br /><br />
Pseudovigna sp. nov. plants were resprouting, while some others were still dormant.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A.1.7. Marampon deposit <br /><br />
The Marampon deposit was not visited during the present trip, but was surveyed during<br /><br />
previous fieldwork (see Darbyshire & van der Burgt, 2010).<br /><br />
Key habitats: Hill summit (wooded) grassland, seasonally wet grassland, Afrotrilepis<br /><br />
tussocks, secondary herbaceous Chromolaena scrub, secondary thicket and woodland.<br /><br />
Conservation importance: HIGH<br /><br />
Species of conservation importance: Pseudovigna sp. nov. (single plant), Bryaspis<br /><br />
humularioides subsp. falcistipulata, Schizachyrium lomaense and Panicum<br /><br />
glaucocladum.<br /><br />
Recommendations: due regard should be given to measures to mitigate or offset the impact<br /><br />
of species losses through a combination of ex situ conservation measures (seed storage and<br /><br />
plant nursery schemes), translocation to secure sites and identification of comparable sites for<br /><br />
protection and/or management.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
12<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Notes: The most important seasonally wet grassland for conservation identified to date is that<br /><br />
on the S slopes of Marampon at the north end of the Simbili-Marampon saddle. The small<br /><br />
area of seepage here holds three species of conservation concern including two potentially<br /><br />
Endangered species: Bryaspis humularioides subsp. falcistipulata and Schizachyrium<br /><br />
lomaense (the third, Panicum glaucocladum, is considered Vulnerable).<br /><br />
Marampon was surveyed previously, but is summarised here for comparative purposes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A.1.8. Simbili deposit <br /><br />
Key habitats: secondary forest, farmbush, secondary grassland.<br /><br />
Conservation importance: medium.<br /><br />
Species of conservation concern: Cryptosepalum tetraphyllum, Entandrophragma<br /><br />
cylindricum, Garcinia kola and Guarea cedrata.<br /><br />
Recommendations: further fieldwork should be considered, covering times of the year that<br /><br />
will supplement the timing of previous visits.<br /><br />

A.2.9. Port Loko Strict Nature Reserve <br /><br />
Key habitats: agroforestry plantations, grassland vegetation.<br /><br />
This is a production forest of plantation species, with a dedicated nursery raising seedlings,<br /><br />
especially of Tectona grandis, Acacia mangium and Gmelina arborea.<br /><br />
Conservation importance: low (potentially HIGH).<br /><br />
Species of conservation concern: none identified in the reserve, but an undescribed species<br /><br />
of Macropodiella (Podostemaceae) has been identified just downstream from the reserve.<br /><br />
Recommendations: The river running by the reserve to be surveyed for rheophytes,<br /><br />
especially Macropodiella sp. nov. The Ministry of Forests should be encouraged to undertake<br /><br />
seed collection using local people and specialists and subsequently introduce species of<br /><br />
conservation concern into their propagation programme at the Port Loko Strict Nature<br /><br />
Reserve plant nursery facility for inclusion in planting mixes. Raise awareness of threatened<br /><br />
species and opportunity for reintroductions.<br /><br />

A.2.11. River Toka rail and road crossing points <br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Key habitats: riverine/gallery forest, swampy patches, grassland vegetation.<br /><br />
Conservation importance: low/potentially medium.<br /><br />
Species of conservation concern: none identified.<br /><br />
Notes: some species identified from this swampy gallery/riverine forest, e.g. Cynometra<br /><br />
vogelii and Uapaca guineensis, were also recorded from the Rokel River strip of forest which<br /><br />
suggests some affinities between these two areas. Time did not allow additional specimen<br /><br />
sampling along the River Toka forest, but it is possible that species of conservation concern<br /><br />
found at River Rokel also occur along this strip. This type of forest is very rare across the<br /><br />
surveyed area and, as such, merits further investigation.<br /><br />
Recommendations: maintain these crossing points, ensuring water flow is uninterrupted.<br /><br />
Extend survey work of this riverine vegetation beyond crossing points for approximately 1<br /><br />
km in either direction to determine presence or absence of conservation species. This could<br /><br />
enable better understanding of the distribution of rare forest plants across this similar, but<br /><br />
rarely occurring, habitat type in different locations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Recommendations: a detailed survey could be considered here, especially on the few forest<br /><br />
patches and the inland valley swamps, but such work is unlikely to reveal many species of<br /><br />
conservation concern.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
REPORT ON THE VEGETATION SURVEY & BOTANICAL INVENTORY OF THE<br /><br />
TONKOLILI PROJECT AREA, SIERRA LEONE<br /><br />
8 February 2010<br /><br />

<br /><br />
AUTHORS AND CONTRIBUTORS:<br /><br />
I. Darbyshire, X. van der Burgt, M. Cheek, R. Clark, G. Marchant & J. Moat. RBG, Kew<br /><br />
A.M.B. Feika & M.S. James. National Herbarium of Sierra Leone, Njala University<br /><br />

<br /><br />
2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY<br /><br />
th<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A vegetation and plant species survey was conducted in the Tonkolili Project area from 24 November<br /><br />
th<br /><br />
to 11 December 2009, building on the 3.5 day reconnaissance survey carried out in September. A<br /><br />
combination of plot-based sampling and walk-over survey was used to characterise the different<br /><br />
vegetation types and to record the plant species found within each habitat. A reconnaissance-scale<br /><br />
survey of the three potential tailings or mine-related infrastructure locations was also conducted.<br /><br />
Whilst the dominant vegetation cover (c. 90%) of the three iron-ore deposits and immediate<br /><br />
surroundings is a mosaic of farmland and fallow bushland of low conservation value, the remaining<br /><br />
areas are found to contain a range of natural or semi-natural vegetation types. Five of these<br /><br />
vegetation types are of conservation significance: hillslope forest, riverine forest, river channel plant<br /><br />
communities, hill summit (wooded) grassland and seasonally wet grassland.<br /><br />
34 plant species of conservation concern (IUCN Red list species or candidate species) have so far<br /><br />
been recorded on the deposits and in the potential tailings or infrastructure locations, of which nine are<br /><br />
considered of high conservation priority. Included within these nine are two newly discovered species,<br /><br />
apparently unique or nearly unique to the Project area based upon current knowledge: Pseudovigna<br /><br />
sp. nov., restricted to the hill summit grasslands, and Eriocaulon sp. nov., found only in the river<br /><br />
channel east of Farangbeya village.<br /><br />
The highest number of species of conservation concern is found in the riverine strip of forest east of<br /><br />
Farangbeya village and the nearby hillslope forest southwest of Kegbema village, both falling within<br /><br />
potential tailings or infrastructure option 4. These areas are considered to be of highest conservation<br /><br />
importance within the Project area based upon the botanical surveys conducted to date. It is<br /><br />
recommended that efforts are made to protect this river system and adjacent forests from any<br /><br />
disturbance by future mine-related activity. Although degraded, the riverine forest in potential tailings<br /><br />
or infrastructure option 1 has been found to contain three conservation priority species so far, with<br /><br />
more likely to be uncovered by more intensive survey. The reconnaissance survey of option 5<br /><br />
revealed no species or habitats of high conservation concern.<br /><br />
On the deposits themselves, the seasonally wet (seepage) grassland on the southern slopes of<br /><br />
Marampon contains a concentration of high conservation priority species, and the hill summit<br /><br />
grassland on Numbara is considered to be of importance due to its large colony of Pseudovigna sp.<br /><br />
nov.<br /><br />
Measures should be put in place to mitigate or offset the impact of these losses through a combination<br /><br />
of ex situ conservation measures (seed storage and plant nursery schemes), translocation to secure<br /><br />
sites and identification of comparable sites for protection and/or management. A range of<br /><br />
recommendations are provided for future plant-related survey and conservation work to meet these<br /><br />
requirements.<br /><br />
Plot data analyses indicates that our survey work to date has not been exhaustive and it is quite<br /><br />
possible that further survey work, particularly at different seasons, will uncover more species of<br /><br />
conservation concern within the Project area.<br /><br />
