4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1. INTRODUCTION<br /><br />
This report summarises the findings of the vegetation survey and plant inventory of the Tonkolili iron<br /><br />
ore mining project (henceforth the Project) in Sierra Leone, under license to African Minerals Ltd. The<br /><br />
th<br /><br />
th<br /><br />
survey was conducted over a two week period from 24 November to 11 December and builds upon<br /><br />
the 3.5 day reconnaissance vegetation survey conducted at the Project site in September 2009. The<br /><br />
field team for the Nov-Dec visit were: Xander van der Burgt, Ruth Clark & Iain Darbyshire (RBG Kew);<br /><br />
Emily Robinson (SRK Consulting UK); Abdulai Feika & Matthew James (Njala University); Kabie Kanu<br /><br />
& Julius Sesay (Fourah Bay College), splitting into two field teams over a 10-day survey period, one<br /><br />
team remaining on site for an extra three days.<br /><br />
This report will feed into the wider Environmental & Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) and Feasibility<br /><br />
Study for the Project, being conducted by Worley Parsons Ltd and SRK Consulting (UK) Ltd. The<br /><br />
scope of the current phase of this work was set out by SRK Consulting (UK) Ltd, the principal points<br /><br />
being to:<br /><br />
• undertake an intensive two-week botanical survey of the three deposits on Numbara, Marampon<br /><br />
and Simbili Hills (figure 1) and immediate vicinity likely to be impacted by mining activity<br /><br />
• identify and characterise the vegetation types and inventory the plant species present on the<br /><br />
deposits with emphasis upon those habitats and species of key conservation concern that will need<br /><br />
to be taken into consideration by the Project Feasibility Study<br /><br />
• identify potential impacts on the vegetation in the study area and provide recommendations for<br /><br />
mitigation of these impacts including protection of species of conservation concern and initial<br /><br />
identification of potential offset areas<br /><br />
• undertake a reconnaissance-level survey of the vegetation of the areas potentially affected by<br /><br />
tailings deposits and/or mine-related infrastructure, including the identification of any sensitive or<br /><br />
“no go” areas.<br /><br />
The Project area is here defined as the area covered by the mining exploration license plus the areas<br /><br />
identified as potential tailings or infrastructure locations. However, the focus of the study within this<br /><br />
wider area is the three deposits (Numbara, Marampon and Simbili) plus the three options (1, 4 & 5)<br /><br />
identified to be the most likely locations for tailings and infrastructure.<br /><br />
Due to delays in obtaining the SPOT satellite imagery required for adequate delimitation of the<br /><br />
vegetation types in the Project area, the vegetation map which accompanies this document is<br /><br />
currently in preparation and will be delivered separately in a supplementary report.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Background information on the vegetation and environment of the Project area<br /><br />
The Project lies within Tonkolili District of Northern Province, Sierra Leone, in the southern portion of<br /><br />
the Sula mountain chain. The Sula Mts are one of a series of isolated highland regions in northern and<br /><br />
eastern Sierra Leone which together form the westernmost extent of the Guinea (or Loma-Man)<br /><br />
Highlands which extend to western Côte d’Ivoire. This is one of the richest regions in West Africa for<br /><br />
plant diversity, with significant numbers of endemic (unique) and rare species.<br /><br />
The Sula Mts coincide with a belt of higher annual rainfall than other regions of Sierra Leone with the<br /><br />
exception of the coastal strip. Rainfall here is highly seasonal, the wet season beginning slowly in<br /><br />
March–April and peaking in July–September. The dry season typically begins in mid-October with very<br /><br />
little rain falling from mid-November through to March.<br /><br />
The altitude at the Project area ranges from 120 m in the Tonkolili River valley, to 830 m on the peak<br /><br />
of Simbili Hill. Submontane elements of the Guinea highlands vegetation extend down to altitudes well<br /><br />
below 1000 m in this part of Sierra Leone, hence the vegetation of the Project area is likely to contain<br /><br />
some submontane elements in addition to lowland elements. Lowland and submontane forest have<br /><br />
suffered extensive losses throughout West Africa, resulting in large and potentially threatening<br /><br />
declines in the range of many species unique to this region. The Tonkolili region is no exception,<br /><br />
where forest, the natural climax vegetation of most of the region, is now largely restricted to narrow<br /><br />
strips along river valleys and on the steepest slopes, and sacred groves and community forests.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 1: location of the three deposits and proposed tailings options at the Tonkolili mine site, reproduced with permission from SRK Consulting UK Ltd. (bold Red Line = total<br /><br />
area covered by the mining exploration license).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
There has been a long history of botanical exploration in Sierra Leone, especially during the British<br /><br />
colonial period, with extensive historic collections held in herbaria, particularly at RBG Kew. Whilst the<br /><br />
larger Loma Mts and Tingi Hills close to the Guinea border have been visited by many botanists, few<br /><br />
previous botanical expeditions appear to have been made in the southern Sula Mts and the vegetation<br /><br />
of this region is not well documented.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2. METHODOLOGY<br /><br />
2.1 DEPOSITS AND ADJACENT TONKOLILI RIVER VALLEY<br /><br />
The three deposits, Simbili, Marampon and Numbara, and adjacent areas likely to be directly impacted<br /><br />
by the mine were surveyed in detail using a combination of walk-over survey (botanical patrol) and plot<br /><br />
sampling. Priority was given to the habitats identified as of potential conservation concern from the<br /><br />
reconnaissance survey. A total of 12 plots were surveyed (table 1, fig. 2). Different vegetation types<br /><br />
were sampled using different plot sizes:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Forest - 25 m × 25 m Hall & Swaine (1981) plots, used widely in West African vegetation survey,<br /><br />
in which every vascular plant species is recorded and, unless identified on the spot with certainty,<br /><br />
vouchered; additionally every tree ≥ 10 cm dbh (diameter at breast height, c. 130 cm) is recorded,<br /><br />
together with basic plot data. As the strip of riverine forest is too narrow to permit a 25 × 25 m<br /><br />
square, plot T4 in this habitat was modified to 12.5 m × 50 m.<br /><br />
Grassland & wooded grassland - 10 m × 10 m plots. Data recorded as above but all trees ≥ 5 cm<br /><br />
dbh are recorded together with estimates of % ground cover for each herb species. Plot T7 is a<br /><br />
composite transect of eight 10 m × 10 m plots aimed primarily at providing more data on the tree<br /><br />
species within this habitat.<br /><br />
Secondary thicket / woodland - 10 m × 10 m plots. Data recorded as for wooded grassland plots.<br /><br />
The three plots taken are intended to provide an overview of this vegetation type which is<br /><br />
considered to be of low conservation concern.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Figure 2: location of vegetation survey plots, important collecting localities in the Project area and potential offset<br /><br />
sites surveyed.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Primarily for reasons of time-constraint and logistics, rather than using pre-selected random sampling<br /><br />
within each vegetation type, the plots were selected on the ground, choosing typical representative<br /><br />
areas of each habitat type.<br /><br />
Standard field data forms were used to collect data in each plot, the information collected including<br /><br />
georeference, altitude, aspect, soil type, evidence of disturbance (human influence, fire), overview<br /><br />
notes on the vegetation including dominant species, and photographs of the plot to record the<br /><br />
vegetation structure together with close-ups of species of interest. Plot forms and plot species lists are<br /><br />
not presented in this report but are available on request.<br /><br />
The survey teams did not enter any sacred forest groves (society bush) and the AML Public Relations<br /><br />
Officer, Atkins Koroma, was consulted prior to entering any forest areas / selecting forest plot localities<br /><br />
to ensure that we were not entering restricted-access areas. Sacred forests within the vicinity of the<br /><br />
deposits, such as that on the west side of the road between Farangbeya and Kegbema, were briefly<br /><br />
surveyed by use of binoculars from the roadside.<br /><br />
Seasonally inundated grasslands were not sampled using formal plots; instead a full species survey<br /><br />
was conducted within these small areas (typically less than 50 × 50 m), recording dominant species<br /><br />
and vouchering all flowering and fruiting species not identified with certainty in the field.<br /><br />
All additional herbarium voucher specimens collected and sight records made during the walk-over<br /><br />
surveys were georeferenced and accompanied by notes on habitat, species abundance etc. Voucher<br /><br />
specimens were pressed and dried using electric fan heaters. Oversized material such as large fruits<br /><br />
were dried separately and cross-referenced to the associated pressed specimen.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.2 RECONNAISANCE SURVEY OF POTENTIAL TAILINGS OR INFRASTRUCTURE LOCALITIES<br /><br />
Of the six potential localities identified by SRK Consulting, the botanical team were asked to provide<br /><br />
an overview survey of the three most likely options: 1, 4 & 5 (see fig. 1). These options were mapped<br /><br />
onto composite aerial photograph images and locations with vegetation of potential conservation<br /><br />
concern were identified. Where possible within the timeframe, these areas were subsequently visited.<br /><br />
The degree of surveying varied depending on the site:<br /><br />
OPTION 1: Tonkolili River system W of the Kunsulma ridge, S of Bumbuna town<br /><br />
This tailings option was covered by a full day walk-over survey by one of the teams, starting at the<br /><br />
bridge over the Tonkolili River on the road south of Bumbuna, and following the river upstream. For<br /><br />
the majority of the time a village path was used; several visits were made to the river to study the<br /><br />
vegetation. In addition to the riverine forest, many observations were made in the farmbush adjacent<br /><br />
to the river.<br /><br />
OPTION 4: Tonkolili River system E of the Kunsulma ridge and W of the mine deposits<br /><br />
The northern sector of this tailings option was surveyed in detail as part of the vegetation survey of the<br /><br />
deposits, including plot T4, as this river system will be directly impacted by the mining activity (see<br /><br />
2.1). The southern sector was covered by a full day walk-over survey by one of the teams,<br /><br />
concentrating on the riverine strips south of Wandugu and west of Foraia, with additional observations<br /><br />
made of the surrounding valley floor and slopes.<br /><br />
OPTION 5: River system E of the mine deposits<br /><br />
A combination of observation from the vehicle and walk-over survey, with brief sampling of the<br /><br />
habitats deemed of most interest (low altitude wooded grassland and inland valley swamps) was<br /><br />
carried out by one of the teams during a full day. The area covered was within the triangle of villages<br /><br />
Numkekoro 1, Sangbaia and Fenkembaia.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

herbarium collections from West Africa housed at RBG Kew.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.4 ASSESSMENT OF SPECIES CONSERVATION STATUS<br /><br />
The Categories & Criteria of the IUCN (2001) provide the international standard for species<br /><br />
conservation assessment, through which species considered to be globally threatened can be added<br /><br />
to the IUCN Red list (2009). The Red list was consulted to check for species identified from Tonkolili<br /><br />
which are already assessed from Sierra Leone. All other species identified from the Tonkolili survey<br /><br />
were then rapidly assessed against the IUCN categories and criteria using current and historic<br /><br />
distribution records obtained from the available literature and existing herbarium collections. Species<br /><br />
considered to be globally threatened were given a provisional threat assessment.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3. LIMITATIONS & ASSUMPTIONS<br /><br />
• The vegetation has only been studied in two seasons to date: briefly during the wet season<br /><br />
(September) and more extensively at the on-set of the dry season (late November–early December).<br /><br />
It is certain that a more complete coverage over the year, including the dry season (December–<br /><br />
March) and onset of the wet season (April–May), would reveal a range of additional species which<br /><br />
may well include further species of conservation concern.<br /><br />
• Some plant groups remain under-represented in the species inventory. Of particular note are the<br /><br />
orchids for which CITES permits are required for specimen export; as we were unable to arrange<br /><br />
these permits within the short timeframe, only photographs were taken and non-flowering plants<br /><br />
(frequently encountered) could not be identified. The survey of large forest trees has not been<br /><br />
exhaustive to date and the species accumulation curve derived from the forest plot data (see section<br /><br />
4.2) indicates that our coverage of the forest plant species in general is still some way from<br /><br />
complete. In addition, weed species are under-represented in the checklist as we did not survey<br /><br />
weedy habitats in detail, as it was assumed that these species are very unlikely to be of<br /><br />
conservation value and priority was given to “natural” habitat types.<br /><br />
• Sacred forest patches were not surveyed in detail due to strict restrictions on access. These may<br /><br />
well contain additional populations of the species of conservation concern found elsewhere in the<br /><br />
Project area.<br /><br />
• As many of the herbarium voucher specimens collected were sterile (lacking flowers and fruits),<br /><br />
complete and confident identifications could not be made for all the material. It is quite possible that<br /><br />
some of the preliminary identifications will be changed if fertile material is collected in future visits.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
10<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• The IUCN conservation assessments listed in this report for the rare species found must be<br /><br />
considered provisional at present in view of the incomplete information we have on the current<br /><br />
distributions of the majority of the species.<br /><br />
• The survey of the three potential tailings or infrastructure locations must be considered highly<br /><br />
provisional in view of the very limited time available and the incomplete coverage.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4. VEGETATION CLASSIFICATION & DESCRIPTIONS<br /><br />
This section details the structure and composition of the eight vegetation types recognised within the<br /><br />
Project area. This classification is based upon the combination of general overview survey and<br /><br />
analyses of the plot data collected to date.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.1 FOREST ON HILLSLOPES<br /><br />
As has been remarked in the reconnaissance survey report, the natural climax vegetation of the<br /><br />
majority of the study area is likely to be lowland rainforest. Presently, only a few small patches of<br /><br />
forest remain, with most of the area now being used for the cultivation of rice by slash-and-burn<br /><br />
agriculture (see 4.7 & 4.8). The two largest forest patches found on aerial photographs were studied in<br /><br />
detail: the forest patch on the western slopes of Simbili (fig. 3), and the forest patch on the slopes to<br /><br />
the southwest of Kegbema village (fig. 4). A 25 m × 25 m plot was made in each of these two patches<br /><br />
(plots T9 and T12), and the forest surrounding these plots was studied by way of a walk-over survey.<br /><br />
Several other small forest patches in the study area were also visited, but more briefly.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 3: the forest patch on the western slopes of Simbili, Nov. 2009 (X. van der Burgt).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Plot T9 in the forest patch on the western slopes of Simbili is situated in a small grove of<br /><br />
Cryptosepalum tetraphyllum (IUCN: VU) trees. All medium sized trees were coppiced several decades<br /><br />
ago by farmers, but there are no signs of any damage by fire. Lower on the slopes on Simbili a large<br /><br />
single tree of Entandrophragma cylindricum (in the centre of Fig. 3; IUCN: VU) is surrounded by a<br /><br />
diverse and little-disturbed patch of forest. Other parts of this forest patch are more degraded, with<br /><br />
tree species such as Piptadeniastrum africanum and Pycnanthus angolensis, characteristic of<br /><br />
secondary forest.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
11<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 4: the forest patch on the slopes to the southwest of Kegbema village, Nov. 2009 (X. van der Burgt).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The forest patch surrounding Plot T12 on the slopes to the southwest of Kegbema village is of good<br /><br />
quality. The canopy is unbroken and consists of a diverse range of tree species characteristic of West<br /><br />
African forests, for example Daniellia thurifera (the large tree in the centre of Fig. 4), Guibourtia<br /><br />
leonensis and Newtonia aubrevillei. The understory is in good condition and consists of a variety of<br /><br />
forest herbs, shrubs and small trees as well as seedlings and saplings of the large trees. The structure<br /><br />
in this patch is characteristic of primary forest, and there are no signs of any damage by fire in the<br /><br />
central portion. The only signs of damage by humans inside the plot are four stumps of medium sized<br /><br />
trees logged several decades ago. Three of these are of the species Baphia nitida, of which the wood<br /><br />
is used for carving, turning and making red dye (Burkill 1985–2004). A single medium sized tree of the<br /><br />
species Afzelia bella was also logged several decades ago, probably for construction wood. Mature<br /><br />
specimens of both species are still present within the forest patch. The absence of grove-forming tree<br /><br />
species from the Legume subfamily Caesalpinioideae, in contrast to their presence in the strip of<br /><br />
forest along the river near Farangbeya village (see below), does not necessarily indicate a higher<br /><br />
degree of disturbance. Primary forests in Africa can have a high percentage of grove-forming<br /><br />
Caesalpinioideae trees, as well as an absence of these.<br /><br />
The Kegbema forest is probably inside the Farangbeya Forest Reserve (demarcation of eastern<br /><br />
boundary is uncertain), which would give it a national protected status. This forest must also have<br /><br />
some kind of protected status given by the local villagers, or it would be much more degraded or lost.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.2 RIVERINE FOREST<br /><br />
Maps of the study area indicate that the rivers in the Project area are usually bordered by a strip of<br /><br />
forest. The forest strip along the river near Farangbeya village, which is the largest and most intact<br /><br />
area identified from aerial photographs, was studied in detail. A 12.5 m x 50 m plot (T4) was made,<br /><br />
and the forest surrounding the plot was studied by way of a walk-over survey. Several other riverine<br /><br />
forest strips in the study area were also visited, but more briefly.<br /><br />
The strip of forest along the river near Farangbeya village (Fig. 5) is approximately 10 m to 50 m<br /><br />
(occasionally more) wide on both sides of the river and bordered by almost treeless farmland. The<br /><br />
forest here is of good quality, both in terms of species composition and structure, despite its proximity<br /><br />
to the village. The canopy of this forest also consists of a diverse sample of tree species characteristic<br /><br />
of West African forests. In addition, there are species characteristic of riverine forest, e.g. Heisteria<br /><br />
parvifolia and Strephonema pseudocola. Four grove-forming tree species from the Legume subfamily<br /><br />
Caesalpinioideae were found: Aphanocalyx pteridophyllus, Brachystegia leonensis, Gilbertiodendron<br /><br />
aylmeri and Copaifera salikounda. These four species are all of conservation concern (see tables 7 &<br /><br />
8). The presence of these grove-forming species indicates that this forest strip is a remnant of<br /><br />
species-rich primary rainforest. The understory is in good condition and contains a variety of forest<br /><br />
species of herbs, shrubs and small trees as well as seedlings and saplings of the large trees. There<br /><br />
<br /><br />
12<br /><br />
<br /><br />
are no signs of fire in most parts of the forest strip, though fire damage was observed in some areas<br /><br />
especially along the forest edges bordering farmland.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 5: the strip of forest along the river near Farangbeya village, Nov. 2009 (X. van der Burgt).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Discussion on hillslope and riverine forests<br /><br />
The edges of the forest patches in the study area are more degraded compared to their interior; fires<br /><br />
have penetrated during the dry season, destroying the shrub layer and damaging the large trees. This<br /><br />
process slowly decreases the size of the forest patches in the study area. These forest patches are<br /><br />
and have been used for the collection of construction wood and firewood, for hunting, fruit gathering<br /><br />
and medicinal plant gathering.<br /><br />
Of the three forest patches studied in detail, the strip of riverine forest near Farangbeya and the patch<br /><br />
to the southwest of Kegbema village have the highest conservation value. This is indicated by the<br /><br />
structure of these forest patches, their species richness, their general species composition and the<br /><br />
presence of species of conservation concern. Both patches are equally rich in species, and richer than<br /><br />
the forest patch on the western slopes of Simbili (Table 3). Plot T4 in the strip of riverine forest near<br /><br />
Farangbeya has four conservation species compared to six such species in plot T12 in the forest<br /><br />
patch to the southwest of Kegbema village (Table 3). Eight conservation species were found in the<br /><br />
whole forest patch to the southwest of Kegbema village compared to 14 such species in the strip of<br /><br />
forest near Farangbeya. The reason for the higher number in the latter site is probably that several<br /><br />
days were spent here on the walk-over survey, while only one day was spent on the walk-over survey<br /><br />
in the Kegbema forest patch. Although the three forest plots do not show large differences in their<br /><br />
species composition, the separation of natural forest vegetation in the study area into forests on hill<br /><br />
slopes and riverine forest is still maintained on the basis of their structural differences.<br /><br />

A species accumulation curve was made for the three plots (Fig. 6). Although three plots is too low a<br /><br />
number for a good analysis of a species accumulation curve, some conclusions can be drawn from the<br /><br />
figure. The total number of species in all three plots is 257. At the third plot the species accumulation<br /><br />
curve still climbs, indicating that not all forest species were found by the present survey. A fourth plot<br /><br />
in forest would on average have an estimated number of 46 species new to the forest plot survey,<br /><br />
bringing the total to an estimated number of 303 species (some of these species may, of course,<br /><br />
already have been found by the walk-over survey). The total number of forest species in the study<br /><br />
area can only be estimated very roughly from this curve, but is expected to have been between 500<br /><br />
and 800 species prior to the loss and disturbance of much of the forest cover. Since much of the forest<br /><br />
between and around the three plots has now been converted to farmland, a proportion of these<br /><br />
species will have disappeared from the study area and a species count towards the lower end of this<br /><br />
estimate is most likely.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 6: species accumulation curve for the three forest plots. If a fourth plot is made it can be expected to have<br /><br />
an average of 46 species new to the forest plot survey.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.3. RIVER CHANNEL COMMUNITIES<br /><br />
Stretches of the Tonkolili River between Farangbeya and Foraia (potential tailings or infrastructure<br /><br />
option 4) are fast-flowing with a series of rapids and small falls over a rocky bed (fig. 7). These<br /><br />
potentially support a rheophytic plant community (plants adapted to fast flowing, clear, welloxygenated water, usually with narrow leaves and strong anchoring rootstocks). Two rheophytic<br /><br />
species have been uncovered to date: the widespread Marsdenia oblanceolata and a probable new<br /><br />
species to science, Eriocaulon sp. nov. nr. E. varians. This latter species is known only from one other<br /><br />
collection, having been collected over 50 years ago from the same locality at Farangbeya. We are<br /><br />
currently awaiting confirmation of its status from the specialist in this plant group.<br /><br />
A more complete survey of the Tonkolili River channel when water levels are lower (late Dec-March)<br /><br />
will almost certainly reveal further rheophytes. Amongst these, we are likely to find species of the<br /><br />
Podostemaceae family, a group of tiny herbs highly specialised to this environment and easily<br /><br />
overlooked, particularly when water levels are high as in the Nov-Dec visit. Many species in this family<br /><br />
are highly localised and scarce; it is therefore anticipated that further species of conservation concern<br /><br />
will be revealed from this habitat.<br /><br />
Rheophytes can be sensitive to environmental change such as changing water levels and increased<br /><br />
sedimentation, processes which may be exacerbated by mining activities. On the other hand, the<br /><br />
population of the Eriocaulon at Farangbeya has clearly survived the large-scale deforestation of the<br /><br />
surrounding hillslopes which will have had a significant impact upon water run-off volumes and<br /><br />
particularly sedimentation rates; the extent to which this species can cope with further environmental<br /><br />
change is unknown and requires further consideration.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
14<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 7: potential rheophyte habitat on the Tonkolili River W of Foraia village, proposed tailings option 4, Dec.<br /><br />
2009 (I. Darbyshire).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The shallow rocky bed along the river margin becomes exposed as the water level falls in the dry<br /><br />
season. These areas support a community of water-loving herbs which are less specialised than<br /><br />
rheophytes. The common species are Anubias afzelii / barteri (no flowers or fruits seen to date, these<br /><br />
being required to separate these two species) and the highly pungent Hygrophila odora which can<br /><br />
form carpets amongst the exposed rock beds. Also recorded in this habitat W of Farangbeya was the<br /><br />
rare Anubias gracilis.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.4. GRASSLAND AND WOODED GRASSLAND ON WELL-DRAINED SOILS<br /><br />
Grassland (characterised by a tree canopy cover of less than 10%) and wooded grassland (canopy<br /><br />
cover 10–40%), often together referred to as “savanna”, are widespread habitats in Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
Although sometimes treated as two distinct vegetation types, the natural grasslands and wooded<br /><br />
grasslands in the Project area form a mosaic, variable over a matter of a few tens of metres<br /><br />
dependent upon subtle changes in slope and soil depth. They are therefore treated as a single entity<br /><br />
here, but are subdivided into two distinct types (secondary grassland is treated separately in section<br /><br />
4.7.1):<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.4.1 Hill summit (wooded) grassland<br /><br />
The summit ridges (over c. 650 m alt.) of the higher peaks in the southern Sula Mts hold extensive<br /><br />
areas of a natural fire-prone grassland / lightly wooded grassland, with the canopy cover varying from<br /><br />
0% to c. 30%, this figure typically increasing on the steeper ridge slopes. This grassland develops<br /><br />
over thin soils, with regular outcrops of iron-rich bedrock. This vegetation type has been surveyed in<br /><br />
plots T1, 2, 3, 5, 6 & 7.<br /><br />
The most intact and extensive examples of this habitat type on the mine site are to be found on<br /><br />
Numbara (fig. 8). Whilst the numerous exporation tracks and drill pads have impacted upon this<br /><br />
habitat to some extent, the effects are localised and the majority of the habitat remains undisturbed.<br /><br />
Whilst these grasslands are also extensive on Marampon, some areas show evidence of recent rice<br /><br />
farming and some invasion of secondary grassland species (see 4.7.1). The summit of Simbili holds<br /><br />
degraded forest, but the subridge to the north of the summit is largely covered by grass with scattered<br /><br />
tree species typical of the natural wooded grassland habitat. However, all the grasslands on Simbili<br /><br />
are much disturbed with secondary grassland species dominant and with evidence of recent farming.<br /><br />
Beyond the mine site, we found a good further example of this hill summit grassland on Sakonke Hill<br /><br />
to the NW of Numbara and outside the mine concession. Viewed through binoculars from the summit<br /><br />
of Numbara, many of the larger hills in the northern sector of the licensed mining exploration area<br /><br />
appear to hold similar habitat, although these have not yet been surveyed on the ground.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
15<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 8: hill summit Loudetia grassland and lightly wooded grassland on Numbara, Nov 2009; the burnt summmit<br /><br />
grasslands of Sakonke Hill can be seen in the top left (I. Darbyshire).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Woody species diversity is low in this habitat, with only 13 tree species recorded (table 4), all being<br /><br />
common species typical of the West African (Guinean) “savannas”. By far the most common is<br /><br />
Pterocarpus erinaceus, with Bridelia micrantha, Lophira lanceolata and Parkia biglobosa also<br /><br />
frequently encountered. The mature trees typically reach a height of 3–7 m. Many tree saplings were<br /><br />
recorded in the plots, including forest/woodland pioneer species such as Allophylus africanus,<br /><br />
Anisophyllea laurina and Albizia zygia but many of these are likely to be lost during dry season<br /><br />
burning (see Fire Regime below) – certainly, very few mature trees of these species were recorded<br /><br />
during our surveys of this habitat.<br /><br />

Table 4: tree species recorded in the hill summit Loudetia grassland / wooded grassland, with summary plot data<br /><br />
(for the purpose of this table, the composite plot T7 is subdivided into eight 10 × 10 m plots).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The ground cover is usually 100% except in areas of bare rock exposure. In the majority of this<br /><br />
habitat, the grass cover is dominated (70–95%) by 2–2.5 m tall Loudetia arundinacea. This is a<br /><br />
widespread species, typical of dry thin soils over rock outcrops. Other common grasses (usually at ≤<br /><br />
5% cover) are Hyparrhenia diplandra, Chasmopodium afzelii, Andropogon gayanus and/or A.<br /><br />
tectorum, typically at 2–3.5 m height. In areas of deeper soils and/or some disturbance, Andropogon<br /><br />
tectorum can dominate (e.g. 75% ground cover in plot T6). Areas of recent and regular disturbance,<br /><br />
<br /><br />
16<br /><br />
<br /><br />
most notably along the fringes of the mining exploration tracks and drill pads, are dominated by the 1–<br /><br />
1.5 m grasses Pennisetum hordeioides and/or P. polystachion.<br /><br />
The herb flora is more varied. Robust perennial herbs and subshrubs are scattered amongst the<br /><br />
grass, common species including Aedesia glabra, Dolichos dinklagei, Droogmansia scaettaiana,<br /><br />
Melastomastrum theifolium, Psorospermum alternifolium and Vernonia guineensis. In areas of loose<br /><br />
rock, the fleshy Cissus caesia can form large sprawling tangles. Common annual herbs, flowering<br /><br />
early in the dry season, include Alectra sessiliflora, Hypoestes cancellata, Polygala multiflora, P.<br /><br />
rarifolia, Sopubia parviflora and the twining Vigna venulosa. A community of small ephemeral herbs<br /><br />
develop on the exposed rocky areas, flowering towards the end of the wet season when surface<br /><br />
moisture is available before setting seed and quickly dying off as the grassland dries; common species<br /><br />
include the widespread Bulbostylis congensis, Cyanotis longifolia, Mesanthemum prescottianum,<br /><br />
Neurotheca loeselioides, Scleria hirtella and Spermacoce pusilla, together with the more localised and<br /><br />
uncommon Osbeckia decandra and Spermacoce bambusicola. The fern Nephrolepis undulata is very<br /><br />
common on exposed rock between the grass tussocks.<br /><br />
Of particular note amongst the herb flora is the discovery of a new species to science: Pseudovigna<br /><br />
sp. nov., a perennial of the pea family. This species has an underground, fire-resistant rootstock.<br /><br />
During the rainy season it develops a series of large trailing stems over exposed rocks where the<br /><br />
grass cover is more sparse. It is particularly numerous on the summit of Numbara but has also been<br /><br />
found on Marampon (a single plant) and was successfully located beyond the Project area on the<br /><br />
summit of Sakonke Hill to the NW of Numbara.<br /><br />
Two rather scarce species restricted to submontane grassland have been recorded from Numbara:<br /><br />
Cyperus (tenuiculmis var.) guineensis and Crassocephalum guineense. It therefore seems that the<br /><br />
Numbara summit is sufficiently high to capture some submontane grassland elements, an important<br /><br />
habitat for rare species in the wider Guinea (Loma-Man) Highlands. Indeed, it is possible that<br /><br />
Pseudovigna sp. nov. is a submontane species which just extends onto these peaks; it is certainly<br /><br />
absent from the lower altitude wooded grasslands.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Fire regime<br /><br />
The presence of several range-restricted species, in particular the apparent endemic Pseudovigna sp.<br /><br />
nov., clearly indicates that the ridge-top wooded grasslands are a natural habitat and have been in<br /><br />
place for some time. Whilst the thin soils with frequent outcrops of bedrock may limit the<br /><br />
encroachment of woodland or forest, it is certain that annual burning plays an important role in<br /><br />
maintaining these grasslands. All the mature tree species found in this habitat have fire resistant bark<br /><br />
and physiology and evidence for regular burning is clear from the blackened trunks.<br /><br />
The grasses grow quickly during the wet season and flower at the end of the rains in November. As<br /><br />
conditions dry, burning (through lightning strikes or often deliberate setting by man) typically<br /><br />
commences in Nov–Dec. Indeed, during our visit the Loudetia grassland on Sakonke Hill had already<br /><br />
been deliberately burnt (fig. 9). It is at this point that many of the woody saplings will be killed off. On<br /><br />
both Marampon and Numbara several deep channels have been cut along the ridge and slopes,<br /><br />
presumably geological sample trenches. Saplings growing in these ditches are protected from fire and<br /><br />
we found several maturing plants or colonies of woodland / forest pioneers such as Alchornea<br /><br />
cordifolia, Margaritaria discoidea and Anthocleista nobilis.<br /><br />
Within a few weeks of burning, fire-resistant herbs with perennial underground rootstocks (pyrophytes)<br /><br />
are likely to emerge to flower and fruit – as we have not visited these sites at the appropriate season,<br /><br />
this set of species remains little-surveyed in the Project area.<br /><br />
Conservation value<br /><br />
Of the hill summit grasslands on the deposits, those on Numbara are considered to be of highest<br /><br />
conservation value in terms of quantity and quality of habitat, species richness and the presence of a<br /><br />
sizable population of the conservation priority species Pseudovigna sp. nov.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
17<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 9: recently burnt Loudetia grassland on the summit of Sakonke Hill, Dec. 2009 (I. Darbyshire).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.4.2 Low Altitude Wooded Grassland<br /><br />
Some areas of the valley floors beyond the riverine fringe and the adjacent lower hillslopes are<br /><br />
occupied by wooded grassland which looks superficially similar to that on the ridge summits. As this<br /><br />
habitat is not recorded on the three mine deposits, it has not been surveyed in detail. However, it is<br /><br />
frequently encountered in the potential tailings or infrastructure locations (particularly option 5) and an<br /><br />
initial assessment has therefore been made on several representative patches of this habitat.<br /><br />
The ground cover is again ± 100% and is dominated by Hyparrhenia-Loudetia grassland. Conspicuous<br /><br />
amongst the grasses are stands of the ginger Aframomum sp. 1 of Tonkolili (unidentifiable to species<br /><br />
at this time of year as not in flower). The woody component in these areas is often more dense than<br /><br />
on the hill summits and, although many of the species encountered are the same (e.g. Pterocarpus<br /><br />
erinaceus, Parkia biglobosa) the dominant species differ, often being Lophira lanceolata, Crossopteryx<br /><br />
febrifuga and/or Hymenocardia acida, the Crossopteryx being apparently absent from hill summit<br /><br />
sites. In several areas within option 5, the native woody species are supplemented by planting of<br /><br />
Gmelina arborea Roxb., a fast growing Asian tree planted here in rows perhaps as a boundary<br /><br />
marker; it is also used locally as a shade tree.<br /><br />
These wooded grasslands are used for cattle grazing by local communities and it is likely that<br /><br />
browsing of tree and shrub saplings by the domestic livestock plays an important role in halting the<br /><br />
succession to thicket and closed woodland. Regular burning is, however, also likely to be significant in<br /><br />
this process as on the ridge summits.<br /><br />
The examples of this habitat found between Numkekoro and Sangbaia (e.g. 8° 58’ 54.1” N, 11° 38’<br /><br />
37.1” W) and between Numkekoro and Fenkembaia (e.g. 8° 58’ 03.3” N, 11° 38’ 30.5” W) in tailings<br /><br />
option 5 have a more diverse woody flora than on the hill summits (fig. 10) and should be surveyed in<br /><br />
more detail if this option is selected for development. However, this is a common habitat type in Sierra<br /><br />
Leone and, from the brief survey, appears to be typical of the widespread “Guinean” wooded<br /><br />
grasslands which extend all the way from West Africa to Sudan and NW Uganda, which is not known<br /><br />
to contain a large number of rare or localised species. The conservation value of this habitat type is<br /><br />
therefore provisionally assessed as low.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
18<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 10: low altitude wooded grassland between Numkekoro and Sangbaia, proposed tailings option 5, Dec.<br /><br />
2009 (I. Darbyshire).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.5. SEASONALLY WET GRASSLAND<br /><br />
Areas of seasonally wet grassland can develop in shallow depressions over flat bedrock (fig. 11) and<br /><br />
in areas of seepage over bedrock on hillslopes (figs. 12 & 13). These sites support an ephemeral<br /><br />
wetland community quite distinct from that supported by the surrounding free-drained soils. They are<br /><br />
usually wet only during the latter part of the wet season and into the earliest part of the dry season.<br /><br />
Many of the herbs have a short life-cycle, dying off quickly after setting seed as the seasonal wetland<br /><br />
dries out. This habitat is widespread in the Guinea Highlands and often contains highly localised and<br /><br />
rare species.<br /><br />
Four such areas were located during the reconnaissance visit in Sept 2009; the Nov-Dec visit<br /><br />
resurveyed these sites and also found two further significant sites for this habitat, one within the<br /><br />
Project area and one beyond the mine concession area (table 5). Unfortunately, the delay in timing of<br /><br />
the Nov-Dec visit meant that several of these sites had dried out and many of the species had<br /><br />
therefore died off. The combined survey from the two visits will not therefore have provided an<br /><br />
exhaustive inventory of this habitat. However, our findings to date confirm that this is a habitat of high<br /><br />
conservation value.<br /><br />

Although the range of species varies considerably from site to site in response to differences in water<br /><br />
depth and whether stagnant or seeping, several species are common and characteristic of this habitat.<br /><br />
The margins of these wetlands are typically dominated by the c. 1 m tall grass Schizachyrium sp. 1<br /><br />
(identity unconfirmed as it had finished flowering by the Nov-Dec visit) and the sedge Nemum<br /><br />
spadiceum which often forms dense carpets 10−20 cm tall (fig. 12). Areas of bare mud hold a<br /><br />
community of diminutive herbs, common species including Adelostigma senegalense, Cyanotis lanata,<br /><br />

<br /><br />
The shallow depression on Numbara (drilling platform NURC005) contains a set of species not<br /><br />
recorded in the seepage areas. Dominant in the areas of wet mud are Panicum humile, Cyperus<br /><br />
pustulatus, Pycreus capillifolius and the rare Schoenoplectiella oxyjulos (fig. 11), with Aponogeton<br /><br />
vallisnerioides, Dopatrium senegalense and Xyris barteri all common here. The drill platform is<br /><br />
situated within this site and it was at first thought that the wetland was created by scraping away of the<br /><br />
topsoil in preparation for the drilling. However, there is no evidence of surface scraping (we would<br /><br />
expect to see mounds of earth around the edge of the site) and the range of species recorded<br /><br />
suggests that the site is a natural depression; in other areas on the ridge summit disturbed by mine<br /><br />
exploration activity there are many weedy species present but these are absent at NURC005.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
20<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The most important seasonally wet grassland for conservation identified to date is that on the S slopes<br /><br />
of Marampon at the north end of the Simbili-Marampon saddle (figs. 12 and 13). The small area of<br /><br />
seepage here holds three species of conservation concern including two potentially Endangered<br /><br />
species: Bryaspis humularioides subsp. falcistipulata and Schizachyrium lomaense (the third, Panicum<br /><br />
glaucocladum, is considered Vulnerable). The survey of this site during Nov-Dec visit was not<br /><br />
exhaustive - a second day visit was planned to conduct a full survey of the grasses at this site but the<br /><br />
area was burnt before this could be conducted (see below).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 12: seepage grassland on the S slopes of Marampon, with abundant Nemum spadiceum in the foreground,<br /><br />
Nov 2009 (I. Darbyshire).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 13: the same site, viewed looking S towards Simbili peak, showing open wet mud with surface seepage;<br /><br />
the rare Bryaspis humularioides subsp. falcistipulata can be seen in the foreground, Nov. 2009 (I. Darbyshire).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Afrotrilepis tussocks<br /><br />
The seasonally wet grasslands on the slopes of Marampon are surrounded by patches of the tussockforming sedge Afrotrilepis pilosa. Regular burning appears to be an important element of this species’<br /><br />
ecology, the plants developing a tough raised and blackened fire-resistant perennial base. Indeed, the<br /><br />
Afrotrilepis tussocks and adjacent Schizachyrium grassland around the seepage site on the S slopes<br /><br />
<br /><br />
21<br /><br />
<br /><br />
of Marampon was burnt (apparently deliberately) during the Nov-Dec visit. This species is commonly<br /><br />
found growing on exposed rock faces and is often associated with granite inselbergs (indeed, it is<br /><br />
much in evidence on granite hills to the west and south of the mine concession area) but on<br /><br />
Marampon it grows on slopes over thin soils which are seasonally wet. It therefore forms a transition<br /><br />
between the freely drained grasslands and the seasonally wet grasslands. On the summit of<br /><br />
Marampon, Afrotrilepis dominates in shallow drainage ditches dug along the ridge-top tracks.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.6. INLAND VALLEY SWAMP<br /><br />
Where river valleys and cut-off former river meanders (ox-bows) are flooded during and following the<br /><br />
wet season, freshwater swamps develop. Some of these swamps are maintained artificially for rice<br /><br />
cultivation. Only small areas of this habitat are to be found in the vicinity of the mine deposits, along<br /><br />
the Tonkolili River east of Farangbeya and at the southern foot of Numbara. This habitat is, however,<br /><br />
common in proposed tailings option 5, with several large examples observed between Numkekoro,<br /><br />
Sangbaia and Fenkembaia (fig. 14).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 14: inland valley swamp with rice cultivation S of Numkekoro in tailings option 5; Raphia palma-pinus and<br /><br />
Hallea stipulosa are frequent in the swamp (I. Darbyshire)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Many of these swamps are intensively cultivated for rice. However, more natural vegetation is to be<br /><br />
found at some sites, though perhaps this develops during fallow periods. A typical shallow-water valley<br /><br />
swamp was surveyed in some detail at the foot of Numbara. It supports a dense sedge community,<br /><br />
most commonly Fuirena stricta var. stricta together with Cyperus haspan, Fuirena umbellata,<br /><br />
Rhynchospora corymbosa and Scleria melanomphala. Wetland herbs interspersed within the sedge<br /><br />
communities include Ludwigia abyssinica, Mesanthemum radicans and the rare Aeschynomene<br /><br />
deightonii.<br /><br />
Some of the swamps in tailings option 5 contain deeper water (to c. 1.5 m or more) and can contain a<br /><br />
range of aquatic species. A reconnaissance survey of one of the less disturbed sites recorded<br /><br />
Eichhornia natans, Limnophila dasyantha, Limnophyton angolense, Nymphaea maculata, Ottelia<br /><br />
ulvifolia and Utricularia gibba. All are widespread species at least in West Africa, only the Limnophila<br /><br />
being at all uncommon, and with none being considered threatened.<br /><br />
Woody species are very few in this habitat. The small palm Raphia palma-pinus is frequent and all the<br /><br />
valley swamps seen contained groves of Hallea stipulosa, a timber species considered Vulnerable on<br /><br />
the IUCN Red list due to over-exploitation. This species is locally very common, acting as a pioneer<br /><br />
tree, and in view of the large extent of valley swamps in this region of Sierra Leone, the Hallea is not<br /><br />
considered a conservation priority.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
22<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Whilst the conservation importance of this habitat is provisionally assessed as low, the presence of<br /><br />
Aeschynomene deightonii, a species considered to be globally threatened based on current evidence,<br /><br />
suggests that further rare species may be uncovered if this habitat is surveyed further.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.7 SECONDARY HABITATS<br /><br />
The slash-and-burn farming practiced by local communities, with long periods of fallow, result in a<br /><br />
mosaic of farmbush and degraded secondary habitats over the majority of the Project area. Increased<br /><br />
recent migration into the area may have exacerbated the rate of slash and burn farming here.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.7.1 Secondary grassland<br /><br />
Extensive areas of the hillslopes on the three mine deposits are covered by dense stands of<br /><br />
Andropogon tectorum grassland 3–3.5 m tall (fig. 15). Very few other herbaceous species are able to<br /><br />
compete for light and nutrients, with the exceptions of the twining Vigna venulosa and the root parasite<br /><br />
Striga macrantha which presumably parasitises the Andropogon here. In some areas on Simbili, the<br /><br />
Andropogon is accompanied by Setaria megaphylla (again to 3 m tall), whilst particularly along<br /><br />
recently disturbed forest margins the shorter (c. 1.5–2 m) Melinis minutiflora can dominate.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 15: extensive Andropogon tectorum secondary grassland on Numbara, Nov 2009. The transition to the hill<br /><br />
summit lightly wooded grassland can be seen in the top right (E. Robinson).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The large stands of Andropogon almost certainly indicate recent human slash and burn activity and<br /><br />
are quite likely the initial stage of a secondary succession. This habitat is of minimal conservation<br /><br />
concern.<br /><br />
The transition from Andropogon grassland to hill summit natural Loudetia grassland is usually gradual<br /><br />
and partially dependent upon the degree of disturbance. However, soil depth may also play an<br /><br />
important role in this transition and it is possible that Andropogon would also dominate on deeper soils<br /><br />
in this region even in the absence of human disturbance.<br /><br />
From a vegetation mapping perspective, it is very difficult to separate areas of secondary grassland<br /><br />
from the “natural” grassland habitats.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.7.2 Secondary herbaceous Chromolaena scrub<br /><br />
Extensive stands 2–2.5 m tall of the invasive introduced weed Chromolaena odorata are recorded on<br /><br />
some hillslopes on the deposits (fig. 16). This is a native of South and Central America and has<br /><br />
<br /><br />
23<br /><br />
<br /><br />
spread rapidly in tropical Africa within the last few decades. Here, it represents an early stage in the<br /><br />
succession following abandonment of agricultural land. Other species commonly associated with this<br /><br />
habitat type are Aspilia africana and the fern Pteridium aquilinum (bracken). It is unclear as to why<br /><br />
some areas are dominated by this species as opposed to Andropogon grassland (see 4.4.3) which<br /><br />
seems to occupy a similar stage in the post-disturbance succession. This habitat is of no conservation<br /><br />
value.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 16: extensive stands of Chromolaena odorata on the saddle between Simbili and Marampon, Dec 2009<br /><br />
(I. Darbyshire).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.7.3 Secondary thicket and woodland<br /><br />
The term “thicket” is precisely defined as a closed stand of bushes and climbers usually between 3–7<br /><br />
m tall, whilst “woodland” is defined as an open stand of trees at least 8 m tall with a canopy cover ≥<br /><br />
40%. The woody secondary growth widespread in the Tonkolili region is intermediate in character.<br /><br />
Within a short period of fallow (estimated at 1–3 years), the hillslopes revert to a dense secondary<br /><br />
thicket of bushes, small trees and lianas with a broken canopy cover, later (estimated at within 5<br /><br />
years) developing into a tree/bush thicket with a canopy cover of over 80%. Good examples of this<br /><br />
habitat type were surveyed on the slopes of the saddle between Marampon and Simbili and the three<br /><br />
plots T8, T10 and T11 provide a snapshot of this vegetation type (fig. 17). Of these, plot T10 contained<br /><br />
the most mature thicket whilst T8 contained the least mature. Table 6 provides a list of the trees with<br /><br />
dbh 5–10 cm and ≥10 cm and gives a good overview of the most commonly encountered species. The<br /><br />
dominant species vary somewhat from site to site, but particularly abundant are Dichrostachys<br /><br />
cinerea, Anisophyllea laurina, Sterculia tragacantha and Alchornea cordifolia (the latter often dominant<br /><br />
along roadsides and margins of disturbed habitat). Immature treelets or shrubs of these species are<br /><br />
also common in the understorey of this habitat. All these species are widespread and common<br /><br />
species and typical fast-growing pioneers of secondary regrowth. Other pioneer species commonly<br /><br />
encountered, though only as immature treelets (or absent) in the three plots surveyed, are Bersama<br /><br />
abyssinica, Napoleonaea cf. heudelotii, Newbouldia laevis and Trema orientalis, the lattermost<br /><br />
abundant along forest margins.<br /><br />
Particularly at the early stages of succession, a shrub layer is also present, with characteristic species<br /><br />
including Chassalia kolly, Diospyros heudelotii, Mareya micrantha, Microdesmis keayana, Solanum<br /><br />
erianthum and S. torvum (both abundant along disturbed forest margins) and Tetracera alnifolia (later<br /><br />
climbing).<br /><br />
Both herbaceous and woody climbers are abundant in this habitat, often forming dense tangles.<br /><br />
Common species include Cardiospermum grandiflorum, Clerodendron splendens, Combretum spp.<br /><br />
including the vivid scarlet C. grandiflora, Entada rheedei, Ipomoea involucrata, Leptoderris fasciculata,<br /><br />
Merremia pterygocaulos, Smilax anceps and Tiliacora louisii.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

2009 (I. Darbyshire).<br /><br />

Nearly all the mature trees and shrubs in these thickets display evidence of past cutting to the base<br /><br />
and dead trees through excessive cutting and burning are a frequent site. However, in the areas of<br /><br />
thicket surveyed, there was no evidence of recent felling of larger trees. Therefore, whilst it is almost<br /><br />
certain that these hillslopes were once forested, it is likely that the majority of forest loss is not recent<br /><br />
(but see discussion on forest margin disturbance in section 4.2).<br /><br />
In the early stages of thicket development, as in plot T8, a rather dense herb layer persists, typically<br /><br />
with the species recorded in the Chromolaena scrub together with Ageratum conyzoides, Desmodium<br /><br />
velutinum, Triumfetta spp. and several Acanthaceous herbs including Justicia ladanoides and<br /><br />
abundant Hypoestes forskaolii. However, as the bushland matures, light availability decreases and the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
25<br /><br />
<br /><br />
ground cover becomes sparse, with secondary forest species such as Psychotria subglabra and the<br /><br />
grass Olyra latifolia being most common.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.8 AGRICULTURAL LAND<br /><br />
Agriculture within the Project area is varied. Farming in the valley bottoms and particularly the swampy<br /><br />
areas consists of monocultures of rice (see fig. 14) or occasionally peanuts. Hill slopes and freedrained valley bottoms are usually farmed at a low intensity subsistence level, the principal crops<br /><br />
being rice and cassava, with maize, okra, pepper, pigeon pea and sorghum also commonly grown. A<br /><br />
variety of fruits as well as oil palms are commonly grown around villages. Hillslope farms are<br /><br />
established following slash and burn, with the crop plants often scattered amongst the regenerating<br /><br />
secondary growth. Cattle are also reared, with grazing on the natural wooded grassland (savanna);<br /><br />
this was only observed in the low-altitude wooded grasslands, with no evidence of grazing on the hill<br /><br />
summit grasslands at least during our visit.<br /><br />
Many weedy plant species are associated with these agricultural lands. Whilst a full weed survey has<br /><br />
not been conducted, we can be confident that there are no species of high conservation concern in<br /><br />
this habitat.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5. SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN<br /><br />
The IUCN Red list (2009) currently lists 46 globally threatened plant species occurring in Sierra Leone,<br /><br />
of which 42 are assessed as Vulnerable (VU), three as Endangered (EN) and one as Critically<br /><br />
Endangered (CR). Nearly all these species are timber trees, assessed on the basis of overexploitation for commercial use coupled with habitat loss and so qualifying as threatened under<br /><br />
criterion A of IUCN (2001); many are widespread in the forests of wet tropical Africa. Of these 46<br /><br />
species, 15 have been recorded in the Tonkolili region through the current survey work, with a further<br /><br />
Red listed species (Placodiscus oblongifolius) recorded in Sierra Leone for the first time (table 7).<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Of the three threat categories recognised by IUCN, EN and CR species are of particular importance<br /><br />
since these currently trigger the requirement for critical habitat assessment under IFC Performance<br /><br />
Standard 6. However, following the current modification of this standard, it is likely that species<br /><br />
<br /><br />
27<br /><br />
<br /><br />
assessed as VU under criterion B (number of localities / populations) will also fall under the critical<br /><br />
habitat definition in the near future. As the species of conservation concern listed in table 8 are, in the<br /><br />
main, assessed under criterion B, these should therefore be considered of the highest priority with<br /><br />
regard to the IFC standards. The nine species considered of highest priority are highlighted in bold in<br /><br />
the table.<br /><br />
A further potential new species to science, Dilophotriche sp. ?nov., has been collected from the<br /><br />
nearby Sakonke Hill (9° 04’ 09.2” N 11° 38’ 51.7” W, fig. 2) but not yet found within the mine<br /><br />
concession. However, this species may well occur in suitable habitat on the mine site and should be<br /><br />
sought for in the seepage grasslands on Marampon.<br /><br />
Whilst we can be confident that all the species listed in table 8 are genuinely scarce, the conservation<br /><br />
status applied to each must be considered provisional in view of our incomplete knowledge of the<br /><br />
current distribution of most of these species. It is quite probable that further survey work in the<br /><br />
montane regions of northern Sierra Leone will reveal additional sites for many of these species and<br /><br />
that their IUCN threat category may then be downgraded. On the other hand, in view of the<br /><br />
surprisingly high number of species of conservation concern already identified, it is quite likely that<br /><br />
some further threatened species will be uncovered by more detailed survey work within the Project<br /><br />
area.<br /><br />
The maps in figs. 18 & 19 pinpoint the distribution of the species of conservation concern in the<br /><br />
Tonkolili region. As anticipated, the four most “natural” habitats identified in the reconnaissance study,<br /><br />
together with the rheophytic community, contain the highest number of conservation species (table 9).<br /><br />
Based upon our current sampling, the highest concentrations of these species can be found:<br /><br />
a) in the riverine forest E of the village of Farangbeya in proposed tailings option 4<br /><br />
b) in the hillslope forest W of the village of Kegbema on the edge of proposed tailings option 4<br /><br />
c) in the small seepage grassland area on the S slopes of Marampon<br /><br />
