<br /><br />
30<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6. RECONNAISSANCE SURVEY OF POTENTIAL TAILINGS OR<br /><br />
INFRASTRUCTURE PLACEMENT<br /><br />
The vegetation and species of conservation concern identified by the reconnaissance survey of the<br /><br />
three potential tailings or infrastructure sites have been covered in sections 4 & 5 of this report; the<br /><br />
current section aims to provide recommendations based upon the relative conservation importance of<br /><br />
the three options; these must, however, be viewed as provisional in view of the limited survey work<br /><br />
carried out at these sites to date:<br /><br />
OPTION 4: Tonkolili River system E of the Kunsulma ridge and W of the deposits<br /><br />
In view of the intact areas of species-rich riverine forest and the high number of conservation priority<br /><br />
species recorded both in the forest and in the river channel along this section of the Tonkolili River<br /><br />
(see sections 4.2 & 4.3), this area is viewed as the most important site for conservation in the Project<br /><br />
area. This area would not, therefore, be recommended for development. Concerns over the potentially<br /><br />
high impact of the mining activity itself upon this river system must also be considered in view of the<br /><br />
presence of several species of high conservation significance here.<br /><br />
OPTION 1: Tonkolili River system W of the Kunsulma ridge, S of Bumbuna town<br /><br />
Whilst much of the riverine forest of the Tonkolili River is degraded in the northern section of option 1,<br /><br />
three species of conservation importance have already been found within the forest remnants and<br /><br />
adjacent degraded habitats (Anthonotha explicans vel sp. aff., Brachystegia leonensis, Dialium<br /><br />
pobeguinii) and it is likely that others will be uncovered if the area is surveyed in more detail.<br /><br />
Furthermore, it appears from aerial photographs that the more remote stretches of the river in the<br /><br />
southern portion of this tailings area may hold more intact riverine forest. Due to difficulties of access,<br /><br />
this portion has not yet been surveyed on foot and it is recommended that this is carried out prior to<br /><br />
any further decision on the development of this site.<br /><br />
OPTION 5: River system E of the deposits<br /><br />
Our preliminary survey work has so far not revealed any sizable areas of conservation importance<br /><br />
within this option, and no species of conservation concern with the exception of the low priority Hallea<br /><br />
stipulosa. Patches of forest within this valley system are largely restricted to small community forests<br /><br />
adjacent to villages, with the riverine fringe being heavily degraded at least in the areas visited.<br /><br />
Further survey work is, however, required in the patches of “natural” wooded grassland and valley<br /><br />
swamp.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7. INITIAL SURVEY OF POTENTIAL OFFSET SITES<br /><br />
The identification of sites suitable for offsetting the losses of biodiversity on the proposed mine site<br /><br />
must be informed by the vegetation survey and the identification of conservation priority species /<br /><br />
habitats. It would therefore have been premature to carry out extensive searches for such sites during<br /><br />
the Nov-Dec 2009 visit. However, some initial work on potential offset / species translocation sites was<br /><br />
conducted in the immeditate vicinity of the Project area (see fig. 2):<br /><br />
Farangbeya Forest Reserve (c. 9°01’ N 11°43’ W)<br /><br />
This reserve lies along the ridge and steep slopes of the Kunsulma Range to the W of the mine<br /><br />
deposits down to the point at which the Tonkolili River bissects this range. Whilst nominally “protected”<br /><br />
as a Reserve, no practical protection is in place and the vast majority of the forest has been replaced<br /><br />
by farmland and regenerating secondary thicket of low conservation value. Several forest remnants<br /><br />
were visited towards the ridge summit and found to contain groves of Cryptosepalum tetraphyllum, a<br /><br />
conservation priority species (IUCN: VU). These sites were, however, degraded and had little<br /><br />
additional conservation value. The notable exception is the forest patch SW of Kegbema which<br /><br />
apparently falls just within the boundary of the Farangbeya F.R. – this site is discussed in detail in<br /><br />
sections 4.1 and 4.2 and should be considered a good candidate for protection as an offset against<br /><br />
the loss of the Simbili forest patches. The Kegbema forest clearly has significance to the local<br /><br />
community and so involvement of the local community in its protection would be vital.<br /><br />
The Farangbeya Forest Reserve may be a good candidate for a habitat restoration project, with<br /><br />
translocation of forest species from the deposit sites. This could provide a high profile positive<br /><br />
<br /><br />
31<br /><br />
<br /><br />
conservation project for the client in collaboration with both national government and local<br /><br />
communities.<br /><br />
Bantho Hill Forest (9°03’ N 11°41’ W)<br /><br />
This small patch of forest is located on the ridge summit of the Kunsulma Range to the north of the<br /><br />
Farangbeya Forest Reserve and is accessed from Bongbongba village to the north on Numbara Hill. A<br /><br />
day visit was made to this site by one of the botanical teams in an attempt to find some of the rare<br /><br />
hillslope forest species recorded at Simbili. The slopes of the ridge here are again almost completely<br /><br />
converted to farmbush and secondary thicket. The forest contains many large trees of<br /><br />
Piptadeniastrum africanum, an indicator of secondary forest, and the open canopy and dense shrubdominated understorey would support this. No Cryptosepalum tetraphyllum was found. Two species of<br /><br />
conservation concern were recorded here: the timber tree Heritiera utilis and the rare shrub Pavetta<br /><br />
platycalyx; this latter species was fairly common at this but has strangely not yet been recorded from<br /><br />
the forests on or adjacent to the deposits. The Bantho Forest appears to be preserved by the local<br /><br />
community, perhaps as a hunting area (hunting trails are certainly in evidence here).<br /><br />
Sakonke Hill (9°04’ N 11°39’ W)<br /><br />
This large hill (summit c. 860 m alt.) is situated to the N of Numbara Hill and is accessed from the<br /><br />
village of Sasakala. It was chosen for survey as it is the most accessible hill outside the mining<br /><br />
exploration license with extensive areas of hill summit grassland and so potentially holding<br /><br />
Pseudovigna sp. nov. A full day site visit was made by one of the botanical teams. The summit had<br /><br />
been recently burnt but we were still able to locate the Pseudovigna here, recording 99 plants over a<br /><br />
wide area. Whilst the population is not as large as on Numbara, this is still an important site for this<br /><br />
species and could be suitable for translocation of plants from the deposit sites.<br /><br />
Also found on the descent on the NE and E sides of the hill was a series of small seepage grasslands.<br /><br />
Whilst these had largely dried out by the time of our visit, two species of high conservation concern<br /><br />
were found: Dilophotriche sp. ?nov. and Bryaspis humularioides subsp. falcistipulata. These wet<br /><br />
grasslands should be surveyed further at the optimum time (late Oct–early Nov) and may prove to<br /><br />
contain a similar range of species to the seepage grasslands on Marampon.<br /><br />
The majority of the lower slopes of this hill are covered in a mosaic of farmland and secondary<br /><br />
bushland of low conservation concern.<br /><br />
Further work on identification of suitable offset / translocation sites will need to involve wider searches<br /><br />
well beyond the Project area, aided by available maps and satellite imagery. Potential sites for such<br /><br />
work are listed in section 9.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
8. PRELIMINARY CONCLUSIONS<br /><br />
Based upon the vegetation survey and plant inventory work carried out to date, we have identified five<br /><br />
habitats of conservation concern within the Tonkolili Project area, here listed together with the key<br /><br />
sites of importance:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Riverine forest (riverine strip near Farangbeya village)<br /><br />
Hillslope forest (forest patch SW of Kegbema village)<br /><br />
Seasonally wet grassland (seepage area on S slopes of Marampon)<br /><br />
Hill summit grassland and wooded grassland (Numbara summit)<br /><br />
River channel plant communities (riverine strip near Farangbeya village)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Whilst these habitats together only constitute a small percentage of the total land cover in the Project<br /><br />
area (the large majority being taken up by farmland and secondary vegetation communities of low<br /><br />
conservation concern), they together contain over 30 rare and potentially threatened plant species and<br /><br />
a rich plant diversity.<br /><br />
Wherever possible, efforts should be made to prevent the loss of these habitats and the populations of<br /><br />
these key species during future mining activity. Where this is unavoidable, measures should be put in<br /><br />
place to mitigate or offset the impact of these losses through a combination of ex situ conservation<br /><br />
measures and identification of comparable sites for protection and/or management as offsets.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
32<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The work conducted to date provides a strong baseline for recommendations on conservation<br /><br />
priorities and proposed conservation actions; however, a series of additional surveys are required to<br /><br />
supplement this work; a full list of recommendations is provided in section 9.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9. RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FURTHER BOTANICAL WORK<br /><br />
1) Further survey work on the deposits<br /><br />
Whilst the survey work conducted to date has covered the vegetation on the deposits in some detail, it<br /><br />
cannot be considered exhaustive. In particular, it would be desirable to cover a greater range of the<br /><br />
seasonal variation to capture:<br /><br />
• dry season flowering species, including short-lived post-burning herbs in the wooded<br /><br />
grasslands (Jan–March)<br /><br />
• species triggered by the onset of the early rains (March-May)<br /><br />
• optimal flowering and fruiting time for the seasonally inundated grasslands (mid Oct–early<br /><br />
Nov)<br /><br />
• low water levels in the rivers for optimal study of the rheophytic communities (Jan–March)<br /><br />
• flowering and fruiting material for those species with currently uncertain identity<br /><br />
• a full survey of the weedy species, with emphasis upon potentially invasive species for<br /><br />
which some control measures may have to be put in place.<br /><br />
The species accumulation curve for the forest plots surveyed to date (fig. 6) demonstrates that our<br /><br />
species coverage in the forests is incomplete (see section 4.2); we would recommend further walkover survey and particularly plot work within the remaining forest patches.<br /><br />
2) Ethnobotanical survey<br /><br />
To engage with local communities, aided by the PROs employed by AML at Farangbeya, to catalogue<br /><br />
the plants used locally for food, medicines etc. This will provide important information on the types and<br /><br />
locations of natural vegetation which have social and cultural significance. It would feed into the wider<br /><br />
social aspects of the ESIA.<br /><br />
3) Further survey work in the proposed tailings options<br /><br />
With the exception of the northern section of option 4, only a rapid reconnaissance survey of the<br /><br />
proposed tailings options has been carried out to date. Further survey is therefore essential within the<br /><br />
chosen option.<br /><br />
A botanical survey of the rail corridor and site of the new port will also need to be conducted as part of<br /><br />
the wider EISA. Initially, a desktop study using baseline data held at RBG Kew could be used to<br /><br />
pinpoint any sites along the proposed route(s) that might have species of high conservation concern.<br /><br />
4) Follow-up surveys of the species of high conservation concern<br /><br />
The 34 species of conservation concern, and in particular the nine species highlighted as of highest<br /><br />
priority (table 8), must be addressed in detail. The first stage must be to investigate more fully their<br /><br />
current distribution. Maps and available satellite imagery (e.g. Google Earth, Landsat), together with<br /><br />
historic plant specimen data, can be used to identify potentially suitable sites for each of the species.<br /><br />
Subsequent site visits should be made to co-incide with peak flowering/fruiting times for each species<br /><br />
(forest species can be surveyed at any time of year, wooded grassland and inundated grassland<br /><br />
species to be targeted at the wet/dry season transition).<br /><br />
Potential sites to concentrate these efforts would be:<br /><br />
• Northern section of the Sula Mts, including Lake Sonfon National Park (c. 9°15’N 11°35’W)<br /><br />
• Tonkolilini Hill and Gbengbe Hills N of Bumbuna (c. 9°15’N 11°45’W)<br /><br />
• Kangari Hills SE of Magburaka (c. 8°30’N 11°40’W)<br /><br />
• Loma Mts National Park (c. 9°10’N 11°5’W)<br /><br />
• Tingi Mts NE of Kono (c. 8°55’N 10°47’W)<br /><br />
• Kekekonko and Gori Hills Se of Kono (c. 8°35’N 10°45’W)<br /><br />
• Nimini Hills SW of Kono (c. 8°30’N 11°10’W)<br /><br />
• Wara Wara Mts N of Fadugu (c. 9°35’N 11°40’W)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
33<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Past experience has shown that it is highly likely that we will be able to uncover additional secure sites<br /><br />
for many of the conservation species. This is likely to lead to a downgrading of their conservation<br /><br />
status. More importantly, it will help us to identify sites suitable for safe-guarding of these species and<br /><br />
potential areas for population translocation as future offset / mitigation for the proposed mine.<br /><br />
Of the two ‘unique’ species at Tonkolili, we have already had some success with Pseudovigna sp.<br /><br />
nov., having located a population of c. 100 plants on Sakonke Hill, beyond the mining concession. It is<br /><br />
anticipated that further investigation along the Sula Mts chain will reveal additional sites for this<br /><br />
species. Of greater concern is the (potentially) new species of Eriocaulon. Whilst our initial suggestion<br /><br />
is to search for other river sites suitable for this species, it is quite likely that this species will remain at<br /><br />
least Endangered. If so, all efforts must be made to protect the Tonkolili River against significant<br /><br />
environmental changes during the mining operations.<br /><br />
5) Identification of suitable offset localities<br /><br />
Where appropriate, the losses of natural vegetation on the mine site can be offset by formal protection<br /><br />
of equivalent (or more diverse and/or larger) site(s) within Sierra Leone. The bulk of this work would<br /><br />
be carried out in tandem with recommendation 4.<br /><br />
However, it should be noted that under the current published IFC Performance Standard 6, habitats<br /><br />
containing species assessed as EN or CR are not offsettable and alternative solutions would be<br /><br />
required. Whilst PS6 is being modified to be more flexible regarding such species, they may well still<br /><br />
trigger strict regulations.<br /><br />
6) Establishment of in-situ and ex-situ conservation measures for the species of high<br /><br />
conservation concern<br /><br />
• Collection and banking of seeds provides an ex situ conservation measure; these seeds could be<br /><br />
stored in country and, as a back up, at the Millennium Seedbank (MSB) at RBG Kew. Initial training<br /><br />
in seed collection and storage could be provided through the MSB. A portion of the seed collections<br /><br />
can subsequently be used for translocation of species to secure sites, post-mining habitat<br /><br />
restoration, growing on in botanic gardens to establish germination protocols etc.<br /><br />
• Establishment of an on-site tree nursery; this is particularly useful for species not suitable for longterm seed storage (usually wet forest species). These trees can again be used for translocation,<br /><br />
restoration etc. Following initial horticultural training, the tree nursery can subsequently be run<br /><br />
through the local community, providing a source of employment.<br /><br />
• One possibility worth exploring would be for African Minerals to work with local government on the<br /><br />
restoration of parts of the Farangbeya Forest Reserve as an offset against the loss of forest on the<br /><br />
mine deposits. This would be a high profile conservation effort which could be run in collaboration<br /><br />
with the local community.<br /><br />
7) Continued institutional capacity building in Sierra Leone<br /><br />
Building in-country capacity, through training and donation of essential equipment, will permit our local<br /><br />
institutional partners to take a more central role in the follow-up survey and conservation work. This<br /><br />
process was begun successfully during the Sept and Nov-Dec visits. To build upon this, it is<br /><br />
recommended that one staff member from each of the two partner institutions are seconded to RBG<br /><br />
Kew for a short intern period (c. 1 month) to train in plant identification, vegetation analysis, seed<br /><br />
collection and storage methods etc.<br /><br />
In addition, it would be highly desirable to have employed an on-site full-time Environmental Scientist<br /><br />
who could be trained through RBG Kew and partner institutions in Sierra Leone in plant survey and<br /><br />
monitoring techniques, specimen and seed collection and basic horticultural skills. This person would<br /><br />
be ideally placed to oversee or assist in the above recommendations, with RBG Kew playing an<br /><br />
advisary and supporting role.<br /><br />
8) Immediate / short-term conservation recommendations<br /><br />
In view of the continuing exploratory work at the mine site, there is a significant risk that some of the<br /><br />
priority habitats and species will be lost or damaged prior to any conservation measures being<br /><br />
implemented. It is therefore recommended that some protection measures are put in-place<br /><br />
immediately, for example through cordoning off the key sites and briefing the ground staff. The key<br /><br />
sites to be protected at present are:<br /><br />
• Strip of riverine forest near Farangbeya<br /><br />
• Forest patch to the southwest of Kegbema on the edge of the Farangbeya Forest Reserve<br /><br />
• Seepage grassland on S slopes of Marampon<br /><br />
<br /><br />
34<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• Hill summit grassland on Numbara<br /><br />
• Seasonally inundated depression on summit of Numbara, drill platform NURC005<br /><br />
• Valley swamp at foot of Numbara (to protect the colony of Aeschynomene deightonii)<br /><br />

<br /><br />
ANNEX 2: DETAILED ANALYSIS OF SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Aeschynomene deightonii Hepper (Leguminosae-Papilionoideae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. On the basis of current evidence, this species would qualify as Vulnerable VU<br /><br />
B2ab(iii). A rare herb of wetlands, it is likely to have suffered declines due to conversion of its favoured habitats to<br /><br />
rice cultivation; the Tonkolili site is threatened by disturbance and pollution/sedimentation from future mining<br /><br />
activity on the adjacent Numbara Hill.<br /><br />
Distribution: Guinea (2 sites); Sierra Leone (5 sites); Côte d'Ivoire; (1 site); Ghana (1 site).<br /><br />
Habitat: Wet grassland, ditches, marshes and shallow valley swamps.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Inland valley swamp – common in shallow sedge-dominated swamp at foot of Numbara (9°0’44.7N<br /><br />
11°40’48.4”W).<br /><br />
Note: this species is also likely to occur in the valley swamps within tailings option 5.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Afzelia africana Sm. (Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU A1d (African Regional Workshop (Conservation & Sustainable Management of Trees,<br /><br />
Zimbabwe) 1998). A widespread species, considered threatened by exploitation of the timber for commercial<br /><br />
trade.<br /><br />
Distribution: Senegal; Guinea-Bissau; Guinea; Sierra Leone; Côte d'Ivoire; Mali; Burkina Faso; Ghana; Togo;<br /><br />
Benin; Nigeria; Cameroon; Chad; Niger; Central African Republic; Congo-Brazzaville; D.R. Congo; Sudan;<br /><br />
Uganda.<br /><br />
Habitat: Tree, typically in drier types of forest and forest-wooded grassland transition; rocky areas in moist forest.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Secondary Thicket – a single tree sapling 0.5 m tall found in plot T11 on the Marampon-Simbili saddle.<br /><br />
Hillslope forest – a tree sapling 1.5 m tall in plot 12, Kegbema forest.<br /><br />
Note: this very widespread species is considered of low conservation priority for the Project, particularly as it has<br /><br />
been found regenariting (albeit 1 plant so far) in secondary habitat.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
53<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Amanoa bracteosa Planch. (Euphorbiaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU A1c, B1+2c (Hawthorne 1998). A local species threatened principally by habitat loss.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone (8 sites); Liberia (5 sites); Côte d'Ivoire (4 sites); Ghana (1 site); Cameroon (1 site –<br /><br />
Korup NP).<br /><br />
Habitat: Tree in a range of wet evergreen forest types, particularly in swampy areas and along riverbanks.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Riverine Forest - recorded from riverine forest strip between Wandugu and Foraia and W of Foraia in<br /><br />
proposed tailings option 4.<br /><br />
Note: the current IUCN assessment of this species is outdated and if re-assessed it would no longer be<br /><br />
considered VU under criterion B, although it is still reasonably treated as VU under criterion A.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Anopyxis klaineana (Pierre) Engl. (Rhizophoraceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU A1cd (Hawthorne 1998). A locally common timber species, threatened by a combination of<br /><br />
habitat loss, over-exploitation of its timber and poor seed viability / regeneration.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone; Liberia; Côte d'Ivoire; Ghana; Nigeria; Cameroon; Congo-Brazzaville; Sudan; Ethiopia.<br /><br />
Habitat: Canopy tree in a range of forest types but particularly in wet evergreen forest.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Riverine Forest – one 30 m tree recorded in Farangbeya riverine forest.<br /><br />
Note: as this species is so widespread and still reasonably common, it is considered of lesser conservation<br /><br />
concern to those species assessed here as VU based on criterion B.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
54<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Anthonotha explicans (Baill.) J.Léonard vel sp. aff. (Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. On the basis of current evidence, A. explicans would qualify as Vulnerable VU<br /><br />
B2ab(iii). This is a rare tree threatened by habitat loss throughout its range.<br /><br />
Distribution: for A. explicans - Senegal (unknown number of sites); Guinea (3 sites); Sierra Leone (1 site); Liberia<br /><br />
(3 sites); Côte d'Ivoire (1 site).<br /><br />
Habitat: Wet evergreen forest and wooded grassland.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Secondary thicket – a colony of several small trees found in farmbush near the Tonkolili River in<br /><br />
proposed tailings option 1.<br /><br />
Note: the first priority is to confirm the identity of the population at the Project area (fertile material is desirable). As<br /><br />
it was found growing in farmbush, this may not be a species of high conservation priority.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Anubias gracilis A.Chev. ex Hutch. (Araceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. On the basis of current evidence, this subspecies would qualify as Vulnerable VU<br /><br />
B2ab(iii). A rare herb restricted to river channels in the Guinea (Loma-Man) Highlands. The current site and one<br /><br />
site in Guinea are directly threatened by proposed mining activity which would alter the river volume and<br /><br />
sedimentation rates significantly.<br /><br />
Distribution: Guinea (4 sites); Sierra Leone (3 sites); Liberia (?1 site).<br /><br />
Habitat: Herb of rocky streambeds, typically in sluggish and shallow water.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: River channel community – a single plant collected from the margins of the Tonkolili River E of<br /><br />
Farangbeya village.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
55<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Aphanocalyx pteridophyllus (Harms) Wieringa (Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. On the basis of current evidence, this subspecies would qualify as Vulnerable<br /><br />
under IUCN criteria A2c and B2ab(iii). This is a localised species and has suffered from extensive habitat loss<br /><br />
throughout its range; a comparison of forest cover loss maps in Chatelain et al. (2004, p.16) with the distribution<br /><br />
map of this species (Poorter et al. 2004) indicates that most of its former potential habitat has been lost.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone (5 sites); Liberia (5 sites).<br /><br />
Habitat: Tree of evergreen forest including riverine fringes.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Riverine forest – a common component of the riverine fringe from E of Farangbeya to W of Foraia and<br /><br />
probably beyond, but not recorded in the disturbed riverine forest of proposed tailings option 1. Many fruiting trees<br /><br />
seen and many young saplings recorded.<br /><br />
Note: The upper Tonkolili River must be considered a site of global significance for this species.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Brachystegia leonensis Burtt Davy & Hutch. (Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. On the basis of current evidence, this subspecies would qualify as Vulnerable<br /><br />
under IUCN criterion A2c. This is a highly localised species and has suffered from extensive habitat loss<br /><br />
throughout its range which is comparable with that of Aphanocalyx pteridophyllus.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone (4 sites); Liberia (4 sites); W Côte d’Ivoire (c. 7 sites).<br /><br />
Habitat: Tree of wet evergreen forest.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Riverine forest – several trees recorded along river E of Farangbeya; 15 large trees and regenerating<br /><br />
seedlings recorded in degraded riverine forest along Tonkolili River in proposed tailings option 1.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
56<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Bryaspis humularioides Gledhill subsp. falcistipulata Gledhill (Leguminosae–Papilionoideae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. On the basis of current evidence, this subspecies would qualify as Endangered<br /><br />
(EN B2ab(iii)), being known from only three sites with the Marampon site being directly threatened by the<br /><br />
proposed mining activity. Subsp. humularioides is similarly rare, being known from a single Liberian collection,<br /><br />
hence the species as a whole must also be considered Endangered.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone (3 sites – type locality is Gbengbe Hill, Bumban, to the NW of Bumbuna).<br /><br />
Habitat: Seepage grassland over bedrock.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Seasonally wet grassland – one population of c. 10 plants on south slopes of Marampon peak; a<br /><br />
second similarly small population on NE slopes of Sakonke Hill.<br /><br />
Note: the wet grassland at the latter site had dried by the time of our visit (1/12/09) with only dried old stems of the<br /><br />
Bryaspis remaining; no herbarium voucher was therefore made and the identification is provisional, as the similar<br /><br />
B. lupulina also occurs in SL. This population should be revisited to confirm the identification.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Copaifera salikounda Heckel (Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU A1d (African Regional Workshop (Conservation & Sustainable Management of Trees,<br /><br />
Zimbabwe) 1998). Considered threatened on the basis of exploitation of its timber and habitat loss throughout its<br /><br />
range causing population declines.<br /><br />
Distribution: Guinea; Sierra Leone; Liberia; Côte d'Ivoire; Ghana. Over 20 sites known.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Riverine forest – one tree in fruit found in Farangbeya river forest.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
57<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Cryptosepalum tetraphyllum (Hook.f.) Benth. (Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU A1c, B1+2c (Hawthorne 1998). A rare forest species, threatened by habitat decline<br /><br />
throughout its range.<br /><br />
Distribution: Guinea; Sierra Leone; Liberia; Côte d’Ivoire; Ghana. Over 20 sites known, the majority in Sierra<br /><br />
Leone.<br /><br />
Habitat: Tree of wet forest and along riverine fringes in drier forest types.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Hillslope forest – Simbili Forest, 14 trees over 10cm dbh and many saplings present in plot 9; several<br /><br />
trees in Kegbema Forest; several small groves of this species in the degraded forest of Farngbeya Forest<br /><br />
Reserve. Riverine forest – single tree recorded in riverine fringe between Wandugu and Foraia in proposed tailings<br /><br />
option 4.<br /><br />
Note: although clearly rare, the assessment of VU under criterion B would no longer stand if reassessed; however,<br /><br />
the assessment of VU under criterion A appears correct. This is an important component of the remnant forests in<br /><br />
the Project area and must be considered a key species for any proposed forest restoration schemes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dactyladenia smeathmannii (Baill.) Prance & F.White (Chrysobalanaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. On the basis of current evidence, this subspecies would qualify as Endangered<br /><br />
under criterion B2ab(iii). A very rare species, with only 5 previous collections known, the 4 Sierra Leone<br /><br />
specimens being historic, two without precise locality. The current site is threatened by alteration of the Tonkolili<br /><br />
River system due to the proposed mining activity.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone (3 known sites); Liberia (1 site).<br /><br />
Habitat: Tree of forest; in Liberia recorded from secondary growth and on almost bare rock but at Tonkolili<br /><br />
restricted to undisturbed riverine forest.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Riverine forest – 3 flowering trees E of Farangbeya; a single flowering tree W of Foraia in proposed<br /><br />
tailings option 4.<br /><br />
Note: this species may prove to be more common along the Tonkolili River than currently documented as it was<br /><br />
not targetted as of high conservation concern during the Nov-Dec survey. A full survey of its status in the Project<br /><br />
area is therefore recommended as a first step. Care should be taken to separate this species from other closely<br /><br />
related Dactyladenia spp.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
58<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dialium pobeguinii Pellegr. (Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. On the basis of current evidence, this subspecies would certainly qualify as<br /><br />
Vulnerable under criterion B2ab(iii) but may well qualify as Endangered under criterion A. This is a rare species<br /><br />
restricted to a very few localities. The current site is threatened by alteration of the Tonkolili River system due to<br /><br />
the proposed mining activity.<br /><br />
Distribution: Guinea (2 sites); Sierra Leone (4 sites).<br /><br />
Habitat: Tree restricted to riverine forest.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Riverine forest – disturbed forest along the Tonkolili River in proposed tailings option 1, a single c. 12 m<br /><br />
high tree recorded to date.<br /><br />
Note: Most of the historic collections are from the Njala area; this area should be revisited to check if it is still<br /><br />
extant there. A survey of this species’ abundance along the Tonkolili River should be conducted.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dilophotriche sp. ?nov. (Gramineae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed, with confirmation of the status of this species needed prior to further assessment;.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone, apparently restricted to the Southern Sula Mts.<br /><br />
Habitat: A perennial grass of seasonal wet flushes on hillslope grassland.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Seasonally wet grassland – a single sizable population in an area c. 20 × 20 m on the slopes of<br /><br />
Sakonke Hill.<br /><br />
Note: the single known site is not on the mine deposits and is actually outside the wider concession area.<br /><br />
However, it is quite possible that this species also occurs on the mine site - the wet flushes were drying out at the<br /><br />
time of the visit and flowering can end abruptly at the onset of the dry season; grasses are largely impossible to<br /><br />
identify when lacking flowers and fruits hence it may have been missed if not flowering e.g. on the flushes S and<br /><br />
SE of Marampon; this area should be thoroughly checked for this species.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
59<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Drypetes afzelii (Pax) Hutch. (Euphorbiaceae / Putranjavaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU A1c, B1+2c (Hawthorne 1998). An uncommon species that has suffered from general<br /><br />
declines in its habitat because of mining, logging and commercial forestry activities.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone (12 sites); Liberia (2 sites); Côte d'Ivoire (4 sites); Ghana (no. of sites unknown).<br /><br />
Habitat: Shrub or small (to medium) tree of wet evergreen forest, generally along rivers.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Hillslope forest - several records from Kegbema Forest including disturbed areas; four small trees in plot<br /><br />
12.<br /><br />
Note: the assessment of VU under criterion B would no longer stand if reassessed; however, the assessment of<br /><br />
VU under criterion A may be correct; it is certainly a local species with Sierra Leone being the most important<br /><br />
country.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Entandrophragma cylindricum (Sprague) Sprague (Meliaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU A1cd (Hawthorne 1998). A prime timber species, exploited heavily throughout its range.<br /><br />
Large-scale depletion of mature individuals from populations has taken place in some countries.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone; Côte d'Ivoire; Ghana; Togo; Nigeria; Cameroon; Gabon; Congo-Brazzaville; D.R.<br /><br />
Congo; Uganda; Angola. Known from many collections.<br /><br />
Habitat: A canopy tree of forest, often in drier, semi-deciduous forest types.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Hillslope forest – one tree to 40 m tall in Simbili Forest.<br /><br />
Note: as this is such a widespread species, it is considered by us to be of lower conservation priority to those<br /><br />
species assessed as VU under criterion B.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
60<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Eriocaulon sp. nov. (Eriocaulaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. Based upon current knowledge, this species would qualify as Critically<br /><br />
Endangered CR B1ab(iii)+B2ab(iii) if it is confirmed as a distinct species. The single locality is threatened by<br /><br />
changes in run-off quantity and reduced water clarity and oxygen-content if/when the mining operations go ahead.<br /><br />
It would be completely lost if proposed tailings option 4 were adopted.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone, apparently restricted to the Southern Sula Mts.<br /><br />
Habitat: A rheophyte growing within river rapids, the foliage often submerged with only the inflorescence exposed<br /><br />
above the water surface.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: River channel community – a single population found in the river E of Farangbeya. The collection made<br /><br />
by Crisp c. 50 years ago is believed to be from the same locality.<br /><br />
Note: it is essential that the status of this species is confirmed as soon as possible; if as expected it proves to be a<br /><br />
new species, all efforts must be made to protect the Tonkolili River from increased disturbance. It should also be<br /><br />
sought for in the southern section of proposed tailings option 4.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Garcinia kola Heckel (Clusiaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU A2cd (Cheek 2004). A widespread but local species, threatened by over-exploitation for use<br /><br />
as chewsticks (dental hygiene) and over-harvesting of the medicinal seeds (bitter cola).<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone; Liberia; Côte d'Ivoire; Ghana; Benin; Cameroon; Gabon; D.R. Congo.<br /><br />
Habitat: Tree of evergreen forest.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Hillslope forest – one record from Simbili Forest; frequent in Kegbema Forest, where the fruits are<br /><br />
harvested by the local community.<br /><br />
Note: This species could be used within a forest restoration programme in view of its value to local communities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
61<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Gilbertiodendron aylmeri (Hutch. & Dalz.) J.Léonard (Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. On the basis of current evidence, this subspecies would qualify as Vulnerable<br /><br />
under criterion B2ab(iii) but may well qualify as Endangered under criterion A2c. It is a rare and very localised<br /><br />
species and is likely to have experienced a serious range decline due to habitat loss.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone (5 sites); Liberia (1 site).<br /><br />
Habitat: A grove-forming canopy tree of wet forest.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Riverine forest – at least 44 trees found in 3 groups in Farangbeya riverine forest; many in fruit.<br /><br />
Note: This is an important species of the Tonkolili riverine forest and in view of its rarity this should be a high<br /><br />
conservation priority in the Project area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Guarea cedrata (A.Chev.) Pellegrin (Meliaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU Alc (World Conservation Monitoring Centre 1998). A timber species with moderate<br /><br />
exploitation; it has also suffered declines due to its similarity to the prime timber tree Entandrophragma angolense.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone; Liberia; Côte d'Ivoire; Ghana; Nigeria; Cameroon; Congo-Brazzaville; D.R. Congo;<br /><br />
Uganda.<br /><br />
Habitat: A canopy tree of moist semi-deciduous forest and in drier areas of evergreen forest; it can be locally<br /><br />
abundant.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Hillslope forest – 3 trees in plot 12 in Kegbema Forest, 1 tree in plot 9 in Simbili Forest.<br /><br />
Note: as this is such a widespread and locally common species, it is considered by us to be of lower conservation<br /><br />
priority to those species assessed as VU under criterion B.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
62<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Guibourtia leonensis J.Léonard (Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. On the basis of current evidence, this subspecies would qualify as Vulnerable<br /><br />
under criterion B2ab(iii) but may well qualify as Endangered under criterion A2c. It is a very rare species and is<br /><br />
likely to have experienced a serious range decline due to habitat loss. Part of the population on the Project area<br /><br />
will be lost if/when the SImbili-Marampon deposits are mined.<br /><br />
Distribution: Guinea Bissau (1 site); Guinea (1 site); Sierra Leone (3 sites); Liberia (1 site); Côte d'Ivoire; Ghana;<br /><br />
Nigeria; Cameroon; Congo-Brazzaville; D.R. Congo; Uganda.<br /><br />
Habitat: A canopy tree of moist semi-deciduous forest and in drier areas of evergreen forest; it can be locally<br /><br />
abundant.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Hillslope forest – saddle between Simbili and Marampon (1 tree seen); Kegbema forest (2 trees seen).<br /><br />
Riverine forest – Tonkolili river at Farangbeya (2 trees seen). All fruiting.<br /><br />
Note: As for the Gilbertiodendron, this should be considerd a high conservation priority species at the Project area<br /><br />
and it is essential to look for additional secure populations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hallea stipulosa (DC.) Leroy (Rubiaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU A1cd (World Conservation Monitoring Centre 1998). An important timber species, overexploited in many areas.<br /><br />
Distribution: Gambia; Senegal; Guinea; Sierra Leone; Ghana; Nigeria;Cameroon; Gabon; Central African<br /><br />
Republic; Congo-Brazzaville; D.R. Congo; Sudan; Uganda; Zambia; Angola.<br /><br />
Habitat: Tree of swamp forest, also growing as a pioneer in open valley swamps including areas cultivated for<br /><br />
rice.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Inland valley swamp – foot of Numbara peak, numerous in small swamp; common as a pioneer tree in<br /><br />
valley swamps in proposed tailings option 5<br /><br />
Note: this species grows as a common pioneer in all valley swamps in this area of Sierra Leone and in view of this<br /><br />
fact, together with its broad distribution, its threatened status must be questioned. It is not considered to be a high<br /><br />
conservation priority here.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
63<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Heritiera utilis (Sprague) Sprague (Sterculiaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU A1cd (Hawthorne 1998). A timber species, threatened by unsustainably high extraction<br /><br />
rates.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone; Liberia; Côte d'Ivoire; Ghana; Gabon.<br /><br />
Habitat: Canopy tree usually in evergreen forest where it can be common.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Hillslope forest – Bantho Hill (1 tree seen). Riverine forest - Farangbeya river forest (1 tree seen).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Leptoderris micrantha Dunn (Leguminosae–Papilionoideae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. On the basis of current evidence, this subspecies would qualify as Endangered EN<br /><br />
B2ab(iii). Despite its wide distribution, it appears to be extremely rare and is threatened by habitat loss.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone (1 site); Ghana (1 site); Nigeria (2 sites).<br /><br />
Habitat: A liana of forest and thicket including riverine forest.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Riverine forest – several lianas seen east of Farangbeya in strip of forest along river bank, collected in<br /><br />
flower.<br /><br />
Note: This is the first record for Sierra Leone, representing a major range expansion for this rarity.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
64<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Nauclea didderrichii (De Wild. & T.Durand) Merrill (Rubiaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: VU A1cd (African Regional Workshop (Conservation & Sustainable Management of Trees,<br /><br />
Zimbabwe)1998). It is heavily exploited for its timber, which is used in general construction work.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone; Liberia; Côte d'Ivoire; Ghana; Nigeria; Cameroon; Central African Republic; Gabon;<br /><br />
Congo-Brazzaville; D.R. Congo; Angola; Uganda; Mozambique.<br /><br />
Habitat: An evergreen forest tree.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Hillslope forest – one large tree seen in Kegbema forest.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Nemum bulbostyloides (S.S.Hooper) J.Raynal (Cyperaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. Based upon current knowledge, this species would qualify as Vulnerable VU<br /><br />
B2ab(i, ii, iii, iv, v). It is a rare submontane species, restricted to the Guinea (Loma-Man) Highlands. The current<br /><br />
site and two sites in the Simandou area of Guinea are directly threatened by planned mining activity.<br /><br />
Distribution: Guinea (6 sites); Sierra Leone (1 site); Liberia (1 site); Côte d'Ivoire (2 sites).<br /><br />
Habitat: Perennial herb of seasonal wet flushes over rock outcrops or laterite.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Seasonally wet grassland – locally common in an area of seasonal wet grassland SE of Marampon Hill<br /><br />
but entirely absent from the well-surveyed seepage area on the S slope of that hill.<br /><br />
Note: This is the first record of this species from Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
65<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Panicum glaucocladum C.E.Hubb. (Gramineae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. Based upon current knowledge, this species would qualify as Vulnerable VU<br /><br />
B2ab(i, ii, iii, iv, v), being known from fewer than 10 sites and with direct threat to the Tonkolili site.<br /><br />
Distribution: Guinea (1 site); Sierra Leone (4 sites); Liberia (1 site); Côte d'Ivoire (2 sites).<br /><br />
Habitat: An annual grass of seasonal wet flushes, growing on shallow bare mud over bedrock.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Seasonally wet grassland – one large population in a small seepage area on S slopes of Marampon.<br /><br />
Note: Several collections have been made from the Loma Mts where it is unlikely to be threatened.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Pavetta platycalyx Bremek.<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. Based upon current knowledge, this species would qualify as Vulnerable VU<br /><br />
B2ab(iii), the principal threat being destruction of its forest habitat.<br /><br />
Distribution: Guinea-Bissau (1 site); Guinea (2 sites); Sierra Leone (2 known sites); Côte d'Ivoire (2 sites).<br /><br />
Habitat: An understorey shrub of wet forest.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Hillslope forest – common in the remnant forest patch on Bantho Hill N of the Farangbeya Forest<br /><br />
Reserve.<br /><br />
Note: This species has not so far been found on the potential mine footprint area, being apparently absent from<br /><br />
the Simbili and Kegbema forests which is curious in view of the proximity of these sites to Bantho hill.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
66<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Placodiscus oblongifolius J.B.Hall (Sapindaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU A1c, B1+2c (Hawthorne 1998). A local species (though apparently fairly common in<br /><br />
Ghana), much of this species’ habitat has been lost to mining, logging and commercial forestry.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone (1 site); Liberia (3 sites); Côte d'Ivoire (5 sites); Ghana (3 sites at Kew).<br /><br />
Habitat: Tree of wet evergreen forest.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Hillslope forest – a single tree 12 m tall in plot 12, Kegbema forest.<br /><br />
Note: This is the first record of this species for Sierra Leone and as it is based on a sterile collection, it requires<br /><br />
confirmation. However, the range extension to SL is not unexpected. This species can no longer be considered VU<br /><br />
under criterion B but its assessment of VU based on criterion A is reasonable.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Placodiscus pseudostipularis Radlk. (Sapindaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Endangered EN B1+2c (Hawthorne 1998) – but see note. Losses of its favoured habitats of lowland<br /><br />
coastal and riverine forest have been severe. Hawthorne & Jongkind (2006) however record it as a “common small<br /><br />
tree…across the region”.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone (6 sites); Liberia (1 site); Côte d'Ivoire (4 sites); Ghana (1 site).<br /><br />
Habitat: A small tree of wet forest, typically in coastal forest remnants and in riverine forest.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Hillslope forest – a single tree 6 m tall in plot 12, Kegbema forest.<br /><br />
Note: Although currently listed as Endangered, this species no longer qualifies as such under criterion B and in<br /><br />
fact would not be considered threatened if reassessed under that criterion; however, it can reasonably considered<br /><br />
as Vulnerable under criterion A.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
67<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Pseudovigna sp. nov. (Leguminoae–Papilionoideae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. Based upon current knowledge, this species would qualify as Endangered EN<br /><br />
B1ab(i, ii, iii, iv, v)+B2ab(i, ii, iii, iv, v). It appears to be restricted to the Sula Mts, with two of the three sites found<br /><br />
to date being directly on the potential mine deposits.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone, apparently restricted to the Southern Sula Mts.<br /><br />
Habitat: A perennial herb of hill-summit lightly wooded fire-prone grassland with exposed iron-rich bedrock.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Natural (wooded) grassland – 3 populations currently known: Numbara peak, estimated population of<br /><br />
several hundred plants; Marampon peak, only one plant found; Sakonke Hill, population survey recorded 99 plants<br /><br />
(but almost certainly not exhaustive).<br /><br />
Note: The successful location of this species on Sakonke Hill bodes well for its discovery on other similar sites<br /><br />
along the Sula Mts chain.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Schizachyrium lomaense A.Camus (Gramineae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. On the basis of current evidence, this subspecies would qualify as Endangered<br /><br />
under criterion B2ab(iii). Previously known only from Mt Bintumane and a single site in the Tingi Mts, Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
The site on the Project area would be destroyed by the proposed mining.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone (3 sites).<br /><br />
Habitat: Perennial grass of wet flushes in montane and submontane grassland.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Seasonally wet grassland – a small population in the seepage area on the S slopes of Marampon.<br /><br />
Note: This species has previously been recorded from higher altitude sites – it is likely to be a submontane<br /><br />
species that just extends into the highest parts of the Sula Mts. This must be considered a high priority<br /><br />
conservation species.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
68<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Schoenoplectiella oxyjulos (S.S.Hooper) Lye (Cyperaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Not currently assessed. Based upon current knowledge, this species would qualify as Vulnerable VU<br /><br />
B2ab(iii). Although very widespread, it is very rare, being known from less than 10 sites globally. The Tonkolili site<br /><br />
would be destroyed by the proposed mining activity.<br /><br />
Distribution: Guinea (2 sites); Sierra Leone (2 sites); Nigeria (2 sites); Cameroon (1 site); Central African<br /><br />
Republic (?1 site); Sudan (1 site).<br /><br />
Habitat: Annual herb of seasonal wet flushes over rock outcrops or laterite.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Seasonally wet grassland – common in a small (c. 10 × 15 m) seasonal wetland on summit of Numbara<br /><br />
Hill.<br /><br />
Note: it is possible that further sites for this species will be uncovered following a visit to the Paris herbarium,<br /><br />
which may result in a down-grading to Near Threatened (NT). It is an inconspicuous species which could be easily<br /><br />
overlooked in the field, perhaps contributing to its apparent scarcity.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Terminalia ivorensis A.Chev. (Combretaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU A1cd (Hawthorne 1998). A timber species, with moderate exploitation in some areas.<br /><br />
Distribution: Guinea; Sierra Leone; Liberia; Côte d’Ivoire; Ghana; Nigeria; Cameroon.<br /><br />
Habitat: Tree of wet forest, often in secondary forest and forest remnants.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Riverine forest – recorded from degraded swampy forest at foot of Numbara peak where this species is<br /><br />
rather frequent with evidence of regeneration.<br /><br />
Note: this species is assessed as VU purely down to its commercial interest; at Tonkolili it has only been found in<br /><br />
degraded habitat, growing as a pioneer and is not considered of high conservation priority.<br /><br />
9<br /><br />
<br /><br />
69<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Turraeanthus africanus (Welw.) Pellegr. (Meliaceae)<br /><br />
IUCN: Vulnerable VU A1cd (African Regional Workshop (Conservation & Sustainable Management of Trees,<br /><br />
Zimbabwe)1998). A widespread timber species, with exploitation resulting in declining populations in some areas.<br /><br />
Distribution: Sierra Leone; Côte d'Ivoire; Ghana; Benin; Nigeria; Cameroon; Equatorial Guinea; D.R. Congo;<br /><br />
Uganda; Angola.<br /><br />
Habitat: Canopy tree of forest, often in semi-deciduous forests on poorly drained soils.<br /><br />
Tonkolili: Hillslope forest – a single 20 m tree recorded in Kegbema forest plot 12.<br /><br />
Note: as this is such a widespread species, it is considered by us to be of lower conservation priority to those<br /><br />
species assessed as VU under criterion B.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Justin Moat, Iain Darbyshire and Xander van der Burgt. RBG, Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:<br /><br />
This report presents the vegetation map for the Tonkolili project area and the wider Tonkolili region,<br /><br />
together with summary information on each of the vegetation classes and their conservation<br /><br />
importance, and an assessment of the confidence limits of the classification. It supplements the<br /><br />
earlier “Report on the Vegetation Survey & Botanical Inventory of the Tonkolili Project Area, Sierra<br /><br />
Leone” (Darbyshire & van der Burgt 2009).<br /><br />
Within the main study area (the deposits Numbara, Marampon and Simbili and the adjacent<br /><br />
potential tailings and infrastructure localities), less than 2% of the total vegetation is classified as<br /><br />
forest despite this being the putative climax vegetation of the region. Less than 7% of the area is<br /><br />
covered by vegetation of high conservation value, with a further 0.6% covered by habitat of<br /><br />
moderate conservation value; these figures are comparable for the wider Tonkolili region. Over<br /><br />
90% of the vegetation is considered to be of low conservation value, the majority being a mosaic of<br /><br />
secondary grassland, bushland and woodland derived from cyclical slash-and-burn agriculture.<br /><br />
This report is presented as a pdf document with the associated GIS data.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS:<br /><br />
The authors would like to thank the following people for their input during the preparation of this<br /><br />
report and accompanying maps: Susana Baena, Martin Cheek, Tracy Irvine and Gemma Marchant<br /><br />
(RBG Kew); Abdulai Feika and Matthew James (Njala University); Kabbie Kanu and Julius Sesay<br /><br />
(Fourah Bay College); Paul Mitchell, Emily Robinson and Craig Watt (SRK Consulting (UK) Ltd.).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
“Tonkolili” Vegetation Map and Botanical Survey. March 2010. RBG Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1. INTRODUCTION<br /><br />
This report provides a written accompaniment to the vegetation maps of the Tonkolili project area.<br /><br />
It concludes the botanical aspects of Phase 2b of the Tonkolili project biodiversity studies,<br /><br />
commissioned by SRK Consulting (UK) Limited on behalf of African Minerals Limited. This report<br /><br />
supplements “Report on the Vegetation Survey & Botanical Inventory of the Tonkolili Project Area,<br /><br />
Sierra Leone” by Darbyshire & van der Burgt (2010) and should be read in conjunction with that<br /><br />
work, although key points from the earlier report are summarised here where appropriate.<br /><br />
The vegetation classification and associated maps fulfil the following deliverables of the Phase 2b<br /><br />
work:<br /><br />
 To provide a detailed characterisation of vegetation types at the project site.<br /><br />
 To provide description and mapping of the habitats of conservation concern.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2. METHODOLOGY<br /><br />
2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
DATA DESCRIPTION<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The main source of data for mapping the vegetation in the Tonkolili project area is a satellite image<br /><br />
from the SPOT family of satellites, tailored to meet the mapping demands. A single multispectral<br /><br />
satellite image (three bands in the visible and near infra red) from HRG – SPOT 5 was acquired<br /><br />
from the SPOT Archive (January 2008, http://www.spotimage.com/) to cover the main area at 5 m<br /><br />
resolution (see Map 1). The image was pre-processed for radiometric corrections and rectified to<br /><br />
UTM WGS 84 (Zone 29 north). This should provide location accuracy to 50 m or better.<br /><br />
A further SPOT image was also purchased from the archive for March 2006, at 20 m resolution<br /><br />
(see Figure 1). This image was to be used to fill in any gaps in the data due to cloud cover on the<br /><br />
2008 image. Ultimately, it was not used for two reasons: first, the cloud cover on the 2008 image<br /><br />
did not impact greatly on the main project area and second, the change in vegetation cover was<br /><br />
significant over the 2 year period.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 1: 2006 SPOT image of the Tonkolili region, 20 m resolution.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In addition to field survey work, the aerial photograph mosaic from March 2009 at 20 cm resolution<br /><br />
was used to provide some ground control and for locational accuracy.<br /><br />
2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
“Tonkolili” Vegetation Map and Botanical Survey. March 2010. RBG Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
An ASTER (Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer) derived Digital<br /><br />
Elevation Model (DEM) was additionally used in the classification.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
VEGETATION CLASSIFICATION SCHEME<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The vegetation classification system adopted is a combined physiognomic-floristic approach which<br /><br />
describes both the vegetation structure and floristic composition (modified from White 1983). The<br /><br />
physiognomic method, looking at the dominant vegetation formation, makes the system easily<br /><br />
recognisable in the field and relates to spectral response from satellite images, which makes the<br /><br />
mapping phase feasible. The physiognomic types are then related to the floristic composition and<br /><br />
key environmental variables to fully describe and characterise the vegetation of the area.<br /><br />
The aim was to produce a repeatable classification process, using standard terminology and<br /><br />
discriminating classification units which are ecologically meaningful and easily discernible in the<br /><br />
field. This vegetation classification scheme intends to discriminate the following vegetation types:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Forest<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Forest on hillslopes<br /><br />
<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Riverine forest<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Grassland<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hill summit (wooded) grassland<br /><br />
<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Grassland<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Bushland<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mature secondary bushland / woodland<br /><br />
<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Secondary bushland / thicket<br /><br />
<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Bushland / grassland transition<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Bare earth / sparse grassland<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Inland Valley Swamp<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Of the vegetation types described in the project area by Darbyshire & van der Burgt (2010), the<br /><br />
River Channel Communities and the Seasonally Wet Grasslands are not mapped here. This is due<br /><br />
in part to their very small areal extent, these sites always being below the minimum mapping unit<br /><br />
area following the map accuracy assessment (see Section 3.3). In addition, it proved impossible to<br /><br />
separate Seasonally Wet Grassland from other grassland communities using GIS and remote<br /><br />
sensing techniques, and we would therefore have had low confidence in any extrapolated areas of<br /><br />
this vegetation class beyond the surveyed sites. Both these vegetation types are of high<br /><br />
conservation concern but together represent only a small fraction of a percentage of the total area<br /><br />
covered. The known Seasonally Wet Grasslands are included as point data on the map of<br /><br />
conservation importance.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FIELD METHODS<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The field survey methods have been outlined in full by Darbyshire & van der Burgt (2010).<br /><br />
The favoured approach to vegetation mapping is to provide an initial GIS-based vegetation<br /><br />
classification using satellite imagery, followed by ground-truthing using pre-selected sampling<br /><br />
localities to cover as wide a range of potential vegetation types and environmental variables as<br /><br />
possible. However, due to both the short timeframe and the unavailability of the SPOT imagery<br /><br />
prior to the field survey period in November-December 2009, this approach could not be adopted.<br /><br />
Instead, the field surveys were conducted using the aerial photograph composite as guidance, with<br /><br />
plots and Ground Control Points (GCPs) being recorded for all the different vegetation types<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
“Tonkolili” Vegetation Map and Botanical Survey. March 2010. RBG Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
observed. These were then used to inform the vegetation classification map. No time has been<br /><br />
available at the time of preparing this report for further ground-truthing of this classification.<br /><br />
It should be noted that accessibility to many areas was limited by the physical terrain, availability of<br /><br />
time and logistics of travel. In addition, sampling effort was different depending on the vegetation<br /><br />
type, giving greater importance to those types considered to have higher conservation value or that<br /><br />
would be most affected by project activities.<br /><br />
Table 1 lists the plots taken in each of the vegetation types considered in this report (also see<br /><br />
Maps 1 and 5):<br /><br />

<br /><br />
2.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
DATA ANALYSIS<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.4.1 REMOTE SENSING ANALYSIS<br /><br />
No additional geometric corrections have been applied to the satellite images (supplied at Level<br /><br />
2A); they have been provided in UTM WGS 84 zone 29N and image analysis was carried out using<br /><br />
this projection to avoid losing data integrity by resampling.<br /><br />
After an initial supervised classification using the SPOT5 image to explore the separability, it<br /><br />
became obvious that some vegetation types could not be easily distinguished spectrally. The main<br /><br />
problems were with the separation of forest from mature bushland / woodland (which grade into<br /><br />
one another). To aid classification, two further bands were added to the SPOT image; these were<br /><br />
two texture images derived from the SPOT infra red and red bands (Variability for a 7x7 pixel area)<br /><br />
which showed the variability in the pixels of the surrounding area (i.e. the higher the number, the<br /><br />
more textured/bumpy the image). This allowed some of the forest areas to be distinguished (as<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
“Tonkolili” Vegetation Map and Botanical Survey. March 2010. RBG Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
these areas are more textured) and also emphasised the more homogenous area (e.g. roads and<br /><br />
areas of bushland).<br /><br />
A supervised classification procedure was applied to a subset of the image (the main study area:<br /><br />
the 3 deposits Numbara, Marampon and Simbili and the adjacent potential tailings and<br /><br />
infrastructure localities) using a maximum likelihood algorithm and training data collected in the first<br /><br />
phase of field work.<br /><br />
The scheme used for this classification tried to separate the 8 broad classes defined in the<br /><br />
vegetation classification scheme.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hill summit grassland did not present a significantly distinctive spectral signature (from<br /><br />
other grassland types), therefore the threshold for this vegetation type was set at 630<br /><br />
metres and above (defined from fieldwork observations) and the classification refined using<br /><br />
a digital elevation model.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Riverine forest also did not present a distinctive spectral signature (from hillslope forest;<br /><br />
this was as expected), but was delimited as forests within 60–90 metres of rivers and<br /><br />
streams (digitised separately). Note: on the maps we have a category called inferred<br /><br />
riverine forest; this is inferred from a combination of river position and fieldwork<br /><br />
observations, as the cloud cover in this region is too high for use of the SPOT imagery.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Inland valley swamps were very difficult to distinguish from secondary bushland and from<br /><br />
the grassland / bushland transition. As there was very little of this vegetation class in the<br /><br />
study area, these were digitised separately and manually.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Areas with cloud cover in the south western part of the image and their associated shadows<br /><br />
provide incorrect reflectance values and disrupted the classification. The main cloud areas were<br /><br />
therefore classified out for the region. There are still areas of haze in the valleys; this again results<br /><br />
in incorrect reflectance values and will disrupt the classification in this area (we note an over<br /><br />
classification of mature bushland in this area; it is more likely to be secondary bushland). These<br /><br />
areas have been left as the algorithm classified, but it should be understood that results here<br /><br />
should be treated as less certain (see Figure 3).<br /><br />
To avoid the “salt-and-pepper” appearance of the pixel-based classified image and to give a more<br /><br />
readable final vegetation map, the original satellite image was run through a segmentation<br /><br />
algorithm, grouping original pixels into segments according to their spectral similarity. The original<br /><br />
pixel-based supervised classification was then used to assign classes to the segmented image.<br /><br />
(see: http://www.idrisi.com/applications/upload/Segmentation-IDRISI-Focus-Paper.pdf).<br /><br />
To test the accuracy of the finalised map, 232 random points were generated for the area. These<br /><br />
were then classified by one of the authors (I.D.) based upon field knowledge and use of the March<br /><br />
2009 aerial photograph composite and SPOT images for the region. Results are given in Section<br /><br />
3.3.<br /><br />
The same analysis was applied to the wider region to give an indication of the vegetation in the<br /><br />
surrounding areas, including the northern sector of the mining exploration license area. It should be<br /><br />
noted that there are no Ground Control Points (GCPs) in these areas, so results are conjectural at<br /><br />
present.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3. RESULTS<br /><br />
3.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
OVERVIEW OF THE VEGETATION<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The vegetation of the Tonkolili region is mapped in Maps 2 and 3. The area is dominated by a<br /><br />
mosaic of grassland and bushland / woodland habitats which are predominantly secondary in<br /><br />
nature and which grade into one another, thus classification into discrete vegetation units can be<br /><br />
difficult.<br /><br />
Comparison of the 2008 SPOT image with the 2009 aerial photo composite shows that a<br /><br />
remarkable amount of vegetation change has occurred in the Tonkolili region within one year; this<br /><br />
is also true based on a comparison of the 2006 and 2008 SPOT images. In particular, large areas<br /><br />
of woody vegetation (chiefly secondary bushland and woodland) has been converted to grassland,<br /><br />
5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
“Tonkolili” Vegetation Map and Botanical Survey. March 2010. RBG Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
almost certainly through slash-and-burn agricultural practices. This may well be typical of the<br /><br />
natural cycling of land from subsistence agricultural land to fallow bushland and back, though it<br /><br />
may also in part reflect the increased migration into the region following the commencement of<br /><br />
mining interest.<br /><br />
In view of this rapid change it should be noted that the precise boundaries of vegetation types<br /><br />
represented on the maps may, in some instances, no longer be the same on the ground, but the<br /><br />
overall picture (that of highly restricted natural vegetation types within a mosaic of secondary<br /><br />
vegetation) remains the same.<br /><br />
Table 2 provides a summary of the areal extent of each vegetation type, with Figure 2 showing the<br /><br />
proportional breakdown for the whole region. Areas and proportional breakdowns are also given for<br /><br />
cloud cover and water (see figure 3 for boundaries of main study are and whole region).<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Map 4 presents the potential conservation importance of habitats in the region, each vegetation<br /><br />
class being assigned High, Medium or Low importance based upon field survey work (see<br /><br />
Darbyshire & van der Burgt 2010). In all areas beyond those visited on the ground, the maximum<br /><br />
conservation importance for that vegetation class is assumed, for example all forest on hillslopes<br /><br />
and all hill summit grassland is recorded as of High importance. In reality, this will of course vary<br /><br />
depending on presence / absence of key species of conservation concern, degree of disturbance<br /><br />
etc. For the sites visited, the conservation importance has been adjusted to reflect knowledge of<br /><br />
the sites. For example, the summit grasslands on Simbili have been downgraded to low importance<br /><br />
as they are disturbed and Pseudovigna sp. nov. (the key conservation priority in this habitat) has<br /><br />
not been found there.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
DESCRIPTION OF THE VEGETATION TYPES<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The vegetation types and the species of conservation concern for each have been described in full<br /><br />
by Darbyshire & van der Burgt (2010) with accompanying photographs and details of their<br /><br />
conservation significance; here, we provide summary information on each type, with:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Areal coverage for the main study area and for the whole SPOT scene (ha & %).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Remote Sensing classification.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
“Tonkolili” Vegetation Map and Botanical Survey. March 2010. RBG Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
