Figure 2: pie chart of vegetation types for the wider Tonkolili region, excluding area of cloud cover<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.1 FOREST ON HILLSLOPES<br /><br />
Statistics<br /><br />
Very small area: c. 590 ha for the wider region and 310 ha (less than 1%) for the main study area.<br /><br />
Locality and physical geography<br /><br />
Often either (1) in the vicinity of villages, these being community forests / sacred groves, or (2) on<br /><br />
hillslopes and ridge summits, in areas rather inaccessible to humans or unfavourable to agriculture.<br /><br />
Remote Sensing classification<br /><br />
This vegetation type can often be confused with the bushland classes, especially mature<br /><br />
secondary bushland / woodland. Some of the vegetation classified as mature bushland may<br /><br />
therefore possibly be forest or have some remnant forest elements. Within the images, forest has a<br /><br />
rough texture.<br /><br />
Vegetation physiognomy/structure<br /><br />
Forest with (partially) closed canopy c. 30 m tall, understory of small trees, shrubs and forest floor<br /><br />
herbs.<br /><br />
Dominant and important species<br /><br />
The canopy layer comprises a diverse range of species with no dominant species, though in some<br /><br />
areas Cryptosepalum tetraphyllum can be locally grove-forming.<br /><br />
7<br /><br />
<br /><br />
“Tonkolili” Vegetation Map and Botanical Survey. March 2010. RBG Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Influential factors and threats<br /><br />
Only very small remnants of this vegetation type, believed to be the climax vegetation of the freedraining areas of the Tonkolili region (with the probable exception of shallow soils on hill summits),<br /><br />
are extant. The remaining sites are usually of cultural significance or used as hunting grounds and<br /><br />
many of the remnants are under continued threat, with evidence of recent fire damage, felling etc.,<br /><br />
particularly along the margins where degradation is clearly evident.<br /><br />
Conservation importance<br /><br />
HIGH or MEDIUM (some of the community forests may be of low conservation importance)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.2 RIVERINE FOREST<br /><br />
Statistics<br /><br />
Very small area: 675 ha (c. 300 classified, 375 inferred) for the wider region and c. 300 (100<br /><br />
classified, 200 inferred) for the main study area (less than 1%).<br /><br />
Locality and physical geography<br /><br />
Within 60–90 m of rivers, often a very narrow strip backing onto agricultural land in the valley floor,<br /><br />
sometimes discontinuous.<br /><br />
Remote Sensing classification<br /><br />
Spatially the same as forest on hillslopes (see Section 3.2.1)., but distinguished by its proximity to<br /><br />
rivers. Whilst this differentiation is perhaps artificial, some minor differences in species composition<br /><br />
justify the separation of the two forest types. Riverine forest can also be confused with the<br /><br />
bushland classes.<br /><br />
Vegetation physiognomy/structure<br /><br />
As for forest on hillslopes.<br /><br />
Dominant and important species<br /><br />
The canopy layer comprises a diverse range of species, including species typical of riverine forest<br /><br />
in West Africa and in some areas grove-forming Caesalpinioid legume species. The understory has<br /><br />
a diverse assemblage of shrubs, small trees and herbs; no species were notably dominant.<br /><br />
Influential factors and threats<br /><br />
Largely as for forest on hillslopes (see above), though these forests would never have occupied a<br /><br />
large total area within the study region.<br /><br />
Conservation importance<br /><br />
HIGH<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.3 GRASSLAND<br /><br />
Statistics<br /><br />
Grassland (excluding hill summit grassland – see below) is extensive in the project area, covering<br /><br />
c. 17,900 ha of the wider region and 6,400 ha (approx. 18%) of the main study area.<br /><br />
Locality and physical geography<br /><br />
Recorded from a wide variety of geographical locations, from valley floors to steep hillslopes.<br /><br />
Remote Sensing classification<br /><br />
Spatially very different to all other vegetation types. There is, however, some variability within the<br /><br />
spatial characteristics of this vegetation type which could be mapped, but much of this is probably<br /><br />
down to seasonal changes, most notably burning. Grassland and bare earth / sparse grassland<br /><br />
form a continuum, hence there is potential for mis-classification of this vegetation type.<br /><br />
8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
“Tonkolili” Vegetation Map and Botanical Survey. March 2010. RBG Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Vegetation physiognomy/structure<br /><br />
“Grassland”, as covered here, includes several inter-related vegetation types which are spatially<br /><br />
indistinguishable (see above): (1) “natural” low altitude (wooded) grassland dominated by tall<br /><br />
perennial grasses with scattered woody species; this habitat is usually associated with cattlegrazing areas; (2) secondary grassland, abundant in the early stages of post-agricultural fallow and<br /><br />
again dominated by tall perennial grasses, and (3) subsistence agricultural land – the low intensity<br /><br />
cropping with irregular field boundaries is not readily separable from “natural” grassland through<br /><br />
the satellite imagery.<br /><br />
Dominant and important species<br /><br />
The “natural” low altitude grasslands are dominated by Loudetia and Hyparrhenia spp. widespread<br /><br />
and common in West Africa. Secondary grasslands are typically dominated by Andropogon<br /><br />
tectorum. The agricultural land will hold cereal species such as rice, often inter-mixed with the<br /><br />
same wild grass species as above.<br /><br />
Influential factors and threats<br /><br />
These grasslands are fire-maintained and reliant on human intervention, through slash-and-burn,<br /><br />
domestic livestock grazing etc. Left fallow and unburnt, pioneer woody species will quickly<br /><br />
encroach.<br /><br />
Conservation importance<br /><br />
LOW<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.4 HILL SUMMIT (WOODED) GRASSLAND<br /><br />
Statistics<br /><br />
Hill Summit Grassland covers 4,870 ha for the wider region and just under 1,800 ha for the main<br /><br />
study area, approx. 5% in both cases.<br /><br />
Locality and physical geography<br /><br />
Hill summits, ridges and upper slopes over c. 630 m altitude, dominating on thin soils over iron-rich<br /><br />
bedrock which is regularly exposed.<br /><br />
Remote Sensing classification<br /><br />
Spatially the same as grassland but is classified as areas over 630 m altitude.<br /><br />
It should be noted that outside the main study area it is not known if the area mapped as hill<br /><br />
summit grassland is compositionally different from “grassland”, although the Sula Mountains ridge<br /><br />
running north was studied through binoculars from the summit of Numbara and did appear to hold<br /><br />
extensive areas of this vegetation type.<br /><br />
There is some variability within the spatial characteristics of this vegetation type which are again<br /><br />
probably due to seasonal changes, principally burning.<br /><br />
Vegetation physiognomy/structure<br /><br />
Tall (2–3 m) grassland with scattered small trees and with areas of bare ground where the bedrock<br /><br />
is exposed, these with a small annual herbaceous community.<br /><br />
Dominant and important species<br /><br />
This grassland is dominated (70–95%) by Loudetia arundinacea, with few associated grass<br /><br />
species. Only 13 tree species have been recorded, the most common being Pterocarpus<br /><br />
erinaceus.<br /><br />
Influential factors and threats<br /><br />
This habitat is fire-maintained. The most obvious threat (beyond the proposed mining activity) is<br /><br />
encroachment of farming which has occurred on Marampon and particularly Simbili. However, the<br /><br />
very thin soils on Numbara have probably prevented encroachment there.<br /><br />
Conservation importance<br /><br />
9<br /><br />
<br /><br />
“Tonkolili” Vegetation Map and Botanical Survey. March 2010. RBG Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
HIGH, but only where (a) Pseudovigna sp. nov. is present and (b) in areas which have not been<br /><br />
degraded by human activity.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.5 SECONDARY BUSHLAND / THICKET<br /><br />
Statistics<br /><br />
Secondary bushland / thicket covers c. 20,200 ha of the wider region and c. 9,200 ha (c. 26%) of<br /><br />
the main study area, this being the most extensive vegetation class.<br /><br />
Locality and physical geography<br /><br />
Recorded from a wide variety of geographical locations, from valley floors to steep hillslopes.<br /><br />
Remote Sensing classification<br /><br />
Secondary bushland / thicket is transitional between the bushland / grassland transition and mature<br /><br />
bushland / woodland (i.e. cut and/or burnt forest) and therefore can be spatially mistaken for these<br /><br />
two classes, but it does have a much more uniform texture than the mature bushland / woodland.<br /><br />
Vegetation physiognomy/structure<br /><br />
A dense thicket of bushes, small trees and lianas, typically 5–10 m tall, with or without a dense<br /><br />
herb layer (depending upon light availability).<br /><br />
Dominant and important species<br /><br />
Pioneer tree species are dominant, notably Dichrostachys cinerea, Anisophyllea laurina, Sterculia<br /><br />
tragacantha and Alchornea cordifolia.<br /><br />
Influential factors and threats<br /><br />
This vegetation class appears to be a phase in the post-fallow vegetation succession. In many<br /><br />
cases it will be temporary, the bushland / thicket being cleared by slash-and-burn. Many of the<br /><br />
woody species show signs of past cutting.<br /><br />
Conservation importance<br /><br />
LOW<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.6 MATURE SECONDARY BUSHLAND / WOODLAND<br /><br />
Statistics<br /><br />
Mature secondary bushland / woodland covers c. 14,100 ha for the wider region and 7,000 ha (c.<br /><br />
20%) for the main study area.<br /><br />
Locality and physical geography<br /><br />
Recorded from a variety of geographical locations, though often adjacent to remnant forest<br /><br />
patches.<br /><br />
Remote Sensing classification<br /><br />
Mature secondary bushland / woodland is often as a secondary transition from forest (i.e. cut<br /><br />
and/or burnt forest) or a more mature phase of secondary bushland/thicket and can therefore can<br /><br />
be spatially mistaken for these classes, but it does have a more uniform texture than forest and a<br /><br />
coarser texture than secondary bushland / thicket.<br /><br />
Vegetation physiognomy/structure<br /><br />
As for secondary bushland / thicket, but often taller (to 15 m or more) and often with some forest<br /><br />
elements (remnant trees or fast growing forest pioneers). Undergrowth usually has few herbs due<br /><br />
to dense woody component.<br /><br />
Dominant and important species<br /><br />
As for secondary bushland / thicket.<br /><br />
Influential factors and threats<br /><br />
10<br /><br />
<br /><br />
“Tonkolili” Vegetation Map and Botanical Survey. March 2010. RBG Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
As for secondary bushland / thicket.<br /><br />
Conservation importance<br /><br />
LOW<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.7 BUSHLAND / GRASSLAND TRANSITION<br /><br />
Statistics<br /><br />
Bushland/grassland transition covers c. 12,000 ha for the wider region and c. 6,300 ha (c. 18%) for<br /><br />
the main study area.<br /><br />
Locality and physical geography<br /><br />
Recorded from a wide variety of geographical locations, from valley floors to steep hillslopes.<br /><br />
Remote Sensing classification<br /><br />
This appears to be a transition vegetation type of low lying bushland mixed within grassland. It can<br /><br />
occasionally be mixed with Inland Valley Swamp.<br /><br />
Vegetation physiognomy/structure<br /><br />
A transitional phase between open grassland / arable land and closed bushland. Some of the<br /><br />
“natural” wooded grassland (almost certainly maintained by cattle grazing) will fall within this<br /><br />
category.<br /><br />
Conservation importance<br /><br />
LOW<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.8 INLAND VALLEY SWAMP<br /><br />
Statistics<br /><br />
Inland Valley Swamp covers only 1,220 ha of the wider region and c. 220 ha (less than 1%) of the<br /><br />
main study area.<br /><br />
Locality and physical geography<br /><br />
Located within river / stream valleys, this habitat is frequently encountered only in the south east<br /><br />
portion of the study area, though it is widespread in Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
Remote Sensing classification<br /><br />
Inland Valley Swamp is often confused with bushland/grassland transition. It was therefore digitised<br /><br />
separately and manually. In view of this confusion, it is possible that this habitat type is somewhat<br /><br />
over-represented in the southeastern portion of the region.<br /><br />
Vegetation physiognomy/structure<br /><br />
Typically dominated by herbaceous species, either native wetland species such as sedges, or with<br /><br />
intensive rice cultivation. Woody species are sparse, though it is possible that, left undisturbed,<br /><br />
these sites would eventually revert to woodland or forest.<br /><br />
Dominant and important species<br /><br />
In the areas not given over to rice cultivation (? fallow), a mixed herb community including a variety<br /><br />
of sedge species dominates. The small palm Raphia palma-pinus and the tree Hallea stipulosa are<br /><br />
also common.<br /><br />
Influential factors and threats<br /><br />
Rice farming is common in this habitat; some of these swamps are probably artificially maintained<br /><br />
for this purpose. Drainage or infilling are the main threats.<br /><br />
Conservation importance<br /><br />
MEDIUM<br /><br />
11<br /><br />
<br /><br />
“Tonkolili” Vegetation Map and Botanical Survey. March 2010. RBG Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.9 OTHER CLASSES<br /><br />
3.2.9.1 BARE EARTH / SPARSE GRASSLAND<br /><br />
This class includes a variety of land uses (most notably towns and villages, recently cleared land<br /><br />
for agriculture etc.). Areas of rock outcrops will be of more interest botanically but there are no<br /><br />
significant areas of this on the mine deposits or likely to be impacted by the associated<br /><br />
infrastructure, tailings etc.<br /><br />
This class can be spatially over-represented in areas where there is haze on the imagery.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.10 OTHER CLASSES: NON-VEGETATION<br /><br />
3.2.10.1 CLOUD<br /><br />
Cloud cover distorts the south west section of the 2008 SPOT image.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.10.2 WATER<br /><br />
Very distinct. Represented here by the rivers and by the (then only partially filled) Bumbuna<br /><br />
reservoir.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
MAP ACCURACY ASSESSMENT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Vegetation maps derived from remotely sensed data inevitably contain errors of various types and<br /><br />
degrees. These errors may arise for a number of reasons:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Limited positional accuracy: more likely when the observations are made close to a class<br /><br />
boundary or in a transition zone.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Inability to sample randomly due to accessibility restrictions.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Misinterpretation of classes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Distortions introduced by data processing and classification techniques.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Therefore, accuracy assessment is an important step in vegetation mapping because estimates of<br /><br />
these errors allows for the assessment of data suitability for a particular application.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.3.1 POSITIONAL ACCURACY<br /><br />
Positional accuracy is an assessment of the closeness of the location of spatial objects in relation<br /><br />
to their true positions on the earth's surface. When working with satellite images, positional<br /><br />
accuracy is dependent on the geometric corrections applied to the original imagery. The SPOT<br /><br />
image used for the development of this vegetation map was provided at level of processing 2A (the<br /><br />
information about the orbit and altitude of the satellite has been used to geolocate each pixel to the<br /><br />
UTM map projection and referenced to WGS84 ellipsoid). The absolute location accuracy for these<br /><br />
corrected products is usually better than 50 m.<br /><br />
The accuracy of the SPOT imagery was checked against the aerial photographs from 2009;<br /><br />
Unfortunately the accuracy of this imagery is unknown, but the discrepancies between the images<br /><br />
was on average 26 m, with a maximum of 73 m in areas of high elevation change (steep hills or<br /><br />
valleys).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
12<br /><br />
<br /><br />
“Tonkolili” Vegetation Map and Botanical Survey. March 2010. RBG Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Locations in the vegetation map must also be positioned with respect to the mapped vegetation<br /><br />
classes. Therefore, apart from the point location accuracy, it is also necessary to know the<br /><br />
accuracy of the map vegetation boundaries. Working at a resolution of 5 m, and after applying the<br /><br />
segmentation analysis, we have a confidence of 30 m. Consequently the minimum mapping unit<br /><br />
(the smallest vegetation area reported in the map) is approximately 900 metres square (30 × 30<br /><br />
m).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.3.2 THEMATIC ACCURACY<br /><br />
The thematic accuracy of a vegetation map refers to the extent to which it agrees with a set of<br /><br />
reference data. One of the most common means of expressing this is to produce an error matrix, a<br /><br />
comparison on a category by category basis of the relationship between known reference data and<br /><br />
the corresponding map results.<br /><br />
Reference data has to be independent from the mapping process. It would be usual to do this<br /><br />
assessment with further field work, but as this was impossible within the short timeframe, accuracy<br /><br />
was access using 232 random points generated for the area. These were then classified by one of<br /><br />
the authors (I.D.) from his field knowledge and using the aerial photos and SPOT images for the<br /><br />
region as a reference (see Table 3 below).<br /><br />

The overall accuracy (number of correctly classified samples divided by the total number of<br /><br />
reference data) yields a result of 91.5 %, which is very high against generally assumed standards<br /><br />
of higher than 80%. However, it should be remembered that this is using the aerial photos and not<br /><br />
on-the-ground observation, so there is the possibility that this accuracy measure is artificially high.<br /><br />
Further, it should be noted that there was much change observed between the 2008 SPOT<br /><br />
imagery and the 2009 aerial photos (most notably the widespread removal of woody vegetation).<br /><br />
Finally, a confidence map was produced which shows the areas where we have high to lower<br /><br />
confidence in the classification (this is only for the main vegetations types and not those derived<br /><br />
from digitising). Confidence is lower outside the main study areas (i.e. those areas for which field<br /><br />
knowledge and GCPs are available) and particularly in the area affected by cloud cover and haze<br /><br />
in the south west portion (see Map 5).<br /><br />

<br /><br />
3.3.3 OTHER DATASETS<br /><br />
Digital Elevation Model - this was downloaded from the ASTER DEM website at 30 m resolution.<br /><br />
Streams and rivers - the available streams and rivers dataset (Tonkolili_Streams_polyline.shp) was<br /><br />
used on the vegetation map. Whilst this was accurate for the mining deposit sites, it was very crude<br /><br />
(up to 640 m out) for areas outside. Therefore rivers and streams that were needed for the riverine<br /><br />
forests were digitised directly from the SPOT imagery (see Figure 3).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 3: additional datasets used for the Tonkolili vegetation map.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4. RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FINE-TUNING THE VEGETATION MAP<br /><br />
1.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Further dataset requirements<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Good quality rivers dataset is needed, especially for accurate delimitation of the riverine<br /><br />
forests.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
High resolution elevation model.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Meta-data, including positional error, of the 2009 aerial photographs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Further survey work<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The current ground survey is limited both in extent and seasonal coverage (see Darbyshire & van<br /><br />
der Burgt 2010). In particular, ground-truthing is required for:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The northern sector of the mining license area, particularly the extent of hill summit<br /><br />
grassland.<br /><br />
14<br /><br />
<br /><br />
“Tonkolili” Vegetation Map and Botanical Survey. March 2010. RBG Kew<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The southwest sector which is under cloud cover on the SPOT image.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Vegetation change<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Recent vegetation change in the region has been both rapid and widespread as is evident through<br /><br />
comparison of the SPOT imagery for 2008 with the aerial photos for 2009. Monitoring of this<br /><br />
situation is important, particularly for the areas of high conservation importance.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Incorporation of the mine plan into the vegetation map<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Including the finalised infrastructure and tailings locations and transport routes.<br /><br />

Graceful Chameleon Chamaeleo gracilis, found near the Nerekoro Sacred Forest<br /><br />
<br /><br />
March 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
THIS REPORT IS PRELIMINARY AND CONFIDENTIAL<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Executive Summary<br /><br />
From the literature review and the ground surveys it is clear that populations of most wildlife<br /><br />
species, historically occurring throughout this area of Sierra Leone, are already in an extremely<br /><br />
precarious position. Very few large mammals were encountered, or even reported. The central<br /><br />
plains of Sierra Leone have been heavily modified by man over a large number of years and<br /><br />
while some species of conservation significance do persist, they do so in small numbers and are<br /><br />
fragmented and isolated. The situation is more encouraging for birds, though they are also under<br /><br />
severe pressure.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Although the overall project site is highly degraded and has lost key components of biodiversity,<br /><br />
the area retains certain faunal values that are important to conserve and that could be lost<br /><br />
without appropriate planning. Non-location specific recommendations are presented with<br /><br />
respect to protecting and enhancing the remaining habitats of conservation concern, with<br /><br />
additional specific recommendations for the mine area, the transport corridor and the port areas.<br /><br />
Means of addressing indirect impacts and using biodiversity offsets to balance unavoidable<br /><br />
impacts are also discussed. Finally, suggestions for follow-on fauna surveys are presented.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
1. Introduction<br /><br />
This is a summary of the Phase 1 (rapid assessment) fauna studies for Tonkolili mine, Sierra<br /><br />
Leone. For more information the reader is referred to the full fieldwork report (in preparation).<br /><br />
A ten day survey of fauna and habitat at the Tonkolili Mine Project was undertaken in March<br /><br />
2010 by WCS staff, assisted by local specialists. A total of thirty sites were surveyed in the mine<br /><br />
area, along the transport corridor and in the port areas. Collectively the sites surveyed comprised<br /><br />
key areas for the Early Cash Flow (ECF) project and the Tonkolili project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The purpose of the survey was to rapidly assess and evaluate the importance of the area for<br /><br />
indigenous fauna, focusing mainly on mammals and birds, but also including herpetofauna, and<br /><br />
to identify opportunities for nature conservation within the full scope of the Tonkolili project,<br /><br />
including provision of a set of recommendations for the avoidance and mitigation of extraction<br /><br />
and transportation-related impacts and possible offsetting opportunities. The findings of the<br /><br />
assessment will also help determine future faunal studies that will be required to characterize the<br /><br />
ecological baseline of the Project area.<br /><br />
2. Methods<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Prior to fieldwork a review of published literature, books and (most importantly) ‘grey’ literature<br /><br />
from relevant Environmental Impact Assessments and faunal surveys in Sierra Leone was<br /><br />
completed. The literature review informed the planning and implementation of the fieldwork,<br /><br />
which included visual observations by the WCS team and local specialists, supplemented by<br /><br />
information gathered from ad-hoc village interviews.<br /><br />
3. Limitations and assumptions<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Due to the rapid nature of the surveys and the wide geographic coverage, investigations in some<br /><br />
areas were cursory, particularly along the transport corridor. In this context, original plans to use<br /><br />
camera-traps, bat nets and spot-lighting techniques were deferred until subsequent (more<br /><br />
detailed) study phases. Survey planning was also hindered by a lack of high resolution satellite or<br /><br />
aerial images for much of the project area.<br /><br />
4. Preliminary results<br /><br />
Preliminary results for the Phase 1 studies are summarised in Table 1 below. Further<br /><br />
information for each location is available in Annex A.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
5. Recommendations<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Headline recommendations are noted below. Many of these recommendations relate to the<br /><br />
protection and enhancement of habitat that supports fauna of conservation concern, rather than<br /><br />
the fauna species themselves. Further details are available in Annex B.<br /><br />
5.1 General (applicable to all locations)<br /><br />
• Project related activities should be undertaken to a high standard, reflecting international<br /><br />
good practice.<br /><br />
• Avoid project development work in remaining patches of forest wherever possible.<br /><br />
• Opportunities to control and minimize uncontrolled in-migration of people should be<br /><br />
explored with relevant stakeholders, including the Government of Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
• Revegetation should be based on indigenous species to enhance long-term sustainability.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.2 Mine area and environs<br /><br />
• Consider offset opportunities to address unavoidable habitat loss as a result of mining and<br /><br />
related activities at Numbara, Marampon and Simbili.<br /><br />
5.3 Roads<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Avoid the Farangbaia Forest Reserve.<br /><br />
Avoid sacred forests / bushes by at least 200 m.<br /><br />
Minimise river crossings and avoid locating crossings in patches of existing forest.<br /><br />
Apart from river crossings, the haul road should not encroach within 500 m of the Tonkolili<br /><br />
River.<br /><br />
• Right-of-way clearance should be minimized, commensurate with relevant design and safety<br /><br />
standards.<br /><br />
5.4 Addressing indirect impacts<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.4.1 Timber<br /><br />
• Source timber required for the project from certified plantations.<br /><br />
• Support the development of local certified plantations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.4.2 Water<br /><br />
• Remaining riparian vegetation should be strictly protected.<br /><br />
• AML should explore opportunities to contribute to the reforestation of the Farangbaia<br /><br />
Forest Reserve.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.4.3 Bushmeat<br /><br />
• Enforce a total ban on hunting and capture of wildlife by AML employees and<br /><br />
contractors.<br /><br />
• AML should explore opportunities to support the development of local animal<br /><br />
husbandry techniques and capacity (as an alternative to bushmeat).<br /><br />
5.5 Coastal conservation and offsets<br /><br />
• Ensure project activities do not contribute to significant existing pollution around the<br /><br />
shoreline of Tagrin.<br /><br />
• Establish ‘no-take’ areas in the mangroves and native bush land at Tagrin and avoid damage<br /><br />
to mangroves and any fresh or brackish waterways and their wetland communities in all areas.<br /><br />
• Consider offset opportunities at Tagrin and Pepel to conserve and improve the area’s natural<br /><br />
heritage throughout the project’s lifecycle.<br /><br />
• Explore tourism and public education opportunities at Tagrin.<br /><br />
• Undertake measures to protect the integrity of Bunce Island, a de facto nature reserve.<br /><br />
5.6 Further fauna surveys<br /><br />
• Assessment of the potential impacts of the major coastal operations on the intertidal<br /><br />
mudflats, sand-flats, mangroves and their associated avifauna.<br /><br />
• Assessment of how and where conservation efforts for Western Chimpanzees can best be<br /><br />
directed.<br /><br />
5 <br /><br />

• Assessment of other marine-based values of the coastal fauna and the impact of the project<br /><br />
on these.<br /><br />
• Assessment of the conservation values of seasonal wetlands and scattered forest patches<br /><br />

<br /><br />
ANNEX A: Preliminary results (further details)<br /><br />
The project area, for the purposes of this report, is divided into three main blocks: the mine site<br /><br />
and environs, the haulage road and corridor, and the coastal areas.<br /><br />
A.1 The mine site and environs<br /><br />
Farangbaia itself (the mine project headquarters) lies in the eastern flank of the Kunsulma range,<br /><br />
location of the Farangbaia Forest Reserve, which while still extant on the statute books has been<br /><br />
almost entirely logged-out. The mine administrative complex is almost circled by extremely small<br /><br />
patches of village-owned evergreen forest in which some smaller wildlife, especially birds,<br /><br />
persists. Some of these are species restricted to the West Guinea forests - an endemic bird area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
With respect to the mountains, despite being already largely deforested, the three peaks<br /><br />
(Numbara, Marampon and Simbili) support rare and interesting wildlife some of which is of<br /><br />
international conservation concern. The 'semi-natural' grassland communities of Numbara are<br /><br />
host to rare flora and also support a grassland specialist bird species, the globally threatened<br /><br />
Sierra Leone Prinia.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Western Chimpanzees persist in the scattered forest patches at the southern end of the<br /><br />
Farangbaia Forest Reserve in small numbers. Reports of recent direct observations of chimps,<br /><br />
both by locals and by mine employees visiting the area suggest that the chimps are still moving<br /><br />
between forest fragments and utilising what available forest habitat remains. The patchwork of<br /><br />
forest fragments in the area exist both inside and outside the Farangbaia Forest Reserve and<br /><br />
include the woodland of the Tonkolili river valley. Interviews with local communities suggest<br /><br />
that the chimps are coming into ever more frequent contact with the rapidly expanding human<br /><br />
population there<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Similarly the last large ungulates, e.g. African Buffalo, were reported as being extirpated from the<br /><br />
tiny pockets of suitable evergreen forest/bush. These larger species might persist only in these<br /><br />
southern and western areas near to the proposed route of the haulage road east of the Anbelo<br /><br />
Hills in the lower Tonkolili valley, though inevitably in very low numbers.<br /><br />
Birds fare slightly better. Inland, even in the hills, larger birds were concentrated in those areas<br /><br />
that are least accessible to villagers. Fortunately it seems that firearms are rare and consequently<br /><br />
smaller bird species persist in some areas in relative abundance; as do the larger unpalatable or<br /><br />
inedible species. It was evident that even in areas that are nominally reserves there are no<br /><br />
protection measures in force and that in many cases the tall woody growth of such places has<br /><br />
been largely removed and replaced by a shifting mosaic of scrub, often grassy, and swidden<br /><br />
agriculture typically on a rotation of five years or less.<br /><br />
Concentrations of birds in particular were found in riparian woodland along the Tonkolili, Rokel<br /><br />
and Toka rivers and their tributaries or in residual pockets of evergreen forest either along other<br /><br />
watercourses or in the widespread community "sacred forests" where villagers, to a varying<br /><br />
degree, restrict access and activity. The value of these forest patches should not be<br /><br />
underestimated especially where they exist in a matrix of less intensively modified anthropogenic<br /><br />
habitats whether agricultural or residential.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
A.2 Haulage road and corridor<br /><br />
As with the mine site, much of the haulage road and its corridor had been heavily modified well<br /><br />
before mine activities began. However, although each ‘priority’ site designated for surveys was<br /><br />
visited, there was insufficient time and a lack of high resolution maps to effectively evaluate all<br /><br />
areas. Traditionally managed agricultural areas (e.g. extensive cattle pastures, rice fields and other<br /><br />
seasonally inundated land) are common along the transport corridorand were remarkably rich in<br /><br />
birds and amphibians especially near the Rokel in the vicinity of Bumbuna and along the Toka<br /><br />
west of Makeni. There are additional sites that warrant further investigation. For instance, north<br /><br />
east of Lunsar where the proposed haul road meets the existing railway, small pockets of forest<br /><br />
that still maintain Western Chimpanzee populations were recently confirmed. Recommendations<br /><br />
are provided, though clearly the on-going road-building process is moving faster than possible<br /><br />
detailed evaluations of optimal routes from a biodiversity perspective.<br /><br />
A.3 Coastal areas<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The coastal areas of the project around Tagrin and the Sierra Leone Estuary provided some of<br /><br />
the most interesting and productive sites; namely Pepel and its associated islands, the eastern<br /><br />
coastline of the Tagrin peninsula itself, some small freshwater wetland areas in the peninsula and<br /><br />
the fully intertidal areas of the estuary: the island mangroves, the 'on-shore' mangroves, the sand<br /><br />
flats, mud flats and sheltered beaches, together with the open waters of the great natural harbour<br /><br />
beyond. Almost the entire Tonkolili iron ore project area at the coast lies within a designated<br /><br />
Ramsar site and the wider estuary has been classified internationally as a globally significant<br /><br />
Important Bird Area. There is considerable opportunity for integrating important conservation<br /><br />
activities within the project’s plans for port development.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
8 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
ANNEX B: Recommendations (further details)<br /><br />
Recommendations presented here should not be considered definitive given the brief nature of<br /><br />
the study. Where further work is necessary, this has been suggested.<br /><br />
Although the overall project site is highly degraded and has lost key components of biodiversity,<br /><br />
the area retains certain faunal values that are important to conserve and that could be lost<br /><br />
without appropriate planning. Consequently, to minimize additional impacts, project related<br /><br />
activities should be undertaken to a high standard, reflecting international good practice.<br /><br />
B.1 General (applicable to all locations)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• AML should work with government to explore opportunities to control and minimise the<br /><br />
uncontrolled in-migration of people into areas newly opened-up by road construction,<br /><br />
especially along the roads themselves. Uncontrolled in-migration will lead to further forest<br /><br />
and wildlife losses and compound pressures on existing human communities.<br /><br />
• Any infrastructure and mine developments should avoid remaining patches of forest. All<br /><br />
remaining forest, regardless of size, social function or location, is of elevated conservation<br /><br />
value given the small amount of mature forest habitat that remains. A patch of forest, no<br /><br />
matter how small or isolated is an important part of the habitat mosaic. While contiguous<br /><br />
forest habitat would be preferable, it is important to understand that a network of small forest<br /><br />
fragments can still retain important values.<br /><br />
• Replanting of vegetation for any purpose should use indigenous species and should be based<br /><br />
on silvicultural systems that promote natural ecosystem functions and that increase the<br /><br />
probability that native species and ecological processes will be maintained.<br /><br />
• Crossings of any drainage lines or water bodies should have appropriate culverts built to<br /><br />
international environmental standards.<br /><br />
B.2 Mine area and environs<br /><br />
<br /><br />
B.3 Roads<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• Loss of habitat at the Numbara, Marampon and Simbili peaks, some of which supports rare<br /><br />
and interesting wildlife, will be unavoidable due to the nature of the mining operations at the<br /><br />
three peaks. In this context, it would be sensible for AML to focus on offsets rather than<br /><br />
mitigation measures for habitat loss associated with Numbara, Marampon and Simbili.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• The main haulage road crosses the Tonkolili River at the existing cleared crossings. From<br /><br />
there the road should head south past the villages of Furia and Sokoia onward to the village<br /><br />
of Nerekoro and from here it should loop around the outside of the southern end of the<br /><br />
forest reserve to cross the Tonkolili river once again at Balaya village. After this the road can<br /><br />
head north-west towards the proposed rail loop area.<br /><br />
• The haulage road should not run through any of the Farangbaia Forest Reserve. Although<br /><br />
this site is highly degraded, it remains a legal forest reserve and would legally require formal<br /><br />
government degazettement. Furthermore, the reserve can recover many of its watershed<br /><br />
maintenance values if well protected, as well as providing refugia for indigenous wildlife.<br /><br />
• All roads should avoid sacred forests/bushes by at least 200m.<br /><br />
• The number of points where roads cross waterbodies should be kept to a minimum.<br /><br />
Crossings should avoid existing forest patches and their immediate surroundings, as identified<br /><br />
using satellite and aerial images.<br /><br />
9 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
• Apart from crossing points the road should not encroach to within approximately 500m of<br /><br />
the Tonkolili River.<br /><br />
• AML should quickly identify opportunities to integrate environmental considerations with its<br /><br />
plans for the design, location, construction, maintenance, control and decommissioning of all<br /><br />
roads in order to avoid or minimize environmental impacts. Excessive right-of-way clearance<br /><br />
has a major environmental impact in tropical forests, particularly areas such as that which<br /><br />
hosts the Tonkolili project, where remaining forests are vulnerable and already in decline.<br /><br />
Roads should be kept to the minimum width possible, consistent with safety and other<br /><br />
pertinent international standards.<br /><br />
B.4 Addressing indirect impacts<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It is possible that the project’s indirect impacts may be as significant as the direct impacts. As<br /><br />
with many major industrial projects in the developing world, people have flocked to the area in<br /><br />
search of employment. With this in-migration has come inevitable added pressure on land and<br /><br />
the limited natural resources that remain. AML should explore opportunities to work with the<br /><br />
Government of Sierra Leone (GoSL) limit uncontrolled or uncoordinated migration to rural<br /><br />
areas, including the mine site. In doing this, AML will also benefit by reducing the pressures that<br /><br />
could impact negatively on the project (e.g. increased conflicts motivated by complications of<br /><br />
land tenure, compensation demands and employment issues). Specific recommendations relate<br /><br />
to timber, water and bushmeat.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
B.4.1 Timber<br /><br />
The last remaining stands of forests in the area are still being logged for a number of purposes,<br /><br />
legally and illegally. The project’s presence is indirectly driving some of this logging and there are<br /><br />
two mitigation measures that could have positive outcomes:<br /><br />
• The project should source all timber from certified plantations (i.e. not local sources of<br /><br />
timber, which come only from the last remaining natural forests, which now require the<br /><br />
highest level of protection).<br /><br />
• The project should investigate the potential for supporting local plantations, which<br /><br />
would be beneficial to the project, local livelihoods and the remaining natural forests<br /><br />
(and therefore, also for fauna).<br /><br />
B.4.2 Water<br /><br />
Given the nature of the project’s activities, the extreme variation in conditions across the<br /><br />
seasons, the likely increase in local human populations, and the massive scale of deforestation<br /><br />
that has occurred prior to inception of the project, the availability and quality of fresh water will<br /><br />
undoubtedly become more important. Two approaches to addressing this issue will deliver<br /><br />
complementary benefits for fauna:<br /><br />
• The strict protection of water bodies and of the riparian vegetation must be a priority for<br /><br />
local government, traditional governance systems and the project itself.<br /><br />
• Reforestation, involving indigenous trees, aimed at significant ecological and watershed<br /><br />
restoration of the Farangbaia Reserve should be a high priority. AML may wish to<br /><br />
explore opportunities to contribute to such work, perhaps as an offset for unavoidable<br /><br />
habitat loss at Numbara, Marampon and Simbili.<br /><br />
B.4.3 Bushmeat<br /><br />
This is one of the most important issues for both fauna conservation and local nutrition and<br /><br />
livelihoods for those living away from the coast. Traditionally, communities have relied on<br /><br />
bushmeat (that is, any wild fauna hunted for consumption) and freshwater fish for their protein<br /><br />
10 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
B.5 Coastal conservation and offsets<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
intake. Over the last few decades, the removal of natural forests and the over-hunting of large<br /><br />
mammals has lead to the local extirpation of many species, a shift in the focus of hunting to<br /><br />
small mammals (cane rats being the most common now) and genuine shortages of available<br /><br />
protein. Systems of animal husbandry are almost absent or very basicand limited. . In this<br /><br />
context there is considerable scope for positive intervention:<br /><br />
• The company should establish and enforce a total ban on undertaking or financing the<br /><br />
hunting and capture of wildlife by its employees and contractors.<br /><br />
• Any form of hunting within the project areas around Tagrin and in the mangroves<br /><br />
around Pepel should be prohibited; this ban should be total and vigorously enforced,<br /><br />
especially with respect to bird congregation locations, in order to avoid the emergence of<br /><br />
‘loop-hole opportunities’ for those seeking to profit from bushmeat and bird-killing.<br /><br />
• The government, supported by AML, should strictly control human in-migration to the<br /><br />
area (see above).<br /><br />
• Communities should be supported in the development of improved animal husbandry<br /><br />
techniques and provided with starter stocks. This would be a positive contribution to the<br /><br />
livelihoods of people and also reduce demand for bushmeat and limit the impact of<br /><br />
hunting restrictions on local communities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
• No waste material from the project operations should be added to the already substantial<br /><br />
amount of solid and liquid pollutants (i.e. every kind of effluent and garbage) present around<br /><br />
the shoreline of Tagrin and, at present, issuing largely from Freetown.<br /><br />
• Project related wastes should be removed for proper disposal or managed on-site in an<br /><br />
appropriate facility, to avoid adding to existing significant pollution along the coastline near<br /><br />
Freetown. AML could investigate opportunities to use any waste disposal facility it creates to<br /><br />
take waste from other clean-up efforts.<br /><br />
• All infrastructure developments should avoid unnecessary damage to mangroves and any<br /><br />
fresh or brackish waterways and their wetland communities, whether via physical or chemical<br /><br />
impacts.<br /><br />
• Crossings of creeks, drainage lines or other water bodies should have appropriate culverts<br /><br />
built to international standards.<br /><br />
• There is considerable opportunity for AML to not only mitigate impacts, but to make genuine<br /><br />
positive contributions to global conservation efforts, and for these efforts to be visible and<br /><br />
tangible. There is high potential to deliver an outcome of lasting value from this investment<br /><br />
both to the people of Tagrin/Pepel and to those of Sierra Leone in general. Especially in the<br /><br />
port area this project could deliver real benefits not only to the village communities but to<br /><br />
many residents of Freetown through the provision of small protected areas around the<br /><br />
estuary, in effect analogous to the national historical monument that is Bunce Island, where<br /><br />
environmental education and ecological precepts might be best explained to the public. There<br /><br />
are also numerous and excellent opportunities for ecotourism, as the area is so close to<br /><br />
Freetown, and immediately adjacent to the international airport. This work could be<br /><br />
undertaken to offset impacts in the coastal areas that cannot be avoided even with the<br /><br />
implementation of international good practice.<br /><br />
• There are significant "offset" opportunities at both Tagrin and Pepel to conserve and restore<br /><br />
some small wetland areas and mangrove habitats, which are of notable livelihood and<br /><br />
biological conservation value. These reserves could help to protect and enhance the faunal<br /><br />
value of the area, while raising awareness within Sierra Leone of the country’s importance to<br /><br />
(for example) migratory shorebirds travelling from the far north of Europe to the southern<br /><br />
tip of Africa.<br /><br />
11 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
• The opportunity exists to put in place measures to conserve and improve the area’s natural<br /><br />
heritage throughout the project’s lifecycle. A further assessment is needed to accurately map<br /><br />
and articulate a strategy for this work. .<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
B.5.1 Tagrin<br /><br />
• Creation of a shorebird and waterfowl observation point and explanatory visitor centre<br /><br />
close to the service wharf ideally overlooking the tidal flats approximately 0.5 – 1 km<br /><br />
northeast of Tagrin point.<br /><br />
• Creation of a local nature reserve and interpretation centre around the freshwater pools<br /><br />
at Rosint village.<br /><br />
• Training of at least two local village people to be guides at each of the above mentioned<br /><br />
sites.<br /><br />
• Establishment of discrete, easily identifiable 'no-take' areas in the mangroves; perhaps<br /><br />
adjacent to the coal stockpile area 3 km northeast of Tagrin point and a buffer zone of<br /><br />
no-take native bush land (from which woody growth may not be extracted) which once<br /><br />
established might provide a partial screen around the adjacent coal-fired power station;<br /><br />
similarly a buffer zone could be established along the Tagrin haul road.<br /><br />
• The haul road which is planned to connect the ore stockyard to the service wharf should<br /><br />
be sited carefully in order to minimize impact on any patches of indigenous woody<br /><br />
vegetation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
B.5.2 Pepel<br /><br />
• Dredging operations in the approach to Pepel, and especially in the vicinity of Bunce<br /><br />
Island should be conducted with the utmost care. The integrity of Bunce Island must be<br /><br />
maintained. It has been long recognized as an historical monument of international<br /><br />
significance and has thereby become a de facto nature reserve, itself of great value.<br /><br />
• The engineering of all transport approaches to Pepel Island by channel dredging, road<br /><br />
construction and rail refurbishment should be closely monitored to avoid any excessive<br /><br />
right-of-way clearance and damage to mangroves.<br /><br />
• Sanbilma island (opposite Pepel) should not be developed further unless absolutely<br /><br />
necessary. In-migration should be prohibited. While this is the responsibility of the<br /><br />
GoSL, if the investment agreement for AML establishes private tenure (even on a lease<br /><br />
basis) then AML should enforce controls on in-migration.<br /><br />
B.6 Further surveys<br /><br />
Additional, focused faunal surveys are required to:<br /><br />
• Assess with greater accuracy the potential impacts of the major coastal operations on the<br /><br />
intertidal mudflats, sand-flats, mangroves and their associated avifauna; a large part of which<br /><br />
is highly migratory, and thus increasingly threatened by intensifying human activity<br /><br />
throughout the flyway network and consequently subject to mounting international concern<br /><br />
and monitoring. It would be best if this were undertaken in two periods: May 2010, during<br /><br />
the afrotropical breeding season at the start of the rains and November-December 2010 at<br /><br />
the height of the shorebird influx from northern Eurasia.<br /><br />
• Assess how and where conservation efforts for Western Chimpanzee populations is best<br /><br />
directed.<br /><br />
• Assess the other marine-based values of the coastal fauna, including a more thorough review<br /><br />
of the areas relevant to cetaceans, sea turtles and certain key fish species (e.g. Tarpon) and<br /><br />
12 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
define the project impacts on, and conservation options for, African Manatee (Trichechus<br /><br />
senegalensis) in the Sierra Leone estuary.<br /><br />
• Assess the conservation value of extensive semi-natural seasonal wetlands and scattered forest<br /><br />
patches along the Toka river valley, essentially those between Makeni and Lunsar, and the<br /><br />
gallery evergreen forest along the Rokel upstream from Makeni to its confluence with the<br /><br />
Tonkolili River. These investigations would be most productive if undertaken in May 2010<br /><br />
and November-December 2010 in conjunction with the monitoring of coastal areas noted<br /><br />
above.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY<br /><br />
This report details the results from a Rapid Aquatic Ecosystem Assessment undertaken by<br /><br />
Hydrobiology on behalf of SRK Consulting (UK) LTD for the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project. The<br /><br />
main purpose of this work was to assess the health of the aquatic ecosystems covered by the<br /><br />
project (particularly the work to be carried out at haul road crossings in the near future) and<br /><br />
to make recommendations on the ecological value of areas potentially impacted by the work.<br /><br />
Overall, the rivers and streams surveyed are in good condition (particularly in regards to instream habitat), despite the potential for anthropogenic impacts.<br /><br />
The impacts at crossings should be minor if the following points are taken into<br /><br />
consideration:<br /><br />
1. That best practice sediment control measures are used during construction of the<br /><br />
crossings. Although it is likely that there is some natural tolerance to sediment loads<br /><br />
of the aquatic ecosystems within and downstream of the mining lease, very few data<br /><br />
are available to assess the natural temporal extent and the magnitude of these<br /><br />
fluctuations;<br /><br />
2. Where bridges are built, that they are designed in a manner that does not confine the<br /><br />
river;<br /><br />
3. Minor in-stream infrastructure can constitute barriers to fish migration. Where<br /><br />
possible, these should be designed to be compatible with the passage of migratory<br /><br />
stream organisms, such as the use of bridges rather than culverts where possible, or<br /><br />
where culverts are built that open box culverts with natural substrata are used in<br /><br />
preference to enclosed culverts, and the avoidance of vertical barriers such as<br /><br />
downstream culvert ends suspended above the natural substrata.<br /><br />
The Mawuru River will be dammed to allow for the construction of a tailings storage facility<br /><br />
(TSF). At the proposed TSF site there are no mitigation measures that can be put in place to<br /><br />
prevent impacts – the river, streams, and swamps in the area will be submerged. There is no<br /><br />
indication that any aquatic surveys have been undertaken in the proposed TSF area. As this<br /><br />
area contains many small streams that may host endemic species, it is strongly suggested<br /><br />
that an aquatic fauna survey is undertaken to fully describe the aquatic biota in this area.<br /><br />
From the information Hydrobiology currently has, it is not possible to assess potential<br /><br />
impacts to the aquatic ecosystems downstream (to the south) of the TSF.<br /><br />
Hydrobiology strongly suggests that an adequate baseline water quality monitoring<br /><br />
program be established for the area. This will enable the assessment of changes (if any) to<br /><br />
the downstream rivers due to the mine’s activities and will supply a baseline dataset for<br /><br />
management action in the future if negative changes to the water quality do occur. It should<br /><br />
be noted that the natural acidity and low conductivity of the water bodies indicates that if<br /><br />
acid rock drainage (ARD) does occur, there is little natural buffering (neutralisation) capacity<br /><br />
available.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rapid Assessment of Aquatic Environments for the Tonkolili Project April 2010 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
iv<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hydrobiology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hydrobiology also suggests that a baseline tissue metal survey of aquatic fauna be<br /><br />
undertaken to assess the existing (pre-Tonkolili) concentrations, which are likely to be<br /><br />
influenced by the activities of artisanal miners in the area and natural mineralisation (for<br /><br />
example, elevated levels of arsenic, chromium and nickel have been detected in the Simbili<br /><br />
ore deposit). Hydrobiology’s experience is that adequate baseline data is an important<br /><br />
defense against pollution-related litigation, particularly concerning human health, which<br /><br />
may be impacted by the accumulation of toxic elements in the food chain.<br /><br />
Freshwater fish are vitally important to the local population as a protein source and<br /><br />
therefore maintaining the fishing resource is critical for food security for local villages. In<br /><br />
general, fishing is at a subsistence level. It is therefore important that African Minerals<br /><br />
Limited acquires a detailed understanding of fisheries in the area, in order to mitigate and<br /><br />
manage any future mining-related impacts that may occur.<br /><br />
 <br /><br />

<br /><br />
1 INTRODUCTION<br /><br />
This report details the results from a Rapid Aquatic Ecosystem Assessment undertaken by<br /><br />
Hydrobiology between the 10th and 16th March 2010 on behalf of SRK Consulting (UK) LTD<br /><br />
for the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project situated in the Sula Mountain Range in Sierra Leone.<br /><br />
The Tonkolili Iron Ore project is expected to commence in two phases:<br /><br />
1. The Early Cash Flow phase (ECF) which involves mining the topmost layer of<br /><br />
hematite ore (mostly found in the Simbili deposit). A haul road will be built for<br /><br />
transfer of ore between the mine site and Lunsar whereupon the ore will be<br /><br />
transferred to rail and transported using the existing rail line to Pepel Port. From<br /><br />
there, it will be shipped out of the country;<br /><br />
2. The Full Project involves mining the whole ore body (consisting of magnetite) and<br /><br />
will involve the construction of a new rail line from the mine site to Tagrin Point for<br /><br />
shipment of the ore out of the country. A large tailings storage facility (TSF) will be<br /><br />
built on the Mawuru River within the project area, for beneficiation tails. As far as<br /><br />
Hydrobiology is aware, there are no other plans for processing on site...<br /><br />
The Rapid Assessment was undertaken with both project phases in mind. At the current<br /><br />
time, a detailed aquatic ecological study has not been undertaken. The main purpose of this<br /><br />
work was to assess the health of the aquatic ecosystems covered by the project and to make<br /><br />
recommendations on the ecological value of areas potentially impacted by the proposed<br /><br />
project development.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2 METHODOLOGY<br /><br />
The study was carried out in the dry season (March 2010) when water levels were<br /><br />
sufficiently low to allow assessment of in-stream and riparian aquatic habitats.<br /><br />
The basic method of assessment included: <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
 Habitat assessment using suitable guidelines and expert knowledge; <br /><br />
 Observations on water quality i.e. clarity, pH, temperature, conductivity; <br /><br />
 Observations on existing stressors and significant aspects of the ecology; <br /><br />
 Observations  on  potential  sampling  techniques  and  requirements  at  each  of  the <br /><br />
sites; <br /><br />
 Observations on any species visible; <br /><br />
 Discussions with locals on species caught in different areas and trends in catches; <br /><br />
 Observations at local markets; <br /><br />
 Observations on hydrology of the river systems <br /><br />
 Inter‐comparison between sites. <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
A subjective assessment of in‐stream habitat at the selected sites was carried out based on in‐<br /><br />
stream  debris  cover  (logs,  branches,  leaves  and  twigs,  algae);  presence  or  absence  of <br /><br />
macrophytes,  rock  faces  and  overhangs,  boulders,  tree  roots,  vegetation  overhang  and <br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rapid Assessment of Aquatic Environments for the Tonkolili Project April 2010 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hydrobiology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
canopy  cover.    Riparian  vegetation  was  assessed  in  terms  of  canopy  cover,  continuity  and <br /><br />
width,  a  general  assessment  of  weeds  and  grass  infiltration  of  the  riparian  vegetation.  <br /><br />
Specialists  from  the  Herbarium,  Royal  Botanic  Gardens,  Kew  have  undertaken  a  more <br /><br />
detailed  assessment  of plant  species  of  conservation  concern  (Burgt,  2009;  Burgt  &  Pollard, <br /><br />
2010; Darbyshire & Burgt, 2010).   <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
Fish observations were planned for at local markets.  Hydrobiology visited two local markets <br /><br />
and the fish were dried and salted, making identification of the fish difficult and due to time <br /><br />
constraints, this approach was not pursued.   <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
3 SITES<br /><br />
The overall project map is shown in Figure 3-1. Hydrobiology was asked to visit the<br /><br />
following general areas to undertake the Rapid Assessment (from west to east):<br /><br />
1) The Petifu Junction Assessment Area (Figure 3‐1); <br /><br />
2) The general Pepel Port area (Figure 3‐2); <br /><br />
3) The Port Loko River mainline crossing (Figure 3‐3);  <br /><br />
4) The Toka River mainline and haul road crossings (Figure 3‐4); <br /><br />
5) The Rokel River mainline and haul road crossing areas (Figure 3‐5); <br /><br />
6) The Mine Site Area (Figure 3‐5) which included: <br /><br />
a. Rail Loop 5 Infrastructure Assessment area;<br /><br />
b. Haul Road Pinch point & Nerekoro Society Bush Assessment area;<br /><br />
c. Matoine Stream and Tonkolili River, Furia & Sokia Villages Assessment areas;<br /><br />
d. The proposed TSF which will include the damming of the Mawuru River.<br /><br />

Hydrobiology<br /><br />

 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
4 RESULTS<br /><br />
An extensive area was assessed over the five days of the study, with a focus on crossing<br /><br />
areas. The survey areas covered lowland swamp areas (Pepel Port), small streams (Petifu<br /><br />
Junction), small rivers (the Toka River) and more substantial rivers (the Tonkolili River and<br /><br />
the Rokel River).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.1 Water quality<br /><br />
Generally, the water in the areas surveyed was clear, with the exception being Tonkolili<br /><br />
River, the water quality of which appeared to be impacted by upstream artisanal mining.<br /><br />
Waters generally had low conductivity and were slightly acidic, meaning little or no<br /><br />
buffering capacity of acid inputs if acid rock drainage occurs from the mining activities<br /><br />
(Table 4-1). It should be noted that the Bumbuna Dam EIA Fish Baseline Study found the<br /><br />
waters in area to be neutral to alkaline (Nippon Koei UK, 2007). However, data collected by<br /><br />
Worley Parsons and supplied to Hydrobiology by SRK (P. Mitchell, Pers. Comm.), also<br /><br />
found the waters to be acidic, casting some doubt on the water quality results from the<br /><br />
Bumbuna Dam EIA Fish Baseline Report. From the anecdotal accounts of various local<br /><br />
guides, the turbidity of the waters increases during the wet season (one guide said that the<br /><br />
Rokel River ‘ran red’). However, the current absence of a cohesive water quality monitoring<br /><br />
program means that a quantitative assessment of the fluctuations in the various rivers and<br /><br />
streams potentially impacted by the mine is not possible at present.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
4.2 Aquatic Habitat<br /><br />
The sites surveyed have been qualitatively assessed with respect to the quality of associated<br /><br />
in-stream and riparian vegetation based on expert knowledge. The rating scheme is<br /><br />
summarized in Table 4.2.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Overall, the springs and streams of the area around Pepel Port and Petifu Junction have<br /><br />
highly disturbed riparian vegetation. In-stream aquatic habitat consists mainly of submerged<br /><br />
macrophyte and sedge communities. The Toka River also has only a thin edge of thick<br /><br />
riparian vegetation (about 5 m width) but in-stream condition (particularly in the general<br /><br />
area of the haul road crossing) is good. The bed of the Toka River at both the haul road and<br /><br />
rail line crossing has about a 90% coverage of terrestrial leaves (typical in tropical streams),<br /><br />
indicating that ecological functioning of the river is probably terrestrially driven<br /><br />
(allochthonous). Therefore, it is possible to conclude that even though the riparian<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rapid Assessment of Aquatic Environments for the Tonkolili Project April 2010 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
10<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hydrobiology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
vegetation is not extensive, it has an important role in the ecosystem functioning of the<br /><br />
stream.<br /><br />
The Port Loko River is a tidally driven river, with mangrove communities occurring almost<br /><br />
continuously along the river (until the more populous Port Loko town is reached). It was not<br /><br />
possible to assess the in-stream habitat from the edge of the river. However, the intact<br /><br />
mangrove communities are a good indicator that the river is ecologically healthy (some<br /><br />
turbidity is natural in tidally driven rivers).<br /><br />
The Rokel River has a high rating for aquatic habitat (Table 3-1), with good continuous<br /><br />
riparian vegetation that only appears to be cleared for river access in small sections. Instream habitats include tree roots, rock faces, boulders and cobbles, vegetation overhang,<br /><br />
riffles, runs, glides and pools.<br /><br />
The rivers in the general mine area are slightly more disturbed than Rokel River and Port<br /><br />
Loko River. Two Tonkolili River sites (TKR3 and TKR2) have good in-stream habitat. TKR2<br /><br />
has very thick riparian vegetation and adjacent forest on the right bank1, but the left bank has<br /><br />
been cleared for farming (apart from the almost continuous riparian vegetation about 10 m<br /><br />
thick). TKR1, upstream of TKR2 (in the Haul Road Pinch point & Nerekoro Society Bush<br /><br />
assessment area) is the most disturbed, with discontinuous riparian vegetation. The site has<br /><br />
slightly elevated turbidity. This made it difficult to assess the in-stream habitat, but the area<br /><br />
appears to be slightly degraded with a little variation in potential aquatic habitat. The<br /><br />
Matoine Stream (MT1) has good in-stream habitat (typical of small mountain streams), but<br /><br />
the riparian vegetation has been recently burnt and almost completely cleared for farming (at<br /><br />
least on the right bank).<br /><br />
Two sites in the Mawuru River (within the TSF) were assessed, and appear to have good instream habitat. The riparian vegetation has been highly disturbed at both sites, but this<br /><br />
appears to have allowed the formation of submerged macrophyte beds (extra habitat) due to<br /><br />
the extra light penetration to the stream resulting from the removal of riparian canopy cover.<br /><br />
Many swampy areas were noted between MR1 and MR2, but these were not assessed due to<br /><br />
lack of time.<br /><br />
Overall ratings for the areas surveyed are summarised in Table 4-3.<br /><br />
Fish were seen at all sites apart from TKR2, but it was not possible to identify them with any<br /><br />
certainty.<br /><br />
