<br /><br />
5 RARE AND THREATENED AND ENDEMIC FISH<br /><br />
An IUCN red list search of threatened freshwater fish species was undertaken. The species<br /><br />
Pristis microdon (Largetooth sawfish) was listed as present in Sierra Leone and critically<br /><br />
endangered. Although this species is usually found in turbid channels, it is known to be<br /><br />
found in freshwater (www.fishbase.org).<br /><br />
A search of http://www.fishbase.org/ indicated three endemic species to Sierra Leone<br /><br />
found in the Rokel River and will potentially be impacted by mining activities. They are:<br /><br />
1. Leptocypris taiaensis (Cyprinidae) (also reported from the Taia River, Little Scarcies<br /><br />
River, Waanje River and Jong rivers);<br /><br />
2. Marcusenius meronai (Mormyridae) (also reported the Sewa River); and<br /><br />
3. Prolabeo batesi (Cyprinidae) (also reported from the Sewa, Pampana, Little Scarcies<br /><br />
and Jong rivers).<br /><br />
None of these species have been assessed under the IUCN red list system, and so their status<br /><br />
is not assigned. However, endemism inherently means that there is a limited geographical<br /><br />
distribution of a species. Of the one critically endangered and three endemic species listed<br /><br />
above, only Marcusenius meronai was recorded, at three sites, in the baseline study for the<br /><br />
Bumbuna Dam (Nippon Koei UK, 2007).<br /><br />
The limited literature review undertaken in conjunction with fieldwork planning indicated<br /><br />
that the fish of Sierra Leone have not been well studied, particularly the smaller fish in<br /><br />
streams and brooks. An example of fish that may have a locally endemic distribution are the<br /><br />
killifish (Cyprinodontiformes) – brightly coloured fish that are found in small streams<br /><br />
throughout the Americas, Eurasia and Africa, but which appear to have a high level of<br /><br />
endemism in west Africa. It is therefore suggested that aquatic fauna surveys be undertaken<br /><br />
in the small streams and swamps likely to be impacted by the Tonkolili Project.<br /><br />
To facilitate future identification of fish it is recommended that local fishermen accompany<br /><br />
the survey team to facilitate cross-referencing collected data with local knowledge and<br /><br />
species names.<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rapid Assessment of Aquatic Environments for the Tonkolili Project April 2010 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
24<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hydrobiology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
6 DISCUSSION<br /><br />
The majority of sites covered in this initial Rapid Assessment could potentially be impacted<br /><br />
by road and rail crossings associated with the transport infrastructure of the project.<br /><br />
Although many of the streams are in good condition (particularly with respect to in-stream<br /><br />
habitat), impacts at crossing points should be minor if the following mitigation measures are<br /><br />
taken into consideration:<br /><br />
1. That best practice sediment control measures are used during construction of the<br /><br />
crossings. It is likely that there is some natural tolerance to sediment loads in the<br /><br />
aquatic ecosystems within and downstream of the mining lease and in the streams<br /><br />
where the crossings will occur, due to the natural fluctuations in turbidity in the wet<br /><br />
seasons as noted by local guides. However, very few data are available to assess the<br /><br />
temporal extent and magnitude of changes in turbidity or to support the assessment<br /><br />
and management of potential impacts should they arise;<br /><br />
2. Where bridges are built, that they are designed in a manner that does not confine the<br /><br />
river. If the river is confined it will cause localised faster flow and scouring and may<br /><br />
impede migratory species;<br /><br />
3. Minor in-stream infrastructure can constitute barriers to fish migration. Where<br /><br />
possible, in-stream infrastructure should be designed to be compatible with the<br /><br />
passage of migratory stream organisms, for example the use of bridges rather than<br /><br />
culverts, or selection of open box culverts with natural substrata rather than enclosed<br /><br />
culverts. Additionally vertical barriers such as downstream culvert ends suspended<br /><br />
above the natural substrata should be avoided. Suitable stream passage construction<br /><br />
designs can be found, for example, in Cotterell (1998) or the Washington Department<br /><br />
of Fish and Wildlife (2003);<br /><br />
4. As the haul road is typically to be 13 m in width, the absence of upstream light<br /><br />
(which can deter fish from entering a passage) is unlikely to be a substantial problem<br /><br />
provided the culvert diameter is kept large enough to keep wet season flows to below<br /><br />
0.3 m/s, but it would also be preferable to add at least a central skylight to the culvert<br /><br />
design.<br /><br />
The Mawuru River will be dammed to allow the construction of the TSF. At the proposed<br /><br />
TSF site, there are no mitigation measures that can be put in place to prevent impacts – the<br /><br />
small streams and the river and swamps in the area will be submerged. There is no evidence<br /><br />
that any aquatic surveys have been undertaken in the proposed TSF area. As this area<br /><br />
contains many small streams that may house endemic species, it is strongly suggested that<br /><br />
an aquatic fauna survey is undertaken to fully describe the aquatic biota in the area. This<br /><br />
will enable AML to illustrate that no endemic species are present in the area, or conversely, if<br /><br />
some do exist in the TSF area, action can be taken.<br /><br />
From  the  information  Hydrobiology  currently  has,  it  is  not  possible  to  adequately  assess <br /><br />
impacts downstream of the TSF.  From available information it appears that the water will <br /><br />
not  be  of  suitable  quality  for  release  into  the  downstream  reaches  without  treatment, <br /><br />
particularly  with  respect  to  alkalinity  (a  pH  of  10‐11  is  predicted)  and  potentially  with <br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rapid Assessment of Aquatic Environments for the Tonkolili Project April 2010 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
25<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Hydrobiology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
 <br /><br />
<br /><br />
respect  to  suspended  solids.  Background  water  quality  data  and  information  on  the <br /><br />
geochemical  aspects  of  the  deposit  are  limited.  While  the  presence  of  pyrite  (a  potential <br /><br />
source of acid rock drainage) has been noted in overburden materials and potentially toxic <br /><br />
elements such as arsenic, chromium and nickel are also present at elevated concentrations in <br /><br />
the  Simbili  deposit,  the  potential  for  related  impacts  on  water  quality  and  aquatic  habitats <br /><br />
downstream  of  the  TSF  are  presently  unknown,  and  will  depend  on  the  mineralogy  and <br /><br />
geochemistry of the tailings stored there.     <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
Detailed  hydrological  data  is  not  available  and  therefore  it  is  not  possible  to  assess  the <br /><br />
potential impacts of a reduced flow from the Mawuru River into downstream reaches, nor is <br /><br />
detailed mapping of the rivers and streams in the area currently available on which to base <br /><br />
an assessment of the hydrological connectivity between the rivers.   <br /><br />
 <br /><br />
Hydrobiology strongly suggests that an adequate baseline water quality monitoring<br /><br />
program be established for the area. This will enable the assessment of changes (if any) to<br /><br />
the downstream rivers due to the mine’s activities and will supply a baseline dataset for<br /><br />
management action in the future if negative changes to water quality do occur. It should be<br /><br />
noted that the natural acidity and low conductivity of the water bodies indicate that if ARD<br /><br />
does occur, there would be little or no natural buffering (neutralization) capacity.<br /><br />
Hydrobiology also suggests that a baseline tissue metal survey of aquatic fauna be<br /><br />
undertaken to assess the existing (pre-Tonkolili) concentrations, which are likely to be<br /><br />
influenced by the activities of artisanal miners in the area, and natural mineralisation<br /><br />
associated with iron ore deposits and gold deposits in the general area.<br /><br />
The assessment of metal concentrations in biological tissues can give an indication of the<br /><br />
overall exposure of biota to toxicants and are particularly useful for those that biomagnify<br /><br />
(increase in concentration as they pass up the food chain), such as mercury. Hydrobiology<br /><br />
made initial enquiries as to whether mercury is being used in the area by artisanal gold<br /><br />
miners, but was unable to acquire reliable data. Although most gold mining activity appears<br /><br />
to be use gravity methods (panning) the likelihood exists that some miners use mercury for<br /><br />
gold extraction.<br /><br />
Hydrobiology’s experience is that adequate baseline data for contaminant concentrations in<br /><br />
biological tissues is an important defense against pollution-related litigation, particularly<br /><br />
concerning human health, which may be impacted by the accumulation of toxic elements in<br /><br />
the food chain, particularly when the local population are reliant on fish as a food source.<br /><br />
Of final note is the importance of fish to the local communities. SRK found that food<br /><br />
shortages wase an issue raised in the social surveys (Kumar & Van Vlaenderen, 2010), and<br /><br />
that it is evident that many villages in the vicinity of the rivers and streams rely on fishing to<br /><br />
supplement their diets. Maintaining the fishing resource is therefore critical in terms of food<br /><br />
security for these villagers. It is therefore important that African Minerals Limited acquires a<br /><br />
detailed understanding of fisheries in the areas that may potentially be impacted by projectrelated activities, in order to design, plan and implement appropriate mitigation and<br /><br />
management measures.<br /><br />

SUBJECT:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
U4041 - Tonkolili Soils and Laterite Profile<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
INTRODUCTION<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The purpose of this Memorandum is to provide information in respect of the soils present in the area surrounding<br /><br />
the Simbili and Numbara deposits at the Tonkolili iron ore project, Republic of Sierra Leone. This information<br /><br />
has been derived from both diamond and reverse circulation drilling and includes an interpretation of the<br /><br />
superficial material. However, it is to be noted that, for most drill sites the first two (2) metres of material was<br /><br />
removed during preparation of the drill pad (i.e. clearing and levelling via bulldozer).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
OVERVIEW<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The upper most surficial material at the Tonkolili iron ore deposits is dependent on the underlying geology.<br /><br />
Where the underlying geology is the iron-ore protolith (quartz and silicate itabirites) then a ferruginous hardcap or<br /><br />
canga profile has developed. Where the underlying geology is either the footwall or hangingwall acid to<br /><br />
intermediate rocks a simple laterite profile has developed.<br /><br />
The canga at the Tonkolili iron-ore project consists of predominantly angular to subrounded fragments of<br /><br />
hematite and pisoliths partially replaced by goethite and cemented by clays, reprecipitated silica and iron oxide.<br /><br />
At the hangingwall/footwall contacts and slope failures, goethite-rich pisoliths, gibbsite and clays are more<br /><br />
common. Simple laterites are typically red in colour, comprising of massive and colloform goethite-hematite,<br /><br />
with common iron-oxide fragments cemented by clays, reprecipitated silica and iron oxides.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SRK Consulting (UK) Ltd.<br /><br />
Registered in England and Wales<br /><br />
Reg. No. 1575403<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Registered Address:<br /><br />
21 Gold Tops,<br /><br />
Newport,<br /><br />
Gwent.<br /><br />
NP9 4PG<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Offices in:<br /><br />
Africa<br /><br />
Asia<br /><br />
Australia<br /><br />
North America<br /><br />
South America<br /><br />

SRK CONSULTING<br /><br />
<br /><br />
MEMORANDUM<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
GEOMORPHOLOGY AND LATERITE DEVELOPMENT<br /><br />
The Tonkolili iron-ore project comprises a portion of the north-south trending Archean Sula Mountain range<br /><br />
which extends for over 20 km and has elevations between 200 and 880m. Superficial laterites, including iron-ore<br /><br />
enrichment, are considered to be the result of laterisation, whereby the previously uplifted land surface has<br /><br />
undergone erosion during an extended period of tectonic stability, under the influence of a tropical to subtropical<br /><br />
climate. Laterite development is likely to have occurred in the Pleistocene or Upper Tertiary, a common age<br /><br />
worldwide for the development of laterite deposits. Importantly, the moderately- to steeply-dipping structure of<br /><br />
the rocks at the Tonkolili iron-ore project assisted groundwater circulation and development of the laterite profile.<br /><br />
Younger east-west trending tectonic movements produced deep trenches and gorges in the Tonkolili laterites and<br /><br />
iron-ores and led to erosion and redeposition of lateritic materials.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SOILS<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The laterite soil profile ( Figure 1-1) at the Tonkolili iron-ore project has developed to depths of between 40 and<br /><br />
105 m, with a goethite-rich surficial crust up of to 10m thick. Due to the acid to intermediate character of the<br /><br />
footwall and hangingwall rocks, the laterite profile at Tonkolili may be generalised into two types: canga and<br /><br />
simple laterite. Canga is a laterite soil developed over iron-ores which presents Fe-enrichments which exceed<br /><br />
58% Fe. Simple laterite comprises a ferruginous crust which has developed over any and all host rocks having<br /><br />
produced a compositional and textural variation related to the protolith.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 1-1. Typical laterite profile at the Simbili deposit<br /><br />
<br /><br />
File Ref: P:\U4041 Tonkolili WP Framework\Task 5 ECF ESHIA Programme\Reps\Soils Memo\Soil_laterite_v4.docx<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SRK CONSULTING<br /><br />
<br /><br />
MEMORANDUM<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Canga<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Canga profile as seen at Tonkolili is presented as a well-developed laterite profile which progresses from<br /><br />
texturally-preserved lower saprolite (at depth) rocks with low to moderate permeability, through a highly<br /><br />
permeable fine grained friable hematite horizon (SHS - main supergene iron-ore at the redox front; Figure 1-2).<br /><br />
The friable hematite horizon, which contains minor clays and granular silica, underlies a hard hematite zone<br /><br />
(SHH; Figure 1-2) which typically comprises banded hematite and minor permeable clays (due to protolith<br /><br />
silicate content). Towards the surface, there is an increase in hematite-goethite infilled fractures and colloform<br /><br />
precipitates, which give way to moderately permeable canga, consisting of angular to subrounded fragments of<br /><br />
hematite and pisoliths, which form the top 2-3m. These surficial sediments are partially replaced by goethite and<br /><br />
cemented by clays, reprecipitated silica and iron oxides. At the hangingwall and footwall contacts and slope<br /><br />
failures goethite-rich pisoliths, gibbsite and clays are more common.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 1-2: examples of hematite mineralisation from the laterite profile. SHStypical soft hematite; SHH typical hard hematite<br /><br />
<br /><br />
File Ref: P:\U4041 Tonkolili WP Framework\Task 5 ECF ESHIA Programme\Reps\Soils Memo\Soil_laterite_v4.docx<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SRK CONSULTING<br /><br />
<br /><br />
MEMORANDUM<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Simple Laterites<br /><br />
The simple laterites profiles observed at a the Tonkolili project consist of two distinct types, based on protolithological associations; clastic-chemical sequences with tuffaceous contribution and acid to intermediate<br /><br />
pyroclastic rocks.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
FT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Clastic-chemical sequence consists of, clays, including kaolin, with minor silica, which is predominantly<br /><br />
white to beige in colour with minor variation to pink-red and browns due to the variable content of mafic minerals<br /><br />
in the protolith. The sequence is typically massive with low permeability. The uppermost surficial metres (Figure<br /><br />
1-3) are typically red and brown and comprises massive and colloform goethite-hematite, with common ironoxide fragments cemented by clays, reprecipitated silica and iron oxides.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 1-3. Clay rich goethite laterite<br /><br />
<br /><br />
D<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The acid, acid to intermediate and acid-intermediate pyroclastic rock related laterites consist of clays, excluding<br /><br />
kaolin, and are predominantly pink to red in colour with minor variation to yellow-ochre and brown. Typically,<br /><br />
this sequence is massive with low permeability (Figure 1-4). The uppermost surficial metres are typically red and<br /><br />
comprises massive and colloform goethite-hematite, with common iron-oxide fragments cemented by clays,<br /><br />
reprecipitated silica and iron oxides, and the development of pisoliths (accretionary mass of iron oxides).<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
SRK Consulting (UK) Ltd – Executive Summary<br /><br />
Tonkolili Geology/Geomorphology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Executive Summary<br /><br />
SRK Consulting (UK) Ltd (SRK) has been engaged by African Mineral Ltd (AML) to undertake a<br /><br />
Geological and Geomorphological Baseline Study to assess the impact of the proposed Tonkolili Iron<br /><br />
Ore Mine. SRK has conducted a thorough desktop review of available literature from a number of<br /><br />
sources.<br /><br />
The Tonkolili Iron Ore project is located in the margins of the Sula Mountains in northern-central<br /><br />
Sierra Leone, approximately 180-200km ENE of the capital, Freetown. This study focuses on the<br /><br />
study area covered by the May 2009 Mineral Resource Estimate reported by SRK which includes the<br /><br />
Simbili, Marampon and Numbara deposits and totals 5.1 Bt of ore, at a grade of 30% Fe.<br /><br />
The Tonkolili region is made up of high rugged mountain ranges, eroded plateaus and smooth hill tops<br /><br />
that rise from 200 to 880 m in elevation. The lowest points which form narrow valleys and gorges<br /><br />
have elevations of between 200 to 350 m. Within the larger area, hills have a dominant NE-SW to<br /><br />
NNE-SWW trend and are intersected by approximately orthogonal valleys, which expand out towards<br /><br />
the south of Numbara.<br /><br />
The primary BIF mineralisation occurs in the form of mixed silicate and quartz itabirite (magnetite),<br /><br />
hosted by metamorphosed successions of acid-volcanics, tuffs, pelitic sediments, clastic sediments and<br /><br />
metacarbonate rocks, all of which are cross cut by pegmatites and porphyritic dykes and sills,<br /><br />
Structurally, the Tonkolili iron deposits are arranged in a left-stepping array, at a very low angle to the<br /><br />
overall trend (NE-SW),displaced, by a series of ESE-WNW trending faults.<br /><br />
The bedrock geology is overlain by laterally and vertically variable laterite and duricrust, which<br /><br />
contribute to the three distinct geomorphological domains that can be observed:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Accumulative valley deposits (domain 1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Denuded weather slopes (domain 2)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Deeply weathered Peneplains (domain 3)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Tonkolili area is host to a network of rivers and seasonal streams that feed the perennial Tonkolili<br /><br />
River. The drainage network is variable in pattern ranging from dendritic to parallel (sub-parallel) to<br /><br />
trellis, to rectangular and annualar.<br /><br />
The Tonkolili Iron Project will significantly alter the geology and geomorphology of the area, with<br /><br />
additional implications of the hydrogeological/hydrological regime. In order to mitigate these affects a<br /><br />
number of steps can be taken. For example, watercourses can be diverted to protect excavation areas<br /><br />
and prevent contamination. Land used during construction should be reclaimed and rehabilitated.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

6\Tonkolili_Geology_Geomorphology_v6.docx<br /><br />

<br /><br />
1.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Qualification of Consultants<br /><br />
The SRK Group comprises over 900 staff, offering expertise in a wide range of resource<br /><br />
engineering disciplines. The SRK Group’s independence is ensured by the fact that it holds<br /><br />
no equity in any project. This permits the SRK Group to provide its clients with conflict-free<br /><br />
and objective recommendations on crucial judgment issues. The SRK Group has a<br /><br />
demonstrated track record in undertaking independent assessments of resources and reserves,<br /><br />
project evaluations and audits, JORC Code compliance audits, independent engineers’<br /><br />
reports and independent feasibility evaluations to bankable standards on behalf of<br /><br />
exploration and mining companies and financial institutions worldwide. The SRK Group has<br /><br />
also worked with a large number of major international mining companies and their projects,<br /><br />
providing mining industry consultancy service inputs. SRK also has specific experience in<br /><br />
commissions of this nature.<br /><br />
This technical report has been prepared based on a technical review by consultants sourced<br /><br />
from the SRK Group’s United Kingdom office. These consultants are specialists in the fields<br /><br />
of geology and Mineral Resource estimation.<br /><br />
SRK’s independence is ensured by the fact that it holds no equity in any project and that its<br /><br />
ownership rests solely with its staff. SRK has a demonstrated track record in providing<br /><br />
independent estimates of Mineral Resources and Ore Reserve Estimates, project evaluations<br /><br />
and audits, competent person’s reports and independent feasibility evaluations to bankable<br /><br />
standards on behalf of exploration and mining companies and financial institutions<br /><br />
worldwide. SRK also has specific expertise in relation to iron ore projects.<br /><br />
Neither SRK nor any of its employees employed in the preparation of this report has any<br /><br />
beneficial interest in the assets of AML. SRK will charge a fee for this work in accordance<br /><br />
with normal professional consulting practice.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Project Location<br /><br />
The Tonkolili License area lies largely within the rugged greenstone belt of the southern<br /><br />
Sula Mountain Range approximately 10 km east-southeast of the town of Bumbuna. The<br /><br />
project area is best accessed by road, using 4-wheel drive vehicles. The journey typically<br /><br />
comprises travel along a series of poorly constructed gravel tracks for approximately two<br /><br />
hours from Lungi to Port Loko, followed by one and half hours on a tarmac highway<br /><br />
between Lunsar and Magburaka, passing through Makeni, and finally a further one and a<br /><br />
half hours on gravel tracks from Magburaka to the exploration camp, passing through<br /><br />
Bumbuna (Figure 1-1).<br /><br />

<br /><br />
PROJECT SCOPE<br /><br />
The scope of work required for the baseline study is as follows:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Desktop review of the available literature on the geology and geomorphology of the<br /><br />
area around the proposed Tonkolili mine.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identification of potential impacts on the integrity of geological structures as well as<br /><br />
on the geomorphology of the area as a result of contamination and/or activities<br /><br />
relating to the proposed mine development.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Suggestion of appropriate mitigation measures to minimise/reduce the impacts on the<br /><br />
geology and geomorphology of the area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SRK does not consider any further fieldwork required to establish the geological and<br /><br />
geomorphological baseline conditions for the site.<br /><br />

Tonkolili Geology/Geomorphology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
GEOLOGY<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Regional Geology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Tonkolili Exploration License is situated within, and marginal to, the Sula Mountains<br /><br />
greenstone belt in the older Achaean granitic basement region of Sierra Leone. Two major<br /><br />
orogenic episodes are reported that resulted in the development of a major intracrustal basin<br /><br />
that was subsequently metamorphosed during a second (Liberian) episode of deformation to<br /><br />
form the Kambui Group greenstones, which has subsequently been uplifted to form the Sula<br /><br />
Mountains.<br /><br />
The License is underlain by various schists of the intracrustal Sula Mountains greenstone<br /><br />
belt, adjacent to basement syn-kinematic granites intruded by late-kinematic granites.<br /><br />
The Sula Mountains greenstones (Kambui Group) are metamorphosed intracratonic basinal<br /><br />
sediments in which lithologies grade upwards and inwards from basal metamorphosed<br /><br />
ultramafic volcanics (chlorite and talc schists), through metamorphosed basic volcanics<br /><br />
(amphibolites) to central quartzites and metasediments with interbedded banded ironstones.<br /><br />
Deep weathering during landform modification and uplift gave rise to the formation of the<br /><br />
duricrust zone on the original Cretaceous peneplanized surfaces<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Local Geology and Mineralisation<br /><br />
The predominantly Archean granite-greenstone belt terranes that comprise approximately<br /><br />
75% of Sierra Leone represent the remnants of continental nuclei at the edge of the West<br /><br />
African Craton. The Archean bedrock geology of Sierra Leone can be broadly subdivided<br /><br />
into; intracrustal gneisses and granitoids; supracrustal greenstone belts and basic-ultra basic<br /><br />
igneous complexes.<br /><br />
The basement of the license area is formed of granitoids of the Leonean and Pre-Liberian<br /><br />
Granites. These basement rocks are believed to have been emplaced during both the syn- and<br /><br />
late-kinematic events related to the Leonean Orogeny. The Leonean Granites are the<br /><br />
precursors to the Liberian Granites and both were formed as intracrustal rock formations.<br /><br />
The various igneous differentiates of these granitic rocks were classified based on the<br /><br />
preservation of the major deformation fabrics (Macfarlane et al, 1981). Late acid gneissic<br /><br />
rocks and pegmatites are common with the granitic rocks.<br /><br />
The syn-kinematic granites (Leonean) were emplaced between 3.2 and 2.9 Ga, and are<br /><br />
exposed as coarse grained, equigranular, grey to light grey coloured with biotite, plagioclase<br /><br />
feldspars and quartz as major mineral components. The late-kinematic (Liberian) granites<br /><br />
were emplaced during the late stages of the Leonean orogensis and are composed of quartz,<br /><br />
microcline, plagioclase feldspar, and ± muscovite and ± hornblende (Frikken, 2006). These<br /><br />
later granites are lighter coloured due to their lack of ferromagnesian minerals.<br /><br />
Within the license area the Liberian Granites occupy mostly the eastern part of the prospect<br /><br />
area, while the Leonean Granites occur to the south eastern end. Cross cutting relationships<br /><br />
<br /><br />
File Ref:P:\U4041 Tonkolili WP Framework\Task 5 ECF ESHIA Programme\Reps\Baseline_Geology_Geomorphology\Version<br /><br />
6\Tonkolili_Geology_Geomorphology_v6.docx<br /><br />
DEND/BROC<br /><br />
March 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SRK Consulting (UK) Ltd<br /><br />
Tonkolili Geology/Geomorphology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
are rare, however approximately 300 m north of Kemadugu village, the Leonean Granites are<br /><br />
intruded by the Liberian Granites.<br /><br />
The granitic basement rocks are unconformably overlain by a regionally metamorphosed<br /><br />
thick sequence of meta-sedimentary, meta-volcanics, volcano-sedimentary and ultramafic<br /><br />
rock units of the Kambui Super group. The metamorphic grade is characterised by mineral<br /><br />
assemblages of the low grade greenschist facies (chlorite-actinolite–hornblende–muscovite-±<br /><br />
epidote-albite). The Kambui Super group forms the north-east trending Sula Mountain<br /><br />
Greenstone Belt sequence.<br /><br />
The license area is dominated by rock units of the Sula Group which is part of the Kambui<br /><br />
Super group. The Sula Group is comprised of the Sonfon Formation and Tonkolili<br /><br />
Formation, of which the latter is the younger rock unit and is largely constituted of metasedimentary and meta-volcanics, particularly tuffaceous layers.<br /><br />
The Sonfon Formation is documented as being composed of amphibolites with basalt pillow<br /><br />
lavas and ultramafic rocks (MacFarlane et al, 1981). The Sonfon Formation in the most part<br /><br />
occupies the western side of the project area, and form possible thrust-bounded bodies within<br /><br />
the project, an example of which can be seen east of Farengbaya.<br /><br />
To the south of Numbara, the Simbili and Marampon prospects are characterised by the<br /><br />
amphibolites and amphibolite schists of the Sonfon formation. These are associated with<br /><br />
mica-quartz-schists interbedded with some pelitic sediments and quartz-mica-schists. Where<br /><br />
the amphibolites are observed to have a gradational contact with the various mica-schist beds<br /><br />
(MacFarlane et al, 1981).<br /><br />
The Sonfon Formation is conformably overlain by the Tonkolili Formation which is<br /><br />
composed of well-stratified interbedded thin beds of quartz-mica-schists, mica-quartzschists, metamorphosed semi-pelitic to pelitic sediments and thin interbeds of metatuffaceous materials. The stratigraphic relationship between the quartz-mica-schist and the<br /><br />
pelitic sediments is not clear, but appears to have an interfingering relationship.<br /><br />
The Tonkolili Formation occupies the majority of the project area and it is within the upper<br /><br />
part of the sequence that the BIF is hosted. The geology of the Tonkolili formation is split<br /><br />
into two, the upper part is mainly comprised of finer, well-stratified and alternating thin beds<br /><br />
of mica-quartz-schist, semi-pelitic to pelitic sediments and possibly tuffites. The lower part<br /><br />
of the sequence is composed of mostly coarser grained quartz-mica-schist which grade into<br /><br />
quartzites further south of the area.<br /><br />
4.2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />

volcanic rock: green, fine grained, porphyritic aspect,<br /><br />

quartz phenocrysts set in a fine grained matrix of<br /><br />
biotote+amphibole+quartz. In drill intersections this rock presents<br /><br />
variable compositional facies, probably due to magmatic<br /><br />
differentiation (evolution). Gradational upper contact with<br /><br />
overlying sequence.<br /><br />

4.2.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 11<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Structure<br /><br />
The Tonkolili iron deposits are arranged in a left-stepping array, at a very low angle to the<br /><br />
overall trend. Major lineaments along the margins of several of the deposits shown on<br /><br />
magnetic survey data are interpreted as significant shear zones which have tectonically<br /><br />
interleaved and juxtaposed the deposits.<br /><br />
The rock units of the Kambui Super Group which includes the Sonfon and Tonkolili<br /><br />
Formations have been subjected to at least two sets of deformation which have developed a<br /><br />
broad south plunging synform with northeast trending open folds. These folds are<br /><br />
documented (Frikken, 2006) to have been formed during a major northwest-southeast<br /><br />
compressional event related to the Leonean Orogeny. These folded metamorphosed volcanosedimentary sequences have been further disturbed by an array of northeast to north<br /><br />
northeast and northwest to north northwest trending lineaments or faults.<br /><br />
The main BIF units comprising the Tonkolili resource constitute a relatively simple package<br /><br />
of moderately to strongly sheared ironstones, dipping steeply towards the NW. Original<br /><br />
depositional banding within the ironstones is almost entirely lost due to metamorphism and<br /><br />
deformation. However, a strong tectonic fabric manifested as compositional banding defines<br /><br />
the structure of the rocks and dips moderately to steeply towards the Northwest. This<br /><br />
relatively planar fabric has resulted from top-to-the-southeast shear along the NE-striking<br /><br />
belt and locally grade into lower strain zones where folds with axial planes dipping parallel<br /><br />
to the banding is evident.<br /><br />
The down-dip extension of the Simbili deposit is affected by a series of subvertical, SE-sidedown shear zones which tectonically interleave BIF and country rocks. This shear zone and<br /><br />
several others like it are believed to flank the main deposit areas and are responsible for<br /><br />
juxtaposing the main ironstone units. Tectonic contacts between the units are characterised<br /><br />
by change in foliation orientation and strain intensity, strong chlorite-actinolite alteration<br /><br />
and, occasionally, narrow slivers of country rock. The setting of the Tonkolili project is<br /><br />
provisionally interpreted as an over-steepened thrust zone or pure-shear dominated zone of<br /><br />
sinistral transpression.<br /><br />
The main Tonkolili range is affected by a set of steep to subvertical northwest-striking fault<br /><br />
zones, which accommodate decimetre-scale apparent displacements of the magnetite<br /><br />
resource. These appear to be zones of preferred fluid ingress and weathering of the<br /><br />
ironstones.<br /><br />
The geometry of the fabrics and the belt as a whole is closest to either an over-steepened<br /><br />
thrust belt (i.e., back-tilted), or a positive flower structure in a zone of pure shear dominated<br /><br />
transpression (contraction with a subordinate component of transcurrent movement).<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Deposit Geometry<br /><br />
The deposits generally strike NE-SW, dipping 60-70° towards the NW, with the exception of<br /><br />
Marampon, which dips at angle of approximately 24° (also towards the NW). Simbili<br /><br />
extends over a strike length of approximately 3600m, Numbara 3000m, Marampon 1600m<br /><br />
and Kasafoni 7600m. Simbili and Numbara range in thickness from 80 to 550m. Marampon<br /><br />
and Kasafoni are generally narrower at 60-220m. The Kasafoni and Numbara South areas of<br /><br />
the deposit are not covered within the remit of this baseline study and as such will not be<br /><br />
further mentioned (Figure 4-3).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 4-3. Orebodies; geometries and sizes<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.2.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Seismicity<br /><br />
Earthquakes are a negligible risk at Tonkolili, the USGS National Earthquake Information<br /><br />
Centre has recorded no earthquakes where the epicentre was within a 180km of the Tonkolili<br /><br />
deposit. In fact there have only been five recorded earthquakes where the epicentre was<br /><br />
within a 500 km radius of the Tonkolili deposit which occurred in 1983, 1987, 1995, 2001<br /><br />
and 2004, all of which occurred within the neighbouring countries of Guinea and Liberia.<br /><br />

Surficial Geology<br /><br />
Ten regolith zones have been defined and exist in varying proportions depending on the<br /><br />
underlying geology (Table 4-1). The zones predominantly define hillside and hilltop<br /><br />
domains.<br /><br />

The regolith zone at Numbara has a depth ranging from 14 to 120m, with an average depth<br /><br />
of 73m, compared with 64m at Simbili, which exhibits a depth range of 2-158m (Figure 4-4).<br /><br />
The area immediately above and down slope of the magnetite BIF is dominated by hematite<br /><br />
and goethite rich duricrust, which ranges from soft hematite sand to hard, silica and alumina<br /><br />
rich duricrust.<br /><br />
As the orebody extends down dip the overlying surficial lithologies tend towards iron poor,<br /><br />
silica and alumina rich saprock typified by earthy, powdery lithologies.<br /><br />

4.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Geological Exploration<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.4.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Drilling<br /><br />
AML has undertaken surface trenching, RC and diamond drilling and across both Numbara<br /><br />
and Simbili, surface trenching and diamond drilling across Marampon. The diamond drilling<br /><br />
makes up the majority of the database that intersects the primary BIF mineralisation and<br /><br />
laterite duricrust while the RC drilling and surface trenching is limited to the laterite<br /><br />
duricrust.<br /><br />
Numbara has been drilled on a dominant 300 m Y by 100 m X grid with partial infill drilling<br /><br />
on a 100 m Y by 100 m X grid. Simbili has been drilled on a dominant 200 m Y by 100 m X<br /><br />
grid, Marampon has been drilled on a 200 m Y by 200 m X grid (Table 4-2).<br /><br />

The majority of holes have been drilled dipping to the southeast, on an azimuth of 130° and a<br /><br />
dip of -60°, to intersect perpendicular to the BIF units that dip to the northwest. Shallow<br /><br />
vertical holes have been completed in the laterite duricrust at the Simbili deposit.<br /><br />
4.4.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Geophysical Surveying<br /><br />
Magnetic surveys were flown over the license area in mid 2005 by Firefly Aviation Inc of<br /><br />
Calgary, Canada, to aid in the evaluation of the iron ore potential. The data presented for this<br /><br />
license represents the merging of several separate datasets including the original Tonkolili<br /><br />
survey totalling 404 line km at 200 m line spacing, a historical survey flown at 200 m<br /><br />
spacing and an infill survey flown to close the historic data at 100 m line spacing. In addition<br /><br />
AML have also performed a series of ground magnetic surveys at an infill 200 m line<br /><br />
spacing.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mineral Resource Estimation<br /><br />
The Mineral Resource Statement (Table 4-3) released by SRK in May 2009 was restricted to<br /><br />
that BIF material falling within the Whittle Shell derived using a metal price of 80<br /><br />
USc/dmtu. This represents the material which SRK considers has reasonable prospect for<br /><br />
eventual economic extraction potential based on the above Whittle optimisation analysis.<br /><br />
In total, Numbara, Marampon and Simbili have a combined resource of 5.1 Bt grading<br /><br />
30.0% Fe Total, 26.5% Fe Mag, 45.3% SiO2 and 4.7% Al2O3. Davis Tube testwork results in<br /><br />
a mass recovery of 29.0% for 1.5 Bt of concentrate grading at 67.7% Fe, 4.92% SiO2, 0.48%<br /><br />
Al2O3 and 0.01% P. Numbara contains an Indicated Resource of 1.6 Bt, Marampon an<br /><br />
Indicated Resource of 0.4 Bt and Simbili an Indicated Resource of 1.1 Bt. Approximately<br /><br />
60% of the resource has been classified as an Indicated Resource (Figure 4-5; Figure 4-6).<br /><br />

4.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Open Pit Optimisation<br /><br />
The Mineral Resources have been reported within a Whittle optimised open pit shell to<br /><br />
define that material which has the potential for economic extraction, giving an indication of<br /><br />
the potential pit area of the proposed mine. This exercise includes consideration of slope<br /><br />
angles, mining costs, mining dilution and losses, ore treatment and recovery, transport costs,<br /><br />
royalties and metal prices. The resultant shells represent a possible outline of the potential<br /><br />
open pit mine, and do not represent the final pit design (Figure 4-7).<br /><br />

<br /><br />
5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
GEOMORPHOLOGY<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
General description<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 19<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Tonkolili region is made up of high rugged mountain ranges, eroded plateaus and<br /><br />
smooth hill tops that rise from 200 to 880 m in elevation. The lowest points which form<br /><br />
narrow valleys and gorges have elevations of between 200 to 350 m. Within the license area,<br /><br />
the smooth hill tops and plateaus trend in a north-easterly direction and are deeply incised by<br /><br />
the Tonkolili River drainage system which flows to the south east. Most of the steeply<br /><br />
inclined drainages are filled with laterite duricrust and boulders, whereas, the downstream<br /><br />
valley-floor areas are typically swampy and flat-lying. Within the larger area hills have a<br /><br />
dominant NE-SW to NNE-SWW trend and are intersected by approximately orthogonal<br /><br />
valleys, which expand out towards the south of Numbara.<br /><br />
The Tonkolili area consists can be subdivided into three distinct geomorphological domains<br /><br />
that directly reflect topography. The topographically lowest domain exists at the base of the<br /><br />
valleys and extends approximately 20 m up slope. This domain yields to the steeply inclined<br /><br />
hill sides (second domain), which in turn lead to the peneplainised hill tops, constituting the<br /><br />
third geomorphological domain:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Accumulative valley deposits (domain 1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Denuded weather slopes (domain 2)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Deeply weathered Peneplains (domain 3)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The local topography is reasonably steeply inclined (see Figure 5-1) with hill sides that<br /><br />
typically range from 15° to 45°. Small cliff sections are common, particularly at the crest of<br /><br />
the numerous landslides, which possess elevated slope angles in excess of 45°. The east<br /><br />
facing slopes of Simbili and west facing slopes of Numbara South represent the steepest<br /><br />
parts of the deposits The undulating bases of valleys dip from 0° to 15° over short ranges.. In<br /><br />
general, the peneplainised hill tops appear as small areas of near horizontal terrain (0-5°~)<br /><br />
surrounded by progressively steeper ground (moving downslope).<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
5.1.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 21<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Geomorphological Domains<br /><br />
Accumulative valley deposits<br /><br />
The accumulative domain consists of deposits of Quaternary alluvial sands, silts, clays and<br /><br />
conglomerates forming as thick, river cut successions at the base of wide “U” shaped<br /><br />
valleys. Alluvial material is overlain by thin deposits of soil. Sedimentation and development<br /><br />
of this domain is particularly active in the wet season via the transport of suspended<br /><br />
sediment, and eroded in the dry season, by the frequent heavy rains. This domain typically<br /><br />
expands in width towards the south of the project area, where valleys expand from 100-200m<br /><br />
in the north to 1.5-2km south of Simbili.<br /><br />
The valley domain varies from flat lying sediment accumulations to gently undulating<br /><br />
mounds and depressions, vegetated by grasses, small trees and localised dense tropical bush<br /><br />
(progressing respectively from the middle of valleys to edges).<br /><br />
Denuded, deeply weathered slopes<br /><br />
The deeply incised (by the Tonkolili River drainage system) slopes that extend from the<br /><br />
valley bottoms to the peneplainised hill tops consist of a mixture of autochthonous weathered<br /><br />
BIF and allochthonous boulders and Fe-rich soils. Slopes are cut by runnels which range in<br /><br />
morphology from shallow seasonal channels to densely vegetated, deeply weathered<br /><br />
perennial runnels associated with aquifer discharge and wet season runoff.<br /><br />
Peneplains<br /><br />
The hill tops are typically gently inclined plateaus, split by steeper horseback-crest style<br /><br />
relief and short, steep ramps. These areas range in gradient from 0° to a maximum of 10°<br /><br />
(Figure 5-2).<br /><br />
The southern half of Simbili, which is geomorphologically distinct from the northern end, is<br /><br />
typically more undulating along its length than Marampon and Numbara. This area consists<br /><br />
of narrower interlinked peneplains, connected by 10-25° ramps either side of the hill top.<br /><br />
This domain is deeply weathered, up to approximately 100m resulting in a variable soil<br /><br />
profile, which is dependent on the positions of the BIF subcrop. Typically this domain is<br /><br />
vegetated by grassy scrubland to green bush with small trees and shrubs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

1200m3/s). The mean annual discharge of 113m3/s is equivalent to around 890 mm of annual<br /><br />

Within the area immediately surrounding the Tonkolili Project, rectangular, trellis, dendritic,<br /><br />
parallel and annular drainage patterns can be observed (Table 6-1). Rectangular patterns<br /><br />
prevail in the northern parts of the Sula Mountains, extending as far south as the town of<br /><br />
Bumbuna. Between the deposit areas there is a strong structural control, with broadly parallel<br /><br />
to dendritic (almost trellis) drainage patterns trending NE-SW to NNE-SSW. Annular<br /><br />
patterns are common over areas of granitic intrusion and other dome like structures (Wilson<br /><br />
& Marmo, 1958).<br /><br />

Lower valley areas (geomorphological domain 1) typically exhibit parallel or dendritic<br /><br />
drainage patterns, whereas slope areas (domain 2), are more commonly characterised by<br /><br />
dendritic, parallel and sub-parallel drainage patterns.<br /><br />
The Tonkolili River is likely to follow the lithological contacts between more resistant quartz<br /><br />
schist and another (unknown), softer lithology. It is suggested that NW-SE trending sections<br /><br />
of the river are likely to parallel the strike of a regional set of faults that exist in that<br /><br />
orientation.<br /><br />

6.1.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 26<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Local Drainage and Flow Characteristics<br /><br />
The sites of Numbara, Marampon and Simbili are drained by three main catchment areas. All<br /><br />
three sites drain in a westerly direction towards the Rokel River catchment (south of the<br /><br />
Bumbuna Dam). Whilst the Numbara site drains exclusively to this catchment, the<br /><br />
Marampon and Simbili sites also drain easterly into the Mawura catchment. The westerly<br /><br />
draining water contributes to the Tonkolili River.<br /><br />
The majority of groundwater flow at the Simbili, Numbara and Marampon deposits occurs<br /><br />
through the weathered cap, which comprises partially weathered amphibolite and BIF.<br /><br />
Within this zone, most groundwater flow occurs through open fractures. The weathered cap<br /><br />
exhibits a permeability that is approximately one order of magnitude higher in the fractures<br /><br />
than in the matrix. Connectivity of fractures varied between test sites and between<br /><br />
observation wells at the same test site, which demonstrates the heterogeneous nature of the<br /><br />
weathered cap aquifer (SRK Open pit hydrogeological investigation, 2010).<br /><br />
Although differences in permeability between the weathered BIF on Simbili and the<br /><br />
weathered amphibolite on Numbara may be lithological, it is likely that the principal control<br /><br />
on the connectivity and alignment of fractures in the weathered cap is structural. However,<br /><br />
little data exists on the distribution and orientation of fracturing in the weathered cap. A<br /><br />
structural interpretation of the geotechnical logging data from the weathered cap (and other<br /><br />
geological units) is clearly required.<br /><br />
Whatever the control on fracture extent, it is clear from the testwork that the weathered cap<br /><br />
is significantly more permeable (hydraulic conductivity (K)=E-1 to E-3m/d) than the more<br /><br />
completely weathered and transported material present on the hill flanks (K=E-4 to E-5m/d).<br /><br />
From examination of the existing core, it is also likely that the underlying fresh BIF and<br /><br />
amphibolite are significantly less permeable than the weathered cap, a hypothesis that is<br /><br />
supported by the very dominant spring line which surrounds all three deposits. However,<br /><br />
this may again depend heavily on structural features and the permeability of the underlying<br /><br />
fresh rock has not been directly investigated in this study.<br /><br />
The completely weathered rock that makes up the overlying laterite and, locally, the<br /><br />
duricrust mainly comprises silt-grade material.<br /><br />
Although the laterite/duricrust is unlikely to play an important role in terms of groundwater<br /><br />
flow, it may play a significant role in groundwater recharge. It is possible that the<br /><br />
laterite/duricrust may act as a buffer to rapid recharge the groundwater flow to springs as<br /><br />
well as to direct through flow to springs, which in turn would control the hydrograph<br /><br />
response in the rivers. Removal of the laterite/duricrust could see a more flashy hydrograph<br /><br />
response in the Tonkolili and Mawura rivers.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
File Ref:P:\U4041 Tonkolili WP Framework\Task 5 ECF ESHIA Programme\Reps\Baseline_Geology_Geomorphology\Version<br /><br />
6\Tonkolili_Geology_Geomorphology_v6.docx<br /><br />
DEND/BROC<br /><br />
March 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SRK Consulting (UK) Ltd<br /><br />
Tonkolili Geology/Geomorphology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 27<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The conceptual hydrogeological model (Figure 6-2) can be summarised as follows.<br /><br />
Recharge percolates through the laterite or duricrust into the weathered cap from where the<br /><br />
majority of groundwater flows laterally, at the contact with fresh rock, towards the ridge<br /><br />
flanks and discharges through springs to the surface water network. The component of<br /><br />
groundwater flow from the weathered cap to the colluvium is unknown but is considered to<br /><br />
be low given the generally low permeability of the colluvium. Similarly, it is thought that<br /><br />
groundwater flow from the weather cap to the underlying fresh BIF and amphibolite, which<br /><br />
appears to be generally competent, is also low.<br /><br />
Mining operations are likely to encounter potentially moderate to high initial inflows from<br /><br />
groundwater as the pit progresses below the water table, but these inflows are likely to be<br /><br />
short lived as groundwater flow from fracture storage is depleted. As the cone of depression<br /><br />
from the open pit extends to beyond the limit of the weathered cap and into the colluvium,<br /><br />
inflows with reduce again.<br /><br />
The impact of mining on groundwater-fed springs discharging from the flanks of the deposits<br /><br />
will most likely be significant as the source of groundwater to springs is dewatered from the<br /><br />
pit. This will affect river baseflow, which will be most noticeable during the dry season.<br /><br />
However, the extent of the impact on baseflow is not known and should be investigated<br /><br />
further in the coming stages of the investigations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

7<br /><br />
<br /><br />
IMPACTS AND MITIGATION MEASURES<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Impacts<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 28<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During the mining operations, mine site infrastructure and mine waste disposal will sterilise<br /><br />
the potential for undertaking further exploration in parts of the project area, and hence<br /><br />
sterilise the use of existing resources. However, work is being undertaken to ensure that<br /><br />
there is no sterilisation of resources in key areas of proposed infrastructure/construction.<br /><br />
The ore will be extracted by open-pit methods, which will be optimised to suit the orebody<br /><br />
geometry and ground conditions. Mining of the ore amounts to the use of a non-renewable<br /><br />
resource; such that once the reserves are depleted this natural resource cannot be used again.<br /><br />
The optimised pit shells suggest the designed pits will occupy a significant area. For<br /><br />
example, the Simbili open pit may be up to 4 km in length and over 2 km wide (Figure 7-1).<br /><br />
Potential impacts on the geology and geomorphology of the Project Area include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
changes to the topography and geological unit geometry as a result of exploratory<br /><br />
drilling and trenching, infrastructure construction, open pit extraction, waste rock<br /><br />
storage, stockpiling and an extensive tailings facility;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
human-induced landslides and other slope processes due to man-made ground<br /><br />
vibrations;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
changes in rock stress regimes;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
potential changes in flow regime, and water quality, of rivers, along with other<br /><br />
ephemeral watercourses, and groundwater, due to extraction and new infrastructure,<br /><br />
and stockpiling potentially harmful material;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
loss of land capability indefinitely in the pit area and in areas of new infrastructure;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
alteration of overland flow and gully pathways due to extraction, infrastructure and<br /><br />
waste and stockpile dumps;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
alteration of local topography surrounding incline ramp, pit, tailings storage dam,<br /><br />
waste rock dumps, processing plant and associated infrastructure (roads etc); and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
creation of man-made soils.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Current exploration work, in the form of trenching, pitting and drill pad construction has<br /><br />
already altered the topography of the area, resulting in changes to local watercourses,<br /><br />
overland flow rates and sedimentation, by weathering and erosion. These changes compound<br /><br />
the existing geological and geomorpholoigcal impacts resulting from extensive artisanal gold<br /><br />
mining that is centred on most local watercourses.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

7.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 30<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mitigation<br /><br />
To reduce the effect the mine will have on the geology and geomorphology of the Project<br /><br />
Area, the following recommendations should be adhered to:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preserve watercourses where possible, and divert others to protect excavations and<br /><br />
containment areas (that is, infrastructure stability).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reclaim and rehabilitate land disturbed during construction by re-grading, recontouring and replacing topsoil following closure and decommissioning.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Rehabilitate and landscape areas disturbed during construction of permanent/semipermanent structures.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reuse excavated material, where possible, for further construction and earth works, in<br /><br />
order to minimise the necessity for construction associated quarrying in the area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reduce harmful effects on the shape of the landscape by using well-designed blasting<br /><br />
programmes and mining techniques to minimise vibrations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
File Ref:P:\U4041 Tonkolili WP Framework\Task 5 ECF ESHIA Programme\Reps\Baseline_Geology_Geomorphology\Version<br /><br />
6\Tonkolili_Geology_Geomorphology_v6.docx<br /><br />
DEND/BROC<br /><br />
March 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SRK Consulting (UK) Ltd<br /><br />
Tonkolili Geology/Geomorphology<br /><br />
<br /><br />
8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 31<br /><br />
<br /><br />
CONCLUSIONS<br /><br />
Following studies by SRK a number of key conclusions have been reached that outline the<br /><br />
geological and geomorphological impacts of the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project. This Baseline<br /><br />
study represents a contribution towards the Scoping Report and eventual Environmental and<br /><br />
Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) report by WorleyParsons.<br /><br />
The most significant potential impacts to the geology and geomorphology by the<br /><br />
development Tonkolili Iron Ore Project include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Loss of a non-renewable Resources;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Loss/change in existing land use within the area during the life of the project;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Irreversible loss of land capability in the proposed open pit area;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Likely changes in water flow regime and drainage patterns and associated impacts on<br /><br />
rivers and landforms; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Potential change in river water quality<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The main mitigation measures for reducing the impact on geology and geomorphology at<br /><br />
Tonkolili include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Preserve watercourses where possible, and divert others to protect excavations and<br /><br />
containment areas (that is, infrastructure stability), and minimise contamination;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reclaim and rehabilitate land disturbed during construction by re-grading, recontouring and replacing topsoil following closure and decommissioning; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reduce harmful effects on the shape of the landscape by using well-designed blasting<br /><br />
programmes and mining techniques to minimise vibrations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

ENVIRONMENTAL NOTE ON MALARIA CONTROL OPTIONS<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
INTRODUCTION<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Malaria is by far the most important insect transmitted disease (Gilles and Warrell, 1993). Latest WHO<br /><br />
estimates are that there are 300-500 million cases of clinical malaria per year, with 1.4 to 2.6 million<br /><br />
deaths, mainly among African children. Malaria is therefore a major cause of infant mortality and is the<br /><br />
only insect borne parasitic disease comparable in impact to the world's major killer transmissible diseases:<br /><br />
diarrhea, acute respiratory infections, tuberculosis and AIDS.<br /><br />
Malaria is a life-threatening disease caused by parasites called plasmodium. Plasmodium are transmitted<br /><br />
by the bites of infected anopheles mosquitoes who require a blood meal for egg production (PAN 2009).<br /><br />
Once inside the body, the plasmodium parasites are carried in the blood stream to the liver, where they<br /><br />
multiply before infecting the red blood cells. Malarial attacks are characterized by fever, severe chills,<br /><br />
headache and vomiting and are triggered when the parasitic load within the red blood cells peaks; the red<br /><br />
blood cells rupture releasing a large number of parasites into the bloodstream, infecting the red blood cells<br /><br />
around them. If not treated, malaria can become life-threatening by disrupting the blood supply to the vital<br /><br />
organs.<br /><br />
There are four main types of plasmodium that cause malaria (P. falciparum, P. vivax, P. malariae and P.<br /><br />
ovale); in sub-Saharan Africa, the predominant one is P. falciparum. Approximately 40 anopheline<br /><br />
mosquito species are capable of transmitting malaria, all of which require water for larvae development.<br /><br />
Outside of this universal requirement, preferred breeding habitats can vary from species to species e.g.<br /><br />
sun or shade, temperature range, flowing or stagnant water, vegetation, floatability, salt content etc. Once<br /><br />
juvenile aquatic stages are completed, most adult mosquitoes have a range of 1-3 km by air. Flying and<br /><br />
feeding times vary by species, with some active at dawn and dusk and others during the daytime. The<br /><br />
dominant mosquito species in sub-Saharan Africa are A. gambiae and A. funestus, species characterised<br /><br />
by high longevity, density and anthropophily i.e. they prefer to feed on human rather than animal blood<br /><br />
(PAN 2009). It is estimated that on average, a person receives c.121 infected bites per year in Africa (PAN<br /><br />
2009).<br /><br />

<br /><br />
2.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
POTENTIAL IMPACT OF RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS<br /><br />
ON MALARIA<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Development projects have the capacity to influence the transmission of malaria. It can be expected that if<br /><br />
not anticipated and corrected for in the initial plan, most development projects will result in an increase in<br /><br />
malaria transmission because of one or more of the following factors:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Irrigation;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
water provision;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
building sites;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
road construction;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
deforestation;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
population shifts (resulting from economic, seasonal, or permanent migration, refugee situations).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In countries with a high malarial burden such as Africa, the health impacts associated with developmentrelated increase in malaria should therefore be given due consideration. Ideally, this is done during initial<br /><br />
planning in order that mitigation might be put in place to reduce the severity of this impact. Since malaria<br /><br />
is a vector-borne disease - meaning that it is transmitted through the bite of another organism (i.e. the<br /><br />
mosquito) - control of malaria transmission can be affected by means designed either to reduce mosquito<br /><br />
populations, or reduce human contact with those populations. The impacts of the development projects on<br /><br />
malaria through increased vector breeding sites should be considered for both inland as well as shoreline<br /><br />
activities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
OPPORTUNITIES FOR CONTROL OF MALARIA ASSOCIATED<br /><br />
WITH DEVELOPMENT EFFORTS<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Planning for and Monitoring of Malaria Control Associated with<br /><br />
Development Efforts<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It is recommended that all development projects take into account the potential for an adverse impact on<br /><br />
malaria disease transmission. Project plans must thus include provisions for reducing the potential for<br /><br />
transmission. Development of such plans and mechanisms for monitoring impact can best be achieved by<br /><br />
cross-sectoral teams.<br /><br />
Prevention of malaria associated with development can best be established at the pre-planning stage.<br /><br />
Early prevention of malaria is generally simpler and cheaper than instituting corrective measures later.<br /><br />
Specified recommended components, to be carried out by the team members, must be included in the<br /><br />
planning and implementation phases, respectively, to prevent an adverse impact on malaria. It is critical<br /><br />
that the implementation phase must continue and reinforce the interventions initiated in the planning<br /><br />
phase. These efforts should include:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
appendix 17 environmental note on malaria control (4).doc<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AFRICAN MINERALS LIMITED<br /><br />
ENVIRONMENTAL NOTE ON MALARIA CONTROL OPTIONS<br /><br />
TONKOLILI IRON ORE PROJECT<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In the planning phase:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In-country epidemiologic assessment for malaria. Projects must include a baseline<br /><br />
epidemiologic characterization of the region selected for development. This characterization will<br /><br />
include the current malaria situation, the biology of the malaria parasite and its various vector<br /><br />
control strategies, and the roles of the health system, the community, and the other sectors in any<br /><br />
existing malaria program;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Community involvement. A commitment to involve the community and develop a plan in<br /><br />
conjunction with the affected community. The input, consultation, and education of the affected<br /><br />
human population;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Design and establishment of safeguards. Preventive and corrective policies and practices must<br /><br />
be instituted to control malaria associated with development efforts; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A real time plan. Opportunity for later modifications to the development plan. The planning phase<br /><br />
must also include a consideration of changes that the development projects may generate and,<br /><br />
most importantly, allow for modifications to the plan to reduce the transmission of malaria in the<br /><br />
future.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In the implementation phase:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Regular and ongoing monitoring (at least yearly) of malaria epidemiology;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Continual involvement of the community in program implementation; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Monitoring and enforcement of safeguards.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The WHO recommends an Integrated Vector Management (IVM) approach, a systematic control approach<br /><br />
based on evidence and knowledge of the local situation (WHO website 2010). Integrated vector<br /><br />
management (IVM) is defined as "a rational decision-making process for the optimal use of resources for<br /><br />
vector control" and includes five key elements: 1) evidence-based decision-making, 2) integrated<br /><br />
approaches 3), collaboration within the health sector and with other sectors, 4) advocacy, social<br /><br />
mobilization, and legislation, and 5) capacity-building (Beier et al 2008). In 2004, the WHO adopted IVM<br /><br />
globally for the control of all vector-borne diseases. Important recent progress has been made in<br /><br />
developing and promoting IVM for national malaria control programmes in Africa at a time when<br /><br />
successful malaria control programmes are scaling-up with insecticide-treated nets (ITN) and/or indoor<br /><br />
residual spraying (IRS) coverage.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Available Control Measures<br /><br />
Since malaria involves three living beings: man (the host), plasmodia (the agent), and anopheles mosquito<br /><br />
(the vector), control of this menace is a formidable task. The measures most widely employed to control<br /><br />
malaria currently include insecticide-treated nets, preventative / curative medicines (chemoprophylaxis<br /><br />
and chemotherapy), and application of pesticides to control the vectors (mosquitoes). Other control<br /><br />
measures involve the use of environmental control strategies which can be used in addition to, or in some<br /><br />
<br /><br />
305000-00006 / WP0205000 : Rev A : 2 June 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
cases in place of more conventional techniques in order to provide a more sustainable approach. An<br /><br />
effective malaria control programme will often incorporate a number of measures that will work in unison.<br /><br />
The type or combination of control measures used for a given development project will depend on a<br /><br />
number of local factors and should be determined during the planning phase.<br /><br />
IRS is one of the primary vector control and transmission disruption measures used to control malaria<br /><br />
(WHO 2006). IRS involves the application of long-acting chemical insecticides to the inside walls and<br /><br />
ceilings of buildings to kill the adult vectors that land on them. This serves two functions, firstly to reduce<br /><br />
the lifespan of infected adult vectors, and secondly to reduce vector density (WHO 2006). The insecticide<br /><br />
used for IRS must be chosen according to local conditions (vector species – susceptibility and behaviour),<br /><br />
safety for humans and environment, and cost effectiveness balanced with efficacy. The WHO recommend<br /><br />
12 different insecticides (WHO 2006). Since many of these chemicals have known health effects (e.g.<br /><br />
DDT), care should be exercised when developing mitigation strategies that involve use of these potentially<br /><br />
toxic insecticides. It is important that IRS is carried out properly and safely and that unwanted exposure or<br /><br />
release does not occur (consider aspects such as training of personnel, subcontracting, prevention of<br /><br />
unauthorized use etc). Also of note is the fact that strategies with a high dependence on chemical<br /><br />
pesticides can be undermined by development of vector resistance, and vector behaviour adaptation<br /><br />
(avoidance) (WHO 2006, PAN 2009). Insecticide resistance is of particular concern in Africa; WHO<br /><br />
recommend a comprehensive assessment of resistance at a local level before planning an IRS<br /><br />
programme (WHO 2006). If such an assessment has been carried out locally, the findings may be of use.<br /><br />
These factors should be taken into consideration when planning a malaria mitigation programme.<br /><br />
Non-insecticide based environmental control techniques are also available. Environmental control<br /><br />
strategies can be regarded in three categories (WHO 1982):<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
manipulation or modification of human habitation or behaviour – e.g. the use of non-pesticidal<br /><br />
personal protection, proofing houses or citing settlements away from major breeding sites;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
environmental modification – permanent or long-lasting measures to prevent, eliminate or reduce<br /><br />
vector habitats; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
environmental manipulation – planned, recurrent activities that reduce the favourability of a habitat<br /><br />
for breeding.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
When planning development projects, these categories can also be viewed from a ‘potential’ rather than<br /><br />
‘existing’ standpoint, i.e. construction can be planned to avoid unnecessary creation of larval habitat. Care<br /><br />
should be taken that mitigation measures are planned and carried out such that there are not excessive<br /><br />
adverse effects on surrounding ecosystems (for example drainage of natural wetlands etc).<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />

<br /><br />
3.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Options for Practical Application of Malaria Control Measures<br /><br />
during Resettlement, Construction and Operation Phases<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Community Resettlement<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Where resettlement of communities is necessary, the following mitigation measures should be taken into<br /><br />
consideration (IFC 2009, WHO 2006):<br /><br />
E duca t io n<br /><br />
Planning sessions for community resettlement should include educational segments for leaders of the<br /><br />
community (including women) on the importance of design and construction of housing with regard to<br /><br />
malaria-protective measures (screened windows and doors) and their proper use.<br /><br />
Co nst ruct ion<br /><br />
When resettlement housing is constructed, malaria-protective measures should be incorporated (if<br /><br />
acceptable to the local community). Boreholes should be designed such that country design requirements<br /><br />
are met, with drainage sufficient to prevent formation of mosquito breeding sites. Insecticidal treatments,<br /><br />
i.e. IRS, for new housing should be considered if appropriate.<br /><br />
L ocat io n<br /><br />
Resettlement housing should located at least 500m from significant anopheles breeding sites. In addition,<br /><br />
communities with low malarial transmission rates should not be placed in or near communities with high<br /><br />
transmission rates.<br /><br />
Co mmunity Sup port<br /><br />
Support of local / regional malarial control programmes e.g. through the provision of insecticide treated<br /><br />
nets at reduced cost to impacted communities. Educate community members on the use of such nets and<br /><br />
other controls e.g. environmental management programmes and community clean-up days.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project Construction Phase<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction creates many opportunities for increased mosquito breeding sites, including creation of pits,<br /><br />
berms and waste piles in which water can pool, or which may affect existing drainage, the rutting of<br /><br />
surfaces by heavy plant and alteration of vegetation patterns. Possible environmental management<br /><br />
techniques for malaria control during construction include (IFC 2009, PAN 2009, WHO 1982, WHO 1984,<br /><br />
WHO 2006):<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Creating adequate drainage;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Filling depressions to prevent pooling of water;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
305000-00006 / WP0205000 : Rev A : 2 June 2010<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Page 5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Covering water tanks and stagnant water;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Due care and planning when re-routing water features (streams, wetlands, rivers, rice plantations<br /><br />
etc);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Vegetation management in construction area to reduce the favourability of breeding habitat for<br /><br />
dominant mosquito species;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Education of workers on the use of personal protection (long sleeve shirts and pants / repellent /<br /><br />
nets for sleeping), provision of suitable clothing where appropriate;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Placement of any worker camps away from mosquito breeding sites (1.5 - 2 km from major<br /><br />
breeding sites);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Good construction of housing and buildings in worker camps (repairing of cracks and holes,<br /><br />
covering eaves where appropriate) installation of screens on windows and doors, and provision of<br /><br />
treated nets for sleeping;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Periodic IRS where appropriate and as per WHO guidance (WHO 2006);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Vegetation clearing around worker camps to reduce favourable breeding or resting sites; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Good housekeeping (e.g. removal of debris that may collect water, vigilance and awareness of<br /><br />
issues, keeping drains clear of refuse and free-flowing, maintenance of all vector control measures<br /><br />
already in place etc).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Operation Phase<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A number of the malaria control techniques were used during construction can be used ‘as is’ or modified<br /><br />
for use during the operation phase of a project; this is especially true in a mine area since there will be<br /><br />
constant remodelling of the landscape. The techniques employed during operation should be sustainable<br /><br />
over the lifetime of the project; some will require maintenance in order to achieve this, and others will be<br /><br />
more permanent. They include (IFC 2009, PAN 2009, WHO 1982, WHO 1984, WHO 2006):<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Creating adequate drainage systems;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Land levelling;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Filling depressions to prevent pooling of water;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Covering water tanks and stagnant water;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Vegetation management in construction area to reduce the favourability of breeding habitat for<br /><br />
dominant mosquito species;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Planting of indigenous water-intensive plants/trees to help dry problem areas (with due care to<br /><br />
avoid biodiversity issues);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Education of workers on the use of personal protection (long sleeve shirts and pants / repellent /<br /><br />
nets for sleeping) to prevent sickness;<br /><br />
<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Placement of any worker camps away from mosquito breeding sites (1.5 - 2 km from major<br /><br />

<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
