<br /><br />
The District Chairman thanked AML for coming. He noted, however, that this<br /><br />
visit was the first time AML have been to his office since they arrived. He<br /><br />
indicated that the District Council have not even opened a file for AML as yet.<br /><br />
He noted that he has tried to visit the site and was turned back at the gate<br /><br />
without being given the chance to meet with the General Manager.<br /><br />
He noted that the Paramount Chiefs reported to him.<br /><br />

He advised that ADDAX had been to visit him as they were aware of his role in<br /><br />

asked for advice on the ethanol project. He emphasized that this was not<br /><br />

He recommended more involvement with the District Council and improved<br /><br />

He made a point of stating that his reports went to ‘State House’ and that the<br /><br />
minutes from District Council meetings were not very complimentary stating that<br /><br />
there was significant ‘disturbance’ amongst local in relation to AML.<br /><br />
4.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
On a positive note the Chief Administrator thanked AML for contributing to the<br /><br />
well being of people in his district noting the educational bursaries that were<br /><br />
provided by AML.<br /><br />
He also commended AML for improving roads in the area.<br /><br />
He stated that the council was meant to provide support to AML and as much as<br /><br />
the district needs AML, AML needs the council as many sectors have been<br /><br />
devolved from central government.<br /><br />
He noted that AML could look at the Tonkolili District website and see in what<br /><br />
areas there could be collaboration.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
On the subject of employment particular emphasis was placed on preferential<br /><br />
treatment for locals indigenous to the area by the Chief Administrator. He<br /><br />
advised AML to ‘strategise’ carefully on the employment issue as it had the<br /><br />
potential to derail company activities.<br /><br />
He claims that complaints are coming in over AML’s employment of people from<br /><br />
Freetown. Local jobs should be for locals and not for people from outside the<br /><br />
area, he reiterated. Furthermore, he stated that it was in AML’s best interest to<br /><br />
employ locals as they were motivated to keep the project going and improve the<br /><br />
area unlike outsiders.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

meeting to officially present the Tonkolili Iron Ore Project. These meetings are<br /><br />
held on the last Wednesday of every month.<br /><br />

7.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Tim Fofana addressed the meeting and stated that it was not AML’s intention to<br /><br />
cause such distress to the Council and its Chairman and would follow up with<br /><br />
his superiors to find out what had happened.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Social Impacts were discussed as a way of gearing members up to participate<br /><br />
actively in ensuring that issues affecting local communities as a result of the<br /><br />
early works were addressed. These included:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Loss of agricultural land<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Loss of economic trees<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Loss of sacred bush<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Relocation of structures<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Loss of social amenities although it was stressed that this would be<br /><br />
dealt with by the larger committee handling the next phase of mining<br /><br />
(magnetite) through a Community Development Plan and the<br /><br />
Resettlement Action Plan.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
It was felt that loss of social cohesion would not be an issue as<br /><br />
settlements would not be moving.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Villages may migrate closer to road once built (safety issue).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Youth felt that employment would be a very positive impactas long as<br /><br />
locals were given jobs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Women would be affected by loss of land reducing their ability to farm<br /><br />
and produce food for their families.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The District Forest Officer stated that measures should be put in place<br /><br />
to address protection of forests.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Part of the EWCC’s role is to ensure that decisions made by the committee are<br /><br />
communicated to people on the ground. This is to be carried out through the<br /><br />
Section Chiefs and the Community Sensitisation Program (CSP).<br /><br />
The CSP would begin with relaying the Project Description to the affected<br /><br />
villages and then carry out regular information sessions through designated<br /><br />
EWCC members to allow for local communities to receive and respond to issues<br /><br />
raised.<br /><br />
Villages will be grouped together to simplify the exercise as follows:<br /><br />
1. Farnagbaya, Wandugu and Furia<br /><br />
2. Basaiya, Kanigba and Balaya<br /><br />
3. Kasikoro and Kapete<br /><br />
th<br /><br />
The first CSP meeting is to be held on 13 March 2010 in Wandugu.<br /><br />

•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
11.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dr Bangura commented that people should take this seriously as they<br /><br />
do not want what happened in Kono to happen in Kafe Simira and the<br /><br />
messages and the results of EWCC deliberations should be<br /><br />
communicated directly to those affected. Mustapha Kamara noted that<br /><br />
this was contained in the Community Sensitisation Program which was<br /><br />
later on in the agenda.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Part of the EWCC’s role is to ensure that decisions made by the committee are<br /><br />
communicated to people on the ground. This is to be carried out through the<br /><br />
Section Chiefs and the Community Sensitisation Program (CSP).<br /><br />
The CSP would begin with relaying the Project Description to the affected<br /><br />
villages and then carry out regular information sessions through designated<br /><br />
EWCC members to allow for local communities to receive and respond to issues<br /><br />
raised.<br /><br />
Villages will be grouped together to simplify the exercise.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
12.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Other points of discussion included:<br /><br />
1. Work carried out by EWCC will be important introduction into modalities<br /><br />
of the larger committee that would be established for the main<br /><br />
magnetite mining phase.<br /><br />
2. Mr Kanu asked whether the work will be carried out mechanically or<br /><br />
manually. Mustapha Kamara replied emphasising that AML first priority<br /><br />
was to employ locals but modern techniques would be used during<br /><br />
construction including heavy machinery. He reassured members that<br /><br />
the contractors in place have been advised that they should maximise<br /><br />
local labour content.<br /><br />
3. The Chairman noted that Mabonto, the Chiefdom headquarters had<br /><br />
problems with communication as there was no phone signal nearby.<br /><br />
Mustapha Kamara noted that as the project is implemented this will<br /><br />
change as a communications tower will be erected nearby.<br /><br />
4. Asked about training for local people Mustapha Kamara explained that a<br /><br />
training program will commence soon.<br /><br />
5. Responding to queries about the number of PRO for Kafe Simira<br /><br />
compared to Kalansongoia, he noted that more PRO’s are being<br /><br />
mobilised.<br /><br />
6. The Chairman noted that the District Council should be given a<br /><br />
familiarisation tour of the project.<br /><br />
7. Dr Bangura noted that AML should increase their presence in the area<br /><br />
and the chiefdom should be given equal representation on the current<br /><br />
community consultation committee as the letter that was sent to them<br /><br />
stating that had fewer places that their neighbours was unacceptable.<br /><br />
Mustapha Kamara responded saying that there was no malice intended<br /><br />
and that the numbers were based on current drilling activities which at<br /><br />
the moment do not affect Kafe Simira. Dr Bangura acknowledged the<br /><br />

<br /><br />

would be undertaken as a last resort. The structure in question must be<br /><br />
assessed in terms of its use, size and construction to determine how to<br /><br />
proceed. Nevertheless house must be replaced prior to removal.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Part of the EWCC’s role is to ensure that decisions made by the committee are<br /><br />
communicated to people on the ground. This is to be carried out through the<br /><br />
Section Chiefs and the Community Sensitisation Program (CSP).<br /><br />

villages and then carry out regular information sessions through designated<br /><br />
EWCC members to allow for local communities to receive and respond to issues<br /><br />
raised.<br /><br />

followed.<br /><br />
2. How would road accidents be dealt with – Tim Fofana noted that this<br /><br />
would be handled in accordance with law. He noted that the road will be<br /><br />
private and is not intended for public vehicles.<br /><br />

through the CSP. They could be scheduled two per day.<br /><br />

Meeting ended with Muslim and Christian prayers followed by lunch.<br /><br />

Minutes of inaugural meeting-Buya Romende<br /><br />
Minutes of the inaugural meeting held for the formation of an Early Works Chiefdom<br /><br />
Committee for Buya Romende.<br /><br />
Location: Kamasundu N.A. Court Barrie<br /><br />
Date: 19th March 2010.<br /><br />
Present: Please see the attached.<br /><br />
The chairing role for the occasion was carried out by Hon.Alhaji Buya Kamara MP<br /><br />
Prayers were recited in both the Muslim and Christian faiths.<br /><br />
The Paramount Chief and Hon.Alhaji Buya Kamara welcomed all the attendees<br /><br />
especially the AML personnel.<br /><br />
Brief introduction of each person on the high table was individually done.<br /><br />
Mustapha Kamara told the attendees that the main purpose of the meeting was to have a<br /><br />
committee formed that represents the interest of all stakeholders to be affected by the<br /><br />
construction of a major haul road being undertaken by AML.<br /><br />
He talked about the following:<br /><br />
¾ AML’s previous activities at the Tonkolili Project Site which yielded the<br /><br />
discovery of some huge amount of iron ore deposit of magnetite that is covered by<br /><br />
oxidized haematite.<br /><br />
¾ The company’s intentions to mine,treat and haul the haematite for export on a<br /><br />
road that will pass through Buya Romende chiefdom to end up at the old Delco<br /><br />
rail line at Rolethe.<br /><br />
¾ Due to the scale of the engineering works to be undertaken in the construction of<br /><br />
this haul road across the chiefdom, many side effects are sure to emerge. He cited<br /><br />
the inevitable loss of some agricultural land e.g. swamps etc. He said every effort<br /><br />
is being made to eliminate or minimize inconveniences to the communities<br /><br />
affected. Bridges, underpasses etc will be built so as to maintain continuity of<br /><br />
road links and services between villages/towns.<br /><br />
¾ Many other issues affecting the communities may come up during and after the<br /><br />
construction of the haul road. The physical dimensions of the road’s width and the<br /><br />
length of the Land Train that will ply the route were indicated outside the court<br /><br />
barrie. (diagrammatic pics. of the Land Train and map showing the road thro’ the<br /><br />
chiefdom were distributed.)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
¾ The need to inform people about the haul road and to address adequately and<br /><br />
promptly any and all problems facing the communities could best be done by a<br /><br />
committee comprising of the Paramount Chief, Section Chiefs of the affected<br /><br />
sections, Political leaders, representation from the Youths, Women and some<br /><br />
actively-based non-Governmental organization or Community-based<br /><br />
Organization plus the line Ministries e.g. Agriculture, Mineral Resources, EPA<br /><br />
etc.<br /><br />
¾ The sheets containing the Terms of Reference for the committee were handed out<br /><br />
and discussed. It was unanimously agreed that the composition of the committee<br /><br />
and its terms of reference are adequate and satisfactory.<br /><br />
Meetings are scheduled to be held once a month. The Councillors and Section Chiefs are<br /><br />
to immediately start sensitizing communities in their respective wards. Mustapha Kamara<br /><br />
apologized to the chiefdom authorities for a complaint that some road contractor started<br /><br />
his work even before AML informed the chiefdom about the project.<br /><br />
The date for the next meeting is to be advised.<br /><br />
The meeting ended with prayers.<br /><br />

APPENDIX 20<br /><br />
The Resettlement Policy Framework<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
THE RESETTLEMENT POLICY FRAMEWORK<br /><br />
The Resettlement Policy Framework (RPF) outlined in this report provides<br /><br />
guidelines for the compensation of those who will be affected by physical and/or<br /><br />
economic displacement. In line with IFC Performance Standard 5, it aims to:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Clarify the legal requirements and principles for compensation for loss of<br /><br />
property, livelihood and relocation or resettlement (of directly affected<br /><br />
people) in order to ensure that project affected people (PAP) will not be<br /><br />
negatively affected by resettlement or economic displacement.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Describe the social context in which the resettlement will take place.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identify affected parties.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Define the actions and tasks that need to be undertaken to plan the<br /><br />
resettlement programme.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Define the roles and responsibilities necessary to develop a full RAP.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Describe the arrangements for funding resettlement and compensation as well<br /><br />
as a timeline for activities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
These objectives are addressed in the following sections.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
LEGISLATIVE OVERVIEW<br /><br />
In the sections below both Sierra Leone legislation and international best practice<br /><br />
for resettlement and compensation are discussed.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Sierra Leone Legislation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.1.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Mines and Minerals Bill<br /><br />
Occupation of Land, Resettlement and Compensation<br /><br />
The Mines and Minerals Bill, August 2009 outlines the legislation in terms of<br /><br />
occupation of land, resettlement and compensation. The relevant sections are<br /><br />
outlined below:<br /><br />
Section 32<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The holder of a mineral right shall not exercise any of his rights, under the<br /><br />
mineral right- except with the written consent of the owner or lawful occupier<br /><br />
or his duly authorised agent, in respect of:<br /><br />
(i)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
any land dedicated as a place of burial or which is a place of religious<br /><br />
or other cultural significance;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(ii)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
any land which is the site of, or which is within two hundred metres or<br /><br />
such greater distance as may be prescribed, of any inhabited, occupied<br /><br />
or temporarily unoccupied house or building;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(iii)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
any land which is within fifty metres or such greater distance as may be<br /><br />
prescribed, of land which has been cleared or ploughed or otherwise<br /><br />
bona fide prepared for the growing of, or upon which there are growing<br /><br />
agricultural crops;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(iv)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
any land which is the site of, or within one hundred metres or such<br /><br />
greater distance as may be prescribed, of any cattle dip, tank, dam, or<br /><br />
other body of water,<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(v)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
in respect of any land within any township, or within two hundred<br /><br />
metres or such greater distance as may be prescribed, of the boundaries<br /><br />
of any township, except with the written consent of the local authority<br /><br />
having control over the township.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Section 33<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The owner or lawful occupier of any land which within an area that is the<br /><br />
subject of a mineral right shall retain the right to graze stock upon or to<br /><br />
cultivate the surface of such land in so far as such grazing or cultivation does<br /><br />
not interfere with the proper use of such area for reconnaissance, exploration,<br /><br />
or mining operations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(3)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The rights conferred by a mineral right shall be exercised reasonably and so<br /><br />
as to affect as little as possible the interests of any owner or lawful occupier<br /><br />
of the land on which such rights are exercised consistent with the reasonable<br /><br />
and proper conduct of the operations concerned.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Section 34<br /><br />
Subject to the provisions of any law relating to the acquisition of land titles1 and<br /><br />
Section 38, the holder of a large-scale mining license shall obtain a land lease or<br /><br />
other rights to use the land upon such terms as to the rents to be paid for the license,<br /><br />
the duration or the extent or area of the land to which such license shall relate, as<br /><br />
may be agreed between such holder and such owner or lawful user of the land or<br /><br />
failing that, such agreement as may be determined by the Minister on the advice of<br /><br />
the Minerals Advisory Board.<br /><br />
Section 35<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The holder of a mineral right shall on demand being made by the owner or<br /><br />
lawful occupier of any land subject to such rights pay such owner or lawful<br /><br />
occupier fair and reasonable compensation for any disturbance of the rights of<br /><br />
such owner or occupier and for any damage done to the surface of the land by<br /><br />
his operations and shall on demand being made by the owner of any crops,<br /><br />
trees, buildings or works damaged during the course of such operations pay<br /><br />
compensation for such damage subject to the following-<br /><br />
<br /><br />
See below: Provinces Land Act, Chapter 122 of the Laws of Sierra Leone, 1960. Section 4.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(a)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
subject to section 38, payment of rent under the provisions of section<br /><br />
34 shall be deemed to be adequate compensation for deprivation of the<br /><br />
use of land to which such rent relates;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(b)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
in assessing compensation payable under this section, account shall be<br /><br />
taken of any improvement effected by the holder of the mineral right or<br /><br />
by his predecessor in title the benefit of which has or will inure to the<br /><br />
owner or lawful occupier;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(c)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the basis upon which compensation shall be payable for damage to the<br /><br />
surface of any land shall be the extent to which the market value of the<br /><br />
land (for which purpose it shall be deemed saleable) upon which the<br /><br />
damage has occurred has been reduced by reason of such damage, but<br /><br />
without taking into account any enhanced value due to the presence of<br /><br />
minerals;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(d)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
no compensation shall be payable to the occupier of a state grant of<br /><br />
land in respect of any operations under a mineral right existing at the<br /><br />
date of such grant; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(e)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
no demand made in terms of this subsection shall entitle the owner or<br /><br />
lawful occupier to prevent or hinder the exercise by the holder of a<br /><br />
mineral right of his rights there under pending the determination of<br /><br />
compensation to be paid.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(2)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
If the holder of a mineral right fails to pay compensation when so demanded<br /><br />
under the provisions of this section, or if the owner or lawful occupier of any<br /><br />
land is dissatisfied with any compensation offered, such compensation may<br /><br />
be determined by the Minister on the advice of the Mineral Advisory Board.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(3)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A claim for compensation under the provisions of subsection (1) shall be<br /><br />
made within a period of two years from the date when the compensation<br /><br />
became due failing which, notwithstanding the provisions of any other<br /><br />
enactment, such claim shall not be enforceable.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Section 36<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Government may, by order published in the Gazette, compulsorily<br /><br />
acquire in the name of the Republic private land or rights over or under<br /><br />
private land for use by the holder of a large scale mining licence.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(2)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Before making an order under subsection (1) the Government shall be<br /><br />
satisfied that;<br /><br />
(a)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the holder of a large-scale mining licence has taken all reasonable steps<br /><br />
to acquire on reasonable terms by agreement with the owner, the land<br /><br />
which he wishes to use or the right which he wishes to exercise and has<br /><br />
been unable to do so; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(b)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the acquisition of such land or right is necessary for mining purposes or<br /><br />
for purposes ancillary to mining.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Section 37<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Subject to Section 38, when land is acquired compulsorily pursuant to Section<br /><br />
36, those persons having an interest in or rights over the land concerned shall<br /><br />
be paid adequate compensation by the holder of the mineral right determined<br /><br />
on the same basis as compensation for disturbance of rights pursuant to<br /><br />
Section 35.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(2)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The holder of a large-scale mining licence shall, before entering into<br /><br />
possession for enjoyment of any land or before exercising any right over the<br /><br />
land, make payment of compensation as determined in accordance with<br /><br />
subsection (1) to the person or persons concerned or if the whereabouts of the<br /><br />
person or persons concerned or any of them are unknown, give such<br /><br />
undertakings concerning the payment of compensation as the Government<br /><br />
may require.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Section 38<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Minister shall ensure that all owners or lawful occupiers of land who<br /><br />
prefer to be compensated by way of resettlement as a result of being displaced<br /><br />
by a proposed mining operation are resettled on suitable alternate land, with<br /><br />
due regard to their economic well-being and social and cultural value so that<br /><br />
their circumstances are similar to or improved when compared to their<br /><br />
circumstances before resettlement, and the resettlement is carried out in<br /><br />
accordance with the relevant planning laws.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(2)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The cost of resettlement shall be borne by the holder of the mineral right,<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(3)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(a)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
as agreed by the holder and the owner or lawful occupier of land or by<br /><br />
separate agreement with the Minister, or<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(b)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
in accordance with a determination by the Minister, except that where<br /><br />
the holder elects to delay or abandon the proposed mining operation<br /><br />
which will necessitate resettlement, the obligation to bear the cost of<br /><br />
resettlement shall only arise upon the holder actually proceeding with<br /><br />
the mining operation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Subject to this section, the Minister and a person authorised by the Minister<br /><br />
may take the necessary action to give effect to a resettlement agreement or<br /><br />
determination.<br /><br />

2.1.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Artisanal Mining<br /><br />
Section 30<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Where the Minister considers that it is in the public interest to encourage<br /><br />
exploration and mining of minerals in any area by methods not involving<br /><br />
substantial expenditure or the use of specialised technology, he may by notice<br /><br />
in the Gazette, declare that area for licensing of artisanal or small-scale<br /><br />
mining operations and the provisions of Part X and Part XI shall apply.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
PART X: Artisanal mining licences<br /><br />
Section 84<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Any person/partnership (Sierra Leone citizen) who wishes to carry out<br /><br />
artisanal mining operations shall apply for an artisanal mining licence.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(3)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
All such partnerships shall register with the Director and shall provide such<br /><br />
documentation as the Director may require.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Section 87<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
No person other than the holder of an exploration licence shall be granted an<br /><br />
artisanal mining licence in respect of land which constitutes the exploration<br /><br />
licence area or part of the exploration licence area, except with the consent of<br /><br />
the exploration licence holder.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(2)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
No artisanal mining licence shall be granted to an applicant in an area<br /><br />
designated under Section 30 for small-scale mining operations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Section 88<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(2)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
An artisanal mining licence in the prescribed form shall<br /><br />
(a)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
state the period for which it is granted;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(b)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
include a description and plan of the area of land over which it is<br /><br />
granted; and<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(c)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
state the conditions on which it is granted.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
There shall be appended to an artisanal mining licence a certified copy of the<br /><br />
agreement between the applicant and the Chiefdom Mining Allocation<br /><br />
Committee or the rightful occupiers or owners of the land over which the<br /><br />
artisanal mining licence is granted which shall form part of the terms and<br /><br />
conditions of the artisanal mining licence.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Section 89<br /><br />
An artisanal mining licence area shall not be more than one half hectare.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Section 90<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Subject to subsection (2), an artisanal mining licence shall be valid for a<br /><br />

exceeding one year at a time.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

An artisanal mining licence shall not be renewed pursuant to subsection (1)(a)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
if the artisanal mining licence area has ceased to be an area declared for<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Section 91<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.1.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Subject to the provisions of this Act or any other law and any condition of an<br /><br />
artisanal mining licence, the holder of an artisanal licence shall have the<br /><br />
exclusive right to carry on exploration and mining operations in the licensed<br /><br />
area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Land Acquisition Law<br /><br />
The leasing of land is dealt with in the Provinces Land Act, Chapter 122 of the<br /><br />
Laws of Sierra Leone, 1960. Section 4 of the Act states: a non-native cannot acquire<br /><br />
a greater interest in land in the provinces than a lease for a period of fifty years. A<br /><br />
clause can however be inserted in a lease, which provides for renewals of such a<br /><br />
lease for terms each not exceeding twenty-one years.<br /><br />
A lease is defined in the Act as “a grant of the possession of land by the tribal<br /><br />
authority (now known as the ‘Chiefdom Council’), as lessor, to a non-native, as<br /><br />
lessee, for a term of years or other fixed period with a reservation of a rent”. The<br /><br />
initial lease cannot be for a period exceeding 50 years; it can then subsequently be<br /><br />
renewed for periods of up to 21 years. The lease agreement is required to state (a)<br /><br />
the rent (b) the term of years (c) the purpose for which the land is to be used (d)<br /><br />
whether the interest is assignable, (e) whether buildings of permanent structures are<br /><br />
to be erected and the rights of the parties on the expiration/determination of the<br /><br />
lease (f) that the rent is subject to review every seven years by the District<br /><br />
Officer/Chief Administration office when the term of years exceeds seven years.<br /><br />
The Act makes no express reference to land owners; therefore a lease under the Act<br /><br />
must be made between the chiefdom council and the non-native The Lease requires<br /><br />
the rent to be split in accordance with the traditional approach of one-third being<br /><br />
retained by the Chief Administrative Officer, one-third being paid to the Chiefdom<br /><br />
Council and one-third being paid and to be shared between the traditional<br /><br />
landowners on the Leased Area. Land lease agreements between AML and the<br /><br />
affected chiefdoms are currently being put place in accordance with the land<br /><br />
acquisition law.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
International Guidelines<br /><br />
<br /><br />
World Bank Operational Policy 4.122 (World Bank, 2004) is regarded<br /><br />
internationally as the standard resettlement guidance. The objective of resettlement<br /><br />
planning is to avoid resettlement whenever feasible, and when resettlement is<br /><br />
unavoidable, to minimise its extent and to explore all viable alternatives. IFC<br /><br />
Performance Standard 3: Land Acquisition and Involuntary Resettlement (IFC,<br /><br />
2006) was developed by the IFC (as part of the World Bank group) from OP 4.12<br /><br />
and provides internationally accepted policies and guidelines for resettlement.<br /><br />
Performance Standard 5 states:<br /><br />
“Where involuntary resettlement is unavoidable, the client will carry out a census<br /><br />
with appropriate socio-economic baseline data to identify the persons who will be<br /><br />
displaced by the project, to determine who will be eligible for compensation and<br /><br />
assistance, to make an inventory of landholdings and immovable/non-retrievable<br /><br />
improvements and to discourage inflow of people who are ineligible for these<br /><br />
benefits. In the absence of host government procedures, the client will establish a<br /><br />
cut-off date for eligibility. Information regarding the cut-off date will be well<br /><br />
documented and disseminated throughout the project area.”<br /><br />
The standard states the following basic principles in terms of resettlement:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2<br /><br />
3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Avoid or at least minimise involuntary resettlement wherever feasible by<br /><br />
exploring alternative project designs;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mitigate adverse social and economic impacts from land acquisition or<br /><br />
restrictions on affected persons’ use of land by:<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
Providing compensation for loss of assets at replacement cost; and<br /><br />
ensuring that resettlement activities are implemented with appropriate<br /><br />
disclosure of information, consultation, and the informed participation<br /><br />
of those affected.<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
Improving or at least restoring the livelihoods and standards of living<br /><br />
of displaced persons.<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
Improving living conditions among displaced persons through<br /><br />
provision of adequate housing with security of tenure at resettlement<br /><br />
sites.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Prepare a RAP and have it accepted by the relevant authorities prior to<br /><br />
implementing resettlement activities. The RPF is a stepping stone towards the<br /><br />
RAP once the project impacts are more clearly defined.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(www.worldbank.org) and in the World Bank's Resettlement and Rehabilitation Guidebook.<br /><br />
The IFC (www.ifc.org) Handbook for Preparing a Resettlement Action Plan.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ensure provision of compensation and the restoration of livelihoods of those<br /><br />
affected prior to any actual resettlement. In particular, the policy requires that<br /><br />
possession of land for project activities may take place only after<br /><br />
compensation has been paid, or alternatively, if adequate guarantees of<br /><br />
compensation have been made to the PAP’s satisfaction. If the latter is<br /><br />
chosen, compensation payments must not be delayed once resettlement has<br /><br />
taken place. Resettlement sites, new homes and related infrastructure, public<br /><br />
services and moving allowances must be provided to the affected persons in<br /><br />
accordance with the provisions of the RAP.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Pay particular attention to the needs of vulnerable groups. These are generally<br /><br />
defined as those below the poverty line, the landless, the elderly, women and<br /><br />
children, indigenous groups, ethnic minorities, orphans, disabled people and<br /><br />
other disadvantaged persons.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

Standards<br /><br />

the most stringent requirements of each. The comparison between both sets of<br /><br />
guidelines is presented in Table 2-1 below.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
SOCIO-ECONOMIC PROFILE OF THE AFFECTED<br /><br />
AREAS<br /><br />
To effectively execute the resettlement process, the social context in which the<br /><br />
resettlement will need to take place needs to be understood. This is described below.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
National context<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.1.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Introduction<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Republic of Sierra Leone, which covers an area of 71,740 km2, is located in<br /><br />
West Africa, bordered by Guinea in the northeast, Liberia in the east, and the<br /><br />
Atlantic Ocean in the southwest. Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone, is located<br /><br />
on the coast4.<br /><br />
3.1.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
History5<br /><br />
Early inhabitants of Sierra Leone include the Sherbro, Temne, Limba, and Tyra<br /><br />
peoples. Later, the Mende and the Kono arrived and settled in the east of the<br /><br />
country. In 1462, the Portuguese explorer Pedro da Cintra gave the country its<br /><br />
name Serra de Leão, meaning Lion Mountains.<br /><br />
Sierra Leone became an important centre of the transatlantic slave trade until 1792,<br /><br />
when Freetown was founded by the Sierra Leone Company as a home for formerly<br /><br />
enslaved African Americans who had been promised their freedom for joining the<br /><br />
British Army during the American Revolution. Thousands of formerly enslaved<br /><br />
Africans, mainly from the West coast of the USA, were returned to or liberated in<br /><br />
Freetown.<br /><br />
In 1808, Freetown became a British Crown Colony, and in 1896, the interior of the<br /><br />
country became a British Protectorate. During colonisation indigenous people<br /><br />
mounted several unsuccessful revolts against British rule. The most notable was the<br /><br />
Hut Tax war of 1898. Its first leader was Bai Bureh, a Temne chief who refused to<br /><br />
recognise the British-imposed tax on huts (dwellings).<br /><br />
In 1961, Sierra Leone gained independence and the Sierra Leone People's Party<br /><br />
(SLPP) won by large margins in the nation's first general election under universal<br /><br />
adult suffrage in May 1962. Turbulent political years followed with several<br /><br />
uprisings and coups, culminating in the development of a one party state.<br /><br />
Government corruption, neglect of the interior, mismanagement of diamond<br /><br />
resources and the spilling over of the Liberian conflict into its borders eventually led<br /><br />
to the Sierra Leone civil war, which began in 1991 and was resolved in 2001 after<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4<br /><br />
5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Information acquired from Wikipedia on 2 April 2010.<br /><br />
Information acquired from Wikipedia on 2 April 2010.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the United Nations led by Nigeria defeated the rebel forces. The war claimed an<br /><br />
estimated 20,000 lives and over 2 million people were displaced from their homes.<br /><br />
In December 2005, UN peacekeeping forces pulled out of Sierra Leone and in<br /><br />
August 2007, presidential and parliamentary elections were held. Ernest Bai<br /><br />
Koroma was elected president.<br /><br />
3.1.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Demographics6<br /><br />
Sierra Leone's population is 6,440,053 with a population growth rate of 2.3%. Forty<br /><br />
four percent of the population is under the age of 14. There are 16 ethnic groups,<br /><br />
each with their own language and culture. The two largest groups are the Mende and<br /><br />
the Temne, each comprises 30% of the population. The Mende predominate in the<br /><br />
South-Eastern Provinces; the Temne in the Northern Province. Other groups include<br /><br />
the Limba, the Kono, the Mandingo and the Krio (descendants of freed West<br /><br />
Indians slaves from the West Indies and freed African American slaves from the<br /><br />
United States). Three religions prevail in Sierra Leone. The majority (60%) are<br /><br />
Muslim, 30% are Christian and the remaining 10% consist of indigenous religions.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.1.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Living Standards7<br /><br />
The UNDP Global Human Development Report (2007) ranked Sierra Leone at the<br /><br />
bottom of 177 countries in terms of general development. About 70% of the<br /><br />
population lives below the national poverty line. Poverty is most prevalent in the<br /><br />
rural areas and amongst the youth (males and females between 15 and 35). Youth<br /><br />
are increasingly leaving agriculture to find economically more rewarding<br /><br />
occupations, often failing to find secure employment or gainful economic activities.<br /><br />
During the war 57% of the population lived on less than US$1 a day.<br /><br />
Sierra Leone’s Poverty Reduction Strategy paper of 2005 outlined its commitment<br /><br />
to poverty alleviation. However, youth unemployment / underemployed remains<br /><br />
high at 70% and food security constitutes a major challenge constrained by lack of<br /><br />
access to markets and poor rural infrastructure. The country is heavily dependent on<br /><br />
Official Development Assistance (ODA), with about 50% of public investment<br /><br />
programmes financed by external resources.<br /><br />
The poor national infrastructure and the small size of the private sector are<br /><br />
significant impediments to the achievement of the higher and more equitable growth<br /><br />
required to effectively address poverty and unemployment.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6<br /><br />
7<br /><br />
<br /><br />
CIA World book.<br /><br />
Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.1.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Economy8<br /><br />
The economy of Sierra Leone has suffered greatly as a result of the civil war.<br /><br />
During the war, economic growth plunged to -4.5% per annum. However Sierra<br /><br />
Leone experienced a robust post-war recovery. In the aftermath of the civil war<br /><br />
(1992-2001) it sustained one of the highest GDP growth rates (an average of 7%) in<br /><br />
Africa. Reconstruction, a substantial increase in aid flows and improved structural<br /><br />
and macroeconomic policies contributed to this rapid growth. Large mineral<br /><br />
deposits enabled strong export growth. Sierra Leone‘s strong recovery continued<br /><br />
into 2008 when real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) grew by an estimated 5.5%<br /><br />
despite rising food and fuel prices.<br /><br />
However, economic recovery has slowed down along with the global economic<br /><br />
downturn. In 2009, the IMF forecasts that real GDP growth is expected to drop to<br /><br />
4.5% as global recession reduces the demand for Sierra Leone‘s mineral exports and<br /><br />
the rate of post-war recovery declines. Given the breadth of the current economic<br /><br />
crisis, and the potentially damaging effect of falling commodity prices, identifying<br /><br />
and remedying investment climate problems is essential. Investment climate reforms<br /><br />
would increase the ability of the economy to adapt to economic shocks more easily.<br /><br />
The goal of sustaining rapid and inclusive growth is made more challenging because<br /><br />
so much of Sierra Leone’s growth has been dependent on the exploitation of natural<br /><br />
resources, such as diamonds, rutile and bauxite. Yet most mining is capital<br /><br />
intensive, and although it contributes more than 19% of GDP, it employs less than<br /><br />
3% of the formal sector population (although closer to 7% of the total population).<br /><br />
In contrast, the agriculture sector (including fisheries) employs more than 60% of<br /><br />
the population while providing 44% of GDP, with both the share of employment<br /><br />
and GDP declining every year. The manufacturing sector has been weak, due to<br /><br />
supply side constraints and competition from cheaper imports.<br /><br />
Economic diversification and more inclusive growth patterns will be critical to<br /><br />
sustain high growth. A recently completed private sector development diagnostic<br /><br />
report noted the critical need to develop a culture of entrepreneurship, as Sierra<br /><br />
Leone is weaker than many of its West African peers in the rate of new business<br /><br />
entry. It also identified fisheries, segments of agriculture and tourism as potentially<br /><br />
strong sources of private sector growth.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.1.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Health<br /><br />
The state of health of Sierra Leone’s population is generally poor. The infant<br /><br />
mortality rate is 165 deaths per 1,000 live births9 and life expectancy is 42.1 years10.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Based on World Bank. (2009). Sierra Leone Country Brief. March.2009, Economist Intelligence Unit (2009).<br /><br />

January 2009. IMF Country Report No. 09/12.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
9<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Approximately 47% of the population do not have access to clean water and 50% is<br /><br />
undernourished.<br /><br />
Malaria and waterborne diseases are the main health threats. An MSF11 study in<br /><br />
2005 showed that 63% of deaths in children were caused by malaria. The estimate<br /><br />
of HIV/ AIDS prevalence in 2007 was 1.7%12.There are, however great disparities<br /><br />
in the prevalence among different segments of the population. In particularly the<br /><br />
uniformed service personnel and commercial sex workers have higher prevalence<br /><br />
rates, estimated at 10%13.<br /><br />
The social costs of the protracted civil war in Sierra Leone have been extremely<br /><br />
high14. About 75% of the country’s health care facilities, including 15 hospitals and<br /><br />
150 primary health care centres, were not functional during that period. Due to<br /><br />
insufficient financial resources, health care facilities have not been adequately<br /><br />
restored. Faced with the shortfall of subsidies from government and international<br /><br />
sources, most public health structures apply a de facto system of cost recovery,<br /><br />
requiring patients to pay for most services15. Since a large section of the population<br /><br />
cannot afford health services the use of the non-official health sector16 is very high.<br /><br />
3.1.7<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Education<br /><br />
In Sierra Leone primary (6 years) and junior secondary (3 years) school level<br /><br />
education is compulsory and free for all children. However a shortage of schools<br /><br />
and teachers has made implementation of this legal requirement impossible. The<br /><br />
civil war resulted in the destruction of 1,270 primary schools and in 2001, 67% of<br /><br />
all school-age children were out of school.<br /><br />
The situation has improved considerably since then with primary school enrolment<br /><br />
doubling between 2001 and 2005, and the reconstruction of many schools since the<br /><br />
end of the war. However, the educational system is still grappling with myriad<br /><br />
problems. Many rural primary schools do not have trained and qualified teachers.<br /><br />
The Government’s recent drive to encourage children to go to school has also<br /><br />
created the unintended effect of overcrowding, even in urban areas.<br /><br />
The country has two universities, whilst teacher training colleges and religious<br /><br />
seminaries are found in many parts of the country. These higher learning institutions<br /><br />
also face considerable resource constraints, leading to shortages of essential<br /><br />
personnel for science and technology teaching, applied agricultural research and<br /><br />
extension and health care.<br /><br />
<br /><br />

The literacy rate in Sierra Leone is low (35.1%, 2004 est.) with a large discrepancy<br /><br />

<br /><br />
3.1.8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Gender<br /><br />
As in many sub-Saharan countries, women are marginalised in terms of economic<br /><br />
and political power. Although women in Sierra Leone carry out the majority of<br /><br />
agricultural work, they have limited control over the economic resources they<br /><br />
generate. Women are dependent on male family members, or the discretion of<br /><br />
community leaders for access to land.<br /><br />
Discrimination against women in Sierra Leone has been exacerbated by the civil<br /><br />
war, when women were submitted to displacement, insecurity and the breakdown of<br /><br />
social services and support. Women and girls fulfilled a variety of functions during<br /><br />
the war, including sex slaves and combatants. Many women were sole<br /><br />
breadwinners, lacking the traditional family networks. Many women were subjected<br /><br />
to extensive sexual violence throughout the period of war.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Regional Context<br /><br />
The Republic of Sierra Leone is composed of three provinces: the Northern<br /><br />
Province, Southern province and the Eastern province and one other region called<br /><br />
the Western Area. The provinces are further subdivided into 12 districts. District<br /><br />
councils were established in 2000 and local government elections held for the first<br /><br />
time in May 2004. The elected councils constitute representative bodies with<br /><br />
<br /><br />
delegated powers and funds to execute local governance. The district administration<br /><br />
is made up of a senior district officer and officers representing various line<br /><br />
ministries. The Ministry of Local Government and Rural Development coordinates<br /><br />
the district officers. The district administration is responsible for the overall<br /><br />
management of the districts, including provision of critical social services to the<br /><br />
population.<br /><br />
The proposed development site and its transport infrastructure are situated in the<br /><br />
Northern Province and cover the Districts of Tonkolili, Bombali and Port Loko (see<br /><br />
Figure 3-1). The sections below provide a short description of these districts.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Figure 3-1: Sierra Leone Districts<br /><br />
3.2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Tonkolili District<br /><br />
Tonkolili District covers 7,003 km2 and comprises 11 chiefdoms. It has a population<br /><br />
of 345,884 (2004 census). The District capital is Magburaka town, with Mile 91<br /><br />
being the commercial centre. The main ethnic groups are the Temne, Limba and<br /><br />
Kuranko. Islam is the dominant religion.<br /><br />
Agriculture remains the largest sector of the economy, providing a livelihood for up<br /><br />
to 75% of the population. However, yields are typically low for the overall food<br /><br />
production (maize, cassava and sweet potatoes). Gold mining is another important<br /><br />
<br /><br />
activity in the District. The livestock sector remains relatively small and<br /><br />
underdeveloped.<br /><br />
Tonkolili District has several industries:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Magbass sugar complex, which produces sugar and ethanol and provides<br /><br />
substantial employment in the area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Gari factory at Robinke, which provides a market for cassava and<br /><br />
employment for people, especially women.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A large scale sugar cane plantation (Addax Biofuel Project), which is in the<br /><br />
process of development.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Other small-scale industries such as tailoring, carpentry, weaving,<br /><br />
blacksmithing, gara tie-dye and soap making.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
There was a market structure in each chiefdom’s main town, but most of these were<br /><br />
destroyed during the civil war. The growing need for locally produced and<br /><br />
manufactured goods has resulted in the emergence of weekly markets commonly<br /><br />
called ‘Loumas’.<br /><br />
Infrastructure and standards of living are low in the District. Life expectancy at birth<br /><br />
is 47.9 years, and infant mortality rates are 118 per 1,000 at birth (although low,<br /><br />
both figures are better than the national standard). The percentage of people without<br /><br />
safe water is 71.1%, (higher than the national average) with 60% using the river as<br /><br />
their water source and only 8.5% having access to running water. The main source<br /><br />
of fuel for cooking is wood (96.2% of the population) and the energy source for<br /><br />
lighting is almost exclusively kerosene and torches. The literacy rate is lower than<br /><br />
the national average at 30.5%.<br /><br />
3.2.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Bombali District<br /><br />
Bombali District17 covers an area of 8,279 km2 and comprises 14 chiefdoms. It has a<br /><br />
population of 494,048 and the main ethnic groups are the Temne, the Loko and the<br /><br />
Limba. The majority of the population are Muslim, with a small percentage<br /><br />
adhering to Christianity and animism18. The main economic activities include small<br /><br />
scale production of food crops (rice, cassava and sweet potatoes), production of<br /><br />
charcoal, small scale mining, and small ruminants. The potential for large scale<br /><br />
farming is significant, but is hampered by several limitations such lack of<br /><br />
mechanisation, inputs and access to markets and poor infrastructure. The Addax<br /><br />
Biofuel Project, involving a large scale sugar cane plantation, is currently under<br /><br />
development.<br /><br />
Makeni, with a population of 82,840 (2004 estimate, probably an underestimate) is<br /><br />
the administrative and commercial centre of the District and the Northern Province<br /><br />
as a whole. It also provides educational and health facilities for the area. It grew as a<br /><br />
<br /><br />
17<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs) in Bombali District.<br /><br />
The attribution of a living soul to plants, inanimate objects and natural phenomena. The belief in a supernatural<br /><br />
power that organises and animates the material universe.<br /><br />
18<br /><br />
<br /><br />
trade and collecting centre among the Temne people. Palm oil, kernels and rice<br /><br />
collected in Makeni were and still are transported by road to Freetown. The town is<br /><br />
known for Gara tie-dyeing, which is an important industrial activity for Makeni<br /><br />
women. The town is lacking in basic facilities such as water, sewerage system,<br /><br />
electricity and a good road network<br /><br />
Bombali District was principally a rebel stronghold during the recent ten year civil<br /><br />
war and experienced considerable destruction, displacement and trauma. Atrocities<br /><br />
including forceful conscription of children, sexual abuse and prostitution were rife,<br /><br />
which had an important effect on the youth, in particular girls. This situation<br /><br />
exacerbated the incidence and prevalence of HIV/AIDS, which has added to the<br /><br />
growing public health burden in the district.<br /><br />
During the war, socio-economic activities and social service delivery was seriously<br /><br />
disrupted, and the enforcement of law and recognition of the authority of traditional<br /><br />
leaders strongly compromised. Since the end of the war, security has largely been<br /><br />
restored, but the local economy, social infrastructure and services have not<br /><br />
adequately recovered. During the period of the study, however, several signs of<br /><br />
development were witnessed in Makeni town: banks were established, several small<br /><br />
businesses opened and a new hospital was built.<br /><br />
Standards of living are low in the District. However, a life expectancy of 52.5 and<br /><br />
infant mortality rates of 96 per 1,000 live births are both better than the national<br /><br />
standard19. The percentage of people without safe water is 57 (which is higher than<br /><br />
the national average), with 40% using the river as their water source and only 25%<br /><br />
having access to running water. The main source for cooking is wood (95% of the<br /><br />
population) and the energy source for lighting is almost exclusively kerosene or<br /><br />
torch.<br /><br />
The District has 437 primary school and 31 junior secondary schools. The majority<br /><br />
of teachers in the primary schools are unqualified and the teacher pupil ratio is 54 to<br /><br />
1. The conscription of children as freedom fighters also led to a drastic reduction in<br /><br />
school-going children, hence a high illiteracy rate of 65%. Nevertheless, post-war<br /><br />
sensitisation and motivation has begun to increase enrolment.<br /><br />
3.2.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Port Loko District<br /><br />
Port Loko District covers an area of 5,943 km2 and is, with a population of 477,978,<br /><br />
the most populous district in the Northern Province. The main ethnic group are the<br /><br />
Temne (80%). The second largest group are the Fula and the Susu. The district is<br /><br />
largely Muslim (75%).<br /><br />
The main economic activities are small scale diamond mining, subsistence farming<br /><br />
(rice, cassava, millet, groundnut, maize and sweet potato in particular, small<br /><br />
commerce) and small scale fishing. The production of charcoal has become a<br /><br />
<br /><br />
19<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Sierra Leone encyclopediahttp://www.daco-sl.org/encyclopedia/3_dist/3_1j_pl.htm<br /><br />
<br /><br />
relatively important economic activity since the civil war, when farming activities<br /><br />
were disrupted.<br /><br />
Its capital is Port Loko and the largest city is Lunsar (16,567, 2004 estimate). Other<br /><br />
major towns in the district include the coastal town of Lungi (host to the Lungi<br /><br />
International Airport) and Kupr20.<br /><br />
Life expectancy is 49 and infant mortality 112 per 1000 live births. Only 1.6% of<br /><br />
the population uses pit latrines21.<br /><br />
The District has 469 primary schools (mainly in a bad state of repair) and 24 junior<br /><br />
secondary schools. Less than half of the teachers are qualified.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Administrative and Authority Structures<br /><br />
Districts in Sierra Leone are subdivided into chiefdoms, which are headed by<br /><br />
paramount chiefs, who are elected for life by chiefdom councillors, who in turn are<br /><br />
elected by the residents of the chiefdom. The paramount chief is responsible for<br /><br />
general administration, the distribution of land, collection of land taxes, the<br /><br />
maintenance of law and order (settlement of disputes) and the development of his<br /><br />
chiefdom. He also inherits custodian rights over land within his chiefdom. The<br /><br />
paramount chief works with a chiefdom committee, council of elders and the Native<br /><br />
Administration.<br /><br />
The chiefdom is subdivided into sections comprising a number of villages. Sections<br /><br />
are headed by a section chief and villages by a town chief. The chiefdoms and the<br /><br />
major towns in the Project area are presented in Table 3-1 and shown in Figures 1, 2<br /><br />
and 3 above.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
20<br /><br />
21<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Wikipedia, April 2010.<br /><br />
