<br /><br />
Social Baseline<br /><br />
The socio-economic baseline in the Project area is outlined below. A more detailed<br /><br />
description is presented in the Preliminary Social Baseline and Impact Assessment<br /><br />
report prepared by SRK (April 2010).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.4.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Demography<br /><br />
The Project impacted area includes small and medium villages as well as some<br /><br />
larger towns. In terms of gender distribution, 49% are males and 51% are females.<br /><br />
The average household size is approximately 9 people, with the smallest household<br /><br />
counting 3 members and the largest 15. Four percent of the households count 10 or<br /><br />
more members. Polygamy is practised in the project area and 35% of the households<br /><br />
have more than one wife per household head, whilst 43% are monogamous and 22%<br /><br />
of the households are single-parented.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.4.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Livelihood Strategies<br /><br />
In the mine area the majority of the population is involved in agriculture (including<br /><br />
economic trees) and animal husbandry, whilst some villages are heavily involved in<br /><br />
artisanal mining. There are few artisans and mechanics.<br /><br />
Along the transport corridor agriculture (including plantations) and animal<br /><br />
husbandry are the main activities, with charcoal production in some villages. There<br /><br />
is also some hunting activity. The transport corridor villages are host to more<br /><br />
artisans, government employees and mechanics than villages in the mine area.<br /><br />
In the Pepel port area the main activity is agriculture (including plantations), sea<br /><br />
fishing and some animal husbandry.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Overall, the most important livelihood strategy across the project area is agriculture<br /><br />
and plantations and to a lesser extent animal husbandry. Hunting is rare and<br /><br />
confined to a small number of villages.<br /><br />
Photo Plate 2: Agriculture fields, artisanal mining site and fishing<br /><br />
location within the proposed project areas<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.4.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Access to Land22<br /><br />
Land tenure in the Republic of Sierra Leone (except the Western Area), is held in<br /><br />
communal ownership under customary tenure and is controlled by traditional chiefs<br /><br />
who administer it on behalf of their communities in accordance with customary<br /><br />
principles.<br /><br />
The rule of customary law in the provinces is established by section 76 (1) of the<br /><br />
Courts Act 1965. However, the validity of customary law is contingent on it being<br /><br />
compatible with statutory law. Three statutes are directly relevant to customary<br /><br />
landholding practices in Sierra Leone:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Provinces Lands Act – (Cap 122).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Chiefdom Councils Act – (Cap 61).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Local Government Act –1994.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Through customary law, ownership of land is vested in the chiefdoms and<br /><br />
communities. Land cannot be owned freehold; land always belongs to the<br /><br />
communities under the different forms of tenure under customary law. This<br /><br />
principle is established by the Chiefdom Councils Act as well as by Section 28 (d)<br /><br />
of the Local Government Act 1994. It provides for the establishment of a local court<br /><br />
authorised to administer customary law in every chiefdom. The most common forms<br /><br />
of customary land tenure are:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Family tenure.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Communal tenure.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Individual tenure.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Family tenure is the most common form of tenure found in the provinces. Family<br /><br />
tenure is a system under which entitlements to land within a particular chiefdom are<br /><br />
claimed by various descent groups each with a common ancestor and that constitute<br /><br />
a family unit. Such family units are a corporate entity and have capacity to claim<br /><br />
and hold land as a body. The paramount title to family land is vested in the family as<br /><br />
a group. However, underneath the umbrella of this title, varying degrees of lesser<br /><br />
interests held in specific or particular portions of family land may be held by some<br /><br />
family groups or individuals. Responsibility for the management of family land is<br /><br />
vested in the head of the family assisted by principal members. The head of the<br /><br />
family has the right to allocate unoccupied portions of family land to members of<br /><br />
the family. They also may bring claims on land against outsiders on behalf of the<br /><br />
family for trespassing on family land.<br /><br />
Communal tenure is the case where title to land in a given area in the chiefdom is<br /><br />
claimed by or on behalf of the community as a whole and not by or on behalf of<br /><br />
<br /><br />
22<br /><br />
The section on land tenure is based on the report: Van Vlaenderen, H. (2010). Addax Biofuel Project: Social<br /><br />
Impact Assessment. Coastal and Environmental Services, Grahamstown, South Africa and Huggins , G (2010)<br /><br />
Addax Biofuel Project: Resettlement Policy Framework . Coastal and Environmental Services, Grahamstown,<br /><br />
South Africa<br /><br />
<br /><br />
families or individuals. The community is also a corporate entity, endowed with<br /><br />
legal capacity to enforce and defend its claims and rights to communal lands vis-avis other communities. Unlike the family, a community is not a kinship, but a sociopolitical entity and its members are not necessarily related to each other. Another<br /><br />
feature of communal tenure is that title to communal lands is not vested directly in<br /><br />
the community as an entity as in the case of the family. Rather, it is vested in the<br /><br />
socio-political head of a particular community. It is so vested in a representative<br /><br />
capacity. Another feature of communal tenure similar to family tenure is that it is<br /><br />
only the unapportioned portions of communal lands and those lands which are<br /><br />
strictly public lands, such as sacred bushes, common grazing lands and communal<br /><br />
farms that are subject to direct management, control and supervision by the sociopolitical heads.<br /><br />
It has been argued that in customary land tenure there is no individual land<br /><br />
ownership. But it is found to exist among some communities. For example, there are<br /><br />
practices whereby families owning large pieces of land allocate portions of land to<br /><br />
individual members of the family to enable them to set up their individual<br /><br />
households. Even though the paramount title remains vested in the family, each<br /><br />
individual member holds interest in his holdings. When the individual dies, the land<br /><br />
is inherited by his immediate or nuclear family or nearest next of kin. It is also<br /><br />
common to find practices where a man may give each of his wives land for her use<br /><br />
and that of her own children. When the man dies the land is inherited by the wife,<br /><br />
who was given the land when the man was living, and her children. Whether the<br /><br />
land would continue to be held as individual holdings would depend on a number of<br /><br />
factors, such as the number of children.<br /><br />
There are generally three ways in which individual acquisition of title is<br /><br />
accomplished:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.4.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
By clearing of virgin forest – any land not appropriated by the community as<br /><br />
a whole can be claimed individually.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
By straight forward purchase – individuals who are not otherwise entitled to<br /><br />
land in a given area can purchase land outright from the recognised owner.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
By gift – individual owners may acquire land as a gift. For example, where a<br /><br />
stranger marries into a land-owning family, land may be given for his use.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Standard of Living<br /><br />
Poverty is pervasive in the area, as in the whole of Sierra Leone, and people need to<br /><br />
pursue a mixed livelihood, to obtain sufficient income for survival. The household<br /><br />
survey conducted for the social impact report shows that only 15% of the adult<br /><br />
population in Project area (age 15-60) had a stable and regular income. The sale of<br /><br />
agricultural produce is an important source of income. Remittances are also<br /><br />
significant.<br /><br />
Photo Plate 3: House structures in the proposed project areas<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A major cost item for the household is food, which indicates that people do not<br /><br />
grow sufficient food to feed themselves or need to sell food at certain times of the<br /><br />
year to purchase other goods, leaving them with insufficient supplies for the entire<br /><br />
year. Clothing, agricultural and livestock expenses are also significant cost items.<br /><br />
People generally do not have many savings.<br /><br />
Lack of food security is common. In the household survey conducted for the<br /><br />
preliminary social baseline and impact assessment (April 2010), 85% of the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
households indicated that they had experienced food shortages at some stage during<br /><br />
the year, predominantly during the period July to September.<br /><br />
The energy source for lighting is predominantly candles, followed by torches and<br /><br />
paraffin. The energy source used for cooking consists almost exclusively of wood,<br /><br />
with a few households using some charcoal.<br /><br />
Although the majority of the rural population is poor, some stratification exists.<br /><br />
There are traditional elite families who can trace descent (usually through the<br /><br />
father's line) to a warrior or hunter who first settled in an area. These families then<br /><br />
control and administer land, which puts them in an advantageous relationship to<br /><br />
non-landholders.<br /><br />
3.4.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Socio-Cultural Situation<br /><br />
The dominant ethnic group in the mine area are the Kuranko. Along the transport<br /><br />
corridor there is a variety of ethnic groups, with large concentrations of Kuranko,<br /><br />
Temne and Susu. In the area of Tagrin Point there are predominantly Susu and<br /><br />
Temne.<br /><br />
The most important cultural phenomena are the secret societies, which are popular<br /><br />
throughout the Project area. Their primary purpose is to regulate sexual identity and<br /><br />
social conduct, and to produce fully socialised human beings with clear gender<br /><br />
identities. Secret societies induct members by means of initiation.<br /><br />
Religion plays an important role. Nominally the majority of the residents are<br /><br />
Muslim. However, most communities have both a mosque and a church.<br /><br />
Mainstream religions are however intertwined with traditional beliefs.<br /><br />
The household is the primary residential unit. There are various types of households,<br /><br />
but most have a family (husband, wife or wives, and their children) as the core.<br /><br />
Some are complex (two or more married men, either father and son or two brothers),<br /><br />
often with other, more-distant kin or even strangers in residence. The household<br /><br />
head (the eldest male/female) is the legal custodian of the household property<br /><br />
(including land), responsible for protection and security and resolves disputes by<br /><br />
mediation and represents the household in village affairs. Land-use rights and most<br /><br />
portable forms of wealth are inherited patrilinealy.<br /><br />
Decision making in the village is done by the chief and the elders of the landowning<br /><br />
families. Youth and women organisations are regularly consulted in decision<br /><br />
making. Youth are consulted in particular with respect to development projects for<br /><br />
the village. In general village issues are discussed and final decisions presented by<br /><br />
the elders to the community during a village assembly. The Imam also plays an<br /><br />
important role in terms of looking after the spiritual well-being of the villagers and<br /><br />
the settling of family and community disputes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.4.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Gender<br /><br />
As in most traditional African communities, gender roles are relatively clearly<br /><br />
defined in the area. However, due to the many socio-economic disruptions, wars and<br /><br />
family break-ups, gender roles may have become less rigid. Data collection shows<br /><br />
however that men make most of the decisions in terms of the household and at the<br /><br />
broader community level, whereas women conduct most of the daily chores. The<br /><br />
secret societies for women reinforce their role as home makers in service of their<br /><br />
husbands.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.4.7<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Health<br /><br />
Health and hygiene conditions in the Project area are generally poor. The household<br /><br />
survey showed that 83% of the households deposit their household waste in the<br /><br />
areas around their homesteads. Many households use the bush for toilet and the<br /><br />
main water sources are rivers, rainwater tanks and unprotected wells. The water<br /><br />
quality is often of inferior standard and wells dry out during the dry season.<br /><br />
Villagers often need to walk long distances to fetch water.<br /><br />
The most prevalent diseases are malaria and diarrhoea related ailments. There is<br /><br />
also malnutrition in the area.<br /><br />
Health facilities in the project area are generally poor, with many villages lacking a<br /><br />
health centre, forcing people to travel long distances to receive medical care. The<br /><br />
existing health posts often lack equipment, trained staff and medication. Often,<br /><br />
villagers call upon traditional healers and local pharmacists for medical treatment.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.4.8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Education<br /><br />
The levels of education and literacy are generally low in Sierra Leone and in the<br /><br />
Project area. The study revealed a 70% of illiteracy in the Project area. The<br /><br />
education sector encounters several problems including:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Lack of schools (not all settlements have primary schools and in the rural<br /><br />
areas there is a lack secondary schools). Children often have to walk long<br /><br />
distances to reach school, resulting in low attendance and large numbers of<br /><br />
drop outs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Shortage of trained and qualified teachers.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Late or no payment of teachers leading to de-motivation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Dilapidated school buildings and shortage of classrooms; overcrowded<br /><br />
classes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RESETTLEMENT PLANNING ACTIONS<br /><br />
This section of the RPF sets out the main tasks and procedures required to develop a<br /><br />
RAP for the Project. It outlines the procedures for identification of affected people,<br /><br />
assessment of eligibility for compensation, identification of host areas for<br /><br />
resettlement, procedures for resettling and compensation, budget categories,<br /><br />
<br /><br />
procedures for monitoring and evaluating the resettlement process and the necessary<br /><br />
institutional arrangements for execution of the resettlement and compensation<br /><br />
process.<br /><br />
It is important to note that this conceptual document differs from a RAP, which sets<br /><br />
out in detail the strategies for resettling people affected by land acquisition. In order<br /><br />
to develop a full scale RAP there are several additional requirements:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Detailed final information about the mining process and the location of the<br /><br />
different project components.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A detailed social baseline.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The RPF needs to be debated and approved by the various stakeholders.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Minimising Resettlement<br /><br />
The IFC standards require that resettlement be minimised as far as possible. The<br /><br />
primary reason for resettlement in the mine area is the location of the mineral<br /><br />
resource and technologies for its exploitation, in this case open pit mining. The<br /><br />
location of the pits is fixed by the location of the mineral resource; and will invoke<br /><br />
involuntary resettlement. As such, resettlement cannot be minimised in this area.<br /><br />
More broadly resettlement will be influenced by the development and location of<br /><br />
project infrastructure in the mine area, the transport corridor and at the port facility.<br /><br />
Such infrastructure includes rock dumps, processing plant, tailings storage facility,<br /><br />
stockpiles, offices, workshops, stores, power generation, housing, the railway line<br /><br />
and port facilities. Resettlement is also influenced by health and safety<br /><br />
considerations (e.g. human settlements should be an appropriate distance from<br /><br />
hazards).<br /><br />
AML’s engineering and environmental and social consultants should be working in<br /><br />
tandem to ensure that infrastructure across the Project area is developed and located<br /><br />
in a way that minimises resettlement.<br /><br />
The following has been done in this respect:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The rail loop, which requires a large area, has been positioned at the mine site<br /><br />
where population density is lower than at Tagrin, the other option.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The rail and haul road alignment has been designed to avoid villages using<br /><br />
Quantm optimisation software.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Construction and operations camps are planned in areas with low population<br /><br />
densities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Waste rock dumps have been optimised to minimise additional area required<br /><br />
beyond the fly rock zone.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Refurbishment of the Pepel rail and port is to be undertaken on the exisiting<br /><br />
footprint to minimise the need to acquire more land for project operations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
At this stage, nonetheless, it is certain that there will be a requirement to relocate<br /><br />
villages either partially or entirely.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identifying Eligibility for Compensation<br /><br />
The definition of eligibility requires an assessment of the type and number of people<br /><br />
residing or using the affected area and the types of loss they incur. This is outlined<br /><br />
below.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.2.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project Affected People<br /><br />
Project affected people (PAP) can be divided into two categories:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.2.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Affected household: households23 are affected if one or more of its members<br /><br />
suffer loss of assets, land and property, and/or access to natural and/or<br /><br />
economic resources as a result of the project activities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Host area households: households in any of the host resettlement sites (sites<br /><br />
where people may be resettled), whose infrastructures and/or resources will<br /><br />
be impacted.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Types of Loss<br /><br />
PAP may incur a loss or disruption of access to the following assets and resources:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Buildings, homesteads and related structures (such as storage facilities,<br /><br />
graves).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Land.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Permanent or temporary use of agricultural land.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Sacred sites.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mining deposits (artisanal mining).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Natural plant and animal (including fish) resources.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Small enterprises.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Communal infrastructure (wells, boreholes, irrigation works, schools, clinics).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Access routes (between villages, to towns and other resources i.e. fishing<br /><br />
beaches).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A detailed description of the number and type of beneficiaries in terms of the<br /><br />
various eligibility criteria will need to be provided once the exact location of the<br /><br />
Project infrastructure is known and a census has been conducted. At this stage,<br /><br />
however, the following information is available:<br /><br />
Homesteads<br /><br />
It is envisaged that 47 villages will have to be partially or entirely resettled. It is<br /><br />
estimated that 2,441 houses and related structures will be affected.<br /><br />
23<br /><br />
For the purposes of this RPF a household consists of people who are economically dependent on<br /><br />
each other and who typically live in the same compound and eat from the same pot.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Land<br /><br />
It is envisaged that 12 674 ha will be affected by the Project; 11,507 ha at the mine<br /><br />
site, 288 ha along the rail corridor and 880 ha at the Port. These belong to various<br /><br />
villages/towns. A land survey will need to be conducted to assess which land<br /><br />
belongs to which villages and to which landowning families.<br /><br />
Agricultural Crops<br /><br />
Approximately 215.30 ha of currently cultivated land will be affected by the<br /><br />
Project; 95 ha at the mine site, 56 ha along the rail corridor and 64 ha at the Port. A<br /><br />
survey will have to be conducted to assess the number and size of fields of affected<br /><br />
households, as well as the crops cultivated.<br /><br />
Tree Plantations<br /><br />
Approximately 21 ha of current plantation will be affected by the Project; 8 ha along<br /><br />
the rail corridor and 12 ha at the Port. A survey will have to be conducted to assess<br /><br />
the number and size of plantations of affected households, as well as the trees/plants<br /><br />
cultivated. The main plantations are palm, mango, banana and pineapple.<br /><br />
Forests<br /><br />
Some forested areas may be affected. These serve several needs. For instance sacred<br /><br />
bushes are an important cultural heritage of the local people in the Project area and<br /><br />
significant for their spiritual well being. It is likely that several sacred bushes will<br /><br />
be affected. Sacred bushes will need to be identified along with other potential uses<br /><br />
of the forest.<br /><br />
Sacred Sites<br /><br />
Sacred sites include such sites or places/features that are important for customary<br /><br />
practices, tradition and culture, and thus considered sacred. Sacred sites include<br /><br />
tombs, graves and cemeteries and ritual sites.<br /><br />
In general people bury their deceased in tombs near their homestead. Resettlement<br /><br />
of villages may involve the relocation of graves.<br /><br />
Artisanal Mining<br /><br />
The social description of the affected villages in the mine lease area shows that<br /><br />
households maintain a mixed livelihood consisting of mining as well as farming.<br /><br />
There are a significant number of artisanal miners (exact figures be established<br /><br />
during RAP preparation) working in and around the concession area, including in<br /><br />
the areas which will be required for the mining infrastructure. Consequently these<br /><br />
miners may lose their livelihoods.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Natural Plant and Animal Life<br /><br />
Some areas used by local residents for collection of natural resources (fire wood,<br /><br />
wild foods, timber, medicinal plants, game) may be affected by the mining and<br /><br />
transport infrastructure. Generally, however, natural resources used by the local<br /><br />
population are plentiful in the larger area and the loss of the area needed for the<br /><br />
project may not require compensation. This will however need to be verified by the<br /><br />
census conducted as part of the RAP.<br /><br />
The port lease area may impact on the access of fishermen to the beach (i.e.<br /><br />
homesteads of fishermen may need to be moved or access to the landing and fishing<br /><br />
beach may be constrained or removed).<br /><br />
Small Enterprises<br /><br />
The villages and towns affected by resettlement are host to several small businesses.<br /><br />
These businesses are generally run from small structures near the homestead or from<br /><br />
the homestead itself. The exact number of small businesses affected will need to be<br /><br />
identified.<br /><br />
Social Infrastructure<br /><br />
The villages affected by physical resettlement are host to schools, clinics,<br /><br />
community halls, drying areas and potentially other communal infrastructure. The<br /><br />
RAP census will need to identify all communal infrastructure which may be affected<br /><br />
Access Routes<br /><br />
The mining and transport infrastructure may have impact on communications<br /><br />
between villages and towns and villages and agricultural fields, cutting some<br /><br />
residents off from their resources. Loss of livelihoods as a result of this<br /><br />
communication severance will need to be assessed and compensated for.<br /><br />
4.2.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Eligibility: Cut-Off Date<br /><br />
The determination of eligibility for various types of compensation is defined in<br /><br />
terms of the PAP categories described above, as well as whether the PAP’s affected<br /><br />
properties were present in the project area prior to the resettlement cut-off date on<br /><br />
land development. A resettlement cut-off date is the date which signifies a<br /><br />
moratorium on settling, building or making improvements on affected land. This<br /><br />
cut-off date needs to be made public to all those affected through a public<br /><br />
consultation process. Sierra Leone law does not make provision for the declaration<br /><br />
of a moratorium. It will be the task of AML to identify and publicise (in<br /><br />
collaboration with local government) the cut-off date, which should coincide with<br /><br />
the completion of the RAP census and asset survey and obtaining a lease agreement.<br /><br />
It should be noted that the cut-off date for building new structures and planting trees<br /><br />
may be different from growing annual crops (the latter may be later if no<br /><br />
resettlement will take place within the next season). An agreement will need to be<br /><br />
<br /><br />
reached with the local authorities on the procedures to be used in the event of claims<br /><br />
being submitted after the cut-off date, as well as in the event of counter-claims and<br /><br />
disputes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Census and Assets Inventory<br /><br />
To develop the resettlement programme a thorough knowledge is required of the<br /><br />
existing socio-economic context of the affected households and communities. The<br /><br />
process for achieving this is set out in the following sections.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.3.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Mapping<br /><br />
The resettlement process should be supported by a Geographic Information Systems<br /><br />
(GIS) interface and field maps with socio-economic infrastructure and land use<br /><br />
patterns and natural features (of the resettlement site and host site(s)).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.3.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Census<br /><br />
A census must be undertaken of all directly affected households (either physically<br /><br />
displaced – losing a homestead) or economically displaced (losing a livelihood).<br /><br />
The census will include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Demographics, family structure (household position, age, residence status,<br /><br />
occupation, educational level).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The incidences of disease or illness amongst household members in the past<br /><br />
year and receipt of health services.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Deaths and births within the household in the past year.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Usage of social infrastructure – e.g. church/clinic/school.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Access to land on a cyclical / rotational basis and access to resources on<br /><br />
communal land.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Possession of livestock.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Household economic activities and their relative importance.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Household income (details of average annual income, monthly sources of<br /><br />
income, annual agricultural sales and other sales sources).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Details of loans / savings.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Expenditure on major items (i.e. food, transport, agricultural inputs, health,<br /><br />
education).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Availability of food throughout the year.<br /><br />
Ownership of a predetermined collection of possessions to be used as<br /><br />
indicators in ascertaining the socio-economic status of the households.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A survey will also need to be conducted on a sample of people using communal<br /><br />
land resources, for example hunting, honey production, wood collection for charcoal<br /><br />
production and artisanal mining or seeing the land used as part of their fallow cycle,<br /><br />
or grazing by nomadic people). As the number of such people may be high and<br /><br />
difficult to demarcate, only a representative sample is surveyed.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.3.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assets Inventory<br /><br />
Inventories will need to be made of both household and communal assets. Aspects<br /><br />
for inclusion are outlined below.<br /><br />
Household Assets<br /><br />
An assets inventory needs to be conducted for each of the affected households24<br /><br />
included in the census, recording all permanent and temporary losses of physical<br /><br />
structures and natural resources incurred. These include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Homesteads and homestead structures (such as outside kitchens, latrines,<br /><br />
chicken pens etc). This includes the number, size and condition of structures<br /><br />
and a field drawing of the homestead buildings as well as photographic<br /><br />
records.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Family business-related structures.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Graves associated with each household.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Agricultural fields owned by each homestead or rented, leased, or given for<br /><br />
use.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Planted trees, within the homestead areas and plantations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The census and assets inventory serves as:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A register of the legitimate beneficiaries as per their residency or locality.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Social data, which can serve as a reference point for compensation and<br /><br />
monitoring.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Communal Infrastructure<br /><br />
An audit will be required of all communal assets affected by relocation. These<br /><br />
include:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.3.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Market areas.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Drying areas (for food produce).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Administrative buildings.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Recreational buildings, community halls.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Churches.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Schools.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Clinics.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Sites of cultural importance (e.g. sacred bushes) or historical importance.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Census and Inventory Asset Methodology<br /><br />
The following steps should be followed in conducting the census and household<br /><br />
assets survey:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
24<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This assets inventory can be conducted at the same time as the census.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Recruitment and training of local fieldworkers in the survey methodology.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Design, piloting and (where necessary) refining of a census and assets<br /><br />
questionnaire.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A meeting with the affected communities to explain the purpose of the<br /><br />
surveys and the procedures to be used.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Provision of an ID number to all households/individuals involved in the<br /><br />
census. They should be photographed with the ID number in front of their<br /><br />
homestead /affected structures.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Photographing of all structures, with GPS coordinates taken for the main<br /><br />
building.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ensuring that the household head of the affected asset is present during the<br /><br />
survey interview and that he/she countersigns the inventory sheets as proof<br /><br />
that he/she agrees to the assets that have been recorded (Note: the signature of<br /><br />
the household head does not signify acceptance of a compensation package<br /><br />
only recognition that the data were correct when collected).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ensuring that a community representative, delegated to this particular task,<br /><br />
also signs the inventory sheets as a witness to the recording exercise.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Entry of data from the census and photographs in a Microsoft Access (or<br /><br />
other electronic) database for record keeping and analysis.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Valuation<br /><br />
This section provides a framework for detailed valuation procedures to be<br /><br />
developed in the RAP. Valuation is based both on Sierra Leone and international<br /><br />
policies. Valuation rates and the process should be ratified by a Resettlement<br /><br />
Working Group (see description below), any relevant authority and the affected<br /><br />
parties.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.4.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Compensation for Loss of Homesteads and Fixed Structures<br /><br />
Two options are available for compensation for physical structures lost due to the<br /><br />
Project.<br /><br />
Option 1:<br /><br />
Compensation for all homestead structures is provided in cash. This includes<br /><br />
replacement costs, cost for transportation and cost for building labour.<br /><br />
Option 2:<br /><br />
Compensation is provided by replacement (to an agreed standard) of the primary<br /><br />
structures of the homestead plot in an identified host area, with structures of similar<br /><br />
or better quality. It is recommended that a local contractor is hired to build the<br /><br />
houses and that local labour is employed, whilst AML ensures quality control.<br /><br />
Professional surveyors should provide cost estimates of replacement housing. (Note:<br /><br />
AML’s estimated cost for construction of a substantial traditional rural house in the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
mine area was about US$13,500, though it is likely to be different in other areas and<br /><br />
for other house types).<br /><br />
Option 2 is the recommended option. In accordance with IFC guidelines cash<br /><br />
compensation for structures is discouraged. This is to avoid the risk that cash is not<br /><br />
spent on housing (which would leave households without shelter).<br /><br />
A variation on this option is to provide cash compensation for the smaller additional<br /><br />
structures (e.g. outside kitchen, fences, latrines, chicken pens). Justification for this<br /><br />
is that these structures may be dismantled and taken by the owners to the new<br /><br />
abode, avoiding the need for AML to build myriad small structures.<br /><br />
In case of partially built structures AML will compensate for lost materials.<br /><br />
Abandoned structures are not compensated.<br /><br />
Taking Occupation of the New Homestead<br /><br />
The following rules are recommended:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.4.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A reasonable time period should be allowed prior to moving people in order<br /><br />
to give them the opportunity to salvage building materials from their old<br /><br />
homes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AML should provide transport for each homestead sufficient to move the<br /><br />
family and belongings (including building materials such as doors and<br /><br />
windows (but not bricks or masonry), livestock, food, and personal effects<br /><br />
from the old homestead) to their new residence.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Households should sign a document to forego all rights to the old homestead<br /><br />
(including trees and materials). AML will demolish the old homestead<br /><br />
(otherwise squatters may take over the abandoned houses).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
An AML representative should visits households a month after they have<br /><br />
moved into their new abode to assess the new structure and note potential<br /><br />
defects and arrange for repairs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AML should provide structural warrantee on the dwelling structures to cover<br /><br />
against defects arising from poor design, workmanship and material for a<br /><br />
period of 5 years.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Compensation for Land<br /><br />
The project will require the lease of land, which will be guided by Sierra Leone’s<br /><br />
Provinces Land Act, Chapter 122 of the Laws of Sierra Leone, 196025. A land lease<br /><br />
contract will then be required for the affected land in the three Districts, identifying<br /><br />
the exact settlements and chiefdoms involved. Lease rent will need to be paid.<br /><br />
Government guidelines are US$3.60 per acre, with one third paid to the Chiefdom<br /><br />
council, one third to the District Council and one third to the respective traditional<br /><br />
<br /><br />
25<br /><br />
<br /><br />
See Section 4.1.2 above.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
landowners. It is the task of the District Council to pay out the fees to the respective<br /><br />
parties.<br /><br />
The section above indicates that land tenure and land use are governed by<br /><br />
customary law and subject to local social and traditional cultural norms. These may<br /><br />
make the process of paying out compensation for loss of land more complex for the<br /><br />
following reasons:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Land belongs to family clans and or villages, not individuals.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Land has generally not been surveyed and no records of (customary or other)<br /><br />
ownership of areas of land exist. Land disputes are common.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
People using the land belong to either landowning families in the area or<br /><br />
tenants (with no tenure claims, so tenants will be a vulnerable group since<br /><br />
they will not receive lease rent).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Land lease infers that land will most likely be returned to the lessor on<br /><br />
completion or termination of the lease agreement. In some instances land<br /><br />
taken for the Project will not be returned.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In order not to disadvantage people, and to enhance the productivity of remaining<br /><br />
land, the mechanism for acquisition of replacement land needs to be examined in<br /><br />
detail in the RAP as well as livelihood restitution programmes which enhance<br /><br />
agricultural productivity.<br /><br />
4.4.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Compensation for Crops and Trees<br /><br />
Crops<br /><br />
Standing crops will be compensated for. The main crops are rice, cassava,<br /><br />
groundnuts, maize and sweet potatoes.<br /><br />
Trees<br /><br />
Only exotic planted trees belonging to households or communities qualify for<br /><br />
compensation. The most common trees used for food and as a source of income are<br /><br />
palm trees, mangoes, bananas, oranges and pineapple.<br /><br />
Valuation Process<br /><br />
The affected area of crops need to be measured and number of trees counted by a<br /><br />
team including the affected person, a representative of AML, a representative of the<br /><br />
Ministry of Agriculture and a representative of the local chiefdom. The numbers of<br /><br />
trees and areas of crops needs to be included in the assets inventory and signed off<br /><br />
by the team doing the assessment.<br /><br />
According to IFC standards, crops and trees need to be compensated in line with the<br /><br />
market rates for the different crops/trees. The Government of Sierra Leone provides<br /><br />
compensation rates, but these were determined in 2006 and are generally regarded<br /><br />
as outdated (see Table 4-1). It is suggested that the compensation rates are guided<br /><br />
<br /><br />
by the recent rates identified for the Addax Biofuel Project (neighbouring the<br /><br />
Tonkolili Project) which is currently developing a RAP. See Table 4-1 for rates<br /><br />
which were identified and ratified by Director of Agriculture in both Bombali and<br /><br />
Tonkolili districts in collaboration with the Addax resettlement team.<br /><br />
