location.<br /><br />
4.4.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Compensation for Disturbance of Graves and Sites of Cultural,<br /><br />
Historical or Religious Importance<br /><br />
Valuation for graves and sacred sites will be as noted below.<br /><br />
Graves<br /><br />
There are 3 options:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Homesteads may choose to re-bury people on or near their resettlement plot.<br /><br />
Providing this does not contradict any by-laws or customary restrictions, this<br /><br />
should be permitted.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Communal re-burial may be arranged with local entities (municipality, and<br /><br />
traditional leaders, as well as religious leaders). In such cases an appropriate<br /><br />
piece of land needs to be identified in consultation with the local authorities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In cases where grave relocation is not necessary and agreement is reached, the<br /><br />
HH may hold a ceremony in accordance with local customs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In both cases appropriate timing and arrangements for the relocation and re-burial of<br /><br />
the deceased will need to be agreed upon with all stakeholders. AML will meet the<br /><br />
costs of:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Exhumation including permit (if required), transport and re-burial (reinterment) of the deceased.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Provision of a coffin. An approved supplier will provide the coffin.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Provision of a flat rate per grave to satisfy any customary cost.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
All works associated with the burial.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
All costs associated with a ceremony if not relocating grave.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The affected households/religious leaders are responsible for organising the<br /><br />
appropriate ceremonies in accordance with their religious beliefs and/or customs.<br /><br />
Sacred Sites<br /><br />
In terms of communal sacred sites or cultural heritage, a process for appeasement of<br /><br />
disturbance of the site and potentially the establishment/inauguration of a new site<br /><br />
will need to be negotiated with the affected communities. AML will cover the cost<br /><br />
of obtaining the new site and the appropriate ceremonies required for this process<br /><br />
(to be negotiated with stakeholders). AML will not be responsible for organising<br /><br />
these ceremonies.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.4.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Compensation for Loss of Access to Mining Areas (Artisanal Mining)<br /><br />
There are significant numbers of artisanal miners working in and around the Project<br /><br />
area (exact figures to be established in the RAP).<br /><br />
In keeping with IFC standards it is proposed that compensation for income from<br /><br />
artisanal mining is dealt with differently from compensation for other livelihood<br /><br />
strategies such as agriculture, small business etc since artisanal mining is generally<br /><br />
transient. Whereas the former is addressed at the level of individual households,<br /><br />
compensation for loss of livelihood based on artisanal mining will be dealt with on a<br /><br />
collective basis (i.e. collective, alternative livelihood projects may be developed<br /><br />
such as agricultural projects, skills development project, agro-small business<br /><br />
projects).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.4.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Compensation for Loss of Natural Plant and Animal Resources<br /><br />
The extent and nature of different types of loss of access to natural resources will be<br /><br />
assessed in the RAP and compensation strategies for each type of loss negotiated.<br /><br />
These may include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Development of wood lots in case of loss of timber and firewood.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Development of nurseries for lost plants.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Development of alternative livelihoods for those relying on natural resource<br /><br />
production (i.e. charcoal production and fishermen).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identification and arrangement of alternative grazing areas.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Providing access to alternative beaching/mooring areas for fishermen.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.4.7 Compensation for Businesses and Enterprises<br /><br />
For the valuation of the loss of an enterprise its function, intensity of use (average<br /><br />
monthly income), location importance and its market catchments will need to be<br /><br />
determined.<br /><br />
Valuation should be based on the cost of re-establishing the commercial activity at a<br /><br />
new location. This may include costs for:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.4.8<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Acquisition of new land.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Material and construction costs of replacement structures (this may involve<br /><br />
rebuilding the structure or providing cash compensation).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Compensation of lost income during resettlement (based on audited monthly<br /><br />
income).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Compensation for loss of wages of staff.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Compensation for Loss of Social Infrastructure<br /><br />
It is necessary to ensure that resettlers are not worse off after the resettlement<br /><br />
process in terms of access to socio-economic services. This may require the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
upgrading of existing social infrastructure in the host areas to accommodate the<br /><br />
enlarged population or it may require the building of new infrastructure. According<br /><br />
to IFC guidelines the infrastructure should be equal to or better than that being<br /><br />
replaced. Community structures or resources may include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Clinics and dispensaries.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Community halls.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Markets.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Schools.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Village rice drying floors or structures.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Wells/boreholes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The valuation of community structure and resources will require consultation with<br /><br />
community leaders, committees or individuals that have responsibility over<br /><br />
community structures of both the resettled community and the host community.<br /><br />
The valuation should be based on replacement costs of materials, buildings costs<br /><br />
and the acquisition of additional land.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identification and Evaluation of Resettlement Sites<br /><br />
Resettlement for the Project will require the identification of multiple residential<br /><br />
areas (for those physically displaced) and identification of multiple areas of<br /><br />
agricultural land for those economically displaced. Ideally for each affected area<br /><br />
several options need to be explored for those to be resettled. In order to assess the<br /><br />
feasibility of different options the following is required:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assessment of land ownership and tenure rights.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assessment of the need for improvement of infrastructure (water resources,<br /><br />
educational, health facilities, road infrastructure) to accommodate additional<br /><br />
inhabitants.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assessment of the impact of resettlement on small businesses in both resettled<br /><br />
communities and host community.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assessment of available agricultural land in the vicinity of the resettled<br /><br />
communities adequate for all of the people eligible for allocation of<br /><br />
agricultural land.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assessment of access to natural resources (i.e. timber and firewood).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Access to livelihoods (fishing/artisanal mining).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assessment of disturbance of community and family support networks.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The assessment needs to be conducted:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In consultation with the affected villages (those to be resettled and in the host<br /><br />
area(s)) in terms of their needs, compatibility, their perceived advantages and<br /><br />
disadvantages.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In consultation with the Resettlement Working Group26 in terms of legal<br /><br />
aspects, perceived advantages and disadvantages of the option.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The process will involve:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Pre-selection of best candidate sites.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Visits to pre-selected resettlement sites with representatives of affected<br /><br />
populations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Selection of preferred sites in collaboration with relevant traditional and local<br /><br />
authorities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Conducting an ESIA of selected sites.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Validation of the choice in general community meetings.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Once the feasibility of the host areas have been established a detailed plan of the<br /><br />
host areas will need to be developed indicating existing dwellings and infrastructure<br /><br />
as well as the areas allocated to new dwellings, additional infrastructure, agricultural<br /><br />
land available for resettlers and transport network.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Transitional Support<br /><br />
IFC guidelines state clearly that additional support may be required for PAP during<br /><br />
the resettlement period. Depending on the timing of the resettlement, it is possible<br /><br />
that households will not be able to farm during a particular period (dry and or wet<br /><br />
season) because they arrive in their new home after the sowing/planting time.<br /><br />
Others may need time to develop new livelihood strategies (i.e. fishermen, artisanal<br /><br />
miners). In such cases households will require transitional support. Individual<br /><br />
support packages will need to be developed with affected families. It is<br /><br />
recommended that this is done in cooperation with competent organisations and in<br /><br />
consultation with the Resettlement Working Group.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.7<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Income Restoration and Sustainable Development Initiatives<br /><br />
Besides the loss of assets, resettlement may lead to permanent disruptions of<br /><br />
income-earning or subsistence capacity. The IFC resettlement guidelines require<br /><br />
that if project-related impacts to livelihoods are significant (with a 10% or greater<br /><br />
loss), livelihood restoration needs to be included in the RAP.<br /><br />
A core aspect of the RAP census will be to understand, at a household level, the<br /><br />
exact nature of household economic and livelihood strategies, so as to assess the<br /><br />
changes in these as a result of economic and or physical resettlement. Livelihood<br /><br />
restoration is addressed in the following sections.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
26<br /><br />
<br /><br />
See section below.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.7.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Agricultural Support Programme<br /><br />
In order to restore livelihoods for farmers, there may be a need to assist with the<br /><br />
preparation of new land and the provision of agricultural support and extension<br /><br />
programme. This may include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Provision of training on improved agricultural techniques.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Support for the purchase of agricultural equipment, fertilisers and improved<br /><br />
seeds.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
An example of a farmers support programme is the Farmer Field School Programme<br /><br />
currently implemented by the Addax Biofuel Project in collaboration with FAO<br /><br />
Sierra Leone in Bombali District. The programme combines training and<br /><br />
demonstration in agricultural practices with representatives of affected<br /><br />
communities.<br /><br />
4.7.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Skills Training<br /><br />
It is recommended that skills replacement training be provided for households for<br /><br />
which the continuation of an agrarian or artisanal mining lifestyle is not possible or<br /><br />
desired. The primary objective of the skills replacement training will be to teach<br /><br />
skills that could be of value to the local economy but not necessarily related to<br /><br />
agriculture. Potential skills to be taught include block making and building;<br /><br />
carpentry; plumbing; welding and tinsmith services; retailing; secondary processing<br /><br />
of agricultural product. In terms of skills training programmes, partnerships should<br /><br />
be established with NGO and other agencies in the area to maximise benefits.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.7.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Artisanal Mining<br /><br />
Agreement between AML and the artisanal mining organisation(s) may be<br /><br />
developed to allow continued artisanal mining on the periphery of the concession<br /><br />
area, with support from AML. This would require legal approval.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.7.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Community Development Initiatives<br /><br />
A key requirement of World Bank OP 4.12 is that ‘all involuntary resettlement will<br /><br />
be conceived and executed as development programmes.’ Key objectives of<br /><br />
community development are:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
To stimulate long-term community, economic and social development<br /><br />
programmes among those to be resettled and host communities that will lead<br /><br />
to sustainable local communities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
To seek ways of building mutually beneficial linkages between AML support<br /><br />
of community development and other development initiatives in the district<br /><br />
and region so as to obtain maximum leverage for the affected people from all<br /><br />
initiatives.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The results of the social impact assessment and the RAP census should provide<br /><br />
information on development priorities in the area, which can become the focus of a<br /><br />
Community Development Plan (CDP). This may include health, education, water<br /><br />
infrastructure, electrification, agricultural processing, micro-credit, fisheries,<br /><br />
aquaculture, poultry etc. The actual CDP will however result from a participatory<br /><br />
process between AML and local, regional stakeholders and potentially international<br /><br />
partners.<br /><br />
Community development benefits will apply in order of priority to:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.7.5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The affected households within the mining area as well as those affected by<br /><br />
the additional infrastructure required for the Project operation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The host resettlement area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The households residing outside of the Project area but who have land within<br /><br />
the Project area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Artisanal miners and fishermen affected.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Vulnerable Individuals and Households<br /><br />
Vulnerable people are those who through any characteristic may be more adversely<br /><br />
affected by resettlement than others, and who may be limited in their ability to claim<br /><br />
or take advantage of resettlement assistance and related development benefits.<br /><br />
Specifically, as defined by the IFC, vulnerable people include the following:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Households headed by women or children, particularly those headed by aged<br /><br />
widows.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
People with disabilities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The extremely poor (those with no visible means of income and the landless<br /><br />
are often the poorest).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The elderly, specifically households where no members are below the age of<br /><br />
60.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The internally displaced and orphaned children.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Groups that suffer social or economic discrimination.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
IFC guidelines state that vulnerable groups need to be identified and given specific<br /><br />
attention. Identification of the vulnerable groups will be done through the RAP<br /><br />
census and additional interviews with community members and leadership. This<br /><br />
step is critical because often vulnerable people do not participate in community<br /><br />
meetings, and their disability/vulnerability may remain unknown. The process of<br /><br />
providing assistance to vulnerable people will include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identification of required assistance at the various stages of the process,<br /><br />
including negotiation, compensation and moving.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Implementation of the measures necessary to assist the vulnerable person<br /><br />
with the resettlement process.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Monitoring and continuation of assistance after resettlement and/or<br /><br />
compensation, if required, and/or identification of those entities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assistance may take the following forms, depending upon vulnerable persons:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Provision for separate and confidential consultation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Priority in site selection in the host area.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assistance with the compensation payment procedure.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Relocation near to kin and former neighbours.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assistance with the post-payment period to secure the compensation money<br /><br />
and reduce risks of misuse/robbery.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assistance with dismantling materials from their original home.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assistance with moving: providing a vehicle, driver and assistance at the<br /><br />
moving stage.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assistance with identifying his/her resettlement plot.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assistance with building: providing materials, workforce, or building houses.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Counselling in matters such as family and health, and budgeting matters.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Priority access to all other mitigation and development assistance during the<br /><br />
post-resettlement period, particularly if the support networks that the<br /><br />
vulnerable person was relying on have been affected, such as food support,<br /><br />
health monitoring, etc.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Health care if required during the moving and transition periods.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
CONSULTATION<br /><br />
WB OP 4.12 specifically states that ‘displaced persons should be meaningfully<br /><br />
consulted and should have opportunities to participate in planning and implementing<br /><br />
resettlement programs.’<br /><br />
Consultation has two aspects. The first is the timely dissemination of information<br /><br />
regarding the project and its resettlement component, which is essentially a one-way<br /><br />
flow of information to the public. The second aspect is the two-way exchange of<br /><br />
information that gives stakeholders a chance to express their concerns and<br /><br />
contribute to the actual planning of resettlement. In order to facilitate consultation<br /><br />
several mechanisms need to be established which will be described in the<br /><br />
Stakeholder Engagement Plan.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Resettlement Working Group (RWG)<br /><br />
Resettlement Working Groups (RWGs) will need to be set up in each of the three<br /><br />
affected Districts. The RWG should comprise:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Representatives of directly affected land owners.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Representatives of directly affected tenants.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A representative of women’s organisations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A representative of youth organisations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A representative of AML.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Representatives from relevant provincial government departments (the<br /><br />
Ministry of<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Agriculture and Food Security, Ministry of Land, Ministry of Health).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Representatives from the traditional and community leadership.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Relevant local NGOs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A representative of the District Council.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A representative of the chiefdom council.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Local MPs.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The RWG has the following functions:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.2<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Acting as the primary channel of communication between the various interest<br /><br />
groups/organisations involved in the resettlement process. In particular, it will<br /><br />
serve to facilitate communication between AML and the PAP.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Acting as a forum at which AML can consult on various resettlement aspects,<br /><br />
i.e. debate the Entitlement Framework (EF) that is generated for the RAP.<br /><br />
The EF is the core of the RAP and spells out who is protected under the<br /><br />
auspices of the RAP, how they are protected and what they can expect in<br /><br />
terms of compensation and livelihood protection or restitution.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Approving suitable host area(s) for people to be resettled.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Serving as the court of first appeal to solve any grievance that arises relating<br /><br />
to the resettlement process. If it is unable to resolve any such problems, it<br /><br />
channels them through the appropriate grievance procedures.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assuming primary responsibility for assisting AML in overseeing the<br /><br />
resettlement processes in all its phases.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Monitoring the stakeholder engagement process related to resettlement and<br /><br />
compensation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Community Resettlement Committees<br /><br />
Community Resettlement Committees (CRCs) will need to be established in all of<br /><br />
the affected villages (clusters of several villages may be appropriate in certain<br /><br />
areas). These will consist of:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The village chief.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A representative of the landowners of the village.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A representative of the tenants of the village.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A representative of the women organisations of the village.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
A representative of the youth organisation of the village.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
These committees will meet regularly to ensure timely and clear communication<br /><br />
between AML and the local communities in terms of resettlement. These<br /><br />
committees will also assist with the census and assets inventory and negotiations in<br /><br />
terms of identifying host areas.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.3<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Public Consultation<br /><br />
Besides the meetings of the RWG and the CRC there will be a need for public<br /><br />
meetings with all PAP. A first meeting will need to be held before the RAP is<br /><br />
prepared, to inform affected people about the process which will unfold, i.e. the<br /><br />
census and assets inventory, identification and ratification of host areas, and<br /><br />
development of entitlement contracts per affected household.<br /><br />
Once the RAP has been developed, a second round of public meetings with PAP<br /><br />
will need to be conducted to present the RAP. At these meetings, the RAP report<br /><br />
and popularised pamphlets explaining the RAP should be made available. The RAP<br /><br />
should be subject to scrutiny by all relevant stakeholders including affected<br /><br />
households, local communities, and relevant authorities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5.4<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Grievance Redress<br /><br />
Even when the project can ultimately claim successful resettlement, there may still<br /><br />
be individuals and groups with grievances. A credible and accessible grievance<br /><br />
mechanism will be required and implemented in consultation with the RWG in line<br /><br />
with local cultural norms.<br /><br />
Individuals or groups who wish to lodge a complaint or grievance, should be able to<br /><br />
do so in various ways: during community meetings, through an AML Community<br /><br />
Liaison Officer (CLO) based at local offices throughout the project area or with the<br /><br />
relevant RWG. The process of receiving formal grievances at the offices will be as<br /><br />
follows:<br /><br />
Step 1: Receipt of Grievance<br /><br />
Grievances will be received by the CLO either verbally or by written notification<br /><br />
and will be entered in a complaints register. Registers will be available in all CLO<br /><br />
offices. Languages used will be English or Krio. The person submitting the<br /><br />
grievance will be given a receipt of their submission. People will also have the<br /><br />
option of making their initial complaint either through the Section Chief/Paramount<br /><br />
Chief, or the District Council. A receipt will be provided to the person lodging the<br /><br />
complaint.<br /><br />
Step 2: Assessment<br /><br />
The CLO will assess the grievance in terms of his/her capacity to resolve it locally.<br /><br />
If this is not possible, the grievance will be communicated to the AML Social<br /><br />
Affairs Manager for further action.<br /><br />
Step 3: Acknowledgement of Complaint/Grievance<br /><br />
Written information (accompanied with verbal explanation) as to the steps that will<br /><br />
be undertaken to resolve the grievance and the expected time for its resolution will<br /><br />
be provided to the complainant within two weeks. This exchange will be recorded<br /><br />
in the register.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Step 4: Investigation and Resolution of Grievance<br /><br />
AML will conduct an internal investigation to determine the underlying cause of the<br /><br />
grievance and make any changes required to internal systems to prevent<br /><br />
reoccurrence of a similar grievance. As appropriate, AML will also hold meetings<br /><br />
with the person/group expressing the grievances to discuss, clarify and solve the<br /><br />
issue, and prevent it from reoccurring.<br /><br />
Step 5: Closure<br /><br />
Once the investigation has been completed and necessary measures been taken, the<br /><br />
results will be communicated to the complainant and entered in the register.<br /><br />
Step 6: Outcome of the corrective action<br /><br />
Outcome of the corrective action is verified with the complainant. Following<br /><br />
completion of the corrective action, the appropriate CLO will verify the outcome<br /><br />
with the complainant. The complainant will be asked to sign off on his/her<br /><br />
acceptance of the ’solution' (or nominate someone to do so on his/her behalf). In the<br /><br />
event that the complainant remains dissatisfied with the outcome, additional<br /><br />
corrective action may be agreed and carried out by AML or the complainant can be<br /><br />
advised of further avenues for recourse. The grievance log will be entered in a<br /><br />
dedicated data base.<br /><br />
Situations may arise where complainants will choose to pursue legal recourse. AML<br /><br />
should not impede access to this recourse.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6<br /><br />
<br /><br />
IMPLEMENTATION RESPONSIBILITIES<br /><br />
To develop and execute the RAP the following entities are required.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
6.1<br /><br />
<br /><br />
AML<br /><br />
AML will provide the financial resources and the managerial and technical expertise<br /><br />
for the resettlement and compensation process (the latter may be handled by a<br /><br />
consultant engaged by AML).<br /><br />
The resettlement activities of AML will be handled by a Resettlement Unit, headed<br /><br />
by a Social and Community Manager (possibly assisted by a consultant), who<br /><br />
coordinates the work of several teams of resettlement officers. It is suggested that<br /><br />
there are three teams, one for the mine area, one for the transport corridor and one<br /><br />
for the port area. The size of the team will need to be established. The Social and<br /><br />
Community Manager will report to the General Manager.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During pre-implementation (development of the RAP), AML will:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Collect all data required to effect resettlement including the census.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Draw up Terms of Reference and contract all major planning services needed<br /><br />
to effect resettlement.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Project manage and financially support the development of the land-use plan<br /><br />
for any host resettlement areas.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Coordinate selection of alternative resettlement sites.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Present, discuss and obtain approval for any developed land-use plans.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Identify vulnerable groups.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ensure that, as necessary, the RWG remains functional in the period<br /><br />
following the finalisation of the RAP and leading up to Project<br /><br />
implementation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Attend RWG meetings, and provide administrative support and ad hoc<br /><br />
managerial and technical support as required.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In the implementation phase, AML will:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
7<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Draw up offer documents for each individual household affected.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Discuss terms and conditions of resettlement with each household.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Plan and supervise compensation activities, including for lost crops, land,<br /><br />
buildings and livestock, and to restore lost livelihoods.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Establish a socio-economic monitoring programme for the affected<br /><br />
households.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Monitor and report on the construction of replacement village structures.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Address compensation and resettlement grievances.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assist and monitor vulnerable groups.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Plan and coordinate the move into replacement housing for affected parties.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Define and implementing community development and monitoring<br /><br />
programmes to ensure that affected households are not worse off in the postimplementation phase through post-implementation monitoring.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
MONITORING<br /><br />
Monitoring is required by IFC standards in order to assess whether the goals of the<br /><br />
resettlement and compensation plan are being met. Monitoring will be undertaken at<br /><br />
two levels:<br /><br />
Internal Monitoring<br /><br />
Internal monitoring is an internal management function allowing the project<br /><br />
management (or consultant) to measure physical progress against milestones set out<br /><br />
in the RAP. Internal monitoring will:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ensure that due process has been followed in the notification of stakeholders<br /><br />
with adequate public meetings being held.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Verify that there are no outstanding or unresolved land acquisition issues<br /><br />
regarding the Project or any of its sub-projects.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ensure that the census of all PAP has been carried out.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ensure that property valuation and resettlement has been carried out properly.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Maintain records of any grievances that require resolution.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Oversee that all resettlement measures are implemented as approved by the<br /><br />
project.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Verify that funds for implementing resettlement activities are provided in a<br /><br />
timely manner, are sufficient for their purposes, and are spent in accordance<br /><br />
with the provisions of the RAP.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Ensure that monitoring and evaluation reports are submitted.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This type of monitoring should be ongoing with monthly reports.<br /><br />
External Independent Monitoring<br /><br />
This type of monitoring focuses on the impact of resettlement. This refers to the<br /><br />
effectiveness of the resettlement in terms of meeting the needs of the resettled<br /><br />
people. Such monitoring should be conducted by an independent consultant twice a<br /><br />
year for at least three years following resettlement.<br /><br />
Impact monitoring and evaluation will include an assessment of social indicators<br /><br />
against baseline data from the census. These will include:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Children in school by age and sex.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Distance to primary school.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Access to safe water.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Distance to water source.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Access to sanitation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Incidence of disease.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Distance to health centre.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Incidence of HIV/AIDS and of other STDs by gender and age.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Housing, quality of roof, walls, floor.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Access to public transport.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Patterns of employment and income generation activities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Income/expenditure/debts per household.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Improvement in production/income for women/youths.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Assets owned (e.g. radios, bicycles, iron bedstead, television, etc).<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Capacity building, skills / vocational training.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Community infrastructure.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Land lease rent.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Agricultural yields, possession of cattle.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This evaluation will employ the following methods:<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Analysis of questionnaires with a random sample of affected people (the same<br /><br />
sample should be used each time). A sample will be drawn based on<br /><br />
statically defensible principles.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Interpretation of public consultations with affected people at the village level.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Use of secondary statistical data.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Reviewing the grievance register.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
•<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Interviews with the local authorities.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The RWG and AML should meet after each monitoring exercise to discuss the<br /><br />
outcomes and to plan steps to rectify issues, if necessary.<br /><br />
